description: Troubleshooting and Maintaining Cisco IP Networks exam is one of three exams required to obtain the Cisco Certified Network Professional - Routing and Switching certification. This exam focuses on troubleshooting Layer 2 and Layer 3 devices, planning regular maintenance, and troubleshooting methodology  in complex medium and large environments. The topics include Systematic Troubleshooting Principles, Layer 2 and Layer 3 technology, Infrastructure Services and Security, and VPN technologies. The typical viewer would be anyone responsible for the maintenance and implementation and administration of Cisco Layer 2 and Layer 3 technologies in complex organizations.
name: CCNP Routing and Switching - TSHOOT
subtitle: Troubleshooting and Maintaining Cisco IP Networks

The topics include Systematic Troubleshooting Principles, Layer 2 and Layer 3 technology, Infrastructure Services and Security, and VPN technologies. The typical viewer would be anyone responsible for the maintenance and implementation and administration of Cisco Layer 2 and Layer 3 technologies in complex organizations.

WEBVTT

14

16

21

22

23

24

25

26

27

28

35
00:01:42.280 --> 00:01:46.190
>> All right so Don, if I was

37

>> Well it certainly can be, right?

39
00:01:54.700 --> 00:01:57.520
The CCNP routing and
switching it's the next step right?

40

So in Cisco certification you have CCENT,

41

That's for somebody just
getting started in networking.

42

And then you have the CCNA,

43

we've got a lot of great topics and

221
00:10:02.265 --> 00:10:03.885
technology coming up.

222
00:10:03.885 --> 00:10:08.216
So if CCMP's, routing and switch, TSHOOT
is something you think you'd like and

223
00:10:08.216 --> 00:10:11.628
want to be a part of, stick around,
cuz we got a lot more coming.

224
00:10:11.628 --> 00:10:13.965
[MUSIC]

225
00:10:13.965 --> 00:10:15.788
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Don and Wes show you how to use different utilities to troubleshoot network communications. They look at using the debug command to extract information out of a switch as well as filtering the debug command to a specific piece of information. They talk about how to use ping to test connectivity to the network and other nodes on the network. They also look at using traceroute to determine paths taken in end to end communications.
episodes.title: IOS Troubleshooting Tools
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.181 --> 00:00:10.181
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.808 --> 00:00:15.563
Hello and welcome back to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.563 --> 00:00:16.730
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:16.730 --> 00:00:20.970
We're gonna be talking about
maintaining Cisco IP based networks.

5
00:00:20.970 --> 00:00:23.640
I'm back here with a networking guru Mr.
Don Pezet.

6
00:00:23.640 --> 00:00:24.880
How are we doing today, Don?

7
00:00:24.880 --> 00:00:25.860
>> I am doing good Wes,

8
00:00:25.860 --> 00:00:29.950
glad to be back on the show and ready to
jump into the world of troubleshooting.

9
00:00:29.950 --> 00:00:32.890
Now here at the beginning of the series
it's important that we understand some

10
00:00:32.890 --> 00:00:34.950
of the different tools that
are available to us and

11
00:00:34.950 --> 00:00:36.310
that's what we're gonna look at today.

12
00:00:36.310 --> 00:00:39.930
Some of the just basic tools that we're
gonna see all throughout this series that

13
00:00:39.930 --> 00:00:44.160
are really kind of important as we isolate
where our problem is on our network.

14
00:00:44.160 --> 00:00:45.020
>> Very good, very good.

15
00:00:45.020 --> 00:00:49.744
So, in networking here in Cisco land, I
am sure, cuz I know I've talked to you in

16
00:00:49.744 --> 00:00:54.148
the background before that they are just
packed full of different utilities.

17
00:00:54.148 --> 00:00:56.260
So, you can help sort that out and

18
00:00:56.260 --> 00:00:59.390
figure out what tools we use at
the appropriate times today?

19
00:00:59.390 --> 00:01:03.310
>> Absolutely and this whole series we
got a lot of episodes lined up, and

20
00:01:03.310 --> 00:01:06.180
you guys are going to see a ton of
different tools that are out there.

21
00:01:06.180 --> 00:01:10.270
I just wanna focus on two or three that
we're going to use every time, right?

22
00:01:10.270 --> 00:01:11.530
That we know that we're
always going to use, and

23
00:01:11.530 --> 00:01:15.120
you guys should already be familiar with
these tools, but I want to make sure, and

24
00:01:15.120 --> 00:01:16.950
so that's where we're going to start.

25
00:01:16.950 --> 00:01:19.100
If you're already familiar with these, and

26
00:01:19.100 --> 00:01:21.590
you want to skip pass the episode
you're not going to hurt my feelings.

27
00:01:21.590 --> 00:01:23.550
But if you don't know these,
we're gonna use them a lot, so

28
00:01:23.550 --> 00:01:24.850
you definitely need to
be familiar with them.

29
00:01:24.850 --> 00:01:28.240
And so I wanna start with a tool
that's pretty important, and

30
00:01:28.240 --> 00:01:30.440
that's the debug utility.

31
00:01:30.440 --> 00:01:33.180
>> All right, now with debugging,
one of the first things I think of, Don,

32
00:01:33.180 --> 00:01:34.450
is software development.

33
00:01:34.450 --> 00:01:37.430
I know enough about code to spell C++.

34
00:01:37.430 --> 00:01:39.310
And when they talk about debugging,

35
00:01:39.310 --> 00:01:42.210
one of the things that they talk
about is a lot of information.

36
00:01:42.210 --> 00:01:43.802
Is that where we're going here,
a lot of output?

37
00:01:43.802 --> 00:01:47.467
>> Absolutely, you know, if you connect
into a Cisco router, or a Cisco switch,

38
00:01:47.467 --> 00:01:51.151
and you do a show log you see the logging
information that's in the background.

39
00:01:51.151 --> 00:01:54.186
And it's not really a ton of data, but
there's good data there you can use for

40
00:01:54.186 --> 00:01:55.490
troubleshooting.

41
00:01:55.490 --> 00:02:00.030
But there's a lot more that happens behind
the scenes that we don't even notice.

42
00:02:00.030 --> 00:02:02.520
Right, they're just kind of invisible
to us because the router, or

43
00:02:02.520 --> 00:02:03.540
the switch hides it.

44
00:02:03.540 --> 00:02:06.720
So if we need to see that
information to help troubleshoot,

45
00:02:06.720 --> 00:02:10.640
we've gotta turn that on to be able
to see it and debug let's us do it.

46
00:02:10.640 --> 00:02:14.160
Now most of you guys have probably
used debugging for other things or

47
00:02:14.160 --> 00:02:19.180
definitely used it in the other shows
as we debug things like PPP and

48
00:02:19.180 --> 00:02:21.440
other network connectivity issues.

49
00:02:21.440 --> 00:02:22.940
So it's pretty handy.

50
00:02:22.940 --> 00:02:25.330
What I want to show you is a few
advanced things that you may or

51
00:02:25.330 --> 00:02:27.410
may not know about debug so.

52
00:02:27.410 --> 00:02:29.330
I've got a switch pulled up here and

53
00:02:29.330 --> 00:02:31.830
I just wanna show you guys
a couple of neat things here.

54
00:02:31.830 --> 00:02:34.280
First off,
let's just talk about debug itself.

55
00:02:34.280 --> 00:02:37.900
I'm SSHed into this switch,
so I have a remote shell.

56
00:02:37.900 --> 00:02:39.250
And with a remote shell,

57
00:02:39.250 --> 00:02:43.410
it will not show you debug
information by default, all right?

58
00:02:43.410 --> 00:02:47.160
I'm not gonna see what's going on on
the network or any information, but

59
00:02:47.160 --> 00:02:48.120
it is actually happening.

60
00:02:48.120 --> 00:02:51.360
Cisco wants to make sure that
you plug in to the console port

61
00:02:51.360 --> 00:02:55.320
of a switch when you debug it, and
not remote into it like I'm doing here.

62
00:02:55.320 --> 00:02:58.510
Because you can get so much information,

63
00:02:58.510 --> 00:03:03.300
that it overwhelms your session, and
you lock yourself out of the device.

64
00:03:03.300 --> 00:03:08.100
So for example,
a great one is debug ip packets, or

65
00:03:08.100 --> 00:03:10.420
even better, debug ip packets detail.

66
00:03:10.420 --> 00:03:11.330
If you run this command,

67
00:03:11.330 --> 00:03:15.330
if I were to run this right now and I were
monitoring that information on my switch,

68
00:03:15.330 --> 00:03:18.080
I would get overwhelmed and
locked out of the switch, all right?

69
00:03:18.080 --> 00:03:19.790
Well I say that.

70
00:03:19.790 --> 00:03:20.820
It's actually not gonna happen though,

71
00:03:20.820 --> 00:03:25.160
because the debugs are not going
to be displayed by default.

72
00:03:25.160 --> 00:03:28.640
So if I run something
like debug ip routing,

73
00:03:28.640 --> 00:03:32.380
that's gonna show me any changes
to my routing table, all right.

74
00:03:32.380 --> 00:03:33.110
So if I go and

75
00:03:33.110 --> 00:03:36.430
start making changes at the routing
table I should see debug information.

76
00:03:36.430 --> 00:03:40.080
But I'm not gonna see that
unless I run terminal monitor.

77
00:03:40.080 --> 00:03:44.400
So when you're remotely connected into
a switch or a router if you wanna see

78
00:03:44.400 --> 00:03:47.880
the debug output you've gotta run
terminal monitor to be able to see it.

79
00:03:47.880 --> 00:03:53.350
If you want to turn that back off
again it's terminal no monitor.

80
00:03:53.350 --> 00:03:56.120
The no command we normally put at
the begging, not this time, right.

81
00:03:56.120 --> 00:03:59.989
Terminal no monitor, and that will make it
where I don't see those messages anymore,

82
00:03:59.989 --> 00:04:03.010
but now that I'm de-bugging IP
routing if I start making changes to

83
00:04:03.010 --> 00:04:05.451
the routing table I'll get
those messages popped up.

84
00:04:05.451 --> 00:04:08.452
And I can do a show debug to
show the debugging that I've got

85
00:04:08.452 --> 00:04:11.221
turned on because I might
turn on more than one thing.

86
00:04:11.221 --> 00:04:16.839
I might say debug ip rip or debug ip
ospf events or something like that,

87
00:04:16.839 --> 00:04:23.320
and if I do a show debug I can see all
the different things that I've turned on.

88
00:04:23.320 --> 00:04:26.451
Now the key thing about these
debugs is that if I leave them on,

89
00:04:26.451 --> 00:04:29.601
they keep generating messages,
and they can fill up my logs.

90
00:04:29.601 --> 00:04:32.763
It could just be a bunch of wasted
resources on the switch, so

91
00:04:32.763 --> 00:04:36.220
whenever you're done debugging,
you gotta turn it off.

92
00:04:36.220 --> 00:04:40.970
And the easiest way to do that is to type,
undebug all, or no debug all,

93
00:04:40.970 --> 00:04:42.480
either way, they do the same thing.

94
00:04:42.480 --> 00:04:45.160
And that'll turn all the debugging off,
and

95
00:04:45.160 --> 00:04:47.370
now we're in the clear and that's that.

96
00:04:47.370 --> 00:04:49.240
>> All right now with the information,

97
00:04:49.240 --> 00:04:51.280
you said that it could
be a lot of information.

98
00:04:51.280 --> 00:04:55.970
Is there any way that maybe we can
target down to more specifics?

99
00:04:55.970 --> 00:04:58.580
Maybe a specific piece of
information that we wanna get to?

100
00:04:58.580 --> 00:04:59.740
>> Yeah, absolutely right.

101
00:04:59.740 --> 00:05:02.410
And that's important especially
if you're doing what I'm doing.

102
00:05:02.410 --> 00:05:04.260
I'm remotely monitoring this switch.

103
00:05:04.260 --> 00:05:07.710
So, if I start turning on
debugging I could get overwhelmed.

104
00:05:07.710 --> 00:05:10.580
Well, wouldn't it be nice if we
could filter down the debug output.

105
00:05:10.580 --> 00:05:15.610
So, for example, I said debut ip packets,
right, or debug ip packets detail, right?

106
00:05:15.610 --> 00:05:19.310
If I just do debug ip packets it
gives me a single line entry for

107
00:05:19.310 --> 00:05:21.200
each packet that's passing
over an interface.

108
00:05:21.200 --> 00:05:24.370
If I do detail, it actually shows me
more information about the payload, too.

109
00:05:24.370 --> 00:05:26.363
So it can be really verbose.

110
00:05:26.363 --> 00:05:29.850
If I run that, it's going to
show me all the IP packets for

111
00:05:29.850 --> 00:05:31.590
the whole stinking switch.

112
00:05:31.590 --> 00:05:33.585
It's a lot of information, right?

113
00:05:33.585 --> 00:05:38.065
Right, but I can filter that down by using
what's called conditional debugging.

114
00:05:38.065 --> 00:05:42.875
Conditional debugging is where we apply
a filter to our debug, and one of

115
00:05:42.875 --> 00:05:46.675
the best types of conditional debugging
we can do is interface filtering.

116
00:05:46.675 --> 00:05:51.571
I can say debug interface fa3/11.

117
00:05:51.571 --> 00:05:52.920
That's the port that I'm plugged into.

118
00:05:52.920 --> 00:05:56.740
Now if I run that,
see what it said, condition 1 set.

119
00:05:57.810 --> 00:05:59.110
What does that mean?

120
00:05:59.110 --> 00:06:00.900
Well, if I do a show debug,

121
00:06:00.900 --> 00:06:05.020
debug interface fa3/11
doesn't actually do anything.

122
00:06:05.020 --> 00:06:06.380
It puts a filter in.

123
00:06:06.380 --> 00:06:11.072
And, it says, all right, from now on,
if I do debugging and give you feedback,

124
00:06:11.072 --> 00:06:15.912
I'm only gonna show you feedback
generated by interface fa3/11, all right?

125
00:06:15.912 --> 00:06:18.440
Now, I'm getting some log
messages popped up here.

126
00:06:18.440 --> 00:06:20.920
These aren't from the debug, all right?

127
00:06:20.920 --> 00:06:23.420
These are line protocol,
up down messages, and

128
00:06:23.420 --> 00:06:27.750
I wouldn't normally see these, except
I've got terminal monitor turned on.

129
00:06:27.750 --> 00:06:31.280
And, this just means somebody
probably rebooted their computer,

130
00:06:31.280 --> 00:06:32.760
unplugged the cable and
plugged it back in.

131
00:06:32.760 --> 00:06:34.760
So I'm seeing that message pop up.

132
00:06:34.760 --> 00:06:40.060
But I know it's not a debug because if I
look at the source, %LINEPROTO-5, right?

133
00:06:40.060 --> 00:06:42.550
Debugs will actually say they
are coming from a debug.

134
00:06:42.550 --> 00:06:48.160
So, for example,
if I do debug ip packets detail,

135
00:06:48.160 --> 00:06:54.740
right, now, oops,
ip packet detail, there we go.

136
00:06:54.740 --> 00:06:57.470
Now I'm starting to get
detailed information and

137
00:06:57.470 --> 00:06:59.410
all this data is coming across my screen.

138
00:06:59.410 --> 00:07:01.670
I'm getting a lot of information.

139
00:07:01.670 --> 00:07:03.910
These are the debugs I just generated.

140
00:07:03.910 --> 00:07:09.310
I'm getting a lot of information, but
its all coming from interface fa3/11, I've

141
00:07:09.310 --> 00:07:14.620
filtered it down to only get what I want,
but even here I'm getting a lot of data.

142
00:07:14.620 --> 00:07:16.340
This is the port that I'm on.

143
00:07:16.340 --> 00:07:20.880
If I were to fire up a web browser and
go to a website like Google, for

144
00:07:20.880 --> 00:07:25.450
example, well in here some of this
is going to be my web traffic

145
00:07:25.450 --> 00:07:27.340
as a browsed out to that server.

146
00:07:27.340 --> 00:07:31.340
I see a lot of stuff on port 22,
because I'm SSHed into the switch.

147
00:07:31.340 --> 00:07:32.860
I expect to see that, right?

148
00:07:32.860 --> 00:07:37.290
But it's more information than I
necessarily care to see, all right?

149
00:07:37.290 --> 00:07:42.670
So what I can do, is I can come in, and
I can start to filter this even more.

150
00:07:42.670 --> 00:07:46.210
I'm going to do a quick undebug all
because I'm just getting too much

151
00:07:46.210 --> 00:07:46.990
information there.

152
00:07:46.990 --> 00:07:47.560
All right.

153
00:07:47.560 --> 00:07:50.200
And notice how I got debugs
after I ran the command?

154
00:07:50.200 --> 00:07:51.320
That's the back log.

155
00:07:51.320 --> 00:07:54.030
My session was getting so
much data I was actually backlogged.

156
00:07:54.030 --> 00:07:56.890
So we have to wait for that to finish and
now it is caught up, all right.

157
00:07:56.890 --> 00:07:59.185
So I can filter it even more.

158
00:07:59.185 --> 00:08:04.042
When you do a debug, you can apply an
access control list to filter that down so

159
00:08:04.042 --> 00:08:06.081
you get even less information.

160
00:08:06.081 --> 00:08:08.845
And that's really helpful
to control the flow.

161
00:08:08.845 --> 00:08:11.120
We don't wanna get overwhelmed
with all this stuff.

162
00:08:11.120 --> 00:08:14.760
So, for example,
I can create a quick access list.

163
00:08:14.760 --> 00:08:17.980
I could say access-list, I'll do 135.

164
00:08:17.980 --> 00:08:21.380
I'm just picking a number out of my hat,
here.

165
00:08:21.380 --> 00:08:26.590
And I'm gonna limit this to
Maybe I'll do tcp traffic

166
00:08:27.760 --> 00:08:31.520
and I'll do the source,
which will be me, 10.1.230.21.

167
00:08:31.520 --> 00:08:34.320
And the destination will
be we'll say anybody.

168
00:08:34.320 --> 00:08:38.940
And should probably just leave it at that,
right?

169
00:08:38.940 --> 00:08:42.240
Actually, here I'll say I'm
going to somebody using.

170
00:08:42.240 --> 00:08:45.010
Port 23 or port 80 or
something like that, right?

171
00:08:45.010 --> 00:08:45.520
So.

172
00:08:45.520 --> 00:08:46.340
Whoops.

173
00:08:46.340 --> 00:08:47.330
Shoot.

174
00:08:47.330 --> 00:08:52.650
I should have done, let's see,
access-list 135 permit tcp.

175
00:08:52.650 --> 00:08:55.670
There, I had to remember my syntax.

176
00:08:55.670 --> 00:08:57.280
I did some basic
troubleshooting right there.

177
00:08:57.280 --> 00:08:59.370
So, I'll put that in place.

178
00:08:59.370 --> 00:09:02.170
And maybe I wanna add to that and
do port 80 also, right?

179
00:09:02.170 --> 00:09:04.660
So web traffic and telnet.

180
00:09:04.660 --> 00:09:07.440
I don't want All that Port 22.

181
00:09:07.440 --> 00:09:10.660
All that SSH because I know I'm SSH'd in,
right?

182
00:09:10.660 --> 00:09:15.480
Or I could have written this
axis list a little different and

183
00:09:15.480 --> 00:09:19.260
said axis list 135 deny tcp any any eq 22,
right?

184
00:09:19.260 --> 00:09:24.200
I don't want to get traffic that
is a destination port of 22.

185
00:09:24.200 --> 00:09:26.130
I don't want to get the siege traffic.

186
00:09:26.130 --> 00:09:29.070
Now, it can apply both ways, too.

187
00:09:29.070 --> 00:09:32.810
So, I might need to add an extra
line just to get the other one.

188
00:09:32.810 --> 00:09:34.590
So, I'm gonna deny those.

189
00:09:34.590 --> 00:09:37.380
And I'll permit everything else.

190
00:09:37.380 --> 00:09:39.920
So, I'll just add in
quick line to do that.

191
00:09:39.920 --> 00:09:41.950
All right.
So, here's a filter that's gonna block out

192
00:09:41.950 --> 00:09:46.000
SSH traffic coming and going, and
it's gonna allow everything else.

193
00:09:46.000 --> 00:09:52.020
And so when I do that debug,
I could say, debug ip packet And then.

194
00:09:52.020 --> 00:09:55.230
I keep putting that S on there.

195
00:09:55.230 --> 00:09:56.130
Oh shoot.

196
00:09:56.130 --> 00:09:56.752
I'm in config.

197
00:09:56.752 --> 00:10:01.900
Debug don't work so well from inside of
config, but if I do a debug IP packet.

198
00:10:01.900 --> 00:10:03.020
There we go.

199
00:10:03.020 --> 00:10:06.580
Notice how I can say like
detail that I did earlier, and

200
00:10:06.580 --> 00:10:11.130
I can also specify and access this to
control exactly what it is I'm debugging.

201
00:10:11.130 --> 00:10:16.720
So, I can say debug ip packet 130,
what was the first one I did?

202
00:10:16.720 --> 00:10:18.850
134?
Oh you know what?

203
00:10:18.850 --> 00:10:21.320
Actually I stacked all that into 135.

204
00:10:21.320 --> 00:10:22.280
Didn't I.
Well, that's fine.

205
00:10:22.280 --> 00:10:25.060
I can do 135 and
now it's going to debug those packets,

206
00:10:25.060 --> 00:10:29.050
but only give me the stuff
that's coming up in that list.

207
00:10:29.050 --> 00:10:31.920
I did stick that permit IP any at the end,
so if I were to turn this on,

208
00:10:31.920 --> 00:10:36.900
I'd get myself back in trouble Unless I
limit it to an interface first, right?

209
00:10:36.900 --> 00:10:40.210
Well, remember that conditional
formatting that I did?

210
00:10:40.210 --> 00:10:41.950
I didn't un debug all.

211
00:10:41.950 --> 00:10:46.980
If I do a show debug, conditional
formatting survives the un debug all.

212
00:10:46.980 --> 00:10:50.170
So, if I do a debug IP packets and

213
00:10:50.170 --> 00:10:54.980
then I specify that access list, right?

214
00:10:56.800 --> 00:11:01.760
It's going to try and debug everything,
but the conditional form,

215
00:11:01.760 --> 00:11:04.240
the conditional filtering
is still in place and

216
00:11:04.240 --> 00:11:07.320
that's going to bring this down
to a much more manageable level.

217
00:11:07.320 --> 00:11:10.753
And so now we can start to debut it and
see how it's on detailed for

218
00:11:10.753 --> 00:11:15.470
access 135, and there it goes and
I seen some traffic happening here.

219
00:11:15.470 --> 00:11:16.430
Traffic on fort 123.

220
00:11:16.430 --> 00:11:18.152
West, you remember 123?

221
00:11:18.152 --> 00:11:19.350
>> 123, no I don't.

222
00:11:19.350 --> 00:11:20.365
Not off the top of my head.

223
00:11:20.365 --> 00:11:22.520
[LAUGH]
>> Well, network time is what we call it.

224
00:11:22.520 --> 00:11:24.130
>> Oh, 123 okay.
>> So,

225
00:11:24.130 --> 00:11:26.150
I'm apparent updated my clock,
or something.

226
00:11:26.150 --> 00:11:28.840
Who knows, but if I try and browse to.

227
00:11:28.840 --> 00:11:32.230
I wonder if that switch has
a web interface turned on.

228
00:11:32.230 --> 00:11:35.430
Oh, it doesn't but
I can see that web traffic there, right?

229
00:11:35.430 --> 00:11:36.360
So.

230
00:11:36.360 --> 00:11:39.730
Debugging, it's really
important to use filters if

231
00:11:39.730 --> 00:11:43.490
you can to minimize that
fire hose of traffic.

232
00:11:43.490 --> 00:11:45.660
But also keep in mind when you're done,

233
00:11:45.660 --> 00:11:51.400
make sure you do that undebug all to
turn it off and if you put conditional

234
00:11:51.400 --> 00:11:55.665
debugs in place, make sure that you
remove them when you're done too.

235
00:11:55.665 --> 00:11:59.780
So,I'm just gonna do a no to get
rid of that and I'll remove it.

236
00:11:59.780 --> 00:12:03.500
And so now when it's done I can do a show
debug, and I should get it empty, and

237
00:12:03.500 --> 00:12:04.990
it's all turned off.

238
00:12:04.990 --> 00:12:07.690
>> Very good, so
we can get a lot of information,

239
00:12:07.690 --> 00:12:10.580
just verbose amount of information.

240
00:12:10.580 --> 00:12:12.880
We can filter it down,
make it a little bit easier.

241
00:12:12.880 --> 00:12:17.270
Now, Don, once we've done our debugging,
we've got all this information.

242
00:12:17.270 --> 00:12:20.970
We've determined what portion of the
information we're actually supposed to be

243
00:12:20.970 --> 00:12:21.916
looking at.

244
00:12:21.916 --> 00:12:25.500
Now, we've got to start using some
utilities to make not only some sense out

245
00:12:25.500 --> 00:12:26.430
of the information, but

246
00:12:26.430 --> 00:12:29.830
to use that information to start
along the troubleshooting, right?

247
00:12:29.830 --> 00:12:30.720
>> Yeah, absolutely.

248
00:12:30.720 --> 00:12:34.650
And debug we use a lot, but sometimes
we don't need all that information.

249
00:12:34.650 --> 00:12:36.500
So, I don't normally start with debug.

250
00:12:36.500 --> 00:12:39.730
I usually end up with debug when
I can't figure something out.

251
00:12:39.730 --> 00:12:42.670
So, as I'm trying to troubleshoot
a problem, one of the first steps that

252
00:12:42.670 --> 00:12:46.620
I usually go through is Trying to
figure out the extent of the problem.

253
00:12:46.620 --> 00:12:47.640
How far out is the problem.

254
00:12:47.640 --> 00:12:49.280
And I do something called
measuring reachability.

255
00:12:49.280 --> 00:12:51.550
So, if I have a computer that
can't get on the network,

256
00:12:51.550 --> 00:12:53.630
I need to figure out where it's dying,
right.

257
00:12:53.630 --> 00:12:57.760
Is it dying when it hits its switch,
is it dying when it hits its gateway,

258
00:12:57.760 --> 00:12:59.290
is it dying when it hits
an external network?

259
00:12:59.290 --> 00:13:01.500
Where is it in that path that it dies out?

260
00:13:01.500 --> 00:13:04.080
And Ping is kinda our go to utility for
that.

261
00:13:04.080 --> 00:13:07.450
Now, Ping on a Cisco switch or
router is pretty straight forward, right?

262
00:13:07.450 --> 00:13:09.260
You just run Ping and punch in an IP.

263
00:13:09.260 --> 00:13:11.910
So, I might Ping 10.1.230.5, right?

264
00:13:11.910 --> 00:13:16.890
I wanna Ping that IP and
there it goes, right?

265
00:13:16.890 --> 00:13:18.280
Pretty cut and dry.

266
00:13:18.280 --> 00:13:20.740
>> Very good.
Now, I've used Ping before and

267
00:13:20.740 --> 00:13:24.090
I know that the protocol that I've
used when I'm using Ping, is ICMP.

268
00:13:24.090 --> 00:13:27.840
Now, can you go a little bit further
with the ping inside of the switch here?

269
00:13:27.840 --> 00:13:31.900
I mean, can we get a little bit more
detailed on what exactly we're using and

270
00:13:31.900 --> 00:13:33.920
some of the parameters we set behind ping?

271
00:13:33.920 --> 00:13:34.640
>> Yeah.
There's

272
00:13:34.640 --> 00:13:36.340
a ton of stuff that you can do with ping.

273
00:13:36.340 --> 00:13:39.040
I'm doing a ping here,
just a straight up regular ping.

274
00:13:39.040 --> 00:13:40.700
This works for IPv6 also.

275
00:13:40.700 --> 00:13:43.200
You can say ping and
specify an IPv6 address and

276
00:13:43.200 --> 00:13:46.580
it'll hit that just fine too But
it's just doing a normal ping.

277
00:13:46.580 --> 00:13:47.780
Sometimes we want to change that.

278
00:13:47.780 --> 00:13:49.360
Especially on routers.

279
00:13:49.360 --> 00:13:52.170
Because sometimes a ping might
work from one network and

280
00:13:52.170 --> 00:13:53.900
not work from another network.

281
00:13:53.900 --> 00:13:58.930
And so one of the things that I will often
times add, is on ping if you do a question

282
00:13:58.930 --> 00:14:03.540
mark after the IP, you'll see where you
can add source, I do source all the time.

283
00:14:03.540 --> 00:14:06.600
I might want to source traffic
From a particular interface.

284
00:14:06.600 --> 00:14:11.040
So, for example, let's say I have
a loopback interface, right?

285
00:14:11.040 --> 00:14:13.650
So, I whip up a loopback interface.

286
00:14:13.650 --> 00:14:15.110
Actually, hang on.

287
00:14:15.110 --> 00:14:17.880
I don't already have
that interface in place.

288
00:14:17.880 --> 00:14:18.820
All right.

289
00:14:18.820 --> 00:14:23.005
And I might give it an IP address
that's in some crazy network And so

290
00:14:23.005 --> 00:14:25.635
I'll just kind of bring this one online.

291
00:14:27.481 --> 00:14:28.133
And it should be up.

292
00:14:28.133 --> 00:14:28.980
There we go.
All right.

293
00:14:28.980 --> 00:14:31.110
So, I've got this network.

294
00:14:31.110 --> 00:14:34.550
And if I ping to another IP.

295
00:14:34.550 --> 00:14:39.950
So, if I do ping to 10.1.230.5 well,
my switch is 10.1.230.2.

296
00:14:39.950 --> 00:14:42.170
But I'm the same network.

297
00:14:42.170 --> 00:14:42.890
I don't need a router.

298
00:14:42.890 --> 00:14:44.110
I should be able to ping that.

299
00:14:44.110 --> 00:14:44.870
Right?

300
00:14:44.870 --> 00:14:50.260
But if I add source lo0, now the source
of my ping is gonna be 10 dot.

301
00:14:50.260 --> 00:14:54.610
No, it's actually gonna be 172 dot,
16 dot, five dot, one.

302
00:14:54.610 --> 00:14:58.600
And when I source it from that,
I can't get there.

303
00:14:58.600 --> 00:15:00.480
And that's because I'm sourced
from a different network.

304
00:15:00.480 --> 00:15:02.430
I've got to go through
a router to get there.

305
00:15:02.430 --> 00:15:06.600
And this switch is not doing any
layer three switching or routing, so

306
00:15:06.600 --> 00:15:08.820
it's just not gonna get there.

307
00:15:08.820 --> 00:15:12.700
So, by changing the source, and
I did the source based on an interface.

308
00:15:12.700 --> 00:15:16.010
You can do the source based on IP also,
so you'll see,

309
00:15:16.010 --> 00:15:18.940
we've got a few different options
of how you wanna enter that in.

310
00:15:18.940 --> 00:15:20.290
But you can specify it.

311
00:15:20.290 --> 00:15:24.240
And now it's gonna reach out that way on a
router that's really useful modification.

312
00:15:24.240 --> 00:15:27.720
But you'll see there's a lot of other
things that you can modify, too.

313
00:15:27.720 --> 00:15:29.480
For example, the data pattern.

314
00:15:29.480 --> 00:15:32.380
By default your ping will carry
a certain amount of payload,

315
00:15:32.380 --> 00:15:33.780
a certain amount of bits of data.

316
00:15:33.780 --> 00:15:36.830
And all it's doing is taking
the alphabet and repeating it.

317
00:15:36.830 --> 00:15:38.120
A through Z, A through Z.

318
00:15:38.120 --> 00:15:39.300
If you ever run a packet sniffer and

319
00:15:39.300 --> 00:15:40.920
intercept these that's
what's in these pings,

320
00:15:40.920 --> 00:15:42.630
just the alphabet over and over again.

321
00:15:42.630 --> 00:15:46.033
You can manipulate the data pattern so
it's not A through Z or

322
00:15:46.033 --> 00:15:50.305
you can manipulate the size which is how
many times it repeats the alphabet so

323
00:15:50.305 --> 00:15:53.330
that it fills up and
create a packet of a certain size.

324
00:15:53.330 --> 00:15:56.547
I've trouble shot some broadband
connections, cable and

325
00:15:56.547 --> 00:15:59.635
DSL where pings of one size
would get through just fine and

326
00:15:59.635 --> 00:16:03.188
then when you increase their payload,
the would start failing.

327
00:16:03.188 --> 00:16:07.085
So, I would call up the support
people at the ISP and say man,

328
00:16:07.085 --> 00:16:08.700
this connection is bad.

329
00:16:08.700 --> 00:16:10.396
And they say, oh,
I'm pinging over it just fine.

330
00:16:10.396 --> 00:16:12.790
And I would say, well,
actually send some payload.

331
00:16:12.790 --> 00:16:14.600
And they would say, oh,
I am sending payload.

332
00:16:14.600 --> 00:16:19.008
And I would say, all right, do this, make
your ping contain at least 500 bytes of

333
00:16:19.008 --> 00:16:21.447
data, or bump it up to 1000 bytes of data.

334
00:16:21.447 --> 00:16:22.909
You got a standard MTU, right?

335
00:16:22.909 --> 00:16:23.443
>> Mm-hm.

336
00:16:23.443 --> 00:16:26.620
>> And once they put payload in it,
also the ping started failing, and

337
00:16:26.620 --> 00:16:29.260
they're like, oh,
turns out our network is garbage.

338
00:16:29.260 --> 00:16:32.730
>> So it was hid the MTU and then it
was just dropping it so it's not going?

339
00:16:32.730 --> 00:16:33.900
>> No it wasn't even hitting the MTU,

340
00:16:33.900 --> 00:16:36.320
it's just that that particular
system was overloaded.

341
00:16:36.320 --> 00:16:38.450
>> Okay.
>> And so it was between the various

342
00:16:38.450 --> 00:16:40.520
customers and
it didn't have enough to handle it.

343
00:16:40.520 --> 00:16:41.190
>> Interesting.

344
00:16:41.190 --> 00:16:44.050
>> Those are the things we can
see by manipulating that size.

345
00:16:44.050 --> 00:16:46.380
You can manipulate that time out also.

346
00:16:46.380 --> 00:16:50.580
That's kind of useful because the time out
on a Cisco device is really, really short.

347
00:16:50.580 --> 00:16:54.150
On a Windows machine or
on a Mac, you do a ping and

348
00:16:54.150 --> 00:16:57.550
it'll give the other system five,
ten seconds to respond, sometimes longer.

349
00:16:57.550 --> 00:17:01.000
On a Cisco switch, it's like one second,

350
00:17:01.000 --> 00:17:04.380
maybe two on an old device, so
it doesn't give it a ton of time, and

351
00:17:04.380 --> 00:17:07.480
you might want to manipulate that time
out to speed that up a little more.

352
00:17:07.480 --> 00:17:09.180
So, these are all different options.

353
00:17:09.180 --> 00:17:10.700
You can do them right here in line, or

354
00:17:10.700 --> 00:17:14.040
if you forget them,
you can just type ping and press Enter.

355
00:17:14.040 --> 00:17:16.150
And then it will walk you through
the different options, right?

356
00:17:16.150 --> 00:17:19.256
You can choose your protocol
which is normally IP on the exam.

357
00:17:19.256 --> 00:17:20.115
It will always be IP.

358
00:17:20.115 --> 00:17:24.930
You can specify the person you wanna
ping and then the repeat count, right?

359
00:17:24.930 --> 00:17:28.910
How many I want to do, maybe I want to
do ten pings instead of the normal five.

360
00:17:28.910 --> 00:17:32.984
The datagram size,
I want this to be 300 instead of 200.

361
00:17:32.984 --> 00:17:36.260
And we kinda keep going through and
specifying these options.

362
00:17:36.260 --> 00:17:38.900
>> Now you mentioned IP, and
a lot of times it's gonna be IP.

363
00:17:38.900 --> 00:17:41.435
Do we have parameters in there
that maybe we could use, and

364
00:17:41.435 --> 00:17:43.364
test other routable protocols [CROSSTALK].

365
00:17:43.364 --> 00:17:45.117
>> Yeah, any routable protocols.

366
00:17:45.117 --> 00:17:48.630
So you can do IPX, you can do,
what are the other ones that are?

367
00:17:48.630 --> 00:17:50.330
Well, it depends on your feature set.

368
00:17:50.330 --> 00:17:51.250
Not every switch has them.

369
00:17:51.250 --> 00:17:52.390
But a lot of them have IPX.

370
00:17:52.390 --> 00:17:55.110
You can do IPv6, so
you could specify those.

371
00:17:55.110 --> 00:17:57.038
On the exam,
they just focus on IP and IPv6.

372
00:17:57.038 --> 00:17:57.676
>> Very good.

373
00:17:57.676 --> 00:18:00.120
>> Now notice I get
these extended commands.

374
00:18:00.120 --> 00:18:02.050
If I say no,
it will just send this ping out here.

375
00:18:02.050 --> 00:18:05.100
But if I say yes, there's even
more options like the source so

376
00:18:05.100 --> 00:18:09.610
I can specify that and
on the source it's kind of annoying.

377
00:18:09.610 --> 00:18:13.770
It makes you actually type out the full
thing so if I need to do a loop back I

378
00:18:13.770 --> 00:18:17.340
gotta type it out, loopback 0,
it's annoying but that takes care of it.

379
00:18:17.340 --> 00:18:21.270
I can set a TOS value,
if I'm trying to test quality of service,

380
00:18:21.270 --> 00:18:25.680
I might have one TOS set for voice
traffic and different TOS set for data.

381
00:18:25.680 --> 00:18:28.130
And so
I can manipulate the TOS right here.

382
00:18:28.130 --> 00:18:32.590
I can set my DF, my DiffServ Code Point
again for quality of service.

383
00:18:32.590 --> 00:18:34.930
We can validate reply data.

00:18:34.930 --> 00:18:38.280
Is the reply data actually coming from
the same path that we sent to, right?

385
00:18:38.280 --> 00:18:40.950
Am I getting it from the same destination?

00:18:40.950 --> 00:18:45.289
And the pattern, see how the pattern
shows that alphabet, right, 0xABCD?

387
00:18:45.289 --> 00:18:47.960
It's just gonna repeat that over and
over again.

388
00:18:47.960 --> 00:18:52.530
And then how I want my data to be sent,

389
00:18:52.530 --> 00:18:54.350
This is the data it's giving us back.

390
00:18:54.350 --> 00:18:56.780
And we can tell it verbose
if we really want data.

391
00:18:56.780 --> 00:18:59.310
The default is it's just gonna give

392
00:18:59.310 --> 00:19:01.140
And that's not a ton of information.

393
00:19:01.140 --> 00:19:03.700
>> Very good.
So we could use the ping utility, right.

394
00:19:03.700 --> 00:19:06.834
Very basic and
we can add parameters to it.

395
00:19:06.834 --> 00:19:08.712
It definitely get a little
more advanced and

396
00:19:08.712 --> 00:19:10.650
really rifle down on what you're testing.

397
00:19:10.650 --> 00:19:14.000
Don, what is the next type
of command that we have for

398
00:19:14.000 --> 00:19:16.360
testing things like connectivity
across our networks?

399
00:19:16.360 --> 00:19:17.608
>> All right, so the problem with ping.

400
00:19:17.608 --> 00:19:18.734
Ping has it's uses.

401
00:19:18.734 --> 00:19:23.160
And if I wanna find out where a fault is
I can start pinging from one host and

402
00:19:23.160 --> 00:19:28.024
start slowly moving my way out to try and
isolate where the fault is on a network,

403
00:19:28.024 --> 00:19:28.905
right?

404
00:19:28.905 --> 00:19:32.601
And so if I wanna test something like
I got a system that can't get to

405
00:19:32.601 --> 00:19:36.099
the Internet, so I usually start
just by like pinging itself,

406
00:19:36.099 --> 00:19:38.938
so this switch is 10.1.230.2, right?

407
00:19:38.938 --> 00:19:40.702
So, I ping itself, yeah!

408
00:19:40.702 --> 00:19:41.620
Right.

409
00:19:41.620 --> 00:19:45.690
And then, whatever its default gateway is,
I might ping that, so if I take a look at,

410
00:19:45.690 --> 00:19:47.760
I actually don't know what
this switches gateway is.

411
00:19:47.760 --> 00:19:49.290
So, let's take a look.

412
00:19:49.290 --> 00:19:50.410
Man, I don't even have a gateway.

413
00:19:50.410 --> 00:19:52.750
So, I'm gonna take a look
at what its gateway is.

414
00:19:52.750 --> 00:19:53.980
There we go, 10.1.10.1.

415
00:19:53.980 --> 00:19:56.250
So, then I ping its default gateway.

416
00:19:56.250 --> 00:19:57.814
Can I get to that gateway and I can.

417
00:19:57.814 --> 00:20:01.780
All right, if I can get to the gateway,
can I get out to the Internet beyond it?

418
00:20:01.780 --> 00:20:03.900
And then I start to ping out to there.

419
00:20:03.900 --> 00:20:05.280
So, I'll ping out to this guy.

420
00:20:05.280 --> 00:20:06.160
And I get out there.

421
00:20:06.160 --> 00:20:07.650
But what if I can't?

422
00:20:07.650 --> 00:20:09.860
Well, is the whole Internet down?

423
00:20:09.860 --> 00:20:10.890
Might be.

424
00:20:10.890 --> 00:20:12.820
Is it my ISP that's down?

425
00:20:12.820 --> 00:20:13.800
More likely.

426
00:20:13.800 --> 00:20:15.610
Is it just my WAN connection?

427
00:20:15.610 --> 00:20:16.610
Most likely.

428
00:20:16.610 --> 00:20:19.890
But I don't know which,
ping doesn't show me that, right?

429
00:20:19.890 --> 00:20:22.570
But we have traceroute that does.

430
00:20:22.570 --> 00:20:27.605
And I can run traceroute and
specify that remote IP.

431
00:20:27.605 --> 00:20:32.495
And now it's gonna lay out all the hops
between me and that estimation.

432
00:20:32.495 --> 00:20:36.485
Now not every network allows traceroutes
and notice I'm getting blocked down here.

433
00:20:36.485 --> 00:20:38.555
But it is giving me
the information I need.

434
00:20:38.555 --> 00:20:42.515
I can see that I'm exiting my building and
I'm jumping to our ISP,

435
00:20:42.515 --> 00:20:45.170
which is GRU, right,
the Gainesville Regional Utilities.

436
00:20:45.170 --> 00:20:46.680
So we jump over to them, and

437
00:20:46.680 --> 00:20:52.590
then we're passing from them out to
the Internet to some other GRU networks.

438
00:20:52.590 --> 00:20:54.660
And then we're jumping all
the way down to Miami, Florida.

439
00:20:54.660 --> 00:20:56.100
Bienvenue a Miami.

440
00:20:56.100 --> 00:20:58.030
And jumping over to level3.net, and

441
00:20:58.030 --> 00:21:01.830
then at some point there we had hit
a device that had trace route blocked.

442
00:21:01.830 --> 00:21:05.710
And then we hit the destination of who
I was pinging, which was the DNS Server

443
00:21:05.710 --> 00:21:08.870
that apparently has an end node
somewhere attached to Miami, right?

444
00:21:08.870 --> 00:21:10.190
So I was able to get out there.

445
00:21:10.190 --> 00:21:11.850
But I see each hop along the way.

446
00:21:11.850 --> 00:21:13.730
And I can spot where the stop was or

447
00:21:13.730 --> 00:21:17.250
where the slow down was because it gives
me this kind of average over here.

448
00:21:17.250 --> 00:21:21.470
The minimum, maximum and
average times of that communication.

449
00:21:21.470 --> 00:21:22.840
So it's kinda laying it out.

450
00:21:22.840 --> 00:21:27.250
So I can see exactly where my slow down or
where my problems might be.

451
00:21:27.250 --> 00:21:28.790
Traceroute is really powerful.

452
00:21:28.790 --> 00:21:29.570
>> Very good.
Very good.

453
00:21:29.570 --> 00:21:33.370
So we can test communications
from source to destination.

454
00:21:33.370 --> 00:21:38.450
We can determine the path a packet takes
between these connectivity devices.

455
00:21:38.450 --> 00:21:40.050
What else we got, Don?

456
00:21:40.050 --> 00:21:43.010
>> All right, now most people never
move beyond that with traceroute, but

457
00:21:43.010 --> 00:21:45.980
I wanna show you guys this really
cool stuff with traceroute that most

458
00:21:45.980 --> 00:21:48.090
people just never actually bother to see.

459
00:21:48.090 --> 00:21:49.596
If you do traceroute question mark,

460
00:21:49.596 --> 00:21:52.130
the first thing you'll notice
is you can do other protocols.

461
00:21:52.130 --> 00:21:56.532
I can traceroute for IP and
IPv6, IPX, Banyan vines.

462
00:21:56.532 --> 00:21:57.948
God forbid, you're having to do that.

463
00:21:57.948 --> 00:21:59.608
>> [LAUGH]
>> So you can do that.

464
00:21:59.608 --> 00:22:02.905
You can do traceroutes to
a host name versus an IP.

465
00:22:02.905 --> 00:22:04.474
So those are kinda cool and

466
00:22:04.474 --> 00:22:08.350
just other ways that you can
kinda track one of those down.

467
00:22:08.350 --> 00:22:11.800
So if I wanna run a traceroute to a host
like that, I can punch in the IP or

468
00:22:11.800 --> 00:22:14.240
the name or
whatever the protocol's gonna be.

469
00:22:14.240 --> 00:22:18.110
But the one I really wanna point out for
you guys is MAC.

470
00:22:18.110 --> 00:22:20.158
All right,
what the heck is the MAC protocol?

471
00:22:20.158 --> 00:22:26.260
It's talking about layer to
Media Control addresses, right?

472
00:22:26.260 --> 00:22:27.610
Why the heck would I wanna do that?

473
00:22:27.610 --> 00:22:30.560
Well on a router you wouldn't,
but on a switch,

474
00:22:30.560 --> 00:22:35.140
maybe I'm trying to trace the path of
traffic that's not going through a router,

475
00:22:35.140 --> 00:22:37.310
but is just moving from
switch to switch to switch.

476
00:22:37.310 --> 00:22:41.070
This is a layer to a traceroute,
and it's really cool.

477
00:22:41.070 --> 00:22:45.060
When you're dealing with traffic
right here in one system,

478
00:22:45.060 --> 00:22:48.530
you might not pass through a router,
traceroute's not gonna show you anything.

479
00:22:48.530 --> 00:22:50.893
My switch is 10.1.

480
00:22:50.893 --> 00:22:53.640
Oh wait, hang on,
I got a couple IP's on this turkey.

481
00:22:53.640 --> 00:22:59.080
So if I [LAUGH], let me just do a quick
show ip int br and there we go.

482
00:22:59.080 --> 00:23:03.695
So my switch on Vlan10,
I am 10.1.10.2, that's my IP.

483
00:23:03.695 --> 00:23:06.821
And let's say that I'm trying
to connect to a host and

484
00:23:06.821 --> 00:23:09.895
that host is 10.1.10.102, all right?

485
00:23:09.895 --> 00:23:15.050
And so I do a ping to 10.1.10.102,
and it's out there, all right?

486
00:23:15.050 --> 00:23:17.140
But maybe I'm losing some pings.

487
00:23:17.140 --> 00:23:20.780
So, if I do a count of 15, right?

488
00:23:20.780 --> 00:23:22.910
And this is a repeat of 15.

489
00:23:22.910 --> 00:23:24.300
There we go.

490
00:23:24.300 --> 00:23:24.970
There.

491
00:23:24.970 --> 00:23:27.549
And I find that out of the 15, 5 fail.

492
00:23:27.549 --> 00:23:29.012
I'm getting a couple of failures.

493
00:23:29.012 --> 00:23:31.470
So I need to figure out
where the problem is.

494
00:23:31.470 --> 00:23:33.980
And it's most probably like
a transceiver or a cable problem.

495
00:23:33.980 --> 00:23:36.050
So I need to know where the cabling runs.

496
00:23:36.050 --> 00:23:37.960
Well, how do I find that?

497
00:23:37.960 --> 00:23:38.840
I could figure it out.

498
00:23:38.840 --> 00:23:41.639
Now that I've done a ping I
could look at the arp table.

499
00:23:42.800 --> 00:23:48.060
And I can hunt down 10.1.10.102 and get
it's MAC address, and then I can do a show

500
00:23:48.060 --> 00:23:53.650
mac address-table and I can filter
that down to just find this guy.

501
00:23:53.650 --> 00:23:55.175
So I'll just look for
the last four of its MAC address.

502
00:23:55.175 --> 00:23:55.755
There we go.

503
00:23:55.755 --> 00:23:57.495
So I'm seeing it on Port-channel1.

504
00:23:57.495 --> 00:23:58.904
Great, that's a connection
to another switch.

505
00:23:58.904 --> 00:24:02.468
Now I've got to go to the other switch and
look at its MAC address table and

506
00:24:02.468 --> 00:24:04.527
figure out what port that's on, right.

507
00:24:04.527 --> 00:24:07.335
So it's kind of a long process
to hunt down a machine.

508
00:24:07.335 --> 00:24:13.420
But if I use trace route,
I can say trace route, Mac.

509
00:24:13.420 --> 00:24:17.150
And I can tell it the Mac address
that I'm trying to hunt down.

510
00:24:17.150 --> 00:24:19.959
And so
I can give it this Mac address right here.

511
00:24:21.630 --> 00:24:23.520
And I need to go a little bit more and

512
00:24:23.520 --> 00:24:28.080
let it know an interface that this exists
on or sometimes you get to specify a VLAN,

513
00:24:28.080 --> 00:24:30.460
and, oh shoot, actually I'm
doing this a little bit wrong.

514
00:24:30.460 --> 00:24:33.150
I need to do that mac
address of the source and

515
00:24:33.150 --> 00:24:37.700
the source is me and then the destination
which would be this Mac here.

516
00:24:37.700 --> 00:24:39.530
So I actually need to add
my own Mac address first.

517
00:24:39.530 --> 00:24:40.910
So let me come back here and add that in.

518
00:24:40.910 --> 00:24:44.180
Now I know what you guys
are thinking this is great,

519
00:24:44.180 --> 00:24:46.670
but all the Mac addresses
I don't know these things.

520
00:24:46.670 --> 00:24:48.490
You can actually do it with IP's also.

521
00:24:48.490 --> 00:24:51.740
So if you know the IP of the system,
you can come in here and you can say,

522
00:24:51.740 --> 00:24:57.050
traceroute Mac, and then you can say,
IP, and specify the IP addresses.

523
00:24:57.050 --> 00:24:59.770
And it will figure out the Mac addresses
for you, which is kinda nice and

524
00:24:59.770 --> 00:25:01.620
will save you the time for
figuring that out.

525
00:25:01.620 --> 00:25:04.750
So if I wanna trace it from the switch,
10, 1, 10, 2, and

526
00:25:04.750 --> 00:25:09.470
I wanna do that to
a destination of 10.1.10.102,

527
00:25:09.470 --> 00:25:13.240
I can do it this way, and
save myself a little bit of trouble.

528
00:25:13.240 --> 00:25:16.565
Now if I run that, I may get an error
about the Mac being found on multiple

529
00:25:16.565 --> 00:25:18.700
VLANs, and
that's because I've got a trunk.

530
00:25:18.700 --> 00:25:21.870
And so, I need to follow that up and
tell it which VLAN this one's on.

531
00:25:21.870 --> 00:25:25.420
And so I'm going to have to
add a little bit more to that.

532
00:25:26.640 --> 00:25:31.250
And, oh shoot,
actually because I have to specify a VLAN,

533
00:25:31.250 --> 00:25:33.380
this is the one time I can't use the IPs.

534
00:25:33.380 --> 00:25:36.270
I actually have to use the Mac address
format, so it's going to get me.

535
00:25:36.270 --> 00:25:36.800
All right.

536
00:25:36.800 --> 00:25:40.520
Well, I'm a lazy typer but
I am dedicated to the show so,

537
00:25:40.520 --> 00:25:42.620
I will type in these Mac addresses for
us here.

538
00:25:42.620 --> 00:25:46.150
So I'm just going to type in my switches
Mac, oh, actually this is my destination.

539
00:25:46.150 --> 00:25:47.360
No, no that's the switch.

540
00:25:47.360 --> 00:25:51.460
Yeah, so I'll punch that in and then
I'll punch in who I'm going to and so,

541
00:25:51.460 --> 00:25:53.420
let me get that one in here.

542
00:25:53.420 --> 00:25:57.730
And we'll run this same thing, and
this time I'll have the VLAN option, so

543
00:25:57.730 --> 00:25:59.950
I can tell it, it's on VLAN 10.

544
00:25:59.950 --> 00:26:03.480
And it's gonna run a traceroute for that
and it's gonna do something really cool.

545
00:26:03.480 --> 00:26:05.900
It's gonna show, oh,
you know, I did it backwards.

546
00:26:05.900 --> 00:26:06.610
Shoot.

547
00:26:06.610 --> 00:26:09.530
I specified my
>> Destination

548
00:26:09.530 --> 00:26:10.710
>> Destination source and my, oh,

549
00:26:10.710 --> 00:26:11.500
I got it backwards.

550
00:26:11.500 --> 00:26:14.750
But, well, you guys kind of see
that if we look at it backwards

551
00:26:14.750 --> 00:26:19.450
we started here on the 4500 series
switch that I'm on, and that's 10.1.0.2.

552
00:26:19.450 --> 00:26:21.470
That's one of my other switch IPs.

553
00:26:21.470 --> 00:26:25.850
And you can see that if I want to get to
that host I'm going to cross port channel

554
00:26:25.850 --> 00:26:27.720
one to get to the other switch.

555
00:26:27.720 --> 00:26:29.940
And on the other switch it's on FA0/6.

556
00:26:29.940 --> 00:26:33.030
That's where this person resides.

557
00:26:33.030 --> 00:26:36.730
I never connected to that other switch,
but that's where that person is, or

558
00:26:36.730 --> 00:26:38.230
actually looks like I got a wrong IP,

559
00:26:38.230 --> 00:26:40.630
I must have a wrong Mac
address all together here.

560
00:26:40.630 --> 00:26:43.110
But you kinda see the steps along the way,
and

561
00:26:43.110 --> 00:26:45.970
actually spot where that
person's plugged in.

562
00:26:45.970 --> 00:26:48.990
>> Now, that's interesting, because
that brings us back to something that's

563
00:26:48.990 --> 00:26:51.590
theoretical, that once we learn it,
we never use it again.

564
00:26:51.590 --> 00:26:54.785
That OSI model, it looks like you're
jumping between layer three and

565
00:26:54.785 --> 00:26:59.435
layer two there to kind of isolate
the problem down using that OSI model and

566
00:26:59.435 --> 00:27:01.165
the layer three, layer two there.

567
00:27:01.165 --> 00:27:02.295
Is that what's going on here?

568
00:27:02.295 --> 00:27:03.225
>> That's exactly what it is.

569
00:27:03.225 --> 00:27:04.885
Normally trace route is
a layer three thing.

570
00:27:04.885 --> 00:27:07.032
You're seeing the routers in In a path,
but

571
00:27:07.032 --> 00:27:09.822
when we use the Mac protocol
it's actually layer two.

572
00:27:09.822 --> 00:27:14.602
I'm seeing the switches in the path and
it's even using sysco discovery protocol

573
00:27:14.602 --> 00:27:18.465
to find the name of that switch to give
it to me and let me know that connection.

574
00:27:18.465 --> 00:27:20.445
10.1.0.2, that's this switch.

575
00:27:20.445 --> 00:27:25.058
10.1.10.31 that's that other switch and
these are the ports that I would cross.

576
00:27:25.058 --> 00:27:28.411
On this switch GI2/15 go
into the port channel and

577
00:27:28.411 --> 00:27:32.970
then going from the port channel to
FA0/6 to get to that other person.

578
00:27:32.970 --> 00:27:35.640
>> Now that one command that you threw
in there where you had the Mac and

579
00:27:35.640 --> 00:27:38.200
the IP address, and you said,
let it do the work.

580
00:27:38.200 --> 00:27:40.660
Is it just kinda slip
streaming ARP in there and

581
00:27:40.660 --> 00:27:42.360
ARPs the one that's doing the work for
you?

582
00:27:42.360 --> 00:27:42.940
>> Yeah.
>> And you don't have

583
00:27:42.940 --> 00:27:43.680
to do all the leg work?

584
00:27:43.680 --> 00:27:44.520
>> Yeah.

585
00:27:44.520 --> 00:27:46.560
Basically it does the ARP lookup.

586
00:27:46.560 --> 00:27:48.910
Kinda like, you know when we do
a Ping that forces an ARP lookup?

587
00:27:48.910 --> 00:27:51.030
>> Sure.
>> So it does an ARP lookup for us.

588
00:27:51.030 --> 00:27:53.070
>> Gets the MAC addresses and
then populates it in the command.

589
00:27:53.070 --> 00:27:53.970
So it's a lot easier.

590
00:27:53.970 --> 00:27:57.810
Don't feel like you get better results,
but do know that I had to specify a VLAN

591
00:27:57.810 --> 00:28:00.890
on this one and so that's why I had
to go in and use MAC addresses on it.

592
00:28:00.890 --> 00:28:01.560
>> All right.

593
00:28:01.560 --> 00:28:03.390
Very good, very good.

594
00:28:03.390 --> 00:28:04.700
Plenty of good information.

595
00:28:04.700 --> 00:28:07.460
Don, do you got anything
else to add on this?

596
00:28:07.460 --> 00:28:08.220
>> No.
I know it's

597
00:28:08.220 --> 00:28:09.620
something you guys are thinking.

598
00:28:09.620 --> 00:28:14.050
Did we just spend a whole episode talking
about ping and traceroute and debug?

599
00:28:14.050 --> 00:28:15.070
And yes we did.

600
00:28:15.070 --> 00:28:16.800
But the reason I wanted to do this,

601
00:28:16.800 --> 00:28:20.180
is we're going to use those three commands
a ton throughput this whole show.

602
00:28:20.180 --> 00:28:23.710
Usually some of the first commands I go
to to establish the scope of our problem.

603
00:28:23.710 --> 00:28:26.160
And from there we start to
troubleshoot and isolate.

604
00:28:26.160 --> 00:28:28.710
So it's really important that
we understand these three tools,

605
00:28:28.710 --> 00:28:32.250
how we can use them, how they work
as far as troubleshooting some of

606
00:28:32.250 --> 00:28:34.220
the advanced features that
you might not be aware of.

607
00:28:34.220 --> 00:28:36.700
You'll see these again in
the episodes that are coming up.

608
00:28:36.700 --> 00:28:39.450
But for here, that's a pretty good
spot for us to wrap this one up.

609
00:28:39.450 --> 00:28:40.280
>> Very good.
Very good.

610
00:28:40.280 --> 00:28:42.380
Well Don, thanks for that information.

611
00:28:42.380 --> 00:28:45.990
It's been another great
episode here at ITProTv.

612
00:28:45.990 --> 00:28:49.430
We're moving on and Troubleshooting and
Maintaining Cisco IP Networks,

613
00:28:49.430 --> 00:28:51.760
but I think we've come to
the end of our show today.

614
00:28:51.760 --> 00:28:54.740
And until we see you next time,
I'm your host Wes Bryan.

615
00:28:54.740 --> 00:28:55.450
>> And I'm Don Paset.

616
00:28:55.450 --> 00:28:56.400
And we'll see you next time.

617
00:28:56.400 --> 00:29:03.919
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Don and Wes continue their discussion on troubleshooting tools. They introduce using packet sniffers to capture data on the network and how to interpret that data with a tool called a protocol analyzer. They show you how to use the Switch Port Analyzer also known as SPAN. They talk about duplicating data across two ports for the purpose of capturing and analyzing that data through port mirroring.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Tools Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:10.025
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.808 --> 00:00:15.600
All right, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITPro TV.

3
00:00:15.600 --> 00:00:19.460
Your time is valuable and we're glad
that you're going to take that time and

4
00:00:19.460 --> 00:00:20.610
spend it with us.

5
00:00:20.610 --> 00:00:25.620
We're continuing on in CCMP routing and
switching, Tshoot and

6
00:00:25.620 --> 00:00:29.880
today we're gonna be continuing with
part two of IOS troubleshooting tools.

7
00:00:29.880 --> 00:00:33.970
And I've got none other than Mr.
Don Pezet here to take us on this journey.

8
00:00:33.970 --> 00:00:35.190
Don, how you doing today sir?

9
00:00:35.190 --> 00:00:38.880
>> I am doing great Wes and
ready to continue our exploration of

10
00:00:38.880 --> 00:00:42.230
the troubleshooting tools available
inside of Cisco routers and switches.

11
00:00:42.230 --> 00:00:46.170
And actually this episode,
I wanna kind of move away from that.

12
00:00:46.170 --> 00:00:49.826
In our first episode,
we saw ping and trace routing and

13
00:00:49.826 --> 00:00:53.550
mind-boggling tools that
are just amazingly complex right.

14
00:00:53.550 --> 00:00:55.010
Basic stuff.

15
00:00:55.010 --> 00:00:56.890
Things that are built into the iOS.

16
00:00:56.890 --> 00:01:00.530
But sometimes there's stuff we need
that's not available in the iOS, or

17
00:01:00.530 --> 00:01:02.470
it is available but
it's very limited, right?

18
00:01:03.470 --> 00:01:08.490
In the last episode I showed you
guys the debug IP packets command.

19
00:01:08.490 --> 00:01:11.530
And what it did was it let
me see some of the IP,

20
00:01:11.530 --> 00:01:15.090
well packets that are passing
through a router or a switch.

21
00:01:15.090 --> 00:01:17.870
And if you do debug IP package detail,

22
00:01:17.870 --> 00:01:19.850
you actually see a little
bit more there too, right?

23
00:01:19.850 --> 00:01:22.570
And I could see the source port and
destination port.

24
00:01:22.570 --> 00:01:27.260
But, there are times where we need
to see even more than that, right?

25
00:01:27.260 --> 00:01:30.620
Where maybe we even need to see
the payload of the packets.

26
00:01:30.620 --> 00:01:33.700
And then a great example of this would
be if you've got a VPN in place.

27
00:01:33.700 --> 00:01:34.940
I run into this all the time.

28
00:01:34.940 --> 00:01:37.990
You put in a VPN, you configure it,
you get it in place.

29
00:01:37.990 --> 00:01:38.845
Is it actually working?

30
00:01:38.845 --> 00:01:40.582
Or an IPsec.

31
00:01:40.582 --> 00:01:45.200
An IPsec's even better because with IPsec,
it's completely transparent to the end

32
00:01:45.200 --> 00:01:48.420
user, so do they know if
it's encrypting data or not?

33
00:01:48.420 --> 00:01:50.740
Well, if it's working,
they should know, right?

34
00:01:50.740 --> 00:01:53.684
So we need a way to verify the data
is actually being encrypted and

35
00:01:53.684 --> 00:01:55.155
debut IP packets won't tell us that.

36
00:01:55.155 --> 00:01:56.190
It'll tell us a port number.

37
00:01:56.190 --> 00:01:57.140
That's good.

38
00:01:57.140 --> 00:01:59.320
But I don't know if my data's
truly being encrypted.

39
00:01:59.320 --> 00:02:03.460
So, we can use other software to be able

40
00:02:03.460 --> 00:02:08.060
to intercept that traffic on the network,
and actually have a good look at it.

41
00:02:08.060 --> 00:02:10.180
And as a trouble shooting tool,
it can be really valuable.

42
00:02:10.180 --> 00:02:11.090
It can be really useful for

43
00:02:11.090 --> 00:02:16.290
us to make sure that we locate where
the actual source of a problem is.

44
00:02:16.290 --> 00:02:20.880
And just another example might be,
let's see,

45
00:02:20.880 --> 00:02:24.440
well you know, Wes, you and I we used to
work together at a different building.

46
00:02:24.440 --> 00:02:27.670
And at this other location
we had a lot of students,

47
00:02:27.670 --> 00:02:29.480
people that would come into the building.

48
00:02:29.480 --> 00:02:33.630
And occasionally somebody
would be browsing websites and

49
00:02:33.630 --> 00:02:34.470
not supposed to go to.

50
00:02:34.470 --> 00:02:36.150
Right?
>> Sure. Sure. >> They'd get a machine and

51
00:02:36.150 --> 00:02:37.900
it would get infected.
It'd get a virus and

52
00:02:37.900 --> 00:02:40.480
it would just start spamming
the network with junk.

53
00:02:40.480 --> 00:02:42.530
Right?
Trying to infect other machines and so

54
00:02:42.530 --> 00:02:44.950
we'd get reports hey the network is slow.

55
00:02:44.950 --> 00:02:47.540
Alright well I can see there's
a lot of traffic on the network.

56
00:02:47.540 --> 00:02:49.230
Where's it coming from right?

57
00:02:49.230 --> 00:02:52.090
Who's generating all that traffic?

58
00:02:52.090 --> 00:02:55.560
Well there's not really a great way
to see that in most Cisco equipment.

00:15:05.140 --> 00:15:11.000

00:15:13.060 --> 00:15:16.070
And if I go and reassemble that stream,

00:15:16.070 --> 00:15:20.190

334
00:15:20.190 --> 00:15:22.570
I wanna get a copy of that webpage and

I gave them information

Whether I've got a cookie set, and so on.

All of this stuff we pass

It's all in the background, right?

00:15:37.430 --> 00:15:41.580
I asked for a simple unencrypted page And

00:15:42.590 --> 00:15:44.090
And then it responded.

00:15:44.090 --> 00:15:46.392
Okay here, we'll give you the response.

00:15:46.392 --> 00:15:50.109
And this is kind of neat because on

00:15:50.109 --> 00:15:54.273
firewall.And so, this is the web

00:15:54.273 --> 00:15:57.761

00:15:57.761 --> 00:16:00.552
I can see that get request

00:16:02.370 --> 00:16:06.810
So all of that stuff is being kinda

351
00:16:06.810 --> 00:16:11.433
And if I look at that stream up here, so
I'm looking at the TCP stream as a whole,

352
00:16:11.433 --> 00:16:15.031
you'll see that it actually took
several packets to do that.

353
00:16:15.031 --> 00:16:17.740
Here is the original SYN, right?

354
00:16:17.740 --> 00:16:19.770
Remember with a TCP connection
you do a handshake.

355
00:16:19.770 --> 00:16:23.254
You do a sync,
the other side does an acknowledgement and

356
00:16:23.254 --> 00:16:24.643
a sync to you and so on.

357
00:16:24.643 --> 00:16:25.863
So, I see that right next.

358
00:16:25.863 --> 00:16:30.719
First, I have the SYN, the
synchronization, then I have a SYN ACK.

359
00:16:30.719 --> 00:16:35.370
The other side sent an acknowledgement
to me and a sync to me.

360
00:16:35.370 --> 00:16:36.980
And then I acknowledged their sync.

361
00:16:36.980 --> 00:16:40.110
That's the three way TCP handshake
just happened right there.

362
00:16:40.110 --> 00:16:43.950
And then I said, okay now that we've done
that, can I get a copy of this webpage?

363
00:16:43.950 --> 00:16:47.450
And then the other side said,
okay, I acknowledge your request.

364
00:16:47.450 --> 00:16:48.390
Here's the copy of the webpage.

365
00:16:48.390 --> 00:16:51.580
And then I send an acknowledgment
saying I got it.

366
00:16:51.580 --> 00:16:54.250
There's that whole
communication right there.

367
00:16:54.250 --> 00:16:56.270
And I can read it and
see it, so if somebody says,

368
00:16:56.270 --> 00:16:59.460
I can't get to the web server and

00:16:59.460 --> 00:17:01.440

Well, I could intercept the communication,

371
00:17:03.660 --> 00:17:07.770
see if there's a breakdown somewhere in

372
00:17:07.770 --> 00:17:11.445
>> Yeah, you know that's interesting that
you say that now it makes me want to get

373
00:17:11.445 --> 00:17:14.284
the tin hat out, you know,
the tinfoil hat and put that on and

375
00:17:15.971 --> 00:17:17.900
But boy you definitely have to

00:17:17.900 --> 00:17:19.320
if you don't want anybody seeing anything.

377
00:17:19.320 --> 00:17:19.991
>> Yeah.

378
00:17:19.991 --> 00:17:23.406
Now let's talk about something really
important with these sniffers and

379
00:17:23.406 --> 00:17:24.820
protocol analyzers.

380
00:17:24.820 --> 00:17:29.290
When I start capturing traffic, you guys
might notice a pattern to the traffic.

381
00:17:29.290 --> 00:17:30.620
If I'm capturing the data,

382
00:17:30.620 --> 00:17:33.610
let me get rid of this filter,
I'm seeing a lot of communications.

383
00:17:33.610 --> 00:17:38.710
I'm seeing communications that aren't from
me like 10.1.230.5 right there, all right.

384
00:17:38.710 --> 00:17:41.578
My laptop is 10.1.230.21.

385
00:17:41.578 --> 00:17:46.370
I'm seeing 10.1.230.5, so I must be
seeing all the traffic out there, right?

386
00:17:46.370 --> 00:17:47.560
Well, no.

387
00:17:47.560 --> 00:17:51.430
When you run a sniffer,
you are only going to see traffic to and

388
00:17:51.430 --> 00:17:55.650
from your device, and broadcasts.

389
00:17:55.650 --> 00:17:58.430
And the reason that is, is because
we plug into switches these days.

390
00:17:58.430 --> 00:17:59.400
If you have a hub, it's different.

391
00:17:59.400 --> 00:18:03.940
But on a switch, a switch will see unicast
traffic and direct it to the right port,

392
00:18:03.940 --> 00:18:05.940
according to a destination MAC address.

393
00:18:05.940 --> 00:18:10.350
And when somebody like 10.1.230.5
goes to talk to another computer,

394
00:18:10.350 --> 00:18:12.210
it's not talking to my MAC address.

395
00:18:12.210 --> 00:18:16.220
So the traffic never makes it to
my port and I don't see it, right.

396
00:18:16.220 --> 00:18:21.081
So whenever I see a different IP here
in the list, the destination address?

397
00:18:21.081 --> 00:18:24.921
I can see broadcast, or 10.1.230.255.

398
00:18:24.921 --> 00:18:26.390
These are broadcast.

399
00:18:26.390 --> 00:18:31.280
I'm only seeing unicast to and
from me, and broadcast.

400
00:18:31.280 --> 00:18:34.345
So, if I want to want to see everything,

401
00:18:34.345 --> 00:18:37.135
this is where I've got to rely
on another troubleshooting tool.

402
00:18:37.135 --> 00:18:40.115
We have the switch port analyzer.

403
00:18:40.115 --> 00:18:41.195
On a Cisco switch,

404
00:18:41.195 --> 00:18:45.650
you've got a span which allows you to
mirror the traffic of one port to another.

405
00:18:46.690 --> 00:18:49.030
So, for example, Wes, your laptop.

406
00:18:49.030 --> 00:18:51.001
>> Yeah.
>> Do you know what your IP is?

407
00:18:51.001 --> 00:18:55.330
>> I think it is 10.1.239, or,

408
00:18:55.330 --> 00:18:59.750
excuse me, I'm sorry, 10.1-
>> .230.195 I

409
00:18:59.750 --> 00:19:00.510
think is-
>> I think

410
00:19:00.510 --> 00:19:01.490
it's 195-
>> Okay.

411
00:19:01.490 --> 00:19:02.050
>> Yeah.

412
00:19:02.050 --> 00:19:04.487
All right.
So Wes is basically a,

413
00:19:04.487 --> 00:19:10.521
I'm gonna say IP source=10.1.230.195.

414
00:19:10.521 --> 00:19:11.320
>> That's it, yep.

415
00:19:11.320 --> 00:19:15.150
>> So I'm now filtering for
traffic that he's generating.

416
00:19:15.150 --> 00:19:19.661
And I'm gonna see the traffic that
Wes is generating on his system.

417
00:19:19.661 --> 00:19:23.022
Now if I look at it,
I see some traffic here from Wes

418
00:19:23.022 --> 00:19:27.361
at 10.1.230.195 to 10.1.230.128.

419
00:19:27.361 --> 00:19:28.521
Well that's not me.

00:19:28.521 --> 00:19:29.280
Well, actually it is.

00:19:29.280 --> 00:19:31.560
That's my Windows virtual
machine sitting over here.

422
00:19:31.560 --> 00:19:34.220
So Wes has a little traffic going
to my Windows virtual machine.

423
00:19:34.220 --> 00:19:38.210
But after that,
I see Wes sending out some multicasts.

424
00:19:38.210 --> 00:19:42.220
I see some other communications that are,
again, him talking to my virtual machine.

425
00:19:42.220 --> 00:19:45.500
But I don't see Wes talking
to anything else, and Wes,

426
00:19:45.500 --> 00:19:47.830
I can see you browse out to
the Internet and stuff, so.

427
00:19:47.830 --> 00:19:50.130
>> Oh, yeah.
>> He's browsed out to the Internet and

428
00:19:50.130 --> 00:19:51.680
I'm not seeing that traffic.

429
00:19:51.680 --> 00:19:56.630
Because the switch is not directing him
through my port, I can't see his data.

430
00:19:56.630 --> 00:19:59.030
So if I wanna see his information,

431
00:19:59.030 --> 00:20:03.300
I need to do something like
using a switch port analyzer.

432
00:20:03.300 --> 00:20:05.490
And I just kicked myself
out of the console.

433
00:20:05.490 --> 00:20:07.750
And I'm gonna get in here and
get that set up.

434
00:20:07.750 --> 00:20:11.950
So I'm plugged into port one on this
switch, and Wes is plugged into port two.

435
00:20:11.950 --> 00:20:14.050
And so what I'm gonna do is I'm
just gonna come in here and

436
00:20:14.050 --> 00:20:18.600
tell it to take traffic on port two and
mirror it to my port so I get a copy.

437
00:20:18.600 --> 00:20:21.950
And we do that by saying monitor session,
and we give it a number,

438
00:20:21.950 --> 00:20:23.110
I'll say monitor session 1.

439
00:20:23.110 --> 00:20:30.960
And then I'll do source interface gi1/0/2,
that's the port he's on.

440
00:20:30.960 --> 00:20:34.906
And then I'll come back in here and
I'll just say the destination

441
00:20:34.906 --> 00:20:39.165
interface is gi1/0/1.

442
00:20:39.165 --> 00:20:43.050
I'm gonna take a copy of all
the traffic it generates and

443
00:20:43.050 --> 00:20:45.430
send it to the port that I'm
plugged in on, all right.

444
00:20:45.430 --> 00:20:50.850
And so now if Wes starts doing something
like, Wes can you browse to CNN or

445
00:20:50.850 --> 00:20:55.180
any website that's out there, or
my test page or whatever you want.

446
00:20:55.180 --> 00:20:59.350
Now as he starts to browse out, I'm gonna
start seeing unicast, oh there it goes,

447
00:20:59.350 --> 00:21:01.130
let me stop this because it's getting,
gonna be a lot.

448
00:21:01.130 --> 00:21:03.890
There, I can see him browsing out,
and here's his IP and

449
00:21:03.890 --> 00:21:06.280
he's talking to someone
completely different, right.

450
00:21:06.280 --> 00:21:08.990
That's really important if
you're going to use a sniffer or

451
00:21:08.990 --> 00:21:13.420
a protocol analyzer you really need
to be using SPAN also to capture

452
00:21:13.420 --> 00:21:14.980
the port that has the data you want.

453
00:21:14.980 --> 00:21:17.820
If you want to see the whole picture,
all right.

454
00:21:17.820 --> 00:21:19.670
We talked about this
a lot in the switch show.

455
00:21:19.670 --> 00:21:21.260
If you haven't watched

456
00:21:21.260 --> 00:21:23.980
We did a whole episode on SPAN and RSPAN.

00:21:23.980 --> 00:21:28.010
Here I'm highlighting more of the sniffer
and protocol analyzer than I am the SPAN

458
00:21:28.010 --> 00:21:31.250
side of things, but it is an important
tool to be able to capture data.

459
00:21:31.250 --> 00:21:35.420
And we'll see this later on in the show,
too, as we troubleshoot particular areas

460
00:21:35.420 --> 00:21:37.550
where it's pretty handy to
have a sniffer like this.

461
00:21:37.550 --> 00:21:38.170
>> Very good.
So,

462
00:21:38.170 --> 00:21:40.690
we've got our collection agency, right?

463
00:21:40.690 --> 00:21:42.180
We've got the sniffer.

464
00:21:42.180 --> 00:21:45.260
The collection agency by itself,
the sniffer's not really gonna do us much

465
00:21:45.260 --> 00:21:47.670
help unless we have some kind
of way to interpret that data.

466
00:21:47.670 --> 00:21:49.090
So we have the protocol analyzer.

467
00:21:49.090 --> 00:21:52.860
The protocol analyzer is going to
help us actually be able to see and

468
00:21:52.860 --> 00:21:55.220
make some kind of sense of
what that information is.

469
00:21:55.220 --> 00:21:57.490
And then we have that
switchboard analyzer.

00:21:57.490 --> 00:21:58.810
All have to work together.

471
00:21:58.810 --> 00:22:00.110
And if we don't have it together,

472
00:22:00.110 --> 00:22:03.810
it might be a little bit tough to
get the results that you need.

473
00:22:03.810 --> 00:22:05.110
>> Yep, and if you're in a bind and

474
00:22:05.110 --> 00:22:10.120
you just need something really quick,
don't forget debug IP packets detail.

475
00:22:10.120 --> 00:22:13.880
We saw it in the first or second episode
where we were able to run that and

476
00:22:13.880 --> 00:22:17.130
see a lot of the communications,
you don't see the payload, but you are at

477
00:22:17.130 --> 00:22:20.990
least able to see source port, destination
port and that basic information.

478
00:22:20.990 --> 00:22:24.530
And you can log that and get it
recorded and you can filter it, right?

479
00:22:24.530 --> 00:22:25.950
Always use filtering with that command.

480
00:22:25.950 --> 00:22:27.770
If you have a lot of traffic you're
going to flood your session.

481
00:22:27.770 --> 00:22:33.200
So just be aware that that's kind of like
a sniffer, but it's a little more limited.

482
00:22:33.200 --> 00:22:34.030
You don't see that payload.

483
00:22:34.030 --> 00:22:36.140
And then there actually is a way

It is a terrible idea though because

session, so.

00:22:42.175 --> 00:22:43.590

00:22:46.620 --> 00:22:47.830

It's definitely not going to be

00:22:47.830 --> 00:22:49.540

00:22:49.540 --> 00:22:52.230
We're probably going to add

There's plenty of other ones

So there's plenty of other

But if you're just trying to learn and

00:23:22.110 --> 00:23:25.150
you don't have a big budget Wireshark's

00:23:25.150 --> 00:23:27.000

It's kind of funny so,
