508
00:23:29.790 --> 00:23:33.760
A few other things to remember,
the instant I started sniffing that port

509
00:23:33.760 --> 00:23:37.700
error, this instant I configured SPAN,
it shut my port off.

510
00:23:37.700 --> 00:23:40.030
So my laptop can't get out
to the Internet anymore.

511
00:23:40.030 --> 00:23:43.550
I can't browse the network because
I'm now tied up in a SPAN port.

512
00:23:43.550 --> 00:23:47.770
So, it's important that if you
still need your own access,

513
00:23:47.770 --> 00:23:49.570
that you get a second network adapter,
right?

514
00:23:49.570 --> 00:23:52.000
So I've got wireless,
I turned the wireless on on my laptop, and

515
00:23:52.000 --> 00:23:52.990
then I can get out.

516
00:23:52.990 --> 00:23:56.070
But on my physical network adapter
it's now tied up as part of that

517
00:23:56.070 --> 00:23:57.250
monitor session.

518
00:23:57.250 --> 00:24:00.270
And so
I need to remove the monitor session

519
00:24:00.270 --> 00:24:02.770
to free my port back up to
be able to communicate.

520
00:24:02.770 --> 00:24:06.230
So, you may need to keep a console cable
handy, if you've done like I have and

521
00:24:06.230 --> 00:24:10.100
basically cut myself out of the network,
I can hit the console and fix that.

522
00:24:10.100 --> 00:24:13.390
Or go to somebody else's computer and
enter enough to get out there.

523
00:24:13.390 --> 00:24:16.180
There is a command you can use to make it
where you are able to communicate, but

524
00:24:16.180 --> 00:24:18.610
that's a bad idea because it kind
of poisons your sniffer logs.

525
00:24:18.610 --> 00:24:20.651
So you don't normally want to do that.

526
00:24:20.651 --> 00:24:23.760
The other thing is be careful
about bandwidth, right?

527
00:24:23.760 --> 00:24:26.110
I am on a gigabit port.

528
00:24:26.110 --> 00:24:29.110
I'm sniffing a gigabit port,
so we're equal, right?

529
00:24:29.110 --> 00:24:33.270
No matter how much traffic Wes generates,
if he generates up to a gig of traffic,

530
00:24:33.270 --> 00:24:34.380
I can handle that.

531
00:24:34.380 --> 00:24:37.960
But if I'm allowed to talk also,
combined we might exceed a gig.

532
00:24:37.960 --> 00:24:40.200
And that will cause my port to go
into the error disabled state.

533
00:24:40.200 --> 00:24:41.060
And now I can't do anything.

534
00:24:41.060 --> 00:24:43.080
It actually caused your port
to go error disabled too.

535
00:24:43.080 --> 00:24:44.455
So it'll annoy the hell out of you.

536
00:24:44.455 --> 00:24:44.960
>> [LAUGH]
>> And so

537
00:24:44.960 --> 00:24:47.800
if you're trying to do this secretly,
that's not a good idea.

538
00:24:47.800 --> 00:24:50.010
So make sure you've got enough
bandwidth to handle it.

539
00:24:50.010 --> 00:24:53.860
If you have a gig port you want to monitor
and you're plugged in to a 100 meg port,

540
00:24:53.860 --> 00:24:55.246
it's a recipe for disaster.

541
00:24:55.246 --> 00:24:58.666
It'll go into air disable, and you'll
have to clear it out, so not a good time.

542
00:24:58.666 --> 00:25:02.975
>> All right, plenty of good information
here with our iOS troubleshooting tools.

543
00:25:02.975 --> 00:25:06.855
It looks like we're going into a part
three, so come back and join us.

544
00:25:06.855 --> 00:25:09.532
But until then,
I've been you're host Wes Bryan.

545
00:25:09.532 --> 00:25:10.412
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

546
00:25:10.412 --> 00:25:13.312
>> And we'll see you next time.

547
00:25:13.312 --> 00:25:18.592
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Don and Wes continue their discussion on troubleshooting tools. They show you the logging command. They demonstrate how not to be limited with temporary logging and export valuable information to an outside location through the syslog command. They look at automating configuration backups and exporting those backups through the archive command. They will also demonstrate how to restore those configurations.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Tools Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.403 --> 00:00:16.360
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.360 --> 00:00:18.210
We know your time's valuable out there, so

4
00:00:18.210 --> 00:00:20.440
we're glad that you're
cashing it in with us.

5
00:00:20.440 --> 00:00:24.270
And we're continuing on in
iOS troubleshooting tools and

6
00:00:24.270 --> 00:00:28.650
who better to help demonstrate these
tools than none other than Don Pezet.

7
00:00:28.650 --> 00:00:29.630
How are we doing today, Don?

8
00:00:29.630 --> 00:00:34.140
>> I am doing great Wes, ready to continue
our iOS troubleshooting tools adventure.

9
00:00:34.140 --> 00:00:35.520
I know we've covered
a lot of good stuff so

10
00:00:35.520 --> 00:00:38.050
far but we've got some other neat
things we're gonna deal with today.

11
00:00:38.050 --> 00:00:41.270
Mostly, the fact that there's a lot of
good information on our routers and

12
00:00:41.270 --> 00:00:42.100
switches.

13
00:00:42.100 --> 00:00:43.720
And sometimes,
we need to get it off of there,

14
00:00:43.720 --> 00:00:47.640
get it somewhere else that we can use it
in a more centralized store type location.

15
00:00:47.640 --> 00:00:50.040
So we'll get a chance,
see a few of those different things,

16
00:00:50.040 --> 00:00:53.770
we move through and continue to work
with our troubleshooting tools.

17
00:00:53.770 --> 00:00:58.020
Now, the one I want to start off
with today are our log files, right.

18
00:00:58.020 --> 00:01:01.910
Every Cisco router and
every Cisco switch generates log files.

19
00:01:01.910 --> 00:01:03.350
And I shouldn't say it that way.

20
00:01:03.350 --> 00:01:05.320
They generate log messages.

21
00:01:05.320 --> 00:01:07.480
And the log messages can be
stored in different places.

22
00:01:07.480 --> 00:01:09.590
It might be a file, it might not, right.

23
00:01:09.590 --> 00:01:13.148
So, they're gonna generate log files
that keep a record of what's happened.

24
00:01:13.148 --> 00:01:16.700
And we troubleshoot the log files
on one of those troubleshooting

25
00:01:16.700 --> 00:01:18.430
tools that we want to make use of.

26
00:01:18.430 --> 00:01:21.490
We wanna jump in and find out
what's going on from the routers or

27
00:01:21.490 --> 00:01:22.390
switches perspective.

28
00:01:22.390 --> 00:01:23.181
And they let us do that.

29
00:01:23.181 --> 00:01:26.817
>> All right, Don,
now you mentioned logs and storage logs.

30
00:01:26.817 --> 00:01:30.030
Now, when it comes to these logs and all
this information, where can we find that?

31
00:01:30.030 --> 00:01:31.910
Where is that information stored?

32
00:01:31.910 --> 00:01:33.661
>> Well, it kinda depends on the device.

33
00:01:33.661 --> 00:01:35.640
But it's supposed to be stored in RAM,
right?

34
00:01:35.640 --> 00:01:39.090
So when your router, your switch generates
these log messages, it sticks in RAM and

35
00:01:39.090 --> 00:01:40.650
that's kinda where it sits.

36
00:01:40.650 --> 00:01:43.590
But there's some devices where it doesn't
store it anywhere, some devices actually

37
00:01:43.590 --> 00:01:46.650
don't save their logs and
they only display it on the console.

38
00:01:46.650 --> 00:01:51.660
So if you happen to be plugged in to the
console at that time, you see the message.

39
00:01:51.660 --> 00:01:53.810
Otherwise, it disappears and that's it.

40
00:01:53.810 --> 00:01:57.840
All right, so one of the first commands
that I usually issue on a new device is

41
00:01:57.840 --> 00:01:59.700
the logging buffered command.

42
00:01:59.700 --> 00:02:02.700
Let me just show you here
on this switch that I'm on.

43
00:02:02.700 --> 00:02:05.217
So if I jump into config,
I can run logging buffered, all right.

44
00:02:05.217 --> 00:02:07.460
And what does that mean?

45
00:02:07.460 --> 00:02:10.861
That means whenever it generates
a log message, stick into RAM.

46
00:02:10.861 --> 00:02:16.130
And so now, when I do a show logging,
I can see my log messages.

47
00:02:16.130 --> 00:02:19.390
And if you ever hit your Space bar here
and you get absolutely nothing back,

48
00:02:19.390 --> 00:02:20.380
that means it's not logging.

49
00:02:20.380 --> 00:02:22.990
But if you hit your Space bar and
you start seeing messages like this,

50
00:02:22.990 --> 00:02:25.800
then it's been logging to RAM and
that's great, right?

51
00:02:25.800 --> 00:02:28.560
We've got all the information right
here and that's a wonderful things for

52
00:02:28.560 --> 00:02:32.430
troubleshooting until
you reboot the device.

53
00:02:32.430 --> 00:02:35.750
Because what happens when we reboot
the device, RAM gets erased and

54
00:02:35.750 --> 00:02:37.130
these logs are now gone.

55
00:02:37.130 --> 00:02:40.301
And so if you are troubleshooting
something like a device crash,

56
00:02:40.301 --> 00:02:42.330
this becomes really challenging.

57
00:02:42.330 --> 00:02:46.680
And I had just a few years ago, they were,
actually it was this same model of switch,

58
00:02:46.680 --> 00:02:52.240
this 3750, where we had rolled out
just a few of them, about 200 of them.

59
00:02:52.240 --> 00:02:56.250
And I noticed this consistent behavior
where they were locking up every

60
00:02:56.250 --> 00:02:57.390
two weeks.

61
00:02:57.390 --> 00:03:00.480
And I thought it was really odd that
we were just seeing it consistently

62
00:03:00.480 --> 00:03:01.960
across 200 of these switches.

63
00:03:01.960 --> 00:03:03.780
Every one of them locking
up about every two weeks.

64
00:03:03.780 --> 00:03:07.300
Not the same time but
at two week intervals.

65
00:03:07.300 --> 00:03:11.350
And one would lock up and
I couldn't SSH into it.

66
00:03:11.350 --> 00:03:13.220
I couldn't remotely connect to it.

67
00:03:13.220 --> 00:03:17.420
I had to have somebody out of the location
reboot the device and then I could get in.

68
00:03:17.420 --> 00:03:20.510
But once it was rebooted,
the log messages were gone.

69
00:03:20.510 --> 00:03:23.830
I couldn't see what had happened and
then the device would run fine for

70
00:03:23.830 --> 00:03:24.810
two weeks again.

71
00:03:24.810 --> 00:03:25.920
That was a real challenge.

72
00:03:25.920 --> 00:03:29.870
Like, how do we isolate what that problem
is when we lose our information every

73
00:03:29.870 --> 00:03:30.900
time it reboots.

74
00:03:30.900 --> 00:03:34.150
So that's one of the big challenges
we have that it is logging to memory

75
00:03:34.150 --> 00:03:37.970
by default, so a lot of times we
want to take these log files and

76
00:03:37.970 --> 00:03:41.510
send them somewhere else so
they can survive a reboot.

77
00:03:41.510 --> 00:03:46.230
Now you can actually configure it to log
to the internal flash, it's not a great

78
00:03:46.230 --> 00:03:48.920
idea though cuz it does create a bit
performance hit on the system,

79
00:03:48.920 --> 00:03:50.750
writing to flash is not very effective.

80
00:03:50.750 --> 00:03:52.190
And you can fill up your flash.

81
00:03:52.190 --> 00:03:55.872
So normally,
we'd log to an external system.

82
00:03:55.872 --> 00:04:01.560
And syslog is a system that is
widely used throughout computing and

83
00:04:01.560 --> 00:04:02.830
Cisco supports it.

84
00:04:02.830 --> 00:04:05.870
So all of these messages here
are just standard event messages and

85
00:04:05.870 --> 00:04:10.410
we can send them to a syslog server and
have the data get recorded there.

86
00:04:10.410 --> 00:04:12.000
Configuring it is pretty easy.

87
00:04:12.000 --> 00:04:14.760
There's really two steps
to configuring syslog.

88
00:04:14.760 --> 00:04:17.480
The first step is sorting
out our time stamps.

89
00:04:17.480 --> 00:04:18.400
Time stamps are pretty important.

90
00:04:18.400 --> 00:04:21.710
And then the second step is actually
configuring the syslog server itself.

91
00:04:21.710 --> 00:04:24.420
Now the reason I say
the time stamp is important.

92
00:04:24.420 --> 00:04:26.450
When I look at the log files here,

93
00:04:26.450 --> 00:04:30.740
I'm seeing the logs as it
pertains to this switch.

94
00:04:30.740 --> 00:04:35.932
And if I do a show clock, oh,
I've got to go do show clock, there we go,

95
00:04:35.932 --> 00:04:41.062
I can see that this switch thinks
that is February 28th, 1993.

96
00:04:41.062 --> 00:04:42.462
Now obviously that's wrong, right.

97
00:04:42.462 --> 00:04:46.130
I know it's wrong because if I
look at the version of my iOS.

98
00:04:46.130 --> 00:04:49.150
I can see that it was
compiled February 11th, 2015.

99
00:04:49.150 --> 00:04:56.350
So, this was compiled 22 years after the
date that this thing thinks that it is.

100
00:04:56.350 --> 00:04:58.740
So the clock is obviously
wrong on this switch.

101
00:04:58.740 --> 00:04:59.670
Now do I care about that?

102
00:05:00.710 --> 00:05:01.420
Not really.

103
00:05:01.420 --> 00:05:05.820
Not on this one switch, right, because
when I look at the logs I see, all right,

104
00:05:05.820 --> 00:05:10.630
this says it was February 28th
at hours of 8:27 PM, right?

105
00:05:10.630 --> 00:05:12.640
But, what does that mean to me?

106
00:05:12.640 --> 00:05:16.339
Well, in terms of the switch, I can
just do a quick show clock, and I see,

107
00:05:16.339 --> 00:05:20.971
all right, so right now it thinks that
it's 9:01 PM, on February 28th, 1993.

108
00:05:20.971 --> 00:05:23.152
So, this was less than an hour ago.

109
00:05:23.152 --> 00:05:25.605
Or actually, I guess it would be
a little bit more than an hour ago.

110
00:05:25.605 --> 00:05:27.305
So, I can put it into a perspective.

111
00:05:27.305 --> 00:05:29.055
I know when that happened.

112
00:05:29.055 --> 00:05:31.668
But, if I am sending this
to a syslog server and

113
00:05:31.668 --> 00:05:34.554
I have got 200 switches
all sending their data.

114
00:05:34.554 --> 00:05:37.601
And routers and firewalls all sending
their data to the syslog server,

115
00:05:37.601 --> 00:05:40.090
I need to make sure
these times are in sync.

116
00:05:40.090 --> 00:05:42.710
I need to make sure that my clocks
are the same across my systems,

117
00:05:42.710 --> 00:05:44.920
that they're reporting their time zone.

118
00:05:44.920 --> 00:05:49.610
Or that they're using a zero time zone,
like a Zulu time, what is it,

119
00:05:49.610 --> 00:05:50.920
the Greenwich Mean Time.

120
00:05:50.920 --> 00:05:51.961
>> Mean Time, yep.

121
00:05:51.961 --> 00:05:52.821
>> UTC, there we go.

122
00:05:52.821 --> 00:05:53.481
Universal Time Code.

123
00:05:53.481 --> 00:05:54.343
>> Yep, Universal Time Code.

124
00:05:54.343 --> 00:05:56.373
>> So I gotta make sure that they're
using something like that so

125
00:05:56.373 --> 00:05:59.560
I can understand the time stamps
between all the different devices.

126
00:05:59.560 --> 00:06:03.300
So when we configure things like syslog,
one of the first steps that I do is to

127
00:06:03.300 --> 00:06:06.260
make sure that I get these time
stamps straight and in order.

128
00:06:06.260 --> 00:06:08.420
So that's what I'm gonna
do on this system.

129
00:06:08.420 --> 00:06:11.830
The first thing I'm gonna do is I'm gonna
set myself up to use a time server.

130
00:06:11.830 --> 00:06:14.130
Now, you may have a time
server on your network or

131
00:06:14.130 --> 00:06:16.360
you might use a public
one that's out there.

132
00:06:16.360 --> 00:06:18.240
So I'm just gonna use a public one.

133
00:06:18.240 --> 00:06:21.518
So I'll say ntp server and

134
00:06:21.518 --> 00:06:27.631
then you can specify like us.pool.ntp.org.

135
00:06:27.631 --> 00:06:30.800
There's several different
public NTP servers you can use.

136
00:06:30.800 --> 00:06:32.200
You can always build up
your own private one.

137
00:06:32.200 --> 00:06:34.710
We talked about this I think in the route

138
00:06:34.710 --> 00:06:37.440
show we talk about how to set
up a your own time server.

139
00:06:37.440 --> 00:06:39.930
But I'm gonna specify a server like
that and it's gonna reach out.

140
00:06:39.930 --> 00:06:43.210
And, oh shoot,
I don't have a DNS Server defined so

141
00:06:43.210 --> 00:06:46.010
I need to give it a name-server so
it can look that up.

142
00:06:46.010 --> 00:06:49.760
So I'll specify one of those and
let's try that again.

143
00:06:49.760 --> 00:06:53.310
Not looking up, let's drop the us part.

144
00:06:53.310 --> 00:06:54.720
And, well shoot.

145
00:06:54.720 --> 00:06:55.916
You know what,
let me just use an internal one.

146
00:06:55.916 --> 00:06:59.970
So, [LAUGH] sometimes we
just have to go internal.

147
00:06:59.970 --> 00:07:01.196
There we go.
[LAUGH] All right, so

148
00:07:01.196 --> 00:07:04.459
now my system's gonna start reaching
out to this internal server and

149
00:07:04.459 --> 00:07:06.055
getting its time, right?

150
00:07:06.055 --> 00:07:07.475
And so it's gonna synchronize it, and

151
00:07:07.475 --> 00:07:09.595
within the next few moments
that should happen.

152
00:07:09.595 --> 00:07:13.378
And so if I do a show clock, I should
see my time update and sure enough,

153
00:07:13.378 --> 00:07:16.087
it now knows that it's October 22, 2015.

154
00:07:16.087 --> 00:07:18.165
At least I'm in the right decade now.

155
00:07:18.165 --> 00:07:20.377
And it shows the time.

156
00:07:20.377 --> 00:07:25.217
Now the time, see how it's reflecting
10:58 Eastern Daylight Time.

157
00:07:25.217 --> 00:07:27.847
How did it know that this
was Eastern Daylight Time?

158
00:07:27.847 --> 00:07:29.929
Well, you may or
may not already have this in your config.

159
00:07:29.929 --> 00:07:31.907
I do.

160
00:07:31.907 --> 00:07:35.777
If I take a look at my running config,
and I'm just gonna look for

161
00:07:35.777 --> 00:07:37.510
some clock commands that I threw in there.

162
00:07:37.510 --> 00:07:40.780
You'll see where I've
defined a time zone and

163
00:07:40.780 --> 00:07:43.730
I've defined daylight savings time, right.

164
00:07:43.730 --> 00:07:46.413
And we saw those in the route show and
even in the CCNA show, we've seen those,

165
00:07:46.413 --> 00:07:47.522
those have been around a while.

166
00:07:47.522 --> 00:07:50.857
But I've defined them so that my device
would know what time zone it was in.

167
00:07:50.857 --> 00:07:55.660
Now where that creates a problem is if I
have devices in more than one time zone

168
00:07:55.660 --> 00:07:59.637
when you generate log messages,
right, so if I do a show log And

169
00:07:59.637 --> 00:08:01.756
I take a look at what's in there.

170
00:08:01.756 --> 00:08:04.228
It tells me the time zone.

171
00:08:04.228 --> 00:08:09.060
It doesn't tell you the time zone by
default, I told it to do that, all right?

172
00:08:09.060 --> 00:08:11.660
So that when I looked at log
files from more than one device,

173
00:08:11.660 --> 00:08:13.210
I would know what time zone it was in.

174
00:08:13.210 --> 00:08:16.290
Now, you got a few different
choices how you wanna handle that.

175
00:08:16.290 --> 00:08:21.190
If I take a look at my config,
I actually put this line in right here,

176
00:08:21.190 --> 00:08:26.350
service time stamps log, date time.

177
00:08:26.350 --> 00:08:29.230
So right, in my logs I wanna
have the date and time, and

178
00:08:29.230 --> 00:08:31.480
I put to make it the local time.

179
00:08:31.480 --> 00:08:34.020
If I leave that off, it will do UTC.

180
00:08:34.020 --> 00:08:37.290
So you might want UTC, and that is fine,
but I chose to do local time.

181
00:08:37.290 --> 00:08:41.610
And because I did that,
I made sure to add show-timezone, so

182
00:08:41.610 --> 00:08:44.340
that it would include what
the timezone was in the file.

183
00:08:44.340 --> 00:08:46.090
So now when I'm looking
at my syslog server and

184
00:08:46.090 --> 00:08:48.780
I see all these different times,
I can recognize what timezone it's in.

185
00:08:50.000 --> 00:08:53.150
All that being said, it might be
easier just to leave it in UTC.

186
00:08:53.150 --> 00:08:54.010
Then you're taken care of.

187
00:08:54.010 --> 00:08:57.460
But at this point, now my log files,
like if I get out of config,

188
00:08:57.460 --> 00:09:00.780
that's gonna generate a log message,
and I'm SSHT so I'm not gonna see it.

189
00:09:00.780 --> 00:09:02.300
Let me do a little terminal monitor.

190
00:09:02.300 --> 00:09:05.200
I guess it's already too late here but
if I do a show log and

191
00:09:05.200 --> 00:09:09.590
I get to the end here's the logs that
were on my system from before and

192
00:09:09.590 --> 00:09:12.430
now that my clock is right,
I can see this guy.

193
00:09:12.430 --> 00:09:14.240
It's got the right time
zone Eastern Time Zone.

194
00:09:14.240 --> 00:09:16.480
It's got the right date and time.

195

I can also adjust the maximum.

420
00:20:26.340 --> 00:20:27.620
Remember I said I had a maximum of 10?

421
00:20:27.620 --> 00:20:31.050
You'll see that I can adjust this one
to as few as one or as many as 14.

422
00:20:31.050 --> 00:20:33.720
So I can kind of tweak that,
and put it in place.

423
00:20:33.720 --> 00:20:37.410
I'm just gonna leave it at the default,
which is ten.

424
00:20:37.410 --> 00:20:41.660
And then lastly, I can do a log.

425
00:20:41.660 --> 00:20:44.150
Log changes to the running configuration.

426
00:20:44.150 --> 00:20:46.400
When somebody makes a change
to the running configuration,

427
00:20:46.400 --> 00:20:49.920
we generate a log message for that, and
I wanna log anytime that that happens.

428
00:20:49.920 --> 00:20:53.260
When this goes to save and there's
a change, I wanna generate a log message.

429
00:20:53.260 --> 00:20:54.900
If it's saying there's not a change,

430
00:20:54.900 --> 00:20:56.600
then I'm not going to bother
with the log message.

431
00:20:56.600 --> 00:20:59.173
So I'll just say logconfig.

432
00:20:59.173 --> 00:21:01.940
And in the logconfig you have
a lot of different options.

433
00:21:01.940 --> 00:21:03.940
You can set up notifications and stuff.

434
00:21:03.940 --> 00:21:07.040
I'm going to talk about those when we get
into the embedded event manager which is

435
00:21:07.040 --> 00:21:08.420
in another episode.

436
00:21:08.420 --> 00:21:13.760
But for now that's pretty much
the archive and if I do a show run and

437
00:21:13.760 --> 00:21:17.300
I look for that command,
you'll see it's kind of nested them and

438
00:21:17.300 --> 00:21:20.650
some of the commands that I ran might have
disappeared because they're defaults but

439
00:21:20.650 --> 00:21:24.820
here's the path I defined, I told it to
write memory and there's that time period.

440
00:21:24.820 --> 00:21:29.360
Now once a minute, it's gonna back
up my config to that FTP server and

441
00:21:29.360 --> 00:21:33.090
that's should be happening all ready
if I browse to my file system, and

442
00:21:33.090 --> 00:21:37.180
take a look at where my FTP
server is storing data.

443
00:21:37.180 --> 00:21:38.360
Here we go.

444
00:21:38.360 --> 00:21:40.450
I've already got some backups.

445
00:21:40.450 --> 00:21:45.470
And see how I've got gnv-3750-config,
that's the name I put in.

446
00:21:45.470 --> 00:21:51.119
And then it's got OCT22-11-11-13 EDT-0-1.

447
00:21:51.119 --> 00:21:52.211
Oh, I guess it starts at -0.

448
00:21:52.211 --> 00:21:53.330
I said it started at -1.

449
00:21:53.330 --> 00:21:57.780
But it's got those little number
there to indicate what time and

450
00:21:57.780 --> 00:22:00.210
what increment this back up is.

451
00:22:00.210 --> 00:22:03.650
So it's backing it up for me and
it's storing it right there.

452
00:22:03.650 --> 00:22:07.080
If I ever need to see the back up,
well these are just text files.

453
00:22:07.080 --> 00:22:12.140
We can open them in WordPad or
whatever text editor's your favorite.

454
00:22:12.140 --> 00:22:14.440
Let me just fire it up
here again in Wordpad.

455
00:22:14.440 --> 00:22:16.190
Did I click on Wordpad?

456
00:22:16.190 --> 00:22:19.605
Apparently using a mouse is
beyond my technical skills.

457
00:22:19.605 --> 00:22:21.670
>> [LAUGH]
>> But it's all open, there we go, and

458
00:22:21.670 --> 00:22:24.330
now I can just read the config
it's all right there.

459
00:22:24.330 --> 00:22:28.310
And once a minute it's gonna take
a backup and store that config.

460
00:22:28.310 --> 00:22:31.550
In fact you can see it just made another
one now I've got -2 and it's gonna

461
00:22:31.550 --> 00:22:35.260
keep incriminating through that as
the time goes on I've got a great back up.

462
00:22:35.260 --> 00:22:39.430
Now restoring the back-up,
let's talk about that.

463
00:22:39.430 --> 00:22:44.120
If something is wrong on the switch and I
know it was fine yesterday but today it's

464
00:22:44.120 --> 00:22:48.150
hosed, I might just wanna restore the back
up form yesterday and put in in place.

465
00:22:48.150 --> 00:22:53.270
Now if you use the copy command and you
copy whatever you had in the beginning and

466
00:22:53.270 --> 00:22:56.810
you copy it to running-start
it does a merge.

467
00:22:56.810 --> 00:23:00.020
So anybody's additional changes they've
added they'll still be there after

468
00:23:00.020 --> 00:23:02.310
the merge and
that can be a bit of a problem.

469
00:23:02.310 --> 00:23:04.609
Merging configs it leads
to all sorts of stuff.

470
00:23:05.610 --> 00:23:08.670
So we can actually do
a replace if we want and

471
00:23:08.670 --> 00:23:11.300
say we don't want to merge what we've got.

472
00:23:11.300 --> 00:23:14.870
We want to get this
exactly put back in place.

473
00:23:14.870 --> 00:23:17.060
And you can use the archive
command to do that also.

474
00:23:17.060 --> 00:23:21.280
It's actually a little bit different
because we use a command called configure.

475
00:23:21.280 --> 00:23:23.790
Now when I say configure,
what do I normally do?

476
00:23:23.790 --> 00:23:27.350
I normally say configure terminal or
comp t or

477
00:23:27.350 --> 00:23:29.810
whatever to get into my configuration.

478
00:23:29.810 --> 00:23:33.200
But the configure command actually
has a lot of other options and

479
00:23:33.200 --> 00:23:37.130
you'll notice that one of
the options is configure replace.

480
00:23:37.130 --> 00:23:40.490
We can replace the running
config with a new config file.

481
00:23:40.490 --> 00:23:42.320
And that's exactly what I want.

482
00:23:42.320 --> 00:23:45.800
Because, whoops, because normally
the only way to do that is to

483
00:23:45.800 --> 00:23:48.310
copy it to the start up config and
then reboot.

484
00:23:48.310 --> 00:23:50.280
Well I don't want to reboot.

485
00:23:50.280 --> 00:23:52.500
I want to get in and and replace.

486
00:23:52.500 --> 00:23:53.237
Let me show you guys an example.

487
00:23:53.237 --> 00:23:57.824
If I, if I go into my config and
I create a new interface,

488
00:23:57.824 --> 00:24:00.378
right, if I do a vlan 2 Right.

489
00:24:00.378 --> 00:24:01.538
There we go.

490
00:24:01.538 --> 00:24:03.005
So I just created a new interface,

491
00:24:03.005 --> 00:24:05.480
an interface that didn't
exist a few moments ago.

492
00:24:05.480 --> 00:24:07.240
Or even like a loopback.

493
00:24:08.300 --> 00:24:11.870
So I might whip something up like that,
just to have it.

494
00:24:11.870 --> 00:24:16.080
Because who knows when you might
need a loopback interface.

495
00:24:16.080 --> 00:24:18.680
When I go and
restore a config, from backup,

496
00:24:18.680 --> 00:24:21.010
if I'm just doing copies, it'll merge.

497
00:24:21.010 --> 00:24:26.100
It'll fix my other interfaces, but
these new interfaces will still be there.

498
00:24:26.100 --> 00:24:29.240
So that is something that would
be left behind in a merge,

499
00:24:29.240 --> 00:24:34.400
this loop back that I just made, but
if I do a replace it's a different story.

500
00:24:34.400 --> 00:24:37.660
So I can say configure replace, and

501
00:24:37.660 --> 00:24:41.480
I can point to the ftp server and
the file I want to replace it with.

502
00:24:41.480 --> 00:24:44.030
Well I've already forgotten the file name,
so I'm going to go and

503
00:24:44.030 --> 00:24:45.170
copy and paste that.

504
00:24:45.170 --> 00:24:49.750
Cuz I just don't have the memory
to handle that apparently.

505
00:24:49.750 --> 00:24:51.900
Let me see if I can find that here.

506
00:24:51.900 --> 00:24:52.720
I'll restore.

507
00:24:52.720 --> 00:24:55.490
Let me just go back a few
here to one from before.

508
00:24:55.490 --> 00:24:59.509
So I'll just copy this file name and
paste that in there.

509
00:25:00.850 --> 00:25:03.670
There we go, and we'll run that, and

510
00:25:03.670 --> 00:25:05.410
now it's going to tell me
it's going to do a replace.

511
00:25:05.410 --> 00:25:08.770
Which is gonna basically wipe that
running config and bring this in, and

512
00:25:08.770 --> 00:25:12.432
I'll say yes go ahead do it and
there it goes.

513
00:25:12.432 --> 00:25:15.690
It's gonna replace the running config
with what I just brought in, so

514
00:25:15.690 --> 00:25:18.990
see how it says roll back
acquired configuration lock.

515
00:25:18.990 --> 00:25:21.850
It locked the config,
it's applying it, and

516
00:25:21.850 --> 00:25:25.260
see how my loop back zero just went down,
right?

517
00:25:25.260 --> 00:25:27.230
It's killing that interface.

518
00:25:27.230 --> 00:25:29.550
And now when it's done,

519
00:25:29.550 --> 00:25:34.330
if I run that show IP interface brief
again, loop back zero is gone, right?

520
00:25:34.330 --> 00:25:37.820
So, it didn't merge like
a copy would normally do.

521
00:25:37.820 --> 00:25:42.220
It replaced, and so that command
again was configure replace and

522
00:25:42.220 --> 00:25:43.560
then the path to a night.

523
00:25:43.560 --> 00:25:45.790
I did FTP,
you can do whatever yours happened to be,

524
00:25:45.790 --> 00:25:47.110
and that brings it back in.

525
00:25:47.110 --> 00:25:50.580
So if a switch is acting up, we might not
need to troubleshoot too much at all.

526
00:25:50.580 --> 00:25:53.050
We just restore a backup,
and you're in business.

527
00:25:53.050 --> 00:25:55.440
These are neat features that
are built into the switches,

528
00:25:55.440 --> 00:25:58.460
built into the routers, but
they don't work by default.

529
00:25:58.460 --> 00:25:59.480
You've gotta configure, right?

530
00:25:59.480 --> 00:26:02.580
You've gotta set up a syslog server,
you've gotta set up an FTP server to

531
00:26:02.580 --> 00:26:06.250
receive this data, and then you've gotta
tell the switches and routers to use them.

532
00:26:06.250 --> 00:26:09.820
But they are great for troubleshooting
cuz you can see what changed.

533
00:26:09.820 --> 00:26:11.740
What changed between yesterday and today?

534
00:26:11.740 --> 00:26:16.750
Let me compare yesterday's config with
today's config and what's different?

535
00:26:16.750 --> 00:26:19.360
Do the side-by-side configs and
look for what changed.

536
00:26:19.360 --> 00:26:21.850
And now I know what's more
than likely my problem.

537
00:26:21.850 --> 00:26:22.770
>> Very good, very good.

538
00:26:22.770 --> 00:26:24.370
A lot of good information there.

539
00:26:24.370 --> 00:26:26.080
We've talked about backing up logs,

540
00:26:26.080 --> 00:26:28.730
exporting that information
to an external location.

541
00:26:28.730 --> 00:26:33.370
Talked about backing up the configuration,
copying, replacing, and merging.

542
00:26:33.370 --> 00:26:35.880
Don, we're getting to
the end of this episode,

543
00:26:35.880 --> 00:26:39.450
you got anything else that we might need
to know before we wrap up this show?

544
00:26:39.450 --> 00:26:41.560
>> I got a lot of other things
that I want to talk to you,

545
00:26:41.560 --> 00:26:43.750
I know I mentioned net flow
in the last episode and

546
00:26:43.750 --> 00:26:46.010
said we might get to it this time,
we didn't get to it here either.

547
00:26:46.010 --> 00:26:47.990
So definitely stay tuned for
that, we got net flow,

548
00:26:47.990 --> 00:26:51.420
we got SNMPU,
we got all sorts of cool stuff coming up.

549
00:26:51.420 --> 00:26:53.200
>> All right, a lot of good information.

550
00:26:53.200 --> 00:26:57.240
Looks like we got some more information
coming up, in iOS troubleshooting tools,

551
00:26:57.240 --> 00:26:59.800
so stick around because we're
going into a part four.

552
00:26:59.800 --> 00:27:01.420
Thanks, Don, for being here.

553
00:27:01.420 --> 00:27:04.010
But until we see you,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

554
00:27:04.010 --> 00:27:05.577
>> And I'm Don Pezet.
>> And we'll see you next time.

555
00:27:05.577 --> 00:27:12.125
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Don and Wes continue their discussion on troubleshooting tools. They look at a great utility to gather information about devices on the network called SNMP. They demonstrate how to make the OIDs easier to to read through SNMP management software. They discuss how to use NetFlow analyzer to get information about the network.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Tools Part 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.803 --> 00:00:15.241
All right, welcome back to another
exciting episode here at ITPro TV.

3
00:00:15.241 --> 00:00:17.340
Your time is valuable, and

4
00:00:17.340 --> 00:00:20.460
we are glad that you're
spending it here with us today.

5
00:00:20.460 --> 00:00:25.500
Today we're going to be continuing on in
troubleshooting tools in the Cisco iOS and

6
00:00:25.500 --> 00:00:30.600
who better to show us around
the Cisco iOS but Don Pezet.

7
00:00:30.600 --> 00:00:31.311
How you doing today Don?

8
00:00:31.311 --> 00:00:32.750
>> I am doing great Wes.

9
00:00:32.750 --> 00:00:35.938
Ready to jump back into the world
of troubleshooting tools.

10
00:00:35.938 --> 00:00:39.210
You know, where I think we're on part 4
now and we'll probably end up doing 5 or

11
00:00:39.210 --> 00:00:41.830
6 parts of this with all the different
tools that we're gonna be using

12
00:00:41.830 --> 00:00:43.220
throughout the show.

13
00:00:43.220 --> 00:00:46.730
The ones I wanna tackle today are pretty
neat because they're good monitoring tools

14
00:00:46.730 --> 00:00:51.385
and they really help you to do proactive
and not just reactive trouble shooting.

15
00:00:51.385 --> 00:00:53.875
You know a lot of what we do is reactive,
it's all putting out fires,

16
00:00:53.875 --> 00:00:56.315
something breaks and
now we got to go in and fix it.

17
00:00:56.315 --> 00:01:00.871
But there's some tools that will actually
help us to see things before they turn

18
00:01:00.871 --> 00:01:06.125
into a full blown problem and the first
one that I want to start off with is SNMP.

19
00:01:06.125 --> 00:01:11.285
SNMP is the Simple Network Management
Protocol and it's been around a long time,

20
00:01:11.285 --> 00:01:13.210
actually came out of the Unix world and

21
00:01:13.210 --> 00:01:15.710
the majority of networking
gear out there supports it.

22
00:01:15.710 --> 00:01:19.231
Most servers support it,
routers, switches, firewalls.

23
00:01:19.231 --> 00:01:23.791
SNMP lets you monitor just
a ton of different things.

24
00:01:23.791 --> 00:01:25.300
All right.

25
00:01:25.300 --> 00:01:28.382
>> I was gonna say you had talked about,
in the last episode,

26
00:01:28.382 --> 00:01:33.340
you had talked about CIS log and what was
it, the switch packet analyzer I believe?

27
00:01:33.340 --> 00:01:37.730
Now we've got those utilities Don, why
would we use SNMP over those other ones?

28
00:01:37.730 --> 00:01:41.440
>> So, when you talk about, like, span,
for example, right, where you're actually

29
00:01:41.440 --> 00:01:46.540
grabbing raw data off the network and then
you have to interpret it, that raw data is

30
00:01:46.540 --> 00:01:51.630
only useful, really, kind of right then,
you know, it's very real time.

31
00:01:51.630 --> 00:01:55.020
And a lot of the tools that we've talked
about have been just that, real time.

32
00:01:55.020 --> 00:01:57.772
If I use ping,
I need the ping results from right now,

33
00:01:57.772 --> 00:01:59.681
not the ping results from a week ago.

34
00:01:59.681 --> 00:02:02.130
But what if I wanna do trend analysis?

35
00:02:02.130 --> 00:02:05.460
If I wanna see like, all right, people
are saying the network is slow today,

36
00:02:05.460 --> 00:02:07.660
what's my network speed like today,
all right?

37
00:02:07.660 --> 00:02:08.700
What was it like last week?

38
00:02:08.700 --> 00:02:10.731
What was it like the week before and
the week before?

39
00:02:10.731 --> 00:02:12.580
SNMP can do that.

40
00:02:12.580 --> 00:02:15.420
You can gather the data and
store it in a database and render it, and

41
00:02:15.420 --> 00:02:17.300
it'll give you just tons of information,
right?

42
00:02:17.300 --> 00:02:20.100
It's a pretty neat system,
a pretty neat protocol, and

43
00:02:20.100 --> 00:02:22.200
it's pretty easy to configure, right?

44
00:02:22.200 --> 00:02:25.390
Now, we've seen SNMP
configurations in other episodes,

45
00:02:25.390 --> 00:02:28.560
but just to kinda do a quick refresher
here, I'll take this router and

46
00:02:28.560 --> 00:02:30.050
I'll get it configured for SNMPs.

47
00:02:30.050 --> 00:02:35.485
So, on Cisco routers,
they usually don't run SNMP by default.

48
00:02:35.485 --> 00:02:38.405
Switches, firewalls, same thing,
they usually don't run it by default.

49
00:02:38.405 --> 00:02:41.235
We got to get in and turn it on,
and fortunately turning it on

50
00:02:41.235 --> 00:02:43.845
is just a matter of creating
what's called an SNMP community.

51
00:02:43.845 --> 00:02:49.145
So if you run SNMP-server, we can tell it
that we're going to create a server and

52
00:02:49.145 --> 00:02:50.655
that we're going to have a community.

53
00:02:50.655 --> 00:02:53.418
You'll see it's one of those
first options right there.

54
00:02:53.418 --> 00:02:58.510
To go in and create that community,
and I'll call it, we'll do public,

55
00:02:58.510 --> 00:03:03.120
and I'm just gonna make this a read
only community, now what does that mean?

56
00:03:03.120 --> 00:03:08.490
That means that somebody can reach out to
this router and ask it questions via SNMP.

57
00:03:08.490 --> 00:03:11.570
They can say,
hey how many interfaces do you have?

58
00:03:11.570 --> 00:03:13.210
What's the bandwidth of that interface?

59
00:03:13.210 --> 00:03:15.180
What version of iOS are you running?

60
00:03:15.180 --> 00:03:16.570
What, what's this, what's that?

61
00:03:16.570 --> 00:03:20.800
It can ask it information and
SNMP is gonna give it the answer.

62
00:03:20.800 --> 00:03:21.390
Right?

63
00:03:21.390 --> 00:03:24.140
And it can read and that's it.

64
00:03:24.140 --> 00:03:27.720
But you can actually do read-write where
you can push changes like, all right,

65
00:03:27.720 --> 00:03:29.630
tell me about your interface,
what bandwidth does it have?

66
00:03:29.630 --> 00:03:32.504
Okay, I'm going to push a new
bandwidth limit to your interface, and

67
00:03:32.504 --> 00:03:33.537
you can push it via SNMP.

68
00:03:33.537 --> 00:03:34.271
That's pretty advanced.

69
00:03:34.271 --> 00:03:35.452
>> Now what you asked about, CIS log.

70
00:03:35.452 --> 00:03:37.061
>> Mm-hm.

71
00:03:37.061 --> 00:03:40.270
>> With CIS log, we're getting log
messages generated on the router or

72
00:03:40.270 --> 00:03:40.990
switch, and

73
00:03:40.990 --> 00:03:46.420
we're sending them out to a server,
well, SNMP by default, isn't like that.

74
00:03:46.420 --> 00:03:49.850
It's not gonna tell you about a problem,
you have to ask it, right?

75
00:03:49.850 --> 00:03:51.710
It's kind of like when people
have a conversation and

76
00:03:51.710 --> 00:03:57.700
say Wes you didn't tell me that I had
a piece of Kleenex stuck to my face.

77
00:03:57.700 --> 00:03:59.600
And you say, well you didn't ask.

78
00:03:59.600 --> 00:04:01.406
Right?
That's how SNMP is versus CIS

79
00:04:01.406 --> 00:04:03.060
log that would have told me.

80
00:04:03.060 --> 00:04:06.690
Now you can configure what
are called SNMP traps.

81
00:04:06.690 --> 00:04:10.370
And in a SNMP trap is where it starts
to function more like CIS log,

82
00:04:10.370 --> 00:04:14.550
where it says hey this happened, I'm
going to force it and tell you about it.

83
00:04:14.550 --> 00:04:15.150
All right.

84
00:04:15.150 --> 00:04:16.460
But that's not the default.

85
00:04:16.460 --> 00:04:22.190
So, what I've done right here, this one
command that turned on SNMP, it opened

86
00:04:22.190 --> 00:04:25.640
it up for people to be able to ask it
questions if they know the community name,

87
00:04:25.640 --> 00:04:27.515
and I just used the name of public,
you can call it whatever you want,

88
00:04:27.515 --> 00:04:30.970
you can call it Bob, people just
have to know the community name.

89
00:04:30.970 --> 00:04:34.860
They can now start to ask it questions and
it will give us answers.

90
00:04:34.860 --> 00:04:36.790
So, pretty simple to get implemented, but

91
00:04:36.790 --> 00:04:39.140
we'll probably need to tweak it to
get it to work the way that we want.

92
00:04:40.180 --> 00:04:42.940
The biggest challenge
that I have with SNMP is,

93
00:04:42.940 --> 00:04:45.320
it's not terribly easy to use, right?

94
00:04:45.320 --> 00:04:51.210
So, if I have a router or switch or
something that's running SNMP and I wanna

95
00:04:51.210 --> 00:04:55.300
reach out and get some of the information
out of it, well, it's all built upon what

96
00:04:55.300 --> 00:04:59.874
we call OIDs and you can actually use,
like I'm on a mac here and so

97
00:04:59.874 --> 00:05:04.930
there's a command line usually called SNMP
walk, and I'm just gonna use SMNP walk.

98
00:05:04.930 --> 00:05:08.630
And I'm going to reach out to that
router and ask it some information.

99
00:05:08.630 --> 00:05:12.180
Now,I need to tell it what
version of SNMP I'm running and

100
00:05:12.180 --> 00:05:14.010
I didn't actually set that
when we turned it on.

101
00:05:14.010 --> 00:05:16.830
I just did SNMP server and
set a community.

102
00:05:16.830 --> 00:05:17.460
Right?

103
00:05:17.460 --> 00:05:20.750
But you can actually set the version for
your community.

104
00:05:20.750 --> 00:05:25.040
And if I go back here and do like a
question mark you'll see where we can set

105
00:05:25.040 --> 00:05:28.880
other things like the ACL if we wanna
limit who has access and so on.

106
00:05:28.880 --> 00:05:32.110
And you can define what
version you wanna run at too.

107
00:05:32.110 --> 00:05:38.560
Now for me if I'm running in version
2C versus version 3 or whatever,

108
00:05:38.560 --> 00:05:41.400
I'm not really gonna take advantage
of a lot of those other features.

109
00:05:41.400 --> 00:05:42.910
But for some people they will.

110
00:05:42.910 --> 00:05:45.670
If you need to run in version three for
example, you wanna have user names and

111
00:05:45.670 --> 00:05:46.560
passwords, right?

112
00:05:46.560 --> 00:05:49.370
You can switch over to the version
three mode and then knock that out.

113
00:05:49.370 --> 00:05:53.000
In my scenario, though,
I'm not too terribly worried about that.

114
00:05:53.000 --> 00:05:54.950
All right, so I'm gonna reach
out to this other system and

115
00:05:56.260 --> 00:05:58.610
I'm gonna query some of that data.

116
00:05:58.610 --> 00:06:01.970
So, I'm gonna reach out to it,
and I'll do a 2c query on it.

117
00:06:01.970 --> 00:06:05.360
And I'm gonna tell it that
the community is called public, and

118
00:06:05.360 --> 00:06:07.510
then I'm gonna look for some information.

119
00:06:07.510 --> 00:06:13.720
I wanna know what version of
the iOS this router's running.

120
00:06:13.720 --> 00:06:14.340
Okay?

121
00:06:14.340 --> 00:06:17.570
So if I wanna know the version of the iOS
well I need to point at the routers.

122
00:06:17.570 --> 00:06:20.220
So the router's 192.168.0.1.

123
00:06:20.220 --> 00:06:24.550
And then I need to ask it for
the iOS version.

124
00:06:24.550 --> 00:06:25.622
And to do that, I need an OID.

125
00:06:25.622 --> 00:06:31.248
It's an identifier that says, this is
the piece of information that I want,

126
00:06:31.248 --> 00:06:38.030
and the OID for iOS version is
1.3.6.1.4.1.9.9 .25.1.1.1.2.

127
00:06:38.030 --> 00:06:39.700
>> Rolls right off the tongue.

128
00:06:39.700 --> 00:06:44.296
>> Wow I tell you what.

129
00:06:44.296 --> 00:06:46.634
>> This is one of those moments where
if I didn't have it in my show notes,

130
00:06:46.634 --> 00:06:47.836
I wouldn't have known it, right?

131
00:06:47.836 --> 00:06:50.260
OIDs are not easy for us to use.

132
00:06:50.260 --> 00:06:52.880
And when I run that query against it,
here it comes back, and

133
00:06:52.880 --> 00:06:58.240
I can see, hey, I'm running version
15.1 in this iOS right, on this router.

134
00:06:58.240 --> 00:07:00.760
So I got the information
I needed right here.

135
00:07:00.760 --> 00:07:02.420
But it's not very usable is it?

136
00:07:02.420 --> 00:07:04.900
So it's rare that we use SNMP by itself.

137
00:07:04.900 --> 00:07:08.710
We normally use it with third party
monitoring software that can go in and

138
00:07:08.710 --> 00:07:09.540
track that.

139
00:07:09.540 --> 00:07:13.986
Because when it comes to these OIDs,
there's tens of thousands of them,

140
00:07:13.986 --> 00:07:17.941
there are tons of them for
every different aspect of that system.

141
00:07:17.941 --> 00:07:21.145
So, for example if I use software like,
where's my MIB walker,

142
00:07:21.145 --> 00:07:22.907
I've got a MIB walker around here.

143
00:07:22.907 --> 00:07:27.183
Here we go, I'm gonna use this MIB walker
and I'm going to point to that system, and

144
00:07:27.183 --> 00:07:31.090
I'm just going to tell it I'm doing
public and I'll reach out to it.

145
00:07:31.090 --> 00:07:33.290
And I'm going to connect, all right.

146
00:07:33.290 --> 00:07:37.930
Here it goes, it's walking the OID's,
it's basically getting all the information

147
00:07:37.930 --> 00:07:42.440
that's available from SNMP and
it's at 600, and 700.

148
00:07:42.440 --> 00:07:46.890
It's gonna cross 1000 and
then 2000 and then 3000.

149
00:07:46.890 --> 00:07:49.887
It's going to take awhile because
SNMP has a ton of information.

150
00:07:49.887 --> 00:07:52.078
So we're not normally going to
use it by itself like this,

151
00:07:52.078 --> 00:07:53.476
in fact I'm just going to stop this.

152
00:07:53.476 --> 00:07:55.810
Well I'll leave it running
in the background, why not?

153
00:07:55.810 --> 00:07:58.352
But we're gonna use it with third
party software, like this one.

154
00:07:58.352 --> 00:08:01.869
So this is the networking performance
monitor from Solar Winds and

155
00:08:01.869 --> 00:08:05.008
they've already done it for
us, they've already gone and

156
00:08:05.008 --> 00:08:08.990
put all the OIDs in the system so it
knows exactly what to reach out and grab.

157
00:08:08.990 --> 00:08:11.512
So I can add a system like that router and

158
00:08:11.512 --> 00:08:16.020
I can give it the SNMP community stream
and now it's gonna reach out and

159
00:08:16.020 --> 00:08:20.080
see how it just pulled to find
the interfaces that I had?

160
00:08:20.080 --> 00:08:21.750
I'm gonna select all of this to monitor.

161
00:08:21.750 --> 00:08:23.800
Here's the interfaces,
I guess I don't need to monitor null.

162
00:08:23.800 --> 00:08:25.390
That one's not really gonna help me.

163
00:08:25.390 --> 00:08:27.480
I've got a NAT virtual interface.

164
00:08:27.480 --> 00:08:31.400
I probably don't care about my NAT rates
and I'm not using the serial interface.

165
00:08:31.400 --> 00:08:35.700
You tweak it to meet what it is
that you need in your environment.

166
00:08:35.700 --> 00:08:39.420
And then when it's done, it's now gonna
start monitoring that system, and

167
00:08:39.420 --> 00:08:42.960
every 30 seconds or five minutes or
whatever it's gonna reach out and

168
00:08:42.960 --> 00:08:45.740
ask it for data, and put it in a database.

169
00:08:45.740 --> 00:08:49.340
And the cool part about that database
is I can come in and I can say boy,

170
00:08:49.340 --> 00:08:51.520
my network is running slow today.

171
00:08:51.520 --> 00:08:53.520
So let me check my router.

172
00:08:53.520 --> 00:08:55.790
And I'm going to go into
one of its interfaces and

173
00:08:55.790 --> 00:09:00.660
pull up a bandwidth chart or
something like that on it

174
00:09:00.660 --> 00:09:04.010
to see am I getting errors,
am I getting a lot of data.

175
00:09:04.010 --> 00:09:07.610
What's going on, right, and because I
just added this one it doesn't have any

176
00:09:07.610 --> 00:09:11.668
information, but I've got another device
on here that should have some information,

177
00:09:11.668 --> 00:09:15.640
and let's just take this one in here,
I'll take CPU load on this one, right?

178
00:09:15.640 --> 00:09:19.840
So I'm gonna pull up the average
CPU load on this switch and,

179
00:09:19.840 --> 00:09:22.110
even it doesn't have enough good data,
does it?

180
00:09:22.110 --> 00:09:25.329
You have to let these things run for
a while to gather all the information and

181
00:09:25.329 --> 00:09:28.310
put it together, and apparently,
I don't have any good data here.

182
00:09:28.310 --> 00:09:32.500
But we'll actually get it soon
enough even on the router.

183
00:09:32.500 --> 00:09:34.820
Here we go,
it's starting on the router already.

184
00:09:34.820 --> 00:09:39.580
So I can see these little red bars over
here that are showing me that my CPU

185
00:09:39.580 --> 00:09:43.660
utilization is really low right now,
I'm just not pulling a lot.

186
00:09:43.660 --> 00:09:48.470
So that's kind of what we expect
on these and we can watch it.

187
00:09:48.470 --> 00:09:54.630
And if I see like memory consistently
climbing up slowly over time.

188
00:09:54.630 --> 00:09:56.280
Well, I know I got a problem.

189
00:09:56.280 --> 00:09:59.632
I know my memory shouldn't be climbing
like that or maybe my network's growing,

190
00:09:59.632 --> 00:10:01.150
I'm adding more employees.

191
00:10:01.150 --> 00:10:03.920
Let me give you guys a great
example this is a true story.

192
00:10:03.920 --> 00:10:09.810
So I used to work for a bank that had
about 100 branchoffs just spread across

193
00:10:09.810 --> 00:10:15.240
four states and at every office
we had three Cisco 3560 switches.

194
00:10:15.240 --> 00:10:18.940
So there were three switches at
each office, about 300 switches.

195
00:10:18.940 --> 00:10:22.390
And I did a really good job of making
sure that we always stayed up to date,

196
00:10:22.390 --> 00:10:25.610
had the latest IOSes on them and
that things were running smoothly.

197
00:10:25.610 --> 00:10:29.050
But I started to notice that
all of the switches, all 300,

198
00:10:29.050 --> 00:10:34.840
were locking up and
requiring a reboot about every two weeks.

199
00:10:34.840 --> 00:10:37.160
About every two weeks each switch
would have to be rebooted.

200
00:10:37.160 --> 00:10:39.940
And it didn't all happen at the same
time but it was always two weeks apart.

201
00:10:39.940 --> 00:10:41.820
And I thought that was odd, right?

202
00:10:41.820 --> 00:10:44.980
And so I started kinda monitoring it and
looking into the logs.

203
00:10:44.980 --> 00:10:45.830
There was nothing.

204
00:10:45.830 --> 00:10:48.130
Cuz you'd have to reboot the switch and
the logs would get cleared and

205
00:10:48.130 --> 00:10:49.300
I'd go to the syslog server and

206
00:10:49.300 --> 00:10:51.810
there really wasn't anything in
there indicated a problem either.

207
00:10:51.810 --> 00:10:53.770
It was just all of a sudden locking up.

208
00:10:53.770 --> 00:10:57.290
Well, I used a slightly different
version of this software.

209
00:10:57.290 --> 00:10:59.570
This the network performance monitor
you run on your own machine.

210
00:10:59.570 --> 00:11:02.460
But they have another one that's
web based called Orion and

211
00:11:02.460 --> 00:11:03.930
that's the one I was using.

212
00:11:03.930 --> 00:11:08.221
And what I was able to see was on the
switches, when I pulled up their memory,

213
00:11:08.221 --> 00:11:12.245
their average memory usage,
that you expect to see at a certain level,

214
00:11:12.245 --> 00:11:17.030
see how this router is running at about 34
megabytes right now of memory consumed.

215
00:11:17.030 --> 00:11:20.560
Now it's got a lot more than 34 megs so
that's not a big deal.

216
00:11:20.560 --> 00:11:24.880
But what I saw in the switch is, was
steadily, over two weeks that memory usage

217
00:11:24.880 --> 00:11:28.590
would grow until it finally hit a point
where the system was out of memory and

218
00:11:28.590 --> 00:11:29.890
the switch would lock up.

219
00:11:29.890 --> 00:11:32.230
And so there wasn't anything in the logs.

220
00:11:32.230 --> 00:11:35.450
But because I was querying
memory utilization with SNMP and

221
00:11:35.450 --> 00:11:38.930
storing in a database where I
could see it as a trend chart,

222
00:11:38.930 --> 00:11:42.710
I was able to see that I had a memory
leak and so I reached out to Cisco and

223
00:11:42.710 --> 00:11:45.630
they worked it through with me and
we found that there was a memory

224
00:11:45.630 --> 00:11:48.670
leak in that version of the IOS and
they put an update out that fixed it.

225
00:11:48.670 --> 00:11:50.973
So we rolled that update out
through all of our switches and

226
00:11:50.973 --> 00:11:53.470
then they started staying up for
months on end with no problem.

227
00:11:53.470 --> 00:11:57.270
But I wouldn't have known that if
I didn't have the trending data.

228
00:11:57.270 --> 00:11:59.770
And SNMP is what gave me that data.

229
00:11:59.770 --> 00:12:04.080
I can see this steady climb from
normal memory all the way up to this

230
00:12:04.080 --> 00:12:05.020
higher level.

231
00:12:05.020 --> 00:12:07.550
And I can even predict when
the switch was going to lock up.

232
00:12:07.550 --> 00:12:10.540
And so that made it where I could
actually schedule a reboot on it.

233
00:12:10.540 --> 00:12:12.090
Instead of having it happen
in the middle of the day,

234
00:12:12.090 --> 00:12:14.950
I could schedule a reboot
until Cisco got me my fix.

235
00:12:14.950 --> 00:12:18.190
And in their defense I think it took
like a whopping three days to get

236
00:12:18.190 --> 00:12:19.290
a fix outta them.

237
00:12:19.290 --> 00:12:22.630
It really didn't take a long time,
once they had isolated the problem,

238
00:12:22.630 --> 00:12:24.420
the fix came very, very quickly.

239
00:12:24.420 --> 00:12:27.670
And actually just kinda
word of caution there.

240
00:12:27.670 --> 00:12:31.580
When you work with Cisco and they actually
have a fix that's available just for

241
00:12:31.580 --> 00:12:34.500
you they'll normally give
you an experimental release.

242
00:12:34.500 --> 00:12:36.720
And in your IOS file name
there'll be an X in there.

243
00:12:36.720 --> 00:12:39.350
If you ever see and X in the file
name it's an experimental release and

244
00:12:39.350 --> 00:12:41.280
it's usually designed for one customer.

245
00:12:41.280 --> 00:12:44.210
So if you're just downloading
random IOS files and

246
00:12:44.210 --> 00:12:47.090
you get a hold of one of those X ones you
don't want to use those in production

247
00:12:47.090 --> 00:12:49.120
unless it was specifically made for you.

248
00:12:49.120 --> 00:12:50.540
That's the only time it's okay.

249
00:12:50.540 --> 00:12:51.680
And so that's how we were.

250
00:12:51.680 --> 00:12:54.360
We ran on one of those X releases for
a week or two.

251
00:12:54.360 --> 00:12:57.920
Before Cisco finally pushed out
the next master out to everybody.

252
00:12:57.920 --> 00:13:01.226
So that's where this information
becomes really handy.

253
00:13:01.226 --> 00:13:06.515
And so SNMP, very powerful gives
us a lot of really good data and

254
00:13:06.515 --> 00:13:10.055
can help you to find problems you
otherwise wouldn't be able to spot.

255
00:13:10.055 --> 00:13:13.585
>> Very good, so when it comes
down to it being a little bit more

256
00:13:13.585 --> 00:13:17.855
proactive on this and being able to see
that, hey, I can see that there's a trend

257
00:13:17.855 --> 00:13:21.435
spike in the utilization and you don't
have to wait until that switch is offline.

258
00:13:21.435 --> 00:13:24.530
And you get all these calls and
well, now we have problems.

259
00:13:24.530 --> 00:13:25.860
So what do we got next here, Don?

260
00:13:25.860 --> 00:13:29.720
>> All right, well so
SNMP does some good stuff, right?

261
00:13:29.720 --> 00:13:32.210
But there's some things
that it just can't do.

262
00:13:32.210 --> 00:13:37.920
And Wes, we were talking before the show
about like, what if I get a call,

263
00:13:37.920 --> 00:13:42.080
a support ticket, and somebody says hey,
the network is slow, all right?

264
00:13:42.080 --> 00:13:45.890
So I fire up SNMP and I say well,
let me take a look at that interface and

265
00:13:45.890 --> 00:13:47.890
one it's what's its average bandwidth?

266
00:13:47.890 --> 00:13:51.310
I wonder if I have any good data,
if I've waited long enough now.

267
00:13:51.310 --> 00:13:51.847
No, still not.

268
00:13:51.847 --> 00:13:55.480
[LAUGH] If I wait long enough this'll
actually start to populate and

269
00:13:55.480 --> 00:13:57.550
show how much bandwidth
that I'm using on the link.

270
00:13:57.550 --> 00:14:00.690
But it'll start to populate and
I can look at it, and

271
00:14:00.690 --> 00:14:03.530
I can look at it and
say wow we're at 98% utilization.

272
00:14:03.530 --> 00:14:06.610
We're consuming all this bandwidth
on the line, I got a problem.

273
00:14:07.650 --> 00:14:09.990
But Where do I go from there?

274
00:14:09.990 --> 00:14:14.980
Well, SNMP doesn't tell me who's
using that bandwidth, right?

275
00:14:14.980 --> 00:14:17.270
It just tells me that I
am using the bandwidth.

276
00:14:17.270 --> 00:14:20.390
And so I don't really have a good
way to break that down and

277
00:14:20.390 --> 00:14:22.370
find out the nitty gritty details.

278
00:14:22.370 --> 00:14:27.570
So, while SNMP is really useful
It's not the be all end all

279
00:14:27.570 --> 00:14:29.170
of monitoring solutions.

280
00:14:29.170 --> 00:14:32.680
So in the past what we would do is we
would fire up the Network Sniffer, right?

281
00:14:32.680 --> 00:14:36.590
Okay I'm at 98% bandwidth utilization,
who's doing that?

282
00:14:36.590 --> 00:14:38.020
Who's consuming all that bandwidth?

283
00:14:38.020 --> 00:14:43.460
So I fire up a sniffer, I do a span and do
the switchboard analyzer I mirror the port

284
00:14:43.460 --> 00:14:46.850
traffic from my router over to my laptop
and I start recording the traffic and

285
00:14:46.850 --> 00:14:49.220
I look and I can analyze it and
find out, all right.

286
00:14:49.220 --> 00:14:51.240
But that's a lot of work.

287
00:14:51.240 --> 00:14:54.920
Well CISCO routers and switches actually
have a technology built into them

288
00:14:54.920 --> 00:14:57.910
that can do that same thing, all right.

289
00:14:57.910 --> 00:15:03.420
What they do is they can monitor
the traffickers going through them,

290
00:15:03.420 --> 00:15:05.170
and instead of giving you the raw data,

291
00:15:05.170 --> 00:15:08.050
like when I run a sniffer,
I'm getting the actual payload.

292
00:15:08.050 --> 00:15:10.780
So if there's a terabyte of
data moving across the network,

293
00:15:10.780 --> 00:15:13.630
my capture file is going
to be a terabyte in size.

294
00:15:13.630 --> 00:15:16.965
But Cisco routers and switches have
a technology in them called NetFlow.

295
00:15:16.965 --> 00:15:20.700
And what NetFlow does is it says, hey when
you're done trouble shooting the network

296
00:15:20.700 --> 00:15:23.400
you usually don't care about the payload.

297
00:15:23.400 --> 00:15:25.950
Heck half the time the payload's
encrypted these days any way so

298
00:15:25.950 --> 00:15:27.360
if you get it what good does it do you?

299
00:15:27.360 --> 00:15:28.690
Nothing, right?

300
00:15:28.690 --> 00:15:34.110
So instead what it does is it
records kind of the metadata,

301
00:15:34.110 --> 00:15:36.950
to use our current jargon, right?

302
00:15:36.950 --> 00:15:39.190
Meta.
So, it gives that metadata information,

303
00:15:39.190 --> 00:15:42.580
just the kind of description
of the communication.

304
00:15:42.580 --> 00:15:43.460
What was the source IP?

305
00:15:43.460 --> 00:15:44.750
What was the destination IP?

306
00:15:44.750 --> 00:15:47.085
What was the source MAC and
the destination MAC?

307
00:15:47.085 --> 00:15:49.095
What protocol was it using?

308
00:15:49.095 --> 00:15:51.805
How big was the packet size wise?

309
00:15:51.805 --> 00:15:55.484
Not the actual payload,
just how big it happened to be.

310
00:15:55.484 --> 00:15:58.701
And it records that information
It puts it into a database and

311
00:15:58.701 --> 00:16:03.130
that's actually a very small amount of
data because you've taken on the payload.

312
00:16:03.130 --> 00:16:05.580
And TCP headers are pretty small as it is.

313
00:16:05.580 --> 00:16:07.820
IP headers, your letter two headers.

314
00:16:07.820 --> 00:16:11.950
They're all pretty small and it's
really just getting a sub set of that.

315
00:16:11.950 --> 00:16:15.000
But it's able to string it together in
a way that we can look at a system and

316
00:16:15.000 --> 00:16:17.560
see how we're at 98%
bandwidth utilization.

317
00:16:17.560 --> 00:16:20.760
Who is consuming it, and
we can find out and see.

318
00:16:20.760 --> 00:16:24.670
And that's all done through
a service called NetFlow.

319
00:16:24.670 --> 00:16:28.620
Now NetFlow is developed by Cisco, they're
working on making a bigger standard

320
00:16:28.620 --> 00:16:31.900
where other vendors can support it,
but on most Cisco equipment,

321
00:16:31.900 --> 00:16:36.050
you can fire and
I say most because behind me here,

322
00:16:36.050 --> 00:16:39.090
you guys can't see it,
is a stack of Cisco equipment.

323
00:16:39.090 --> 00:16:43.590
And one of the switches that I've been
using in the show a lot of a 3750.

324
00:16:43.590 --> 00:16:47.075
And I told the guys here at the office
like I'm done net folding 3750s

325
00:16:47.075 --> 00:16:47.730
several times.

326
00:16:47.730 --> 00:16:48.630
No big deal.

327
00:16:48.630 --> 00:16:51.270
Well in the first taping of this
show I tried to turn it on.

328
00:16:51.270 --> 00:16:52.853
It wasn't there and
I was like what the heck's going on?

329
00:16:52.853 --> 00:16:59.250
Well, I've got a 3750G behind me,
only the 3750Xs support NetFlow.

330
00:16:59.250 --> 00:17:00.770
So we've got to be aware of that.

331
00:17:00.770 --> 00:17:03.620
You've got to be aware that not
all equipment does support it.

332
00:17:03.620 --> 00:17:05.380
So, You gotta check and see.

333
00:17:05.380 --> 00:17:07.670
Now I'm gonna use
a router in this show and

334
00:17:07.670 --> 00:17:11.050
pretty much every router made in the last
four or five years supports NetFlow.

335
00:17:11.050 --> 00:17:12.930
It's on the switches where
it gets a little bit flaky.

336
00:17:12.930 --> 00:17:14.780
Not all of them do NetFlow.

337
00:17:14.780 --> 00:17:17.269
So I've got this router here
that's running the 15.1 IOS.

338
00:17:17.269 --> 00:17:21.076
And I can just verify that, right,
If I look at it I'm running 15.1-1.

339
00:17:21.076 --> 00:17:22.655
We saw that with SNMP earlier, right?

340
00:17:22.655 --> 00:17:26.430
So I know I'm running that, and
I should be good to go to support NetFlow.

341
00:17:26.430 --> 00:17:28.510
It's pretty easy to verify,
if you support it or not.

342
00:17:28.510 --> 00:17:30.820
If you jump into your configuration.

343
00:17:30.820 --> 00:17:35.960
If you just do a IP flow ?, if you see all
the various flow commands, you support it.

344
00:17:35.960 --> 00:17:38.420
If you don't see the flow commands,
you don't, right?

345
00:17:38.420 --> 00:17:41.050
NetFlow, they just call it Flow here,
you actually see

346
00:17:41.050 --> 00:17:44.310
a couple of different names for it because
over the years it evolved a little bit.

347
00:17:44.310 --> 00:17:46.360
But NetFlow is the official name.

348
00:17:46.360 --> 00:17:47.460
And when we look at it,

349
00:17:47.460 --> 00:17:49.790
you'll see that there's a lot of
different commands that we can do here.

350
00:17:49.790 --> 00:17:53.390
And what we're really doing is
what's called a flow cache.

351
00:17:53.390 --> 00:17:58.240
We're caching data about each flow of
traffic that's going across the network,

352
00:17:58.240 --> 00:18:01.010
and just storing that to be
interpreted by another machine.

353
00:18:01.010 --> 00:18:05.160
Now we don't actually store it
on the router itself, all right?

354
00:18:05.160 --> 00:18:09.220
It's gonna gather the data and
it's going to do what's called an export.

355
00:18:09.220 --> 00:18:12.490
We export the data to a third
party monitoring system.

356
00:18:12.490 --> 00:18:15.460
And Cisco doesn't actually have a third
party monitoring system for you or

357
00:18:15.460 --> 00:18:18.180
a first party monitoring system I guess,
if it's Cisco.

358
00:18:18.180 --> 00:18:21.220
So, they expect you to bring
in somebody else's software.

359
00:18:21.220 --> 00:18:23.940
So, I'm already using the Solar Winds
toolkit here so I'm gonna go ahead and

360
00:18:23.940 --> 00:18:27.980
use the Solar Winds NetFlow monitor also
and that way I can send the data to it and

361
00:18:27.980 --> 00:18:29.420
get it reported.

362
00:18:29.420 --> 00:18:33.455
If we wanna configure NetFlow, what we
need to do is just a couple of things.

363
00:18:33.455 --> 00:18:36.345
First off, we need to figure out
what interface we want to monitor.

364
00:18:36.345 --> 00:18:41.255
So if you look on my router, I've got
a couple of different interfaces, right?

365
00:18:41.255 --> 00:18:44.040
I've got my internal interface,
where my clients connect and

366
00:18:44.040 --> 00:18:47.090
I've got my external interface
that sends me out to the Internet.

367
00:18:47.090 --> 00:18:51.970
Now I also need to be aware of the flow,
the direction of the flow.

368
00:18:51.970 --> 00:18:54.990
Am I wanting to monitor the traffic
going out of the network or

369
00:18:54.990 --> 00:18:58.430
monitor the traffic coming into the
network or do I wanna monitor both, right?

370
00:18:58.430 --> 00:19:00.430
You can certainly do both.

371
00:19:00.430 --> 00:19:03.200
But if I'm dealing with
a bandwidth constraint

372
00:19:03.200 --> 00:19:08.000
people are downloading too much data and
so I'm just running out of bandwidth.

373
00:19:08.000 --> 00:19:13.680
Well then what I need to do is
monitor either the incoming

374
00:19:13.680 --> 00:19:18.690
traffic on my Internet connection or
the outgoing traffic on my LAN connection.

375
00:19:18.690 --> 00:19:20.240
That's why I need to know the direction,

376
00:19:20.240 --> 00:19:23.800
think of it as ACLs, when we apply ACL's
we need to apply a direction to them.

377
00:19:23.800 --> 00:19:27.350
Same thing with NetFlow we use a direction
to dictate the traffic from our monitor.

378
00:19:27.350 --> 00:19:31.090
If I'm wanting to do monitor uploads
then its just the opposite right?

379
00:19:31.090 --> 00:19:34.170
I need to monitor the inbound
traffic on my LAN connection and

380
00:19:34.170 --> 00:19:35.470
the outbound traffic on my WAM.

381
00:19:35.470 --> 00:19:37.900
But its usually downloads, right?

382
00:19:37.900 --> 00:19:41.500
You got some users somewhere in your
building that's watching movies on Netflix

383
00:19:41.500 --> 00:19:45.170
right or downloading with Bittorrent and
that's what you want to see.

384
00:19:45.170 --> 00:19:49.580
So we normally monitor
the incoming of the WAN, but

385
00:19:49.580 --> 00:19:51.240
there is a limitation on
the incoming with the WAN.

386
00:19:51.240 --> 00:19:56.570
If somebody has a VPN tunnel
that terminates on this router,

387
00:19:56.570 --> 00:19:59.030
when it's incoming on the WAN,
that data's encrypted and

388
00:19:59.030 --> 00:20:01.530
you're not gonna get a lot of
benefit out of it, all right?

389
00:20:01.530 --> 00:20:04.952
Versus if you measure it
on the outgoing on the LAN.

390
00:20:04.952 --> 00:20:07.650
It's gonna be decrypted at that
point because the VPN tunnel

391
00:20:07.650 --> 00:20:08.750
terminated on the router.

392
00:20:08.750 --> 00:20:11.080
So, depending on
the interface you monitor,

393
00:20:11.080 --> 00:20:14.030
it may influence whether that
traffic is encrypted or decrypted.

394
00:20:14.030 --> 00:20:16.202
So, be aware of that for your monitoring.

395
00:20:16.202 --> 00:20:19.008
All right, so I'm going to
monitor it on my LAN interface.

396
00:20:19.008 --> 00:20:21.500
And I'm gonna get the traffic as
it comes out of the LAN interface.

397
00:20:21.500 --> 00:20:24.080
So these will be downloads that
my internal users are doing.

398
00:20:24.080 --> 00:20:27.400
And so I'm just going to get into that
interface, and I'm going to say ip

399
00:20:27.400 --> 00:20:32.220
flow and you'll see where I can
do ingress or egress, all right.

400
00:20:32.220 --> 00:20:33.710
And I'm gonna specify egress.

401
00:20:33.710 --> 00:20:37.840
I wanna monitor the traffic
as it comes out of this port.

402
00:20:37.840 --> 00:20:42.720
Now when you do that notice that there's
also this monitor command, all right.

403
00:20:42.720 --> 00:20:44.870
What a monitor does is allow
you to apply a filter.

404
00:20:44.870 --> 00:20:46.930
Maybe I don't wanna get all the traffic.

405
00:20:46.930 --> 00:20:50.720
Maybe I'm targeting this one IP
specifically so I can create a filter.

406
00:20:50.720 --> 00:20:52.530
It's basically an ACL that we apply and

407
00:20:52.530 --> 00:20:55.010
we limit the traffic that we're
monitoring now, all right.

408
00:20:55.010 --> 00:20:56.110
But for me, I just want everything.

409
00:20:56.110 --> 00:20:58.430
So, IP, flow, egress,
that's all I need, right.

410
00:20:58.430 --> 00:21:00.332
So, now that I've got that turned on,

411
00:21:00.332 --> 00:21:03.051
there's just two other things
I need to do, all right.

412
00:21:03.051 --> 00:21:06.970
One, I need to decide which
version of NetFlow I'm gonna run.

413
00:21:06.970 --> 00:21:10.000
There's two main versions,
version five and version nine.

414
00:21:10.000 --> 00:21:12.209
Depending on the third party
software I'm gonna use,

415
00:21:12.209 --> 00:21:14.030
it's gonna need one or the other.

416
00:21:14.030 --> 00:21:16.506
Now, I mentioned I'm going to
use the Solar Winds one, right?

417
00:21:16.506 --> 00:21:18.293
So if I fire up my Solar Winds.

418
00:21:18.293 --> 00:21:18.995
Oh, hey,

419
00:21:18.995 --> 00:21:24.130
my MIB walker finally finished back
here that was running in the background.

420
00:21:24.130 --> 00:21:25.030
>> It got some information.

421
00:21:25.030 --> 00:21:27.070
>> Yeah, so here's all of those.

422
00:21:27.070 --> 00:21:29.185
You can see there are literally
thousands of them.

423
00:21:29.185 --> 00:21:31.732
21,813 entries that I got.

424
00:21:31.732 --> 00:21:36.457
But I'm gonna use the NetFlow real time
monitor here and basically when you set it

425
00:21:36.457 --> 00:21:41.685
up to run it's gonna monitor on a port and
you'll see mine's defaulting to 2,055.

426
00:21:41.685 --> 00:21:45.888
But, you've got a few different
options you can kind of tweak in here,

427
00:21:45.888 --> 00:21:48.199
and set different things up coming in,

428
00:21:48.199 --> 00:21:52.420
and define your devices and it can
even help you configure your device.

429
00:21:52.420 --> 00:21:56.950
So like, if I go here to Tools, NetFlow
Configurator, you can choose a device, and

430
00:21:56.950 --> 00:21:59.200
it'll give you a sample
config to apply to it.

431
00:21:59.200 --> 00:22:00.920
Now, I haven't defined
any devices in here.

432
00:22:00.920 --> 00:22:06.090
So I'm gonna add a NetFlow device and
I'll specify an IP address, and

433
00:22:06.090 --> 00:22:12.340
it's gonna use an SNMP community string
to talk to the device just to find it.

434
00:22:12.340 --> 00:22:15.030
So I'm just going to add that so
it can find the device.

435
00:22:15.030 --> 00:22:16.400
There, it found it.

436
00:22:16.400 --> 00:22:18.680
So now it knows about the device.

437
00:22:18.680 --> 00:22:23.114
And now I can say, if I want to monitor
this interface, I can choose it and

438
00:22:23.114 --> 00:22:28.058
I can go to the NetFlow Configurator and,
oh shoot, I'm in the eval version so it

439
00:22:28.058 --> 00:22:32.785
might not let me do it, but it'll actually
give you the sample config to go and

440
00:22:32.785 --> 00:22:36.540
put on your router to get it
configured and get it doing that.

441
00:22:36.540 --> 00:22:39.440
So, actually is it about to let me?

442
00:22:39.440 --> 00:22:40.427
Let's see if it'll let me do it here.

443
00:22:40.427 --> 00:22:42.359
So, we're just doing public.

444
00:22:43.570 --> 00:22:47.490
And oh it needs, if you do rewrite it
will actually push the config to it.

445
00:22:47.490 --> 00:22:48.860
And I'll do the config myself.

446
00:22:48.860 --> 00:22:50.290
But the port number's what's important.

447
00:22:50.290 --> 00:22:51.390
And then the version number.

448
00:22:51.390 --> 00:22:53.920
Is it version five or is it version nine?

449
00:22:53.920 --> 00:22:56.650
And this one if I remember right it's
running version nine by default.

450
00:22:56.650 --> 00:22:58.140
And I don't think we can even change it.

451
00:22:58.140 --> 00:23:01.680
I think it's always stuck that way so
I am okay with that.

452
00:23:01.680 --> 00:23:06.552
I'm gonna jump back over to my router and
I'm gonna come in here and

453
00:23:06.552 --> 00:23:08.590
just say ip flow-export.

454
00:23:08.590 --> 00:23:12.980
Right, I'm exporting my data and
I'm gonna export of this version nine.

455
00:23:12.980 --> 00:23:14.730
if I want to run version
five I can do that.

456
00:23:14.730 --> 00:23:16.500
You'll see this router
even supports version one.

457
00:23:16.500 --> 00:23:19.050
I've never actually seen any
software that supports version one.

458
00:23:19.050 --> 00:23:21.060
I'm sure something had to or
it wouldn't exist.

459
00:23:21.060 --> 00:23:23.430
But I'm gonna do version nine, okay?

460
00:23:23.430 --> 00:23:26.200
So now I'm ready to export that data.

461
00:23:26.200 --> 00:23:27.840
I need to tell it who to export it to.

462
00:23:27.840 --> 00:23:33.000
So I'm gonna go ahead and
just ip flow-export destination and

463
00:23:33.000 --> 00:23:36.285
I'm gonna put the IP of my
workstation here, this guy.

464
00:23:36.285 --> 00:23:42.607
Now my workstation is 101 so
I'm gonna put 192.168.0.101.

465
00:23:42.607 --> 00:23:45.740
And if just press Enter it's
gonna use the default port.

466
00:23:45.740 --> 00:23:49.070
Unfortunately there's a little bit of
debate over what is the default port.

467
00:23:49.070 --> 00:23:52.010
You'll see Cisco uses 5000 for
a lot of stuff.

468
00:23:52.010 --> 00:23:56.151
But notice back here in my
software it's defaulting to 2055.

469
00:23:56.151 --> 00:23:58.906
So I'm just gonna come in and
manually type that port number in so

470
00:23:58.906 --> 00:24:00.959
that I know it's using the right thing,
okay.

471
00:24:00.959 --> 00:24:04.499
Now Whenever I generate
traffic on this link,

472
00:24:04.499 --> 00:24:08.870
it's gonna be getting
recorded as part of Netflow.

473
00:24:08.870 --> 00:24:11.561
So if I were to fire a webpage up and

474
00:24:11.561 --> 00:24:16.860
maybe I'll browse to ITProTV and
maybe I start watching a video.

475
00:24:16.860 --> 00:24:20.340
So I want to come in here and
check out a video of Shirley.

476
00:24:20.340 --> 00:24:23.025
A site like ours is going to have
some kind of video available.

477
00:24:23.025 --> 00:24:24.960
>> [LAUGH]
>> And so I'll jump in here and

478
00:24:24.960 --> 00:24:28.580
we'll take a course.

479
00:24:28.580 --> 00:24:29.460
And hey, look at that guy.

480
00:24:29.460 --> 00:24:31.430
>> I've seen him before.

481
00:24:31.430 --> 00:24:33.310
>> Anyhow, so
I'm gonna start playing this video, right?

482
00:24:33.310 --> 00:24:34.540
So I'm watching this video.

483
00:24:34.540 --> 00:24:35.820
I gotta get a discount.

484
00:24:35.820 --> 00:24:38.800
And so I'm playing the video and
I'm generating bandwidth, right?

485
00:24:38.800 --> 00:24:40.550
I'm going through that router.

486
00:24:40.550 --> 00:24:44.670
Now I'm going out to a CDM on the internet
saying can you please give me a video.

487
00:24:44.670 --> 00:24:46.680
And then the CDM is sending
the video down to me.

488
00:24:46.680 --> 00:24:49.510
So I'm downloading a video,
which is generating bandwidth.

489
00:24:49.510 --> 00:24:52.850
Now how do I know whether
Netflow if working or not?

490
00:24:52.850 --> 00:24:55.660
Okay, well I guess
technically I don't know.

491
00:24:55.660 --> 00:24:58.000
But we can go in and we can verify right?

492
00:24:58.000 --> 00:25:05.750
On the right router the only real command
we have to verify is show IP cache flow.

493
00:25:05.750 --> 00:25:07.910
And that'll show you the cache data.

494
00:25:07.910 --> 00:25:11.180
So I won't actually see the raw data,
but I'll see a little bit of the cache.

495
00:25:11.180 --> 00:25:15.330
And so I can see here like I've
got some www, web browsing.

496
00:25:15.330 --> 00:25:18.890
I've got other protocols, TCP and UDP,
and it's starting to show how many

497
00:25:18.890 --> 00:25:23.120
flows it's monitoring and
even some basic statistics down here.

498
00:25:23.120 --> 00:25:29.520
And so if I look like 192.168.0.100 that's
my Mac and I'm watching that video.

499
00:25:29.520 --> 00:25:32.950
So one of these IPs over here will
be the video streaming server,

500
00:25:32.950 --> 00:25:36.330
I'm gonna assume it's this one
that's got 154 packets already.

501
00:25:36.330 --> 00:25:40.000
And so if I just keep watching this
those numbers should continue to change,

502
00:25:40.000 --> 00:25:43.980
right, as it continues to play that video
and the flow is starting to increase.

503
00:25:43.980 --> 00:25:49.340
But notice a moment ago I had one
that had a counter of 154 packets and

504
00:25:49.340 --> 00:25:51.570
now the highest one is 78.

505
00:25:51.570 --> 00:25:54.090
What happened to the one that was 154?

506
00:25:54.090 --> 00:25:55.610
Well, that flow is gone.

507
00:25:55.610 --> 00:25:58.760
If I look, the video in the background
is done, it stopped playing.

508
00:25:58.760 --> 00:26:03.200
And so when that stopped playing that
flow is now over and it's out of here.

509
00:26:03.200 --> 00:26:06.050
The router is not actually
storing this data.

510
00:26:06.050 --> 00:26:10.950
It's gathering it and it's exporting
it and then it's forgetting about it.

511
00:26:10.950 --> 00:26:14.591
So if you're not running a software
package to monitor that you're losing

512
00:26:14.591 --> 00:26:15.120
the data.

513
00:26:15.120 --> 00:26:16.730
You might as well not
have Netflow turned on.

514
00:26:16.730 --> 00:26:18.700
There is no sense in turning it on,

515
00:26:18.700 --> 00:26:22.400
unless you got a Netflow receiver
somewhere on the network.

516
00:26:22.400 --> 00:26:23.630
Now I did.

517
00:26:23.630 --> 00:26:27.460
I had this guy up and running but
[LAUGH] I kind of forgot to hit the start
