00:26:27.460 --> 00:26:31.430
flow capture button, so that's gonna
influence my numbers here a little bit.

519
00:26:31.430 --> 00:26:34.260
I can actually see that it is
getting some data over here but

520
00:26:34.260 --> 00:26:36.480
it's just getting that through SNMP.

521
00:26:36.480 --> 00:26:38.280
I'm gonna start the flow-capture.

522
00:26:38.280 --> 00:26:41.530
There we go.
So now it's gonna start capturing data.

523
00:26:41.530 --> 00:26:45.710
And it's running, it's waiting for that
data, it's listening, and I can go and

00:26:45.710 --> 00:26:47.695
start to generate some more traffic again.

525
00:26:47.695 --> 00:26:50.040
[LAUGH] That wasn't
exactly what I intended.

526
00:26:50.040 --> 00:26:51.110
I wonder if it's gonna cache that.

527
00:26:51.110 --> 00:26:54.790
I might need to skip to
some other video here.

528
00:26:54.790 --> 00:26:55.710
And here's that guy again.

529
00:26:55.710 --> 00:26:58.460
So I'm just gonna generate
some more traffic and

530
00:26:58.460 --> 00:27:01.640
it's gonna start doing this and
sending it over to that Netflow receiver.

531
00:27:01.640 --> 00:27:02.490
And there we go,

532
00:27:02.490 --> 00:27:06.620
I can see the traffic is already starting
to appear, it's gathering that data.

533
00:27:06.620 --> 00:27:08.350
And if I look at my conversations,

534
00:27:08.350 --> 00:27:12.920
start breaking this down,
I can see who is really consuming it.

535
00:27:12.920 --> 00:27:15.800
And so that video, right here I can see
it coming out of Alchamie Technologies,

536
00:27:15.800 --> 00:27:19.610
that's one of our CDNs, and we've got
that stuff kind of flowing through and

537
00:27:19.610 --> 00:27:21.355
I can start to see the information.

538
00:27:21.355 --> 00:27:24.370
Who's generating the most communications,

539
00:27:24.370 --> 00:27:26.780
what they're doing to generate
those communications.

540
00:27:26.780 --> 00:27:29.280
So when I look at my laptop
here this 192.168.0.100,

541
00:27:29.280 --> 00:27:34.980
I start to get a breakdown of
who I'm talking to and so on.

542
00:27:34.980 --> 00:27:37.860
Now on my outbound traffic
is what I'm monitoring.

543
00:27:37.860 --> 00:27:39.980
That's why the bottom part
of the screen is lit up.

544
00:27:39.980 --> 00:27:42.580
The inbound traffic I'm not
monitoring on the interface and

545
00:27:42.580 --> 00:27:45.250
that's why I've got this giant
no data available warning.

546
00:27:45.250 --> 00:27:48.250
So, that top part isn't gonna update for
me.

547
00:27:48.250 --> 00:27:50.150
But the bottom part is
what I'm monitoring.

548
00:27:50.150 --> 00:27:51.050
I can see that data.

549
00:27:51.050 --> 00:27:53.060
In fact,
let me just get rid of the inbound.

550
00:27:53.060 --> 00:27:53.870
There we go.

551
00:27:53.870 --> 00:27:55.600
And now it's a little bit
more meaningful for me.

552
00:27:55.600 --> 00:28:00.510
So I can start to see not only who it is
that's actually eating up my bandwidth,

553
00:28:00.510 --> 00:28:02.520
but what protocol it is they're using.

554
00:28:02.520 --> 00:28:04.500
And who it is they're talking to.

555
00:28:04.500 --> 00:28:06.230
Right?
So, they're watching a video.

556
00:28:06.230 --> 00:28:09.810
I can see them talking to a CDN or
they're talking to Amazon web services or

557
00:28:09.810 --> 00:28:11.830
whoever, you can spot that information.

558
00:28:11.830 --> 00:28:17.680
This is really good data that your packets
and protocol analyzer would give you also,

559
00:28:17.680 --> 00:28:21.670
but here we have the benefit of
not actually carrying the payload.

560
00:28:21.670 --> 00:28:25.350
This could be a ten gig
bandwidth connection and

561
00:28:25.350 --> 00:28:27.120
I could be on a 100 megabit connection.

562
00:28:27.120 --> 00:28:30.072
And that would be okay cuz the Netflow
data is not gonna be ten gig.

563
00:28:30.072 --> 00:28:32.610
It's gonna be a very, very small subset.

564
00:28:32.610 --> 00:28:36.290
So we don't have the same demands on our
system that we would with a sniffer or

565
00:28:36.290 --> 00:28:37.060
a protocol analyzer.

566
00:28:37.060 --> 00:28:38.450
So pretty cool stuff.

567
00:28:38.450 --> 00:28:39.420
>> Absolutely, very good.

568
00:28:39.420 --> 00:28:40.170
Well thanks, Don.

569
00:28:40.170 --> 00:28:42.920
It looks like we're coming
to the end of this episode.

570
00:28:42.920 --> 00:28:47.940
Remember we've talked about SNMP and
why you might use SNMP over things

571
00:28:47.940 --> 00:28:52.040
like the switch port analyzer and CIS log
and if you're not familiar with what we're

572
00:28:52.040 --> 00:28:55.630
talking about go back and watch some of
the earlier episodes and you'll see that.

573
00:28:55.630 --> 00:28:59.980
We also talked about the net flow analyzer
and actually identifying who it is,

574
00:28:59.980 --> 00:29:03.700
the culprit behind that
excessive bandwidth utilization.

575
00:29:03.700 --> 00:29:06.925
But looks like we're gonna go
into a part five of this episode.

576
00:29:06.925 --> 00:29:09.540
>> [LAUGH]
>> And we've got much more to come in

577
00:29:09.540 --> 00:29:13.270
our Troubleshooting Tools, but until then,
I've been your host Wesley Bryan.

578
00:29:13.270 --> 00:29:13.970
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

579
00:29:13.970 --> 00:29:15.416
>> And we'll see you next time.

580
00:29:15.416 --> 00:29:21.670
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Don and Wes continue their discussion on troubleshooting tools. They look at how to use the Embedded Event Manager(EEM). They discuss the type of events found in the EEM and how to monitor events. They will talk about creating actions that can be applied to the events that are detected. Theydemonstrate using telnet to troubleshoot protocols used to communicate between nodes.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Tools Part 5
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.372 --> 00:00:15.041
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.041 --> 00:00:20.150
We're glad that you have joined us
we are moving on in a part 5 of

4
00:00:20.150 --> 00:00:22.900
iOS troubleshooting tools and

5
00:00:22.900 --> 00:00:27.010
nobody better here to dive into
this topic with us than Don Pezet.

6
00:00:27.010 --> 00:00:28.260
Don, how're you doing today, sir?

7
00:00:28.260 --> 00:00:30.250
>> I'm doing great, Wes,
glad to be back on the show and

8
00:00:30.250 --> 00:00:33.232
ready to continue on with some of the
great troubleshooting tools we've seen.

9
00:00:33.232 --> 00:00:35.020
We're gonna cover one
of my favorites today,

10
00:00:35.020 --> 00:00:37.640
which is the embedded event manager.

11
00:00:37.640 --> 00:00:40.780
And if you've never heard of the EEM,
I don't blame you.

12
00:00:40.780 --> 00:00:42.810
It's not a very highly publicized feature,

13
00:00:42.810 --> 00:00:46.360
it's important in just about every
CISCO device that's out today.

14
00:00:46.360 --> 00:00:49.570
But it's one that a lot of people just
don't know about or don't mess with.

15
00:00:49.570 --> 00:00:52.270
It's kind of one of those unsung
heroes in the background.

16
00:00:52.270 --> 00:00:53.690
And what that EEM is, right?

17
00:00:53.690 --> 00:00:57.985
The Embedded Event Manager,
it's basically a service that runs in

18
00:00:57.985 --> 00:01:02.370
the background on your equipment and
it watches for stuff to happen.

19
00:01:02.370 --> 00:01:05.400
It says, all right,
let me see when some event occurs, right?

20
00:01:05.400 --> 00:01:06.810
That is the event part.

21
00:01:06.810 --> 00:01:10.390
And then take some kind
of action about it.

22
00:01:10.390 --> 00:01:12.730
The router or
the switch is kind of already doing that.

23
00:01:12.730 --> 00:01:13.790
Right?

24
00:01:13.790 --> 00:01:17.510
If an interface goes down and
a routes tied to that interface,

25
00:01:17.510 --> 00:01:19.900
it removes the route from
the routing table and

26
00:01:19.900 --> 00:01:23.360
it generates a log message that
says the interface went down.

27
00:01:23.360 --> 00:01:25.472
So those things are already built in and

28
00:01:25.472 --> 00:01:30.400
what Cisco's built in place is really
what 99% of the people need anyway.

29
00:01:30.400 --> 00:01:33.160
But with the EEM,
we can get really advanced.

30
00:01:33.160 --> 00:01:36.170
We can jump in and tell it to
monitor all sorts of cool stuff,

31
00:01:36.170 --> 00:01:40.470
to do all sorts of neat things and it's
really just limited by our imagination,

32
00:01:40.470 --> 00:01:41.720
whatever we come up with.

33
00:01:41.720 --> 00:01:44.140
And you can really build
some cool stuff with it.

34
00:01:44.140 --> 00:01:44.770
>> Well, that's awesome.

35
00:01:44.770 --> 00:01:47.040
So we've got a lot of stuff
that we can monitor, Don.

36
00:01:47.040 --> 00:01:50.270
When it comes to all these different
cool things that we can monitor,

37
00:01:50.270 --> 00:01:51.880
what's some of the types of
stuff that we can monitor?

38
00:01:51.880 --> 00:01:53.210
What can we see here?

39
00:01:53.210 --> 00:01:55.410
>> It's actually a pretty big list.

40
00:01:55.410 --> 00:01:58.000
Let me show you guys because it does vary
a little bit from equipment to equipment,

41
00:01:58.000 --> 00:01:59.310
so you always wanna test your device and

42
00:01:59.310 --> 00:02:03.270
see what it supports, but I I'll show
you here on this router that I've got.

43
00:02:03.270 --> 00:02:07.750
Basically on this system
if jump into my config

44
00:02:07.750 --> 00:02:11.720
well you actually have to start by
creating what's called an applet.

45
00:02:11.720 --> 00:02:15.800
The event manager, remember how I said
it runs as a service in the background?

46
00:02:15.800 --> 00:02:19.948
Well, each EEM thing that
you configure to monitor.

47
00:02:19.948 --> 00:02:22.630
[LAUGH] There's probably a better term for
it than that but each thing that

48
00:02:22.630 --> 00:02:26.560
you go to monitor basically creates its
own little service in the background.

49
00:02:26.560 --> 00:02:29.790
So you create what
are called EEM applets and

50
00:02:29.790 --> 00:02:32.280
each applet is monitoring
something different.

51
00:02:32.280 --> 00:02:37.870
And so I'm gonna create an applet here and
I'll just call it event manager applet.

52
00:02:37.870 --> 00:02:39.090
And you have to give it a name.

53
00:02:39.090 --> 00:02:41.210
And the name can be whatever you want.

54
00:02:41.210 --> 00:02:43.220
You normally name it based on
what it is you're gonna monitor.

55
00:02:43.220 --> 00:02:45.125
I'll just call mine eem-xample.

56
00:02:45.125 --> 00:02:49.660
Okay.
That's gonna create an applet, a service.

57
00:02:49.660 --> 00:02:51.700
And now I can tell it what to monitor.

58
00:02:51.700 --> 00:02:53.380
Now what we monitor for are events.

59
00:02:53.380 --> 00:02:55.400
We monitor for changes in the system.

60
00:02:55.400 --> 00:02:57.600
If something is just running like
normal we don't care about it.

61
00:02:57.600 --> 00:02:59.400
We want to know when there's a change.

62
00:02:59.400 --> 00:03:00.910
And so if you type event?

63
00:03:02.810 --> 00:03:05.800
You'll see a list of all
the things that you can monitor.

64
00:03:05.800 --> 00:03:08.780
And some of the stuff is really powerful,
some of it's kinda lame.

65
00:03:08.780 --> 00:03:10.490
But there's some good stuff in here.

66
00:03:10.490 --> 00:03:14.960
Some of the ones that I usually monitor,
things like counters, right?

67
00:03:14.960 --> 00:03:18.160
On every interface,
there's an error counter, right?

68
00:03:18.160 --> 00:03:21.070
Input out errors,
output errors, and that stuff.

69
00:03:21.070 --> 00:03:24.360
So I can actually monitor for
when those errors start to increase.

70
00:03:24.360 --> 00:03:25.940
And, then take some kind of action.

71
00:03:25.940 --> 00:03:28.800
I can monitor for interface event status,
if a link goes up or

72
00:03:28.800 --> 00:03:33.590
a link goes down, we can monitor our
SLA's, an IP SLA goes up or down or

73
00:03:33.590 --> 00:03:35.660
above a control limit or
below a control limit.

74
00:03:35.660 --> 00:03:39.330
We can monitor for
syslog events, snmp traps,

75
00:03:39.330 --> 00:03:44.270
tags, track objects, all of these
different things we can monitor them.

76
00:03:44.270 --> 00:03:47.870
And if they change,
we can do something about it.

77
00:03:47.870 --> 00:03:48.400
All right?

78
00:03:48.400 --> 00:03:53.220
So for example I might wanna monitor for
any time my configuration changes.

79
00:03:53.220 --> 00:03:54.430
Right?
Think about what happens

80
00:03:54.430 --> 00:03:55.930
is when your configuration changes.

81
00:03:55.930 --> 00:03:57.100
Right?
So I get in to config.

82
00:03:57.100 --> 00:03:57.790
I do some stuff.

83
00:03:57.790 --> 00:03:58.760
I get out.

84
00:03:58.760 --> 00:04:01.020
And when I get out, what happens?

85
00:04:01.020 --> 00:04:03.230
A little log message is generated, right?

86
00:04:03.230 --> 00:04:06.760
It generates a syslog message to let
me know that the system was modified.

87
00:04:06.760 --> 00:04:08.420
That somebody was in configuration.

88
00:04:08.420 --> 00:04:11.380
Right.
So what I can do is I can monitor for

89
00:04:11.380 --> 00:04:13.910
when this message is displayed,
I'm just gonna look for

90
00:04:13.910 --> 00:04:17.210
right here where it says
percent SYS-5-CONFIG_I,

91
00:04:17.210 --> 00:04:22.770
that lets me know it's a system message
and somebody went into configuration.

92
00:04:22.770 --> 00:04:27.420
So I can watch Syslog for
any time that this message is generated.

93
00:04:27.420 --> 00:04:29.820
And we can generate
an alert based on that.

94
00:04:29.820 --> 00:04:35.720
So I could say something like event
manager applet eem-config-change, right?

95
00:04:35.720 --> 00:04:39.420
So I'm gonna create
a configuration change applet.

96
00:04:39.420 --> 00:04:41.750
And I'm gonna monitor for an event.

97
00:04:41.750 --> 00:04:42.990
It's a syslog event.

98
00:04:42.990 --> 00:04:46.450
And I'm gonna look for the pattern.

99
00:04:46.450 --> 00:04:51.594
And the pattern I'm gonna look for
is sys-5-config_i.

100
00:04:51.594 --> 00:04:57.640
So any time I see that message in my
syslog, I wanna do something about it.

101
00:04:57.640 --> 00:05:02.390
>> Very good, so we can monitor and see if
some kind of system configuration changes.

102
00:05:02.390 --> 00:05:03.740
But, are our hands tied on that one?

103
00:05:03.740 --> 00:05:05.740
Is there anything that we can implement,

104
00:05:05.740 --> 00:05:08.790
any kind of action we can perform
if we do notice something changes?

105
00:05:08.790 --> 00:05:10.620
>> The accent's kind of
the most important part.

106
00:05:10.620 --> 00:05:15.590
If I stop here, it's gonna monitor
it anytime that message is logged in

107
00:05:15.590 --> 00:05:19.562
the syslog it's gonna recognize it and
then do absolutely nothing about it.

108
00:05:19.562 --> 00:05:23.956
>> [LAUGH] So what I've done here is semi
pointless cuz we already had the event log

109
00:05:23.956 --> 00:05:25.160
mesage or syslog message.

110
00:05:25.160 --> 00:05:27.060
So now I need to take an action.

111
00:05:27.060 --> 00:05:31.090
And remember how I showed you guys if you
do event?, you can see all the stuff that

112
00:05:31.090 --> 00:05:36.982
you can monitor
>> Well if you do action?

113
00:05:36.982 --> 00:05:39.420
Well if you type it right,
you don't get a whole lot.

114
00:05:39.420 --> 00:05:40.310
There we go.

115
00:05:40.310 --> 00:05:42.650
Because each action gets a name.

116
00:05:42.650 --> 00:05:44.890
When we monitor something,
we only monitor one thing.

117
00:05:44.890 --> 00:05:45.390
Right.

118
00:05:45.390 --> 00:05:48.210
Each EEM applet monitors one thing.

119
00:05:48.210 --> 00:05:50.509
Mine's monitoring for
that one syslog message.

120
00:05:51.560 --> 00:05:55.630
>> But
each applet can have more than one action.

121
00:05:55.630 --> 00:05:58.240
And so we have to give the action a name.

122
00:05:58.240 --> 00:06:01.200
And you can name it whatever you want,
but I'll tell you guys,

123
00:06:01.200 --> 00:06:04.220
in the places that I learn from and

124
00:06:04.220 --> 00:06:07.990
what you'll see across the internet,
is almost everybody uses numbers.

125
00:06:07.990 --> 00:06:11.570
We use numbers because we can
kind of sort by those numbers and

126
00:06:11.570 --> 00:06:13.600
get a nice little order going to things.

127
00:06:13.600 --> 00:06:14.690
But you don't have to use numbers.

128
00:06:14.690 --> 00:06:15.910
You can use names if you want.

129
00:06:15.910 --> 00:06:18.210
So it's really asking for a label.

130
00:06:18.210 --> 00:06:21.630
And so if I'm gonna take an action,
my first action I'll normally do 1.0.

131
00:06:21.630 --> 00:06:22.170
Right.

132
00:06:22.170 --> 00:06:23.440
This is actually 1.0.

133
00:06:23.440 --> 00:06:27.440
And later, I might do an action 2.0, but
then I can do an action 1.5 if I wanted to

134
00:06:27.440 --> 00:06:30.010
stick one in the middle,
cuz I left a little bit of room for me.

135
00:06:30.010 --> 00:06:32.110
Right.
Or you could say action 10, 20, 30, 40.

136
00:06:32.110 --> 00:06:34.620
Or like we do with ACLs, right,

137
00:06:34.620 --> 00:06:37.030
always skipping in increments
of 10 to leave room in-between.

138
00:06:37.030 --> 00:06:40.160
So that's kind of what I'm doing here,
all right.

139
00:06:40.160 --> 00:06:44.310
And now, if I do a question mark,
I'll see all the actions I can take and

140
00:06:44.310 --> 00:06:45.690
you'll see there's a lot.

141
00:06:45.690 --> 00:06:47.860
There's a lot of actions that we can do.

142
00:06:47.860 --> 00:06:52.570
Some of them are programmatic,
appending data to a variable,

143
00:06:52.570 --> 00:06:54.840
breaking out of a conditional loop, right?

144
00:06:54.840 --> 00:06:58.000
So we can actually do some
complex logic in our actions.

145
00:06:58.000 --> 00:07:00.500
But other ones are a little
more straightforward.

146
00:07:00.500 --> 00:07:03.660
We can force a switchover.

147
00:07:03.660 --> 00:07:04.180
Right?

148
00:07:04.180 --> 00:07:06.950
If we've got some kind of like,
HSRP cluster or whatever,

149
00:07:06.950 --> 00:07:08.490
we can cause that to trigger.

150
00:07:08.490 --> 00:07:10.150
You can run commands.

151
00:07:10.150 --> 00:07:12.080
This CLI, this is the one I normally use.

152
00:07:12.080 --> 00:07:13.260
Execute a CLI command.

153
00:07:13.260 --> 00:07:16.380
So we can cause the router
to do something.

154
00:07:16.380 --> 00:07:21.870
If I'm detecting attack traffic for
example, I might want to add a line

155
00:07:21.870 --> 00:07:26.130
to an ACL that blocks the IP address
that's generating the attack traffic.

156
00:07:26.130 --> 00:07:29.210
Now it's not just an action,
it's a security countermeasure.

157
00:07:29.210 --> 00:07:30.620
Right?
We're actually getting in there and

158
00:07:30.620 --> 00:07:31.460
making changes.

159
00:07:31.460 --> 00:07:34.400
This is kind of one of the key
pieces that helps Cisco's self

160
00:07:34.400 --> 00:07:35.770
healing network function.

161
00:07:35.770 --> 00:07:39.250
All the protections they have in there.

162
00:07:39.250 --> 00:07:42.450
But you'll see a lot of this stuff
is tied to handling variables.

163
00:07:42.450 --> 00:07:45.710
We've got things like foreach loops for

164
00:07:45.710 --> 00:07:49.890
as we iterate through some kind
of outputs to take an action.

165
00:07:49.890 --> 00:07:51.990
You've got error handling and so on.

166
00:07:51.990 --> 00:07:55.240
It can really get bery programmatic.

167
00:07:55.240 --> 00:07:57.771
Or you can do simple things,
like reload the system, right?

168
00:07:57.771 --> 00:08:01.621
If something goes completely wrong,
reboot, that solves everything, right?

169
00:08:01.621 --> 00:08:03.052
So we've got that option but

170
00:08:03.052 --> 00:08:07.411
you'll see there's some really cool stuff
in here You can generate syslog messages.

171
00:08:07.411 --> 00:08:10.131
You can turn tracking on or off.

172
00:08:10.131 --> 00:08:11.980
You can do a lot of neat stuff.

173
00:08:11.980 --> 00:08:15.540
So for action 1.0, I might choose to do,
well here, I'll do cli.

174
00:08:15.540 --> 00:08:17.010
I've gotta be honest with you guys.

175
00:08:17.010 --> 00:08:18.120
I'm not a programmer.

176
00:08:18.120 --> 00:08:21.930
So I recognize the value and all the
various programming options that we saw up

177
00:08:21.930 --> 00:08:25.270
here, but 99% of the time,
I'm jumping to cli.

178
00:08:25.270 --> 00:08:26.440
I wanna take some cli action.

179
00:08:26.440 --> 00:08:29.780
So if I see that somebody
did a configuration change,

180
00:08:29.780 --> 00:08:32.600
what I wanna do,
is I wanna grab that data.

181
00:08:32.600 --> 00:08:33.510
What did they change?

182

00:19:02.130 --> 00:19:05.250
So that's basically how the EEM works,

371
00:19:05.250 --> 00:19:08.030
is it takes these actions based on

372
00:19:08.030 --> 00:19:10.760
So for you as an admin,
if you're monitoring routers,

373
00:19:10.760 --> 00:19:15.060
you're monitoring switches this can
notify you of the problem immediately.

374
00:19:15.060 --> 00:19:17.360
You don't have to wait for
somebody to find it or

375
00:19:17.360 --> 00:19:19.070
even have third party monitoring software.

376
00:19:19.070 --> 00:19:20.120
This can just notify you.

00:19:20.120 --> 00:19:20.860
Shoot you an email.

378
00:19:20.860 --> 00:19:24.370
It can log to a syslog server and
do all sorts of really cool stuff

379
00:19:24.370 --> 00:19:28.400
to let you know that it's happening, and
from there you can start to take action.

00:19:28.400 --> 00:19:33.430
It's one thing to get an email that says,

00:19:33.430 --> 00:19:37.000
But it's a lot nicer if that email

as well as who was connected at the time.

00:19:38.680 --> 00:19:40.750
And now you can say, oh yeah that

00:19:41.830 --> 00:19:43.360

00:19:43.360 --> 00:19:47.500
Because remember that like passwords in

00:19:47.500 --> 00:19:51.320

00:19:51.320 --> 00:19:54.170

your email's being sent in plain text.

00:19:54.170 --> 00:19:55.820
Somebody can intercept it and
get those passwords.

389
00:19:55.820 --> 00:19:59.190
So you do need to take a little care
with what you send out in these.

00:19:59.190 --> 00:20:02.540
But it is a nice piece of information to

00:20:42.420 --> 00:20:47.060
This is telling me it got an error when it
went to send email to the SMTP server, and

404
00:20:47.060 --> 00:20:51.060
it's telling me,
error in reply from the SMTP server.

405
00:20:51.060 --> 00:20:53.510
Now I could turn on some debugs and
go and check that out, but

406
00:20:53.510 --> 00:20:56.440
I would have to cause whatever
this failure was to do it.

407
00:20:56.440 --> 00:20:59.200
Now in my case, I'd just have to go in and
out of configs, no big deal.

408
00:20:59.200 --> 00:21:02.010
But if you were monitoring for an
interface to go down, I would have to go

409
00:21:02.010 --> 00:21:05.000
and shut the interface down and
regenerate this for the debugs to work.

410
00:21:05.000 --> 00:21:07.370
So instead of using debugs,
I could just use Telnet.

411
00:21:07.370 --> 00:21:11.130
And with Telnet, you specify
a server you want to connect to.

412
00:21:11.130 --> 00:21:13.010
So like I'll specify that email server.

413
00:21:14.530 --> 00:21:18.210
And you can then specify a port number.

414
00:21:18.210 --> 00:21:21.300
And this is the part that's
really gonna help us.

415
00:21:21.300 --> 00:21:23.520
You know, actually it doesn't
show it in here, does it?

416
00:21:23.520 --> 00:21:24.270
Is it an undocumented?

417
00:21:24.270 --> 00:21:25.680
I didn't think it was
an undocumented feature.

418
00:21:25.680 --> 00:21:28.250
But yeah,
you can type a port number of it.

419
00:21:28.250 --> 00:21:28.910
So I can say 25.

420
00:21:28.910 --> 00:21:33.100
I want to connect to that
IP address on port 25.

421
00:21:33.100 --> 00:21:38.100
And a lot of protocols like HTTP and
IMAP, POP3,

422
00:21:39.410 --> 00:21:44.290
SMTP, if they're not encrypted, you can
just connect right to them with Telnet and

423
00:21:44.290 --> 00:21:48.300
if you know the commands to issue you
can simulate the whole communication.

424
00:21:48.300 --> 00:21:51.390
So if I Telnet,
I'm connected to that mail server.

425
00:21:51.390 --> 00:21:53.840
So I know I can get there,
I'm not being blocked by an ACL.

426
00:21:53.840 --> 00:21:55.291
There's not a firewall that's blocking me.

427
00:21:55.291 --> 00:21:59.344
Cuz I know at home, I have a cable
connection to our cable company, and

428
00:21:59.344 --> 00:22:01.420
they block connections port 25.

429
00:22:01.420 --> 00:22:03.000
They will not let you connect.

430
00:22:03.000 --> 00:22:04.930
But here, I'm connecting.

431
00:22:04.930 --> 00:22:07.940
And I can try to do a hello.

432
00:22:07.940 --> 00:22:12.690
I'll just say on work
station.lab.itpro.tv, and there you go.

433
00:22:12.690 --> 00:22:17.060
It took my hello, right,
and I can say mail from.

434
00:22:17.060 --> 00:22:18.431
And who did I say I was from?

435
00:22:18.431 --> 00:22:26.331
I think I just did like
GNV-C2821@lab.itpro.tv.

436
00:22:26.331 --> 00:22:27.911
All right, and so
that's who the mail's from.

437
00:22:27.911 --> 00:22:29.400
It says that's okay.

438
00:22:29.400 --> 00:22:36.170
And I did receipt to and
we're sending that to Don@itpro.tv.

439
00:22:36.170 --> 00:22:38.300
It says that's okay, all right.

440
00:22:38.300 --> 00:22:43.700
Let me start to throw some data in here
and I'll say subject this is a test.

441
00:22:43.700 --> 00:22:45.420
Oops, which I did typo.

442
00:22:45.420 --> 00:22:46.480
This is a test.

443
00:22:46.480 --> 00:22:50.400
Very, very exciting and
queued for delivery.

444
00:22:50.400 --> 00:22:51.020
All right.

445
00:22:51.020 --> 00:22:53.530
So I was not only able to
connect to the server,

446
00:22:53.530 --> 00:22:57.299
I was able to generate an email and
by doing that

447
00:22:58.430 --> 00:23:02.670
I was completely successful, so I actually
don't see what the problem is on this one.

448
00:23:02.670 --> 00:23:06.710
So now is where we have to start tweaking
a little bit, and we can use debugs.

449
00:23:06.710 --> 00:23:13.645
And with the debugs, we can monitor the
SMTP part of the embedded event manager.

450
00:23:13.645 --> 00:23:15.485
We can also just go and
try and make some changes.

451
00:23:15.485 --> 00:23:17.915
I mentioned that we had to
put those dots before and

452
00:23:17.915 --> 00:23:20.455
after our addresses cuz
they're regular expressions.

453
00:23:20.455 --> 00:23:21.875
It may not be interpreting those right.

454
00:23:21.875 --> 00:23:24.665
So I can always jump in and
try it without those.

455
00:23:24.665 --> 00:23:27.155
We shouldn't have to, but
I have seen that before.

456
00:23:27.155 --> 00:23:31.685
So let me jump in there,
and we'll test that out.

457
00:23:31.685 --> 00:23:34.230
All right.

458
00:23:34.230 --> 00:23:40.293
So I'm gonna get back into
my applet that I made.

459
00:23:40.293 --> 00:23:43.857
And I'm just gonna remove the,

460
00:23:43.857 --> 00:23:48.083
oh it wasn't action 7.0, was it?

461
00:23:48.083 --> 00:23:50.461
It was 6.0, that's my problem.

462
00:23:50.461 --> 00:23:55.924
So I'm gonna pull that line back up And
I'm gonna just kinda remove it and

463
00:23:55.924 --> 00:23:59.570
we'll try with that rdots, and see.

464
00:23:59.570 --> 00:24:02.340
But that is exactly not what I wanted.

465
00:24:02.340 --> 00:24:03.650
Now it looks more than one line.

466
00:24:03.650 --> 00:24:05.040
See this is where we start that has some

467
00:24:06.900 --> 00:24:10.620
tough parts with editing
inside the command line.

468
00:24:10.620 --> 00:24:13.440
So sometime you've got to copy and
paste into a separate file so

469
00:24:13.440 --> 00:24:16.610
you can get this stuff
kind of set up correctly.

470
00:24:16.610 --> 00:24:17.540
There we go.

471
00:24:17.540 --> 00:24:18.890
All right, so I'm going to correct this.

472
00:24:18.890 --> 00:24:21.780
I'm just going to remove
these dots out of here and

473
00:24:21.780 --> 00:24:23.410
we'll see if it gets happy with that.

474
00:24:24.570 --> 00:24:25.530
Then we'll retry it.

475
00:24:25.530 --> 00:24:28.960
This is basically a part of
the troubleshooting process because we

476
00:24:28.960 --> 00:24:31.060
can't necessarily see these
things that are running.

477
00:24:31.060 --> 00:24:34.620
When it runs the command line it's
doing it in the background and

478
00:24:34.620 --> 00:24:36.170
we don't see that.

479
00:24:36.170 --> 00:24:38.610
That's all happening,
just behind the scenes.

480
00:24:38.610 --> 00:24:41.910
So it's very easy to
lose some of this stuff.

481
00:24:41.910 --> 00:24:46.700
So I'm gonna remove that action and
then I'm gonna just paste this back in.

482
00:24:48.830 --> 00:24:50.120
There we go.

483
00:24:50.120 --> 00:24:51.920
And let me just pull that back up.

484
00:24:53.010 --> 00:24:55.510
Now I can see that 6.0.

485
00:24:55.510 --> 00:24:57.820
Basically the same thing
except I removed those dots,

486
00:24:57.820 --> 00:24:59.760
and actually there it succeeded.

487
00:24:59.760 --> 00:25:02.810
So it looks like it wasn't happy
with my regular expression dots.

488
00:25:02.810 --> 00:25:07.570
So I've got it fired up here and
I didn't get an error on 6.0, and

489
00:25:07.570 --> 00:25:11.860
I can see here is a log message being
generated saying EEM email sent.

490
00:25:11.860 --> 00:25:15.130
And let me just dork out here,
and on my watch sure enough,

491
00:25:15.130 --> 00:25:20.560
I got an email from GNVC2821 letting
me know the configuration change.

492
00:25:20.560 --> 00:25:21.850
And if I were to open that email,

493
00:25:21.850 --> 00:25:26.330
I guess a smarter me would open it on
a desktop client or something, but

494
00:25:26.330 --> 00:25:31.570
if I open it, what I should see in that
email is the output of the command line.

495
00:25:31.570 --> 00:25:34.850
And the information that was put
inside of it, and we'll have it.

496
00:25:34.850 --> 00:25:37.660
So that's now up and
working and were in business.

497
00:25:37.660 --> 00:25:41.600
Now if I do a show log,
hopefully I see at the end of it.

498
00:25:41.600 --> 00:25:43.930
There it is, email sent.

499
00:25:43.930 --> 00:25:48.340
It's the Embedded Event Manager now doing
it's job, sending us it's information and

500
00:25:48.340 --> 00:25:50.640
we got a great system to self monitoring.

501
00:25:50.640 --> 00:25:53.460
When someone goes in and changes
something, going to send me the data.

502
00:25:53.460 --> 00:25:54.270
>> Very good, very good.

503
00:25:54.270 --> 00:25:58.910
Lots of good information here so we been
talking about the Embedded Event Manager.

504
00:25:58.910 --> 00:26:01.810
Talked about monitoring and
setting the criteria for

505
00:26:01.810 --> 00:26:03.060
the things that you want to monitor.

506
00:26:03.060 --> 00:26:06.010
And also the actions that
can be taken based on

507
00:26:06.010 --> 00:26:07.890
the criteria of what you are monitoring.

508
00:26:07.890 --> 00:26:10.055
We've also looked at using Telnet.

509
00:26:10.055 --> 00:26:13.280
Telnet's test protocols as well,
which is an interesting concept.

510
00:26:13.280 --> 00:26:14.662
An oldie but a goodie there.

511
00:26:14.662 --> 00:26:19.120
Don, do you have any parting words of
wisdom based on what we're talking about.

512
00:26:19.120 --> 00:26:20.350
>> That's really it.

513
00:26:20.350 --> 00:26:24.300
And as far as trouble shooting tools
what we've seen over the last five parts

514
00:26:24.300 --> 00:26:28.590
are really a whole range of tools that
you can implement to do proactive and

515
00:26:28.590 --> 00:26:31.820
reactive trouble shooting
depending on you environment.

516
00:26:31.820 --> 00:26:36.390
We're gonna be shifting focus after
this episode and moving into actually

517
00:26:36.390 --> 00:26:39.590
troubleshooting particular areas of the
network that are having problems and we're

518
00:26:39.590 --> 00:26:42.260
gonna be using these same tools that you
guys have seen over the last five parts.

519
00:26:42.260 --> 00:26:43.640
So that's why I wanted
to spend time on these,

520
00:26:43.640 --> 00:26:46.710
made sure you got exposed to them and
got a chance to see what those were.

521
00:26:46.710 --> 00:26:47.810
>> All right, very good.

522
00:26:47.810 --> 00:26:51.170
Well it looks like we're coming to
the end of this episode but stick around,

523
00:26:51.170 --> 00:26:54.250
cuz we got a lot more to come but
until we see you next time

524
00:26:54.250 --> 00:26:55.980
>> I've been your host Wes Ryan.

525
00:26:55.980 --> 00:26:56.950
>> And I'm Dom Pezet.

526
00:26:56.950 --> 00:26:59.511
>> We'll see you next time.

527
00:26:59.511 --> 00:27:06.370
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Don and Wes talk about using a systematic approach to addressing problems with in a network by applying a troubleshooting methodology. They show you how to use the Open Systems Interconnect(OSI) and TCP/IP models as a guide to troubleshooting problems inside your network. They discuss how to maintain consistency through change documentation.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Methods
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.790 --> 00:00:16.690
Hello and welcome back to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.690 --> 00:00:19.670
I'm Wes Bryan, your host with the most,
back with the gentleman that I

4
00:00:19.670 --> 00:00:22.330
swear doesn't have DNA in
his bloodstream anymore.

5
00:00:22.330 --> 00:00:23.825
He's replaced it with binary.

6
00:00:23.825 --> 00:00:25.798
Mr. Don Pezet, how are we doing today?

7
00:00:25.798 --> 00:00:28.080
>> I am doing great, Wes,
glad to be back in this show and

8
00:00:28.080 --> 00:00:31.190
to jump into another episode
of CCP routing and switching.

9
00:00:31.190 --> 00:00:32.380
Particularly troubleshooting, right?

10
00:00:32.380 --> 00:00:34.460
That's kinda what we're
focusing on on this series.

11
00:00:34.460 --> 00:00:39.040
And we're gonna kick this show off talking
about some troubleshooting methodologies,

12
00:00:39.040 --> 00:00:43.340
and then really, this isn't the show
we're gonna jump into here's some tools.

13
00:00:43.340 --> 00:00:44.570
And we're gonna dig into this protocol.

14
00:00:44.570 --> 00:00:48.270
We're gonna start really high level with
the process that Cisco expects us to

15
00:00:48.270 --> 00:00:49.240
follow.

16
00:00:49.240 --> 00:00:50.970
As we move through
troubleshooting a problem,

17
00:00:50.970 --> 00:00:52.670
it ultimately resolving a problem.

18
00:00:52.670 --> 00:00:55.190
Because that's what this
series is all about.

19
00:00:55.190 --> 00:00:59.700
Now, when you ask yourself, okay, how do
I approach troubleshooting a problem?

20
00:00:59.700 --> 00:01:03.660
Most people have kind of an intuitive way,
a way you've learned throughout life,

21
00:01:03.660 --> 00:01:05.890
and it probably works just fine for you.

22
00:01:05.890 --> 00:01:06.990
And that's great.

23
00:01:06.990 --> 00:01:09.808
But on the exam,
they expect you to know a certain way.

24
00:01:09.808 --> 00:01:12.750
And Cisco's gonna changed
a bit over the years and

25
00:01:12.750 --> 00:01:17.490
what we've kinda settled on now is
a model that conforms with ITIL.

26
00:01:17.490 --> 00:01:21.815
And now if you haven't heard of ITIL
that's the Information technology industry

27
00:01:21.815 --> 00:01:26.025
library or ITIL, it was developed by
the British government as a way for

28
00:01:26.025 --> 00:01:30.045
IT companies to kind of properly manage
themselves, to ensure that they're doing

29
00:01:30.045 --> 00:01:34.165
the right types of record keeping, and
operations and management practices, and

30
00:01:34.165 --> 00:01:38.010
that they're basically trying to
improve their odds of success.

31
00:01:38.010 --> 00:01:39.460
It's not something everybody follows.

32
00:01:39.460 --> 00:01:42.210
Here in the United States it's pretty
popular on the west coast, but

33
00:01:42.210 --> 00:01:44.780
over here on the east coast you
don't see it all that often, but

34
00:01:44.780 --> 00:01:48.270
more IT companies are starting
to follow this methodology and

35
00:01:48.270 --> 00:01:52.055
so Cisco said if we want to create
a consistent troubleshooting methodology.

36
00:01:52.055 --> 00:01:55.870
Must just base it on ITIL,
it's what people are doing already.

37
00:01:55.870 --> 00:01:58.410
So, if you've been working
in an ITIL environment

38
00:01:58.410 --> 00:02:01.050
then you're actually probably
already set up for this.

39
00:02:01.050 --> 00:02:04.250
>> All right, so what you're saying here
is we've gotta have some kind of method to

40
00:02:04.250 --> 00:02:08.000
the madness, so to apply a method
to that madness where do we start?

41
00:02:08.000 --> 00:02:10.710
>> All right, well there's a few
places you could start and

42
00:02:10.710 --> 00:02:11.410
there's one that I like to,

43
00:02:11.410 --> 00:02:15.250
I'm actually, a little off the beaten
path because the ITIL troubleshooting

44
00:02:15.250 --> 00:02:18.260
methodology that I mentioned, they
didn't create that from scratch either.

45
00:02:18.260 --> 00:02:22.195
That's actually based off of some
other things that kinda goes way back.

46
00:02:22.195 --> 00:02:26.425
For those of you who have studied project
management there was a guy named Deming

47
00:02:26.425 --> 00:02:31.400
who, this is way back right, we're talking
about half a decade or half a century ago.

48
00:02:31.400 --> 00:02:34.132
Where he basically came up with
this process improvement model and

49
00:02:34.132 --> 00:02:37.725
it centered around this idea of four
steps that you always go through,

50
00:02:37.725 --> 00:02:42.780
right which is plan,
do, check, act, right.

51
00:02:42.780 --> 00:02:45.030
We plan our network.

52
00:02:45.030 --> 00:02:49.111
We plan what we're gonna be doing,
and then we do it.

53
00:02:49.111 --> 00:02:51.370
You never just jump in and
start doing something.

54
00:02:51.370 --> 00:02:54.950
You always have a plan first, right
this paper idea of what's gonna happen.

55
00:02:54.950 --> 00:02:58.460
And then you do it, and
after you've done it you check.

56
00:02:58.460 --> 00:03:01.710
You check to make sure that things
actually went according to the plan from

57
00:03:01.710 --> 00:03:02.810
the beginning.

58
00:03:02.810 --> 00:03:05.380
And then once all that's done,
you planned it,

59
00:03:05.380 --> 00:03:08.030
you did it,
you checked it to make sure it was right.

60
00:03:08.030 --> 00:03:11.930
Then you act and the act part is kind
of where troubleshooting falls in.

61
00:03:11.930 --> 00:03:14.900
Act is now you use whatever
it is you just implemented.

62
00:03:14.900 --> 00:03:17.880
So, maybe I need a new router
in my environment so I plan.

63
00:03:17.880 --> 00:03:19.360
What's the right router for me?

64
00:03:19.360 --> 00:03:21.570
I go out and I select,
I find the right one.

65
00:03:21.570 --> 00:03:24.680
And I figure out how I wanna
configure it and all that.

66
00:03:24.680 --> 00:03:27.860
Then I do,
I implement that router in my environment.

67
00:03:27.860 --> 00:03:30.160
I take my old router out,
I put the new router in.

68
00:03:30.160 --> 00:03:33.350
I put its configuration on there and
now I'm running.

69
00:03:33.350 --> 00:03:34.540
And then I check.

70
00:03:34.540 --> 00:03:38.790
I check to make sure that everything is
working the way that it's supposed to be.

71
00:03:38.790 --> 00:03:40.370
And after that we act.

72
00:03:40.370 --> 00:03:41.850
The router is running.

73
00:03:41.850 --> 00:03:45.980
If something goes wrong, we have to
take action to correct it, right.

74
00:03:45.980 --> 00:03:51.610
Now, that is plan, do, check, act in
terms of implementing something new.

75
00:03:51.610 --> 00:03:54.820
But, once it's up and
running and a problem happens,

76
00:03:54.820 --> 00:03:56.140
we really do the same thing again.

77
00:03:56.140 --> 00:03:59.530
We plan there's something
wrong with the network.

78
00:03:59.530 --> 00:04:00.060
What is it?

79
00:04:00.060 --> 00:04:00.820
I've gotta figure it out.

80
00:04:00.820 --> 00:04:02.950
I've gotta come up with a plan
of how i'm gonna fix this.

81
00:04:02.950 --> 00:04:07.520
I've gotta find out what the problem
is first and then I can plan the fix.

82
00:04:07.520 --> 00:04:08.670
And then do.

83
00:04:08.670 --> 00:04:10.820
I do the fix.

84
00:04:10.820 --> 00:04:14.880
And then check I check to see
if the fix actually worked.

85
00:04:14.880 --> 00:04:18.130
Because I'll tell you guys a lot
of times we implement a change and

86
00:04:18.130 --> 00:04:19.780
it doesn't fix the problem.

87
00:04:19.780 --> 00:04:22.770
And what you just did is
broke something else.

88
00:04:22.770 --> 00:04:24.540
And that's a really bad thing.

89
00:04:24.540 --> 00:04:27.150
So, we wanna make sure that we check and

90
00:04:27.150 --> 00:04:29.870
assuming that everything's working the way
that it's supposed to then we act.

91
00:04:29.870 --> 00:04:32.580
We're back to normal things kind a run,
and off they go.

92
00:04:32.580 --> 00:04:34.320
So, the pretty straight forward process.

93
00:04:34.320 --> 00:04:36.390
One you can use in pretty
much use in any walk of life.

94
00:04:36.390 --> 00:04:36.910
>> All right.

95
00:04:36.910 --> 00:04:39.450
Very good.
So, one of the things I'm thinking here is

96
00:04:39.450 --> 00:04:42.130
over the years I've seen a few
different troubleshooting models.

97
00:04:42.130 --> 00:04:43.320
Comp T is one that has.

98
00:04:43.320 --> 00:04:44.650
Novell's got one out there.

99
00:04:44.650 --> 00:04:46.660
Now, with this troubleshooting model,

100
00:04:46.660 --> 00:04:49.860
is this gonna be something that we're
really gonna see inside of the exam,

101
00:04:49.860 --> 00:04:53.230
this systematic approach and
something that we're gonna need to know?

102
00:04:53.230 --> 00:04:54.025
>> It is and it isn't.

103
00:04:54.025 --> 00:04:55.740
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, remember that the exam,

104
00:04:55.740 --> 00:04:59.950
it's only got 12 to 25 questions,
a really short exam.

105
00:04:59.950 --> 00:05:02.930
So, they hit hard and
heavy on the troubleshooting.

106
00:05:02.930 --> 00:05:05.670
You're probably not gonna see a lot
of questions on the methodology side.

107
00:05:05.670 --> 00:05:06.180
Right?

108
00:05:06.180 --> 00:05:07.700
But you might see one.

109
00:05:07.700 --> 00:05:10.820
But even if you see one,
if you've only got a 12 question exam,

110
00:05:10.820 --> 00:05:13.270
that 1 question's a pretty
important part of it, right.

111
00:05:13.270 --> 00:05:14.800
So, you definitely wanna be aware of this.

112
00:05:14.800 --> 00:05:18.112
I think on the official exam objectives,
which I've got around here somewhere,

113
00:05:18.112 --> 00:05:19.264
it's like 5% of the exam.

114
00:05:19.264 --> 00:05:21.554
So we're not talking about
a huge percentage, again,

115
00:05:21.554 --> 00:05:23.190
that falls in this category.

116
00:05:23.190 --> 00:05:25.990
But, as you approach
the problems on the exam,

117
00:05:25.990 --> 00:05:28.750
if you approach them this way,
you'll be fine.

118
00:05:28.750 --> 00:05:30.681
Let me tell you what happens if you
don't follow the plan, all right.

119
00:05:30.681 --> 00:05:31.790
I'll give you a great example.

120
00:05:31.790 --> 00:05:34.760
Most of you guys will probably
be able to relate to this story.

121
00:05:34.760 --> 00:05:37.150
Have you every worked with somebody,
cause I'm sure it wasn't you, right.

122
00:05:37.150 --> 00:05:41.006
So, I've got a friend that they see a
problem on a server, they see a problem on

123
00:05:41.006 --> 00:05:44.760
a router, they see a problem on a switch,
and they start troubleshooting.

124
00:05:44.760 --> 00:05:47.120
Well I think it might be this,
let me change the setting.

125
00:05:47.120 --> 00:05:47.970
That didn't fix it.

126
00:05:47.970 --> 00:05:49.440
Maybe it's this, I change the setting.

127
00:05:49.440 --> 00:05:50.090
No that wasn't it.

128
00:05:50.090 --> 00:05:51.800
Let me change this other setting.

129
00:05:51.800 --> 00:05:55.120
And they change four or five things and
all of a sudden the problem is fixed.

130
00:05:55.120 --> 00:05:58.660
And they say yep I'm done,
let's call it a day, I'm heading home.

131
00:05:58.660 --> 00:05:59.380
Right?

132
00:05:59.380 --> 00:06:01.310
Well they change five things.

133
00:06:01.310 --> 00:06:03.140
Which of the five things fixed it?

134
00:06:03.140 --> 00:06:04.450
Was it the last one?

135
00:06:04.450 --> 00:06:07.680
Right, if it was the last one, what
about the first four changes that I did?

136
00:06:07.680 --> 00:06:10.380
The first four changes
I shouldn't have done,

137
00:06:10.380 --> 00:06:12.500
they might have broken something else.

138
00:06:12.500 --> 00:06:15.570
And so on the exam you might be
working through a problem and

139
00:06:15.570 --> 00:06:19.940
you're just doing change after change
after change trying to fix the problem and

140
00:06:19.940 --> 00:06:23.940
you might fix the problem,
but cause another problem.

141
00:06:23.940 --> 00:06:26.070
And if you do that you
get the question wrong.

142
00:06:26.070 --> 00:06:28.010
You might as well have not fixed
the problem in the first place cause

143
00:06:28.010 --> 00:06:28.930
you just caused another one.

144
00:06:28.930 --> 00:06:32.820
So, we've gotta make sure that the changes
we implement actually fix the problem.

145
00:06:32.820 --> 00:06:34.710
That's part of a check process, right.

146
00:06:34.710 --> 00:06:35.860
Plan, do, check, act.

147
00:06:35.860 --> 00:06:38.830
We check to make sure we
actually fixed the problem.

148
00:06:38.830 --> 00:06:42.330
And if we didn't fix it,
we've gotta make a decision.

149
00:06:42.330 --> 00:06:44.975
Do we roll back the change we made?

150
00:06:44.975 --> 00:06:46.050
Cause it didn't fix the problem.

151
00:06:46.050 --> 00:06:47.380
Maybe this need to take that out.

152
00:06:47.380 --> 00:06:51.386
Or if there's a second fix I needed
to put in place that combines with

153
00:06:51.386 --> 00:06:52.920
the first to fix it.

154
00:06:52.920 --> 00:06:54.130
I need to understand that.

155
00:06:54.130 --> 00:06:58.381
I need to understand that every
change I make has consequences.

156
00:06:58.381 --> 00:07:01.040
A great example and Wes,
I'm sure you've seen this.

157
00:07:01.040 --> 00:07:02.520
I complain about this all the time.

158
00:07:02.520 --> 00:07:05.080
I complain about a lot of things,
but this one in particular.

159
00:07:05.080 --> 00:07:07.450
If you have a problem on your computer,
right?

160
00:07:07.450 --> 00:07:10.090
Mac, Linux, Windows,
it doesn't really matter.

161
00:07:10.090 --> 00:07:13.620
And you go onto the Internet and
you do a search, like this isn't working.

162
00:07:13.620 --> 00:07:19.220
You can, in the first ten Google results
you'll find somebody in Windows it's UAC,

163
00:07:19.220 --> 00:07:20.180
user access control.

164
00:07:20.180 --> 00:07:23.570
They'll say oh, just turn off UAC and
then it'll work just fine.

165
00:07:23.570 --> 00:07:28.090
On Linux you'll see where they say like
SE Linux, just turn off SE Linux and

166
00:07:28.090 --> 00:07:28.710
it'll be find.

167
00:07:28.710 --> 00:07:31.540
Or on Mac it'll be the system
integrity protection.

168
00:07:31.540 --> 00:07:33.080
Just turn that off and you'll be fine.

169
00:07:33.080 --> 00:07:36.190
Well, when you turn those off,
all of those things I just said,

170
00:07:36.190 --> 00:07:37.860
they're security sub layers.

171
00:07:37.860 --> 00:07:40.310
And if you turn off all
the security on your system, yeah,

172
00:07:40.310 --> 00:07:42.650
a lot of your software will
start working just fine.

173
00:07:42.650 --> 00:07:45.100
But, now you're very unsecure.

174
00:07:45.100 --> 00:07:48.150
And an attacker can get into your system
and really start to cause some problems.

175
00:07:48.150 --> 00:07:51.290
And you see this same thing on routers,
and switches, and firewalls.

176
00:07:51.290 --> 00:07:52.950
If you started disabling this stuff,

177
00:07:52.950 --> 00:07:55.090
you can really be opening
yourself up to attacks.

178
00:07:55.090 --> 00:07:56.905
You've gotta understand
the change you're gonna make.

179
00:07:56.905 --> 00:08:00.136
>> Yeah and one of the things I've seen
too is where you're troubleshooting

180
00:08:00.136 --> 00:08:03.331
more so a piece of software and
it needs to communicate with the network.

181
00:08:03.331 --> 00:08:06.627
One of the first things that you'll
hear some people in forum say, well,

182
00:08:06.627 --> 00:08:07.916
just disable the firewall.

183
00:08:07.916 --> 00:08:08.913
That fixes everything.

184
00:08:08.913 --> 00:08:09.539
Right?

185
00:08:09.539 --> 00:08:12.869
And then now we don't know why all
ten other computers are now having,

186
00:08:12.869 --> 00:08:14.630
manifesting all kinds of problems.

187
00:08:14.630 --> 00:08:18.820
So I don't think that's probably the best
methodology, if you will, to implement.

188
00:08:18.820 --> 00:08:19.890
Right?
>> Yeah.

189
00:08:19.890 --> 00:08:23.585
Why are there 10,000 emails a second going
out on my network, I don't understand.

190
00:08:23.585 --> 00:08:25.120
[LAUGH]
>> Well, they're doing this blacklist now,

191
00:08:25.120 --> 00:08:26.622
and I can't figure it out.

192
00:08:26.622 --> 00:08:27.330
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, and

193
00:08:27.330 --> 00:08:30.830
that does happen all too often, so we've
gotta be careful with that, we've gotta

194
00:08:30.830 --> 00:08:34.140
make sure we understand the effects
of the change that we're gonna make.

195
00:08:34.140 --> 00:08:36.030
So plan, do, check, act.

196
00:08:36.030 --> 00:08:39.340
Now, the other thing is
when we approach a problem,

197
00:08:39.340 --> 00:08:41.500
sometimes we don't know where to start,
right?

198
00:08:41.500 --> 00:08:43.440
There's a problem and I'm like, man,

199
00:08:43.440 --> 00:08:45.870
I really don't understand
what's causing this.

200
00:08:45.870 --> 00:08:48.280
If you've been in the industry
a long time, maybe you know it.

201
00:08:48.280 --> 00:08:50.350
Oh yeah, I know what's causing that,
this is the fix,

202
00:08:50.350 --> 00:08:51.680
that'll take care of it and you're done.

203
00:08:51.680 --> 00:08:52.370
Right?

204
00:08:52.370 --> 00:08:56.490
But if somebody says, hey, when I'm
on this computer, I can print to that

205
00:08:56.490 --> 00:08:59.530
printer, but when I'm on this other
computer, I can't print to the printer.

206
00:08:59.530 --> 00:09:00.810
What's up?

207
00:09:00.810 --> 00:09:02.140
Well, where do we start?

208
00:09:02.140 --> 00:09:04.030
We're network engineers,
so we think network.

209
00:09:04.030 --> 00:09:06.720
All right, well is the cable plugged in,
do we have an IP address?

210
00:09:06.720 --> 00:09:10.260
But there's really a number of different
places that problem can originate.

211
00:09:10.260 --> 00:09:13.820
And so one of the great troubleshooting
methodologies we can use

212
00:09:13.820 --> 00:09:15.880
Is called the top down model.

213
00:09:15.880 --> 00:09:20.650
Now the top down model, what we're really
talking about there is the OSI model,

214
00:09:20.650 --> 00:09:24.440
the open systems interconnect,
yeah that's right.

215
00:09:24.440 --> 00:09:25.251
>> Yeah you got it.
>> [CROSSTALK]

216
00:09:25.251 --> 00:09:27.295
>> And the way we can use that model to

217
00:09:27.295 --> 00:09:28.905
troubleshoot a problem.

218
00:09:28.905 --> 00:09:32.120
>> Yeah now when you say top down
what I'm thinking of is the fact

219
00:09:32.120 --> 00:09:34.350
that the OSI model is a layered system.

220
00:09:34.350 --> 00:09:37.510
So you're talking about working from
the top of the protocol stack or

221
00:09:37.510 --> 00:09:41.160
the top portion that we first
start to interact with.

222
00:09:41.160 --> 00:09:44.320
And then systematically
just maybe checking

223
00:09:44.320 --> 00:09:46.400
things off as we work down
those different layers.

224
00:09:46.400 --> 00:09:47.450
Is that what you're talking about there?

225
00:09:47.450 --> 00:09:48.520
>> Yeah, absolutely.

226
00:09:48.520 --> 00:09:50.360
You guys know the OSI model.

227
00:09:50.360 --> 00:09:53.220
We saw it way back in CCENT,
and again in CCNA.

228
00:09:53.220 --> 00:09:55.300
So, why not see it here in CCNP again.

229
00:09:55.300 --> 00:09:56.800
I've got it pulled up on my screen here.

230
00:09:56.800 --> 00:09:59.540
This is our seven layer OSI model.

231
00:09:59.540 --> 00:10:00.760
If you're approaching a problem and

232
00:10:00.760 --> 00:10:04.600
you just have no idea where to start,
The OSI model can really help you out.

233
00:10:04.600 --> 00:10:06.560
When I say top down,

234
00:10:06.560 --> 00:10:12.180
I mean let's start right up here at
layer 7, the application layer, right?

235
00:10:12.180 --> 00:10:15.380
If somebody says, hey, when I'm on one
computer, I can print to a printer.

236
00:10:15.380 --> 00:10:18.020
When I'm on another computer,
I can't print to the printer.

237
00:10:18.020 --> 00:10:20.030
Maybe it's the software they're using.

238
00:10:20.030 --> 00:10:22.570
Maybe they're using
Microsoft Word on one computer and

239
00:10:22.570 --> 00:10:25.290
they're using Adobe Acrobat Reader
on the other one.

240
00:10:25.290 --> 00:10:29.280
And it's the program that's not printing,
not the network, not the OS or

241
00:10:29.280 --> 00:10:30.630
anything like that.

242
00:10:30.630 --> 00:10:32.930
So we start troubleshooting there.

243
00:10:32.930 --> 00:10:34.930
Then we start moving down.

244
00:10:34.930 --> 00:10:36.350
And troubleshooting additional problems.

245
00:10:36.350 --> 00:10:37.800
It might be the presentation layer.

246
00:10:37.800 --> 00:10:39.960
Maybe I've got a bad print driver,

247
00:10:39.960 --> 00:10:42.040
and I'm using the wrong print language or
something.

248
00:10:42.040 --> 00:10:45.020
This is kinda outside of the range
of Cisco troubleshooting.

249
00:10:45.020 --> 00:10:49.230
On the Cisco side, we really start down
here at layer five, the session layer.

250
00:10:49.230 --> 00:10:51.290
All right, the session layer,
I'm printing.

251
00:10:51.290 --> 00:10:52.860
So I'm using a print protocol.

252
00:10:52.860 --> 00:10:56.590
What protocol am I using, what port
number is it using to cross the network.

253
00:10:56.590 --> 00:10:58.970
Is is using Apple Talk or TCPIP?

254
00:10:58.970 --> 00:11:05.170
Is is using IPXSPX to get to that printer
and am I allowing that to pass through,

255
00:11:05.170 --> 00:11:07.760
do I have access control lists
that are blocking it, right?

256
00:11:07.760 --> 00:11:10.590
That's the kind of stuff that can
happen at the session layer and

257
00:11:10.590 --> 00:11:12.240
the transport layer.

258
00:11:12.240 --> 00:11:15.920
Then as we get beneath that we get to
layer three, the network layer, all right.

259
00:11:15.920 --> 00:11:19.010
Am I able to see the IP
address of that printer?

260
00:11:19.010 --> 00:11:21.090
Is that printer on
the same network as I am?

261
00:11:21.090 --> 00:11:22.180
If it's not on the same network,

262
00:11:22.180 --> 00:11:25.590
is there a router in between
that can route between the two?

263
00:11:25.590 --> 00:11:29.490
Does that router know about my network and
the network the printer is on,

264
00:11:29.490 --> 00:11:33.470
as layer three technology, is when you
have more than one network involved.

265
00:11:33.470 --> 00:11:38.060
Maybe I've only got one network involved
and so it's just layer two communications.

266
00:11:38.060 --> 00:11:42.250
Am I able to do an ARP broadcast and
find the Mac address of that printer.

267
00:11:42.250 --> 00:11:43.920
Can I even see it that way?

268
00:11:43.920 --> 00:11:46.960
Cuz if that doesn't work
everything above it fails, right?

269
00:11:46.960 --> 00:11:49.080
The OSI model stacks together.

270
00:11:49.080 --> 00:11:52.460
If a bottom layer fails,
everything above it fails.

271
00:11:52.460 --> 00:11:56.720
So we're kind of moving down the model
trying to find where that failure is.

272
00:11:56.720 --> 00:11:59.515
And when we get to the very bottom
we're at the physical layer,

273
00:11:59.515 --> 00:12:01.640
maybe the network cable's unplugged.

274
00:12:01.640 --> 00:12:03.810
Maybe the wireless access
point is powered off.

275
00:12:03.810 --> 00:12:07.140
Maybe there's some kind of break
in the network connection,

276
00:12:07.140 --> 00:12:11.590
the physical network, between this work
station and the rest of the network.

277
00:12:11.590 --> 00:12:18.200
So, as we move down, we can really start
to dial in where that problem is, right.

278
00:12:18.200 --> 00:12:19.950
But from the Cisco perspective,

279
00:12:19.950 --> 00:12:24.150
we're normally focused on layers one
through five, these guys right here.

280
00:12:24.150 --> 00:12:28.050
Because those are the ones that
routers and switches pay attention to.

281
00:12:28.050 --> 00:12:31.090
Routers and switches don't normally
care about layer six and seven.

282
00:12:31.090 --> 00:12:35.038
>> All right, so when we talk
about those lower layers there,

283
00:12:35.038 --> 00:12:39.240
at this point we're not really care about
too much what the application's doing or

284
00:12:39.240 --> 00:12:41.290
how it's bundling it and
getting it ready for the network.

285
00:12:41.290 --> 00:12:46.350
We just really need to know when it gets
on that wire, or it's being prepared

286
00:12:46.350 --> 00:12:50.360
on that wire, the communication between
those two end points becomes more crucial?

287
00:12:50.360 --> 00:12:54.730
>> Yeah, absolutely, and it's all
kind of built upon each other, so you

288
00:12:54.730 --> 00:12:57.820
have to target that one layer, and some
layers are more important than others.

289
00:12:57.820 --> 00:13:02.590
If you're troubleshooting with Ping for
example, Ping doesn't build a session.

290
00:13:02.590 --> 00:13:04.780
Doesn't have any special presentation.

291
00:13:04.780 --> 00:13:07.650
Doesn't even have really
an application that we care about.

292
00:13:07.650 --> 00:13:11.240
Ping is just an echo sound on
the network and a reply that comes back.

293
00:13:11.240 --> 00:13:14.780
So it really lets us test
areas one through four.

294
00:13:14.780 --> 00:13:15.350
Right?

295
00:13:15.350 --> 00:13:18.540
But the higher application layers here,
like five, six, and seven,

296
00:13:18.540 --> 00:13:19.730
they're important.

297
00:13:19.730 --> 00:13:20.310
Right?

298
00:13:20.310 --> 00:13:23.600
If we look at the TCP IP model, right?

299
00:13:23.600 --> 00:13:26.560
So this is not the OSI model itself.

300
00:13:26.560 --> 00:13:28.400
This is kind of boiled down for TCP IP.

301
00:13:28.400 --> 00:13:31.800
See how TCP IP combines those top
three layers all into application.

302
00:13:31.800 --> 00:13:34.660
Because as far as TCP IP is concerned,

303
00:13:34.660 --> 00:13:38.510
it doesn't really care what application
you use, it functions one way.

304
00:13:38.510 --> 00:13:42.680
And so your routers and your switches
are all getting involved in these bottom

305
00:13:42.680 --> 00:13:45.690
four layers here so they kind of block
that out a little bit differently.

306
00:13:45.690 --> 00:13:46.270
All right.

307
00:13:46.270 --> 00:13:51.490
Now I will tell you one thing,
as far as the top down model is concerned,

308
00:13:51.490 --> 00:13:56.470
it's a good model, it certainly works,
but for me personally,

309
00:13:56.470 --> 00:14:01.520
I've found many times where I prefer
to use the bottom up model, right?

310
00:14:01.520 --> 00:14:05.750
Just because over the years, I've found
where a lot of times, problems are more

311
00:14:05.750 --> 00:14:09.690
easily solved from the bottom where you
get your kind of common sense things and

312
00:14:09.690 --> 00:14:12.540
then go up to the more difficult to
troubleshoot things like applications.

313
00:14:12.540 --> 00:14:13.160
>> Yeah, definitely.

314
00:14:13.160 --> 00:14:15.220
In fact this is one that
I've heard of a lot.

315
00:14:15.220 --> 00:14:16.340
One of the first things,

316
00:14:16.340 --> 00:14:20.140
in fact I think you've told me before,
is the cable plugged in?

317
00:14:20.140 --> 00:14:21.630
Right. is that the first thing?
Simple fixes first.

318
00:14:21.630 --> 00:14:24.940
If the cable's not plugged in then
we don't have any communications.

319
00:14:24.940 --> 00:14:26.750
Do we have any power on the device?

320
00:14:26.750 --> 00:14:28.110
Well, that's it we don't have any power,

321
00:14:28.110 --> 00:14:29.740
it doesn't matter if
the cable's plugged in or not.

322
00:14:29.740 --> 00:14:32.218
So basically you're just
reversing the order and

323
00:14:32.218 --> 00:14:34.050
you're saying simple fixes first.

324
00:14:34.050 --> 00:14:36.110
Let's start with the physical cabling.

325
00:14:36.110 --> 00:14:38.390
>> Yeah,
I like to call it the low hanging fruit.

326
00:14:38.390 --> 00:14:41.535
Right?
If you go to a tree, like an orange tree,

327
00:14:41.535 --> 00:14:44.305
there's oranges at the very top of the
tree that are really hard to get to, and

328
00:14:44.305 --> 00:14:46.840
there's oranges at the bottom of the tree
that you just reach up and grab, right?

329
00:14:46.840 --> 00:14:50.760
So the bottom layers of the OSI model
are the easiest to troubleshoot.

330
00:14:50.760 --> 00:14:51.960
The physical layer.

331
00:14:51.960 --> 00:14:53.230
Is the cable plugged in?

332
00:14:53.230 --> 00:14:54.140
I mean it's so easy.

333
00:14:54.140 --> 00:14:55.070
Does it have link lights.

334
00:14:55.070 --> 00:14:56.130
You just look.

335
00:14:56.130 --> 00:14:59.364
And so that's far easier than saying okay
what version of this application am I

336
00:14:59.364 --> 00:15:02.402
running, are there updates available,
let me read the release notes and

337
00:15:02.402 --> 00:15:06.040
see if they've addressed this problem,
let me go to a knowledge base and search.

338
00:15:06.040 --> 00:15:07.340
That's hard stuff.

339
00:15:07.340 --> 00:15:10.040
I'm kind of lazy so
I don't want to deal with that.

340
00:15:10.040 --> 00:15:11.390
I want to deal with the easy stuff.

341
00:15:11.390 --> 00:15:13.690
So physical layer,
is the cable plugged in?

342
00:15:13.690 --> 00:15:18.490
Data-link layer, can I do an art broadcast
and get a Mac address back for their IP?

343
00:15:18.490 --> 00:15:20.560
Can I even see the network
at the layer two side?

344
00:15:20.560 --> 00:15:23.100
Can I see that I'm plugged into a switch?

345
00:15:23.100 --> 00:15:26.450
Layer three, can I access
the network this other side is on?

346
00:15:26.450 --> 00:15:27.210
I can use Ping.

347
00:15:27.210 --> 00:15:28.140
I can use trace route.

348
00:15:28.140 --> 00:15:30.310
We've got a ton of tools for
trouble shooting that stuff.

349
00:15:30.310 --> 00:15:33.900
These are easy to troubleshoot and
we can locate where that problem is.

350
00:15:33.900 --> 00:15:36.810
And if the problem is in one of these
layers, we can find it and fix it.

351
00:15:36.810 --> 00:15:39.730
If the problem's up here,
they're often complex problems.

352
00:15:39.730 --> 00:15:41.930
It can be very hard to troubleshoot and
solve.

353
00:15:41.930 --> 00:15:45.840
So I like bottom up because we can
knock out the easy stuff first, and

354
00:15:45.840 --> 00:15:47.210
if it's a hard problem,
we'll deal with it.

355
00:15:47.210 --> 00:15:50.270
But if it's an easy problem, we're solved,
and we never messed with the hard stuff.

356
00:15:50.270 --> 00:15:51.710
That's the bottom up analysis.

357
00:15:51.710 --> 00:15:52.337
>> Very good, very good.

358
00:15:52.337 --> 00:15:55.682
So we're talking about that
systematic approach, so

359
00:15:55.682 --> 00:16:00.419
what's the next thing gonna be for
us in the method to the madness here, Don?

360
00:16:00.419 --> 00:16:04.563
Remember that the OSI model,
that's one way to go about it, right?

361
00:16:04.563 --> 00:16:06.420
And that's simply a suggestion,
you don't have to do it.

362
00:16:06.420 --> 00:16:08.670
There's plenty of other
methodologies out there.

363
00:16:08.670 --> 00:16:12.020
I'll tell you guys, to be really honest
with you, when I'm troubleshooting

364
00:16:12.020 --> 00:16:16.010
something like individual link, I don't
even think about the OSI models so much.

365
00:16:16.010 --> 00:16:19.610
I think, I've got router A and
it's connected to router B, and

366
00:16:19.610 --> 00:16:20.620
something's not working right?

367
00:16:20.620 --> 00:16:26.250
Maybe the VPN tunnel's not coming up or
a link is not passing traffic,

368
00:16:26.250 --> 00:16:29.120
or EIGRP is not exchanging routes,
all right.

369
00:16:29.120 --> 00:16:30.830
But these two routers
are connected to each other.

370
00:16:30.830 --> 00:16:35.010
So, I take the config of one router and
I compared the config to the other router.

371
00:16:35.010 --> 00:16:38.680
If you want them to talk their configs
should be pretty close to the same, right?

372
00:16:38.680 --> 00:16:42.510
If I want EIGRP to talk I've gotta have
the same autonomous system number.

373
00:16:42.510 --> 00:16:45.540
If authentication is turned on I've gotta
have the same password set as one of

374
00:16:45.540 --> 00:16:47.570
the keys to share on my keychain.

375
00:16:47.570 --> 00:16:53.100
If I have OSPF, I need area numbers,
hello timers, adjacency information.

376
00:16:53.100 --> 00:16:55.750
All that stuff had got to match
in between the different nodes or

377
00:16:55.750 --> 00:16:57.410
they're not going to exchange routes.

378
00:16:57.410 --> 00:17:00.040
So if I just look at the configs I
can compare and I can find it and

379
00:17:00.040 --> 00:17:03.010
I don't care if it's layer one or
layer five or whatever.

380
00:17:03.010 --> 00:17:04.310
We're just looking at the configs.

381
00:17:04.310 --> 00:17:07.090
So, that's not something
you should discard

382
00:17:07.090 --> 00:17:09.190
especially in the exam where
time is of the essence.

383
00:17:09.190 --> 00:17:12.490
If you can just compare configs and find
the problem, certainly do that, right?

384
00:17:12.490 --> 00:17:16.960
So, don't feel bound to go through and
test all the layers of the OSI model.

385
00:17:16.960 --> 00:17:19.430
There's also other things
somethings that are easy,

386
00:17:19.430 --> 00:17:22.790
somethings that are hard,
stuff like debugs, right?

387
00:17:22.790 --> 00:17:26.930
That's another one that we can do to
really get in and find some information.

388
00:17:26.930 --> 00:17:30.950
>> Now debugging, when talk about dubugs,
I start to get a little nervous here.

389
00:17:30.950 --> 00:17:33.860
Because I don't know a lot
about software development but

390
00:17:33.860 --> 00:17:37.000
the first thing I think about
debugging is, man, get ready for it,

391
00:17:37.000 --> 00:17:38.890
cuz you're going to get
a whole bunch of information.

392
00:17:38.890 --> 00:17:43.560
Maybe it could be a little, I don't know,
daunting task or a little confusing.

393
00:17:43.560 --> 00:17:45.135
Sounds like it might even be overwhelming.

394
00:17:45.135 --> 00:17:47.025
Are we talking about the same thing here?

395
00:17:47.025 --> 00:17:47.925
>> Yeah, absolutely.

396
00:17:47.925 --> 00:17:52.255
And on routers and switches, debugging,
it's turned off for v2i connections, for

397
00:17:52.255 --> 00:17:53.615
SSH and Telnet.

398
00:17:53.615 --> 00:17:56.805
It's turned off by default because it can
be so much information it can overwhelm

399
00:17:56.805 --> 00:17:58.645
your session and
lock you out of the device, right?

400
00:17:58.645 --> 00:18:02.695
So Cisco recommends that you
debug from the console port.

401
00:18:02.695 --> 00:18:06.200
And we're gonna see debug several
times throughout this series.

402
00:18:06.200 --> 00:18:08.690
>> And it's important that you
always keep it filtered to

403
00:18:08.690 --> 00:18:10.640
just the information you need.

404
00:18:10.640 --> 00:18:13.250
If you just open it up like a firehose,
it is so

405
00:18:13.250 --> 00:18:15.420
much data you're not gonna be able
to make any use out of it, right?

406
00:18:15.420 --> 00:18:18.170
So we've really got to do targeted debugs.

407
00:18:18.170 --> 00:18:21.520
But it is a great way to get additional
information to find more of what's going

408
00:18:21.520 --> 00:18:23.030
on behind the scenes.

409
00:18:23.030 --> 00:18:25.340
Also, if you're keeping good
documentation on your network,

410
00:18:25.340 --> 00:18:28.080
this is an important one,
change documentation, right?

411
00:18:28.080 --> 00:18:33.360
This is a kind of a concept that comes
from ITEL is you plan any change.

412
00:18:33.360 --> 00:18:37.270
If your network is broken you've got to
make a change to fix it so you plan it and

413
00:18:37.270 --> 00:18:39.030
you document it, right?

414
00:18:39.030 --> 00:18:42.540
Change documentation is something
a lot of small businesses don't do.

415
00:18:42.540 --> 00:18:44.120
CCNP's not about small business.

416
00:18:44.120 --> 00:18:46.210
Now we're talking about large business and
enterprise.

417
00:18:46.210 --> 00:18:49.070
You have more than one network engineer,
and you've got to

418
00:18:49.070 --> 00:18:53.280
keep each person informed of what's going
on and change documentation does that.

419
00:18:53.280 --> 00:18:56.160
>> Yeah, one of the things I'm thinking
right now is I'm gonna jump in,

420
00:18:56.160 --> 00:18:57.070
and I'm gonna fix this, Don.

421
00:18:57.070 --> 00:19:00.060
I'm gonna make a whole bunch of changes,
and nobody's gonna know about it.

422
00:19:00.060 --> 00:19:03.900
What kind of problems might that introduce
to our networks I mean doesn't sound like

423
00:19:03.900 --> 00:19:05.450
a good idea to me honestly.

424
00:19:05.450 --> 00:19:07.480
>> Yeah, I've got a great example of this.

425
00:19:07.480 --> 00:19:12.100
So many years ago, over a decade ago, I
worked at an insurance company with one of

426
00:19:12.100 --> 00:19:15.260
our other show hosts here Daniel and
there was a gentleman there,

427
00:19:15.260 --> 00:19:18.970
he was a brilliant guy,
he did a lot of the networking with me and

428
00:19:18.970 --> 00:19:21.350
he was actually the one who
supported all of our firewalls.

429
00:19:21.350 --> 00:19:25.430
We had like 110 firewalls
spread across the state And

430
00:19:25.430 --> 00:19:27.500
whenever he was gonna go on vacation.

431
00:19:27.500 --> 00:19:30.490
You always knew he was going on
vacation because he'd get super busy.

432
00:19:30.490 --> 00:19:34.490
He would bust his butt to
get a lot of work done so

433
00:19:34.490 --> 00:19:36.290
that he could then go on vacation right?

434
00:19:36.290 --> 00:19:40.910
Well the problem was he would always
implement a ton of change and

435
00:19:40.910 --> 00:19:42.640
then go on vacation.

436
00:19:42.640 --> 00:19:45.320
And so Monday would roll around,
I'd come in the office, and

437
00:19:45.320 --> 00:19:47.880
we'd have all these branches down or
software not working and

438
00:19:47.880 --> 00:19:52.080
I'd have to scramble to figure out man,
what the heck did he change?

439
00:19:52.080 --> 00:19:54.080
I gotta figure this out, right?

440
00:19:54.080 --> 00:19:58.470
Then if we had changed documentation
which we certainly did after a while,

441
00:19:58.470 --> 00:20:02.260
but if we had changed documentation,
all I had to do was say all right,

442
00:20:02.260 --> 00:20:05.920
let me go pull all the change tickets from
Thursday and Friday and see what changed.

443
00:20:05.920 --> 00:20:07.690
I'm having this problem,
this software isn't working,

444
00:20:07.690 --> 00:20:10.130
which of these change tickets
could have caused it, right?

445
00:20:10.130 --> 00:20:13.120
And now I look at it and I have a better
idea of what happened on the network and

446
00:20:13.120 --> 00:20:14.070
I can see that.

447
00:20:14.070 --> 00:20:17.700
If you are a one man IT shop the change
tickets are right here, right?

448
00:20:17.700 --> 00:20:18.950
They're right in your skull.

449
00:20:18.950 --> 00:20:20.310
But if you've got ten, 20,

450
00:20:20.310 --> 00:20:23.740
100 network engineers you've got
a full network operations center.

451
00:20:23.740 --> 00:20:27.010
Well one person could make a change and
the other people don't know and now

452
00:20:27.010 --> 00:20:29.730
it becomes a troubleshooting nightmare,
especially if they're not available.

453
00:20:29.730 --> 00:20:32.730
So a change ticket,
when somebody fills out,

454
00:20:32.730 --> 00:20:34.790
they should contain a lot of information.

455
00:20:34.790 --> 00:20:38.350
It really should contain,
what the change is?

456
00:20:38.350 --> 00:20:40.850
Why your making the change,
or what's the business case?

457
00:20:40.850 --> 00:20:44.160
How does it improve your environment
known as to fix the problem, right?

458
00:20:44.160 --> 00:20:46.060
When you're gonna make the change?

459
00:20:46.060 --> 00:20:47.850
What systems it's going to impact.

460
00:20:47.850 --> 00:20:50.760
So, what we can expect to happen
after the change is in place.

461
00:20:50.760 --> 00:20:55.600
And then we should also have steps to undo
the change should we need to undo it.

462
00:20:55.600 --> 00:20:57.580
That's the one a lot of people leave out.

463
00:20:57.580 --> 00:21:00.540
And we should also contain in there,
not just the steps to undo it,

464
00:21:00.540 --> 00:21:03.710
but what are the triggers that
indicate we should undo it?

465
00:21:03.710 --> 00:21:06.330
How do I know if, yeah,
I need to roll this back, right?

466
00:21:06.330 --> 00:21:09.740
One of my kind of, witness test or

467
00:21:09.740 --> 00:21:12.160
measuring stick that tells me
when I need to roll that back.

468
00:21:12.160 --> 00:21:14.630
Those are all things that should
be in that change ticket.

469
00:21:14.630 --> 00:21:18.790
And the most important part of a change
ticket is an authorization signature.

470
00:21:18.790 --> 00:21:21.740
If your following Itel's methodology
the organization will have

471
00:21:21.740 --> 00:21:26.000
what's called a change advisory board or
a CAB And the CAB is a group of people,

472
00:21:26.000 --> 00:21:27.620
you might even be on it, right?

473
00:21:27.620 --> 00:21:31.160
That reviews the change tickets and
approves them or declines them.

474
00:21:31.160 --> 00:21:33.460
If you decline it,
it might be because it's a bad change or

475
00:21:33.460 --> 00:21:34.690
you might just need more information.

476
00:21:34.690 --> 00:21:37.620
But if you approve it, it's green-lighted
and you're gonna move forward and

477
00:21:37.620 --> 00:21:39.470
this is a change that's gonna happen.

478
00:21:39.470 --> 00:21:42.020
A CAB, Change Advisory Board,
helps to ensure that

479
00:21:42.020 --> 00:21:46.320
only authorized changes happen and that
there's good documentation on the changes.

480
00:21:46.320 --> 00:21:49.020
It really improves the stability
of your environment.

481
00:21:49.020 --> 00:21:50.050
>> All right, very good.

482
00:21:50.050 --> 00:21:54.630
Well Don, is there anything else
we need to know moving on here?

483
00:21:54.630 --> 00:21:56.120
We've got our changed documentation.

484
00:21:56.120 --> 00:21:58.520
We've got a whole bunch
of verbose information.

485
00:21:58.520 --> 00:21:59.720
What's next on our list?

486
00:21:59.720 --> 00:22:02.695
>> All right, well, so
we've kind of trouble shot to

487
00:22:02.695 --> 00:22:07.285
find the source of our problem, we've come
up with a solution and we've implemented

488
00:22:07.285 --> 00:22:10.135
a change ticket to get it approved so
we could put the solution in place, right?

489
00:22:10.135 --> 00:22:11.945
So we go and put the solution in place.

490
00:22:11.945 --> 00:22:16.495
We did plan and do and
that next part is check.

491
00:22:16.495 --> 00:22:19.045
You always verify your solution.

492
00:22:19.045 --> 00:22:20.925
Did I actually fix the problem?

493
00:22:20.925 --> 00:22:21.895
And here's the key thing.

494
00:22:21.895 --> 00:22:26.570
A lot of people will implement a change
And they're fixing a symptom and

495
00:22:26.570 --> 00:22:28.350
not the cause, right?

496
00:22:28.350 --> 00:22:33.450
A great example of this,
this was on a server, not on a router,

497
00:22:33.450 --> 00:22:37.660
where there was a gentleman where the
server was running on hard drive space.

498
00:22:37.660 --> 00:22:41.190
And so they looked at it and they found
where the anti-virus software was

499
00:22:41.190 --> 00:22:45.780
generating log files, so many log files
it was filling up the hard drive.

500
00:22:45.780 --> 00:22:47.260
So, what did he do?

501
00:22:47.260 --> 00:22:49.440
He wrote a script that
would run once an hour and

502
00:22:49.440 --> 00:22:51.510
delete the log files, problem solved.

503
00:22:51.510 --> 00:22:54.310
Now the server's not on a hard drive
space run business, right now.

504
00:22:54.310 --> 00:22:55.670
What did he do there?

505
00:22:55.670 --> 00:22:58.610
He fixed the symptom, the symptom was that
we were running on a hard drive space.

506
00:22:58.610 --> 00:23:01.170
The cause was, the server had a virus.

507
00:23:01.170 --> 00:23:04.010
And so the antivirus software
was logging that information,

508
00:23:04.010 --> 00:23:05.480
that was generating log files.

509
00:23:05.480 --> 00:23:09.310
So he didn't really fix the cause,
he fixed the symptom.

510
00:23:09.310 --> 00:23:11.760
And so
that's where we have to be really careful.

511
00:23:11.760 --> 00:23:13.305
And when we check or we verify.

512
00:23:13.305 --> 00:23:14.635
Fire solution.

513
00:23:14.635 --> 00:23:15.915
We need to be able to spot that.

514
00:23:15.915 --> 00:23:20.305
Did I actually fix what the cause was,
or is this problem gonna continue on?

515
00:23:20.305 --> 00:23:23.445
Just the fact that he had to schedule
that script to run, delete the files,

516
00:23:23.445 --> 00:23:26.385
that should have been his indicator
that he didn't fix the cause.

517
00:23:26.385 --> 00:23:31.235
If he had removed the virus, or rebuilt
the server really, if that had happened,

518
00:23:31.235 --> 00:23:33.485
then it wouldn't be running on a hardware
space, and you actually fixed the problem.

519
00:23:33.485 --> 00:23:35.480
So we always have to check and verify.

520
00:23:35.480 --> 00:23:38.430
And verification needs to
go beyond the problem.

521
00:23:38.430 --> 00:23:40.400
If you just verify that you
just fixed the problem,

522
00:23:40.400 --> 00:23:44.210
you might have fixed it by
sacrificing some other functionality.

523
00:23:44.210 --> 00:23:44.830
Right?

524
00:23:44.830 --> 00:23:46.920
I have a web server that
is getting attacked.

525
00:23:46.920 --> 00:23:48.850
So, how can I fix that?

526
00:23:48.850 --> 00:23:50.330
I can unplug its network cord.

527
00:23:50.330 --> 00:23:53.390
It's not getting attacked anymore is it?

528
00:23:53.390 --> 00:23:55.490
But nobody can get to
the website anymore either.

529
00:23:55.490 --> 00:24:01.420
So sometimes a solution can break your
