network and break your functionality.

530
00:24:01.420 --> 00:24:04.220
So we gotta make sure that we
verify that we actually solved it.

531
00:24:04.220 --> 00:24:06.970
That we've removed the problem,
the cause of the problem, and

532
00:24:06.970 --> 00:24:10.040
that we still have our normal
functionality when we're done.

533
00:24:10.040 --> 00:24:11.760
If you can't achieve that,

534
00:24:11.760 --> 00:24:16.100
if fixing the problem requires
disabling some normal functionality.

535
00:24:16.100 --> 00:24:16.990
You gotta do a change to it,

536
00:24:16.990 --> 00:24:20.610
you gotta make sure that That everybody
in the company is on board with that.

537
00:24:20.610 --> 00:24:22.680
The great example is the finger protocol.

538
00:24:22.680 --> 00:24:23.990
Did you ever use Finger, Wes?

539
00:24:23.990 --> 00:24:24.920
>> No, no, not at all.

540
00:24:24.920 --> 00:24:25.830
>> I know we talked about it.

541
00:24:25.830 --> 00:24:29.750
If any of you guys did the CCNA Security
show, we talked about it in there.

542
00:24:29.750 --> 00:24:33.320
It was a great protocol because you
ever send somebody an email, and

543
00:24:33.320 --> 00:24:35.810
you're like man, did they get my email,
have they read it?

544
00:24:35.810 --> 00:24:36.930
I don't know.

545
00:24:36.930 --> 00:24:40.510
You could run Finger and
then specify their email address.

546
00:24:40.510 --> 00:24:43.670
And it would reach up to their
nail server and it would tell you

547
00:24:43.670 --> 00:24:47.010
the last time the person logged in,
and if they had any unread email.

548
00:24:47.010 --> 00:24:50.820
So you could say, oh, I sent Wes an email,
but he hasn't logged in in two days, so

549
00:24:50.820 --> 00:24:51.460
he hasn't seen it yet.

550
00:24:51.460 --> 00:24:53.290
Which was kind of nice to see that.

551
00:24:53.290 --> 00:24:57.430
Well, there was an exploit that could
use that to access somebody's mailbox.

552
00:24:57.430 --> 00:25:01.210
And the exploit was so bad that there
really wasn't a good way to fix it and so

553
00:25:01.210 --> 00:25:02.320
they ended up abandoning the protocol.

554
00:25:02.320 --> 00:25:05.220
The solution was to disable the protocol.

555
00:25:05.220 --> 00:25:08.680
So your company had to make a decision,
do we rely on that protocol?

556
00:25:08.680 --> 00:25:10.960
If so we need to implement
something else to replace it.

557
00:25:10.960 --> 00:25:13.840
If we don't rely on it It's time to
bump it and get it out of there, right?

558
00:25:13.840 --> 00:25:16.940
So that's kind of the decision that has
to be made and sometimes it happens.

559
00:25:16.940 --> 00:25:19.900
But when you verify that's
the key thing you need to do is

560
00:25:19.900 --> 00:25:23.390
make sure that your change
actually solved the problem.

561
00:25:23.390 --> 00:25:25.450
And that your your network is back up and

562
00:25:25.450 --> 00:25:27.940
operational in the way that
it was intended to do.

563
00:25:27.940 --> 00:25:29.770
>> All right Don,
lots of good information there.

564
00:25:29.770 --> 00:25:32.730
Do you have anything else to add on this?

565
00:25:32.730 --> 00:25:33.980
>> I think we've been pretty exhaustive.

566
00:25:33.980 --> 00:25:36.010
I know it's not the most
exciting of episodes cuz we were

567
00:25:36.010 --> 00:25:37.430
talking about fundamentals and theory.

568
00:25:37.430 --> 00:25:40.230
We will be deep diving into
the whole trouble shooting and

569
00:25:40.230 --> 00:25:41.920
really breaking some
stuff a little bit later.

570
00:25:41.920 --> 00:25:44.670
Definitely stay tuned for those episodes
but this is a pretty good spot for

571
00:25:44.670 --> 00:25:45.340
us to wrap this.

572
00:25:45.340 --> 00:25:49.370
>> All right, well we've got plenty more
episodes coming up in troubleshooting and

573
00:25:49.370 --> 00:25:53.080
maintaining Cisco IP networks so
stick around and come back for more.

574
00:25:53.080 --> 00:25:56.320
But until we see you I've been your host,
Wes Bryan.

575
00:25:56.320 --> 00:25:56.990
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

576
00:25:56.990 --> 00:26:00.416
>> And we'll see you next time.

577
00:26:00.416 --> 00:26:06.530
>> [MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains what to expect in the following episodes. Many of the episodes on ITProTV are produced in 30 minute blocks, however troubleshooting is doesn't always fit that format. The following Sets are broken down into more granular segments focusing on specific troubleshooting scenarios.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.026 --> 00:00:10.026
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.309 --> 00:00:15.198
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening and

3
00:00:15.198 --> 00:00:17.283
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:17.283 --> 00:00:18.768
I'm your host Don Pezet,

5
00:00:18.768 --> 00:00:22.920
back again with another episode
of Cisco CCNP troubleshooting.

6
00:00:22.920 --> 00:00:26.220
And what I wanna do in this
episode is kind of set up what

7
00:00:26.220 --> 00:00:29.330
we're about to see in
the next set of episodes.

8
00:00:29.330 --> 00:00:33.020
So, in most of our shows, if you've been
an ITProTV viewer for a while, you know

9
00:00:33.020 --> 00:00:36.710
that we normally take topics and we break
them up into these 30 minute episodes.

10
00:00:36.710 --> 00:00:39.080
And it works great for
learning a lot of things.

11
00:00:39.080 --> 00:00:43.280
But with troubleshooting,
not every problem is the same.

12
00:00:43.280 --> 00:00:46.160
Some troubleshooting problems
only take 5 minutes to solve,

13
00:00:46.160 --> 00:00:48.010
some take 45 minutes to solve.

14
00:00:48.010 --> 00:00:50.370
So, there's differing
levels of difficulty.

15
00:00:50.370 --> 00:00:53.353
And so what we're gonna do is for
the next set of videos,

16
00:00:53.353 --> 00:00:56.300
we're gonna deviate from
our normal ITProTV format.

17
00:00:56.300 --> 00:00:59.090
We're gonna take some network
topology that have problems, and

18
00:00:59.090 --> 00:01:01.760
we're gonna jump in and
start to resolve those problems.

19
00:01:01.760 --> 00:01:02.580
We'll get a chance to see that.

20
00:01:02.580 --> 00:01:05.000
And if it takes ten minutes,
it takes ten minutes.

21
00:01:05.000 --> 00:01:06.658
If it takes 45 minutes,
it takes 45 minutes.

22
00:01:06.658 --> 00:01:10.259
We're just gonna see that process
as we go through each one, and

23
00:01:10.259 --> 00:01:11.535
we resolve the issue.

24
00:01:11.535 --> 00:01:14.830
Now, I had a really neat opportunity for
this show.

25
00:01:14.830 --> 00:01:18.322
Normally we set up the labs, and
by we, a lot of the times I mean me.

26
00:01:18.322 --> 00:01:22.380
I'll build up routers just to suit
the needs for what I wanna teach you guys.

27
00:01:22.380 --> 00:01:25.660
But for this one, I thought it would
be fun to go a little different.

28
00:01:25.660 --> 00:01:28.850
And what we've done is ITProTV's partnered
with another organization that can

29
00:01:28.850 --> 00:01:30.220
provide practice labs.

30
00:01:30.220 --> 00:01:32.400
They have rental equipment for
Cisco devices, and

31
00:01:32.400 --> 00:01:35.710
they built up some labs that
have a lot of problems.

32
00:01:35.710 --> 00:01:38.340
They built up nine different
network topologies,

33
00:01:38.340 --> 00:01:42.150
each featuring different issues
that we need to go in and resolve.

34
00:01:42.150 --> 00:01:45.050
And they've given me
the questions the support ticket.

35
00:01:45.050 --> 00:01:47.820
So I have the little piece of paper
sitting right here right beside me that'll

36
00:01:47.820 --> 00:01:51.960
say something like, this server is
unable to access this particular IP.

37
00:01:51.960 --> 00:01:54.160
Or this router is not learning this route.

38
00:01:54.160 --> 00:01:59.152
Or this other router is choosing
a suboptimal route, why?

39
00:01:59.152 --> 00:02:00.770
And then we've gotta find out why.

40
00:02:00.770 --> 00:02:03.380
Well, the answer to why is, I don't know.

41
00:02:03.380 --> 00:02:05.330
I haven't actually seen
the solutions on these.

42
00:02:05.330 --> 00:02:08.086
I'm seeing these questions for
the first time just like you guys are.

43
00:02:08.086 --> 00:02:11.242
And so this will be a great chance
to be able to see how we go through

44
00:02:11.242 --> 00:02:13.470
troubleshooting and finding that problem.

45
00:02:13.470 --> 00:02:15.927
And we'll hope I don't
stumped on any of them.

46
00:02:15.927 --> 00:02:17.182
Because it's certainly possible.

47
00:02:17.182 --> 00:02:20.975
But as we go through, we're gonna take
all the tools that we learned about in

48
00:02:20.975 --> 00:02:24.990
the first couple of episodes, and
we're gonna start applying them.

49
00:02:24.990 --> 00:02:27.930
And I'll walk you through
the process of how I decide

50
00:02:27.930 --> 00:02:29.860
which tool to use when, right?

51
00:02:29.860 --> 00:02:31.535
Which one is suitable for which solution.

52
00:02:31.535 --> 00:02:34.458
And I'll show you guys examples
of time saving techniques,

53
00:02:34.458 --> 00:02:37.210
ways that you can get to
that information faster.

54
00:02:37.210 --> 00:02:38.700
And that's really important.

55
00:02:38.700 --> 00:02:40.530
For the first set of labs,
I'll take my time.

56
00:02:40.530 --> 00:02:41.330
We'll go nice and slow.

57
00:02:41.330 --> 00:02:44.540
I'll walk you through the methodology,
get you guys kind of used to that format.

58
00:02:44.540 --> 00:02:48.340
But as we move on into the later ones,
I'll start speeding things up.

59
00:02:48.340 --> 00:02:50.000
We'll start using some
time saving techniques.

60
00:02:50.000 --> 00:02:50.920
That way we can dive in and

61
00:02:50.920 --> 00:02:54.880
get the information, cuz on the exam
you don't have a ton of time.

62
00:02:54.880 --> 00:02:58.056
But even in real life, you don't normally
have a bunch of time there either.

63
00:02:58.056 --> 00:03:00.535
When there's a problem on the network,
you've got your boss and

64
00:03:00.535 --> 00:03:01.992
their boss breathing down your neck.

65
00:03:01.992 --> 00:03:04.315
You need to resolve that
issue as quickly as possible.

66
00:03:04.315 --> 00:03:07.019
Being able to get to
the information quickly and

67
00:03:07.019 --> 00:03:09.800
accurately is really an important skill.

68
00:03:09.800 --> 00:03:10.860
And so that's they way that we'll do this.

69
00:03:10.860 --> 00:03:13.510
We'll just ramp up as things go on.

70
00:03:13.510 --> 00:03:15.720
We're gonna cover a lot of stuff.

71
00:03:15.720 --> 00:03:19.917
We've got HSRP issues, IPv6, IPv4.

72
00:03:19.917 --> 00:03:21.391
We've got VPN issues.

73
00:03:21.391 --> 00:03:23.858
Tons of different problems that
can occur on the network, and

74
00:03:23.858 --> 00:03:25.290
tons of different causes for them.

75
00:03:25.290 --> 00:03:29.860
So we'll have to narrow that down,
find the solution and get it resolved.

76
00:03:29.860 --> 00:03:33.200
Now the cool part about this is, the
organization that we've partnered with on

77
00:03:33.200 --> 00:03:35.120
this, they provide
the online lab experience.

78
00:03:35.120 --> 00:03:38.350
So, if you wanna go through these
yourself, you actually can.

79
00:03:38.350 --> 00:03:41.952
We have that option, or we will soon have
that [LAUGH] option available on the site.

80
00:03:41.952 --> 00:03:43.875
Where you'll be able to in and
jump into these labs and

81
00:03:43.875 --> 00:03:46.270
actually go through the same
procedures on your own.

82
00:03:46.270 --> 00:03:50.120
In which case, you can use my videos
as basically like a solution,

83
00:03:50.120 --> 00:03:54.040
a guide that shows you how to solve
it if you can't solve it yourself.

84
00:03:54.040 --> 00:03:56.080
But if you can solve it yourself, great.

85
00:03:56.080 --> 00:03:57.937
That's how you know you're ready for
the exam.

86
00:03:57.937 --> 00:03:59.776
So it's kind of neat to be
able to work through that.

87
00:03:59.776 --> 00:04:03.452
So, I'm gonna be using a web interface to
connect to all of these different devices.

88
00:04:03.452 --> 00:04:05.433
And it'll let me move around through them.

89
00:04:05.433 --> 00:04:09.130
And it's cool, because if you do
participate in the same lab environment as

90
00:04:09.130 --> 00:04:11.920
I do, you'll have the same router names,
the same IPs.

91
00:04:11.920 --> 00:04:13.238
You'll have the same experience and

92
00:04:13.238 --> 00:04:15.118
environment that I'm using
right here on the show.

93
00:04:15.118 --> 00:04:16.678
So it's a great opportunity.

94
00:04:16.678 --> 00:04:18.720
And the topologies, boy they're complex.

95
00:04:18.720 --> 00:04:19.690
Let me show you one.

96
00:04:19.690 --> 00:04:22.060
I've got one of the topologies
pulled up here.

97
00:04:22.060 --> 00:04:26.604
And so, you'll see on this network
we've got a nice mixture of OSPF, RIP,

98
00:04:26.604 --> 00:04:29.920
EIGRP, two different
autonomous systems there.

99
00:04:29.920 --> 00:04:32.355
We've got routers, we've got switches.

100
00:04:32.355 --> 00:04:35.518
We've got devices that we control,
like all of these.

101
00:04:35.518 --> 00:04:38.781
And there's devices out here that
are actually controlled, well,

102
00:04:38.781 --> 00:04:39.970
outside of our company.

103
00:04:39.970 --> 00:04:41.360
Just like in real-life land,

104
00:04:41.360 --> 00:04:44.470
you might have an Internet service
provider, and you see their routers,

105
00:04:44.470 --> 00:04:47.430
you communicate to their routers all the
time, but you have no control over them.

106
00:04:47.430 --> 00:04:49.880
Well, that's how these
two boxes are in the lab.

107
00:04:49.880 --> 00:04:51.710
I have no control over these two, but

108
00:04:51.710 --> 00:04:56.090
the whole rest of the environment I do and
I need to solve those problems.

109
00:04:56.090 --> 00:04:59.943
So, we're gonna break this up
into troubleshooting sets.

110
00:04:59.943 --> 00:05:04.999
What we just saw was one set, and
its' got six to eight problems.

111
00:05:04.999 --> 00:05:07.625
And so we'll have to go through and
resolve all those little problems.

112
00:05:07.625 --> 00:05:09.835
And then we'll move onto the second set,
which will have,

113
00:05:09.835 --> 00:05:12.535
I don't know something like six
to eight problems there too.

114
00:05:12.535 --> 00:05:14.545
And then the next set,
and then the next set.

115
00:05:14.545 --> 00:05:15.895
There's a good nine sets here.

116
00:05:15.895 --> 00:05:20.145
There's a lot of chances to see techniques
for troubleshooting different problems,

117
00:05:20.145 --> 00:05:21.125
different solutions.

118
00:05:21.125 --> 00:05:22.485
Some really good stuff.

119
00:05:22.485 --> 00:05:23.770
So, I'm looking forward to this.

120
00:05:23.770 --> 00:05:27.365
It's always a lot of fun to go full on,
just hands on troubleshooting and

121
00:05:27.365 --> 00:05:28.410
isolating problems.

122
00:05:28.410 --> 00:05:29.790
We've seen all the tools.

123
00:05:29.790 --> 00:05:30.770
We've read all the theory.

124
00:05:30.770 --> 00:05:33.490
We know the different
techniques we can use.

125
00:05:33.490 --> 00:05:34.890
Let's see them in real life.

126
00:05:34.890 --> 00:05:37.800
Because knowing the syntax for
a command, that's one thing.

127
00:05:37.800 --> 00:05:40.740
Seeing the output of a command,
that's one thing.

128
00:05:40.740 --> 00:05:44.220
But seeing the output of a command
under different scenarios.

129
00:05:44.220 --> 00:05:46.830
You can start to learn the difference
between when it's working right and

130
00:05:46.830 --> 00:05:47.730
when it's not working right.

131
00:05:47.730 --> 00:05:50.418
You can start to recognize
when something doesn't quite

132
00:05:50.418 --> 00:05:51.930
fit the mold that it should fit.

133
00:05:51.930 --> 00:05:53.869
And that's what we're
gonna get a chance to see.

134
00:05:53.869 --> 00:05:56.367
It's gonna be a different
type of ITProTV episode.

135
00:05:56.367 --> 00:05:59.466
But it'll be neat, it'll be fun and
it'll be a great experience.

136
00:05:59.466 --> 00:06:04.190
The other thing is that the episodes
aren't dependent on each other.

137
00:06:04.190 --> 00:06:06.452
So, if you wanna skip four or
five episodes and

138
00:06:06.452 --> 00:06:08.540
jump ahead to the next one, you can.

139
00:06:08.540 --> 00:06:11.850
Each one is a self-contained,
troubleshooting problem.

140
00:06:11.850 --> 00:06:16.140
So if you you just wanna learn about
troubleshooting HSRP, you can search for

141
00:06:16.140 --> 00:06:19.660
the episodes that have the keyword
of HSRP and just watch those.

142
00:06:19.660 --> 00:06:23.160
And now you'll see five or
six episodes just on troubleshooting HSRP.

143
00:06:23.160 --> 00:06:27.560
Or if you just wanna learn about IPv6,
again, you can filter based on that.

144
00:06:27.560 --> 00:06:30.230
So, feel free to jump around
on these if you want.

145
00:06:30.230 --> 00:06:32.763
But just as a quick warning,
I'll take it nice and slow for

146
00:06:32.763 --> 00:06:35.661
the first couple of sets and
then we'll start to speed things up for

147
00:06:35.661 --> 00:06:37.954
the later sets because
that's where you need to be.

148
00:06:37.954 --> 00:06:41.449
You need to be speeding things up too,
to find those resolutions as fast and

149
00:06:41.449 --> 00:06:42.620
as quickly as possible.

150
00:06:42.620 --> 00:06:45.160
So, just keep that in mind
as you work through these.

151
00:06:45.160 --> 00:06:48.000
But I think that's enough about
what were gonna be doing.

152
00:06:48.000 --> 00:06:51.360
I'm really excited to get in here, cuz I
love working with the equipment and not

153
00:06:51.360 --> 00:06:55.542
boring you guys with pictures and slides
of bullet points and all that stuff.

154
00:06:55.542 --> 00:06:57.938
So just getting in there and
actually doing some work,

155
00:06:57.938 --> 00:06:59.146
it's gonna be a lot of fun.

156
00:06:59.146 --> 00:07:01.404
You'll definitely wanna stay tuned for it.

157
00:07:01.404 --> 00:07:07.010
For now, signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Don Pezet, and I'll see you next time.

158
00:07:07.010 --> 00:07:12.359
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #1` from set #1. The trouble ticket states that "NYACCESS1 is unable to communicate to its configured gateway of 192.168.16.1."
episodes.title: Set 1 Issue 1
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.025
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.025 --> 00:00:12.001
In this video,
we're gonna be tackling Set 1, Issue 1.

3
00:00:12.001 --> 00:00:15.200
Jumping right into troubleshooting for
CCMPT shoot, and the problem that

4
00:00:15.200 --> 00:00:18.810
we got today is what looks like
a fairly straightforward one, we've got

5
00:00:18.810 --> 00:00:22.020
the instance of a host that's unable
to ping another host on the network.

6
00:00:22.020 --> 00:00:27.160
So the troubleshooting problem actually
reads like this, it says NYACCESS1 is

7
00:00:27.160 --> 00:00:33.604
unable to communicate to its configured
default gateway of 192.168.16.1.

8
00:00:33.604 --> 00:00:37.200
So let's look at our topology and
get an idea of what it's talking about.

9
00:00:37.200 --> 00:00:40.684
What they are telling us here,
is, that this guy right here,

10
00:00:40.684 --> 00:00:45.441
this switch NYACCESS1, is unable to
communicate with it's default gateway, and

11
00:00:45.441 --> 00:00:49.670
it's telling me that the default
gateway is 192.168.16.1.

12
00:00:49.670 --> 00:00:54.651
Well, when I look at this network map,
I got a little bit of a problem here

13
00:00:54.651 --> 00:00:58.510
in that I don't see who 192.168.16.1 is.

14
00:00:58.510 --> 00:01:00.989
So, one of the first things we're gonna
have to do is we're gonna have to figure

15
00:01:00.989 --> 00:01:02.270
out that piece of the puzzle, right?

16
00:01:02.270 --> 00:01:06.050
Who is it that we're talking to and
then why can't we get there?

17
00:01:06.050 --> 00:01:09.350
Now, the only IP that I'm really seeing
jump out at me is this guy down here.

18
00:01:09.350 --> 00:01:14.050
I've got a server, and
that server is 192.168.16.10,

19
00:01:14.050 --> 00:01:17.020
so that's apparently on that 16 network.

20
00:01:17.020 --> 00:01:19.950
I've got ACCESS1 is apparently
gonna be on that network.

21
00:01:19.950 --> 00:01:21.600
We're gonna find out a little bit more,
right?

22
00:01:21.600 --> 00:01:26.520
So the troubleshooting question didn't
give us a ton of data about the network.

23
00:01:26.520 --> 00:01:28.680
We're gonna have to do some exploration,
right?

24
00:01:28.680 --> 00:01:29.940
So first off,

25
00:01:29.940 --> 00:01:35.690
if I know that NYACCESS1 is supposed
to be able to contact 192.168.16.1,

26
00:01:35.690 --> 00:01:39.350
I'm assuming that it's going to have
an IP address in that same network.

27
00:01:39.350 --> 00:01:40.240
Let's not assume.

28
00:01:40.240 --> 00:01:41.751
Let's find out for sure.

29
00:01:41.751 --> 00:01:46.329
So I'm gonna jump over to NYACCESS1,
and on that switch,

30
00:01:46.329 --> 00:01:50.460
we're just gonna verify its IP or
lack of IP, right?

31
00:01:50.460 --> 00:01:51.000
Who knows?

32
00:01:51.000 --> 00:01:52.400
Maybe it doesn't even have an IP address,

33
00:01:52.400 --> 00:01:53.780
and we'll have to figure that out,
all right?

34
00:01:53.780 --> 00:01:57.865
So I'm just gonna get in here and
just do a quick show IP interface brief.

35
00:01:57.865 --> 00:02:02.740
Show IP interface brief is a great way
to find out what IPs a switch has, and

36
00:02:02.740 --> 00:02:03.900
it usually shows us pretty quick.

37
00:02:03.900 --> 00:02:06.780
But a lot of times, I'll pipe
them into the exclude command and

38
00:02:06.780 --> 00:02:10.960
exclude the word unassigned so
I don't get all these extra interfaces.

39
00:02:10.960 --> 00:02:19.040
But as it stands, I can see that I got an
interface on Vlan16 that is 192.168.16.7.

40
00:02:19.040 --> 00:02:21.880
So we've got a Vlan and

41
00:02:21.880 --> 00:02:25.820
we've got an IP in the subnet in question
that's on that Vlan so that looks good.

42
00:02:25.820 --> 00:02:29.390
Now remember I mentioned that there was
another server in the diagram, right?

43
00:02:29.390 --> 00:02:33.270
If I go back to my network diagram,
there's this server down here

44
00:02:33.270 --> 00:02:38.280
which is plugged into FA0/1 on ACCESS1.

45
00:02:38.280 --> 00:02:41.870
So, I'm assuming that's on Vlan16 also.

46
00:02:41.870 --> 00:02:43.590
It should be, but I can check port one and

47
00:02:43.590 --> 00:02:45.830
see it's configuration
real quick to get an idea.

00:02:45.830 --> 00:02:50.357
So, if I jump back to that switch,

00:03:09.740 --> 00:03:13.097
Maybe there's some kind of Vlan issue,

00:03:13.097 --> 00:03:16.890

00:03:16.890 --> 00:03:20.600

00:03:20.600 --> 00:03:24.756
But the problem was that I can't

00:03:24.756 --> 00:03:28.271

And if I try and ping that, well, sure

00:03:31.851 --> 00:03:32.980

00:03:32.980 --> 00:03:35.680
So I definitely have some

00:03:35.680 --> 00:03:38.562

00:03:38.562 --> 00:03:41.960
It ould be a problem with the VLAN,

00:03:41.960 --> 00:03:43.690
I still don't know who .1 is, right?

00:03:43.690 --> 00:03:47.054
That could be a router,

00:03:47.054 --> 00:03:49.221

67
00:03:49.221 --> 00:03:51.661
Now this system,
if I'm trying to get to that,

00:03:51.661 --> 00:03:53.920
it said I had a default gateway set,

69
00:03:53.920 --> 00:03:57.539
Now the troubleshooting question said I'm

70
00:03:57.539 --> 00:04:00.550
it doesn't say anything about

00:04:00.550 --> 00:04:06.830
So I might wanna check the running

72
00:04:06.830 --> 00:04:11.130

73
00:04:11.130 --> 00:04:15.460
So I've got that ip default-gateway,
and there's the IP.

74
00:04:15.460 --> 00:04:17.934
But they didn't actually ask me to

75
00:04:17.934 --> 00:04:20.560
they just want to make sure

76
00:04:20.560 --> 00:04:23.180
But I do have that line,

00:04:23.180 --> 00:04:24.710
I can't get to that IP.

78
00:04:24.710 --> 00:04:27.730
So my next step is gonna be

79
00:04:27.730 --> 00:04:32.340
It's not me, I'm .7, so it must be one

80
00:04:32.340 --> 00:04:37.940
Now normally when it comes to something
like a layer three address like this,

81
00:04:37.940 --> 00:04:40.450
I'm gonna assume that it's gonna
be one of these three routers

82
00:04:40.450 --> 00:04:41.640
here in the LAN, right.

83
00:04:41.640 --> 00:04:44.400
Your router is normally gonna
be your default gateway.

84
00:04:44.400 --> 00:04:47.330
But I've got these core switches also, and

85
00:04:47.330 --> 00:04:51.270
remember in CISCO's recommended
design model, your core, and

86
00:04:51.270 --> 00:04:54.900
really your distribution switches, are
normally going to be layer three switches.

87
00:04:54.900 --> 00:04:56.400
So they can be routers also.

88
00:04:56.400 --> 00:05:03.901
So I expect 192.168.16.1 to be
on one of these five devices.

89
00:05:03.901 --> 00:05:05.320
I don't know which one.

90
00:05:05.320 --> 00:05:07.080
So to try and make this go faster,

91
00:05:07.080 --> 00:05:09.850
cuz on the exam you don't have a ton of
time, what you usually wanna do is start

92
00:05:09.850 --> 00:05:12.490
with the devices closest to
who you're troubleshooting,

93
00:05:12.490 --> 00:05:15.850
because usually the gateway is
gonna be very close to those nodes.

94
00:05:15.850 --> 00:05:17.640
So I'm gonna check these
two switches first.

95
00:05:17.640 --> 00:05:20.180
If it's not them,
then I'll check these two routers, and

96
00:05:20.180 --> 00:05:22.840
if it's not them,
I'll check this other router here last.

97
00:05:22.840 --> 00:05:24.810
Okay, now how do I check?

98
00:05:24.810 --> 00:05:29.320
Just a quick show IP Interface brief on
each of the systems and we can spot it.

99
00:05:29.320 --> 00:05:37.490
So, I am gonna jump over here to CORE1 and

100
00:05:37.490 --> 00:05:42.044
So here I am on CORE1 and I am gonna
do a quick show IP interface brief, and

101
00:05:42.044 --> 00:05:46.975
I am going to exclude any unassigned
interfaces, so I just see interfaces that

102
00:05:46.975 --> 00:05:52.230

103
00:05:52.230 --> 00:05:54.184
It looks like it's dot 1 from
one that we've done here,

104
00:05:54.184 --> 00:05:55.372
but it's not the one I care about.

105
00:05:55.372 --> 00:06:01.770
The one that I care about is 192.168.16.2,
and that's not .1, so I can move on.

106
00:06:01.770 --> 00:06:03.900
Now, I do see that interface
is administratively down,

107
00:06:03.900 --> 00:06:08.470
but again, the IP doesn't match, and since
it doesn't match, I don't really care.

108
00:06:08.470 --> 00:06:10.550
So [LAUGH] I'll move on.

109
00:06:10.550 --> 00:06:12.240
On NYCORE2, I'll do the same thing.

110
00:06:12.240 --> 00:06:15.560
And I'm gonna do another
show IP interface brief, and

111
00:06:15.560 --> 00:06:18.100
I'll exclude any unassigned addresses.

112
00:06:18.100 --> 00:06:21.090
And on this one it looks
like it's .3 on everything.

113
00:06:21.090 --> 00:06:23.680
So we found .2, we found .3,
we've still not .1.

114
00:06:23.680 --> 00:06:26.170
So, now I'm gonna start
checking those routers.

115
00:06:26.170 --> 00:06:28.940
And I had three different routers
that were on the network.

116
00:06:28.940 --> 00:06:32.250
There were NYEDGE1 and EDGE2 and NYWAN1.

117
00:06:32.250 --> 00:06:36.000
I'm gonna start with the EDGE routers and
jump over to those guys.

118
00:06:36.000 --> 00:06:37.860
And just kinda rinse and repeat, right?

119
00:06:37.860 --> 00:06:43.570
I'm just doing a quick show ip int
brief and excluding the unassigned.

120
00:06:43.570 --> 00:06:45.840
On a router I probably don't
need to exclude the unassign.

121
00:06:45.840 --> 00:06:48.020
They're usually not gonna
have that many interfaces.

122
00:06:48.020 --> 00:06:50.810
This guy is .4 not .1.

123
00:06:50.810 --> 00:06:58.130
And EDGE2 is, let's see, .5, not .1.

124
00:06:58.130 --> 00:07:00.740
Well actually, it doesn't have
a 192.168.16 address at all.

125
00:07:00.740 --> 00:07:02.200
So I just ignore EDGE2.

126
00:07:02.200 --> 00:07:04.340
And then, we've only got one more,

127
00:07:04.340 --> 00:07:09.130
so I think this one's gonna be our winner,
and this is NYWAN1.

128
00:07:11.670 --> 00:07:15.160
And oh, that almost got me there.

129
00:07:15.160 --> 00:07:16.560
I thought we had a winner.

130
00:07:16.560 --> 00:07:19.200
I see 172.16.16.1.

131
00:07:19.200 --> 00:07:21.380
It's got the 16, but
the rest of it's wrong.

132
00:07:21.380 --> 00:07:27.400
It doesn't have 192.168.16.1.
So now I got a head scratcher, right?

133
00:07:27.400 --> 00:07:28.460
I know that this switch,

134
00:07:28.460 --> 00:07:34.350
NYACCESS1 is supposed to have
a default gateway of 192.168.16.1.

135
00:07:34.350 --> 00:07:37.750
But nobody has that IP,
whose it supposed to be?

136
00:07:37.750 --> 00:07:40.910
Well, when I ran through each of
these devices, I ran a command,

137
00:07:40.910 --> 00:07:43.700
show IP interface brief, right, and

138
00:07:43.700 --> 00:07:47.530
that will show you the IP addresses
assigned to all of your interfaces.

139
00:07:47.530 --> 00:07:51.480
But there are sometimes where
you can have an IP address, and

140
00:07:51.480 --> 00:07:53.480
it won't show up with that command.

141
00:07:53.480 --> 00:07:55.430
For example, a secondary address.

142
00:07:55.430 --> 00:07:58.649
An interface can have more than one IP,
and if I have a secondary attached to it,

143
00:07:58.649 --> 00:07:59.768
it won't show up, right?

144
00:07:59.768 --> 00:08:03.949
Let me give you an example here, just so
you know what I'm talking about.

145
00:08:03.949 --> 00:08:07.179
If I go, I'll go back to ACCESS1.

146
00:08:07.179 --> 00:08:11.072
And on ACCESS1,
let's say I create a loopback.

147
00:08:11.072 --> 00:08:13.733
So I'm gonna create interface loopback 99.

148
00:08:13.733 --> 00:08:22.210
And I'm gonna get an IP
address of 192.168.99.2.

149
00:08:22.210 --> 00:08:26.710
All right, and so that's the IP address
that's gonna be on that interface.

150
00:08:26.710 --> 00:08:31.710
Now when I assign that IP, I can do a show
IP interface brief, and I can exclude

151
00:08:31.710 --> 00:08:36.080
the unassigned interfaces and I'll see
Loopback99 and there's it's IP right?

152
00:08:37.240 --> 00:08:41.614
Now if I do a secondary address,

153
00:08:41.614 --> 00:08:50.691
if I say IP address 192.168.99.1
with a subnet mask.

154
00:08:50.691 --> 00:08:51.482
Whoops!

155
00:08:51.482 --> 00:08:55.026
And I need to do dotted decimal
not slashed decimal and

156
00:08:55.026 --> 00:08:58.274
then I'm just gonna add
the key word secondary.

157
00:08:58.274 --> 00:09:00.712
Okay, when I add that keyword secondary,

158
00:09:00.712 --> 00:09:03.740
the interface now has two IP addresses,
right?

159
00:09:03.740 --> 00:09:07.710
So if I do a show run for
interface loopback 99,

160
00:09:07.710 --> 00:09:10.780
I can see it's got .1 and it's got .2.

161
00:09:10.780 --> 00:09:12.710
So it's got two addresses.

162
00:09:12.710 --> 00:09:15.020
But when I do a show
IP interface brief and

163
00:09:15.020 --> 00:09:18.460
I exclude any unassigned,
see how I don't see .1?

164
00:09:18.460 --> 00:09:20.570
So there's times were we can have
an IP address that doesn't show

165
00:09:20.570 --> 00:09:23.490
up on the interface and that's
probably what's going on here, okay.

166
00:09:23.490 --> 00:09:26.710
Somebody has to have that dot one if
it's gonna be our default gateway,

167
00:09:26.710 --> 00:09:28.120
I just didn't find it.

168
00:09:28.120 --> 00:09:30.810
So I needed to do a better job looking for
it.

169
00:09:30.810 --> 00:09:33.200
And so, instead of doing
a show IP interface brief,

170
00:09:33.200 --> 00:09:35.460
I can do a show running config.

171
00:09:35.460 --> 00:09:41.330
And I could just do something like this,
show running dash config and

172
00:09:41.330 --> 00:09:45.794
include lines with 192.168.16.1, right?

173
00:09:45.794 --> 00:09:47.800
Is that in here anywhere?

174
00:09:47.800 --> 00:09:50.750
And I can see that I've got my default
gateway on this switch but that's it.

175
00:09:50.750 --> 00:09:53.890
But I can run through and
do that on my other switches.

176
00:09:53.890 --> 00:09:56.410
And hopefully find out which one has that.

177
00:09:56.410 --> 00:09:58.565
So I'm just gonna do a quick
show running config and

178
00:09:58.565 --> 00:10:02.580
include lines with 192.168.16.1.

179
00:10:02.580 --> 00:10:04.800
And we will, oop, there we go.

180
00:10:04.800 --> 00:10:07.000
All right, I mentioned a secondary IP.

181
00:10:07.000 --> 00:10:10.910
Here's another example of where an IP
address might not show up on an interface.

182
00:10:10.910 --> 00:10:11.942
It's a standby.

183
00:10:11.942 --> 00:10:13.580
All right, what is standby?

184
00:10:13.580 --> 00:10:14.910
HSRP.

185
00:10:14.910 --> 00:10:19.441
This switch, I know it has 192.168.16.2.

186
00:10:19.441 --> 00:10:20.816
We saw that earlier.

187
00:10:20.816 --> 00:10:25.899
But, it's also got .1
as an HSRP virtual IP.

188
00:10:25.899 --> 00:10:28.121
This is a virtual IP so,
it might be on this switch,

189
00:10:28.121 --> 00:10:31.485
it might be on another router, it might
be on another system somewhere else,

190
00:10:31.485 --> 00:10:34.040
this one may or may not be active for it.

191
00:10:34.040 --> 00:10:40.031
So, let's find out if it's active, so
I'm gonna do a show standby for vlan 16.

192
00:10:42.540 --> 00:10:43.980
Sure enough, I can see we're active.

193
00:10:43.980 --> 00:10:49.910
Okay, so this guy is active for Vlan16 and

194
00:10:49.910 --> 00:10:53.720
I can see that virtual IP is 192.168.16.1
and here is the virtual MAC address for

195
00:10:53.720 --> 00:10:58.470
it right there, so
this guy is the active one.

196
00:10:58.470 --> 00:11:02.340
And I'm gonna write down that MAC address
because we're probably gonna need that.

197
00:11:02.340 --> 00:11:05.840
With HSRP,
it dynamically generates the MAC address.

198
00:11:05.840 --> 00:11:07.555
So it's gonna generate this for us and so

199
00:11:07.555 --> 00:11:09.482
you can't always assume
you know what it is.

200
00:11:09.482 --> 00:11:12.983
And so I'm gonna write this one down in
case we need to do any tracking based on

201
00:11:12.983 --> 00:11:13.816
the MAC address.

202
00:11:13.816 --> 00:11:17.823
So I'm just writing it down right here on
my piece of paper, handy-dandy paper, and

203
00:11:17.823 --> 00:11:21.290
remember on the exam, you will have
a piece of paper that you can write on.

204
00:11:21.290 --> 00:11:24.580
If they don't give you one, you can ask
for it and they will, and it's handy for

205
00:11:24.580 --> 00:11:26.010
jotting down things like this MAC address.

206
00:11:26.010 --> 00:11:29.890
So I need that, so
I've got it and there's my IP.

207
00:11:29.890 --> 00:11:33.590
So I just found 192.168.16.1.

208
00:11:33.590 --> 00:11:39.070
And if I go back to my diagram,
that was right here on NYCORE1.

209
00:11:39.070 --> 00:11:42.370
So when they tell me that
NYACCESS1 can't ping its gateway,

210
00:11:42.370 --> 00:11:44.220
its gateway is right here.

211
00:11:44.220 --> 00:11:45.790
That's not very far away.

212
00:11:45.790 --> 00:11:49.090
Well, I've got this link right here.

213
00:11:49.090 --> 00:11:53.470
This link needs to be carrying VLAN16
in order for me to reach over and

214
00:11:53.470 --> 00:11:56.760
get to that other side, so
if there's a problem with this link

215
00:11:56.760 --> 00:11:58.620
then that may explain why
I can't get to that host.

216
00:11:58.620 --> 00:12:00.610
So I need to figure that out, all right.

217
00:12:00.610 --> 00:12:02.840
So let's go and
do some experimenting there and

218
00:12:02.840 --> 00:12:04.000
see if we can't isolate this problem.

219
00:12:04.000 --> 00:12:07.670
So I'm gonna jump over to NYACCESS1 and
see what I can find.

220
00:12:07.670 --> 00:12:15.375
So on NYACCESS1, I know that I've got
an IP address on the 192.168.16 network.

221
00:12:15.375 --> 00:12:18.420
And I know I can ping that server so
I know I'm functional.

222
00:12:18.420 --> 00:12:21.080
I just don't know if I can
get to the other side, right.

223
00:12:21.080 --> 00:12:24.740
And on my side that trunk
is right here on port 24.

224
00:12:24.740 --> 00:12:31.670
So I'm just gonna do a quick show run
interface fa0/24 And take a look at it.

225
00:12:31.670 --> 00:12:33.318
And I've got a trunk configured.

226
00:12:33.318 --> 00:12:37.100
So it says switch port mode trunk,
and the trunk is allowing VLAN 16,

227
00:12:37.100 --> 00:12:40.750
so right off the bat,
things are looking good there.

228
00:12:40.750 --> 00:12:43.310
I'm definitely carrying the VLAN,
I'm definitely trunking.

229
00:12:43.310 --> 00:12:49.690
And if I do a show interface trunk,
I should be able to see, on port 24.

230
00:12:49.690 --> 00:12:54.710
There's VLAN 16, it's allowed and active,
and it's forwarding and not pruned.

231
00:12:55.840 --> 00:12:58.410
It should be good to go,
on this side, right?

232
00:12:58.410 --> 00:13:01.820
Let's go check the other side of this
trunk and see if it's actually working.

233
00:13:01.820 --> 00:13:06.730
Now the other side of the trunk
is port 22 on NYCORE1,

234
00:13:06.730 --> 00:13:08.960
so I'm going to jump over to NYCORE1.

235
00:13:10.880 --> 00:13:14.390
And we're gonna take a look at
the other end of this trunk.

236
00:13:14.390 --> 00:13:16.399
And I said that was port 22.

237
00:13:16.399 --> 00:13:21.649
So I'm gonna do a show run int fa1/0/22.

238
00:13:21.649 --> 00:13:26.060
And well,
I'm not configured as a trunk here, right?

239
00:13:26.060 --> 00:13:28.630
I don't see a trunk encapsulation set.

240
00:13:28.630 --> 00:13:34.050
I don't see any allowed VLANs, but
I might be doing dynamic trunking right?

241
00:13:34.050 --> 00:13:37.570
Some Cisco switches default to
doing dynamic trunking, some don't.

242
00:13:37.570 --> 00:13:40.742
Even within the same model of
switch some versions of the iOS do,

243
00:13:40.742 --> 00:13:42.398
some versions of the iOS don't.

244
00:13:42.398 --> 00:13:45.404
So just because I don't see trunking
commands here doesn't mean that I'm

245
00:13:45.404 --> 00:13:46.390
not trunking.

246
00:13:46.390 --> 00:13:48.170
I might be doing it dynamically right.

247
00:13:48.170 --> 00:13:51.070
You can find that out real fast
by doing a show interface trunk,

248
00:13:51.070 --> 00:13:53.090
because it will tell you in there, right?

249
00:13:53.090 --> 00:13:56.080
When I look at show interface trunk,
here's Fa1/0/22 and

250
00:13:56.080 --> 00:13:59.780
see how the mode is auto, right?

251
00:13:59.780 --> 00:14:01.060
It's doing dynamic trunking.

252
00:14:01.060 --> 00:14:04.450
And I can see that it negotiated 802.1q.

253
00:14:04.450 --> 00:14:05.903
So, it is negotiating, it is trunking,

254
00:14:05.903 --> 00:14:07.857
even though I don't see
the commands on the interface.

255
00:14:07.857 --> 00:14:12.969
And looking down here, at port 22,
it's allowing Vlans 1-4094.

256
00:14:14.060 --> 00:14:16.800
VLANs that are active, 1 and 10-16.

257
00:14:16.800 --> 00:14:21.274
And then down here VLANs in
spanning tree forwarding state and

258
00:14:21.274 --> 00:14:24.815
not pruned 1 and 10-15, 16 is missing.

259
00:14:24.815 --> 00:14:26.191
I think we just found the problem.

260
00:14:26.191 --> 00:14:26.774
All right?

261
00:14:26.774 --> 00:14:29.110
Now, what does that mean?

262
00:14:29.110 --> 00:14:32.870
It's telling me here VLANs in spanning
tree forwarding state, right?

263
00:14:32.870 --> 00:14:34.020
And not pruned.

264
00:14:34.020 --> 00:14:37.140
When would spanning tree prune a VLAN?

265
00:14:37.140 --> 00:14:37.690
If there was a loop.

266
00:14:37.690 --> 00:14:41.080
If there was a loop on this interface
then it might shut if off, right?

267
00:14:41.080 --> 00:14:47.196
And if I do a show spanning-tree vlan 16,
let's see what we'll get here.

268
00:14:47.196 --> 00:14:52.566
Sure enough, for
Fa1/0/22 is blocking, right.

269
00:14:52.566 --> 00:14:57.578
It's in a BKN right blocking state and if
I look all the way over to this side here,

270
00:14:57.578 --> 00:15:01.857
I can see where it says ROOT_Inc
which means, root inconsistent and

271
00:15:01.857 --> 00:15:06.670
what is that, root guard, looks like
we're running root guard, right.

272
00:15:06.670 --> 00:15:10.060
And we saw that on the interface, right
when I do the show running config for

273
00:15:10.060 --> 00:15:13.600
interface fa1/0/22.

274
00:15:13.600 --> 00:15:15.840
Spanning tree guard root.

275
00:15:15.840 --> 00:15:20.400
So we will not let the switch on the other
end of this line become the root.

276
00:15:20.400 --> 00:15:23.660
And if I go back to my diagram the switch
on the other end of the line ACCESS1.

277
00:15:23.660 --> 00:15:27.760
So if ACCESS1 is trying to become
the root I'm gonna block it and

278
00:15:27.760 --> 00:15:29.310
that's gonna cut it off from VLAN 16.

279
00:15:29.310 --> 00:15:33.735
Now that's not the end of the world
because ACCESS1 might be able to go

280
00:15:33.735 --> 00:15:36.441
this other way to get to VLAN 16, right?

281
00:15:36.441 --> 00:15:39.573
I know it's not cuz the ping fails but
it could,

282
00:15:39.573 --> 00:15:42.400
so do I have root guard over here also?

283
00:15:42.400 --> 00:15:43.200
I probably do.

284
00:15:43.200 --> 00:15:46.060
I'm gonna go take a look at port 22
on the other switch just to see if we

285
00:15:46.060 --> 00:15:47.940
have root guard there also.

286
00:15:47.940 --> 00:15:50.620
And what this is gonna do is
it's gonna help me decide

287
00:15:50.620 --> 00:15:54.620
do I want to disable root guard or do I
want to influence who the root is right?

288
00:15:54.620 --> 00:15:58.100
We've got to figure out which
solution we're gonna pick, and so

289
00:15:58.100 --> 00:16:01.148
I'm gonna look at this guy and
it's got root guard also.

290
00:16:01.148 --> 00:16:06.155
So whoever set up this network obviously
intended the core switches to be root,

291
00:16:06.155 --> 00:16:06.688
right?

292
00:16:06.688 --> 00:16:11.448
They wanted one of these course which is
to be root and not some access switch.

293
00:16:11.448 --> 00:16:14.912
And in my scenario, the access switch
is trying to become the root, and

294
00:16:14.912 --> 00:16:17.530
so it's blocking that port and
that's stopping it.

295
00:16:17.530 --> 00:16:18.400
That's going to be our problem.

296
00:16:18.400 --> 00:16:21.480
Now, why is ACCESS1 trying
to become the root?

297
00:16:21.480 --> 00:16:23.180
It might not be intentional.

298
00:16:23.180 --> 00:16:26.160
ACCESS1 might have a lower MAC address.

299
00:16:26.160 --> 00:16:29.227
Now, when it comes to root election
priorities, what we really care about,

300
00:16:29.227 --> 00:16:32.122
right, it is a priority number and
that's the one that really matters.

301
00:16:32.122 --> 00:16:36.406
But every Cisco switched
defaults to 32,768.

302
00:16:36.406 --> 00:16:40.274
If these are the defaults we have tie,
and it could be that access one just has

303
00:16:40.274 --> 00:16:43.980
a lower mac address and
it's winning the tiebreaker.

304
00:16:43.980 --> 00:16:46.310
And if that's the case,
this could be an innocent mistake.

305
00:16:46.310 --> 00:16:49.300
All we have to do is adjust priority
to make sure that this guy doesn't

306
00:16:49.300 --> 00:16:49.859
win the election.

307
00:16:50.990 --> 00:16:54.550
Or it could be that somebody manually
set it to WAN, right, someone

308
00:16:54.550 --> 00:16:58.520
could have manually set that priority, and
if that's the case, then that's going to

309
00:16:58.520 --> 00:17:01.550
be our problem, and we just need to fix
that, and that will solve our problem too.

310
00:17:01.550 --> 00:17:04.920
Alright, so let's go look at Access One
and see what is the true case here.

311
00:17:04.920 --> 00:17:09.377
So, on Access One,
I'm just going to search the config, and

312
00:17:09.377 --> 00:17:14.040
I'm going to look for
any command with spanning tree in it.

313
00:17:14.040 --> 00:17:16.200
All right and I'm looking to see
if somebody set the priority and

314
00:17:16.200 --> 00:17:17.363
sure enough they have right here.

315
00:17:17.363 --> 00:17:22.809
I've got spanning tree
vlan 16 priority 4096.

316
00:17:22.809 --> 00:17:25.510
Okay, that's a really low priority and

317
00:17:25.510 --> 00:17:29.420
the lower number wins in
the spanning tree election.

318
00:17:29.420 --> 00:17:33.850
So this guy's trying to become the root,
the other guys are blocking it and

319
00:17:33.850 --> 00:17:34.870
not allowing it.

320
00:17:34.870 --> 00:17:38.610
Now I could just remove this and
put it back to the default, right?

321
00:17:38.610 --> 00:17:40.900
But I don't know what the priority
is on the other switches, so

322
00:17:40.900 --> 00:17:42.570
I don't necessarily know if
that affects the problem.

323
00:17:42.570 --> 00:17:44.385
I'm going to go checkout
their priorities real quick.

324
00:17:44.385 --> 00:17:48.970
On NY Core one, I'm just going to do
a shows spinning dash three for vlan 16,

325
00:17:48.970 --> 00:17:52.220
I'm being really particular
here in saying vlan 16.

326
00:17:52.220 --> 00:17:55.033
Because you can have different
priorities for different vlans.

327
00:17:55.033 --> 00:18:01.048
And on this one,
it's got a priority of 12288, right.

328
00:18:01.048 --> 00:18:03.470
So good to know.

329
00:18:03.470 --> 00:18:06.250
And then if I take a look
at the other core switch,

330
00:18:06.250 --> 00:18:11.380
core two, and
look at its spanning tree for VLAN16.

331
00:18:11.380 --> 00:18:16.345
It has a priority of 8,192, all right.

332
00:18:16.345 --> 00:18:20.670
So on NY axis one, if I just give
it a priority higher than 12,188,

333
00:18:20.670 --> 00:18:24.500
then that will solve my problem,
resetting it to the default.

334
00:18:24.500 --> 00:18:25.780
So we'll do that.
So that's what I'm going to do.

335
00:18:25.780 --> 00:18:27.765
I'm going to jump over to access one, and

336
00:18:27.765 --> 00:18:30.840
on access one I'm just going
to kill this priority line.

337
00:18:30.840 --> 00:18:34.830
So you can just copy and paste it or
retype it however you want to do it.

338
00:18:34.830 --> 00:18:36.590
You don't have to remember the default.

339
00:18:36.590 --> 00:18:39.940
If you just do a no command for
the command that's already in there

340
00:18:41.830 --> 00:18:45.770
like this, that'll remove the command and
put it back to the defaults.

341
00:18:45.770 --> 00:18:49.250
I could have also said spanning
dash tree vlan 16 priority 32,768,

342
00:18:49.250 --> 00:18:52.720
that would have achieved it also, right?

343
00:18:52.720 --> 00:18:57.180
But in this case it removes it, I should
be going back to my default priority.

344
00:18:57.180 --> 00:19:02.429
And when I do that,
assuming I can spell here, there we go.

345
00:19:02.429 --> 00:19:06.805
Then I should be back to 32,768.

346
00:19:06.805 --> 00:19:10.634
And now we should start communicating with
the other side and we should get some new

347
00:19:10.634 --> 00:19:13.950
negotiations happening and
some ports should start to come up.

348
00:19:13.950 --> 00:19:16.130
Ports that were blocking
should be fine now.

349
00:19:16.130 --> 00:19:19.130
Now, technically,
root guard was blocking that port.

350
00:19:19.130 --> 00:19:21.370
We need to verify that
it stopped blocking it.

351
00:19:21.370 --> 00:19:23.830
We might have to reset the port for
that to happen.

352
00:19:23.830 --> 00:19:26.100
But oh, oh, I got a message right here.

353
00:19:26.100 --> 00:19:28.860
It's actually telling
me root guard unblock.

354
00:19:28.860 --> 00:19:32.837
Root guard is unblocking port
FastEthernet1/0/22 on VLAN0016, so

355
00:19:32.837 --> 00:19:33.916
I should be covered.

356
00:19:33.916 --> 00:19:39.418
If we jump back out to NYAccess1,
we can test our ping that failed earlier.

357
00:19:39.418 --> 00:19:45.690
I'm going to see if I can ping
192.168.16.1, and we can.

358
00:19:45.690 --> 00:19:49.430
All right looks like our problem is solved
and I wrote that Mac address down earlier,

359
00:19:49.430 --> 00:19:52.560
ended up not using it, so
that worked out really well.

360
00:19:52.560 --> 00:19:56.250
So you might remember I wrote down that
Mac address for the hsrp cluster earlier.

361
00:19:56.250 --> 00:19:57.820
Ended up not needing that right?

362
00:19:57.820 --> 00:20:00.590
It is useful though in the event
that I did have to find

363
00:20:00.590 --> 00:20:03.570
the path that I was following across the
network to see where I had a stoppage or

364
00:20:03.570 --> 00:20:05.780
whatever I could have used
that bit neater this time.

365
00:20:05.780 --> 00:20:07.480
Better to have more
information than not enough.

366
00:20:07.480 --> 00:20:09.160
You never know what you're going to need.

367
00:20:09.160 --> 00:20:12.340
But in this case, it turned out
to be a root bridge election.

368
00:20:12.340 --> 00:20:13.450
We solved that problem.

369
00:20:13.450 --> 00:20:14.440
Now the network's up and going.

370
00:20:14.440 --> 00:20:16.490
We were able to ping and
we resolved the issue.

371
00:20:16.490 --> 00:20:18.490
And it's time to move
on to the next problem.

372
00:20:18.490 --> 00:20:19.950
So stay tuned.

373
00:20:19.950 --> 00:20:22.112
We've got more Cisco
trouble shooting coming up.

374
00:20:22.112 --> 00:20:27.800
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #2` from set #1. The trouble ticket states that "HSRP Group 12 on NYCORE1 and NYCORE2 are both reporting as active, but NYCORE1 should be active for odd numbered VLANs (11,13,15) and NYCORE2 should be active for even numbered VLANs (10,12,14,16) and NYEDGE1 should be the last device to become active in this group."
episodes.title: Set 1 Issue 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.495
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.495 --> 00:00:11.310
All right, welcome back to another
troubleshooting scenario for CCMPT shoot.

3
00:00:11.310 --> 00:00:15.400
We're gonna be tackling Set 1, Issue 2,
and this one is a bit of a doozy.

4
00:00:15.400 --> 00:00:17.465
Most of ours are like one sentence,
this one's a whole paragraph.

5
00:00:17.465 --> 00:00:21.996
[LAUGH] Here's our problem,
we've got HSRP group 12, so

6
00:00:21.996 --> 00:00:28.260
a very particular group, on NYCORE1 and
NYCORE2 are both reporting as active.

7
00:00:28.260 --> 00:00:33.294
But NYCORE1 should be active for
odd numbered VLANS, 11, 13 and 15, and

8
00:00:33.294 --> 00:00:38.420
NYCORE2 should be active for
even numbered VLANS 10, 12, 14, and 16.

9
00:00:38.420 --> 00:00:44.850
And NYEDGE1 should be the last device
to become active in this group.

10
00:00:44.850 --> 00:00:48.040
All right, so we're gonna have to go to
the diagram on this one cuz it sounds

11
00:00:48.040 --> 00:00:50.550
like we got a bizarre love
triangle of HSRP here.

12
00:00:50.550 --> 00:00:52.750
So let's take a look at what we've got.

13
00:00:52.750 --> 00:00:58.770
Taking a look at our diagram, the three
nodes they called out were NYCORE1,

14
00:00:58.770 --> 00:01:04.350
NYCORE2 and NYEDGE1,
these three guys right here, okay.

15
00:01:04.350 --> 00:01:07.770
And what they told me,
was that we're gonna be running HSRP for

16
00:01:07.770 --> 00:01:09.990
VLANs 10 through 16, right?

17
00:01:09.990 --> 00:01:13.430
So we've got seven VLANs
that we're running this for.

18
00:01:13.430 --> 00:01:16.270
And for the even numbered VLANs,

19
00:01:16.270 --> 00:01:22.020
NYCORE1 should be standby and
NYCORE2 should be active.

20
00:01:22.020 --> 00:01:26.300
And for the odd numbered VLANs,
NYCORE1 should be active, and

21
00:01:26.300 --> 00:01:29.940
NYCORE2 should be standby, so
they're kinda dividing up the load.

22
00:01:29.940 --> 00:01:35.620
But then for all of the VLANs,
NYEDGE1 should be in third place,

23
00:01:35.620 --> 00:01:40.180
and if you remember HSRP,
you have active, standby, and other.

24
00:01:40.180 --> 00:01:43.300
So this is like the other in HSRP.

25
00:01:43.300 --> 00:01:45.190
It's not standby or active.

26
00:01:45.190 --> 00:01:48.150
So that's kind of the priority we
want to have, and I'm glad I used

27
00:01:48.150 --> 00:01:50.800
the word priority there because priorities
are going to come into the mix.

28
00:01:50.800 --> 00:01:53.810
If you want to influence who is active,
and who's standby, and

29
00:01:53.810 --> 00:01:55.990
who's other, we've got to set priorities.

30
00:01:55.990 --> 00:01:56.950
So right off the bat,

31
00:01:56.950 --> 00:02:00.500
I'm starting to remember all
the things we've learned about HSRP.

32
00:02:00.500 --> 00:02:03.310
I know I gotta set priorities for
each group to get this set right and

33
00:02:03.310 --> 00:02:08.050
I know that the higher the priority
number, the better, right.

34
00:02:08.050 --> 00:02:11.290
This is where things get kinda confusing,
cuz sometimes, it's the lower number that

35
00:02:11.290 --> 00:02:15.980
wins, like in a expanding tree protocol,
the lower number becomes root.

36
00:02:15.980 --> 00:02:19.382
But in HSRP,
the higher the number becomes active.

37
00:02:19.382 --> 00:02:22.180
Another thing I need to be on
the look out for is preemption.

38
00:02:22.180 --> 00:02:25.940
If I got a network failure and
then the network failure is corrected,

39
00:02:25.940 --> 00:02:31.610
if I don't have preemption turned on,
a lower priority router might stay active

40
00:02:31.610 --> 00:02:35.650
because the higher priority router isn't
jumping in and taking back over again.

41
00:02:35.650 --> 00:02:38.000
So we'll need to pay attention for
those as we go through and

42
00:02:38.000 --> 00:02:39.190
we look at the configurations.

43
00:02:39.190 --> 00:02:42.580
Now, I'm gonna start with
these two guys down here and

44
00:02:42.580 --> 00:02:46.750
I'm kind of going to NYEDGE in the start
and just kinda put it out of my mind.

45
00:02:46.750 --> 00:02:49.450
And I'm really just focusing
in on one VLAN because

46
00:02:50.850 --> 00:02:54.080
the problem told me all
about these other VLANs.

47
00:02:54.080 --> 00:02:58.440
The problem itself is HSRP
group 12 on NYCORE1 and

48
00:02:58.440 --> 00:03:01.180
NYCORE2 are both reporting as active.

49
00:03:01.180 --> 00:03:02.050
Okay?

50
00:03:02.050 --> 00:03:04.779
Everything else in the paragraph
is really just supporting info.

51
00:03:04.779 --> 00:03:09.422
So they're telling you that CORE1 and
CORE2 are both active, not EDGE1.

52
00:03:09.422 --> 00:03:11.058
So again,
I'm just gonna put EDGE1 out of my mind.

53
00:03:11.058 --> 00:03:14.813
And then CORE1 and
CORE2 are both active and, let's see,

54
00:03:14.813 --> 00:03:16.970
who's suppose to be active?

55
00:03:16.970 --> 00:03:20.910
For an even-numbered network
we should have CORE2.

56
00:03:20.910 --> 00:03:25.310
So CORE2 should be active,
which it is, and CORE1 should not.

57
00:03:25.310 --> 00:03:29.870
All right, now before I jump in and
really start troubleshooting this,

58
00:03:29.870 --> 00:03:33.552
what could cause two devices
to go active at the same time?

59
00:03:33.552 --> 00:03:35.258
Well, it's actually really hard for

60
00:03:35.258 --> 00:03:38.829
HSRP to have two nodes go active at the
same time, cuz they're sending these low

61
00:03:38.829 --> 00:03:41.406
level broadcast type
communications over the network.

62
00:03:41.406 --> 00:03:46.430
It's pretty straight forward,
as long as they can see each other.

63
00:03:46.430 --> 00:03:50.880
If these two switches can't see each
other, then they'll both go active.

64
00:03:50.880 --> 00:03:53.380
Cuz they both think
the other person has failed.

65
00:03:53.380 --> 00:03:56.200
So I'm probably dealing with
a communications problem.

66
00:03:56.200 --> 00:03:59.390
And HSRP does not like to
pass through routers, so

67
00:03:59.390 --> 00:04:01.570
I don't have to worry about
it going up through this way.

68
00:04:01.570 --> 00:04:04.570
You have to do like GRE tunnels and
all sorts of craziness to make it happen.

69
00:04:04.570 --> 00:04:05.680
It's not worth it.

70
00:04:05.680 --> 00:04:12.090
So, it's more than likely going to be some
kind of connectivity issue here or here.

71
00:04:12.090 --> 00:04:15.640
And you can have all sorts of v-link
configuration, spanning tree and so on

72
00:04:15.640 --> 00:04:18.710
that can break that, but I'll bet we are
dealing with a communications issue and

73
00:04:18.710 --> 00:04:20.430
I haven't even dug into the problem yet.

74
00:04:20.430 --> 00:04:23.060
So, let's get in here and
start to take a look at it.

75
00:04:23.060 --> 00:04:25.920
I'm gonna focus just on
HSRP group 12 cuz that's

76
00:04:25.920 --> 00:04:27.990
really what the problem's all about.

77
00:04:27.990 --> 00:04:32.010
And I wanna see this guy be standby,
I wanna see this guy be active, and

78
00:04:32.010 --> 00:04:34.720
by the end of this, I wanna see
this last guy up here, NYEDGE1,

79
00:04:34.720 --> 00:04:39.000
I want him to be the other,
not active or standby.

80
00:04:39.000 --> 00:04:41.320
So I'm gonna start way over here in CORE2.

81
00:04:41.320 --> 00:04:43.660
The person who's supposed to be active and
is.

82
00:04:43.660 --> 00:04:46.810
I just wanna see their configuration,
cuz it's more than likely correct.

83
00:04:46.810 --> 00:04:48.082
And then I can jump and
look at the other one.

84
00:04:48.082 --> 00:04:55.835
So if I jump over to CORE2,
We can get into that switch.

85
00:04:55.835 --> 00:04:59.755
And I'm gonna keep the switch names up
here in the screen cuz it's easy to get

86
00:04:59.755 --> 00:05:00.820
them mixed up.

87
00:05:00.820 --> 00:05:07.120
So I'm gonna jump into CORE2 here, and
I'm gonna do a show standby for VLAN 12.

88
00:05:07.120 --> 00:05:07.670
All right?

89
00:05:07.670 --> 00:05:10.010
I just wanna look at the configuration for
VLAN12.

90
00:05:10.010 --> 00:05:13.674
And so what I can see is that it is
active, which is kind of what I wanted.

91
00:05:13.674 --> 00:05:15.601
I can see that I've had
some state changes,

92
00:05:15.601 --> 00:05:18.167
which just lets me know that
it's not completely stable.

93
00:05:18.167 --> 00:05:24.900
I've got a virtual IP of 192.168.12.1 and
since I'm active, I have that IP fired up.

94
00:05:24.900 --> 00:05:27.140
And then here's my virtual Mac address for
it.

95
00:05:27.140 --> 00:05:28.960
Ends in ac0c.

96
00:05:28.960 --> 00:05:35.100
Now, looking down here, I can see standby
router is unknown, active router is local.

97
00:05:35.100 --> 00:05:39.740
Now that standby router is unknown,
that's a red flag to me,

98
00:05:39.740 --> 00:05:44.860
because we have three routers involved
in this HSRP cluster, so I might not be

99
00:05:44.860 --> 00:05:48.950
able to see CORE1, but I should still be
able to see that other edge router, right?

100
00:05:48.950 --> 00:05:49.980
Well, not necessarily.

101
00:05:49.980 --> 00:05:54.490
If we go back to our diagram, NYCORE2,

102
00:05:54.490 --> 00:05:59.060
its paths to get to EDGE1
always pass through CORE1.

103
00:05:59.060 --> 00:06:03.050
So we're probably dealing with some kind
of connectivity issue right here where

104
00:06:03.050 --> 00:06:07.350
we're not able to make it to CORE1, which
means we can't make it to EDGE1 also.

105
00:06:07.350 --> 00:06:10.680
Cuz if CORE1 had dropped off the network,
EDGE1 should be my backup.

106
00:06:10.680 --> 00:06:13.740
That one should come up as a standby and
that's not what I'm seeing.

107
00:06:13.740 --> 00:06:17.180
So, so that's a red flag, the fact
that my standby router is unknown.

108
00:06:17.180 --> 00:06:20.040
I'm going to also note the priority here.

109
00:06:20.040 --> 00:06:24.950
Priority is 100 and preemption is enabled.

110
00:06:24.950 --> 00:06:28.750
So assuming this is all configured
correctly, what should happen here

111
00:06:28.750 --> 00:06:33.150
Is the other two routers should have
priorities lower than a hundred, and

112
00:06:33.150 --> 00:06:35.540
I'm set to preempt so
I should become active, right?

113
00:06:35.540 --> 00:06:38.100
So that's the supporting
information I need before I go and

114
00:06:38.100 --> 00:06:39.510
look at the other guys.

115
00:06:39.510 --> 00:06:42.530
I do want to get one more piece of
information since I think I'm dealing with

116
00:06:42.530 --> 00:06:48.099
a connectivity issue, I need to know
what IP address I have in vlan 12.

117
00:06:49.150 --> 00:06:51.470
And so this one is dot three, right.

118
00:06:51.470 --> 00:06:54.045
I'm just gonna test connectivity,
so I need to know my own IP.

119
00:06:54.045 --> 00:06:57.656
All right, so now that I've got that,
I'm gonna jump over to CORE1.

120
00:06:57.656 --> 00:07:00.522
And I'm gonna basically
check the same thing, right.

121
00:07:00.522 --> 00:07:03.730
So do the same checks that I
just did on the other switch,

122
00:07:03.730 --> 00:07:06.412
but doing it right here on CORE1,
all right.

123
00:07:06.412 --> 00:07:13.798
And on CORE1 if I do
a show standby vlan 12.

124
00:07:13.798 --> 00:07:17.600
I can see that it also is active.

125
00:07:17.600 --> 00:07:20.310
So the troubleshooting scenario
was telling the truth.

126
00:07:20.310 --> 00:07:22.490
I can see that it's got
that virtual IP address,

127
00:07:22.490 --> 00:07:25.090
it's got the same MAC address so it's up.

128
00:07:25.090 --> 00:07:26.750
It's only showing one state change, so

129
00:07:26.750 --> 00:07:29.260
it's a little more stable
than what the other one was.

130
00:07:29.260 --> 00:07:30.948
I can see that preemption is enabled.

131
00:07:30.948 --> 00:07:33.549
It does have a standby router.

132
00:07:33.549 --> 00:07:36.508
Its standby router is 192.168.12.4.

133
00:07:36.508 --> 00:07:40.656
That's not NYCore 2, it must be NYEDGE1.

134
00:07:40.656 --> 00:07:41.329
All right.

135
00:07:41.329 --> 00:07:46.420
So if NYEDGE1 is supposed to be the other
here, I can see I still see it.

136
00:07:46.420 --> 00:07:50.140
But it's not an other it's a standby
because I've become the active.

137
00:07:50.140 --> 00:07:55.560
All right, so this switch is active and
it looks like NYEDGE1 is the other.

138
00:07:55.560 --> 00:07:57.990
Now notice that my priority is a 90,
which is good.

139
00:07:57.990 --> 00:08:03.960
It's less than 100, so that should allow
the other switch to become the active.

140
00:08:03.960 --> 00:08:08.340
And then I can see EDGE1 here,
with a priority of 85, it's the lowest.

141
00:08:08.340 --> 00:08:10.910
So it looks like my priority
numbers are set correctly.

142
00:08:10.910 --> 00:08:15.280
Kind of recapping that NYCORE2
has a priority of 100,

143
00:08:15.280 --> 00:08:19.010
NYCORE1 has a priority of 90,
and NYEDGE1 has a priority of 85.

144
00:08:19.010 --> 00:08:21.600
So, we got our steps are setup right.

145
00:08:21.600 --> 00:08:23.340
NYCORE2 should be active.

146
00:08:23.340 --> 00:08:26.380
But again, I think we're just dealing
with connectivity at this point.

147
00:08:26.380 --> 00:08:29.820
So, what I'm gonna do next is I'm
gonna test that connectivity.

148
00:08:29.820 --> 00:08:34.536
On CORE1 we'll see what
IP address we have.

149
00:08:34.536 --> 00:08:40.469
So on vlan12 I'm 192.168.12.1,
well no sorry that's the stand by.

150
00:08:40.469 --> 00:08:41.293
That's our virtual IP.

151
00:08:41.293 --> 00:08:45.529
I'm actually 12.2 and
the other switch was .3 and so

152
00:08:45.529 --> 00:08:49.450
I'm gonna try and ping 192.168.12.3.

153
00:08:49.450 --> 00:08:51.740
Do I have basic connectivity?

154
00:08:51.740 --> 00:08:55.160
If I don't have basic connectivity,
HSRP is not gonna work either.

155
00:08:55.160 --> 00:08:56.860
And I see that I don't.

156
00:08:56.860 --> 00:08:58.560
Now my IP address is correct.

157
00:08:58.560 --> 00:09:00.090
My subnet mask is right.

158
00:09:00.090 --> 00:09:04.050
If I look at the other core router,
its IP address is right.

159
00:09:04.050 --> 00:09:05.820
Its subnet mask is right.

160
00:09:05.820 --> 00:09:07.590
So if things look good there,

161
00:09:07.590 --> 00:09:11.720
we must be dealing with something kind of
low-level like a layer two type problem.

162
00:09:11.720 --> 00:09:15.360
So let's target the links
between the switches.

163
00:09:15.360 --> 00:09:17.080
Looks like we've got two links here.

164
00:09:17.080 --> 00:09:19.530
One that's a layer three and
one that's a layer two.

165
00:09:19.530 --> 00:09:22.545
A layer three link I can rule that
out because HSRP doesn't pass through

166
00:09:22.545 --> 00:09:23.357
a router, right?

167
00:09:23.357 --> 00:09:24.390
It's not designed for that.

168
00:09:24.390 --> 00:09:28.059
So, port 24 here,
this is the trunk running between them and

169
00:09:28.059 --> 00:09:31.190
I should be able to see that
other switch on port 24.

170
00:09:31.190 --> 00:09:34.710
Let's take a look at its configuration and
see what's going on there.

171
00:09:34.710 --> 00:09:37.570
So here I am on CORE2 and

172
00:09:37.570 --> 00:09:42.486
I'm just gonna do a show run for
interface fa1/0/24.

173
00:09:42.486 --> 00:09:45.301
And [LAUGH] well,
our problem creeps up right here.

174
00:09:45.301 --> 00:09:51.082
I've got switchport trunk encapsulation
dot1q and I've got switchport trunk

175
00:09:51.082 --> 00:09:56.617
allowed vlan 10,11, 13 through 16,
it's skips right over 12.

176
00:09:56.617 --> 00:10:01.158
All right VLAN12 is not allowed to
pass over this link, and as a result,

177
00:10:01.158 --> 00:10:04.030
I'm not gonna be able to
get to the other side.

178
00:10:04.030 --> 00:10:07.742
Now, that's not the only path that I could
follow, this could be a trick, right?

179
00:10:07.742 --> 00:10:11.710
Because NYCORE2 might be able
to go across this other switch.

180
00:10:11.710 --> 00:10:14.380
I say the HSRP doesn't like to
have a router in between it but

181
00:10:14.380 --> 00:10:15.310
it doesn't care if there's a switch.

182
00:10:15.310 --> 00:10:17.310
There could be a switch in between,
it'd be fine.

183
00:10:17.310 --> 00:10:19.230
So I might be able to go this other route.

184
00:10:19.230 --> 00:10:20.580
But I don't know much
about this interface.

185
00:10:20.580 --> 00:10:24.000
So let's take a look at interface 22,
and see what it's set up for.

186
00:10:25.800 --> 00:10:30.040
So I'm gonna pull up it's running config,
and it looks like it's a trunk.

187
00:10:30.040 --> 00:10:31.030
Nothing too exciting there.

188
00:10:31.030 --> 00:10:36.025
And if I do a show interface trunk,
I can see that Port 22 is carrying,

189
00:10:36.025 --> 00:10:38.358
it's carrying all the VLANs, so

190
00:10:38.358 --> 00:10:43.188
in theory VLAN 12 should be passing
right here across this link, so

191
00:10:43.188 --> 00:10:48.886
I might be able to jump to the other side,
but if you did issue number one, right?

192
00:10:48.886 --> 00:10:52.659
The first troubleshooting issue for
set one, you'll remember,

193
00:10:52.659 --> 00:10:55.433
these links were configured just for
VLAN16.

194
00:10:55.433 --> 00:10:58.721
So it's actually on this end,
filtered down to VLAN16 and

195
00:10:58.721 --> 00:11:01.090
not carrying VLAN12, all right?

196
00:11:01.090 --> 00:11:03.880
So I now have to make a choice.

197
00:11:03.880 --> 00:11:08.920
I have to add VLAN12 either to
this link here, or this link here.

198
00:11:08.920 --> 00:11:11.940
And on the exam it's kind of up to
you how to figure out, how to fix or

199
00:11:11.940 --> 00:11:13.120
pick the solution.

200
00:11:13.120 --> 00:11:18.840
For us, we wanna pick the optimal solution
and one hop is better than two hops.

201
00:11:18.840 --> 00:11:21.010
And so we usually wanna enable it here.

202
00:11:21.010 --> 00:11:23.710
I know the VLAN is just
being filtered out here, so

203
00:11:23.710 --> 00:11:27.580
I'm just gonna add VLAN12 to that list and
that should solve our problem.

204
00:11:27.580 --> 00:11:30.000
So, on CORE2, and let's go do that.

205
00:11:30.000 --> 00:11:33.140
We're gonna make our change and
we'll verify that it actually works.

206
00:11:33.140 --> 00:11:38.510
So on CORE2 when I did a show run for
interface fa1/0/24 we saw how

207
00:11:38.510 --> 00:11:44.600
vlan 12 was left out of that list so
I'll get into fa1/0/24 and I'll just

208
00:11:45.860 --> 00:11:51.294
say switchport trunk allowed vlan

209
00:11:51.294 --> 00:11:56.160
add 12 so
I'm going to add the vlan 12 to that list.

210
00:11:57.170 --> 00:12:01.220
And now,
when I take a look at that configuration,

211
00:12:01.220 --> 00:12:05.380
I'll see that it's allowing 10-16 so
it's flowing through on this side.

212
00:12:05.380 --> 00:12:08.340
I need to check the other side too and
actually need to stall to give

213
00:12:08.340 --> 00:12:12.660
HSRP a minute to solve itself anyway so
let's verify the other side while we wait.

214
00:12:12.660 --> 00:12:17.380
I'll jump over to CORE1 and on CORE1 I'm
just gonna look at that same interface

215
00:12:20.080 --> 00:12:23.930
and it's already carrying VLAN 12 so
I should be okay.

216
00:12:23.930 --> 00:12:27.352
Should be fine, should and
are are two different things.

217
00:12:27.352 --> 00:12:29.860
Oh, I stalled long enough, there it is.

218
00:12:29.860 --> 00:12:32.293
Vlan12 Grp state changed.

219
00:12:32.293 --> 00:12:35.190
This guy just went from Active to Speak.

220
00:12:35.190 --> 00:12:37.330
What does that mean?

221
00:12:37.330 --> 00:12:40.220
That means it saw somebody else active on
the network, so it started speaking to

222
00:12:40.220 --> 00:12:43.370
find out who's gonna stay active,
who's gonna become standby.

223
00:12:43.370 --> 00:12:48.640
And then I just got another message
that said I moved from Speak to Standby.

224
00:12:48.640 --> 00:12:54.238
This guy just became the standby router
for VLAN12 and if I go look at CORE2,

225
00:12:54.238 --> 00:12:59.490
what I will hopefully see is if
I do a show standby vlan 12,

226
00:12:59.490 --> 00:13:03.860
I'm hoping to see this guy as
active which I saw before, right?

227
00:13:03.860 --> 00:13:07.380
That's no different but
what I'm hoping to see is, there we go.

228
00:13:07.380 --> 00:13:10.910
Standby router is 192.168.12.2.

229
00:13:10.910 --> 00:13:14.220
Now we know about a standby,
we know about the other core router.

230
00:13:14.220 --> 00:13:18.196
The only other person we need to
check is to jump over to NYEDGE1 and

231
00:13:18.196 --> 00:13:21.817
makes sure that it's an other,
and so when I come over to it,

232
00:13:21.817 --> 00:13:25.370
looks like we got some nice
interface failures on this guy.

233
00:13:25.370 --> 00:13:30.563
So on this guy, I'm just gonna come
over here and do a show standby vlan 12.

234
00:13:30.563 --> 00:13:32.340
Oh, I get an error.

235
00:13:32.340 --> 00:13:33.190
Shoot.

236
00:13:33.190 --> 00:13:34.090
This is a router.

237
00:13:34.090 --> 00:13:35.130
This isn't a switch.

238
00:13:35.130 --> 00:13:38.480
On the switches, we configure standby on
our vlan, our virtual interfaces, right?

239
00:13:38.480 --> 00:13:41.870
Your bridge or
SVI switch virtual interfaces.

240
00:13:41.870 --> 00:13:44.070
On a router we configure it
on the interface itself, and

241
00:13:44.070 --> 00:13:46.368
I have no idea what interface it's on,
so let's find out.

242
00:13:46.368 --> 00:13:53.550
It is GI0/0.12 is more than
likely gonna be our winner.

243
00:13:53.550 --> 00:13:56.570
So we'll check that one and
make sure that it has the stamp.

244
00:13:56.570 --> 00:13:57.440
I can see it does.

245
00:13:57.440 --> 00:13:57.979
So there it is.

246
00:13:57.979 --> 00:14:06.188
So if I do a show standby, it's not on
the VLAN interface, it's on gi0/0.12.

247
00:14:06.188 --> 00:14:10.460
And here I can see it's state is listen.

248
00:14:10.460 --> 00:14:11.640
It's not active.

249
00:14:11.640 --> 00:14:13.050
It's not standby.

250
00:14:13.050 --> 00:14:13.600
It's listen.

251
00:14:13.600 --> 00:14:14.500
It's in third place.

252
00:14:14.500 --> 00:14:15.570
It's an other.

253
00:14:15.570 --> 00:14:18.110
It's sitting there listening for
the chance to come active.

254
00:14:18.110 --> 00:14:22.340
And it knows who the active and
standby are, everything's good, right.

255
00:14:22.340 --> 00:14:27.053
Now, I haven't looked at the other vlans,
I didn't look at vlan 10, 11, 13,

256
00:14:27.053 --> 00:14:28.232
14, 15, 16.

257
00:14:28.232 --> 00:14:31.643
They told me about those other
vlans in the problem, but

258
00:14:31.643 --> 00:14:34.918
they were just telling me about them,
I don't care.

259
00:14:34.918 --> 00:14:38.083
The problem was that
HSRP Group 12 on NYCORE1 and

260
00:14:38.083 --> 00:14:40.154
2 are both reporting as active.

261
00:14:40.154 --> 00:14:43.680
That's no longer happening, I solved
the problem, the ticket's done and

262
00:14:43.680 --> 00:14:44.790
this one's resolved.

263
00:14:44.790 --> 00:14:50.141
All right so this was a great example
right here of what looked like a HSRP

264
00:14:50.141 --> 00:14:56.220
problem, ended up being a vlan filter on
an interface, right, not HSRP at all.

265
00:14:56.220 --> 00:14:59.454
So understand that high level
technologies are typically affected by

266
00:14:59.454 --> 00:15:02.918
low level technology, you got to look
at the lower level OSI model as well.

267
00:15:02.918 --> 00:15:06.523
And going trying to find that, this,
we have just to add a vlan to that trunk,

268
00:15:06.523 --> 00:15:07.364
problem solved.

269
00:15:07.364 --> 00:15:08.756
I hope you guys enjoined,

270
00:15:08.756 --> 00:15:12.251
stay tuned we've got more
troubleshooting episodes coming up.

271
00:15:12.251 --> 00:15:18.439
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #3` from set #1. The trouble ticket states that "PLABCSCO01 is unable to communicate to 192.168.16.2 which is a standby HSRP router address."
episodes.title: Set 1 Issue 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.144 --> 00:00:02.645
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.728 --> 00:00:08.547
In this video,

3
00:00:08.547 --> 00:00:12.530
we're gonna take a look at troubleshooting
set number 1 issue number 3.

4
00:00:12.530 --> 00:00:15.260
And once again, we've got another host
that's who's not communicating right on

5
00:00:15.260 --> 00:00:19.030
the network, and we've gotta troubleshoot
out, find out why, and get it fixed.

6
00:00:19.030 --> 00:00:20.980
Let's start by looking at our
troubleshooting ticket, and

7
00:00:20.980 --> 00:00:22.840
the ticket on this one's
pretty straightforward.

8
00:00:22.840 --> 00:00:25.220
Looks like our Cisco server
again has a problem.

9
00:00:25.220 --> 00:00:32.120
PLABCSCO01 is unable to
communicate with 192.168.16.2,

10
00:00:32.120 --> 00:00:35.460
which is a standby HSRP router address,
all right?

11
00:00:35.460 --> 00:00:38.430
Now, we've seen that HSRP address
before on another system,

12
00:00:38.430 --> 00:00:42.700
but let's go to our network map and get
an idea of where all this stuff falls in.

13
00:00:42.700 --> 00:00:47.690
So, if we take a look at our diagram, that
PLABCSCO, that's this guy way down here.

14
00:00:47.690 --> 00:00:53.450
And I can see his IP address
is 192.168.16.10, right?

15
00:00:53.450 --> 00:00:59.955
So, that's the person that's trying
to reach out to 192.168.16.2.

16
00:00:59.955 --> 00:01:05.404
Now, if we remember from our earlier
issues, we've got these two guys up here,

17
00:01:05.404 --> 00:01:10.640
core one and core two, and
these guys are running HSRP between them.

18
00:01:10.640 --> 00:01:14.877
This one on the left is 192.168.16.2,

19
00:01:14.877 --> 00:01:19.499
this one on the right is 192.168.16.3, and

20
00:01:19.499 --> 00:01:26.158
they're sharing 192.168.16.1
between them as an HSRP virtual IP.

21
00:01:26.158 --> 00:01:30.541
Now the interesting part about this
question is that it's telling me here

22
00:01:30.541 --> 00:01:36.210
PLABCSCO01, the server down here,
can't communicate with 192.168.16.2.

23
00:01:36.210 --> 00:01:40.208
That's the unique IP assignment to this
switch, and then it goes on to say,

24
00:01:40.208 --> 00:01:42.340
which is a standby HSRP router address.

25
00:01:42.340 --> 00:01:46.171
Now, it's funny they add that because
we don't really care, do we, right?

26
00:01:46.171 --> 00:01:49.870
The unique IP for a router is always
going to respond regardless of

27
00:01:49.870 --> 00:01:52.962
whether it's active, or
standby in an HSRP cluster,

28
00:01:52.962 --> 00:01:56.610
or whether it's running HSRP at all,
doesn't really matter.

29
00:01:56.610 --> 00:02:00.114
So they've given us a little more
information then we necessarily need,

30
00:02:00.114 --> 00:02:01.807
we can put that out of our minds, and

31
00:02:01.807 --> 00:02:04.660
really boil this down to just
a straight up layer two issue.

32
00:02:04.660 --> 00:02:11.480
This guy down here the server,
is 192.168.16.10 on a slash 24 network,

33
00:02:11.480 --> 00:02:15.489
this switch should be 192.168.16.2.

34
00:02:15.489 --> 00:02:17.377
It should also be on a /24.

35
00:02:17.377 --> 00:02:19.010
We'll double-check, but it should be.

36
00:02:19.010 --> 00:02:22.089
And that means these two
are on the same subnet.

37
00:02:22.089 --> 00:02:22.985
They should be able to
communicate right to each other.

38
00:02:22.985 --> 00:02:27.385
Now, I've got NYACCESS1 down here at
the bottom that I have to pass through on

39
00:02:27.385 --> 00:02:32.580
my way up to that switch, so I could have
a problem there stopping connectivity.

40
00:02:32.580 --> 00:02:36.990
And because we're running spanning tree,
and there is a three way connection

41
00:02:36.990 --> 00:02:40.490
right here, we could have
a loop that's being suppressed.

42
00:02:40.490 --> 00:02:45.710
And in theory, our server might have
to go ACCESS1 to CORE2 over to CORE1.

43
00:02:45.710 --> 00:02:48.240
We might have to jump through a few
different systems to actually get

44
00:02:48.240 --> 00:02:49.960
to where we need to be, all right?

45
00:02:49.960 --> 00:02:53.390
So we'll need to verify that path and find
out where our connectivity breaks down.

46
00:02:53.390 --> 00:02:57.050
But where I want to start is way
down here on PLABCSCO01, right?

47
00:02:57.050 --> 00:03:00.630
I'm going to start on that guy and
just see what it's experiencing.

48
00:03:00.630 --> 00:03:06.640
So if I jump over to that system,
I'm just gonna fire up a command prompt,

49
00:03:06.640 --> 00:03:08.570
and we'll see where it's getting to.

50
00:03:08.570 --> 00:03:15.820
So if I look at its IP Configuration,
I can see that it is 192.168.16.10.

51
00:03:15.820 --> 00:03:18.670
And it does have that 24 bit subnet mask,
so

52
00:03:18.670 --> 00:03:21.451
I know that's accurate here on the client.

53
00:03:21.451 --> 00:03:30.116
And if I try and ping to 1.82.168.16.2,
I don't get there.

54
00:03:30.116 --> 00:03:31.570
Right so the troubleshooting
ticket didn't lie to me.

55
00:03:31.570 --> 00:03:36.020
This server actually can't get there so
we'll need to find out why, right?

56
00:03:36.020 --> 00:03:39.080
Now if we start with our troubleshooting,
there's a few difference

57
00:03:39.080 --> 00:03:42.410
places we can go on this, but
I like to just think of the path and

58
00:03:42.410 --> 00:03:44.820
follow the path around, and
see where the problem is, right?

59
