00:03:44.820 --> 00:03:48.165
So looking at my path,
if I go back to my network diagram,

60
00:03:48.165 --> 00:03:51.512
the first step on my journey
is to jump over to ACCESS1 and

61
00:03:51.512 --> 00:03:56.252
I'm doing that on Port 1, so I'm gonna go
take a look at port 1 on NYACCESS1 and

62
00:03:56.252 --> 00:04:00.577
start there, and work my way through
the rest of this communication, and

63
00:04:00.577 --> 00:04:04.330
figure out where we're going to
get to the rest of the network.

64
00:04:04.330 --> 00:04:07.406
So, I'll jump over to NYACCESS1, and

65
00:04:07.406 --> 00:04:13.204
let's just get connected to this guy,
and see what we can find, all right?

66
00:04:13.204 --> 00:04:16.800
Now on NYACCESS1, I'm looking for
a few pieces of information on this guy.

67
00:04:16.800 --> 00:04:20.020
The first thing I want to do is I want to
look at the interface that the server is

68
00:04:20.020 --> 00:04:21.970
plugged in to,
I need to see how that's configured.

69
00:04:21.970 --> 00:04:26.220
So I'm just gonna do a show
running-config for interface fa0/1,

70
00:04:26.220 --> 00:04:28.720
that's the port that I'm plugged in.

71
00:04:28.720 --> 00:04:31.960
I can see it's set for
switchport access vlan 16 And

72
00:04:31.960 --> 00:04:33.160
it's got spanning-tree portfast.

73
00:04:33.160 --> 00:04:38.980
So we're on vlan 16,
the 192.168.16 network is on vlan 16.

74
00:04:38.980 --> 00:04:45.250
Great, and if I do a show vlan,
I can see who else is on vlan 16.

75
00:04:45.250 --> 00:04:49.030
And if I If I look here, VLAN 16,
I'm all by myself, Fa0/1.

76
00:04:49.030 --> 00:04:53.683
All right,
now that's not necessarily a bad thing.

77
00:04:53.683 --> 00:04:55.610
I know at our first view we're like,
ooh well, it's all by itself,

78
00:04:55.610 --> 00:04:57.040
of course you can't ping anybody.

79
00:04:57.040 --> 00:04:59.710
But remember that trunks
don't show up in here and so

80
00:04:59.710 --> 00:05:04.650
I'm gonna take a trunk off to another
switch to get the rest away on my journey.

81
00:05:04.650 --> 00:05:09.730
If I look back on my diagram, by the time
I get to NYACCESS1, I'm on VLAN 16.

82
00:05:09.730 --> 00:05:12.830
Now I need to jump up to
one of these switches,

83
00:05:12.830 --> 00:05:16.660
to ultimately end up on this switch, and

84
00:05:16.660 --> 00:05:21.620
it should have 192.168.16.2
assigned to it's VLAN 16 interface.

85
00:05:21.620 --> 00:05:23.870
In fact,
I could jump up to verify that real quick.

86
00:05:23.870 --> 00:05:29.020
Maybe this will turn out to be an easy
problem, and just be a bad IP address.

87
00:05:29.020 --> 00:05:32.400
Never underestimate easy problems,
they do pop up on the exam.

88
00:05:33.640 --> 00:05:40.820
So I'm gonna do a show running-config for
interface vlan16, all right?

89
00:05:43.930 --> 00:05:49.350
And when I look at it I can see
192.168.16.2 with a 24 bit subnet mask.

90
00:05:49.350 --> 00:05:51.530
So, it's not that simple, right?

91
00:05:51.530 --> 00:05:53.400
It's not just a bat, oh well shoot.

92
00:05:53.400 --> 00:05:55.220
It is gonna be that simple, isn't it?

93
00:05:55.220 --> 00:05:58.830
Looking at this one the problem
jumps out right at me here.

94
00:05:58.830 --> 00:06:03.530
I can see the IP address is 192.168.16.2
like it's supposed to be, the subnet mask

95
00:06:03.530 --> 00:06:07.980
is right, I can see that it's got HSRP
configured, but remember what I've said,

96
00:06:07.980 --> 00:06:12.220
that doesn't really matter on this problem
because the unique IP will always respond.

97
00:06:12.220 --> 00:06:16.530
But this next little command right here,
that's gonna be a bit of a problem.

98
00:06:16.530 --> 00:06:18.120
This interface is shut down.

99
00:06:18.120 --> 00:06:20.870
As long as the interface is shut down, I'm
not gonna be able to communicate with it.

100
00:06:20.870 --> 00:06:22.665
This IP will never respond.

101
00:06:22.665 --> 00:06:25.950
Now this might only be part of my problem.

102
00:06:25.950 --> 00:06:29.540
It might not be the whole problem, but
it's definitely part of the problem.

103
00:06:29.540 --> 00:06:31.420
So I'm gonna jump in and fix this part.

104
00:06:33.560 --> 00:06:37.720
And I'll just do a no shutdown
on that vlan16 interface.

105
00:06:37.720 --> 00:06:39.290
Now I know what you might be thinking.

106
00:06:39.290 --> 00:06:40.890
In real life land,
how is this going to happen?

107
00:06:40.890 --> 00:06:42.050
Who's going to shut it down?

108
00:06:42.050 --> 00:06:43.950
Well there are some Cisco switches,

109
00:06:43.950 --> 00:06:48.360
usually older ones, that will have their
VLAN interfaces shut down by default.

110
00:06:48.360 --> 00:06:52.400
So it could be that somebody
configured this and just never

111
00:06:52.400 --> 00:06:56.390
ran a no shutdown command on it, so it
could be a mistake you find up there, but

112
00:06:56.390 --> 00:06:58.240
it would usually be during
the deployment of a switch.

113
00:06:58.240 --> 00:07:00.910
This isn't something that
would randomly pop up.

114
00:07:00.910 --> 00:07:04.510
Now that that's done,
RIP should be active on that vlan.

115
00:07:04.510 --> 00:07:06.530
Let's go see if we can ping it now, and

116
00:07:06.530 --> 00:07:11.230
then if that was our whole
problem all in one fell swoop.

117
00:07:11.230 --> 00:07:15.150
So, I'm just gonna connect right back
here and try and redo that ping, and

118
00:07:15.150 --> 00:07:16.560
sure enough that was it.

119
00:07:16.560 --> 00:07:18.320
This turned out to be
a pretty easy problem.

120
00:07:18.320 --> 00:07:20.070
Just a shut down interface.

121
00:07:20.070 --> 00:07:24.110
Now, the key takeaway for this is not
necessarily that it was an easy problem,

122
00:07:24.110 --> 00:07:27.490
but the way that we
found that easy problem.

123
00:07:27.490 --> 00:07:29.250
Remember that when you
start to troubleshoot this,

124
00:07:29.250 --> 00:07:33.210
you've gotta think about the path across
your network that your journey is taking.

125
00:07:33.210 --> 00:07:38.280
I knew that I could have problems
in any of these three switches, but

126
00:07:38.280 --> 00:07:40.330
I used the ones that I
thought were in line, so

127
00:07:40.330 --> 00:07:42.800
I didn't waste time over here
in CORE2 if I didn't need to,

128
00:07:42.800 --> 00:07:47.630
and that helped us to dial in, find the
solution, and get it resolved, all right?

129
00:07:47.630 --> 00:07:49.860
Well that's about it for Set 1, Issue 3.

130
00:07:49.860 --> 00:07:53.190
So we got a chance to see that a shutdown
interface doesn't respond to pings.

131
00:07:53.190 --> 00:07:54.340
Big surprise there.

132
00:07:54.340 --> 00:07:57.060
We found it, we fixed it,
trouble ticket resolved.

133
00:07:57.060 --> 00:07:58.450
So hope you guys enjoyed that one.

134
00:07:58.450 --> 00:07:59.170
Stay tuned.

135
00:07:59.170 --> 00:08:01.232
We've got more troubleshooting
tickets coming up.

136
00:08:01.232 --> 00:08:03.300
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #4` from set #1. The trouble ticket states that "PLABCSCO01 is unable to communicate to 192.168.11.4 which is located on NYEDGE1."
episodes.title: Set 1 Issue 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.507
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.507 --> 00:00:10.431
All right its time for
set one, issue four.

3
00:00:10.431 --> 00:00:13.220
And in this one we've got another
host with some connectivity issues.

4
00:00:13.220 --> 00:00:16.030
Were gonna jump in, try and
find the problem and get it resolved.

5
00:00:16.030 --> 00:00:19.890
I look at my troubleshooting ticket,
it tells me here that PLABCISCO, that same

6
00:00:19.890 --> 00:00:26.030
server, is unable to communicate with
192.168.11.4, which is located on NYEDGE1.

7
00:00:26.030 --> 00:00:31.210
That's convenient that they tell us that,
cuz that's an IP we haven't seen yet,

8
00:00:31.210 --> 00:00:34.010
and I didn't know where it resided,
fortunately, they let us know.

9
00:00:34.010 --> 00:00:36.670
So, let's take a look at
our topology map here, and

10
00:00:36.670 --> 00:00:39.920
get an idea of where this
problem actually exists.

11
00:00:39.920 --> 00:00:42.330
Now, PLABCISCO01,
we're kind of familiar with that guy,

12
00:00:42.330 --> 00:00:44.270
that server's been our
problem child all along.

13
00:00:44.270 --> 00:00:48.668
So, we've got this server way down
here at the bottom of our network,

14
00:00:48.668 --> 00:00:50.130
and it's 192.168.16.10.

15
00:00:50.130 --> 00:00:53.270
We've seen previously that
it's on Velan 16, but

16
00:00:53.270 --> 00:00:56.130
here we're having a problem
communicating with 192.168.11.4.

17
00:00:56.130 --> 00:01:01.790
That's going to be on a different velan,
a different subnet somewhere.

18
00:01:01.790 --> 00:01:05.090
So, I'm no longer just
facing layer two issues now.

19
00:01:05.090 --> 00:01:07.810
I've got layer three in the mix also.

20
00:01:07.810 --> 00:01:14.720
And when I communicate that IP resides on
NYEDGE1, which if I look, is way up here.

21
00:01:14.720 --> 00:01:17.010
So now I've got more devices in the mix,

22
00:01:17.010 --> 00:01:20.170
if I kinda take a look at
the big picture view here.

23
00:01:20.170 --> 00:01:21.960
Devices that could be a problem?

24
00:01:21.960 --> 00:01:26.190
Well, I'm coming from my server,
I'm going to NY access one.

25
00:01:26.190 --> 00:01:28.140
Then I'm going to one
of these two switches.

26
00:01:28.140 --> 00:01:29.670
Core one or core two.

27
00:01:29.670 --> 00:01:32.420
And from there I should be
jumping up to edge one.

28
00:01:32.420 --> 00:01:36.080
So I've actually got four different
hardware devices in between my server and

29
00:01:36.080 --> 00:01:37.060
the destination.

30
00:01:37.060 --> 00:01:39.570
Well I guess we really only have three
in between, but four different Cisco

31
00:01:39.570 --> 00:01:42.510
devices where the problem could exist,
and I'll have to troubleshoot.

32
00:01:42.510 --> 00:01:45.930
And just like before,
I wanna think about that path and

33
00:01:45.930 --> 00:01:49.310
see how we're gonna float
to get to that destination.

34
00:01:49.310 --> 00:01:52.410
All right, now troubleshooting a problem
like this is all about doing things

35
00:01:52.410 --> 00:01:53.670
quickly and efficiently.

36
00:01:53.670 --> 00:01:57.100
And you'll remember the last one
turned out to be a pretty simple one,

37
00:01:57.100 --> 00:01:58.650
in that we had an interface
that was shut down.

38
00:01:58.650 --> 00:02:00.520
It could be as simple as that.

39
00:02:00.520 --> 00:02:03.500
Or it could be VLAN assignments,
could be all sorts of problems, right.

40
00:02:03.500 --> 00:02:07.970
So let's jump in here and take a look,
and see where our problem is going from.

41
00:02:07.970 --> 00:02:12.330
So I want to start on PLABCSCO01, and just
test out the troubleshooting ticket and

42
00:02:12.330 --> 00:02:13.780
make sure they're not lying to me.

43
00:02:13.780 --> 00:02:18.670
So here I am on that server, and I'm gonna
fire up in my command prompt here, and

44
00:02:18.670 --> 00:02:22.690
I'm just gonna do a quick ipconfig
to verify my configuration.

45
00:02:22.690 --> 00:02:26.780
And I see I'm 192.160.16.10 on
that 24 bit subnet mask, so

46
00:02:26.780 --> 00:02:29.070
all that is all I expect it to be.

47
00:02:29.070 --> 00:02:36.165
And then I'm just gonna run a quick
ping to the ip address in question.

48
00:02:36.165 --> 00:02:39.920
192.168.11.4. All right.
Now I'm doing the ping for two reasons.

49
00:02:39.920 --> 00:02:42.340
One I wanna make sure
the problem actually exists.

50
00:02:42.340 --> 00:02:43.880
Right?
That's one reason.

51
00:02:43.880 --> 00:02:48.400
The other reason I'm doing it,
is because I've got a default gateway set.

52
00:02:48.400 --> 00:02:52.550
And if my default gateway doesn't have
a route to get to the destination,

53
00:02:52.550 --> 00:02:54.420
I'll get a message here saying
destination unreachable.

54
00:02:54.420 --> 00:02:56.080
And that's not what I'm getting.

55
00:02:56.080 --> 00:02:57.790
I'm getting request timed out.

56
00:02:57.790 --> 00:02:59.610
And so
that actually helps me a little bit.

57
00:02:59.610 --> 00:03:04.430
It lets me know that I got tot he gateway,
the gateway had a route, and

58
00:03:04.430 --> 00:03:07.730
sent me along, and
I just didn't get to wherever I was going.

59
00:03:07.730 --> 00:03:10.690
If I get destination unreachable,
that would tell me the gateway didn't

60
00:03:10.690 --> 00:03:13.150
have a route, and now I know I'm
dealing with a routing issue.

61
00:03:13.150 --> 00:03:15.150
So I might not be dealing
with routing at all.

62
00:03:15.150 --> 00:03:16.890
I might be dealing with
Access Control List.

63
00:03:16.890 --> 00:03:18.960
I might be dealing with Layer two issues.

64
00:03:18.960 --> 00:03:22.120
But routing is more than likely
fine in this scenario, all right?

65
00:03:22.120 --> 00:03:24.580
This is a really small network, so
it probably won't work here, but

66
00:03:24.580 --> 00:03:29.330
on a large network you can use tracert
to kind of solve that same issue.

67
00:03:29.330 --> 00:03:32.490
And so if I were to do a trace route and
send that along,

68
00:03:32.490 --> 00:03:33.600
it'll kind of show me
where the problem is.

69
00:03:33.600 --> 00:03:37.400
And if I had multiple routers in the mix,
I would see which router this died on,

70
00:03:37.400 --> 00:03:39.660
and then again that help
me narrow down the problem.

71
00:03:39.660 --> 00:03:42.800
In my scenario, I'm more than
likely only to have one router.

72
00:03:42.800 --> 00:03:45.410
If we take a look at our
diagram while that's running.

73
00:03:47.490 --> 00:03:51.495
Remember from the earlier sets or
the earlier issues, that NYCORE1 and

74
00:03:51.495 --> 00:03:54.370
CORE2 are running HSRP, and
they have a virtual IP, 192.168.16.1, and

75
00:03:54.370 --> 00:03:58.480
that's what I'm using
as my default gateway.

76
00:03:58.480 --> 00:04:01.460
Well, those switches have
interfaces on each of the VLANs.

77
00:04:01.460 --> 00:04:04.870
So they're routing me
from VLAN16 to VLAN11,

78
00:04:04.870 --> 00:04:08.470
and then that should allow
me to get over to NYEDGE1.

79
00:04:08.470 --> 00:04:09.790
That's not working.

80
00:04:09.790 --> 00:04:12.010
But the problem is most likely
not here on these guys.

81
00:04:12.010 --> 00:04:15.570
We can double check to be sure,
but it's most likely not there.

82
00:04:15.570 --> 00:04:18.990
All right, looking back on my server,
I can see where I got to 192.168.16.3,

83
00:04:18.990 --> 00:04:25.040
which is the core two switch, right,
that's the one that's active right now.

84
00:04:25.040 --> 00:04:26.600
And then we died out right there.

85
00:04:26.600 --> 00:04:30.540
All right, so if I wanna jump over to core
three I can start troubleshooting there.

86
00:04:30.540 --> 00:04:33.240
I can skip NYACCESS1.

87
00:04:33.240 --> 00:04:37.530
All right I can skip NYACCESS1 because
I'm able to reach my default gateway, so

88
00:04:37.530 --> 00:04:38.960
I know the problem is not on that switch.

89
00:04:38.960 --> 00:04:40.780
And that's really important on the exam,

90
00:04:40.780 --> 00:04:44.500
you've got to be able to eliminate
devices so you don't waste time on them.

91
00:04:44.500 --> 00:04:48.260
And I can jump up to CORE2 and
take a look at its configuration, and

92
00:04:48.260 --> 00:04:50.550
see where we go from there, all right.

93
00:04:50.550 --> 00:04:54.040
So let me just jump over to CORE2, and

94
00:04:54.040 --> 00:04:56.680
we'll start doing some
information gathering here.

95
00:04:56.680 --> 00:05:01.730
Now, CORE2 is part of an HSRP cluster,
and so if I do a show standby for

96
00:05:01.730 --> 00:05:06.050
vlan 16, that's the vlan
that our Cisco server is on.

97
00:05:06.050 --> 00:05:09.790
And we can see that this guy is active for
192.168.16.1.

98
00:05:09.790 --> 00:05:12.700
So it is what I'm using
as the default gateway.

99
00:05:12.700 --> 00:05:14.950
When that server goes out,
this is where it ends up.

100
00:05:16.070 --> 00:05:18.540
And once it gets here
we're telling that router,

101
00:05:18.540 --> 00:05:23.750
hey we need to get to 193.168.11.4, so
it's doing a routing table look up.

102
00:05:23.750 --> 00:05:25.149
And you can do a show ip route.

103
00:05:26.390 --> 00:05:27.750
And filter down from 192.168.11.whatever.

104
00:05:27.750 --> 00:05:31.000
i'll just leave it off.

105
00:05:31.000 --> 00:05:33.480
And you can see the route there, or

106
00:05:33.480 --> 00:05:36.380
I could have actually just done
a show ip route and punch in the IP.

107
00:05:36.380 --> 00:05:39.750
That gives you a little bit
more detailed information.

108
00:05:39.750 --> 00:05:41.300
And we can see that we do have a route.

109
00:05:41.300 --> 00:05:44.680
In fact, it's not even a learn route,
it's directly connected.

110
00:05:44.680 --> 00:05:50.360
This switch has an interface, which is
the VLAN11 interface right on that subnet.

111
00:05:50.360 --> 00:05:53.980
And so that's why I'm able to get
routed from VLAN16 to VLAN11.

112
00:05:53.980 --> 00:05:56.320
This guy has an interface
right on that network.

113
00:05:56.320 --> 00:06:01.470
And if I do a show run for
interface VLAN11,

114
00:06:01.470 --> 00:06:04.830
I can see the switch is
192.168.11.3 on that network.

115
00:06:07.040 --> 00:06:10.910
Now if I'm not positive
the routing is working fine,

116
00:06:10.910 --> 00:06:13.520
I can always ping this IP and
that'll verify it right.

117
00:06:13.520 --> 00:06:19.730
So if I jump back to the server,
and I know I can't ping.

118
00:06:20.870 --> 00:06:22.810
Oops, we'll just break out of that,
there we go.

119
00:06:22.810 --> 00:06:26.835
I know I can't ping 192.168.11.4, cuz
that's what the troubleshooting ticket is,

120
00:06:26.835 --> 00:06:28.040
right?

121
00:06:28.040 --> 00:06:29.680
We can't get to that.

122
00:06:29.680 --> 00:06:35.930
But if I try and ping .3, well that's
the other interface of the switch.

123
00:06:35.930 --> 00:06:42.810
So right there, what that tells me
is that I can get to that VLAN.

124
00:06:42.810 --> 00:06:44.200
I can get to 192.168.11.

125
00:06:44.200 --> 00:06:45.110
Whatever.

126
00:06:45.110 --> 00:06:47.020
But for some reason, I can't get to .3.

127
00:06:47.020 --> 00:06:51.800
So, again, trying to eliminate devices,
if I'm properly being routed, and

128
00:06:51.800 --> 00:06:57.520
being deposited on VLAN 11,
then I should be able to get to NYEDGE1.

129
00:06:57.520 --> 00:07:01.680
At this point, I think we're either
dealing with a problem on NYEDGE1,

130
00:07:01.680 --> 00:07:04.335
or possibly this interface, right here.

131
00:07:04.335 --> 00:07:08.980
Fa1/0/1, that's where that NY Edge
is plugged in to this switch.

132
00:07:08.980 --> 00:07:11.690
What if it's not assigned to VLAN 11?

133
00:07:11.690 --> 00:07:15.090
If it's not on VLAN 11,
then I'm misnumbered and

134
00:07:15.090 --> 00:07:17.340
I won't be able to get there,
so that can be my problem.

135
00:07:17.340 --> 00:07:20.920
Well, that's over on Core one, so I'm just
gonna go doublecheck that interface real

136
00:07:20.920 --> 00:07:24.110
quick before moving on to Edge 1 itself,
all right?

137
00:07:24.110 --> 00:07:27.400
So let me jump over to Core one and
we'll do a little verification.

138
00:07:29.200 --> 00:07:35.040
So, I'm just going to jump in here, and
I'll do a show run for interface fa1/0/1.

139
00:07:35.040 --> 00:07:40.780
Oh, well this will be a little
bit trickier than I wanted.

140
00:07:40.780 --> 00:07:45.280
So, what I was expecting was to see
the interface be an access port and

141
00:07:45.280 --> 00:07:47.330
be assigned the VLAN 11..

142
00:07:47.330 --> 00:07:49.932
Instead, I can see that it's a trunk port.

143
00:07:49.932 --> 00:07:53.040
All right, so
switchport trunk encapsulation dot1q, or

144
00:07:53.040 --> 00:07:55.460
set up as an dot1q trunk.

145
00:07:55.460 --> 00:07:58.130
And I've got VLAN's being
allowed ten through 16.

146
00:07:58.130 --> 00:08:02.100
Now that includes VLAN 11 and
that's the one I'm worried about, right.

147
00:08:02.100 --> 00:08:03.740
So at least there's that.

148
00:08:03.740 --> 00:08:08.050
But it is such a trunk, and
what that means is that the router,

149
00:08:08.050 --> 00:08:12.640
this NYEDGE1 Is configured for
router on a stick.

150
00:08:12.640 --> 00:08:15.840
With router on a stick, we take
a physical interface like GI0/0, and

151
00:08:15.840 --> 00:08:21.150
we divide it into virtual sub-interfaces,
and assign each sub-interface to a VLAN.

152
00:08:21.150 --> 00:08:25.380
So we've got VLANs ten through
16 crossing this line.

153
00:08:25.380 --> 00:08:30.150
On this end, I should expect to see
sub-interfaces handling those seven VLANs.

154
00:08:30.150 --> 00:08:32.236
Well, let's go take a look at that.

155
00:08:32.236 --> 00:08:34.140
Router on a stick is not
that hard to configure, but

156
00:08:34.140 --> 00:08:36.130
it's not something people work with a lot.

157
00:08:36.130 --> 00:08:38.150
And so if you don't work with it a lot,

158
00:08:38.150 --> 00:08:40.260
it's easy to kind of
forget the configuration.

159
00:08:40.260 --> 00:08:44.290
And boy, we've got some nice
little messages popping up here.

160
00:08:44.290 --> 00:08:47.220
It looks like we've got a serial
interface that is flapping.

161
00:08:47.220 --> 00:08:50.920
Well our troubleshooting ticket is not
built on that serial interface, or

162
00:08:50.920 --> 00:08:52.280
at least as far as I know.

163
00:08:52.280 --> 00:08:56.350
Looks like that's just
gonna keep flapping for us.

164
00:08:56.350 --> 00:09:00.250
If you ever bump into this in
real life for example, and

165
00:09:00.250 --> 00:09:03.700
you start getting really annoyed with
messages that are constantly popping up

166
00:09:03.700 --> 00:09:07.760
like this, there's a few things you can do
to make life a little bit easier on you.

167
00:09:07.760 --> 00:09:10.780
The real problem with messages popping
up like this is they interrupt while we

168
00:09:10.780 --> 00:09:11.510
type a command.

169
00:09:11.510 --> 00:09:14.010
So you might be typing, show version, and

170
00:09:14.010 --> 00:09:17.270
as you start typing your command
the message pops up and interrupts you.

171
00:09:17.270 --> 00:09:20.260
So you can turn on synchronous logging,
and that will make it basically

172
00:09:20.260 --> 00:09:24.450
redraw your line every time you go to
type, and that can help out a little bit.

173
00:09:24.450 --> 00:09:29.730
To turn that on you just
get into line con 0.

174
00:09:29.730 --> 00:09:30.900
Oops.

175
00:09:30.900 --> 00:09:32.680
And yeah, see how it's like
interrupting me right here and

176
00:09:32.680 --> 00:09:37.550
I can hit control R to redraw my line,
or I can turn on synchronous logging.

177
00:09:37.550 --> 00:09:39.710
And that'll happen automatically,
so I'm just gonna come in here and

178
00:09:39.710 --> 00:09:42.390
say logging synchronous.

179
00:09:42.390 --> 00:09:45.430
And now it will redraw my line
every time a message comes up.

180
00:09:45.430 --> 00:09:46.780
I can also turn the messages off.

181
00:09:46.780 --> 00:09:49.860
Like that serial interface, if I don't
need it I can just go and shut it down.

182
00:09:49.860 --> 00:09:55.050
Or here in config,
I could say no logging console, and that

183
00:09:55.050 --> 00:09:57.930
would stop it from logging to the console,
and I wouldn't get the pop-up messages.

184
00:09:57.930 --> 00:10:00.960
I'd just need to remember to turn
that back on before I was done.

185
00:10:00.960 --> 00:10:04.710
But for right now I'm just gonna leave
it be, and kind of ignore the messages.

186
00:10:04.710 --> 00:10:07.300
Now that I've got synchronous logging on,
it'll redraw my lines for

187
00:10:07.300 --> 00:10:08.360
me so I should be good.

188
00:10:09.382 --> 00:10:12.520
All right so, I was saying that I
expect to see some sub interfaces here.

189
00:10:12.520 --> 00:10:15.930
I expect to see these setup for
each of the different VLAN's, so

190
00:10:15.930 --> 00:10:18.360
I'm just gonna do a show
IP interface brief.

191
00:10:18.360 --> 00:10:22.051
So I can get an idea of
what interfaces there are,

192
00:10:22.051 --> 00:10:25.780
and sure enough GI 0
slash 0 is divided up.

193
00:10:25.780 --> 00:10:26.560
Okay.

194
00:10:26.560 --> 00:10:29.410
I can see we've got 0.10, 0.11,
0.12, all the way through 0.16.

195
00:10:29.410 --> 00:10:35.390
It looks like they've taken each VLAN and
given it it's own sub interface.

196
00:10:35.390 --> 00:10:39.500
Now remember, the sub interface
number really doesn't matter.

197
00:10:39.500 --> 00:10:41.300
You can number it whatever you want.

198
00:10:41.300 --> 00:10:46.318
This could say gi0/0.16, but
it could be the interface for VLAN 11.

199
00:10:46.318 --> 00:10:49.550
Right?
The sub-interface number you make up

200
00:10:49.550 --> 00:10:53.550
Inside of each sub-interface, we have
to tell it what VLAN it's attached to.

201
00:10:53.550 --> 00:10:56.520
And, that's what really matters,
all right?

202
00:10:56.520 --> 00:10:59.040
So, I could assume that .11 is for
VLAN 11.

203
00:10:59.040 --> 00:11:01.160
That's what a normal
network admin would do.

204
00:11:01.160 --> 00:11:03.170
On the exam, don't assume anything.

205
00:11:03.170 --> 00:11:05.200
We need to verify the configuration.

206
00:11:05.200 --> 00:11:07.990
So, I'm gonna do a show running-config.

207
00:11:07.990 --> 00:11:10.230
And, I'm just gonna pull up
A full configuration on this one.

208
00:11:11.380 --> 00:11:13.800
And as we start to look
at that configuration,

209
00:11:13.800 --> 00:11:16.540
we'll get down to the interfaces
eventually, here we go.

210
00:11:16.540 --> 00:11:21.610
And here is Gi/0/0.10 and see how it's
got this line, encapsulation dot1Q 10.

211
00:11:21.610 --> 00:11:23.730
That's the important line.

212
00:11:23.730 --> 00:11:27.390
That's what's telling us
to do 80Q.1 trunking, and

213
00:11:27.390 --> 00:11:32.280
this interface is going to be responsible
for anything tagged for VLAN 10.

214
00:11:32.280 --> 00:11:34.630
Well, I hope to see that for 11.

215
00:11:34.630 --> 00:11:35.590
There we go.

216
00:11:36.620 --> 00:11:40.530
And, well, here's something kinda
sticking out at us, isn't it?

217
00:11:40.530 --> 00:11:42.230
encapsulation dot1Q 111.

218
00:11:42.230 --> 00:11:42.730
Right?

219
00:11:44.160 --> 00:11:49.370
The sub interface is .11, but
the encapsulation is set to 111.

220
00:11:49.370 --> 00:11:54.140
This is set to handle traffic for
VLAN 111, not VLAN 11.

221
00:11:54.140 --> 00:11:58.240
And this is the IP that I'm trying to
ping, since it's on the wrong subnet,

222
00:11:58.240 --> 00:12:00.740
I'm not gonna be able to
communicate to it, right?

223
00:12:00.740 --> 00:12:02.560
And it's not that
the subnet mask is wrong,

224
00:12:02.560 --> 00:12:05.980
it's VLANed into the wrong subnet, right?

225
00:12:05.980 --> 00:12:09.770
So Although this looked like
a routing issue at first,

226
00:12:09.770 --> 00:12:11.420
it actually turned out to be layer two,
right.

227
00:12:11.420 --> 00:12:12.670
We're just on the wrong vlan,

228
00:12:12.670 --> 00:12:16.280
and we need to fix it right here so
that's what we'll do.

229
00:12:16.280 --> 00:12:22.744
I'm gonna go ahead and get into my
config and get into interface gi0/0.11.

230
00:12:22.744 --> 00:12:26.860
And I'll just tell it
encapsulation dot1Q 11.

231
00:12:26.860 --> 00:12:30.400
And that's gonna shift it from
vlan 111 over to vlan 11.

232
00:12:30.400 --> 00:12:31.020
There we go.

233
00:12:31.020 --> 00:12:36.130
And actually it looks like
HSRP is kicking up on that.

234
00:12:36.130 --> 00:12:38.530
I wasn't paying attention earlier, but

235
00:12:38.530 --> 00:12:41.650
I gues HSRP,
yep it is configured on these guys.

236
00:12:41.650 --> 00:12:44.990
So we should be good there.

237
00:12:44.990 --> 00:12:46.430
And I'm going to give it just a second,

238
00:12:46.430 --> 00:12:48.970
because you know how spanning tree
can be on some of these things.

239
00:12:48.970 --> 00:12:53.010
That it can take a moment for
an interface to come all the way up.

240
00:12:53.010 --> 00:12:57.840
And we'll just make sure that
that interface does actually

241
00:12:57.840 --> 00:13:02.690
change to be up, which it is, and
let's go see if that fixed our problem.

242
00:13:02.690 --> 00:13:08.430
So I'll jump back over to our server,
and I was unable to ping .4 earlier,

243
00:13:08.430 --> 00:13:12.820
and if I try now, now we're in business.

244
00:13:12.820 --> 00:13:15.950
So this one turned out
to be router on a stick,

245
00:13:15.950 --> 00:13:18.550
in this case it really wasn't
that bad of a problem, right?

246
00:13:18.550 --> 00:13:20.990
We had to track down the possible causes,
and

247
00:13:20.990 --> 00:13:23.490
I kinda stepped through each of the switch
until I got to the destination.

248
00:13:23.490 --> 00:13:25.720
We could've done it in reverse,
I could've started at the destination and

249
00:13:25.720 --> 00:13:27.740
we would've found this problem right off,
right?

250
00:13:27.740 --> 00:13:31.790
But you never know where the problem is
gonna be, so really there's no difference.

251
00:13:31.790 --> 00:13:34.310
Whether you start at the beginning or
the end of the communication, one way or

252
00:13:34.310 --> 00:13:35.970
another you'll find it.

253
00:13:35.970 --> 00:13:38.070
Here, once we made it to NYEDGE1,

254
00:13:38.070 --> 00:13:40.810
we were able to recognize that
interface was configured wrong.

255
00:13:40.810 --> 00:13:42.960
We fixed the router on
a stick configuration.

256
00:13:42.960 --> 00:13:45.850
And we were in business, so
not that bad on this one.

257
00:13:45.850 --> 00:13:48.400
All right, well that's about it for
issue number four.

258
00:13:48.400 --> 00:13:50.700
Stay tuned, got more issues coming up.

259
00:13:50.700 --> 00:13:53.340
Some of them easy, some of them hard,
definitely all entertaining.

260
00:13:53.340 --> 00:13:55.927
So stay tuned, I'll see you there.

261
00:13:55.927 --> 00:14:01.489
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #5` from set #1. The trouble ticket states that "The route to network 10.6.1.1 is not in the routing table of any device. This route should originate from OSPF Area 61 which is connected to NYEDGE2."
episodes.title: Set 1 Issue 5
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.499
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.499 --> 00:00:10.684
All right it is time for Set 1 Issue 5.

3
00:00:10.684 --> 00:00:12.422
We're gonna jump right
back into troubleshooting.

4
00:00:12.422 --> 00:00:15.030
This one's going to be a lot of
fun because this one is definitely

5
00:00:15.030 --> 00:00:15.955
a routing issue,

6
00:00:15.955 --> 00:00:18.800
it's right there in the troubleshooting
ticketfor us, let's read it.

7
00:00:18.800 --> 00:00:23.705
The troubleshooting ticket
basically says the route to network

8
00:00:23.705 --> 00:00:27.420
10.61.1.1 is not in the routing
table of any devices.

9
00:00:27.420 --> 00:00:32.800
This route should originate from OSPF Area
61, which is connected to NYEDGE2.

10
00:00:32.800 --> 00:00:37.240
So up until now, everything that we've had
has really turned out to be a layer 1 or

11
00:00:37.240 --> 00:00:38.750
layer 2 issue.

12
00:00:38.750 --> 00:00:41.200
This is gonna be a good one
because it's going to be routing.

13
00:00:41.200 --> 00:00:44.050
Now unfortunately because it is routing,
it's a lot of stuff we haven't seen yet.

14
00:00:44.050 --> 00:00:49.110
So let's jump over to our diagram and
kinda get a handle on what is what.

15
00:00:49.110 --> 00:00:52.890
First off it's telling us that this route
is not showing up in the routing table of

16
00:00:52.890 --> 00:00:53.750
any of our devices.

17
00:00:53.750 --> 00:00:55.690
Now, what are our devices?

18
00:00:55.690 --> 00:01:00.980
Well, in this network,
our devices are NYWAN1, NYEDGE1,

19
00:01:00.980 --> 00:01:03.890
NYCORE1, NYCORE2, and NYEDGE2.

20
00:01:03.890 --> 00:01:05.970
These five devices right here.

21
00:01:05.970 --> 00:01:09.049
And we've got a problem with the routing
table not containing this one

22
00:01:09.049 --> 00:01:09.945
particular route.

23
00:01:09.945 --> 00:01:14.471
Now, the route in question,
10.61.1.1, everything we've seen so

24
00:01:14.471 --> 00:01:19.540
far has been 192.168.something,
right, those are our local networks.

25
00:01:19.540 --> 00:01:20.960
This one's outside of the network.

26
00:01:20.960 --> 00:01:22.940
And so we need to figure out where
it's supposed to be coming from, and

27
00:01:22.940 --> 00:01:30.230
it says here this route should originate
from OSPF Area 61, which is right up here.

28
00:01:30.230 --> 00:01:35.430
I can see I've got ISP1 and
ISP2 that are both connected to NYEDGE2,

29
00:01:35.430 --> 00:01:38.410
and that's where this route
is supposed to originate.

30
00:01:38.410 --> 00:01:42.328
And in fact if I look at my diagram here,
right there is

31
00:01:42.328 --> 00:01:47.500
10.61.1.1 coming from OSPF Area 61,
that's that network right there.

32
00:01:47.500 --> 00:01:50.050
So, it's supposed to be coming
from one of these two guys.

33
00:01:50.050 --> 00:01:52.640
Now, do I care which one it comes from?

34
00:01:52.640 --> 00:01:55.440
Not really, it could come from
either one of these, that's fine.

35
00:01:55.440 --> 00:01:58.960
But the point is that
it's coming in NYEDGE2.

36
00:01:58.960 --> 00:02:03.890
That means that NYEDGE2 is
supposed to be allowing routes

37
00:02:03.890 --> 00:02:07.280
to pass from Area 61 into Area 0.

38
00:02:07.280 --> 00:02:10.950
We've got OSPF in multiple areas, right?

39
00:02:10.950 --> 00:02:14.150
Now in my mind I start trying to
think of what could cause this route

40
00:02:14.150 --> 00:02:15.850
not to come over, right?

41
00:02:15.850 --> 00:02:18.647
There's easy things,
the network could be down, right?

42
00:02:18.647 --> 00:02:20.943
Whatever router's connected to
that network could be offline and

43
00:02:20.943 --> 00:02:22.090
that's that, right?

44
00:02:22.090 --> 00:02:24.770
I don't think that's going
to be the case here because

45
00:02:24.770 --> 00:02:27.260
we can't control the ISP routers and

46
00:02:27.260 --> 00:02:30.490
so if that was the case we wouldn't
be able to fix the problem, right?

47
00:02:30.490 --> 00:02:32.810
And they expect you to fix
the problem on the exam.

48
00:02:32.810 --> 00:02:35.091
In real life it very well could
be that one of those guys,

49
00:02:35.091 --> 00:02:36.460
just the router is down, right?

50
00:02:36.460 --> 00:02:41.018
But assuming the route is up, NYEDGE2 is
supposed to be learning the route and

51
00:02:41.018 --> 00:02:43.570
then advertising it to other people.

52
00:02:43.570 --> 00:02:45.410
So I need to find out why
that's not happening,

53
00:02:45.410 --> 00:02:48.740
why isn't this particular
router advertising the routes?

54
00:02:48.740 --> 00:02:51.370
Now, it may be that it's not
learning it in the first place.

55
00:02:51.370 --> 00:02:55.510
We could have a prefix list or an access
control list, we could have authentication

56
00:02:55.510 --> 00:02:58.280
turned on for OSPF and
these guys are failing authentication.

57
00:02:58.280 --> 00:03:01.090
There's all sorts of OSPF type issues
that could be causing that route

58
00:03:01.090 --> 00:03:01.632
not to come in, all right.

59
00:03:02.940 --> 00:03:07.820
And then once it comes in,
NYEDGE2 is supposed to advertise

60
00:03:07.820 --> 00:03:12.120
that out to everybody else in Area 0,
they're supposed to learn it, okay?

61
00:03:12.120 --> 00:03:17.150
And those area numbers are important
because if this is area 61 up here, and

62
00:03:17.150 --> 00:03:18.742
this down here was, say,

63
00:03:18.742 --> 00:03:22.140
Area 1, you wouldn't be allowed to
advertise the routes between it.

64
00:03:22.140 --> 00:03:26.140
You can only advertise routes between
one area and Area 0, right, well in this

65
00:03:26.140 --> 00:03:29.350
case I have Area 0, so I'm fine,
that's not gonna be our issue, but it is

66
00:03:29.350 --> 00:03:33.036
something to remember as you troubleshoot
these types of problems on the exam.

67
00:03:33.036 --> 00:03:37.120
So, this one's gonna be kind of easy in a
way because I know exactly where to start.

68
00:03:37.120 --> 00:03:41.170
I need to start right here on NYEDGE2
because it's the responsible party,

69
00:03:41.170 --> 00:03:44.840
it should be learning the routes and
advertising it into my OSPF Area.

70
00:03:44.840 --> 00:03:48.817
So I'm gonna jump over the NYEDGE2 and
see what's up, all right?

71
00:03:48.817 --> 00:03:56.110
Now on NYEDGE2 I'm just going to
enable and do a show ip route.

72
00:03:56.110 --> 00:03:59.880
I'm gonna take a look at its routing
table and see what's learning,

73
00:03:59.880 --> 00:04:02.660
and in fact, if the routing table is big,
I might need to filter that.

74
00:04:02.660 --> 00:04:05.040
In my case, [LAUGH] the routing
table is very, very small.

75
00:04:05.040 --> 00:04:07.490
Looking at the routing table on NYEDGE2,

76
00:04:07.490 --> 00:04:10.560
I see something that is kind
of indicative of our problem.

77
00:04:10.560 --> 00:04:15.350
We're supposed to be
participating in OSPF Area 0, and

78
00:04:15.350 --> 00:04:18.420
we're supposed to be participating
in OSPF Area 61, right?

79
00:04:18.420 --> 00:04:23.210
This router is a border router,
an ABR, an area border router.

80
00:04:23.210 --> 00:04:26.730
And so it should be participating both
which means I should be learning routes,

81
00:04:26.730 --> 00:04:30.230
I should be learning all these routes
over here in this table, and I'm not.

82
00:04:30.230 --> 00:04:34.840
In fact, when I look at that routing
table, it's a little bit sparse, right,

83
00:04:34.840 --> 00:04:36.890
there's no OSPF routes.

84
00:04:36.890 --> 00:04:38.810
I've got some directly
connected routes and that's it.

85
00:04:38.810 --> 00:04:41.410
I'm not learning anything
about these other networks.

86
00:04:41.410 --> 00:04:47.569
Now that's really odd because I know even
on our LAN, there's 192.168.11, .13, .16,

87
00:04:47.569 --> 00:04:52.323
right, all those other networks that are
out there, I'm not seeing any of those.

88
00:04:52.323 --> 00:04:54.670
I should be learning about them,
and I'm not.

89
00:04:54.670 --> 00:04:56.440
So it could be that we're
not even running OSPF,

90
00:04:56.440 --> 00:04:58.460
that would be an interesting problem.

91
00:04:58.460 --> 00:05:04.020
We can verify that real quick with
a show ip protocols and well,

92
00:05:04.020 --> 00:05:05.970
we are, we're running OSPF, right?

93
00:05:05.970 --> 00:05:10.473
Now, my protocol, it says ospf 100,
well 100 is just the process number,

94
00:05:10.473 --> 00:05:13.760
I don't really care about that,
but I do care about areas.

95
00:05:13.760 --> 00:05:19.033
And looking down here I can see
I've got 172.14.0.0 set for

96
00:05:19.033 --> 00:05:22.340
Area 61, 192.168.12.0 for

97
00:05:22.340 --> 00:05:27.272
Area 0, and 192.168.255.0 set for
Area 0 also.

98
00:05:27.272 --> 00:05:31.326
So I've got interfaces in Area 0 and
Area 61, I'm a border route,

99
00:05:31.326 --> 00:05:33.123
that's kind of what I expect.

100
00:05:33.123 --> 00:05:36.099
Now, I don't know what interfaces
these are assigned to, so

101
00:05:36.099 --> 00:05:37.710
I'm gonna do a show ip int brief.

102
00:05:39.330 --> 00:05:40.549
Try and get an idea of that.

103
00:05:40.549 --> 00:05:45.981
So looking at my interfaces
I've got a serial link,

104
00:05:45.981 --> 00:05:50.310
I'm gonna ignore that one for right now.

105
00:05:50.310 --> 00:05:53.197
But my other interfaces
Gi0/1 is 172.14.0.2 and

106
00:05:53.197 --> 00:05:55.760
up here I can see 172.14.0 is set for
area 61.

107
00:05:55.760 --> 00:05:58.082
So that's Gi0/1.

108
00:05:58.082 --> 00:06:01.840
If I go to my diagram,
that's this interface right here.

109
00:06:01.840 --> 00:06:05.807
So that interface is associated
with Area 61 like I expect.

110
00:06:05.807 --> 00:06:11.863
And then down here I've got Gi0/0 which
is pointing to my internal network and

111
00:06:11.863 --> 00:06:18.290
if I look, 0/0 is 192.168.12.5,
so it's on VLAN 12 apparently.

112
00:06:19.300 --> 00:06:21.210
And that is set for Area 0.

113
00:06:21.210 --> 00:06:27.790
So it looks like my OSPF configuration
is good, but I'm not seeing any routes.

114
00:06:27.790 --> 00:06:29.890
Now, why wouldn't I see routes?

115
00:06:29.890 --> 00:06:33.570
Well, it could be that nobody
out there is running OSPF.

116
00:06:33.570 --> 00:06:37.070
Maybe I'm the only person running OSPF and
nobody else is.

117
00:06:37.070 --> 00:06:38.940
All right,
few ways that we could verify that.

118
00:06:38.940 --> 00:06:42.709
We could do a show ip ospf neighbor,
right?

119
00:06:42.709 --> 00:06:44.707
We'll see if there's any
neighbors that are out there.

120
00:06:44.707 --> 00:06:48.990
And I don't have any neighbors,
well, that's not good.

121
00:06:48.990 --> 00:06:51.950
If we expect to learn routes,
we probably need some neighbors, right?

122
00:06:51.950 --> 00:06:55.420
And if I don't have any neighbors to find,
well I'm not gonna learn any routes.

123
00:06:55.420 --> 00:06:57.860
So that's gonna be an issue, right?

124
00:06:57.860 --> 00:07:00.600
It could be that nobody
else is running OSPF, or

125
00:07:00.600 --> 00:07:02.800
it could be that my interfaces are down,
right?

126
00:07:02.800 --> 00:07:05.580
Maybe I've got interfaces that aren't
functional, I know they are, right?

127
00:07:05.580 --> 00:07:08.330
I can see up here that I've got
a bunch of up ups and stuff, so

128
00:07:08.330 --> 00:07:12.690
I know I'm okay, but
that's a possible scenario, right?

129
00:07:12.690 --> 00:07:14.660
I could test this out
a little bit further.

130
00:07:14.660 --> 00:07:19.253
So if I take NYEDGE2 here and
test out to ISP1 and ISP2,

131
00:07:19.253 --> 00:07:24.914
they've given me the IPs,
right, 172.14.0.3 and .4.

132
00:07:24.914 --> 00:07:28.180
I could try and ping those and
see how far I get.

133
00:07:28.180 --> 00:07:30.710
So I'm just going to ping
out to that .3 and .4.

134
00:07:30.710 --> 00:07:37.678
So right here from NYEDGE2 I should
just be able to ping to 172.14.0.3,

135
00:07:37.678 --> 00:07:41.480
and .4, I've got connectivity, right?

136
00:07:41.480 --> 00:07:44.290
If I didn't have connectivity, if I
couldn't even get to those other systems,

137
00:07:44.290 --> 00:07:46.630
then I'd have a problem there,
but I can get to them.

138
00:07:46.630 --> 00:07:50.270
Supposedly, they're running OSPF,
supposedly I'm running OSPF,

139
00:07:50.270 --> 00:07:52.300
and I'm not seeing them, all right.

140
00:07:52.300 --> 00:07:54.650
They're not in my neighbor table but
I can ping them, so

141
00:07:54.650 --> 00:07:56.420
it's not a reachability issue.

142
00:07:56.420 --> 00:07:57.825
So what else is it from there?

143
00:07:57.825 --> 00:08:02.300
Well, maybe they aren't set up for
OSPF, right?

144
00:08:02.300 --> 00:08:03.440
We can figure that out.

145
00:08:03.440 --> 00:08:08.066
If you do a debug you can
do a quick debg ip ospf.

146
00:08:08.066 --> 00:08:12.882
And then there's a few different, oops,
I guess I have to spell debug right.

147
00:08:12.882 --> 00:08:16.450
debug ip ospf, and there's a few
different things we can debug with OSPF,

148
00:08:16.450 --> 00:08:19.050
packet is one of the most
useful ones right there.

149
00:08:19.050 --> 00:08:22.287
Because regardless of whether OSPF
is configured right or wrong,

150
00:08:22.287 --> 00:08:25.716
you should at least see packets coming
in and out from that other host.

151
00:08:25.716 --> 00:08:30.369
And so I could do a debug ip ospf packet
just to see whether or not any packets

152
00:08:30.369 --> 00:08:35.774
are coming in, and ospf, well it normally
responds a little faster than this, oh, I

153
00:08:35.774 --> 00:08:41.280
might have console logging turned off, so
let's jump in here and do logging console.

154
00:08:42.820 --> 00:08:45.700
Or if you're SSHD, and you might
have terminal monitor turned off, so

155
00:08:45.700 --> 00:08:47.220
you just do terminal monitor.

156
00:08:47.220 --> 00:08:49.910
And so we should start to see
some messages, there we go.

157
00:08:49.910 --> 00:08:53.450
And I just saw an OSPF-100 PAK come in,
right?

158
00:08:53.450 --> 00:08:56.780
OSPF is the protocol,
100 is my process id.

159
00:08:56.780 --> 00:08:59.330
And then PAK letting you know
this is packet debugging.

160
00:08:59.330 --> 00:09:04.920
And then I can see Drop packet,
OSPF not running or passive.

161
00:09:04.920 --> 00:09:07.420
Well, now there's a good indicator.

162
00:09:07.420 --> 00:09:10.050
OSPF not running,
I know that's not true, I am running it,

163
00:09:10.050 --> 00:09:11.990
I saw it with show ip protocols.

164
00:09:11.990 --> 00:09:15.700
Or passive, I might have
a passive interface configured.

165
00:09:15.700 --> 00:09:18.445
If I've got a passive interface
configured, I might be receiving those

166
00:09:18.445 --> 00:09:20.878
routes from the other guys and
just throwing them away, right?

167
00:09:20.878 --> 00:09:23.181
Throwing them away because I
don't need them or whatever, so

168
00:09:23.181 --> 00:09:24.610
I'll bet that's what my problem is.

169
00:09:24.610 --> 00:09:28.810
So I'm gonna do a quick undebug all and

170
00:09:28.810 --> 00:09:34.776
just get that turned off and
I'm gonna turn off console logging also.

171
00:09:34.776 --> 00:09:40.230
All right, and now I wanna check and
see if I've got a passive interface,

172
00:09:40.230 --> 00:09:42.210
and the easiest way to do that,
there's a few ways.

173
00:09:42.210 --> 00:09:47.120
If you do show ip protocols,
it's actually in there,

174
00:09:47.120 --> 00:09:48.650
where you can see passive interfaces,

175
00:09:48.650 --> 00:09:53.620
and sure enough, I do right on Gi0/1, so
I've got a little bit of a problem there.

176
00:09:53.620 --> 00:09:55.550
But I could have also seen
it in the configuration.

177
00:09:55.550 --> 00:09:58.250
If I do a show running-config and
I look for

178
00:09:58.250 --> 00:10:03.940
the OSPF section, right in there you'll
see that passive interface, all right?

179
00:10:03.940 --> 00:10:08.870
Now it's not uncommon to have a passive
interface when you're pointing to an ISP.

180
00:10:08.870 --> 00:10:12.400
Cuz we don't normally want the ISP to
be able to propagate routes to us or

181
00:10:12.400 --> 00:10:14.430
we don't want to send them routes.

182
00:10:14.430 --> 00:10:16.510
But in this case I need
to learn those routes.

183
00:10:16.510 --> 00:10:19.250
And having a passive interface
is gonna stop that from working.

184
00:10:19.250 --> 00:10:21.740
So if I want to learn routes on the ISP,
but

185
00:10:21.740 --> 00:10:25.240
I still want security, what I need to
do is couple this to the route map.

186
00:10:25.240 --> 00:10:29.460
I can learn routes but not advertise
routes, or advertise only specific routes.

187
00:10:29.460 --> 00:10:30.870
You can do all sorts of things, but

188
00:10:30.870 --> 00:10:32.670
that's not what the troubleshooting's
ticket's asking us to do.

189
00:10:32.670 --> 00:10:35.590
It's just asking us to
learn from this route so

190
00:10:35.590 --> 00:10:39.340
we're just gonna turn off that passive
interface and that should fix this, easy.

191
00:10:39.340 --> 00:10:41.360
So let's go see if it
is actually that easy.

192
00:10:41.360 --> 00:10:44.920
So I'm gonna get into my configuration and
router ospf 100.

193
00:10:44.920 --> 00:10:49.931
I'll do a no passive-interface gi0/1.

194
00:10:49.931 --> 00:10:54.080
And now I should start receiving those
communications from the other side and

195
00:10:54.080 --> 00:10:56.010
I should start learning those routes.

196
00:10:56.010 --> 00:11:00.150
So, we'll find out right here
if we wait just a moment.

197
00:11:00.150 --> 00:11:02.730
And OSPF is fairly fast, but

198
00:11:02.730 --> 00:11:08.390
I'm gonna just monitor show ip ospf
neighbor and I've got some neighbors.

199
00:11:08.390 --> 00:11:12.390
And I'm gonna wait for them to show full,
which they already are, but when they fire

200
00:11:12.390 --> 00:11:17.050
up you might see ex start or something
else as it goes through the negotiations.

201
00:11:17.050 --> 00:11:20.330
But once you're full you should
be exchanging networks with them.

202
00:11:20.330 --> 00:11:25.710
And if I do a show ip route, hopefully
I'll see some OSPF routes and I do.

203
00:11:25.710 --> 00:11:29.640
And there's 10.61.1.1 in my routing table.

204
00:11:29.640 --> 00:11:33.010
So passive interface here was
blocking those communications,

205
00:11:33.010 --> 00:11:34.670
I saw it with the debug.

206
00:11:34.670 --> 00:11:36.970
I could have seen it if I
had just scanned the config,

207
00:11:36.970 --> 00:11:39.690
probably would have been faster that way,
but the debug turned up if you

208
00:11:39.690 --> 00:11:42.130
know the command to run you
can find it really quick.

209
00:11:42.130 --> 00:11:45.842
Now normally at this point, I would
start taking a look at my other devices,

210
00:11:45.842 --> 00:11:48.511
right, because the troubleshooting
question said,

211
00:11:48.511 --> 00:11:52.993
the route to network 10.61.1.1 is not in
the routing table of any device, right?

212
00:11:52.993 --> 00:11:55.909
So when you say any device to me that
makes me think of all the devices in

213
00:11:55.909 --> 00:11:58.547
the network and so I'd run and
start checking the other ones.

214
00:11:58.547 --> 00:12:02.252
But in this case I'm gonna hold off on
doing that and the reason is we're gonna

215
00:12:02.252 --> 00:12:05.788
see that we still have two more
troubleshooting issues in this set, one of

216
00:12:05.788 --> 00:12:09.860
which is actually stopping this route
from making it to the other devices too.

217
00:12:09.860 --> 00:12:11.520
So I don't wanna overlap my issues and

218
00:12:11.520 --> 00:12:14.430
kinda wrap them all up in one, but we'll
get a chance to see that in a moment.

219
00:12:14.430 --> 00:12:18.190
But for now we've made sure that
that route is coming from the ISP,

220
00:12:18.190 --> 00:12:20.570
coming into the edge router, and

221
00:12:20.570 --> 00:12:24.570
it's now available to Area 0 assuming
the other devices are working properly.

222
00:12:24.570 --> 00:12:26.000
We'll see that some of them aren't but

223
00:12:26.000 --> 00:12:28.130
that's kinda the nature
of troubleshooting.

224
00:12:28.130 --> 00:12:31.060
But for now we've solved this problem,
turned out to be a passive interface,

225
00:12:31.060 --> 00:12:32.410
we got it squared away.

226
00:12:32.410 --> 00:12:34.760
Now we're learning those routes and
we're back in business.

227
00:12:34.760 --> 00:12:38.410
Now just keep in mind in real life land
that you might wanna go a step further and

228
00:12:38.410 --> 00:12:42.750
put a route map in place in between you
and the ISP, so you can control what

229
00:12:42.750 --> 00:12:46.010
routes they're allowed to tell you and
what routes you're gonna tell them.

230
00:12:46.010 --> 00:12:48.520
A great way to do that and
still maintain security.

231
00:12:48.520 --> 00:12:51.470
Some people don't like to run
dynamic protocols with an ISP

232
00:12:51.470 --> 00:12:52.710
like this because of that.

233
00:12:52.710 --> 00:12:55.980
It's not that you can't, it's just
that you've gotta take precautions,

234
00:12:55.980 --> 00:12:56.960
so not such a bad thing.

235
00:12:56.960 --> 00:12:59.880
All right, well that wraps it up for
this one, stay tuned, we

236
00:12:59.880 --> 00:13:03.782
still have two more troubleshooting issues
in this set and they'll be coming up next.

237
00:13:03.782 --> 00:13:09.519
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #6` from set #1. The trouble ticket states that "The WAN conection between NYEDGE1 and NYEDGE2 is not up. The physical interface is up, however the line protocol is down and the console shows that the interface is flapping."
episodes.title: Set 1 Issue 6
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.362
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.362 --> 00:00:11.930
All right, it's time to take a look at
troubleshooting Set 1, Issue number 6.

3
00:00:11.930 --> 00:00:15.160
And on this one, we're gonna nice little
break that we're not gonna do a lot of

4
00:00:15.160 --> 00:00:16.820
hunting and gathering on this one.

5
00:00:16.820 --> 00:00:20.020
We've got a problem that exists
between two particular routers.

6
00:00:20.020 --> 00:00:22.750
Looks like a WAN link is down, the
troubleshooting ticket reads like this.

7
00:00:22.750 --> 00:00:28.490
It says, the WAN connection between
NYEDGE 1 and NYEDGE 2 is not up.

8
00:00:28.490 --> 00:00:30.170
The physical interface is up.

9
00:00:30.170 --> 00:00:31.680
However, the line protocol is down and

10
00:00:31.680 --> 00:00:34.880
the console shows that
the interface is flapping.

11
00:00:34.880 --> 00:00:38.450
So we've got a serial interface that's
going up, down, up down over and

12
00:00:38.450 --> 00:00:39.420
over and over again.

13
00:00:39.420 --> 00:00:41.500
We need to find out why and
get it resolved.

14
00:00:41.500 --> 00:00:44.580
Well, before we do that,
let's jump into our diagram and

15
00:00:44.580 --> 00:00:47.400
kind of look at our map of the network and
get an idea of where this problem is.

16
00:00:47.400 --> 00:00:51.330
So our issue is right here in
between NYEDGE1 and NYEDGE2.

17
00:00:51.330 --> 00:00:57.090
And you'll see on both of them, it's
Ser0/0/0, that'll make life easy on us.

18
00:00:57.090 --> 00:01:00.700
And it's a point-to-point WAN link,
and it's going up, down.

19
00:01:00.700 --> 00:01:03.270
Now, with a point-to-point WAN link,

20
00:01:03.270 --> 00:01:07.820
it's typically always going to be up, but
there's certain things that can go wrong.

21
00:01:07.820 --> 00:01:10.000
When you've got a serial link like this,

22
00:01:10.000 --> 00:01:14.840
you've got layer 2 protocols like HDLC or
PPP that could be running.

23
00:01:14.840 --> 00:01:16.580
It could be configured improperly.

24
00:01:16.580 --> 00:01:21.110
We might have other issues going on
between the lines, clock rates and

25
00:01:21.110 --> 00:01:23.120
timings, all sorts of stuff.

26
00:01:23.120 --> 00:01:25.960
Heck, this could frame relaying
encapsulated for all I know.

27
00:01:25.960 --> 00:01:27.960
We'll have to take a look
at the configurations and

28
00:01:27.960 --> 00:01:29.340
see where that issue is.

29
00:01:29.340 --> 00:01:31.700
But the fact that the line's going up and
then down, up and

30
00:01:31.700 --> 00:01:36.530
then down, that tells you that it's more
than likely not a layer one problem.

31
00:01:36.530 --> 00:01:39.040
The physical cable is
more than likely okay.

32
00:01:39.040 --> 00:01:42.130
It could be, though,
that there is a physical cable problem

33
00:01:42.130 --> 00:01:46.072
if we have something like UDLD, the
Unidirectional Link Detection, turned on.

34
00:01:46.072 --> 00:01:49.540
Maybe we're sending traffic one way and
not getting responses back so

35
00:01:49.540 --> 00:01:54.220
the line goes down, and then it comes back
up, and then it goes down, and so on.

36
00:01:54.220 --> 00:01:58.190
On the exam, a physical cable failure is
pretty unlikely cuz you can't fix it, but

37
00:01:58.190 --> 00:02:00.270
in real life,
it's something that does happen.

38
00:02:00.270 --> 00:02:03.530
This was more than likely just gonna
be a protocol misconfiguration,

39
00:02:03.530 --> 00:02:05.220
so let's jump in there and find out.

40
00:02:05.220 --> 00:02:08.160
We don't have to hunt around
a bunch in this topology cuz

41
00:02:08.160 --> 00:02:10.030
it's all really gonna be here on EDGE1 and
EDGE2.

42
00:02:10.030 --> 00:02:13.090
Doesn't matter which one you start with,
one's as good as the other.

43
00:02:13.090 --> 00:02:16.840
I'll start on EDGE1 and
see what we can find.

44
00:02:16.840 --> 00:02:18.580
So if I jump over to EDGE1,

45
00:02:18.580 --> 00:02:22.810
well, before I even get logged in we
can see the interface flapping, right.

46
00:02:22.810 --> 00:02:26.680
If you look at all these messages,
line protocol 5 up, down.

47
00:02:26.680 --> 00:02:31.075
Line protocol and interface Ser00/0/0,
change state to down, then up,

48
00:02:31.075 --> 00:02:33.150
then down, then up.

49
00:02:33.150 --> 00:02:38.520
And if I look at the timers on it,
they look to be about four seconds apart.

50
00:02:38.520 --> 00:02:42.260
Well, it's not always,
some of them are a little more spread out.

51
00:02:42.260 --> 00:02:44.180
But some of them are as
close as four seconds apart,

52
00:02:44.180 --> 00:02:45.619
some of them are a little bit further.

53
00:02:45.619 --> 00:02:51.648
And so it is doing this over and over and
over again, just constantly failing.

54
00:02:51.648 --> 00:02:53.614
So I'm going to go ahead and
get logged into this and

55
00:02:53.614 --> 00:02:55.200
let's see if we can't find out why.

56
00:02:55.200 --> 00:02:57.940
Now, the first thing I want to do is I
want to do is I want to figure out what

57
00:02:57.940 --> 00:02:59.500
kind of interface this is.

58
00:02:59.500 --> 00:03:03.150
Is it frame relay, is it PPP, is it HDLC,
you know what the heck is it,

59
00:03:03.150 --> 00:03:06.540
and then we can kind of gauge
our troubleshooting from there.

60
00:03:06.540 --> 00:03:10.349
So I'm gonna do a show run,
or show running-config, for

61
00:03:10.349 --> 00:03:14.860
interface Ser0/0/0 to see
what I'm dealing with.

62
00:03:14.860 --> 00:03:19.430
And it looks like we've got
a PPP serial interface,

63
00:03:19.430 --> 00:03:22.480
all right, and
we've got authentication turned on.

64
00:03:22.480 --> 00:03:27.850
Now authentication, if authentication
is failing the line may come up,

65
00:03:27.850 --> 00:03:29.611
you send your credentials, and

66
00:03:29.611 --> 00:03:33.670
then if your credentials fail the line
goes back down again, and then it retries.

67
00:03:33.670 --> 00:03:36.500
So that very well could be
the cause of our flapping.

68
00:03:36.500 --> 00:03:38.940
Could be a physical cable,
could be other things, but

69
00:03:38.940 --> 00:03:42.080
I bet that authentication
is where our problems is.

70
00:03:42.080 --> 00:03:45.672
Now looking at it here,
I've got an ip address, 192.168.255.1.

71
00:03:45.672 --> 00:03:51.709
And the subnet mask is 255.255.255.252,
really small subnet there.

72
00:03:51.709 --> 00:03:55.392
That's a slash 30, and so
the only other valid IP is .2.

73
00:03:55.392 --> 00:03:57.550
I'll have to make sure
the other side has that.

74
00:03:57.550 --> 00:03:58.630
Encapsulation is set for ppp.

75
00:03:58.630 --> 00:04:03.130
I've got my authentication set for
chap, challenge handshake.

76
00:04:03.130 --> 00:04:05.570
It's important to pay attention to that
because the other side might be set for

77
00:04:05.570 --> 00:04:07.690
pap or something that doesn't match.

78
00:04:07.690 --> 00:04:13.015
My chap hostname is NYEDGE1,
and my chap password is cisco.

79
00:04:13.015 --> 00:04:15.340
And I've got a 0 here letting
me know that's unencrypted,

80
00:04:15.340 --> 00:04:16.985
just sending the word cisco.

81
00:04:16.985 --> 00:04:21.580
Well, this is NYEDGE1, the host name,
but they're overridden it here

82
00:04:21.580 --> 00:04:23.780
with the same thing,
not really necessary, but they did it.

83
00:04:23.780 --> 00:04:27.530
So that's what we're trying to log
into the other router as, okay.

84
00:04:27.530 --> 00:04:31.790
The other router is connecting to us, and
trying to log in as, well, something else.

85
00:04:31.790 --> 00:04:33.175
Let's go take a look at it real quick.

86
00:04:33.175 --> 00:04:38.520
So if I go to NYEDGE2, I'm just
gonna do that same exact thing, so

87
00:04:38.520 --> 00:04:45.240
I'll jump in here and
do a show running-config for int s0/0/0.

88
00:04:45.240 --> 00:04:48.740
And it does have the .2 ips,
so that's good.

89
00:04:48.740 --> 00:04:53.030
Encapsulation ppp, ppp, authentication
chap, so those are the same.

90
00:04:53.030 --> 00:04:57.259
It's got a host name of NYEDGE2, and
it's got a chap password of cisco.

91
00:04:57.259 --> 00:05:00.453
Now it's got a clock rate set,
the other side didn't, but that's okay,

92
00:05:00.453 --> 00:05:01.480
I expect that, right.

93
00:05:01.480 --> 00:05:05.960
With a point-to-point serial line,
you have a DTE side and

94
00:05:05.960 --> 00:05:09.560
a DCE side, right, the data terminal and
the data communications.

95
00:05:09.560 --> 00:05:12.640
And one side determines the clock rate,
and

96
00:05:12.640 --> 00:05:15.360
the other side listens,
the DTE side listens.

97
00:05:15.360 --> 00:05:17.260
This guy must be the DCE side.

98
00:05:17.260 --> 00:05:21.150
So, it's got a clock rate set of 2
megabit, and that should be fine.

99
00:05:21.150 --> 00:05:24.400
Well, I mean, the clock rate could be set
to something the line doesn't support,

100
00:05:24.400 --> 00:05:27.660
that could be a problem, but 2 megabits,
well within the range for a Cisco router.

101
00:05:28.840 --> 00:05:32.630
All right, so this one is sending
NYEDGE2 with a password of cisco.

102
00:05:32.630 --> 00:05:36.750
The other side's sending NYEDGE1
with a password of cisco, also.

103
00:05:36.750 --> 00:05:39.570
So it looks like authentication
is set up correctly, right?

104
00:05:39.570 --> 00:05:42.690
Well, tricky part about
ppp authentication,

105
00:05:42.690 --> 00:05:46.560
this isn't the whole thing,
this is what we're sending.

106
00:05:46.560 --> 00:05:50.280
It's not necessarily what we're receiving,
right, what we expect to receive.

107
00:05:50.280 --> 00:05:53.780
When you set up authentication,
the password has to match on both sides.

108
00:05:53.780 --> 00:05:54.910
Well, I've got cisco here and

109
00:05:54.910 --> 00:05:58.120
I've got cisco on the other side,
as far as what we're sending.

110
00:05:58.120 --> 00:05:59.940
But what are we expecting to receive?

111
00:05:59.940 --> 00:06:02.880
We might be expecting to receive
something different, and

112
00:06:02.880 --> 00:06:05.620
if they don't match,
then we have a failure, okay.

113
00:06:05.620 --> 00:06:08.120
So I need to look at my user accounts and
find that out.

114
00:06:08.120 --> 00:06:12.380
Now, there's two ways to go about
figuring out if this is the issue.

115
00:06:12.380 --> 00:06:15.695
One way if the password is encrypted,
one way if it isn't.

116
00:06:15.695 --> 00:06:17.740
We'll see if the password is encrypted.

117
00:06:17.740 --> 00:06:22.260
I should be receiving a connection from
the other router, NYEDGE1, all right.

118
00:06:22.260 --> 00:06:25.440
And when NYEDGE1 connects,
they're sending me a password of cisco, so

119
00:06:25.440 --> 00:06:28.320
I expect to receive a password of cisco.

120
00:06:28.320 --> 00:06:31.510
So if I do a show running-config, and

121
00:06:31.510 --> 00:06:34.560
I filter that to include
any line with username.

122
00:06:34.560 --> 00:06:37.050
I want to see anywhere where
I've defined a username.

123
00:06:37.050 --> 00:06:42.730
Here I can see username NYEDGE1,
password, and then the password.

124
00:06:42.730 --> 00:06:46.080
And you'll see here it's got an encryption
type of 0, so it's plain text and

125
00:06:46.080 --> 00:06:46.810
here's the password.

126
00:06:46.810 --> 00:06:49.080
And actually here's gonna be our problem,
right.

127
00:06:49.080 --> 00:06:52.650
I've got cisco with an extra o on it.

128
00:06:52.650 --> 00:06:56.130
We saw the other side was set to send
us cisco with one o at the end of it,

129
00:06:56.130 --> 00:06:57.420
here it's got two.

130
00:06:57.420 --> 00:06:58.640
I've got a problem.

131
00:06:58.640 --> 00:07:00.020
Now there's two ways to fix this.

132
00:07:00.020 --> 00:07:03.390
I could fix it by changing what the other
router is sending, or I could change it

133
00:07:03.390 --> 00:07:06.890
right here to fix that password,
which is probably the easier path.

134
00:07:06.890 --> 00:07:08.450
I'll go that route, all right.

135
00:07:08.450 --> 00:07:12.870
So, actually before I do that,
all I did was fix that password and

136
00:07:12.870 --> 00:07:14.540
that will more than likely fix the line,
and that will come up.

137
00:07:14.540 --> 00:07:18.820
But before I do it, I was lucky here
that the password was unencrypted.

138
00:07:18.820 --> 00:07:21.010
What if the password was encrypted,
though?

139
00:07:21.010 --> 00:07:25.290
If it was an encrypted password, could
I look at it and tell there was a typo?

140
00:07:25.290 --> 00:07:26.170
No.

141
00:07:26.170 --> 00:07:29.580
So I know some people, you'll see this out
on the Internet, where they'll say, hey,

142
00:07:29.580 --> 00:07:32.240
just go and reset the password and
that way you know what it is, right..

143
00:07:32.240 --> 00:07:34.620
You can certainly do that, right.

144
00:07:34.620 --> 00:07:38.380
But we could also use debug commands to
find out whether the password is right or

145
00:07:38.380 --> 00:07:40.690
wrong, or if the password is
even's the problem, right.

146
00:07:40.690 --> 00:07:42.120
When you do a debug,

147
00:07:42.120 --> 00:07:45.450
you've actually got a whole set
of ppp debugging that you can do.

148
00:07:46.880 --> 00:07:47.590
There we go.

149
00:07:47.590 --> 00:07:48.700
If you do debug ppp ?, and

150
00:07:48.700 --> 00:07:52.730
you'll see one of the things you
can debug is authentication.

151
00:07:52.730 --> 00:07:55.950
And so you can actually see whether
authentication is your problem or not.

152
00:07:55.950 --> 00:08:00.770
I'm gonna say debug ppp authentication,
and we'll turn that on.

153
00:08:02.680 --> 00:08:04.310
Console logging might
not be on on this one.

154
00:08:04.310 --> 00:08:07.670
Let me go to the other router cuz
I know it's actually logging.

155
00:08:07.670 --> 00:08:08.920
There we go.

156
00:08:08.920 --> 00:08:12.870
So on this one I'll just do
a debug ppp authentication.

157
00:08:14.100 --> 00:08:18.290
There, and now in addition to seeing the
line flap, I should see authentication,

158
00:08:18.290 --> 00:08:19.730
information, and there we go.

159
00:08:19.730 --> 00:08:23.440
And if you've never debugged PPP, it's
actually one of the nicer ones to debug.

160
00:08:23.440 --> 00:08:26.270
Let me turn off debugging here,
I'm gonna get inundated with junk.

161
00:08:27.690 --> 00:08:32.020
Because as it communicates, what it does
is it breaks it up for you with these

162
00:08:32.020 --> 00:08:37.030
little Os and Is, okay, and O, that's
an output, that's something you sent.

163
00:08:37.030 --> 00:08:39.970
An I, that's an input,
it's something you received.

164
00:08:39.970 --> 00:08:42.590
So notice here I've got CHAP, right?

165
00:08:42.590 --> 00:08:47.540
So here we got PPP is turning on,
and then CHAP does an output.

166
00:08:47.540 --> 00:08:51.950
We've got a challenge, and we're sending
a challenge from us, from NYEDGE1.

167
00:08:51.950 --> 00:08:54.820
And then I've got an input,
right, here's an input challenge.

168
00:08:54.820 --> 00:08:58.570
It's coming from NYEDGE2,
I'm receiving that one.

169
00:08:58.570 --> 00:09:02.820
And then we're sending a AUTH request,

170
00:09:02.820 --> 00:09:04.760
jeez my debug's just
kind of kicked me out.

171
00:09:04.760 --> 00:09:07.020
There we go.
So we're sending that AUTH request and

172
00:09:07.020 --> 00:09:08.360
we're getting a response.

173
00:09:08.360 --> 00:09:10.090
And as we look, we can find,

174
00:09:10.090 --> 00:09:14.100
here I'm outputting a failure, and
we've got an authentication failure.

175
00:09:14.100 --> 00:09:16.900
So, I can see that my authentication
is the problem, right.

176
00:09:16.900 --> 00:09:19.330
So, you can kinda drill it down that way,

177
00:09:19.330 --> 00:09:22.920
even if the password is encrypted,
to find out if that's really the problem.

178
00:09:22.920 --> 00:09:26.090
If I see here that
authentication is successful,

179
00:09:26.090 --> 00:09:30.000
then I know it's not a password problem,
and I can stop from resetting that.

180
00:09:30.000 --> 00:09:32.748
Why change somebody's password if that's
not what the problem is, and on the exam,

181
00:09:32.748 --> 00:09:33.487
you gotta be careful.

182
00:09:33.487 --> 00:09:36.833
You don't want to fix a problem that
doesn't exist, so that's why I wanted

183
00:09:36.833 --> 00:09:40.195
to show you that debug just in case you
have to do that on the exam, all right.

184
00:09:40.195 --> 00:09:43.620
But in my case I do just
have a bad password, so

185
00:09:43.620 --> 00:09:48.500
I'm gonna jump over to NYEdge2,
and we'll fix that, right?

186
00:09:48.500 --> 00:09:50.250
I just need to reset that user name.

187
00:09:51.770 --> 00:09:55.460
So if I take a look at my
running config again, and

188
00:09:55.460 --> 00:09:58.720
I look at that username,
it just has that bad password.

189
00:09:58.720 --> 00:10:04.300
So I'll come in here and
say username NYEDGE1 password 0 cisco.

190
00:10:05.660 --> 00:10:07.470
And that's gonna set it, okay.

191
00:10:07.470 --> 00:10:12.590
So now that that's set, the passwords
match, the line should come up.

192
00:10:12.590 --> 00:10:17.240
And if I jump back over to NYEDGE1,
which is doing logging, I can see that

193
00:10:17.240 --> 00:10:21.965
interface did just come up and
it's not flapping, it actually stayed up.

194
00:10:21.965 --> 00:10:26.300
And I know that because I can see OSPF
just formed an adjacency over it, right.

195
00:10:26.300 --> 00:10:30.510
And so if I do a #show ip int br,

196
00:10:30.510 --> 00:10:38.620
I expect to see serial 0/0/0 as an up,
up line, which we'll find right down here.

197
00:10:38.620 --> 00:10:39.880
So it is up, up.

198
00:10:41.060 --> 00:10:44.460
And now if I watch it, I should see it
stay up for a longer period of time.

199
00:10:44.460 --> 00:10:47.600
If I do a show interface for s0/0/0, and

200
00:10:47.600 --> 00:10:51.070
take a look at it's counters, before
we were having a lot of state changes.

201
00:10:51.070 --> 00:10:55.550
If I look down here at my counters,
we should be able to find, now let's see,

202
00:10:55.550 --> 00:10:58.240
where are the state changes that
varied in here, right here.

203
00:10:58.240 --> 00:11:02.598
2,037 interface resets,
it flapped 2,037 times, but

204
00:11:02.598 --> 00:11:06.110
now it's up and it should stay up and
be a lot happier.

205
00:11:07.340 --> 00:11:08.550
So we can just wait.

206
00:11:08.550 --> 00:11:10.538
It's a good idea to wait
just a few moments.

207
00:11:10.538 --> 00:11:13.400
We saw where the failures were as
little as four seconds apart, but

208
00:11:13.400 --> 00:11:14.170
as many as 30 seconds.

209
00:11:14.170 --> 00:11:17.100
So I'm just gonna wait and
make sure this stays up for 30 seconds.

210
00:11:17.100 --> 00:11:20.530
I haven't seen any other messages pop up,
so I think we're in good shape.

211
00:11:20.530 --> 00:11:25.360
And we can ping across it,
just to make sure the line is actually up.

212
00:11:25.360 --> 00:11:28.840
So I'm gonna ping the other side,
and we're in business, all right?

213
00:11:28.840 --> 00:11:31.980
So this one turned out to be
a little bit of authentication.

214
00:11:31.980 --> 00:11:35.200
Once that was squared away, the line
came up, and now we're in business.

215
00:11:35.200 --> 00:11:37.400
So not a bad one to jump into.

216
00:11:37.400 --> 00:11:39.620
I used debugs to find this one.

217
00:11:39.620 --> 00:11:42.510
You didn't have to use debugs,
you could have just done where you look at

218
00:11:42.510 --> 00:11:45.350
the running configuration and
spotted the bad password right there.

219
00:11:45.350 --> 00:11:47.210
If it's unencrypted, right.

220
00:11:47.210 --> 00:11:50.928
Just remember when you configure PPP
you configure a password to send,

221
00:11:50.928 --> 00:11:54.930
but the receive side is
defined with a user name.

222
00:11:54.930 --> 00:11:56.740
So you gotta check the user name settings,
also,

223
00:11:56.740 --> 00:11:59.130
outside of PPP to make sure that's right.

224
00:11:59.130 --> 00:12:02.130
But once you've got that squared away the
lines come up, and that problem is solved.

225
00:12:02.130 --> 00:12:04.690
So that wraps it up for
this troubleshooting issue.

226
00:12:04.690 --> 00:12:06.620
Stay tuned.
We still have a few a few more to tackle

227
00:12:06.620 --> 00:12:09.020
here in Set 1 before we
move on to the next set.

228
00:12:09.020 --> 00:12:10.290
So tune back in for that.

229
00:12:10.290 --> 00:12:11.452
I look forward to seeing you then.

230
00:12:11.452 --> 00:12:14.343
[MUSIC]

231
00:12:14.343 --> 00:12:17.269
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #7` from set #1. The trouble ticket states that "NYEDGE2 and NYCORE2 are not forming an OSPF adjacency."
episodes.title: Set 1 Issue 7
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.747
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.747 --> 00:00:10.390
All right, welcome to Set 1 in Issue 7.

3
00:00:10.390 --> 00:00:12.710
And in this one we've got
another troubleshooting issue,

4
00:00:12.710 --> 00:00:15.580
and this is actually gonna
tie back to Issue 5.

5
00:00:15.580 --> 00:00:18.810
Back in Issue 5 we troubleshot
a problem with some OSPF

6
00:00:18.810 --> 00:00:20.900
routes not making it into our environment.

7
00:00:20.900 --> 00:00:23.950
And at the end of Issue 5,
I made a comment I said.

8
00:00:23.950 --> 00:00:28.030
At this point I normally continue on
to troubleshoot additional devices.

9
00:00:28.030 --> 00:00:30.510
But there's another problem somewhere
that's actually causing it not to work, so

10
00:00:30.510 --> 00:00:31.870
we stopped there.

11
00:00:31.870 --> 00:00:33.930
Well, here we're gonna take
a look at that problem.

12
00:00:33.930 --> 00:00:38.050
So if you didn't do Issue 5,
what we basically had was one router.

13
00:00:38.050 --> 00:00:40.760
Let me bring up my topology
here to recap it for us.

14
00:00:40.760 --> 00:00:42.420
Basically what we had
was this guy up here,

15
00:00:42.420 --> 00:00:46.400
NYEDGE2 was not learning
some routes from the ISPs.

16
00:00:46.400 --> 00:00:49.780
And so we troubleshot that we found
a problem was that NYEDGE2 had a passive

17
00:00:49.780 --> 00:00:51.840
interface, and
the route started coming in.

18
00:00:51.840 --> 00:00:55.710
NYEDGE2 has nice full routing table,
all right.

19
00:00:55.710 --> 00:00:58.660
Now we need to find out whats going
on with the rest of our routers.

20
00:00:58.660 --> 00:01:04.090
Well, in Issue 6 we saw where this
link between EDGE2 and EDGE1 was down.

21
00:01:04.090 --> 00:01:06.160
We fixed that in Issue 6,
so that's up and so

22
00:01:06.160 --> 00:01:08.550
now we're exchanging routes between these.

23
00:01:08.550 --> 00:01:13.490
But in this troubleshooting problem,
we've got an issue between NYEDGE2 and

24
00:01:13.490 --> 00:01:16.820
NYCORE2 that's causing OSPF
routes not to propagate.

25
00:01:16.820 --> 00:01:20.060
The ticket actually reads, NYEDGE2 and

26
00:01:20.060 --> 00:01:25.880
NYCORE2 are not forming an OSPF adjacency,
so these two guys are not communicating.

27
00:01:25.880 --> 00:01:28.030
So at the end of Issue 5.

28
00:01:28.030 --> 00:01:31.150
This link was down, and
this link is not forming adjacencies.

29
00:01:31.150 --> 00:01:35.668
That's why the route stated right here in
EDGE2 and didn't make it to anybody else.

30
00:01:35.668 --> 00:01:38.150
In Issue 6 we solved this problem so

31
00:01:38.150 --> 00:01:40.800
now the routes are kind of
propagating around this way.

32
00:01:40.800 --> 00:01:43.070
But we still have this
nice gigabit link here.

33
00:01:43.070 --> 00:01:45.430
Well I guess it's only a 100 mega
cuz this end is 100 megabit.

34
00:01:45.430 --> 00:01:49.040
But we've got this nice link over her that
we could be using over the serial link

35
00:01:49.040 --> 00:01:52.300
If the route's propagated properly,
we need to find out what's going on.

36
00:01:52.300 --> 00:01:54.250
Fortunately, this one's narrowed down for
us.

37
00:01:54.250 --> 00:01:56.120
It's just these two systems, right?

38
00:01:56.120 --> 00:01:59.550
NYEDGE2 and
NYCORE2 are not forming an adjacency.

39
00:01:59.550 --> 00:02:03.620
Now we've worked with
NYEDGE2 previous issues.

40
00:02:03.620 --> 00:02:04.860
We know it's running OSPF.

41
00:02:04.860 --> 00:02:05.490
We know it's up.

42
00:02:05.490 --> 00:02:08.480
We know it's interfaces appear
to be configured properly.

43
00:02:08.480 --> 00:02:10.540
So, for me to troubleshoot this one.

44
00:02:10.540 --> 00:02:12.580
I wanna start way down here on NYCORE2.

45
00:02:12.580 --> 00:02:16.062
And the only reason I'm doing that is
because I just know we've worked with

46
00:02:16.062 --> 00:02:19.810
the other router so I kind of assume
most of the problems are fixed up there.

47
00:02:19.810 --> 00:02:22.365
The problems are more likely to be
on a host we haven't worked on yet.

48
00:02:22.365 --> 00:02:24.330
Right.
But, on an exam when you're dealing with

49
00:02:24.330 --> 00:02:26.620
a communication between
two nodes like this.

50
00:02:26.620 --> 00:02:28.480
If this is the very first
time you've seen them,

51
00:02:28.480 --> 00:02:30.260
it doesn't really matter
which one you pick.

52
00:02:30.260 --> 00:02:33.200
The problem could be on either one,
so one's as good as another.

53
00:02:33.200 --> 00:02:34.960
I'm gonna start down here
on this switch though,

54
00:02:34.960 --> 00:02:37.959
