279
00:14:02.430 --> 00:14:08.730
All right, now, your router ID is
actually determined when OSPF starts.

280
00:14:08.730 --> 00:14:12.570
So notice it gives me a warning message
that I need to clear the OSPF process so

281
00:14:12.570 --> 00:14:13.649
that's what I'm gonna do next.

282
00:14:14.860 --> 00:14:17.830
Otherwise it won't actually take
affect and so I'll run that.

283
00:14:17.830 --> 00:14:22.435
It's gonna dump all of my OSPF adjacencies
and then rebuild and come back up.

284
00:14:22.435 --> 00:14:24.290
Okay.

285
00:14:24.290 --> 00:14:25.580
So that fixed this one.

286
00:14:25.580 --> 00:14:28.160
If I do a show ip protocols.

287
00:14:28.160 --> 00:14:31.810
I can see that router ID is now
dynamically generated right,

288
00:14:31.810 --> 00:14:32.600
not statically set.

289
00:14:32.600 --> 00:14:37.910
And I'm gonna go and do the same thing on
EDGE2 so I'll jump over to that router.

290
00:14:37.910 --> 00:14:40.590
And I'll find out where it's getting
its router ID and I'll clear that out.

291
00:14:40.590 --> 00:14:45.940
Now again, could be a loopback,
which is easy to spot on a router.

292
00:14:45.940 --> 00:14:48.120
In my case, not a loopback, and so

293
00:14:48.120 --> 00:14:51.850
the only other thing then is to
have that router ID defined.

294
00:14:51.850 --> 00:14:54.900
And so if we look at the OSPF section,
there it is, and

295
00:14:54.900 --> 00:14:56.580
we can just go and clear that out.

296
00:14:56.580 --> 00:14:58.540
Now technically,
I've already fixed the problem.

297
00:14:58.540 --> 00:15:00.600
Now there's only one router with 1.1.1.1.

298
00:15:00.600 --> 00:15:01.470
But I wanna be thorough here.

299
00:15:01.470 --> 00:15:03.840
Im gonna clear this router ID out.

300
00:15:03.840 --> 00:15:06.920
Because all the other ones were
set to automatically generated.

301
00:15:06.920 --> 00:15:10.520
So its kinda odd to have this one just
be statically assigned for no reason.

302
00:15:10.520 --> 00:15:12.332
So, Im just gonna get rid of that one.

303
00:15:15.302 --> 00:15:18.700
And then well be nice and
consistent across our environment.

304
00:15:18.700 --> 00:15:20.980
All of our switches, all of our routers.

305
00:15:20.980 --> 00:15:24.170
Will be dynamically
generating the router ID, and

306
00:15:24.170 --> 00:15:27.140
that'll dump all my adjacencies and
rebuild them.

307
00:15:27.140 --> 00:15:32.620
And hopefully what we'll see is
that we get a relationship built up

308
00:15:32.620 --> 00:15:35.900
with the switch on the other side,
all right.

309
00:15:35.900 --> 00:15:40.836
And i'll verify that
from the other switch So,

310
00:15:40.836 --> 00:15:45.340
if I come over here to CORE2,
where we didn't have an adjacency before.

311
00:15:45.340 --> 00:15:48.610
If I do a show ip ospf neighbor,
I can see.

312
00:15:48.610 --> 00:15:49.328
Whoops.

313
00:15:49.328 --> 00:15:51.630
[LAUGH] I got a couple of different IPs.

314
00:15:51.630 --> 00:15:52.920
Now, I'm still seeing 1.1.1.1.

315
00:15:52.920 --> 00:15:55.240
I have to wait for that to age out, right?

316
00:15:55.240 --> 00:15:57.070
So, that one will age out eventually.

317
00:15:57.070 --> 00:15:59.680
But I can see that I do have
a neighbor here, 192.168.255.2.

318
00:15:59.680 --> 00:16:04.530
And if I look over a little bit I've

319
00:16:04.530 --> 00:16:09.820
got 192.168.12.5 is the actual
address of that node so

320
00:16:09.820 --> 00:16:13.580
that is NYEDGE2 so
now we're building that adjacency.

321
00:16:13.580 --> 00:16:16.500
Oh, and
I just saw that 1.1.1.1 aged out, right?

322
00:16:16.500 --> 00:16:19.862
The timer expired and so
if I do a show ip ospf neighbor.

323
00:16:19.862 --> 00:16:21.812
That one now gone.

324
00:16:21.812 --> 00:16:25.390
All right, so in this case,
duplicate router ID,

325
00:16:25.390 --> 00:16:28.670
and while the message wasn't displayed on
my screen in the beginning because console

326
00:16:28.670 --> 00:16:30.650
logging wasn't on, it was in my logs.

327
00:16:30.650 --> 00:16:33.270
A show log would have
turned that up right away.

328
00:16:33.270 --> 00:16:35.090
We see the issue, we get in, we fix it.

329
00:16:35.090 --> 00:16:37.820
So, duplicate router IDs,
that will stop an adacency from forming.

330
00:16:37.820 --> 00:16:41.630
All right, well that pretty much wraps
it up for this troubleshooting ticket.

331
00:16:41.630 --> 00:16:45.196
Now, we should have all of our OSPF routes
spread through our environment nice and

332
00:16:45.196 --> 00:16:46.643
happy, everybody's talking,

333
00:16:46.643 --> 00:16:49.760
and exchanging,
the way that routes are supposed to work.

334
00:16:49.760 --> 00:16:53.130
We do still have one more troubleshooting
ticket to tackle in this set so

335
00:16:53.130 --> 00:16:54.319
we'll get to that next.

336
00:16:54.319 --> 00:16:57.252
Stay tuned, I hope to see you there.

337
00:16:57.252 --> 00:17:03.209
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #8` from set #1. The trouble ticket states that "PLABCSCO01 is unable to communicate to 192.168.226.0. Routes exist to this subnet, but you are unable to communicate to it from PLABCSCO01 and you can from NYWAN1. "
episodes.title: Set 1 Issue 8
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:05.976
[SOUND] Now it's time for
the final issue in Set 1 and

2
00:00:05.976 --> 00:00:12.352
it looks like we have a doozy here for
the grand finale.

3
00:00:12.352 --> 00:00:15.970
This one sounds a little more complex that
the other ones we've dealt with before.

4
00:00:15.970 --> 00:00:19.033
Let me read the scenario here,
We've got PLAB Cisco 01,

5
00:00:19.033 --> 00:00:20.820
our good old trusty Cisco server.

6
00:00:20.820 --> 00:00:26.694
It's unable to communicate
to 192.168.226.0.

7
00:00:26.694 --> 00:00:28.485
Well, .0, so that's a whole network.

8
00:00:28.485 --> 00:00:30.410
Apparently this whole
network it can't get to.

9
00:00:30.410 --> 00:00:33.740
And it says,
while routes exists to the subnet,

10
00:00:33.740 --> 00:00:40.180
you are unable to communicate to it from
PLAB Cisco 01 but you can from NYWAN1.

11
00:00:40.180 --> 00:00:41.300
That's pretty interesting.

12
00:00:41.300 --> 00:00:44.660
Let's look at our diagram and
see if we can't unravel this mystery.

13
00:00:44.660 --> 00:00:47.620
I just want to start by figuring out
what the path of traffic is that

14
00:00:47.620 --> 00:00:49.380
we're even talking about here.

15
00:00:49.380 --> 00:00:50.510
We know our trusty server.

16
00:00:50.510 --> 00:00:53.930
This guy way down at the bottom who's been
in almost every trouble shooting scenario

17
00:00:53.930 --> 00:00:55.380
we've had to deal with so far.

18
00:00:55.380 --> 00:00:59.340
This guys is where we're trying to
ping from and it's not working.

19
00:00:59.340 --> 00:01:01.830
And so
it rattles around all this equipment.

20
00:01:01.830 --> 00:01:04.410
A couple of switches,
a couple of routers and

21
00:01:04.410 --> 00:01:09.110
then it's trying to get to 192.168.226
which is a network I haven't seen yet.

22
00:01:09.110 --> 00:01:12.900
So, if we look in our little tables here,
there we go.

23
00:01:12.900 --> 00:01:14.295
It's actually staring right at me.

24
00:01:14.295 --> 00:01:18.011
192.168.226 and
it looks like it's subnetted.

25
00:01:18.011 --> 00:01:23.113
Now, in the problem it
specifically said 192.168.226.0.

26
00:01:23.113 --> 00:01:27.650
It didn't mention 0.32 so I'm going to
ignore that one and focus in on this one.

27
00:01:27.650 --> 00:01:29.200
We've got a /27.

28
00:01:29.200 --> 00:01:33.831
So, this network is residing
out here in EIGRP 800 and

29
00:01:33.831 --> 00:01:38.050
that's a public network
here that we've got.

30
00:01:38.050 --> 00:01:42.130
London WAN, New York WAN, these
are ISP's or other vendors or whatever.

31
00:01:42.130 --> 00:01:43.750
This is equipment that we don't control.

32
00:01:43.750 --> 00:01:46.266
So I can't log into this router,
I can't log into that router.

33
00:01:46.266 --> 00:01:49.207
I can't see what's going on in them,
I just know that they're out there, and

34
00:01:49.207 --> 00:01:50.915
that I should be able
to communicate to them.

35
00:01:50.915 --> 00:01:57.910
And it told me in the problem that NYWAN1,
this guy, could get to the network.

36
00:01:57.910 --> 00:01:59.690
So this guy's okay reaching out and

37
00:01:59.690 --> 00:02:02.840
getting to wherever that particular
network happens to reside.

38
00:02:02.840 --> 00:02:05.760
It's people inside of my network,
apparently, that can't, or

39
00:02:05.760 --> 00:02:07.630
at least PLABCISCO01.

40
00:02:07.630 --> 00:02:13.470
So, what we need to think about are what
are some of the possible causes, okay?

41
00:02:13.470 --> 00:02:18.920
If NYWAN1 can get to the network,
shouldn't everybody?

42
00:02:18.920 --> 00:02:19.604
Well, not necessarily.

43
00:02:19.604 --> 00:02:21.726
See how we've got EIGRP right here?

44
00:02:21.726 --> 00:02:22.969
EIGRP 500?

45
00:02:22.969 --> 00:02:28.240
And then we've got OSPF Area 0 here, and
we've got our system all behind that.

46
00:02:28.240 --> 00:02:32.250
So if NYWAN1 is sending
the route into our network,

47
00:02:32.250 --> 00:02:35.990
somebody's gotta redistribute that route,
like NYEDGE1 here.

48
00:02:35.990 --> 00:02:38.881
It's gotta be doing route redistribution
between the two networks or

49
00:02:38.881 --> 00:02:40.547
these guys won't even know about that.

50
00:02:40.547 --> 00:02:43.075
It could be that I'm going
to my default gateway,

51
00:02:43.075 --> 00:02:45.132
which is in between these two switches.

52
00:02:45.132 --> 00:02:47.071
And then they don't have
a route to get there.

53
00:02:47.071 --> 00:02:51.372
So I needed to get an idea of
where the breakdown is happening.

54
00:02:51.372 --> 00:02:54.066
The best way to do that is traceroute.

55
00:02:54.066 --> 00:02:55.603
Traceroute will help me spot that, so

56
00:02:55.603 --> 00:02:57.940
that I don't have to go
device to device to device.

57
00:02:57.940 --> 00:03:00.780
There's a lot of devices involved
in this potential problem.

58
00:03:00.780 --> 00:03:04.370
I could have one route where I
go through ACCESS1, to CORE1,

59
00:03:04.370 --> 00:03:06.082
to EDGE1, to WAN1 and out.

60
00:03:06.082 --> 00:03:12.621
Another route which would be ACCESS1 to
CORE2 to EDGE2 to EDGE1 to LAN1 and out.

61
00:03:12.621 --> 00:03:14.280
So different ways we could go.

62
00:03:14.280 --> 00:03:17.530
I'd have to look at every device, but
traceroute's going to help me dial this

63
00:03:17.530 --> 00:03:19.660
down and
get an idea of where to actually look.

64
00:03:19.660 --> 00:03:23.200
So I'm going to jump over to my
Cisco Server, and I'll start here.

65
00:03:23.200 --> 00:03:24.840
Right, so here's the Cisco Server.

66
00:03:24.840 --> 00:03:29.260
I'm going to fire open my
command prompt and oh shoot.

67
00:03:29.260 --> 00:03:30.450
I'm forgetting something.

68
00:03:30.450 --> 00:03:32.500
I probably need something to ping.

69
00:03:32.500 --> 00:03:33.240
In the problem,

70
00:03:33.240 --> 00:03:36.690
they go to great length to tell me about
these networks that I can't get to.

71
00:03:36.690 --> 00:03:40.180
But they didn't really give me any host
on the network to test with, right?

72
00:03:40.180 --> 00:03:42.752
So if I read a little
more into the problem,

73
00:03:42.752 --> 00:03:44.975
if I bother read the documentation.

74
00:03:44.975 --> 00:03:50.465
The very next thing it does is it gives an
example and shows pinging 192.168.226.1.

75
00:03:50.465 --> 00:03:54.445
So apparently there is a host out
there and before I even start there,

76
00:03:54.445 --> 00:03:57.200
I'm gonna go verify that host is active.

77
00:03:57.200 --> 00:04:01.567
They told me that NYWAN1 could get to the
host, so I'm gonna jump over the NYWAN1,

78
00:04:01.567 --> 00:04:05.625
to this router, and I'm just gonna verify
that it can just before I get heavily

79
00:04:05.625 --> 00:04:10.055
invested in troubleshooting a problem that
might be a little trickier than we think,

80
00:04:10.055 --> 00:04:11.923
so that's why I want to start here.

81
00:04:11.923 --> 00:04:17.146
And I'm just gonna do a quick
ping to 192.168.226.1.

82
00:04:17.146 --> 00:04:18.916
All right, and I am able to get there.

83
00:04:18.916 --> 00:04:21.571
That host is up and functional,
this guy can get there,

84
00:04:21.571 --> 00:04:23.220
just like the problem described.

85
00:04:24.390 --> 00:04:27.900
So now I'm gonna go back and
we'll do that traceroute.

86
00:04:27.900 --> 00:04:34.880
So I'll switch over to that Cisco Server
I'm gonna run just a quick traceroute.

87
00:04:34.880 --> 00:04:37.360
I guess I could start with a ping just
to verify that it doesn't work, but

88
00:04:37.360 --> 00:04:39.520
that doesn't really tell us all that much.

89
00:04:39.520 --> 00:04:41.260
We might get a destination
Unreachable message.

90
00:04:41.260 --> 00:04:41.830
That would help us.

91
00:04:41.830 --> 00:04:43.500
That would let us know
the route was missing.

92
00:04:43.500 --> 00:04:46.890
But, in the problem it said
the routes do exist so

93
00:04:46.890 --> 00:04:48.870
I can probably trust
the question on that one.

94
00:04:48.870 --> 00:04:50.483
In this case I'm just getting a time out.

95
00:04:50.483 --> 00:04:56.608
I'm gonna do a traceroute
to 192.168.226.1.

96
00:04:56.608 --> 00:04:58.385
And I'm going to send that out.

97
00:04:58.385 --> 00:05:00.321
Now I know NYWAN1 can get there,

98
00:05:00.321 --> 00:05:03.375
I just don't know what other
devices know about it.

99
00:05:03.375 --> 00:05:04.803
So I'm going to wait and see.

100
00:05:04.803 --> 00:05:07.303
The first hop is going to
be my default gateway, and

101
00:05:07.303 --> 00:05:09.780
my default gateway is that HSRP cluster.

102
00:05:09.780 --> 00:05:13.444
So I'm going to NYCORE1 or
NYCORE2 and that shared IP.

103
00:05:13.444 --> 00:05:17.752
The next hop is 192.168.16.4.

104
00:05:17.752 --> 00:05:19.319
That's NYEDGE1.

105
00:05:19.319 --> 00:05:21.170
Remember from the previous problems.

106
00:05:21.170 --> 00:05:23.780
So I made it to NYEDGE1.

107
00:05:23.780 --> 00:05:25.700
Now, that's gonna help me.

108
00:05:25.700 --> 00:05:28.610
It doesn't necessarily tell me where
the problem is but what it does,

109
00:05:28.610 --> 00:05:29.960
it lets me rule out these guys.

110
00:05:29.960 --> 00:05:32.160
So I can just skip right
over those switches and

111
00:05:32.160 --> 00:05:34.980
now I've shrunk my world down quite a bit.

112
00:05:34.980 --> 00:05:39.580
My world is basically this server,
makes it to EDGE1 and

113
00:05:39.580 --> 00:05:41.146
then times out after EDGE1.

114
00:05:41.146 --> 00:05:44.530
Well, EDGE1 is passing through
WAN1 on its way out, and so

115
00:05:44.530 --> 00:05:47.710
I've got a problem on
one of these two nodes.

116
00:05:47.710 --> 00:05:51.080
So, I just went from having five or
six devices to troubleshoot to only having

117
00:05:51.080 --> 00:05:53.790
two devices to troubleshoot, and
now we can start to narrow it down.

118
00:05:55.100 --> 00:05:57.290
Now one thing I wanna
do is jump to EDGE1 and

119
00:05:57.290 --> 00:06:02.180
I'm gonna try and do the same ping
from EDGE1 and see if it can get out.

120
00:06:02.180 --> 00:06:05.770
Because if it can't get out then I can
stop paying attention to the server and

121
00:06:05.770 --> 00:06:07.390
I can just work on these two nodes.

122
00:06:07.390 --> 00:06:10.360
Again just trying to minimize the amount
of devices I have to work with.

123
00:06:10.360 --> 00:06:11.935
So I'm gonna jump over to EDGE1.

124
00:06:13.990 --> 00:06:15.180
And I don't know if.

125
00:06:15.180 --> 00:06:18.030
We haven't logged into this guy in
a while, so let's jump in here and

126
00:06:18.030 --> 00:06:20.100
just see what we have.

127
00:06:20.100 --> 00:06:23.960
I'm going to go show IP interface brief,
just see what interfaces I've got.

128
00:06:23.960 --> 00:06:25.657
Oh, this is the guy with
router on a stick, I remember.

129
00:06:25.657 --> 00:06:30.233
So we've got a bunch of different
interfaces here, to communicate to WAN1.

130
00:06:30.233 --> 00:06:33.855
I'm communicating over the serial
interface, serial 001.

131
00:06:33.855 --> 00:06:37.805
And if I look at serial 001,
I'm 192.168.255.4, and

132
00:06:37.805 --> 00:06:41.560
we could probably guess the person
on the other side, but let's just

133
00:06:41.560 --> 00:06:46.610
do a show CDP neighbor and see if that
will show us the person on the other side.

134
00:06:46.610 --> 00:06:48.960
There we go NYWAN1.

135
00:06:48.960 --> 00:06:53.280
And so
I'm gonna say show cdp entry NYWAN1,

136
00:06:53.280 --> 00:06:55.840
just to get some nice
detailed information.

137
00:06:55.840 --> 00:06:58.848
And so I can see the IP
address on the other side.

138
00:06:58.848 --> 00:07:01.841
So it is 192.168.255.5.

139
00:07:01.841 --> 00:07:04.550
So I'm just gonna test that connectivity.

140
00:07:06.170 --> 00:07:08.190
And see that I can ping across them.

141
00:07:08.190 --> 00:07:11.650
So what I just tested, it was whether or
not this serial link was good.

142
00:07:11.650 --> 00:07:13.840
The serial link is up,
I'm able to ping across it.

143
00:07:13.840 --> 00:07:17.190
So NYEDGE1 can ping across it.

144
00:07:17.190 --> 00:07:21.553
And it's running EIGRP, so I should have
an EIGRP adjacency in between those two or

145
00:07:21.553 --> 00:07:22.248
a neighbor.

146
00:07:22.248 --> 00:07:27.216
So if I do a show ip eigrp neighbor,
there it is,

147
00:07:27.216 --> 00:07:30.708
192.168.255.5.

148
00:07:30.708 --> 00:07:33.168
So I am talking to it, looks like it's up.

149
00:07:33.168 --> 00:07:39.366
If I do a show ip route eigrp, I should
see that I'm learning some eigrp routes,

150
00:07:39.366 --> 00:07:47.010
and I am, including 192.168.226.0, I can
see it right there in my routing table.

151
00:07:47.010 --> 00:07:50.458
So, I'm learning the routes,
and they're coming in.

152
00:07:50.458 --> 00:07:55.568
Remember, NYEDGE1, this is the guy who
would be redistributing between two areas.

153
00:07:55.568 --> 00:07:57.808
So I might have a route
redistribution problem.

154
00:07:57.808 --> 00:07:59.188
Well, be careful with that.

155
00:07:59.188 --> 00:08:01.306
Route redistribution is hard, right.

156
00:08:01.306 --> 00:08:04.187
It's a difficult thing to configure and
there's a lot of different options and

157
00:08:04.187 --> 00:08:05.700
stuff that can go wrong.

158
00:08:05.700 --> 00:08:07.510
But is that my problem?

159
00:08:07.510 --> 00:08:09.970
Well, I never did look at
the routing tables down here.

160
00:08:09.970 --> 00:08:12.585
But, let me see if I can ping.

161
00:08:12.585 --> 00:08:14.410
Cuz if this guy can ping out.

162
00:08:14.410 --> 00:08:16.350
Then maybe it is a redistribution problem.

163
00:08:16.350 --> 00:08:19.731
But if this guy can't ping out, that's
before the redistribution even occurs,

164
00:08:19.731 --> 00:08:22.867
I might be able to skip past all the

610
00:31:43.960 --> 00:31:46.750
It turned out to probably be
the most complex of the issues for

611
00:31:46.750 --> 00:31:48.860
set one but
it was kind of a fun one right?

612
00:31:48.860 --> 00:31:53.120
A lot of different problems could have
crept up in there and we troubleshot it,

613
00:31:53.120 --> 00:31:54.640
we found it, and we got it resolved.

614
00:31:54.640 --> 00:31:58.182
So in this case, redistributing
between the two routing protocols.

615
00:31:58.182 --> 00:32:00.150
All right, well, ladies and gentleman,
I hope you guys enjoyed that.

616
00:32:00.150 --> 00:32:01.560
That's it for set one.

617
00:32:01.560 --> 00:32:02.880
We resolved all the issues.

618
00:32:02.880 --> 00:32:07.617
Stay tuned cause set two coming up, and
more Cisco troubleshooting down the road.

619
00:32:07.617 --> 00:32:13.830
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #1` from set #2. The trouble ticket states that "PLABCSCO01 is unable to ping 192.168.16.3 "
episodes.title: Set 2 Issue 1
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:05.519
[SOUND] In this video,
we're gonna start with

2
00:00:05.519 --> 00:00:10.735
Set 2 of our troubleshooting scenarios.

3
00:00:10.735 --> 00:00:13.004
We've got an all new
network in front of us and

4
00:00:13.004 --> 00:00:15.570
an all new set of problems to try and
sort out.

5
00:00:15.570 --> 00:00:19.890
And so we're gonna jump right in with
troubleshooting ticket issue number one.

6
00:00:19.890 --> 00:00:21.870
And we got a straightforward
one on this one,

7
00:00:21.870 --> 00:00:23.210
I'm looking at my support
ticket right here.

8
00:00:23.210 --> 00:00:27.125
It says,
we've got a server called PLab Cisco 01,

9
00:00:27.125 --> 00:00:30.877
it's unable to ping 192.168.16.3.

10
00:00:30.877 --> 00:00:32.690
So, sounds simple enough.

11
00:00:32.690 --> 00:00:35.548
I've got a server that,
it's on my network,

12
00:00:35.548 --> 00:00:38.934
it's got an IP,
I don't actually know what its IP is.

13
00:00:38.934 --> 00:00:40.500
And it's trying to ping another host and
it can't get there.

14
00:00:40.500 --> 00:00:44.040
So a whole plethora of problems
[LAUGH] that could cause that.

15
00:00:44.040 --> 00:00:46.020
Let's start by looking at
our network topology and

16
00:00:46.020 --> 00:00:48.760
see if we can't get an idea of
where that problem is coming from.

17
00:00:48.760 --> 00:00:51.260
So, I've got our network
topology pulled up here and

18
00:00:51.260 --> 00:00:54.720
let me just zoom in a bit on it
cuz it's a big network, right.

19
00:00:54.720 --> 00:00:56.950
So here's all the different systems
that we're gonna be working with

20
00:00:56.950 --> 00:00:57.500
this time around.

21
00:00:57.500 --> 00:00:59.550
We've got routers,
switches all sorts of stuff.

22
00:00:59.550 --> 00:01:03.990
And way down here at the bottom
we've got our lonely little server.

23
00:01:03.990 --> 00:01:07.128
And this is PLab Cisco 01, and

24
00:01:07.128 --> 00:01:14.233
this guy is 192.168.16.10,
that's its IP right there.

25
00:01:14.233 --> 00:01:21.307
So it's 192.168.16.10, I can see
it's a /24, so a 24-bit subnet mask.

26
00:01:21.307 --> 00:01:24.403
That means if I can't ping 192.168.16.3,

27
00:01:24.403 --> 00:01:27.700
I'm likely dealing with a layer one or
layer two issue here.

28
00:01:27.700 --> 00:01:29.220
Now, how do I know that?

29
00:01:29.220 --> 00:01:33.490
Well, layer three would be routing, and
we only route when we go between subnets.

30
00:01:33.490 --> 00:01:35.810
I'm trying to ping somebody
who's on the same subnet as me.

31
00:01:35.810 --> 00:01:38.470
Now, there's a chance there
still could be a router issue.

32
00:01:38.470 --> 00:01:42.700
For example, the other node could have
its subnet mask set wrong, and it could

33
00:01:42.700 --> 00:01:45.590
think that it's on a different network and
be trying to go through a router.

34
00:01:45.590 --> 00:01:47.860
Versus this guy trying to go direct,
that is possible.

35
00:01:47.860 --> 00:01:50.110
So I'll need to double check
my IP configurations but

36
00:01:50.110 --> 00:01:53.410
assuming those are right, then I can
put layer three out of my mind and

37
00:01:53.410 --> 00:01:55.100
focus on layer one and layer two.

38
00:01:55.100 --> 00:01:58.470
This'll more than likely turn out
to be a switching issue, all right?

39
00:01:58.470 --> 00:02:01.000
So I'm gonna verify that subnet mask.

40
00:02:01.000 --> 00:02:03.620
That's probably the first thing I need
to do is verify that subnet mask on this

41
00:02:03.620 --> 00:02:09.820
machine and on 192.168.16.3
since that's who I can't ping.

42
00:02:09.820 --> 00:02:16.436
Unfortunately, as I look at my map here,
I don't see 192.168.16.3, so I'm gonna

43
00:02:16.436 --> 00:02:21.293
have to do a little bit of exploring,
I'm gonna have to find this node.

44
00:02:21.293 --> 00:02:24.540
And that's gonna be particularly tricky
because, think about my problem.

45
00:02:24.540 --> 00:02:25.960
I can't ping the host.

46
00:02:25.960 --> 00:02:28.740
If I could ping the host I
could look at my ARP table and

47
00:02:28.740 --> 00:02:29.830
figure out the MAC address.

48
00:02:29.830 --> 00:02:31.980
I could then look at the MAC
address table of switches and

49
00:02:31.980 --> 00:02:33.720
figure out where it's plugged in.

50
00:02:33.720 --> 00:02:36.440
And from there, once I know where
it's plugged in I know who it is.

51
00:02:36.440 --> 00:02:40.800
But if I can't ping it, I'm gonna have
a hard time finding it on the network.

52
00:02:40.800 --> 00:02:44.643
So sometimes there's no substitute for
just jumping host to host and looking for

53
00:02:44.643 --> 00:02:48.160
who has that IP and, unfortunately,
that's what I'm gonna have to do.

54
00:02:48.160 --> 00:02:51.600
Now, because the problem is
located right here on this server,

55
00:02:51.600 --> 00:02:53.460
I'm gonna go from the inside out.

56
00:02:53.460 --> 00:02:56.180
So I'm gonna start here, I'll jump to this
switch, then I'll jump up to these two

57
00:02:56.180 --> 00:02:58.720
switches, and
then I'll jump up to all these routers.

58
00:02:58.720 --> 00:03:01.860
One of them will have the IP I want,
but I'm going inside out,

59
00:03:01.860 --> 00:03:04.920
because that's usually the way you
most quickly find the problem.

60
00:03:04.920 --> 00:03:06.870
The further I get away from this host,

61
00:03:06.870 --> 00:03:09.200
the more likely I am to be
jumping to a different subnet.

62
00:03:09.200 --> 00:03:11.650
So that's why I want to start there and
kind of move out.

63
00:03:11.650 --> 00:03:13.510
So I'm gonna start on that server.

64
00:03:13.510 --> 00:03:16.310
So I'll jump back, and it's a Windows
Server, I've got it pulled up right here.

65
00:03:16.310 --> 00:03:18.810
Let me get into a command prompt.

66
00:03:20.320 --> 00:03:25.810
And, I'm just gonna start
with a quick ip config,

67
00:03:25.810 --> 00:03:29.350
to make sure that this is
192.168.16.10 like the diagram said.

68
00:03:29.350 --> 00:03:30.300
And it is.

69
00:03:30.300 --> 00:03:35.240
And I'm gonna make sure that subnet
mask is set to 255.255.255.0,

70
00:03:35.240 --> 00:03:41.040
which it is also, so I know that it is
configured according to the documentation.

71
00:03:41.040 --> 00:03:45.520
So somewhere on the network,
there's 192.168.16.3 and

72
00:03:45.520 --> 00:03:48.040
it could be configured wrong,
but at least this guy is right.

73
00:03:48.040 --> 00:03:50.790
And while I'm here,
it's probably a good idea for

74
00:03:50.790 --> 00:03:53.310
me to verify that
the problem actually exists.

75
00:03:53.310 --> 00:03:55.973
You every get a troubleshooting ticket
from a user, and then you go and

76
00:03:55.973 --> 00:03:58.017
you verify it and
the problem's not actually there?

77
00:03:58.017 --> 00:03:59.015
That does happen.

78
00:03:59.015 --> 00:04:03.330
So I'm gonna try and ping 192.168.16.3.

79
00:04:03.330 --> 00:04:06.645
And in fact, I'm gonna leave it as
just a constantly running ping, so

80
00:04:06.645 --> 00:04:09.845
it'll just be pinging in the background so
that I'll know when I've fixed my problem.

81
00:04:09.845 --> 00:04:14.240
Right, and sure enough, it's not looking
good, I'm not pinging out to that host.

82
00:04:14.240 --> 00:04:16.460
The first ping might have failed
because of ARP, I'll wait for

83
00:04:16.460 --> 00:04:17.530
a second, there we go.

84
00:04:17.530 --> 00:04:21.932
And now I see two pings failed,
it's pretty much verified there,

85
00:04:21.932 --> 00:04:23.590
we know we got a problem.

86
00:04:23.590 --> 00:04:26.482
So, going back to my network topology,

87
00:04:26.482 --> 00:04:30.550
the next hop in the path is
New York Access 1, right.

88
00:04:30.550 --> 00:04:35.022
So my server plugs into that switch,
let's take a look at that switch and see.

89
00:04:35.022 --> 00:04:38.084
Maybe this'll be real easy and
that will be 192.168.16.3 and

90
00:04:38.084 --> 00:04:40.282
we'll get an idea where that problem is,
all right.

91
00:04:40.282 --> 00:04:47.130
So I'm gonna jump over to that switch, and
I wanna find out what IP address it has.

92
00:04:47.130 --> 00:04:49.640
Now, one of the best commands for this,

93
00:04:49.640 --> 00:04:54.330
one that I use all the time,
is show ip int brief.

94
00:04:54.330 --> 00:04:57.290
Now, on a switch that returns
a lot of information, and so

95
00:04:57.290 --> 00:05:00.710
I'll normally apply
an exclude filter to that.

96
00:05:00.710 --> 00:05:03.950
And I'll exclude the word unassigned,
okay?

97
00:05:03.950 --> 00:05:05.360
So why am I excluding that?

98
00:05:05.360 --> 00:05:09.224
Because these are interfaces that
don't have an IP address, and

99
00:05:09.224 --> 00:05:12.957
I can filter those out and
only see interfaces that do have IPs.

100
00:05:12.957 --> 00:05:20.280
And I can see that I've got Vlan16, and
I've got an IP in there of 192.168.16.7.

101
00:05:20.280 --> 00:05:24.650
I'm on the same network, but
I'm not .3 so I haven't found our target.

102
00:05:24.650 --> 00:05:27.940
Now, just as a word of caution,
sometimes Cisco can be a little sneaky.

103
00:05:27.940 --> 00:05:32.050
Sometimes there's IP addresses that
don't show up here in show ip int brief.

104
00:05:32.050 --> 00:05:35.002
For example, if I had a secondary IP.

105
00:05:35.002 --> 00:05:37.004
Secondary IPs don't show up here,

106
00:05:37.004 --> 00:05:40.200
I would need to look at
the interface itself to see that.

107
00:05:40.200 --> 00:05:43.925
So another useful command is you can so
show running-config.

108
00:05:45.150 --> 00:05:48.150
And if you filter that with
an include filter and look for

109
00:05:48.150 --> 00:05:52.300
the key words interface and address,

110
00:05:52.300 --> 00:05:56.690
that'll show you each of the interface
names followed by primary and

111
00:05:56.690 --> 00:05:59.890
secondary addresses as well as IPv6
addresses assigned to each one.

112
00:05:59.890 --> 00:06:01.850
It's a great way to
quickly find all those.

113
00:06:01.850 --> 00:06:04.800
And so I can run that same command there.

114
00:06:04.800 --> 00:06:08.690
And there's all my other interfaces and
then here's the Vlan interface and so

115
00:06:08.690 --> 00:06:10.990
it is the only IP I have, is that one.

116
00:06:10.990 --> 00:06:14.330
And, just for connectivities sake,
I'll try and ping that server.

117
00:06:14.330 --> 00:06:16.730
So I'm gonna try and
ping 192.168.16.10 and I can,

118
00:06:16.730 --> 00:06:20.004
so I'm able to ping PLab Cisco 01.

119
00:06:20.004 --> 00:06:24.630
And I'll try and ping .3, and
it's got the same problem.

120
00:06:24.630 --> 00:06:27.020
So it's got the same problem
as my workstation or server or

121
00:06:27.020 --> 00:06:28.970
whatever, I'm not able
to get to that host.

122
00:06:28.970 --> 00:06:31.680
So now I know a little bit more
of the scope of my problem.

123
00:06:31.680 --> 00:06:33.792
If I go back to my diagram,

124
00:06:33.792 --> 00:06:38.982
the server can't ping whoever .3 is,
neither can ACCESS1.

125
00:06:38.982 --> 00:06:42.121
So I could kinda put the server out of
my mind then start troubleshooting from

126
00:06:42.121 --> 00:06:42.720
this switch.

127
00:06:42.720 --> 00:06:45.270
Why can't this switch get to that IP?

128
00:06:45.270 --> 00:06:46.800
Now I need to move on
to my next switches and

129
00:06:46.800 --> 00:06:51.520
see if I can't find this IP address,
maybe it'll be on one of these two.

130
00:06:51.520 --> 00:06:54.120
So I'll look at CORE1 and CORE2,
I'll go ahead and start with CORE1.

131
00:06:55.360 --> 00:06:59.510
So I'll jump over to that guy, and
we'll kind of rinse and repeat,

132
00:06:59.510 --> 00:07:00.870
running through that same process.

133
00:07:00.870 --> 00:07:03.140
So on this one, let me just get logged in.

134
00:07:05.580 --> 00:07:07.930
And then I'll do a show ip int brief.

135
00:07:10.380 --> 00:07:13.799
And I can see it's got 192.168.16.2,
and then it,

136
00:07:13.799 --> 00:07:16.550
well, it's down, down,
that's not a good sign.

137
00:07:16.550 --> 00:07:21.016
But it doesn't matter cuz it's the wrong
IP anyway, it's 192.168.16.2, so

138
00:07:21.016 --> 00:07:21.827
that was close.

139
00:07:21.827 --> 00:07:25.846
And just to make sure there's
not a secondary in there,

140
00:07:25.846 --> 00:07:28.677
maybe I'll do a show run int vlan16.

141
00:07:28.677 --> 00:07:30.240
And, well this is a neat one.

142
00:07:30.240 --> 00:07:34.390
I don't have a secondary IP,
but I do have a standby IP.

143
00:07:34.390 --> 00:07:35.770
Now what does mean?

144
00:07:35.770 --> 00:07:38.490
HSRP, right,
the hot standby routing protocol.

145
00:07:38.490 --> 00:07:45.643
So I've got a primary or
an active router and I've got a standby.

146
00:07:45.643 --> 00:07:50.194
This one's 192.168.16.2, and
it's got a standby of 192.168.16.1.

147
00:07:50.194 --> 00:07:52.095
So there's some virtual
IPs on the network now.

148
00:07:52.095 --> 00:07:55.311
But I'm gonna put that out of my
mind cuz I don't care about those,

149
00:07:55.311 --> 00:07:57.624
I care about .3 and
neither of these are .3.

150
00:07:57.624 --> 00:07:58.701
So that's not my problem for today.

151
00:07:58.701 --> 00:08:00.448
We'll keep moving on, right?

152
00:08:00.448 --> 00:08:05.350
So as we keep moving on,
the next switch in line is CORE2.

153
00:08:05.350 --> 00:08:08.630
So I'll jump over to this guy, and
let's see what we can find here.

154
00:08:08.630 --> 00:08:13.280
So on this one,
I'll do a show running-config, and

155
00:08:13.280 --> 00:08:17.730
I'll do the include like I mentioned
earlier, looking for interface and

156
00:08:17.730 --> 00:08:21.140
looking for address, all right.

157
00:08:21.140 --> 00:08:23.350
And as I run that,
I start to get my interfaces back,

158
00:08:23.350 --> 00:08:25.000
nothing too exciting there.

159
00:08:25.000 --> 00:08:28.242
And then here's my VLAN interfaces in,
there we go.

160
00:08:28.242 --> 00:08:34.183
Interface Vlan16 has an IP address of
192.168.16.3, I just found our target.

161
00:08:34.183 --> 00:08:39.780
All right, now this is CORE2,
so if I go back to my diagram.

162
00:08:39.780 --> 00:08:44.109
My Cisco server here
can Ping to ACCESS1 and

163
00:08:44.109 --> 00:08:49.030
then it should go from
ACCESS1 up to CORE2.

164
00:08:49.030 --> 00:08:50.540
So we've got a direct link right here.

165
00:08:50.540 --> 00:08:55.622
Port 23 on ACCESS1, port 22 on CORE2,
that's connecting those two together.

166
00:08:55.622 --> 00:08:57.700
I should just be able to jump
right across that link and

167
00:08:57.700 --> 00:08:59.740
get to the destination, right.

168
00:08:59.740 --> 00:09:03.070
But that's apparently not working,
now why isn't it working?

169
00:09:03.070 --> 00:09:04.508
I don't know, let's find out, right?

170
00:09:04.508 --> 00:09:08.540
So on CORE2,
I found my IP that was in question, right,

171
00:09:08.540 --> 00:09:11.610
so it was right back
here on interface Vlan16.

172
00:09:12.960 --> 00:09:17.780
And if I do a quick show run for
interface Vlan16, I can look at its

173
00:09:17.780 --> 00:09:23.290
configuration and I can see that it's
192.168.16.3 and the subnet mask is right.

174
00:09:23.290 --> 00:09:26.000
Remember at the beginning I said one
possible problem here is the subnet mask

175
00:09:26.000 --> 00:09:28.220
could be wrong and
we could be trying to go through a router.

176
00:09:28.220 --> 00:09:29.980
That's not happening here, it is correct.

177
00:09:29.980 --> 00:09:35.541
All right, it does have a standby IP which
means it's part of the HSRP cluster,

178
00:09:35.541 --> 00:09:38.448
but let's think about that for a moment.

179
00:09:38.448 --> 00:09:41.430
The standby IP is 192.168.16.1.

180
00:09:41.430 --> 00:09:47.740
The active HSRP router will answer
to that, the standby won't.

181
00:09:47.740 --> 00:09:50.410
So if this guy is the standby,
it might not answer to that.

182
00:09:50.410 --> 00:09:51.960
But what about my unique IP?

183
00:09:52.980 --> 00:09:55.260
It doesn't matter if you're active or

184
00:09:55.260 --> 00:09:58.820
standby, you always
answer to your unique IP.

185
00:09:58.820 --> 00:10:02.890
So, we should be answering to this
regardless of the status of HSRP.

186
00:10:02.890 --> 00:10:07.340
HSRP in this case is just a distraction,
so we'll put that out of our mind.

187
00:10:07.340 --> 00:10:10.430
We need to find out why we're not
responding on this IP, right?

188
00:10:10.430 --> 00:10:13.100
Well, what's the status of this interface?

189
00:10:13.100 --> 00:10:18.830
If I do a show interface vlan16 and
look at its status, right?

190
00:10:18.830 --> 00:10:20.770
That's gonna roll out here.

191
00:10:20.770 --> 00:10:23.600
And well, this might be a problem.

192
00:10:23.600 --> 00:10:25.840
Vlan16 is down, line protocol is down.

193
00:10:25.840 --> 00:10:28.500
If the interface is down,
I'm not gonna respond to the IP.

194
00:10:28.500 --> 00:10:32.408
But where this is confusing is,
this is a virtual interface, Vlan16.

195
00:10:32.408 --> 00:10:37.120
I'm not talking about a physical interface
where you unplug a cable and it goes down.

196
00:10:37.120 --> 00:10:38.690
This is a virtual interface.

197
00:10:38.690 --> 00:10:40.892
So, what could cause
the interface to go down?

198
00:10:40.892 --> 00:10:43.641
I could only think of two things, right.

199
00:10:43.641 --> 00:10:46.560
I'm sure there's more, but
in my mind, I can only think of two.

200
00:10:46.560 --> 00:10:48.250
One is somebody did a shutdown command.

201
00:10:48.250 --> 00:10:49.840
All right, you can manually shut it down.

202
00:10:49.840 --> 00:10:52.760
But if that was the case,
it wouldn't say down here, it would say

203
00:10:52.760 --> 00:10:57.040
administratively down, and I looked at its
configuration just a moment ago, right?

204
00:10:57.040 --> 00:11:00.600
If we were to scroll back on this,
right here,

205
00:11:00.600 --> 00:11:04.660
I don't see a shut down command, so
it's not been administratively shut down.

206
00:11:04.660 --> 00:11:08.340
So what's the other scenario where
our VLAN interface can go down?

207
00:11:08.340 --> 00:11:10.940
Well in order for
a VLAN interface to be up,

208
00:11:10.940 --> 00:11:15.170
you have to have at least
one port in that same VLAN.

209
00:11:16.280 --> 00:11:18.540
And if I don't have
a single port in vlan16,

210
00:11:18.540 --> 00:11:23.360
then the VLAN interface is gonna go down,
that's the most likely.

211
00:11:23.360 --> 00:11:24.854
Now it doesn't normally happen, and

212
00:11:24.854 --> 00:11:26.960
that's because we normally
have at least one trunk.

213
00:11:26.960 --> 00:11:29.398
And if you have a trunk,
it carries all your VLANs, and

214
00:11:29.398 --> 00:11:32.578
that means you got at least one port
in every VLAN, the ports stay up, so

215
00:11:32.578 --> 00:11:35.360
it's pretty rare to see
an interface like this be down.

216
00:11:35.360 --> 00:11:38.662
So I've got an issue,
let's see if we can figure out what it is.

217
00:11:38.662 --> 00:11:40.680
All right, so now that I know that,

218
00:11:42.030 --> 00:11:45.450
let's take a look at my VLAN configuration
to see if they can teach us anything.

219
00:11:45.450 --> 00:11:47.080
So if I do a show vlan,

220
00:11:47.080 --> 00:11:51.998
what I'm expecting to see here
is at least one port in vlan16.

221
00:11:51.998 --> 00:11:53.710
Now I see a bigger problem.

222
00:11:53.710 --> 00:11:57.894
I see VLAN 1, I see VLAN 12,
I don't even see VLAN 16.

223
00:11:57.894 --> 00:12:01.180
So it's not even in my list.

224
00:12:01.180 --> 00:12:02.949
My switch here doesn't
even know about VLAN 16.

225
00:12:02.949 --> 00:12:08.125
But I've got a virtual interface,
so it should exist, right?

226
00:12:08.125 --> 00:12:10.180
But it isn't, so I've got a problem here.

227
00:12:10.180 --> 00:12:12.079
So I might need to go in and
manually create VLAN 16.

228
00:12:12.079 --> 00:12:15.320
But I'm gonna hold off on that for a
second, just to verify a few other things.

229
00:12:15.320 --> 00:12:18.600
Because if I have a trunk,
I should be getting it from there, right?

230
00:12:18.600 --> 00:12:21.820
That should be working,
apparently it isn't, right.

231
00:12:21.820 --> 00:12:24.380
So let's check out our trunk status.

232
00:12:24.380 --> 00:12:30.977
Well if I do a show interface trunk, we
can get an idea of what's going on there.

233
00:12:30.977 --> 00:12:33.699
Now when I look at my trunks,
if I go back to my diagram,

234
00:12:33.699 --> 00:12:36.120
I'm concerned about this one right here.

235
00:12:36.120 --> 00:12:41.710
It's port 22 on NYCORE2 and
it's port 23 on ACCESS1.

236
00:12:41.710 --> 00:12:45.800
So I'm gonna look at port 22 here and
see what it's got, right?

237
00:12:45.800 --> 00:12:52.520
And when I look at that back here, I can
see that port 22 has trunking turned on.

238
00:12:52.520 --> 00:12:56.050
It's set for ISL, which is a little
weird but not out of the question.

239
00:12:56.050 --> 00:12:57.682
ISL is Inter-Switch Link, right,

240
00:12:57.682 --> 00:13:00.810
that's Cisco's proprietary
trunking encapsulation.

241
00:13:00.810 --> 00:13:04.554
And it's got a native VLAN, which you
don't actually have native VLANs in ISL.

242
00:13:04.554 --> 00:13:08.241
And then we've got port 24
which we don't care about, or

243
00:13:08.241 --> 00:13:10.907
at least, we don't care about right now.

244
00:13:10.907 --> 00:13:14.003
[LAUGH] And then we've got port 22 down
here showing that it's allowing VLANs 1

245
00:13:14.003 --> 00:13:14.890
through 4,094.

246
00:13:14.890 --> 00:13:18.740
So if VLAN 16 exists,
it should cross this line.

247
00:13:18.740 --> 00:13:23.160
But then down here I can see,
Fa1/0/22, VLANs allowed and

248
00:13:23.160 --> 00:13:28.250
active in the management domain,
just 1 and 12, okay?

249
00:13:28.250 --> 00:13:33.380
So, while VLAN 16 is allowed,
it's not allowed and

250
00:13:33.380 --> 00:13:37.260
active, and it's not active because
it's not in our VLAN database.

251
00:13:37.260 --> 00:13:41.490
So if we want to fix that, well,
we'll need to create the VLAN, all right?

252
00:13:41.490 --> 00:13:43.260
And creating a VLAN is
pretty straightforward.

253
00:13:43.260 --> 00:13:46.929
You just go in your configuration,
and you say vlan 16, right?

254
00:13:46.929 --> 00:13:49.630
So that's gonna create that.

255
00:13:51.290 --> 00:13:56.050
And now when I do a show vlan and
I look at my VLAN database,

256
00:13:56.050 --> 00:14:01.080
I can see that I've got VLAN 16 right
there, right, so I now know about VLAN 16.

257
00:14:01.080 --> 00:14:06.100
And if I do a show interface trunk,
I can look at my trunk

258
00:14:06.100 --> 00:14:10.918
configuration and
port 22 is now carrying VLAN 16, right.

259
00:14:10.918 --> 00:14:15.403
And if I wait a moment, it hasn't happened
yet which is also a little odd, but

260
00:14:15.403 --> 00:14:20.168
the VLAN interface should come up because
now I have at least one port on that VLAN.

261
00:14:20.168 --> 00:14:23.862
So if I do a show interface vlan16,

262
00:14:23.862 --> 00:14:27.920
what I expect to see is it should come up.

263
00:14:27.920 --> 00:14:30.714
And in fact,
I see that vlan16 is now up, up.

264
00:14:30.714 --> 00:14:33.770
So looks like I've solved my problem,
right.

265
00:14:33.770 --> 00:14:35.220
The interface is up.

266
00:14:35.220 --> 00:14:37.170
Now here's where things get really tough.

267
00:14:37.170 --> 00:14:39.210
On the exam, you don't have a lot of time.

268
00:14:39.210 --> 00:14:41.890
So you'll be tempted, hey I got
the interface up, it's good to go,

269
00:14:41.890 --> 00:14:43.710
let's jump pass it, all right.

270
00:14:43.710 --> 00:14:46.150
But you always need to verify your work,
right.

271
00:14:46.150 --> 00:14:49.220
Remember, I left that work station doing
Pings in the background so I can go and

272
00:14:49.220 --> 00:14:51.360
test it to see if whether or
not this is working.

273
00:14:51.360 --> 00:14:53.560
Did that solve my problem?

274
00:14:53.560 --> 00:14:59.640
And so I'll jump back to PLABCSCO01 and
things aren't looking good here, right?

275
00:14:59.640 --> 00:15:01.200
It's still failing, so

276
00:15:01.200 --> 00:15:04.790
I'm glad that I came here to verify
it because did I fix a problem?

277
00:15:04.790 --> 00:15:08.908
Yeah, I fixed a problem on my network,
but it's not the only thing,

278
00:15:08.908 --> 00:15:13.610
I got that VLAN interface to go up but
something else is stopping me.

279
00:15:13.610 --> 00:15:15.460
So, let's find out what, all right?

280
00:15:15.460 --> 00:15:17.420
Now, when I look at my topology,

281
00:15:18.540 --> 00:15:22.720
I can see that that interface was up,
the trunk appeared to be healthy.

282
00:15:22.720 --> 00:15:26.180
Well, actually, I verified one end of it.

283
00:15:26.180 --> 00:15:30.540
Trunks are really bad about telling you
they're up and healthy when they aren't.

284
00:15:30.540 --> 00:15:33.450
And the reason is that trunks only
check their side of the configuration.

285
00:15:33.450 --> 00:15:35.880
So there can be a problem on the other
side and we wouldn't know it.

286
00:15:35.880 --> 00:15:38.800
And I only verified one side,
I verified CORE2.

287
00:15:38.800 --> 00:15:40.745
CORE2 looked fine.

288
00:15:40.745 --> 00:15:42.760
ACCESS1, I haven't
really looked at at all.

289
00:15:42.760 --> 00:15:46.580
So let's take a look at the two ends of
this trunk and verify that configuration.

290
00:15:46.580 --> 00:15:53.400
So on CORE2, if I get back to it,
so I'll just jump over to CORE2.

291
00:15:53.400 --> 00:15:57.851
We pulled up its configuration way
back here, well at this point,

292
00:15:57.851 --> 00:16:00.404
it would be faster to pull it up again.

293
00:16:00.404 --> 00:16:01.847
All right well, we'll pull it up again.

294
00:16:01.847 --> 00:16:05.437
[LAUGH] So
if we take a look at it's configurations.

295
00:16:05.437 --> 00:16:07.590
So I'm just going to do
a show run interface.

296
00:16:07.590 --> 00:16:10.109
Fa1/0/22.

297
00:16:10.109 --> 00:16:13.388
All right, and when I look at it
I can see switchport trunk and

298
00:16:13.388 --> 00:16:17.390
encapsulation ISL, switchport mode trunk,
spanning tree guard root.

299
00:16:17.390 --> 00:16:19.240
So it's got some root guard turned on it.

300
00:16:19.240 --> 00:16:21.759
I don't think that's going to be
a problem for him but we'll see.

301
00:16:21.759 --> 00:16:23.791
There could be some root
election stuff going on.

302
00:16:23.791 --> 00:16:27.347
But it's set up,
I'm not blocking VLAN16, and

303
00:16:27.347 --> 00:16:32.060
I knew that because I saw it in
show interface trunk that VLAN's 1,

304
00:16:32.060 --> 00:16:35.550
12 and
16 were all being carried on port 22.

305
00:16:35.550 --> 00:16:37.220
So things look good here.

306
00:16:37.220 --> 00:16:40.110
I don't see any glaring problems, right?

307
00:16:40.110 --> 00:16:45.330
If I jump over to access one I can kind
of repeat that same process right so

308
00:16:45.330 --> 00:16:47.530
over here on access one I'm
gonna do that same thing.

309
00:16:49.360 --> 00:16:53.065
And see if this one's good or
having problems too.

310
00:16:53.065 --> 00:16:57.514
So on this side,
if I go back to my diagram it's port 23.

311
00:16:57.514 --> 00:17:02.022
And so if I do a show run for
fa0/23 I can see

312
00:17:02.022 --> 00:17:06.786
it's got switchport trunk allowed vlan 16.

313
00:17:06.786 --> 00:17:11.371
That means that I'm set up to be a trunk
right, switchport mode trunk and

314
00:17:11.371 --> 00:17:13.337
I'm only allowing vlan 16.

315
00:17:13.337 --> 00:17:15.270
Now is that a problem?

316
00:17:15.270 --> 00:17:19.530
Well, it could be if I was using any other
vlan but vlan 16 is what I care about.

317
00:17:19.530 --> 00:17:21.800
And so
the fact that it only carries vlan 16.

318
00:17:21.800 --> 00:17:22.960
I'm okay with that.

319
00:17:22.960 --> 00:17:26.210
The other side of sending vlan 1 and
vlan 12, we're just throwing it away.

320
00:17:26.210 --> 00:17:27.200
We're just ignoring those right.

321
00:17:27.200 --> 00:17:29.320
We're only doing vlan 16.

322
00:17:29.320 --> 00:17:29.960
And I'm fine with that.

323
00:17:31.260 --> 00:17:31.990
So that looks good.

324
00:17:31.990 --> 00:17:36.390
If I do a show interface trunk, here's
where I can verify that it is actually

325
00:17:36.390 --> 00:17:41.618
trunking and I can see on port 23 my
trunking is on, and here is our problem.

326
00:17:41.618 --> 00:17:44.695
Encapsulation 802.1q.

327
00:17:44.695 --> 00:17:46.330
So that doesn't match.

328
00:17:46.330 --> 00:17:50.246
The other end was ISL, this end is A02.1q
but it seems to think that it's happy.

329
00:17:50.246 --> 00:17:54.862
Hey, I'm doing vlan16,
we've got it carried on port 23, it's up,

330
00:17:54.862 --> 00:17:56.549
it's allowed and active,

331
00:17:56.549 --> 00:18:01.784
it doesn't realize the other side isn't
understanding what we're sending to it.

332
00:18:01.784 --> 00:18:05.630
So I need to switch to
a matching protocol.

333
00:18:05.630 --> 00:18:08.310
So on access one I had a choice, right?

334
00:18:08.310 --> 00:18:12.792
I could change the other side to be dot1Q
or I could change this side to ISL.

335
00:18:12.792 --> 00:18:15.470
So let's say I want to change
this side to be ISL, right?

336
00:18:15.470 --> 00:18:22.846
I can get into interface fa0/23 and
I can say switchport.

337
00:18:22.846 --> 00:18:27.478
Trunk, encapsulation dot1q, right?

338
00:18:27.478 --> 00:18:29.591
And so I'm gonna set that.

339
00:18:29.591 --> 00:18:30.932
This is a tricky one.

340
00:18:30.932 --> 00:18:33.760
All right, so I tried to set the
encapsulation, and I got an error, right?

341
00:18:33.760 --> 00:18:36.830
It says switchboard trunk, and
then encapsulation gave me an error.

342
00:18:36.830 --> 00:18:40.960
And so if I do a switchboard trunk
question mark, what's going on there?

343
00:18:40.960 --> 00:18:42.460
I don't have an encapsulation command.

344
00:18:43.540 --> 00:18:44.285
Why is that?

345
00:18:44.285 --> 00:18:49.264
Well this switch,
if I do a show version, the switch,

346
00:18:49.264 --> 00:18:53.832
there it is, is a 2960, the Cisco 2960.

347
00:18:53.832 --> 00:18:58.910
The Cisco 2960 is a mid-range switch and
it doesn't support ISL.

348
00:18:58.910 --> 00:19:03.720
It only supports 802.1Q and that's why I
didn't see anything in the configuration.

349
00:19:03.720 --> 00:19:07.190
And here I can't set it to ISL, so
the decisions actually been made for me.

350
00:19:07.190 --> 00:19:10.273
I can't set this one to ISL that means I
have to change the other side to .1Q or

351
00:19:10.273 --> 00:19:11.709
this isn't going to work, right.

352
00:19:11.709 --> 00:19:16.582
So if I jump over to New York core two,

353
00:19:16.582 --> 00:19:21.614
this guy, I can go into this switch and

354
00:19:21.614 --> 00:19:26.658
get into interface FA 1/0/22.

355
00:19:26.658 --> 00:19:31.589
And I can say switchport
trunk encapsulation, and

356
00:19:31.589 --> 00:19:38.481
from here I can tell it that I wanna
do dot1q or ISL and I wanna do dot1q.

357
00:19:38.481 --> 00:19:39.070
All right.

358
00:19:39.070 --> 00:19:43.840
Now I should be talking the same language
as the other side of this trunk.

359
00:19:43.840 --> 00:19:49.590
And now vlan 16 traffic should be able
to pass over this link just fine.

360
00:19:49.590 --> 00:19:51.230
All right.

361
00:19:51.230 --> 00:19:52.380
How can we test that?

362
00:19:52.380 --> 00:19:53.960
Well, we can jump back
to our work station.

363
00:19:53.960 --> 00:19:55.990
And I do wanna wait just a moment.

364
00:19:55.990 --> 00:19:58.950
And that's because we've got spanning
tree running, right, loop detection.

365
00:19:58.950 --> 00:20:01.210
And so sometimes when you bring
a new interface up like this,

366
00:20:01.210 --> 00:20:03.350
it can take it a moment
to get through that.

367
00:20:03.350 --> 00:20:06.460
So for example,
if I do a show spanning-tree for vlan 16,

368
00:20:06.460 --> 00:20:09.760
what you might is the ports are still in
listening and learning, and sure enough,

369
00:20:09.760 --> 00:20:11.580
I see I caught this one in learning.

370
00:20:11.580 --> 00:20:14.620
If it's set to the default, which on
the exam it may or may not be, but

371
00:20:14.620 --> 00:20:17.520
if it's set to the defaults
it'll listen for 15 seconds and

372
00:20:17.520 --> 00:20:22.020
learn for 15 seconds so I have to wait 30
seconds before this link comes active.

373
00:20:22.020 --> 00:20:23.660
And so I'm gonna do that.

374
00:20:23.660 --> 00:20:25.510
There we go, now it's active.

375
00:20:25.510 --> 00:20:29.260
And now I'm going to jump
over to my server and

376
00:20:29.260 --> 00:20:30.980
sure enough we fixed our problem.

377
00:20:30.980 --> 00:20:34.510
So right there we got vlan 16 up and
going.

378
00:20:34.510 --> 00:20:39.040
What this problem boiled down to in the
end was actually two little issues, right?

379
00:20:39.040 --> 00:20:43.184
The first issue was that NYCORE2
didn't know about vlan 16,

380
00:20:43.184 --> 00:20:46.440
I had to create vlan 16 on that switch.

381
00:20:46.440 --> 00:20:51.170
The other problem was that
the trunking protocol was mismatched.

382
00:20:51.170 --> 00:20:54.020
We had ISL on one side and
.Q on the other.

383
00:20:54.020 --> 00:20:55.590
Those are completely different protocols.

384
00:20:55.590 --> 00:20:59.802
It could've been that they were set with
auto negotiation wrong, right, it wasn't

385
00:20:59.802 --> 00:21:02.330
auto negotiating, but here we manually
set it, so it didn't really matter.

386
00:21:02.330 --> 00:21:05.800
But once those are set it came up healthy,
and our problem is solved.

387
00:21:05.800 --> 00:21:07.430
So that takes care of this one.

388
00:21:07.430 --> 00:21:10.360
Sounded like a pretty simple one,
one host couldn't ping another host,

389
00:21:10.360 --> 00:21:11.840
turned out to be quite
a bit of digging there.

390
00:21:11.840 --> 00:21:14.650
But you guys get an idea of how
we can isolate those problems and

391
00:21:14.650 --> 00:21:16.570
get them resolved and
then move forward on it.

392
00:21:16.570 --> 00:21:19.666
So that's it for question number one or
issue number one.

393
00:21:19.666 --> 00:21:22.836
Stay tuned cuz we've got the remaining
issues for set two coming up.

394
00:21:22.836 --> 00:21:29.570
[NOISE]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #2` from set #2. The trouble ticket states that "VLANs are not being propagated to NYACCESS1 when you create them on NYCORE1 or NYCORE2. "
episodes.title: Set 2 Issue 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:05.188
[SOUND] In this video, we're gonna

2
00:00:05.188 --> 00:00:10.716
be taking a look at set two issue two.

3
00:00:10.716 --> 00:00:12.734
So we're continuing with
the same network environment,

4
00:00:12.734 --> 00:00:14.390
we got a slightly different
problem this time.

5
00:00:14.390 --> 00:00:18.990
So let me read to you the support ticket
is VLANs are not being propagated to

6
00:00:18.990 --> 00:00:22.890
New York access one, when you create
them on New York core one and

7
00:00:22.890 --> 00:00:23.850
New York core two.

8
00:00:23.850 --> 00:00:27.610
Now it's a short question, just a little
bit of information given us there.

9
00:00:27.610 --> 00:00:29.520
Really just the names of three switches,
and

10
00:00:29.520 --> 00:00:31.350
the fact that VLANs aren't propagating.

11
00:00:31.350 --> 00:00:33.640
And if I take a look at my topology,

12
00:00:33.640 --> 00:00:36.830
we kinda get an idea of where
this problem is occurring.

13
00:00:36.830 --> 00:00:40.040
I've got New York access one,
New York core one and New York core two.

14
00:00:40.040 --> 00:00:42.660
These three, which have or

15
00:00:42.660 --> 00:00:46.050
more than likely have trunks that in
between them to exchange VLAN information.

16
00:00:46.050 --> 00:00:49.070
Now, when they say VLANs
aren't propagating,

17
00:00:49.070 --> 00:00:51.850
they mean if I create a Vlan here.

18
00:00:51.850 --> 00:00:53.240
Access one is not learning about it.

19
00:00:53.240 --> 00:00:56.230
Or if I create a VLAN here access
one is not learning about it.

20
00:00:56.230 --> 00:00:59.950
Now, how can switches learn about VLANs?

21
00:00:59.950 --> 00:01:01.970
Well, VLAN Trunking Protocol,
it's the only way.

22
00:01:01.970 --> 00:01:05.000
There's no other technology on
the Cisco switches where they can learn

23
00:01:05.000 --> 00:01:06.120
about a VLAN.

24
00:01:06.120 --> 00:01:08.460
So this is a VTP problem, right?

25
00:01:08.460 --> 00:01:11.920
I'm gonna have some kind of issue where
VLAN Trunking Protocol's not working.

26
00:01:11.920 --> 00:01:14.760
Well, whenever I hear about a VTP problem,

27
00:01:14.760 --> 00:01:17.070
the first thing I always
think about are the trunks.

28
00:01:17.070 --> 00:01:20.690
A lot of people, it's hard to connect
when you read the Cisco documentation,

29
00:01:20.690 --> 00:01:24.320
but VTP only works over trunks.

30
00:01:24.320 --> 00:01:26.870
So if I have access ports
between these switches,

31
00:01:26.870 --> 00:01:28.760
they're not gonna propagate information.

32
00:01:28.760 --> 00:01:32.140
So I need to have valid trunks
in between these switches for

33
00:01:32.140 --> 00:01:33.960
