I guess if I

258
00:12:49.000 --> 00:12:50.830
don't type it twice, that'll help.

259
00:12:50.830 --> 00:12:54.550
If I do a show VTP password,
I can see that password is set to Cisco.

260
00:12:54.550 --> 00:12:59.020
So let's go take a look at Access1 and
see what it's doing, all right.

261
00:12:59.020 --> 00:13:03.760
So on this one we'll do a show VTP status.

262
00:13:04.800 --> 00:13:07.990
And I can see my version number is 2,
that's good.

263
00:13:07.990 --> 00:13:10.450
My Domain Name is practicelabs,
so that matches.

264
00:13:10.450 --> 00:13:13.300
I'm not doing any pruning,
so I'm okay there.

265
00:13:13.300 --> 00:13:16.930
I'm set to a Server,
my revision number is revision number two,

266
00:13:16.930 --> 00:13:18.710
I didn't pay attention to my
revision number on the other side.

267
00:13:18.710 --> 00:13:19.310
I probably should have.

268
00:13:19.310 --> 00:13:22.500
Let me just jump back and
verify that real quick and

269
00:13:22.500 --> 00:13:24.810
make sure my revision number
isn't something silly here.

270
00:13:24.810 --> 00:13:26.260
Nope, revision number is four.

271
00:13:26.260 --> 00:13:29.470
That's a higher number so access one
should be learning that new one.

272
00:13:29.470 --> 00:13:33.130
And I've got a password, I guess I
don't know what that password is so

273
00:13:33.130 --> 00:13:34.100
we can verify that, right.

274
00:13:34.100 --> 00:13:41.190
So let's see what that password is I do a
show vtp password, and there's a problem.

275
00:13:41.190 --> 00:13:45.200
All right, now, this problem should
have been a lot more obvious to us.

276
00:13:45.200 --> 00:13:48.390
Right here,
I can see VTP Password Cisco111, right?

277
00:13:48.390 --> 00:13:50.990
It doesn't match, the other side
was set to Cisco, this one's Cisco.

278
00:13:50.990 --> 00:13:53.850
All right, now,
I say it should have been more obvious.

279
00:13:53.850 --> 00:13:55.440
And that's because right here,

280
00:13:55.440 --> 00:14:00.070
it shows the MD five digest, no one
knows the MD five digest number, right.

281
00:14:00.070 --> 00:14:04.960
So if it doesn't match you actually
normally get a little status message that

282
00:14:04.960 --> 00:14:08.590
pops up to let, I didn't get that, I don't
know why I didn't get it, I should have,

283
00:14:08.590 --> 00:14:09.630
but it didn't happen.

284
00:14:09.630 --> 00:14:11.570
It doesn't matter now, because I
see the password doesn't match so

285
00:14:11.570 --> 00:14:12.810
I'm gonna get in and fix it.

286
00:14:12.810 --> 00:14:16.570
But in the back of my mind, I'm thinking
I didn't get that status message.

287
00:14:16.570 --> 00:14:19.260
So I probably have another issue.

288
00:14:19.260 --> 00:14:22.450
VTP is probably not communicating or
I would've gotten that message.

289
00:14:22.450 --> 00:14:23.870
Should be there, but it's not.

290
00:14:23.870 --> 00:14:28.960
So I'm gonna go in here, and
I'm just gonna say, VTP password Cisco.

291
00:14:28.960 --> 00:14:32.000
I'm gonna set it to match the other side,
okay.

292
00:14:32.000 --> 00:14:34.140
So now I've got that set,
and as soon as that's done,

293
00:14:34.140 --> 00:14:35.520
I should start learning
from the other side.

294
00:14:35.520 --> 00:14:38.310
Now, before I changed that it looks,
it looks simple right?

295
00:14:38.310 --> 00:14:42.100
I changed the password, but the back of
mind I'm thinking about other things,.

296
00:14:42.100 --> 00:14:47.040
The revision number, if my revision number
was higher than the other switches.

297
00:14:47.040 --> 00:14:51.330
I'm now gonna overwrite those
switches with my VTP configuration.

298
00:14:51.330 --> 00:14:54.920
But their VTP configuration had
a revision number of six or eight, or

299
00:14:54.920 --> 00:14:55.720
something like that.

300
00:14:55.720 --> 00:14:58.170
So they're gonna overwrite me,
and that's okay.

301
00:14:58.170 --> 00:15:01.000
But in real life land, be aware of this.

302
00:15:01.000 --> 00:15:03.800
Be aware that you could be
bringing in a bad switch and

303
00:15:03.800 --> 00:15:06.100
overwriting your VTP database
all across you network.

304
00:15:06.100 --> 00:15:07.080
That'd be really bad.

305
00:15:07.080 --> 00:15:08.910
So you might need to tweak
the revision number.

306
00:15:08.910 --> 00:15:10.440
In this case, I didn't need to do it.

307
00:15:10.440 --> 00:15:11.550
But if you ever need to,

308
00:15:11.550 --> 00:15:16.080
the easiest way is just go into config and
do a VTP mode transparent.

309
00:15:16.080 --> 00:15:17.890
And that'll flip your
revision number back to zero.

310
00:15:17.890 --> 00:15:22.190
And then you can say VTP mode server or
VTP mode client to flip back.

311
00:15:22.190 --> 00:15:23.770
And your revision number will be zero.

312
00:15:23.770 --> 00:15:24.970
The other people will overwrite you.

313
00:15:24.970 --> 00:15:26.750
You always wanna do
that with a new switch.

314
00:15:26.750 --> 00:15:31.110
But in my scenario, my number was already
lower, so I didn't care about it.

315
00:15:31.110 --> 00:15:32.650
All right, so that's already done.

316
00:15:32.650 --> 00:15:37.690
And if I do a show VTP status,
I can look in here and

317
00:15:37.690 --> 00:15:39.140
my revision number went up a little bit.

318
00:15:39.140 --> 00:15:43.650
I'm revision number 4, so
something's going on in the background.

319
00:15:43.650 --> 00:15:48.130
And if I do a show VLAN and
start to look at what I've got here.

320
00:15:48.130 --> 00:15:49.835
I've got VLAN 1, 12, 16 and 999.

321
00:15:49.835 --> 00:15:53.262
VLAN are propagating now
like they're supposed to.

322
00:15:53.262 --> 00:15:58.930
All right, so at the end of the day my
problem boiled down to two problems, okay.

323
00:15:58.930 --> 00:16:02.130
My first problem was
that the native VLAN for

324
00:16:02.130 --> 00:16:03.890
the link was being blocked on the trunk.

325
00:16:03.890 --> 00:16:10.090
And that's a bad idea, because it breaks
somethings like CDP and, VTP in this case.

326
00:16:10.090 --> 00:16:12.650
So those can start to break,
if you block your native VLAN.

327
00:16:12.650 --> 00:16:15.040
I chose not to change my native VLAN,
but just to allow it.

328
00:16:15.040 --> 00:16:16.670
So I added VLAN one to that trunk.

329
00:16:16.670 --> 00:16:19.840
All right, and then my second problem,
passwords didn't match.

330
00:16:19.840 --> 00:16:21.610
My VTP passwords, they just weren't right.

331
00:16:21.610 --> 00:16:23.440
Once I fixed that, now I'm in business.

332
00:16:23.440 --> 00:16:28.020
So two little problems knocked away, now
VLAN are propagating through the network

333
00:16:28.020 --> 00:16:29.400
and it looks like we're in good shape.

334
00:16:29.400 --> 00:16:32.830
So always be aware that a problem
can have more than one cause,

335
00:16:32.830 --> 00:16:35.630
you might have to fix two
things to solve one problem.

336
00:16:35.630 --> 00:16:36.620
And that's how this scenario was.

337
00:16:36.620 --> 00:16:39.080
All right,
well that wraps up this problem.

338
00:16:39.080 --> 00:16:42.975
Stay tuned, we've got more
troubleshooting problems coming up.

339
00:16:42.975 --> 00:16:44.434
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #3` from set #2. The trouble ticket states that "Unable to communicate from PLABCSCO01 to 192.168.11.4 (NYEDGE1) "
episodes.title: Set 2 Issue 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.098
[SOUND] All right,
in this video we're gonna be

2
00:00:05.098 --> 00:00:10.850
continuing on with our
troubleshooting lab set 2,

3
00:00:10.850 --> 00:00:14.519
and moving into issue number 3.

4
00:00:14.519 --> 00:00:17.144
And we've got another communications
error on the network.

5
00:00:17.144 --> 00:00:20.008
It looks like we've got
our PLABCISCO01 server,

6
00:00:20.008 --> 00:00:22.945
that's unable to communicate
with another system.

7
00:00:22.945 --> 00:00:28.939
The way the ticket reads,is it says we're
unable to communicate from PLABCISCO01,

8
00:00:28.939 --> 00:00:33.075
to 192.168.11.4,
which is New York Edge One.

9
00:00:33.075 --> 00:00:35.175
Well, just hearing that
doesn't mean a lot to us.

10
00:00:35.175 --> 00:00:38.630
Let's take a look at the diagram and
get an idea of what that actually means.

11
00:00:38.630 --> 00:00:43.536
So here's my network topology and way down
here at the bottom there's our server,

12
00:00:43.536 --> 00:00:48.513
our PLABCISCO01 and it's communicating
to this guy up here in NYEDGE1, right,

13
00:00:48.513 --> 00:00:53.000
so we're passing across quite a few
devices to get there than any one of those

14
00:00:53.000 --> 00:00:55.131
devices to be causing our problem.

15
00:00:55.131 --> 00:00:57.067
Now before we dive into
the router configuration,

16
00:00:57.067 --> 00:00:58.652
we need to think about a few other things.

17
00:00:58.652 --> 00:01:03.519
If I zoom in on the diagram here,
you can see where that server

18
00:01:03.519 --> 00:01:07.930
is 192.168.16.10/24, all right?

19
00:01:07.930 --> 00:01:14.070
It told me in the problem that I'm
trying to get to 192.168.11.4.

20
00:01:14.070 --> 00:01:16.540
So right off the bat,

21
00:01:16.540 --> 00:01:19.930
I need to be aware that there's some
layer three routing going on, right?

22
00:01:19.930 --> 00:01:25.250
And in the first two questions on this
set, we just had layer two issues.

23
00:01:25.250 --> 00:01:27.155
Now, we're starting to move
a little higher in the OSI model.

24
00:01:27.155 --> 00:01:28.810
Routing might be working fine.

25
00:01:28.810 --> 00:01:30.230
It might still be a layer two issue,

26
00:01:30.230 --> 00:01:33.510
but we may need to do a little
additional troubleshooting.

27
00:01:33.510 --> 00:01:36.130
Any time that I have a question
where routing is involved,

28
00:01:36.130 --> 00:01:38.720
the first thing I usually start with
is what's called scoping the problem.

29
00:01:38.720 --> 00:01:42.670
I'm trying to figure out where
the problem actually exists.

30
00:01:42.670 --> 00:01:45.790
And our topology's actually
a little bit complex, right?

31
00:01:45.790 --> 00:01:48.650
Because we've got more than one
path through the network, and

32
00:01:48.650 --> 00:01:51.290
we've got some tricky protocols going on.

33
00:01:51.290 --> 00:01:56.152
So NYEDGE1 is a router, and
it's got three interfaces.

34
00:01:56.152 --> 00:02:00.356
It's got Ser/0/0/0, Gi0/0, Ser0/0/1.

35
00:02:00.356 --> 00:02:00.955
Oh, it's got four.

36
00:02:00.955 --> 00:02:02.191
Actually it's got Gi0/1 up there.

37
00:02:02.191 --> 00:02:04.820
So it's got four different interfaces.

38
00:02:04.820 --> 00:02:08.080
One of those interfaces could
be on the 192.168.11 network and

39
00:02:08.080 --> 00:02:12.790
another interface could be
on the 192.168.16 network.

40
00:02:12.790 --> 00:02:15.370
So it could be doing
the routing right there and

41
00:02:15.370 --> 00:02:17.470
I'm getting lost in the unit itself.

42
00:02:17.470 --> 00:02:22.120
I might actually be making it to
NYEDGE1 and dying there, all right, but

43
00:02:22.120 --> 00:02:23.500
I don't know.

44
00:02:23.500 --> 00:02:26.040
I could also be having
a problem down here.

45
00:02:26.040 --> 00:02:30.630
These two switches, NYCORE1 and
NYCORE2, are layer three switches and

46
00:02:30.630 --> 00:02:33.170
that means they can do routing also.

47
00:02:33.170 --> 00:02:35.890
So I might be getting routed there, right?

48
00:02:35.890 --> 00:02:38.710
And you might remember from
the earlier questions in this set,

49
00:02:38.710 --> 00:02:40.550
these guys are running HSRP.

50
00:02:40.550 --> 00:02:45.459
The one on the left is 192.168.16.2, and

51
00:02:45.459 --> 00:02:49.310
the one on the right is 192.168.16.3.

52
00:02:49.310 --> 00:02:54.637
And they're sharing
192.168.16.1 between them.

53
00:02:54.637 --> 00:03:01.860
So there's .1, .2, and .3, and NYEDGE1
up here has all the .4 addresses on it.

54
00:03:01.860 --> 00:03:05.960
So those are the systems that are going to
be involved in this and that means that my

55
00:03:05.960 --> 00:03:11.670
server could be going to ACCESS1
up to CORE1, and then up to EDGE1.

56
00:03:12.700 --> 00:03:18.570
Or I could be going from the server
to ACCESS1, then to CORE2,

57
00:03:19.670 --> 00:03:23.970
over to CORE1, over to EDGE1, right, so
I could be going two different paths.

58
00:03:23.970 --> 00:03:25.820
I don't know which path I'm following.

59
00:03:25.820 --> 00:03:27.300
So when it comes to a routing issue,

60
00:03:27.300 --> 00:03:30.370
the easiest way to determine
a path is to use traceroute.

61
00:03:30.370 --> 00:03:32.900
And it's also a great way
to scope the problem.

62
00:03:32.900 --> 00:03:37.220
Because if the traceroute stops, then
you know where your problem is, right?

63
00:03:37.220 --> 00:03:40.400
You hit a point where you stopped on
the network and that was the end, right?

64
00:03:40.400 --> 00:03:42.510
So it helps us to scope it and
find the issue.

65
00:03:42.510 --> 00:03:43.510
On the small network,

66
00:03:43.510 --> 00:03:46.530
like what you'll see on the exam,
it's usually not that big of a deal.

67
00:03:46.530 --> 00:03:49.950
But in real life you might have 16
hops between you and the destination.

68
00:03:49.950 --> 00:03:52.470
The problem could be
anywhere along that path.

69
00:03:52.470 --> 00:03:53.840
So let's take a look at that.

70
00:03:53.840 --> 00:03:54.900
Now for this one,

71
00:03:54.900 --> 00:03:57.630
I'm gonna use the Windows machine
down here to do the traceroute from.

72
00:03:57.630 --> 00:03:59.357
That's the source of our problem anyway,
right?

73
00:03:59.357 --> 00:04:02.862
But in real life you might not
have access to that machine.

74
00:04:02.862 --> 00:04:06.350
I could use ACCESS1 down here and
do the traceroute from there.

75
00:04:06.350 --> 00:04:09.900
But if I can, I want to do it from
the unit where they reported the problem.

76
00:04:09.900 --> 00:04:12.840
In this case,
the problem was reported from that server.

77
00:04:12.840 --> 00:04:18.120
So I'm gonna jump back to that server,
and I'll fire up a command prompt, and

78
00:04:18.120 --> 00:04:20.860
I'm just gonna do a couple
of quick things, right?

79
00:04:20.860 --> 00:04:25.500
First off, I'm gonna verify the IP
configuration on this system, and

80
00:04:25.500 --> 00:04:29.300
just make sure it's got the right IP
address and subnet mask, that basic stuff.

81
00:04:29.300 --> 00:04:31.964
Those are easy problems that
can slip by sometimes, and

82
00:04:31.964 --> 00:04:35.373
then I waste a lot of time troubleshooting
when it turned out to be easy.

83
00:04:35.373 --> 00:04:39.021
So I'm gonna do a quick ipconfig and
what I'm looking for

84
00:04:39.021 --> 00:04:44.799
is on the 192.168.16 network, I wanna make
sure I have the right subnet mask and

85
00:04:44.799 --> 00:04:50.806
the right default gateway, and looking
at this I've got 192.168.16.10, and

86
00:04:50.806 --> 00:04:57.829
I've got 255.255.255.0, that's a 24- bit
subnet mask, and my default gateway is .1.

87
00:04:57.829 --> 00:04:59.909
So things are looking correct there.

88
00:04:59.909 --> 00:05:05.304
I might wanna do a quick test to see if
I can even get to my default gateway,

89
00:05:05.304 --> 00:05:08.502
so can I ping 192.168.16.1?

90
00:05:08.502 --> 00:05:09.897
And I can, all right.

91
00:05:09.897 --> 00:05:13.196
So, it looks like this system
is set up right for its end, but

92
00:05:13.196 --> 00:05:18.185
it's trying to get to 192.168.11.4, so
there's any number of problems that

93
00:05:18.185 --> 00:05:22.190
could happen down the road, but
it looks like this server is fine.

94
00:05:22.190 --> 00:05:24.190
And that's what you'll
normally see on the exam.

95
00:05:24.190 --> 00:05:27.480
They're not normally gonna give you
a problem in a Windows machine,

96
00:05:27.480 --> 00:05:30.770
because it's a trouble shooting Sysco
exam, not a trouble shooting Windows.

97
00:05:30.770 --> 00:05:33.190
So it's not normally gonna be here.

98
00:05:33.190 --> 00:05:35.010
But I am going to do a trace route.

99
00:05:35.010 --> 00:05:38.800
And remember on a Sysco router or switch,
the command is traceroute fully written

100
00:05:38.800 --> 00:05:43.310
out, but on a Windows box it's tracert,
so I'm just going to do tracert.

101
00:05:43.310 --> 00:05:46.480
And I'm gonna punch in the IP
address I'm trying to get to.

102
00:05:46.480 --> 00:05:50.380
Now, I know I can get to my default
gateway so my first entry in my trace

103
00:05:50.380 --> 00:05:53.830
route should be my default gateway,
and so here it's coming back.

104
00:05:53.830 --> 00:05:58.400
I expect to see 192.168.16.,
well, I got .3.

105
00:05:58.400 --> 00:06:00.240
Why did I get .3?

106
00:06:00.240 --> 00:06:03.014
Well, my default gateway is .1, but

107
00:06:03.014 --> 00:06:08.909
you'll remember that that's actually
HSRP between these two switches, right?

108
00:06:08.909 --> 00:06:13.413
So they're sharing .1,
this guy is .2, this guy is .3.

109
00:06:13.413 --> 00:06:17.910
I got .3 back in my traceroute, which
tells me I'm actually going to CORE2.

110
00:06:17.910 --> 00:06:23.310
So I need to put that in my mind,
that my path is going over to ACCESS1,

111
00:06:23.310 --> 00:06:28.010
up to CORE2, over to CORE1 most likely,
and then up here to EDGE1, so

112
00:06:28.010 --> 00:06:30.350
I'm following this roundabout path.

113
00:06:30.350 --> 00:06:34.300
Or it's even possible that I'm going up to
EDGE2 and over this serial line, right?

114
00:06:34.300 --> 00:06:37.740
Those are all possibilities, so
I'll have to check those out.

115
00:06:37.740 --> 00:06:39.680
And that's assuming I've
got layer three issues.

116
00:06:39.680 --> 00:06:41.600
There could be layer two
issues still in the mix,

117
00:06:41.600 --> 00:06:45.020
too, I'll have to verify those, all right?

118
00:06:45.020 --> 00:06:47.380
Well, look at my trace route,
things die there.

119
00:06:47.380 --> 00:06:50.870
So I really don't get beyond 192.168.16.3,
but I do get there.

120
00:06:52.630 --> 00:06:54.970
So I know, looking at my diagram,

121
00:06:54.970 --> 00:06:58.420
at a minimum,
I was able to make it here to CORE2.

122
00:06:58.420 --> 00:07:00.930
So for my next stage of troubleshooting,
I'm gonna move to CORE2 and

123
00:07:00.930 --> 00:07:03.340
look at things from its perspective.

124
00:07:03.340 --> 00:07:06.149
So I'm gonna jump over to that switch.

125
00:07:08.140 --> 00:07:10.440
And looks like I'm already logged in here.

126
00:07:10.440 --> 00:07:13.780
So, we'll just pick right
back up with that one.

127
00:07:13.780 --> 00:07:17.330
And taking a look at this switch,
I just need to verify a few things.

128
00:07:17.330 --> 00:07:20.905
Right, the first think I want to do is I
know the switch is doing routing, right?

129
00:07:20.905 --> 00:07:22.535
It's running HSRP.

130
00:07:22.535 --> 00:07:24.781
And you can do a show standby to see that.

131
00:07:24.781 --> 00:07:28.668
And Vlan16 is the 192.168.16 network.

132
00:07:28.668 --> 00:07:30.137
And so I can say, whoops.

133
00:07:30.137 --> 00:07:33.181
[LAUGH] I can see that it's up and
it's active, right?

134
00:07:33.181 --> 00:07:38.307
This is the active node for it, so
it is the one answering to 192.168.16.1.

135
00:07:38.307 --> 00:07:40.641
And we already knew that
from our traceroute, right?

136
00:07:40.641 --> 00:07:43.757
So it's up and happy,
as far as Vlan16 is concerned.

137
00:07:43.757 --> 00:07:45.672
But what about all the other VLANs?

138
00:07:45.672 --> 00:07:51.625
I'm trying to get to 192.168.11.4,
so I'm gonna do a show IP route,

139
00:07:51.625 --> 00:07:55.961
and I wanna look at my routing table and
see if I have a route for

140
00:07:55.961 --> 00:08:00.490
192.168.11, and sure enough,
I can see that I do.

141
00:08:00.490 --> 00:08:01.640
It's right there.

142
00:08:01.640 --> 00:08:05.190
All right, and
that route is directly connected.

143
00:08:05.190 --> 00:08:10.280
That means that this switch is able
to route between vlan16 and vlan11.

144
00:08:10.280 --> 00:08:14.268
So this switch has an interface
directly on vlan11,

145
00:08:14.268 --> 00:08:18.990
seems odd that my workstation
couldn't ping across that VLAN.

146
00:08:18.990 --> 00:08:26.060
And if I look I can see this switch is
192.168.11.3 on that network also, okay?

147
00:08:26.060 --> 00:08:29.480
Well, if it's 11.3,
I can do just a quick test.

148
00:08:29.480 --> 00:08:33.281
If I jump over to my server.

149
00:08:33.281 --> 00:08:38.534
Earlier, I was trying to ping,
let me break out of that, there we go.

150
00:08:38.534 --> 00:08:43.490
Earlier, I was trying to
ping 192.168.11.4, right?

151
00:08:43.490 --> 00:08:48.070
And it didn't get me there, that was
EDGE1 that I couldn't contact, right?

152
00:08:48.070 --> 00:08:50.450
Well, what if I try .3, .3 is that switch.

153
00:08:50.450 --> 00:08:52.240
I know I can make it to the switch.

154
00:08:52.240 --> 00:08:55.280
And if I do that, it's working.

155
00:08:55.280 --> 00:08:57.420
So that takes routing out of the picture.

156
00:08:57.420 --> 00:09:00.340
I'm getting routed to vlan11,

157
00:09:00.340 --> 00:09:04.710
but I'm not actually making it to 11.4,
that particular IP.

158
00:09:04.710 --> 00:09:07.360
Now, there could still be
an ACL in the mix, right, but

159
00:09:07.360 --> 00:09:08.670
the ACLs aren't technically routing.

160
00:09:08.670 --> 00:09:10.050
It's security filtering.

161
00:09:10.050 --> 00:09:12.130
So I may still need to
pay attention to that.

162
00:09:12.130 --> 00:09:16.520
But otherwise, it looks like I can jump
over that VLAN, just not getting to .4.

163
00:09:16.520 --> 00:09:21.400
And when something like that happens,
we really do narrow it down to two things.

164
00:09:21.400 --> 00:09:25.760
It could be that there's an ACL
on CORE2 that's filtering my

165
00:09:25.760 --> 00:09:30.530
communications between those VLANs, or
it could be a problem up here on EDGE1

166
00:09:30.530 --> 00:09:34.930
with a slight possibility of
being an issue here on CORE1.

167
00:09:34.930 --> 00:09:37.310
HSRP makes this a lot more complex.

168
00:09:37.310 --> 00:09:40.270
I might be active for one VLAN but
not active for another, so

169
00:09:40.270 --> 00:09:43.400
we've gotta pay attention to that and
see how that's configured.

170
00:09:43.400 --> 00:09:45.650
This could also be a return trip issue.

171
00:09:45.650 --> 00:09:48.450
My traffic could be making it to EDGE1,
and

172
00:09:48.450 --> 00:09:50.840
EDGE1 might not have
a route to get back to me.

173
00:09:50.840 --> 00:09:52.570
So I'm gonna have to verify that.

174
00:09:52.570 --> 00:09:56.980
But I do wanna test one more thing on
CORE2 before I jump over to EDGE1, and

175
00:09:56.980 --> 00:09:58.038
test from there.

176
00:09:58.038 --> 00:10:04.273
So on CORE2, what I want to test
is whether it can get to EDGE1,

177
00:10:04.273 --> 00:10:08.661
so if I jump over to CORE2,
I'm just gonna do

178
00:10:08.661 --> 00:10:13.521
a quick ping here to 192.168.11.4.

179
00:10:13.521 --> 00:10:15.634
I know my server can't get there.

180
00:10:15.634 --> 00:10:16.609
Can this switch?

181
00:10:16.609 --> 00:10:21.746
This switch is directly
plugged into 192.168.11.0/24.

182
00:10:21.746 --> 00:10:25.152
So if it can't do it,
I can take routing out of the picture now.

183
00:10:25.152 --> 00:10:29.970
It's not a routing problem, it's gonna
be layer two, something going on there.

184
00:10:29.970 --> 00:10:32.590
Or I guess there is still
the possibility we could have

185
00:10:32.590 --> 00:10:34.040
a misconfiguration on the other side.

186
00:10:34.040 --> 00:10:36.740
Let's go take a look at that other side,
we'll rule that out real quick.

187
00:10:36.740 --> 00:10:41.120
So, at NYCORE2, I get get there,
just like the server can't.

188
00:10:41.120 --> 00:10:45.400
So, now I'm going to jump over to
NYEDGE1 and see how it's set up, right?

189
00:10:45.400 --> 00:10:47.430
NYEDGE1 is who I'm trying to get to.

190
00:10:47.430 --> 00:10:52.060
That's the node I'm trying to get into,
and it's just not working, right?

191
00:10:52.060 --> 00:10:55.260
Well, I can at least see the node is
powered on, that counts for something, and

192
00:10:55.260 --> 00:10:58.520
then from here I can try and
isolate what's actually wrong with it.

193
00:10:58.520 --> 00:11:01.512
So I'm gonna do a quick show
IP interface brief, and

194
00:11:01.512 --> 00:11:04.241
just see what I'm dealing
with on this system.

195
00:11:04.241 --> 00:11:11.827
So looking at it, it's got an interface
192.168.11 well shoot .44.

196
00:11:11.827 --> 00:11:13.594
This is gonna turn out to be an easy one,
right?

197
00:11:13.594 --> 00:11:17.826
I'm trying to ping 192.168.11.4.

198
00:11:17.826 --> 00:11:20.610
Look at these IPs, I don't see a .4.

199
00:11:20.610 --> 00:11:24.800
Now, always be weary that it could
be just hidden away in the config.

200
00:11:24.800 --> 00:11:27.350
I might have a secondary IP on this.

201
00:11:27.350 --> 00:11:29.500
Looks like we're doing router
on a stick though, and

202
00:11:29.500 --> 00:11:34.160
so I'll only have one interface on vlan11,
which is probably this one.

203
00:11:34.160 --> 00:11:35.460
I say probably because remember,

204
00:11:35.460 --> 00:11:39.620
these sub-interface numbers,
they don't have to match the VLAN number.

205
00:11:39.620 --> 00:11:41.500
It's the encoding that has to match.

206
00:11:41.500 --> 00:11:43.943
So let me take a look at
that actual interface.

207
00:11:43.943 --> 00:11:49.690
So I'll just do a show running
config interface gi0/0.11,

208
00:11:49.690 --> 00:11:55.340
and I don't see any secondary IPs,
but I do see a standby.

209
00:11:55.340 --> 00:11:58.120
This guy's actually
participating in HSRP also, but

210
00:11:58.120 --> 00:12:01.630
I don't really care about that because
it's .1, and I'm concerned about .4.

211
00:12:01.630 --> 00:12:05.500
Notice there's no secondary IP,
there's just this one and

212
00:12:05.500 --> 00:12:07.550
it's the wrong IP, right?

213
00:12:07.550 --> 00:12:09.080
In fact, not only is it the wrong IP,

214
00:12:09.080 --> 00:12:11.650
if I look a little more at it,
it's the wrong subnet mask.

215
00:12:11.650 --> 00:12:14.230
Right, this is just
completely assigned wrong.

216
00:12:14.230 --> 00:12:16.840
Well, I assume it's assigned wrong.

217
00:12:16.840 --> 00:12:18.720
What if it's not?
What if they meant for

218
00:12:18.720 --> 00:12:20.130
this to be assigned?

219
00:12:20.130 --> 00:12:21.280
I don't really know.

220
00:12:21.280 --> 00:12:24.200
So, I gotta make a decision,
there's two ways I can fix this, right?

221
00:12:24.200 --> 00:12:27.410
One way, I can replace this with
what I think is the correct IP,

222
00:12:27.410 --> 00:12:29.410
and that's probably what
we need to do here.

223
00:12:29.410 --> 00:12:32.350
But if the instructions
specifically tell you not

224
00:12:32.350 --> 00:12:33.840
to remove anything, you'll see that.

225
00:12:33.840 --> 00:12:35.360
Sometimes it will say,
you've gotta fix this problem,

226
00:12:35.360 --> 00:12:38.050
you're not allowed to remove
any configuration lines.

227
00:12:38.050 --> 00:12:41.530
If you see that, I can always add
the right IP as a secondary IP,

228
00:12:41.530 --> 00:12:44.070
and then that would fix our problem,
right?

229
00:12:44.070 --> 00:12:45.420
So, it's kind of done the same way.

230
00:12:45.420 --> 00:12:46.440
I'll show you guys.

231
00:12:46.440 --> 00:12:52.424
If I jump into that interface, so
I'm going to jump into 0/0.11 and

232
00:12:52.424 --> 00:12:58.805
I'll say IP address 192.168.11.4
with the correct subnet ask.

233
00:12:58.805 --> 00:12:59.387
All right,

234
00:12:59.387 --> 00:13:03.124
now if I press enter right now it's
gonna replace the IP I've all ready got.

235
00:13:03.124 --> 00:13:08.982
But if I type the word secondary after
that, when I do that secondary now,

236
00:13:08.982 --> 00:13:13.910
it's gonna add that as an addition IP and
leave the other one.

237
00:13:13.910 --> 00:13:16.750
So if they tell me not to remove anything,
I could always do this.

238
00:13:16.750 --> 00:13:19.230
But in my case,
I'm pretty sure it's just the wrong IP, so

239
00:13:19.230 --> 00:13:22.560
I'm going to replace it, and
I'll bet that'll solve our problem.

240
00:13:22.560 --> 00:13:26.092
While I'm in here, I'm just gonna
double check the encapsulation line and

241
00:13:26.092 --> 00:13:28.035
make sure that it says vlan11, right?

242
00:13:28.035 --> 00:13:30.179
That's another common
mistake that people make.

243
00:13:30.179 --> 00:13:33.129
They assume the subinterface
number has to match when it

244
00:13:33.129 --> 00:13:36.140
is actually the encapsulation
line that has to match, so

245
00:13:36.140 --> 00:13:39.104
I'm just gonna double check it,
nut that should be it.

246
00:13:39.104 --> 00:13:45.734
I can do a quick test from here to
see if I can ping 192.168.11.3,

247
00:13:45.734 --> 00:13:49.510
which should be my switch,
and there we go.

248
00:13:49.510 --> 00:13:52.580
And that's getting through, so
I'll bet our problem is solved.

249
00:13:52.580 --> 00:13:56.242
Although that ping problem would have gone
through before cuz we had a .44 address,

250
00:13:56.242 --> 00:13:59.710
but I had the wrong subnet mask, so that
what it caused its own little problems.

251
00:13:59.710 --> 00:14:02.565
So let's go take a look at our server and
see if that fixed our issue, and

252
00:14:02.565 --> 00:14:05.530
if it did, this will turn out to be
one of our easier problems, all right?

253
00:14:05.530 --> 00:14:09.586
So I'm just gonna come right
back to the server where

254
00:14:09.586 --> 00:14:13.364
we started this whole thing and
I'm gonna try and

255
00:14:13.364 --> 00:14:18.909
ping 192.168.11.4,
which I guess I never actually did.

256
00:14:18.909 --> 00:14:20.936
So let's do it there and
now we're getting through.

257
00:14:20.936 --> 00:14:25.737
All right, so this problem turned out to
be straight, easy, just wrong IP address,

258
00:14:25.737 --> 00:14:27.350
and just wrong subnet mask.

259
00:14:27.350 --> 00:14:33.417
So our traffic, when it did an ARP
broadcast to say who is 192.168.11.4,

260
00:14:33.417 --> 00:14:39.087
nobody responded, and so we had a layer
2 breakdown because nobody had that IP.

261
00:14:39.087 --> 00:14:41.740
We fixed it,
now the problem is solved, right?

262
00:14:41.740 --> 00:14:43.960
So pretty straightforward one there,
not so bad.

263
00:14:43.960 --> 00:14:47.480
It did take us awhile to find it just
because of how much equipment is involved.

264
00:14:47.480 --> 00:14:50.090
Better documentation could have
saved us a lot of trouble there.

265
00:14:50.090 --> 00:14:51.660
But you get what you get right.

266
00:14:51.660 --> 00:14:54.530
On the exam, they give you some diagrams
and you gotta make do with what you got.

267
00:14:54.530 --> 00:14:56.860
Sometimes exploring is
half the troubleshooting.

268
00:14:56.860 --> 00:14:58.795
So this one turned out to be not so bad.

269
00:14:58.795 --> 00:15:00.760
All right,
well that wraps up this problem,

270
00:15:00.760 --> 00:15:03.926
definitely stay tuned we got more
trouble shooting scenario coming up.

271
00:15:03.926 --> 00:15:09.195
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #4` from set #2. The trouble ticket states that "From PLABCSCO01 you are unable to ping 172.16.16.2, a host on NYWAN1s Gi0/1 interface: "
episodes.title: Set 2 Issue 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.090
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.090 --> 00:00:10.912
In this video, we're going to
continue on to set number two,

3
00:00:10.912 --> 00:00:12.880
we're taking a look at issue number four.

4
00:00:12.880 --> 00:00:15.480
And on this one we've got
More communications issues.

5
00:00:15.480 --> 00:00:16.570
I tell you, this network's terrible.

6
00:00:16.570 --> 00:00:21.440
So, we've got PLAB Cisco 01,
our little Windows server out there.

7
00:00:21.440 --> 00:00:23.250
This time it's unable to ping a host but

8
00:00:23.250 --> 00:00:26.530
this one is a lot different cuz
the host is way outside of our network.

9
00:00:26.530 --> 00:00:29.670
The host is 172.16.16.2.

10
00:00:29.670 --> 00:00:33.400
And all they tell us
here is that it's a host

11
00:00:33.400 --> 00:00:38.080
out NY wan one's gigabit
zero slash one interface.

12
00:00:38.080 --> 00:00:41.340
Now, where is that,
this is all new for us right.

13
00:00:41.340 --> 00:00:42.680
If I pull up my topology,

14
00:00:42.680 --> 00:00:46.160
let me just kind of zoom in here and
we'll try and find that.

15
00:00:46.160 --> 00:00:49.540
So, it mentioned that it was outside
NY wan one, this guy right here.

16
00:00:49.540 --> 00:00:54.240
Now, NY wan one that's a router we
control, we have access to that But

17
00:00:54.240 --> 00:00:57.370
it's a router that's on the edge
of our autonomous system.

18
00:00:57.370 --> 00:01:00.650
Which means, that it's the last
router that we actually control.

19
00:01:00.650 --> 00:01:03.710
Anything beyond that, we don't control.

20
00:01:03.710 --> 00:01:08.520
And we're trying to get to 172.16.16.2,
that's this network, right here.

21
00:01:08.520 --> 00:01:10.940
Which points to the NWRKWAN1.

22
00:01:10.940 --> 00:01:12.940
So, that server or

23
00:01:12.940 --> 00:01:15.950
whatever it is that we're trying to reach
is on the network that we don't control.

24
00:01:15.950 --> 00:01:18.050
We don't have access to this router,
we can't view it,

25
00:01:18.050 --> 00:01:21.430
we can't see its config,
it's out on the Internet, right?

26
00:01:21.430 --> 00:01:25.910
So, we know that, we only have so
much control over this.

27
00:01:25.910 --> 00:01:29.890
And our problem is really
send it around ping And

28
00:01:29.890 --> 00:01:32.390
the ping is coming from this server.

29
00:01:32.390 --> 00:01:34.530
And so
it's bouncing through some switches.

30
00:01:34.530 --> 00:01:36.170
It's coming up to New York edge one.

31
00:01:36.170 --> 00:01:38.620
It's jumping over to NY Win one and
heading out.

32
00:01:38.620 --> 00:01:41.300
That's a lot of equipment
in between point A and

33
00:01:41.300 --> 00:01:44.930
point B and the problem can
be anywhere along that path.

34
00:01:44.930 --> 00:01:46.510
And so we're going to have to jump in and

35
00:01:46.510 --> 00:01:50.230
Scope this problem just like
we did with issue three.

36
00:01:50.230 --> 00:01:52.620
So, I'm really gonna start this one
the same way we did issue three,

37
00:01:52.620 --> 00:01:53.610
which is traceroute.

38
00:01:53.610 --> 00:01:56.720
Traceroute's a great way to
identify where that problem is.

39
00:01:56.720 --> 00:02:00.950
So, I'm gonna jump over to that server and
that's where we'll start.

40
00:02:00.950 --> 00:02:07.000
So, here I am on that server, and
I'm just gonna do a quick Trace route

41
00:02:07.000 --> 00:02:12.435
to the host that we're trying to get to,
so the host is 172.16.16.2.

42
00:02:12.435 --> 00:02:13.331
All right.

43
00:02:13.331 --> 00:02:14.910
And let's see where this dies out,

44
00:02:14.910 --> 00:02:17.740
I'm assuming it'll die out since
that's what the tickets all about.

45
00:02:17.740 --> 00:02:21.590
So, the first hop should be my default
gateway and assuming we haven't messed up

46
00:02:21.590 --> 00:02:24.120
anything on our local network,
we should be able to get there.

47
00:02:24.120 --> 00:02:26.520
And after that,
I really don't know what's gonna happen.

48
00:02:26.520 --> 00:02:30.190
If we go back to the diagram, my default
gateway you'll remember from the earlier

49
00:02:30.190 --> 00:02:34.300
questions is an HSRP shared IP
between these two switches.

50
00:02:34.300 --> 00:02:36.080
So, I'm gonna get there.

51
00:02:36.080 --> 00:02:40.140
From there, I'll get routed over to
the other VLANs where I should end up

52
00:02:40.140 --> 00:02:40.980
on NYEDGE1.

53
00:02:40.980 --> 00:02:45.030
That should be the next step in my
journey or what I expect to see.

54
00:02:45.030 --> 00:02:47.670
And then from there we should
be jumping over to N1WAN1.

55
00:02:47.670 --> 00:02:53.113
And if I go back to my server I can
see the next IP I got was 1.92.

56
00:02:53.113 --> 00:02:54.121
168.13.5.

57
00:02:54.121 --> 00:02:58.960
That's not really what expected
to see 13.5 because N1EDGE1,

58
00:02:58.960 --> 00:03:04.170
if you remember from the last question,
all of it's IPs ended in .4.

59
00:03:04.170 --> 00:03:04.760
I'm seeing dot five.

60
00:03:04.760 --> 00:03:09.870
Alright, well I don't who dot five is and
the diagram doesn't really show me either.

61
00:03:09.870 --> 00:03:12.630
So we might have to do a little bit of
exploration to figure out who the heck is

62
00:03:12.630 --> 00:03:15.380
dot five cuz that's my next hop..

63
00:03:15.380 --> 00:03:18.800
And then whoever dot five is,
that's the end of my journey.

64
00:03:18.800 --> 00:03:23.790
And so, their either the problem or
whoever their next hop is the problem.

65
00:03:23.790 --> 00:03:26.990
But I don't know who their next hop
is I'm gonna need to go to them

66
00:03:26.990 --> 00:03:27.560
one way or another.

67
00:03:27.560 --> 00:03:31.480
I'm gonna have to go to whoever .5 is
to figure out if they are the issue or

68
00:03:31.480 --> 00:03:34.060
at least to figure out
who their next hop is.

69
00:03:34.060 --> 00:03:36.340
So, let's go find who's .5.

70
00:03:36.340 --> 00:03:40.460
Maybe it is EDGE1,
it would make sense I guess, and

71
00:03:40.460 --> 00:03:42.810
it just has an extra IP that
I didn't notice before.

72
00:03:42.810 --> 00:03:45.600
So, let's jump over to EDGE1 and
see if we can't figure that out.

73
00:03:45.600 --> 00:03:51.160
So, if I jump over to EDGE1,
This is that router and

74
00:03:51.160 --> 00:03:53.190
I'm gonna do a show IP interface brief.

75
00:03:54.290 --> 00:03:58.240
And we'll just pull up its interface list
and see how everything ends in .4 here,

76
00:03:58.240 --> 00:03:59.490
I don't see any .5's.

77
00:03:59.490 --> 00:04:03.520
I guess it's possible it could be
hidden away in the configuration.

78
00:04:03.520 --> 00:04:11.005
So, if I do a show run, and I filter to
include and hunt specifically for that IP.

79
00:04:11.005 --> 00:04:15.210
192.168.16.5.

80
00:04:15.210 --> 00:04:18.030
I got nothing, right.

81
00:04:18.030 --> 00:04:21.600
So, this guy is not .5,

307
00:15:55.260 --> 00:15:58.850
So, how far I want to limit
this is kinda up to me.

308
00:15:58.850 --> 00:16:02.780
But if I want to be really super literal,
I'm just trying to fix this one node.

309
00:16:02.780 --> 00:16:04.760
This is a nice,
specific line that's gonna do that.

310
00:16:05.810 --> 00:16:10.850
And then I can do a show
If I spell it right here.

311
00:16:10.850 --> 00:16:12.160
show access list.

312
00:16:14.510 --> 00:16:17.180
And I can verify that it's in there,
whoops.

313
00:16:17.180 --> 00:16:17.730
And there we go.
So,

314
00:16:17.730 --> 00:16:19.840
I've got that line right there and
it did give it line number 40.

315
00:16:19.840 --> 00:16:21.110
It's right at the end.

316
00:16:21.110 --> 00:16:22.870
It's gonna permit that traffic in.

317
00:16:22.870 --> 00:16:25.340
In theory,
I should be able to get there now, right.

318
00:16:25.340 --> 00:16:26.560
Or at least I should be NAT'ed.

319
00:16:26.560 --> 00:16:27.540
We might still have another problem.

320
00:16:27.540 --> 00:16:29.670
So, let's go see if I can get there,
right.

321
00:16:29.670 --> 00:16:32.960
So, I'll jump back over
to that server And,

322
00:16:32.960 --> 00:16:36.070
it still kind of churning along with
its trace routs, let me just kill that.

323
00:16:37.520 --> 00:16:40.490
Let me try and kill that, there we go, and

324
00:16:40.490 --> 00:16:45.290
I'm going to try and ping to 172.16.16.2
which is what failed way back in

325
00:16:45.290 --> 00:16:49.650
the beginning of this episode and
now I'm getting there.

326
00:16:49.650 --> 00:16:51.210
RIght?
So, now its working.

327
00:16:51.210 --> 00:16:52.440
I didn't fix it for
the rest of my network.

328
00:16:52.440 --> 00:16:53.660
I just fixed it for this host.

329
00:16:53.660 --> 00:16:56.250
But that's what the ticket was,
and it's now resolved.

330
00:16:56.250 --> 00:17:01.820
So, this one turned out to be a bad access
control list in a NAT configuration.

331
00:17:01.820 --> 00:17:05.140
So, the hardest part here was just
figuring out where the problem was and

332
00:17:05.140 --> 00:17:09.010
having an inaccurate network diagram
that's a bit of a problem, too.

333
00:17:09.010 --> 00:17:13.480
I didn't know that we could bypass
those edge routers, so I kinda wasted

334
00:17:13.480 --> 00:17:16.940
time looking at the edge routers when I
could've jumped right over to NYWAN 1.

335
00:17:16.940 --> 00:17:19.630
So, just be aware that sometimes
there can be a red herring there.

336
00:17:19.630 --> 00:17:22.220
You're gonna follow the wrong path
as you troubleshoot something.

337
00:17:22.220 --> 00:17:25.570
And it's always important to verify
your work and just assume nothing.

338
00:17:25.570 --> 00:17:27.120
Right?
Jump and check each unit if you can.

339
00:17:27.120 --> 00:17:30.220
You just want to make sure you
do it as quickly as possible.

340
00:17:30.220 --> 00:17:32.340
All right, well that wraps up
this troubleshooting problem.

341
00:17:32.340 --> 00:17:33.240
I hope you guys enjoyed it.

342
00:17:33.240 --> 00:17:36.276
Stay tuned, we've got more
troubleshooting scenarios coming up.

343
00:17:36.276 --> 00:17:42.519
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #5` from set #2. The trouble ticket states that "Time is not synchronised on NYCORE1, all the other devices show the same time, but this switch does not. "
episodes.title: Set 2 Issue 5
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.006
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.806 --> 00:00:10.270
All right,
welcome back to troubleshooting, set 2.

3
00:00:10.270 --> 00:00:14.130
We're moving on to issue 5 on this one,
and it looks like we've got some time

4
00:00:14.130 --> 00:00:17.945
protocol errors on this one, so
it'll be a good time, no pun intended.

5
00:00:17.945 --> 00:00:21.440
[LAUGH] So we'll pick this one up, the
troubleshooting ticket reads like this.

6
00:00:21.440 --> 00:00:25.480
It says,
time is not synchronized on NYCORE1.

7
00:00:25.480 --> 00:00:28.869
All other devices show the same time,
but the switch does not.

8
00:00:28.869 --> 00:00:31.938
So we've got one switch that's
not synchronizing its time.

9
00:00:31.938 --> 00:00:34.670
Everybody else is fine,
this one guy, not doing it.

10
00:00:34.670 --> 00:00:36.490
So, we need to find out why.

11
00:00:36.490 --> 00:00:40.420
So, lets find out why.

12
00:00:40.420 --> 00:00:41.780
Lets take a look in our topology.

13
00:00:41.780 --> 00:00:44.110
So in our topology we have a bunch
of devices, a bunch of routers,

14
00:00:44.110 --> 00:00:45.200
a bunch of switches.

15
00:00:45.200 --> 00:00:48.490
This one is nice cuz they've
really narrowed us down to one.

16
00:00:48.490 --> 00:00:50.190
So by reading the question we're like, oh,

17
00:00:50.190 --> 00:00:54.130
we're gonna have a time problem right
here in NYCORE1, this is gonna be easy.

18
00:00:54.130 --> 00:00:57.730
But remember that when it comes
to a time problem like this,

19
00:00:57.730 --> 00:01:00.520
it can actually be something far,
far different.

20
00:01:00.520 --> 00:01:03.920
For example, maybe the time server is
out there and I just can't reach it.

21
00:01:03.920 --> 00:01:08.330
And if I can't reach the time server,
well, I might have a routing issue,

22
00:01:08.330 --> 00:01:11.010
I might have access control lists,
I might have NAD issues, there's

23
00:01:11.010 --> 00:01:14.530
all sorts of issues that might be blocking
me from getting to the time server.

24
00:01:14.530 --> 00:01:17.440
So all of a sudden what seems
like a simple NTP question,

25
00:01:17.440 --> 00:01:19.940
becomes a layer three routing question.

26
00:01:19.940 --> 00:01:23.511
So always be aware of that on the exam
that you've gotta just be ready for

27
00:01:23.511 --> 00:01:25.380
anything as we jump into these.

28
00:01:25.380 --> 00:01:28.143
So on this one though, NYCORE1,
can't synchronize its time,

29
00:01:28.143 --> 00:01:30.380
everybody else is doing it just fine.

30
00:01:30.380 --> 00:01:32.010
Let's find out why, okay?

31
00:01:32.010 --> 00:01:37.750
So, on NYCORE1, I'm just gonna
jump over to it, and I wanna see

32
00:01:37.750 --> 00:01:42.110
what its current setup is, and on this
one, I just wanna start with a simple one.

33
00:01:42.110 --> 00:01:43.840
I'll do a show clock, right?

34
00:01:43.840 --> 00:01:47.490
And when I do a show clock on this one,
I can see that I've got good old Monday,

35
00:01:47.490 --> 00:01:51.680
March 1st, 1993,
which is just a little bit wrong, right?

36
00:01:51.680 --> 00:01:55.760
So, 1993, that's 22 years ago.

37
00:01:55.760 --> 00:01:57.190
So that's a long time ago.

38
00:01:57.190 --> 00:02:00.100
And this is definitely wrong,
so my time's not synced.

39
00:02:00.100 --> 00:02:06.930
If I take a look at somebody else, I'll
take CORE2, and take a look at this guy.

40
00:02:06.930 --> 00:02:08.529
We can just do a quick show clock.

41
00:02:11.090 --> 00:02:13.760
And, here we've got November 24th, 2015.

42
00:02:13.760 --> 00:02:16.010
Which, let me verify that,
is indeed today.

43
00:02:16.010 --> 00:02:17.220
So, this one's current.

44
00:02:17.220 --> 00:02:19.330
So, this guy is getting a valid clock.

45
00:02:19.330 --> 00:02:20.410
The other guy's not, all right?

46
00:02:20.410 --> 00:02:21.920
So, why is that?

47
00:02:21.920 --> 00:02:22.970
Let's find out.

48
00:02:22.970 --> 00:02:23.780
Well, first off,

49
00:02:23.780 --> 00:02:27.010
we need to figure out who it is that
we're getting our time from, right?

50
00:02:27.010 --> 00:02:29.040
So, where am I getting my time from?

51
00:02:29.040 --> 00:02:30.620
There's a few different
ways you can find out.

52
00:02:30.620 --> 00:02:33.530
What I normally do is
just show running-config.

53
00:02:33.530 --> 00:02:35.880
And piped it in the include command and
looked for NTP, right?

54
00:02:35.880 --> 00:02:38.460
So I'm just gonna look for
any instance of NTP,

55
00:02:38.460 --> 00:02:40.570
and then we can find
out who our server is.

56
00:02:40.570 --> 00:02:46.724
So you can see I've got a time
server of 192.168.12.55, all right?

57
00:02:46.724 --> 00:02:49.760
So that's one way we can figure out
who we're synchronizing against.

58
00:02:49.760 --> 00:02:52.480
Now notice when I look here
I've got at authentication key.

59
00:02:52.480 --> 00:02:53.660
Authentication is turned on.

60
00:02:53.660 --> 00:02:57.130
I've got a trusted key,
I've got all the stuff set.

61
00:02:57.130 --> 00:02:58.900
Any one of those could be a problem,
right?

62
00:02:58.900 --> 00:03:00.140
I could have a bad key.

63
00:03:00.140 --> 00:03:01.970
I could have all sorts of stuff, but

64
00:03:01.970 --> 00:03:04.598
I'm just trying to figure out who that is,
right?

65
00:03:04.598 --> 00:03:07.376
And now I know that there's other
ways I could have done it, right?

66
00:03:07.376 --> 00:03:12.676
There's show ntp associations.

67
00:03:12.676 --> 00:03:16.156
When you set up an NTP server,
you create an association with it, and

68
00:03:16.156 --> 00:03:19.586
show ntp associations will tell you
who you're set to reach out to.

69
00:03:19.586 --> 00:03:23.966
So I can see, 192.168.12.55.

70
00:03:23.966 --> 00:03:25.980
Now, if you can remember that command,
great.

71
00:03:25.980 --> 00:03:29.180
If you can't, the show running
config works just as well.

72
00:03:29.180 --> 00:03:29.880
But in here,

73
00:03:29.880 --> 00:03:34.830
I get a little more information like this,
that my session is still initializing.

74
00:03:34.830 --> 00:03:37.850
I'm not actually communicating with it,
okay?

75
00:03:37.850 --> 00:03:42.460
So when I reach out to it,
it's got this little tilde to the left.

76
00:03:42.460 --> 00:03:46.930
And if I scroll over here, I can see that
the tilde says that I'm configured, right,

77
00:03:46.930 --> 00:03:49.610
but I'm not selected or a candidate.

78
00:03:49.610 --> 00:03:53.420
I'm not getting a lot of good data
from there really at all, all right?

79
00:03:53.420 --> 00:03:56.530
So, that's not necessarily a good sign.

80
00:03:56.530 --> 00:03:58.890
I've got this host,
I know that's who I'm talking to, but

81
00:03:58.890 --> 00:04:00.990
it doesn't look like I'm
actually communicating.

82
00:04:00.990 --> 00:04:02.880
Now, I could test and
see if I can get to it.

83
00:04:02.880 --> 00:04:06.160
I'll do a quick ping,
we'll see if I can even ping that guy.

84
00:04:06.160 --> 00:04:10.310
And when I go and ping,
I don't get there, right?

85
00:04:10.310 --> 00:04:13.120
Or well, let's wait, okay, sometimes
you lose that first ping just for

86
00:04:13.120 --> 00:04:14.870
the ARP broadcast, so
I'll just wait a second.

87
00:04:14.870 --> 00:04:16.510
But this time it's failing.

88
00:04:16.510 --> 00:04:17.200
I can't ping it.

89
00:04:17.200 --> 00:04:22.113
Now, be careful with this, because
the ping could be being blocked by an ACL,

90
00:04:22.113 --> 00:04:24.578
and NTP's working just fine, right?

91
00:04:24.578 --> 00:04:27.259
So pings aren't always a guarantee,
but it's a great way to test,

92
00:04:27.259 --> 00:04:29.766
at least basically, whether or
not you're able to get there.

93
00:04:29.766 --> 00:04:31.046
And I'm not getting there.

94
00:04:31.046 --> 00:04:38.460
If I do a show ip route for 192.168.12.55,
I can see if I even have a route.

95
00:04:38.460 --> 00:04:40.880
I do have a route, oh,
it's actually a really good route.

96
00:04:40.880 --> 00:04:42.610
Known via connected.

97
00:04:42.610 --> 00:04:44.750
I'm directly plugged into
the 192.168.12 network, so

98
00:04:44.750 --> 00:04:48.860
that tells me I'm not
dealing with a routing issue.

99
00:04:48.860 --> 00:04:52.800
And if I am dealing with an ACL,
it's either on me or on that host, and

100
00:04:52.800 --> 00:04:54.770
if it's a time server,
it probably doesn't have an ACL.

101
00:04:54.770 --> 00:04:59.550
So in this case, I really just ruled out
several different possible problems there

102
00:04:59.550 --> 00:05:03.580
on the routing side, because I'm
directly plugged into that network, so

103
00:05:03.580 --> 00:05:07.060
I should be able to get to
that host right, but I can't.

104
00:05:07.060 --> 00:05:09.070
Now, why not?

105
00:05:09.070 --> 00:05:10.730
Well let's check somebody else right.

106
00:05:10.730 --> 00:05:13.150
We saw NYCORE2 was
synchronizing just fine.

107
00:05:13.150 --> 00:05:16.970
So if I jump over to NYCORE2, this guy,

108
00:05:16.970 --> 00:05:21.659
well I can do a quick
show ntp associations.

109
00:05:22.750 --> 00:05:28.700
And when I do that, I can see that
it's got 192.168.12.5 set up.

110
00:05:28.700 --> 00:05:32.640
And instead of having the init like it
was initializing, it shows that I've got

111
00:05:32.640 --> 00:05:36.510
a local reference clock, that I'm actually
functioning here, that I'm communicating.

112
00:05:36.510 --> 00:05:40.630
I've got a delay and
an offset listed off to the side here.

113
00:05:40.630 --> 00:05:42.180
I'm communicating with this one.

114
00:05:42.180 --> 00:05:45.240
And I don't just have a tilde over here,
I also have an asterisk,

115
00:05:45.240 --> 00:05:47.400
which tells me I've got a system here.

116
00:05:47.400 --> 00:05:50.750
I've peered with the system,
I'm communicating, and

117
00:05:50.750 --> 00:05:52.460
I'm getting that time, right?

118
00:05:52.460 --> 00:05:53.420
I know it's working.

119
00:05:53.420 --> 00:05:56.170
On the other side it's not, right?

120
00:05:56.170 --> 00:05:58.402
Well you might have already
noticed the problem here,

121
00:05:58.402 --> 00:06:00.158
it's a different IP address, isn't it?

122
00:06:00.158 --> 00:06:03.238
This guy's not peered with 192.168.12.55.

123
00:06:03.238 --> 00:06:05.038
In fact, I bet the host doesn't exist.

124
00:06:05.038 --> 00:06:09.796
We're probably just dealing with
the wrong IP and let's see, wait for

125
00:06:09.796 --> 00:06:11.700
that first one, and yeah.

126
00:06:11.700 --> 00:06:12.660
So, we're not getting there.

127
00:06:12.660 --> 00:06:15.970
So more than likely this is just
as simple as having the wrong IP.

128
00:06:15.970 --> 00:06:18.780
If I set the other one to .5
it will probably be fine.

129
00:06:18.780 --> 00:06:21.090
This one is already set to .5,
that's why it's working.

130
00:06:21.090 --> 00:06:23.570
So, if I change that IP,
we'll probably be in business.

131
00:06:23.570 --> 00:06:25.630
Now, let's say that wasn't the case.

132
00:06:25.630 --> 00:06:29.470
Let's say that this was actually
a little bit harder than a wrong IP.

133
00:06:29.470 --> 00:06:33.398
Well, there's other commands we can use to
troubleshoot NTP which are pretty handy.

134
00:06:33.398 --> 00:06:37.506
So for example, while I've got this one
configured wrong before I can fix it,

135
00:06:37.506 --> 00:06:40.068
if we do something like show ntp status,
right?

136
00:06:40.068 --> 00:06:46.450
Show ntp status will let us see
what our reference time is.

137
00:06:46.450 --> 00:06:49.350
And, if you're communicating with an NTP
server, you will have a time there.

138
00:06:49.350 --> 00:06:52.995
If it's all zeroes, like mine, then you're
not communicating with an NTP server.

139
00:06:52.995 --> 00:06:55.495
So that's a good way to spot that and
kind of see.

140
00:06:55.495 --> 00:06:58.915
And also down here I've got this
system poll interval is 64,

141
00:06:58.915 --> 00:07:02.975
never updated, so
I'm not really communicating with anybody.

142
00:07:02.975 --> 00:07:06.855
But even outside from that,
we could use debugs, right?

143
00:07:06.855 --> 00:07:09.565
So there's several NTP debugs you can do.

144
00:07:09.565 --> 00:07:11.975
I usually do debug NTP packet.

145
00:07:11.975 --> 00:07:14.950
That's a great way just to see the packet
communications that are happening.

146
00:07:14.950 --> 00:07:19.270
But you could do debug NTP all, and
see everything that's going on.

147
00:07:19.270 --> 00:07:24.420
But if I do a debug ntp packet,
it's gonna start that debug,

148
00:07:24.420 --> 00:07:29.010
and when my system goes to send out those
checks, they're trying to send it out to

149
00:07:29.010 --> 00:07:32.120
that other host, and I would see
that I never get a response back.

150
00:07:32.120 --> 00:07:34.460
And this one's gonna just sit
here idle for the most part.

151
00:07:34.460 --> 00:07:36.890
So, let me undebug that.

152
00:07:36.890 --> 00:07:39.580
But that's another command that you
can use that's pretty useful for

153
00:07:39.580 --> 00:07:40.480
troubleshooting this.

154
00:07:40.480 --> 00:07:43.310
But I'm pretty certain here that
I just happen to have a wrong IP.

155
00:07:43.310 --> 00:07:47.520
So if we take a look at that
command that we had before,

156
00:07:47.520 --> 00:07:51.680
let me get that show
running-config back up.

157
00:07:51.680 --> 00:07:53.728
I'm gonna take that other server out.

158
00:07:53.728 --> 00:08:00.868
So I'll do a no ntp server 192.168.12.55,
and then I'll put the new one in.

159
00:08:03.478 --> 00:08:04.730
There we go.

160
00:08:04.730 --> 00:08:07.850
And as soon as we do that we should
start talking to it in the background.

161
00:08:07.850 --> 00:08:12.379
And if I do a show ntp associations,

162
00:08:14.250 --> 00:08:16.880
I can see I'm still initializing
I still have that tilde.

163
00:08:16.880 --> 00:08:18.060
I need to wait for it communicate.

164
00:08:18.060 --> 00:08:20.130
I guess I could ping it and
make sure I can actually get there.

165
00:08:21.450 --> 00:08:23.750
And I can, so
I'm gonna give that just a moment.

166
00:08:23.750 --> 00:08:26.560
It's not necessarily the fastest
thing in the planet.

167
00:08:26.560 --> 00:08:28.950
So we have to give it some time,
it can take 30 seconds,

168
00:08:28.950 --> 00:08:30.830
even 60 seconds in some cases.

169
00:08:30.830 --> 00:08:36.300
And I guess we could be doing like a debug
NTP all right now, and see that happen.

170
00:08:36.300 --> 00:08:39.080
But basically, it's gonna reach out and
start to sync with that host, and

171
00:08:39.080 --> 00:08:40.920
there we go, I'm starting to
see some traffic going on here.

172
00:08:40.920 --> 00:08:42.200
I'm receiving that communication,

173
00:08:42.200 --> 00:08:46.450
and then that last line right here
telling me clock is synchronized, right?

174
00:08:46.450 --> 00:08:50.820
So it just happened and
now if I do a show ntp associations,

175
00:08:52.350 --> 00:08:54.530
I can see that I've got a reference clock.

176
00:08:54.530 --> 00:08:59.560
And I've got that asterisk over to
the side so that I'm peered, and

177
00:08:59.560 --> 00:09:04.280
show ntp status, I can see that I actually
have that reference time filled in,

178
00:09:04.280 --> 00:09:07.740
it's not all zeroes, and
I can see that system poll interval,

179
00:09:07.740 --> 00:09:11.240
last update was 23 seconds ago,
so I know I'm communicating.

180
00:09:11.240 --> 00:09:13.858
And if I do a show clock, there we go.

181
00:09:13.858 --> 00:09:16.318
November 24th, 2015, all right?

182
00:09:16.318 --> 00:09:19.593
So this one turned out to be really easy,
it was just a bad IP address,

183
00:09:19.593 --> 00:09:23.060
wrong NPT server defined, but
be aware of the things it could have been.

184
00:09:23.060 --> 00:09:26.470
It could have been routing issues,
could have been access control lists,

185
00:09:26.470 --> 00:09:29.550
could have been a number of other things
like that, so that's why I wanted to make

186
00:09:29.550 --> 00:09:31.470
sure I showed you guys some of
the other commands, the debugs,

187
00:09:31.470 --> 00:09:34.660
things you might bump into, but this one
turned out to be pretty straightforward.

188
00:09:34.660 --> 00:09:36.230
So that one is all wrapped up.

189
00:09:36.230 --> 00:09:37.808
All right, well,
I hope you guys enjoyed that one.

190
00:09:37.808 --> 00:09:40.708
Stay tuned,
we've got more troubleshooting coming up.

191
00:09:40.708 --> 00:09:48.274
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #6` from set #2. The trouble ticket states that "You are unable to ping 172.14.0.2 from PLABCSCO01 "
episodes.title: Set 2 Issue 6
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.837
[SOUND] All right welcome back to

2
00:00:04.837 --> 00:00:10.240
troubleshooting set number two.

3
00:00:10.240 --> 00:00:12.330
We're moving onto issue number six.

4
00:00:12.330 --> 00:00:14.320
And we've got another reachability issue.

5
00:00:14.320 --> 00:00:16.620
Reachability issues are common
on the exam because.

6
00:00:16.620 --> 00:00:18.290
They can be caused by
any number of things so

7
00:00:18.290 --> 00:00:20.170
it really makes you have to work hard for
it.

8
00:00:20.170 --> 00:00:25.290
For this one, the way the problem reads,
it says, from our PLAB Cisco 01 server,

9
00:00:25.290 --> 00:00:28.259
we're unable to ping 172.14.0.2.

10
00:00:28.259 --> 00:00:31.780
Now that IP address is new to me, so

11
00:00:31.780 --> 00:00:33.770
I don't really know who
we're trying to ping there.

12
00:00:33.770 --> 00:00:37.120
So let's start by looking
at our network diagram.

13
00:00:37.120 --> 00:00:40.600
And looking at my network diagram,
I know that that server,

14
00:00:40.600 --> 00:00:45.880
the server in question is this guy
down here, 192.168.16.10, right?

15
00:00:45.880 --> 00:00:47.170
That's our server.

16
00:00:47.170 --> 00:00:49.020
And that in my LAN,

17
00:00:49.020 --> 00:00:53.120
all of my IPs are really 192.168
dot something dot something.

18
00:00:53.120 --> 00:00:58.083
And here they're telling me I'm trying to
ping 172.14 dot something dot something,

19
00:00:58.083 --> 00:00:59.120
or 14.0.2.

20
00:00:59.120 --> 00:01:02.270
So, I need to look around on my diagram,
and

21
00:01:02.270 --> 00:01:04.800
see if I can't spot that network anywhere.

22
00:01:04.800 --> 00:01:09.970
And I know I've got 16.16 there,
got some public networks over here.

23
00:01:09.970 --> 00:01:13.040
Some public networks over here,
which I'm just scanning real quickly.

24
00:01:13.040 --> 00:01:15.480
And oh, there we go.

25
00:01:15.480 --> 00:01:18.610
Here's 172.14.0.4.

26
00:01:18.610 --> 00:01:24.060
So it looks like this ISP here is on
that network, and our other ISP is also.

27
00:01:24.060 --> 00:01:26.880
So our these guys are 172.14.0.3 and 0.4.

28
00:01:26.880 --> 00:01:32.160
So, there's a host out here on
this network that's 172.14.0.2 and

29
00:01:32.160 --> 00:01:33.610
we're unable to ping it.

30
00:01:33.610 --> 00:01:36.806
Now it was important for me to find that
because I need to understand the path that

31
00:01:36.806 --> 00:01:38.290
I'm gonna follow, right?

32
00:01:38.290 --> 00:01:43.280
My server is gonna go to these switches,
hit the switches, probably get routed

33
00:01:43.280 --> 00:01:47.140
to EDGE2, but it's possible that I could
go to EDGE1 first and then over to EDGE2.

34
00:01:47.140 --> 00:01:49.300
And then up to this network up here.

35
00:01:49.300 --> 00:01:52.475
And with any luck,
that IP might even be assigned to EDGE2.

36
00:01:52.475 --> 00:01:54.445
If it is, that's good,
cuz we have control of it.

37
00:01:54.445 --> 00:01:56.865
If it's a host out here,
we don't have control over it, right?

38
00:01:56.865 --> 00:01:58.415
So we always have to
kinda be aware of that.

39
00:01:58.415 --> 00:02:00.775
So, let's actually verify it real quick.

40
00:02:00.775 --> 00:02:03.775
Let's go see what IP address EDGE2 has,
and that'll help us out.

41
00:02:03.775 --> 00:02:05.135
So, I'm gonna jump over to EDGE2.

42
00:02:06.515 --> 00:02:12.210
And on this one, I'm just gonna do
a real quick, show IP interface brief.

43
00:02:13.240 --> 00:02:15.780
And you'll see what IP it is,
it has assignment, there we go.

44
00:02:15.780 --> 00:02:16.520
Winner.

45
00:02:16.520 --> 00:02:17.270
We've got 172.14.0.2.

46
00:02:17.270 --> 00:02:20.510
Assigned right here to EDGE2.

47
00:02:20.510 --> 00:02:22.910
So on my server

48
00:02:22.910 --> 00:02:27.430
I'm not able to ping what's affectively
the WAN interface of this router.

49
00:02:27.430 --> 00:02:30.130
All right, so that's what they're
telling me and we can verify that.

50
00:02:30.130 --> 00:02:32.770
Just by jumping over to the server.

51
00:02:32.770 --> 00:02:33.900
And giving that a shot, right.

52
00:02:33.900 --> 00:02:36.610
So I can try and ping 172.14.0.2.

53
00:02:36.610 --> 00:02:42.500
And there we go, destination unreachable.

54
00:02:42.500 --> 00:02:46.910
Now, I'm glad I did that ping and
I haven't even done a traceroute yet.

55
00:02:46.910 --> 00:02:51.740
I'm glad I did this ping though because
look at the error message I got back.

56
00:02:51.740 --> 00:02:54.850
I got a destination host unreachable,
and I got it from 192.168.16.3.

57
00:02:54.850 --> 00:02:59.570
Now if you remember from
the earlier questions,

58
00:02:59.570 --> 00:03:05.745
my default gateway is 192.168.16.1.

59
00:03:05.745 --> 00:03:10.360
And .16.1 is the HSRP address.

60
00:03:10.360 --> 00:03:13.980
It's shared between New York CORE1 and
New York CORE2.

61
00:03:13.980 --> 00:03:16.492
And I got that destination
unreachable from CORE2.

62
00:03:16.492 --> 00:03:18.590
So CORE2 is the active one for

63
00:03:18.590 --> 00:03:22.620
that HSRP cluster and I'm getting
the destination unreachable from the hit.

64
00:03:22.620 --> 00:03:26.790
So that means that this problem
is not limited just to my server.

65
00:03:26.790 --> 00:03:30.550
That the problem also extends
out to my core switches.

66
00:03:30.550 --> 00:03:32.530
So my core switches
can't get there either.

67
00:03:32.530 --> 00:03:34.540
So that's a good indicator of a problem.

68
00:03:34.540 --> 00:03:38.740
The core switches are routing so let's
go see if it even has a routing table.

69
00:03:38.740 --> 00:03:41.860
This could be ACLs or whatever but
when you get destination unreachable.

70
00:03:41.860 --> 00:03:43.390
It's usually a routing table issue.

71
00:03:43.390 --> 00:03:45.190
I don't have route to get there so

72
00:03:45.190 --> 00:03:47.065
the destination is unreachable,
I don't have a way.

73
00:03:47.065 --> 00:03:48.040
Right?

74
00:03:48.040 --> 00:03:49.990
So let's go take a look at
CORE2s routing table and

75
00:03:49.990 --> 00:03:51.060
get an idea of what's happening there.

76
00:03:53.370 --> 00:03:55.960
All right so I'm gonna jump over to CORE2.

77
00:03:55.960 --> 00:03:57.716
And let me just zoom in
on this a little bit.

78
00:03:57.716 --> 00:04:04.080
All right so
I'm just gonna do a show IP route.

79
00:04:05.190 --> 00:04:08.680
And punch in the IP that I'm
trying to get to 172.14.0.2.

80
00:04:08.680 --> 00:04:12.140
So I'm doing a show IP route
instead of just a ping.

81
00:04:12.140 --> 00:04:14.010
Because with a ping an ACL can block it.

82
00:04:14.010 --> 00:04:14.620
But show ip route.

83
00:04:14.620 --> 00:04:16.440
I just wanna look at the routing table.

84
00:04:16.440 --> 00:04:17.590
Show me what you want to do.

85
00:04:17.590 --> 00:04:18.820
You don't actually have to do it.

86
00:04:18.820 --> 00:04:21.632
Now when I run that network not in table.

87
00:04:21.632 --> 00:04:26.200
All right now it's easy to look at
that and say well I can't get there.

88
00:04:26.200 --> 00:04:28.789
Right?
But you'll get network not in table.

89
00:04:28.789 --> 00:04:33.110
Even if you have a default route,
a gateway of last resort to find.

90
00:04:33.110 --> 00:04:36.060
So it's possible I have a gateway
of last resort that would work here

91
00:04:36.060 --> 00:04:38.520
even though I don't have
a route in the table.

92
00:04:38.520 --> 00:04:42.420
So I'm gonna do a show IP route just to
see if I have a gateway of last resort.

93
00:04:42.420 --> 00:04:43.090
And I don't.

94
00:04:43.090 --> 00:04:43.690
Right?
So that's it.

95
00:04:43.690 --> 00:04:46.440
So I don't have a default gateway or
a default route.

96
00:04:46.440 --> 00:04:48.080
I have to have in route on
the table to get there.

97
00:04:48.080 --> 00:04:49.740
I don't have a route.

98
00:04:49.740 --> 00:04:52.968
To get to 172.14.0.

99
00:04:52.968 --> 00:04:53.663
Whatever.

100
00:04:53.663 --> 00:04:57.662
So without a route I'm not gonna get there
that's more than likely what my problem is

101
00:04:57.662 --> 00:04:58.190
gonna be.

102
00:04:58.190 --> 00:05:03.490
Now looking at the diagram I'm supposed
to be running RIP Version 2 in

103
00:05:03.490 --> 00:05:08.900
between NYWAN1, NYEDGE2 And NYCORE2.

104
00:05:08.900 --> 00:05:11.200
These three guys are supposed
to be running RIP, and

105
00:05:11.200 --> 00:05:13.840
they should be exchanging routes.

106
00:05:13.840 --> 00:05:18.320
If NYEDGE2 is directly plugged
into the 172.14 network.

107
00:05:18.320 --> 00:05:21.190
It should be sharing
that to CORE2 via RIP.

108
00:05:21.190 --> 00:05:22.225
But that's not happening.

109
00:05:22.225 --> 00:05:22.810
Right.

110
00:05:22.810 --> 00:05:25.420
In fact, is it sharing anything via RIP?

111
00:05:25.420 --> 00:05:27.050
I don't know, let's find out.

112
00:05:27.050 --> 00:05:29.410
First off I need to know what
the internal IP of EDGE2 is.

113
00:05:29.410 --> 00:05:32.227
LIke, what is the IP on GI0/0,
I wanna know that, and

114
00:05:32.227 --> 00:05:35.360
then we'll see what routes
are coming across from it.

115
00:05:35.360 --> 00:05:37.965
So, I'm gonna jump over to EDGE2.

116
00:05:37.965 --> 00:05:45.150
And on EDGE2, that GI00 is 192.168.12.5.

117
00:05:45.150 --> 00:05:48.271
Now I wanted to know that because that's
letting me know that it's on VLAN12.

118
00:05:48.271 --> 00:05:50.750
And I need to make sure I've
got VLAN12 connectivity.

119
00:05:50.750 --> 00:05:51.760
Remember RIP.

120
00:05:51.760 --> 00:05:55.460
RIP just broadcasts, or it's version
two here, so it multicasts, right?

121
00:05:55.460 --> 00:06:00.050
But a multicast won't cross between VLANs
unless we have that set to forward.

122
00:06:00.050 --> 00:06:01.710
So this is on VLAN12.

123
00:06:01.710 --> 00:06:04.950
I need to make sure that CORE2
is listening on VLAN12 also.

124
00:06:04.950 --> 00:06:08.270
I'm trying to build this network map out
a little more than what they gave me.

125
00:06:09.490 --> 00:06:10.710
All right, so, I've got that information.

126
00:06:10.710 --> 00:06:14.170
And, heck, while I'm in here, I can
see if I even have that route, right?

127
00:06:14.170 --> 00:06:15.370
We've got that network.

128
00:06:15.370 --> 00:06:16.870
Well, we have to have that route.

129
00:06:16.870 --> 00:06:17.860
We're directly plugged into it.

130
00:06:17.860 --> 00:06:18.780
That is us.

131
00:06:18.780 --> 00:06:20.320
Obviously, we're gonna
be able to get there.

132
00:06:20.320 --> 00:06:20.850
It is us.

133
00:06:20.850 --> 00:06:23.800
The interface is up, so
I don't even really have to look for that.

134
00:06:23.800 --> 00:06:28.939
All right, so, let's jump into CORE2 and
verify that it's on VLAN12.

135
00:06:30.410 --> 00:06:37.430
And so on this guy, I'm gonna do just
that quick, show ip interface brief.

136
00:06:39.110 --> 00:06:41.620
And I'll exclude
the unassigned interfaces.

137
00:06:41.620 --> 00:06:43.920
And I'm looking for VLAN12, there we go.

138
00:06:43.920 --> 00:06:44.770
So I'm on VLAN12, 192.168.12.3.

139
00:06:44.770 --> 00:06:49.840
And I'm gonna test my connectivity.

140
00:06:49.840 --> 00:06:52.846
To that edge router which was .5.

141
00:06:52.846 --> 00:06:55.650
and I can get there so
I'm good communications wise, right?

142
00:06:55.650 --> 00:06:59.670
So that's telling me back
on my diagram I am able to

143
00:06:59.670 --> 00:07:02.660
communicate across this line
in between these two systems.

144
00:07:02.660 --> 00:07:06.160
So assuming that RIP is configured
right we should be exchanging routes.

145
00:07:06.160 --> 00:07:07.510
And I should be getting a route.

146
00:07:07.510 --> 00:07:09.488
But I'm not, it's not on my routing table.

147
00:07:09.488 --> 00:07:11.326
Why not?

148
00:07:11.326 --> 00:07:15.010
Well keep in mind when a route doesn't
make it into your routing table it can be

149
00:07:15.010 --> 00:07:16.580
a number of different things.

150
00:07:16.580 --> 00:07:20.310
It can be ACLs,
it can be route maps, prefix lists.

151
00:07:20.310 --> 00:07:25.920
It can be routing metrics, administrative
distance, maximum hop count, there's

152
00:07:25.920 --> 00:07:29.380
a ton of things that can stop a route
from making it into your routing table.

153
00:07:29.380 --> 00:07:31.000
But before we jump into
the complex things,

154
00:07:31.000 --> 00:07:32.610
there's some basic
things that it could be.

155
00:07:32.610 --> 00:07:33.660
Be an interface being down.

156
00:07:33.660 --> 00:07:36.250
That's why I did that ping,
can I even communicate?

157
00:07:36.250 --> 00:07:36.820
Right?

158
00:07:36.820 --> 00:07:38.780
It could be a misconfiguration.

159
00:07:38.780 --> 00:07:41.940
Now, there's not a lot of
RIP to configure, right?

160
00:07:41.940 --> 00:07:44.600
With OSPF, maybe we have mismatched areas.

161
00:07:44.600 --> 00:07:48.050
With EIGRP, maybe we have summary routes,
or bad AS numbers.

162
00:07:48.050 --> 00:07:49.130
Things like that.

163
00:07:49.130 --> 00:07:52.700
But in RIP, you really just turn it on and
you set some interfaces.

164
00:07:52.700 --> 00:07:54.580
We could have some passive interfaces,
right?

165
00:07:54.580 --> 00:07:57.220
These interfaces are up and
maybe they're passive, right?

166
00:07:57.220 --> 00:07:58.550
That could cause this problem.

167
00:07:58.550 --> 00:08:01.180
So I need to verify my RIP
configuration [COUGH].

168
00:08:01.180 --> 00:08:02.890
And get in here and
verify this is gonna work.

169
00:08:02.890 --> 00:08:04.420
Now before I do that.

170
00:08:05.450 --> 00:08:08.790
My problem is that CORE2
is missing some routes.

171
00:08:08.790 --> 00:08:11.340
And one of the things that I like to do.

172
00:08:11.340 --> 00:08:14.140
Is if I'm gonna fix the problem,
I wanna know when it works.

173
00:08:14.140 --> 00:08:16.200
I wanna know when those routes show up,
and so

174
00:08:16.200 --> 00:08:19.080
there's a little debug command we can run,
debug IP routing.

175
00:08:19.080 --> 00:08:23.725
And what it does is it says any
time that a route goes in or

176
00:08:23.725 --> 00:08:26.010
comes out of the routing
table we get a message.

177
00:08:26.010 --> 00:08:28.210
And I like to run that
before I get started just so

178
00:08:28.210 --> 00:08:29.540
I can see when I've fixed the problem.

179
00:08:29.540 --> 00:08:31.650
So, I'm gonna do that on CORE2.

180
00:08:31.650 --> 00:08:36.068
So I'm gonna jump back over to CORE2.

181
00:08:36.068 --> 00:08:40.532
And I'm just gonna run debug ip routing.

182
00:08:40.532 --> 00:08:41.210
Right?

183
00:08:41.210 --> 00:08:43.110
And now anytime a route gets added or

184
00:08:43.110 --> 00:08:46.040
removed from the routing table I'll see
a message about it, and so that cool,

185
00:08:46.040 --> 00:08:48.410
that's gonna let me know
when I've fixed the problem.

186
00:08:48.410 --> 00:08:52.239
Then I'm gonna do a show run or
show running-config.

187
00:08:52.239 --> 00:08:55.110
And I wanna view the section for RIP.

188
00:08:55.110 --> 00:08:56.620
All right?

189
00:08:56.620 --> 00:08:58.580
And so when I run that, there we go.

190
00:08:58.580 --> 00:09:01.850
I can see my RIP configuration,
I see router rip version 2.

191
00:09:01.850 --> 00:09:03.870
And I see a bunch of
networks that are added.

192
00:09:03.870 --> 00:09:07.034
Now, on this guy,
I need it to learn rip routes.

193
00:09:07.034 --> 00:09:07.708
From the EDGE router.

194
00:09:07.708 --> 00:09:10.510
And the EDGE router we saw
was on 192.168.12, and

195
00:09:10.510 --> 00:09:13.040
I've got that network added in.

196
00:09:13.040 --> 00:09:15.700
So technically that's
the only line I care about.

197
00:09:15.700 --> 00:09:17.265
I don't really care
about these other lines.

198
00:09:17.265 --> 00:09:20.360
Cuz I'm just trying to learn
from that one EDGE router for

199
00:09:20.360 --> 00:09:21.880
the sake of this troubleshooting question.

200
00:09:21.880 --> 00:09:23.350
So I've got it.

201
00:09:23.350 --> 00:09:25.390
Rip is set for version two.

202
00:09:25.390 --> 00:09:28.110
There's not really much
else to do on that.

203
00:09:28.110 --> 00:09:29.710
It seems to be right.

204
00:09:29.710 --> 00:09:31.820
I don't have any passive
interfaces to find.

205
00:09:31.820 --> 00:09:34.930
I guess I could be overriding
something on the interface itself, so

206
00:09:34.930 --> 00:09:37.690
let's take a look there,
just to be on the safe side.

207
00:09:37.690 --> 00:09:39.420
And, nope, no RIP commands.

208
00:09:39.420 --> 00:09:41.920
Cuz there are interface RIP
commands that you can run.

209
00:09:41.920 --> 00:09:42.990
In this case they are not set.

210
00:09:42.990 --> 00:09:45.170
I don't have any crazy route maps.

211
00:09:45.170 --> 00:09:46.820
This really looks simple.

212
00:09:46.820 --> 00:09:47.390
All right.

213
00:09:47.390 --> 00:09:48.840
So I think we're good here.

214
00:09:48.840 --> 00:09:49.990
Let's go take a look at the other end.

215
00:09:51.370 --> 00:09:56.180
If I jump over to our other one
which remember that's EDGE2 up here.

216
00:09:56.180 --> 00:09:59.160
If I jump up to EDGE2.

217
00:09:59.160 --> 00:10:01.690
And kind of repeat that process, right.

218
00:10:01.690 --> 00:10:04.370
Now in this guy, I'm not gonna bother
debugging it's routing table because it

219
00:10:04.370 --> 00:10:06.550
already has the route in question, right.

220
00:10:06.550 --> 00:10:08.650
It's directly plugged in so it has to.

221
00:10:08.650 --> 00:10:09.750
When I look at it 172.

222
00:10:09.750 --> 00:10:14.230
Woops.
172.14, right there,

223
00:10:14.230 --> 00:10:16.860
is always gonna be in it's routing
table unless the interface is down.

224
00:10:16.860 --> 00:10:20.295
So I don't need to run any
crazy debug to see that.

225
00:10:20.295 --> 00:10:20.951
Right?
But

226
00:10:20.951 --> 00:10:23.310
I do wanna verify it's RIP configuration.

227
00:10:23.310 --> 00:10:27.335
So I'm gonna do a show run, and
I'll filter that for this section for RIP.

228
00:10:29.020 --> 00:10:30.840
And here I've got it.

229
00:10:30.840 --> 00:10:32.090
It's gotten network 172.14.0.0.

230
00:10:32.090 --> 00:10:34.170
So that's the network I wanna learn.

231
00:10:34.170 --> 00:10:38.070
And it's got 192.168.12.0, that where I
want it to advertise, so that looks good.

232
00:10:38.070 --> 00:10:41.050
Looks like a good configuration, right?

233
00:10:42.220 --> 00:10:42.920
Almost.

234
00:10:42.920 --> 00:10:44.440
You've probably spotted it already.

235
00:10:44.440 --> 00:10:47.740
There was one command that was on
the other router that's not on this one.

236
00:10:47.740 --> 00:10:50.110
And that command was version 2.

237
00:10:50.110 --> 00:10:53.850
Okay this router is running in version 1.

238
00:10:53.850 --> 00:10:56.265
The other router is running in version 2.

239
00:10:56.265 --> 00:10:58.460
Now why is that a problem?

240
00:10:58.460 --> 00:11:01.190
Well there is actually a little bit
of compatibility between the two.

241
00:11:01.190 --> 00:11:04.960
But version 1 uses
broadcast to communicate.

242
00:11:04.960 --> 00:11:08.170
Version 2 uses multicast to communicate.

243
00:11:08.170 --> 00:11:12.060
Even communication mechanisms so
they probably don't see each other at all.

244
00:11:12.060 --> 00:11:16.730
The more than likely broadcasting and not
even seeing each other because of that.

245
00:11:16.730 --> 00:11:21.230
A show IP protocols would have turned off
also when you run show IP protocols and

246
00:11:21.230 --> 00:11:22.945
it gives you a list of
the protocols you running.

247
00:11:22.945 --> 00:11:28.640
here's RIP and see you on my
interfaces I'm sending version 1.

248
00:11:28.640 --> 00:11:31.570
And I'm set to receive version 1 and
version 2.

249
00:11:31.570 --> 00:11:34.220
Right.
And so that, sending version 1,

250
00:11:34.220 --> 00:11:36.620
that's how I could have spot for
that right here.

251
00:11:36.620 --> 00:11:40.920
So to fix this, I should just able to move
to version 2, and we'll be in business.

252
00:11:40.920 --> 00:11:41.480
Right.
So

253
00:11:41.480 --> 00:11:43.010
let's see if that's
take care of this here.

254
00:11:43.010 --> 00:11:46.560
So I'm gonna go to configuration and
router rip and

255
00:11:46.560 --> 00:11:48.150
I'll just throw in a version 2.

256
00:11:48.150 --> 00:11:49.050
Whoops.

257
00:11:49.050 --> 00:11:50.230
There we go.

258
00:11:50.230 --> 00:11:52.620
And now,
I should be communicating the new way, and

259
00:11:52.620 --> 00:11:54.870
I can do a show IP
protocols to verify that.

260
00:11:55.990 --> 00:11:58.850
And now, what I should see,
is that I'm sending version 2.

261
00:11:58.850 --> 00:12:03.120
And see how, when I put myself into
