version 2, what happened to my receives.

262
00:12:03.120 --> 00:12:05.750
They went to receive only version 2.

263
00:12:05.750 --> 00:12:06.650
So, on the other side,

264
00:12:06.650 --> 00:12:09.830
it was only receiving version 2,
when I was sending version 1.

265
00:12:09.830 --> 00:12:11.100
It was getting ignored.

266
00:12:11.100 --> 00:12:12.930
So we weren't communicating, right?

267
00:12:12.930 --> 00:12:15.880
A debug ip rip probably would
have turned that up also.

268
00:12:15.880 --> 00:12:20.590
You can do, what is it,
debug ip rip, packets or events.

269
00:12:20.590 --> 00:12:21.410
Events.

270
00:12:21.410 --> 00:12:24.230
Debug ip rip events probably
would have turned that up.

271
00:12:24.230 --> 00:12:25.690
Debug ip packets would
have turned it up too,

272
00:12:25.690 --> 00:12:28.540
but it probably would have
been way too much information.

273
00:12:28.540 --> 00:12:31.170
We found it without doing a debug, really.

274
00:12:31.170 --> 00:12:34.590
Now I'm kind of stalling here
because RIP runs on timers.

275
00:12:34.590 --> 00:12:37.240
So every 30 seconds it's
sending out table updates.

276
00:12:37.240 --> 00:12:39.370
So I'm just waiting for
that 30 seconds to pass.

277
00:12:39.370 --> 00:12:41.630
The other side should learn about it and
start to learn the routes.

278
00:12:41.630 --> 00:12:45.020
Now I am running debug IP
routing on the other side.

279
00:12:45.020 --> 00:12:48.545
So if those routes make it in the routing
table I should see them on debug messages.

280
00:12:48.545 --> 00:12:50.550
Well, let's see if that happen.

281
00:12:50.550 --> 00:12:54.050
So I'm gonna jump over to the other side
here and take a look at New York CORE2.

282
00:12:54.050 --> 00:12:56.450
And well this isn't what I wanted to see.

283
00:12:56.450 --> 00:12:58.100
So I left a debug running.

284
00:12:58.100 --> 00:12:59.340
Right?
It was supposed to debug and

285
00:12:59.340 --> 00:13:01.690
tell me when a route got
added to the routing table.

286
00:13:01.690 --> 00:13:03.080
Nothing has happened.

287
00:13:03.080 --> 00:13:05.190
Right?
It's still just kinda sitting here and

288
00:13:05.190 --> 00:13:09.140
maybe I turned it on on the wrong switch,
but I was pretty sure I turned it on here.

289
00:13:09.140 --> 00:13:12.320
Let's see.
I've got IP routing turned on.

290
00:13:12.320 --> 00:13:15.010
I'm probably not logging to console for
this one so

291
00:13:15.010 --> 00:13:16.160
that's probably why I'm not seeing it.

292
00:13:16.160 --> 00:13:17.790
So its too late to fix that.

293
00:13:17.790 --> 00:13:21.550
If you ever this, if you turn on
debugging and you don't get any messages.

294
00:13:21.550 --> 00:13:25.080
If your SSH or terminal end,
remember that you need to run terminal

295
00:13:25.080 --> 00:13:28.080
monitor like that or
you won't see the commands.

296
00:13:28.080 --> 00:13:31.720
But I'm in the console and so the command
I have to run is logging console and

297
00:13:31.720 --> 00:13:35.290
you do that from config, so it's turned
off here but I'm not worried about it.

298
00:13:35.290 --> 00:13:37.780
Let's take a look at the routing table and
see if that route made it.

299
00:13:37.780 --> 00:13:39.720
I'm gonna do a show IP route.

300
00:13:39.720 --> 00:13:43.120
And I'm gonna filter it to just
show me rip routes, right?

301
00:13:43.120 --> 00:13:44.650
Because that's all I care about.

302
00:13:44.650 --> 00:13:46.840
And so I'm gonna go to show IP route rip.

303
00:13:46.840 --> 00:13:51.960
And now I can see 172.14.0.0
is in the routing table,

304
00:13:51.960 --> 00:13:54.640
and that will most likely fix our problem.

305
00:13:54.640 --> 00:13:58.140
So if I try and ping out to that host,
that's who I couldn't get to, and

306
00:13:58.140 --> 00:14:01.770
I do need to troubleshoot from my server,
cuz that's where all this originated.

307
00:14:01.770 --> 00:14:03.200
This guy right here.

308
00:14:03.200 --> 00:14:04.430
And so, I'm gonna jump back to it.

309
00:14:06.440 --> 00:14:09.736
And I'm gonna repeat the ping
that started it all.

310
00:14:09.736 --> 00:14:13.916
I'm gonna try and ping 172.14.0.2.

311
00:14:13.916 --> 00:14:15.193
And now we can get there.

312
00:14:15.193 --> 00:14:15.797
Right?

313
00:14:15.797 --> 00:14:20.430
So this problem blow down
to RIP version mismatches.

314
00:14:20.430 --> 00:14:23.310
If somebody's set to RIP version 1 and
somebody else is set to RIP version 2.

315
00:14:23.310 --> 00:14:25.630
They're not going to communicate.

316
00:14:25.630 --> 00:14:28.172
Now there was another way
I could have solved this.

317
00:14:28.172 --> 00:14:32.390
I could've set the version 2 router
to accept version 1 messages or

318
00:14:32.390 --> 00:14:34.000
I could have even
downgraded it to version 1.

319
00:14:34.000 --> 00:14:37.590
But in this case the easiest solution
was to move to version 2 which is

320
00:14:37.590 --> 00:14:38.230
preferred, right.

321
00:14:38.230 --> 00:14:40.280
We always wanna deploy
version 2 if we can.

322
00:14:40.280 --> 00:14:41.630
Because it's classless.

323
00:14:42.730 --> 00:14:46.790
RIP version 1 is classful and that can
cause some other problems on the network.

324
00:14:46.790 --> 00:14:51.330
So going version 2 is the easiest solution
here and more than likely the correct one.

325
00:14:51.330 --> 00:14:54.360
All right, well that is another
troublingshooting issue under our belts.

326
00:14:54.360 --> 00:14:55.990
That one's wrapped up,
turned out to be not so

327
00:14:55.990 --> 00:14:57.850
bad once we tracked down the problem.

328
00:14:57.850 --> 00:15:00.290
The fixes usually are kinda
easy at that point.

329
00:15:00.290 --> 00:15:01.630
But, hope you guys enjoyed it.

330
00:15:01.630 --> 00:15:05.824
Stay tuned, we've got more
troubleshooting issues coming up.

331
00:15:05.824 --> 00:15:10.153
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #7` from set #2. The trouble ticket states that "You are unable to ping 100.10.10.10 which is a loopback interface on NYCORE1 from PLABCSCO01 "
episodes.title: Set 2 Issue 7
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:04.924
[SOUND] All right welcome

2
00:00:04.924 --> 00:00:09.593
back to Set number 2.

3
00:00:09.593 --> 00:00:12.630
We're moving into the final issue
on this one, Issue number 7.

4
00:00:12.630 --> 00:00:14.830
And well, wouldn't you know it,

5
00:00:14.830 --> 00:00:17.560
looks like our Cisco server is
unable to ping an IP address.

6
00:00:17.560 --> 00:00:19.020
Can this guy ping anybody?

7
00:00:19.020 --> 00:00:21.371
I mean, really, the troubleshooting
question reads like this.

8
00:00:21.371 --> 00:00:25.911
It says you are unable
to ping 100.10.10.10,

9
00:00:25.911 --> 00:00:29.726
easy to remember, 100.10.10.10,

10
00:00:29.726 --> 00:00:35.283
which is a loopback interface on
New York Core 1, from PLab Cisco 01.

11
00:00:35.283 --> 00:00:37.390
Well, this actually
sounds like an easy one.

12
00:00:37.390 --> 00:00:38.880
Let's take a look at the topology.

13
00:00:38.880 --> 00:00:41.050
The easier it sounds,
the harder it probably is though, so

14
00:00:41.050 --> 00:00:42.230
I'm a little cautious.

15
00:00:42.230 --> 00:00:46.542
But, they're telling me that
there's a loopback interface here

16
00:00:46.542 --> 00:00:49.857
on NYCORE1 that's 100.10.10.10.

17
00:00:49.857 --> 00:00:51.901
And I'm trying to ping
it from this server,

18
00:00:51.901 --> 00:00:54.670
there's not a whole lot
involved in this equation.

19
00:00:54.670 --> 00:00:57.237
I've got a work station that's
gonna ping to ACCESS1, and

20
00:00:57.237 --> 00:01:00.073
then it's gonna go to one of these
two guys cuz it has to get routed.

21
00:01:00.073 --> 00:01:02.442
And if it's anything
like the previous issues,

22
00:01:02.442 --> 00:01:04.910
I'm gonna get sent to CORE2 to get routed.

23
00:01:04.910 --> 00:01:09.970
Cuz I've gotta get routed from the
192.168.16 network that that sever resides

24
00:01:09.970 --> 00:01:15.120
on, over to this other system, this
other loopback to then pass over there.

25
00:01:15.120 --> 00:01:18.744
So I got a few little hops that
I'm gonna have to go through but

26
00:01:18.744 --> 00:01:22.741
it should just be a simple path
like that and, that's it, right?

27
00:01:22.741 --> 00:01:24.971
Just three devices I need to look at and
kinda solve that problem.

28
00:01:24.971 --> 00:01:27.408
Now, I am going to have to get routed.

29
00:01:27.408 --> 00:01:29.923
I'm on the 192.168.16 network,

30
00:01:29.923 --> 00:01:34.950
100.10.10.10 is a different network
no matter what subnet mask I use.

31
00:01:34.950 --> 00:01:39.680
So, in order to get to that one,
I'm gonna have to get routed and

32
00:01:39.680 --> 00:01:41.790
I know that my default
gateway is 192.168.16.1.

33
00:01:41.790 --> 00:01:46.576
And as we've seen time and
time again, that is right here,

34
00:01:46.576 --> 00:01:49.852
this is the active HSRP node for that IP.

35
00:01:49.852 --> 00:01:51.382
So I should be going there,

36
00:01:51.382 --> 00:01:55.650
and then somehow magically hopping
over to CORE1 to access this loopback.

37
00:01:55.650 --> 00:01:59.530
Now that means my problem is
most likely not on NYACCESS1.

38
00:01:59.530 --> 00:02:02.220
If I can ping my default gateway
then I can rule that one out, and

39
00:02:02.220 --> 00:02:05.090
I can narrow my troubleshooting
down to just these two hosts.

40
00:02:05.090 --> 00:02:05.720
So let's do that.

41
00:02:05.720 --> 00:02:07.600
I'm gonna go see if I can
ping my default gateway,

42
00:02:07.600 --> 00:02:11.290
and then I'll see if I can ping the IP
that actually in trouble anyway.

43
00:02:11.290 --> 00:02:15.987
So I'm gonna jump back to that server,
so here's the server in question.

44
00:02:15.987 --> 00:02:18.055
And if I do a quick ipconfig,

45
00:02:18.055 --> 00:02:23.067
I can see that my IP address
is indeed 192.168.16.10.

46
00:02:23.067 --> 00:02:28.390
And my default gateway is .1, and
let's see if I can ping that gateway.

47
00:02:28.390 --> 00:02:34.690
So if I do a quick ping to 192.168.16.1,
I am able to ping it, okay.

48
00:02:34.690 --> 00:02:38.340
So, at that point I can kind of rule out
this work station as the problem and

49
00:02:38.340 --> 00:02:40.300
I can rule out NYACCESS1.

50
00:02:40.300 --> 00:02:44.490
And I can focus the rest of my
efforts on NYCORE1 and CORE2, right,

51
00:02:44.490 --> 00:02:46.910
narrow down the scope of the problem.

52
00:02:46.910 --> 00:02:48.950
So let's jump over to CORE2.

53
00:02:48.950 --> 00:02:50.800
Well actually, let's start on CORE1.

54
00:02:50.800 --> 00:02:52.900
They're telling me it's
a loopback interface.

55
00:02:52.900 --> 00:02:55.090
I don't recall seeing it earlier so
maybe it's missing,

56
00:02:55.090 --> 00:02:58.510
or maybe just magically appeared
in time for this exam question.

57
00:02:58.510 --> 00:02:59.850
[LAUGH] That can happen.

58
00:02:59.850 --> 00:03:01.430
So let me jump over to CORE1, and

59
00:03:01.430 --> 00:03:04.958
let's verify that it is actually set
up the way they say it's set up.

60
00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:09.543
So on CORE1, I'm just gonna do
a quick show ip int brief and

61
00:03:09.543 --> 00:03:11.848
kinda see what's out there.

62
00:03:14.554 --> 00:03:17.220
And I'll exclude
the unassigned interfaces.

63
00:03:17.220 --> 00:03:20.201
And so if I look at it,
I do have a loopback way down here and,

64
00:03:20.201 --> 00:03:22.362
sure enough 100.10.10.10.

65
00:03:22.362 --> 00:03:26.752
That's its IP and it is up,
up ,as loopbacks typically tend to be.

66
00:03:26.752 --> 00:03:31.508
And if I do a quick
show running-config for

67
00:03:31.508 --> 00:03:34.553
lo0, for that loopback.

68
00:03:34.553 --> 00:03:36.759
Whoops, for int lo0.

69
00:03:38.917 --> 00:03:40.427
Well, it's not liking that.

70
00:03:40.427 --> 00:03:43.100
Oh, it's loopback 10,
I'm reading it wrong.

71
00:03:43.100 --> 00:03:45.160
So, sometimes you gotta pay
attention to what's on the screen.

72
00:03:45.160 --> 00:03:47.600
It is loopback 10, not loopback 0.

73
00:03:47.600 --> 00:03:49.960
So I'm gonna do a quick
show running-config for

74
00:03:49.960 --> 00:03:52.900
int lo10, just to see if there's
any weird on there, right?

75
00:03:52.900 --> 00:03:56.080
You might have access lists,
you might have policies,

76
00:03:56.080 --> 00:03:58.210
there's all sorts of things
you can have on there.

77
00:03:58.210 --> 00:04:01.860
Not on a loopback normally though, this
one looks to be up and happy, all right.

78
00:04:01.860 --> 00:04:04.521
So it's up and happy,
it's there, it's great.

79
00:04:04.521 --> 00:04:06.260
I can get to it, right?

80
00:04:06.260 --> 00:04:08.020
Well, hopefully, we'll see.

81
00:04:08.020 --> 00:04:11.280
When you create loopback interfaces on
a switch, they're layer three ports,

82
00:04:11.280 --> 00:04:12.660
they're not switch ports.

83
00:04:12.660 --> 00:04:15.590
And that means they don't have a VLAN
number assigned to it, so there is no

84
00:04:15.590 --> 00:04:19.276
VLAN number assigned to this interface,
it's just a layer three interface.

85
00:04:19.276 --> 00:04:21.595
So there's gonna have to
be some routing involved,

86
00:04:21.595 --> 00:04:23.187
I'm gonna have to get routed to it.

87
00:04:23.187 --> 00:04:27.640
Well, the other switch, CORE2, that's
the one that's active for HSRP right now.

88
00:04:27.640 --> 00:04:30.710
So I'm going there,
that's where the routing has to happen.

89
00:04:30.710 --> 00:04:34.510
But the route then has to send somebody
over here, it's kinda convoluted.

90
00:04:34.510 --> 00:04:38.330
And so a dynamic routing protocol
is what would normally work.

91
00:04:38.330 --> 00:04:42.305
But if I go back to my diagram here,
I can see that I am running RIP for

92
00:04:42.305 --> 00:04:45.252
NYWAN1, NYEDGE2, and NYCORE2.

93
00:04:45.252 --> 00:04:48.400
NYCORE1 is not participating in RIP.

94
00:04:48.400 --> 00:04:53.640
So, that means NYCORE2 doesn't necessarily
know about that loopback, does it?

95
00:04:53.640 --> 00:04:56.650
Well, it might, maybe we put it in
there with the static route, right?

96
00:04:56.650 --> 00:05:00.020
Or, maybe it's undocumented that this
guy is actually participating in RIP,

97
00:05:00.020 --> 00:05:01.140
we don't really know.

98
00:05:01.140 --> 00:05:02.410
Let's take a look, right?

99
00:05:02.410 --> 00:05:04.970
So I'll start here in CORE1 and
see if it's running a routing protocol.

100
00:05:06.910 --> 00:05:11.610
Easiest way to find that is show ip
protocols, so I will do exactly that.

101
00:05:13.110 --> 00:05:17.996
And, well I am running ospf, that's
good to know, so ospf 100 is running.

102
00:05:17.996 --> 00:05:20.944
I'm running it for a couple of networks,
neither of which are my loopback, and

103
00:05:20.944 --> 00:05:22.290
that's not gonna help me.

104
00:05:22.290 --> 00:05:23.510
But I am running ospf.

105
00:05:23.510 --> 00:05:26.337
The other router,
I mean the other switch in this case,

106
00:05:26.337 --> 00:05:29.478
may not be running ospf though,
so this may not help me at all.

107
00:05:29.478 --> 00:05:33.906
But I am running it, I am running
it on the 192.168.16 network, but

108
00:05:33.906 --> 00:05:35.660
my loopback is not a part of it.

109
00:05:35.660 --> 00:05:39.200
And hey, maybe that 's the problem,
maybe the loopback should be a part of it.

110
00:05:39.200 --> 00:05:42.690
But, if the other side's not running ospf
then I'm gonna have a problem there.

111
00:05:42.690 --> 00:05:44.380
All right, so
let's go take a look at the other side,

112
00:05:44.380 --> 00:05:45.840
I'm gonna switch over to CORE2.

113
00:05:47.910 --> 00:05:53.460
And on CORE2,
I'm gonna do a show ip protocols,

114
00:05:53.460 --> 00:05:55.320
and just verify that it
is running something.

115
00:05:55.320 --> 00:05:58.590
It's running RIP, so
I've got that, and that's it.

116
00:05:58.590 --> 00:06:01.810
So I'm just running RIP,
not running OSPF or anything else.

117
00:06:01.810 --> 00:06:05.410
So I'm not gonna learn OSPF routes
from the other side anyway.

118
00:06:05.410 --> 00:06:09.800
So even I brought that loopback
interface into OSPF, it wouldn't matter,

119
00:06:09.800 --> 00:06:11.690
we're not gonna learn it here, all right.

120
00:06:11.690 --> 00:06:15.570
Well, do I have a route for
that network at all, right?

121
00:06:15.570 --> 00:06:20.512
I'm gonna do a show ip route and
I'm gonna filter that for 100.10.10.

122
00:06:20.512 --> 00:06:24.200
So I'm just gonna look for any line on
that and, hey I got a route for it, right?

123
00:06:24.200 --> 00:06:26.840
Here's a route, 100.10.10.10.

124
00:06:26.840 --> 00:06:29.300
Somebody took the time to put
a static route in there so

125
00:06:29.300 --> 00:06:30.390
I'd be able to get to it.

126
00:06:30.390 --> 00:06:31.770
That was very nice of them, right?

127
00:06:31.770 --> 00:06:35.070
So I've got a static route, now I don't
have to worry about the routing protocol.

128
00:06:35.070 --> 00:06:38.892
In theory what's happening is
my traffic leaves my server,

129
00:06:38.892 --> 00:06:41.996
crosses ACCESS1 and
goes to my default gateway at CORE2.

130
00:06:41.996 --> 00:06:47.072
And at CORE2 it says, all right, I need
to get you to the 100.10.10.10 network,

131
00:06:47.072 --> 00:06:50.124
I've got a static route and
it tells me where to send you.

132
00:06:50.124 --> 00:06:57.722
And it's sending me to .5,
it's sending me to 192.168.12.5.

133
00:06:57.722 --> 00:06:59.160
Well who is that?

134
00:06:59.160 --> 00:07:03.664
Well, if you just did Issue number
6 you'll remember that 12.5 is our

135
00:07:03.664 --> 00:07:04.990
Edge router.

136
00:07:04.990 --> 00:07:08.140
That is this guy up here, NYEDGE2.

137
00:07:08.140 --> 00:07:12.170
So this guy is gonna send that route and
send that traffic up to here.

138
00:07:12.170 --> 00:07:14.390
That's not really the right way, is it?

139
00:07:14.390 --> 00:07:17.973
Well it could be, right, we could set it
up here and then send it over to EDGE1 and

140
00:07:17.973 --> 00:07:19.477
then send it back down to CORE1.

141
00:07:19.477 --> 00:07:23.950
Little bit round about way of
going about it but it might work.

142
00:07:23.950 --> 00:07:25.000
The problem with that is there's so

143
00:07:25.000 --> 00:07:28.420
many hops that you'll have to have return
paths back to get the traffic back.

144
00:07:28.420 --> 00:07:30.775
It can be really messy,
it may or may not work.

145
00:07:30.775 --> 00:07:32.640
You'll probably have to do a static here,
a static here,

146
00:07:32.640 --> 00:07:34.070
to get it all the way around.

147
00:07:34.070 --> 00:07:37.300
So, what's more than likely going on
here is that we just have it pointing to

148
00:07:37.300 --> 00:07:41.100
the wrong place, right,
not going where we want it.

149
00:07:41.100 --> 00:07:43.620
Now, I probably could've
spotted this a different way.

150
00:07:43.620 --> 00:07:46.149
From the server,
I could have done a tracert.

151
00:07:46.149 --> 00:07:49.865
So if I go back to my server and,
instead of doing a ping,

152
00:07:49.865 --> 00:07:52.805
I could do a tracert out to that one,
right?

153
00:07:52.805 --> 00:08:01.620
So I could do a tracert to 100.10.10.10
to see what path I follow.

154
00:08:01.620 --> 00:08:04.190
And the first step on that journey
is gonna be my Default Gateway,

155
00:08:04.190 --> 00:08:07.090
which I did the ping here
to verify I could get to.

156
00:08:07.090 --> 00:08:12.530
The second hop would be 192.168.12.5,
which would be that Edge server.

157
00:08:12.530 --> 00:08:15.360
And looks like I can get to that
too cuz I'm getting a response.

158
00:08:15.360 --> 00:08:20.070
But then that guy needs to send me
somewhere, and where's it gonna send me?

159
00:08:20.070 --> 00:08:22.770
Well, it depends,
it could have a route, but

160
00:08:22.770 --> 00:08:25.550
instead it's telling me
Destination host unreachable.

161
00:08:25.550 --> 00:08:28.210
So because of that,

162
00:08:28.210 --> 00:08:32.120
I know that this Edge server up here
doesn't have a route to get there.

163
00:08:32.120 --> 00:08:35.170
I mean, I can go and verify it, let's go
and verify it just for completeness so

164
00:08:35.170 --> 00:08:36.770
we can say we did it all, right.

165
00:08:36.770 --> 00:08:42.660
So I'll go to NYEDGE2 and,
let me get logged back into this thing.

166
00:08:42.660 --> 00:08:48.331
And on NYEDGE2,
I'm just gonna do a show ip route for

167
00:08:48.331 --> 00:08:51.619
100.10.10.10.

168
00:08:51.619 --> 00:08:52.896
Network not in table.

169
00:08:52.896 --> 00:08:56.970
And if I do a show ip route,
do I have a gateway of last resort?

170
00:08:56.970 --> 00:08:59.050
I don't, so
I have no gateway of last resort and

171
00:08:59.050 --> 00:09:02.740
that network is not in my table,
so this guy has no route.

172
00:09:02.740 --> 00:09:05.770
So it looks like I've got a choice
here on how I'm gonna fix this one.

173
00:09:07.090 --> 00:09:12.500
My traffic is leaving the server and
making it to NYCORE2,

174
00:09:12.500 --> 00:09:17.440
and from here, a static route is sending
it to NYEDGE1, so now I've got a choice.

175
00:09:17.440 --> 00:09:20.860
I could put a static route on,
NYEDGE2, sorry, so

176
00:09:20.860 --> 00:09:23.510
we're leaving NYCORE2 to go to NYEDGE2.

177
00:09:23.510 --> 00:09:28.090
I could put a static route on NYEDGE2
to send the traffic to NYEDGE1.

178
00:09:28.090 --> 00:09:32.740
And then I could put a static route
here to send it back to CORE1, right.

179
00:09:32.740 --> 00:09:34.320
That's a lot of routes.

180
00:09:34.320 --> 00:09:37.310
Or, I could just change
the static route on CORE2

181
00:09:37.310 --> 00:09:41.385
to send this directly over to CORE1,
that's probably the better path, okay.

182
00:09:41.385 --> 00:09:44.120
S that's what I'm gonna do,
is I'm gonna take this static route, and

183
00:09:44.120 --> 00:09:46.890
just redirect it and
point it to the other place, all right.

184
00:09:46.890 --> 00:09:48.960
And that's easy enough for us.

185
00:09:48.960 --> 00:09:53.080
Well, assuming that static route
isn't some crazy policy-based thing.

186
00:09:53.080 --> 00:09:54.168
So let's go verify that.

187
00:09:54.168 --> 00:09:56.400
Sometimes you can get over
your head real fast on these.

188
00:09:57.850 --> 00:10:04.200
All right, so let's do a show run and
I'm just gonna look for that static route.

189
00:10:04.200 --> 00:10:07.570
So when you do a static route,
you say ip route something.

190
00:10:07.570 --> 00:10:11.090
So I'm just gonna search for
that line, and there it is.

191
00:10:11.090 --> 00:10:12.220
So, nothing special here.

192
00:10:12.220 --> 00:10:16.170
No track objects, nothing crazy to worry
about, just a straight-up IP route for

193
00:10:16.170 --> 00:10:20.520
that network being sent
to that destination.

194
00:10:20.520 --> 00:10:24.930
And notice that subnet mask,
all 255s so a 32-bit subnet mask, so

195
00:10:24.930 --> 00:10:27.838
were just routing to that one IP and
that's it.

196
00:10:27.838 --> 00:10:30.688
Now I have to be careful here
because if I add a route, well,

197
00:10:30.688 --> 00:10:34.990
they'll both make it in the routing table,
they'll have an equal-cost metric.

198
00:10:34.990 --> 00:10:38.480
So I need to remove the route that's
there before I put my new route in.

199
00:10:38.480 --> 00:10:42.500
So I'm gonna say, no ip route,
and get rid of that route.

200
00:10:44.600 --> 00:10:49.180
And we'll just get rid of that one so
that it's outta there.

201
00:10:49.180 --> 00:10:52.149
And I'm gonna verify that it's actually
gone cuz sometimes you don't get proper

202
00:10:52.149 --> 00:10:52.760
confirmation.

203
00:10:52.760 --> 00:10:56.877
So, I'm just gonna rerun
that show run command and

204
00:10:56.877 --> 00:10:59.668
kinda filter it, and it's gone.

205
00:10:59.668 --> 00:11:02.400
And now I'm gonna put
a new route in place.

206
00:11:02.400 --> 00:11:05.990
And when I put that new route in place,
I'm gonna send it to the other switch.

207
00:11:05.990 --> 00:11:08.460
Now, what IP address I'm gonna use for

208
00:11:08.460 --> 00:11:11.140
that destination because
I've got choices here.

209
00:11:11.140 --> 00:11:12.490
It's nice to have choices.

210
00:11:12.490 --> 00:11:16.860
So, NYCORE2 needs to be
able to talk to NYCORE1.

211
00:11:16.860 --> 00:11:19.180
And it can communicate, probably,

212
00:11:19.180 --> 00:11:21.880
on several different networks cuz
they're routing for several VLANs.

213
00:11:21.880 --> 00:11:25.630
It doesn't really matter which one I pick,
I just need to pick one of them.

214
00:11:25.630 --> 00:11:30.578
Well, I was talking to this guy up here
on VLAN12, so maybe I'll stick with that.

215
00:11:30.578 --> 00:11:35.165
We were using VLAN12 up here, I'll bet
NYCORE1 has an interface on VLAN12 also.

216
00:11:35.165 --> 00:11:39.882
Let's test that though,
I'll jump over to CORE1, and

217
00:11:39.882 --> 00:11:45.896
just do a quick show ip int brief and
exclude the unassigned interfaces.

218
00:11:45.896 --> 00:11:50.086
And I'm gonna look for anything on 12,
there we go we've got 12.2, so

219
00:11:50.086 --> 00:11:51.638
I'll try and route to that.

220
00:11:51.638 --> 00:11:54.550
I should probably test
reachability before I get too far.

221
00:11:54.550 --> 00:11:57.308
I don't wanna put a route in for
some IP that I can't even get to, right?

222
00:11:57.308 --> 00:12:03.883
So let me just do a quick
ping to 192.168.12.2 and,

223
00:12:03.883 --> 00:12:07.510
there we go, and it's good.

224
00:12:07.510 --> 00:12:12.460
All right, so originally, the way the
route read, you can see it up here where

225
00:12:12.460 --> 00:12:18.471
we did a route for 100.10.10.10 and
we pointed it to 192.168.12.5.

226
00:12:18.471 --> 00:12:23.159
I'm just gonna change it, so
that it points to .2 instead,

227
00:12:23.159 --> 00:12:25.850
which is the other switch.

228
00:12:25.850 --> 00:12:27.179
So we're gonna redirect that.

229
00:12:30.904 --> 00:12:34.730
And point it to that other IP, okay?

230
00:12:34.730 --> 00:12:36.360
And once I've got that in place,

231
00:12:36.360 --> 00:12:38.780
now I have a route that should
be a little more valid.

232
00:12:38.780 --> 00:12:42.340
And this switch didn't have
a valid route before so

233
00:12:42.340 --> 00:12:45.850
we should be able to ping now,
what we couldn't ping a moment ago.

234
00:12:47.090 --> 00:12:49.620
And if I do that ping,
it's working from here.

235
00:12:49.620 --> 00:12:55.890
The ultimate test is going to be jumping
over to our server and testing from here.

236
00:12:55.890 --> 00:12:58.662
So, looking at this guy,

237
00:12:58.662 --> 00:13:04.585
if I just do a quick ping to 100.10.10.10,

238
00:13:04.585 --> 00:13:08.999
and survey says, mm, not looking good.

239
00:13:08.999 --> 00:13:13.195
Oh there we go, all right, so [LAUGH] that
first one we might lose because of ARPs,

240
00:13:13.195 --> 00:13:15.130
but the other one should succeed.

241
00:13:15.130 --> 00:13:17.370
If they don't,
I might stall another issue.

242
00:13:17.370 --> 00:13:20.600
I fixed the path on the way there, but
as is the way with static routes, we have

243
00:13:20.600 --> 00:13:23.999
to worry about the return path also, that
would be the next thing I troubleshot.

244
00:13:23.999 --> 00:13:26.662
But in this case, it actually did work,
we're able to get there and

245
00:13:26.662 --> 00:13:27.987
communicate with that network.

246
00:13:27.987 --> 00:13:32.790
So, this problem really boiled down to
a static route that was pointing to

247
00:13:32.790 --> 00:13:34.770
the wrong destination.

248
00:13:34.770 --> 00:13:36.420
And we always have to
be careful with those,

249
00:13:36.420 --> 00:13:40.260
because static routes can override
dynamic routing protocols.

250
00:13:40.260 --> 00:13:44.470
They have a really low administrative
distance, right, an admin distance of one.

251
00:13:44.470 --> 00:13:47.320
The only thing that beats a static
route is a directly connected route.

252
00:13:47.320 --> 00:13:49.999
So I could have a perfectly
valid RIP route coming in and

253
00:13:49.999 --> 00:13:51.581
the static route overrides it.

254
00:13:51.581 --> 00:13:53.891
So always be on the lookout for
static routes and

255
00:13:53.891 --> 00:13:55.810
don't assume that they're correct.

256
00:13:55.810 --> 00:13:59.262
Oftentimes they can point the wrong way
and that's exactly what we had right here.

257
00:13:59.262 --> 00:14:03.374
All right, well that wraps up Issue 7,
and it wraps up Set 2.

258
00:14:03.374 --> 00:14:07.099
But stay tuned cuz we're gonna be
starting Set 3 next as we continue our

259
00:14:07.099 --> 00:14:08.726
troubleshooting adventure.

260
00:14:08.726 --> 00:14:09.887
Hope to see you then.

261
00:14:09.887 --> 00:14:17.679
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #1` from set #3. The trouble ticket states that "PLABCSCO01 is unable to ping its default gateway "
episodes.title: Set 3 Issue 1
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:08.550
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.550 --> 00:00:12.890
Well, it's that time again, the time to
start a new set of troubleshooting issues.

3
00:00:12.890 --> 00:00:16.970
We're gonna be kicking off with set number
three now as we move into a slightly

4
00:00:16.970 --> 00:00:19.500
different topology than what
we had in the earlier sets.

5
00:00:19.500 --> 00:00:21.360
Few little things have been moved around,
and

6
00:00:21.360 --> 00:00:24.600
that means we need to have our eyes on,
we need to be looking for

7
00:00:24.600 --> 00:00:26.840
slight changes that could influence
the way that our problems work.

8
00:00:26.840 --> 00:00:29.410
It's really easy on the exam as
you move between question and

9
00:00:29.410 --> 00:00:32.270
question to start assuming
things about the topology.

10
00:00:32.270 --> 00:00:33.910
We have to make sure we don't do that.

11
00:00:33.910 --> 00:00:37.540
Well, here we've got what looks like
mostly the same equipment as before,

12
00:00:37.540 --> 00:00:38.970
couple of variations and

13
00:00:38.970 --> 00:00:42.440
we've got a problem that really sounds
like something we've before also.

14
00:00:42.440 --> 00:00:46.970
Our troubleshooting issue number one is,
PLABCISCO01, that server we've

15
00:00:46.970 --> 00:00:51.540
worked with so many times,
is unable to ping its default gateway.

16
00:00:51.540 --> 00:00:55.120
All right, well I know in the previous
sets the default gateway for

17
00:00:55.120 --> 00:00:59.400
that server was actually a virtual
IP assigned to an HSRP cluster and

18
00:00:59.400 --> 00:01:01.110
we had to deal with that a good bit.

19
00:01:01.110 --> 00:01:03.480
Well I don't know if
that's still the same way.

20
00:01:03.480 --> 00:01:06.210
So when we kick this problem off,
I kind of need to start off with a little

21
00:01:06.210 --> 00:01:09.200
research and let's start with
the network topology here first.

22
00:01:09.200 --> 00:01:11.500
The server that's causing,
well not causing the problem,

23
00:01:11.500 --> 00:01:15.890
that's being affected by the problem
is PLABCSCO01, this guy down here.

24
00:01:15.890 --> 00:01:18.080
And I can see that is is 192.168.16.10,
so that's good.

25
00:01:18.080 --> 00:01:23.110
It's got an IP and
it's ready to communicate on the network.

26
00:01:23.110 --> 00:01:25.450
Now, it doesn't tell me who
the default gateway is, and

27
00:01:25.450 --> 00:01:28.920
that default gateway used to be
shared between these guys up here.

28
00:01:28.920 --> 00:01:31.050
I don't know if that's the case anymore,
all right?

29
00:01:31.050 --> 00:01:34.250
So let's dive in here and
see if we can verify this information and

30
00:01:34.250 --> 00:01:36.690
figure out how that path is working.

31
00:01:36.690 --> 00:01:38.780
So I'm gonna start right on that server.

32
00:01:39.810 --> 00:01:42.510
And the first thing I'm going to do is
just look at that server's configuration,

33
00:01:42.510 --> 00:01:46.470
so I'll do a quick ipconfig on here,
just to see how it's set.

34
00:01:46.470 --> 00:01:50.090
And I can see that it's 192.168.16.10, and

35
00:01:50.090 --> 00:01:52.180
it's got a default
gateway of 192.168.16.1.

36
00:01:52.180 --> 00:01:55.600
So that hasn't changed
from the previous sets.

37
00:01:57.050 --> 00:02:02.070
Now, in the previous sets we had
those two switches that were

38
00:02:02.070 --> 00:02:06.990
running HSRP and they were sharing
that virtual IP between them and

39
00:02:06.990 --> 00:02:10.320
that's where we had that
default gateway IP residing.

40
00:02:10.320 --> 00:02:12.450
I could assume that's still the same but
let's go and verify it.

41
00:02:12.450 --> 00:02:15.810
Core 2 used to be the active one so
I'll jump over to Core 2 and

42
00:02:15.810 --> 00:02:19.580
we'll take a look and kind of see where
it sits in the middle of all this.

43
00:02:21.300 --> 00:02:23.770
Let me just get that kind of reset for me.

44
00:02:23.770 --> 00:02:27.700
And what I'm going to do is
basically just jump right in and

45
00:02:27.700 --> 00:02:29.640
see if we can't figure out where that is.

46
00:02:29.640 --> 00:02:32.870
So I'm going to do a show
I P interface brief and

47
00:02:32.870 --> 00:02:35.560
I'm going to exclude all
the unassigned interfaces.

48
00:02:35.560 --> 00:02:38.820
I'm just trying to find out where
the 192.168.16 network is and

49
00:02:38.820 --> 00:02:40.950
it's still on VLAN 16.

50
00:02:40.950 --> 00:02:43.770
Again, I could have guessed that from
the previous sets, but I want to be

51
00:02:43.770 --> 00:02:47.630
better safe than sorry here and make
sure I know where that actually resides.

52
00:02:47.630 --> 00:02:52.254
Then if I do a show run for
interface VLAN 16.

53
00:02:53.330 --> 00:02:53.990
There we go.

54
00:02:53.990 --> 00:02:56.420
I see that it's running HSRP.

55
00:02:56.420 --> 00:03:02.440
It's got that standby IP address so this
is the default gateway for PLABCISCO 01.

56
00:03:02.440 --> 00:03:03.980
So I found the default gateway.

57
00:03:03.980 --> 00:03:08.000
And the problem was that PLABCISCO 01
could not reach this default gateway.

58
00:03:08.000 --> 00:03:11.960
So, well, actually,
I say this is the default gateway.

59
00:03:11.960 --> 00:03:15.640
this is one node of an HSRP cluster,
it might not be the active node.

60
00:03:15.640 --> 00:03:18.650
So let me do a quick show standby for
vlan 16.

61
00:03:18.650 --> 00:03:21.040
And see, we are active, okay.

62
00:03:21.040 --> 00:03:23.820
So this is the active one,
this is the default gateway and for

63
00:03:23.820 --> 00:03:27.450
some reason that server can't get to us.

64
00:03:27.450 --> 00:03:30.610
And if I do a quick ping to 196.168.16.10

65
00:03:30.610 --> 00:03:33.660
I can see that core two
can't get to it either.

66
00:03:33.660 --> 00:03:35.550
Alright, so I've got a bit of a problem.

67
00:03:35.550 --> 00:03:40.810
Now, if this were separate subnets
then I might use traceroute and

68
00:03:40.810 --> 00:03:44.680
try to figure out where in a path
a particular connection fails, but

69
00:03:44.680 --> 00:03:47.450
in my scenario we're on the same subnet.

70
00:03:47.450 --> 00:03:51.290
I'm trying to get to my default gateway,
so I've got two hosts on

71
00:03:51.290 --> 00:03:54.700
the 192.168.16 network tools like
TraceRoute really aren't gonna help me.

72
00:03:54.700 --> 00:03:58.110
I just know that one node
isn't able to see the other.

73
00:03:58.110 --> 00:04:00.290
Now if I look at my network topology,

74
00:04:00.290 --> 00:04:03.410
there's a lot of places
this problem could occur.

75
00:04:03.410 --> 00:04:07.140
PLABCSCO01, if it wants to go to
the gateway, it's gotta get to NYCORE2.

76
00:04:07.140 --> 00:04:13.040
It could go to ACCESS1, and
from ACCESS1 up to CORE2

77
00:04:13.040 --> 00:04:17.430
or, it could go from access1
to core1 over to core2, right?

78
00:04:17.430 --> 00:04:18.340
Two different paths.

79
00:04:18.340 --> 00:04:20.860
And, there could be something
wrong with either path

80
00:04:20.860 --> 00:04:22.290
that's causing this to break down.

81
00:04:22.290 --> 00:04:24.480
So, I need to figure out what
path it's gonna take and,

82
00:04:24.480 --> 00:04:27.770
what's gonna determine the path,
well, spanning tree.

83
00:04:27.770 --> 00:04:30.120
Spanning tree is gonna
see this as a loop and

84
00:04:30.120 --> 00:04:31.690
it's gonna block a port somewhere on it.

85
00:04:31.690 --> 00:04:32.580
I don't know where, right.

86
00:04:32.580 --> 00:04:35.560
And, one of these switches will be
the master now or the root bridge and

87
00:04:35.560 --> 00:04:37.000
that'll keep its ports up.

88
00:04:37.000 --> 00:04:40.990
Somebody else will have to turn F port
off and that's gonna affect that path.

89
00:04:40.990 --> 00:04:42.160
So I can just look.

90
00:04:42.160 --> 00:04:44.220
The easiest way to find out
is right here on ACCESS1.

91
00:04:44.220 --> 00:04:46.910
I can just look at
the spanning tree topology for

92
00:04:46.910 --> 00:04:49.740
VLAN16 and get an idea of where
that traffic's going to go.

93
00:04:49.740 --> 00:04:55.630
So I'm going to jump over to NYACCESS1 and
see if I can't figure that out, all right?

94
00:04:55.630 --> 00:05:01.160
So on NYaccess1,
I'm just gonna come in here and

95
00:05:01.160 --> 00:05:06.420
get into theat switch and
I'm gonna do a quick show.

96
00:05:06.420 --> 00:05:08.760
Well, first off, I'm gonna do
a show of VLan.Well first off,

97
00:05:08.760 --> 00:05:13.520
I'm doing a show of VLan because VLan
16 is the one that I care about, right?

98
00:05:13.520 --> 00:05:17.280
And I wanna make sure that
VLan is present and, Oh well,

99
00:05:17.280 --> 00:05:19.280
actually I think I've spotted
our problem right here.

100
00:05:19.280 --> 00:05:21.580
I wanted to make sure
the VLAN was present, right?

101
00:05:21.580 --> 00:05:24.210
And the reason I was doing that is you
might have things like VLAN trunking

102
00:05:24.210 --> 00:05:26.470
protocol where the VLAN gets deleted.

103
00:05:26.470 --> 00:05:29.870
And it might still exist on a port but
it's deleted in the database and so

104
00:05:29.870 --> 00:05:31.200
which it was missing here.

105
00:05:31.200 --> 00:05:35.420
Well, it's not missing, I see VLAN 16,
it's there like I expected it, right?

106
00:05:35.420 --> 00:05:39.340
And When I look at Spanning Tree what I
was really intending to do when I came

107
00:05:39.340 --> 00:05:43.500
here was to look and
see if my trunks were carrying that VLAN.

108
00:05:43.500 --> 00:05:49.105
So, what I wanted to do is show
spanning-dash for VLAN 16,

109
00:05:49.105 --> 00:05:54.005
and take a look at which
port we were sending out.

110
00:05:54.005 --> 00:05:58.035
And see how I've got port
23 here is forwarding and

111
00:05:58.035 --> 00:06:01.145
port 24 is blocking; that's
the information I was actually going for.

112
00:06:01.145 --> 00:06:05.705
And that was gonna tell me that if I
look at my network map here, port 23,

113
00:06:05.705 --> 00:06:08.530
that's the one that was forwarding,
which goes to CORE2.

114
00:06:08.530 --> 00:06:10.670
Port 24 was blocking, that goes to core 1.

115
00:06:10.670 --> 00:06:16.330
That told me my path that I'm going from
PLABCISCO 01 to NYACCESS1 to NYCORE2.

116
00:06:16.330 --> 00:06:18.800
That's the path that I
should be following.

117
00:06:18.800 --> 00:06:22.700
That's what I was looking for
when I came here and as often happens,

118
00:06:22.700 --> 00:06:27.000
accidentally while looking for
that information, I found the problem.

119
00:06:27.000 --> 00:06:32.170
The problem, which you guys might have
noticed was back here when I ran show vlan

120
00:06:32.170 --> 00:06:33.940
and let me just bring that back up again.

121
00:06:33.940 --> 00:06:38.360
When when I ran show vlan to pull
up my VLAN list, I was just making

122
00:06:38.360 --> 00:06:41.810
sure VLAN 16 wasn't deleted,
right, or that it wasn't disabled.

123
00:06:41.810 --> 00:06:43.670
See how I've got this
active status over here?

124
00:06:43.670 --> 00:06:46.430
It could be suspended and
then it wouldn't be moving traffic either.

125
00:06:46.430 --> 00:06:48.030
So I was just doing a quick glance for

126
00:06:48.030 --> 00:06:52.070
that, but what I didn't expect
is what I see over here.

127
00:06:52.070 --> 00:06:53.600
What ports are assigned to VLAN 16?

128
00:06:53.600 --> 00:06:54.920
None.

129
00:06:54.920 --> 00:06:56.890
There's no ports assigned to VLAN 16.

130
00:06:56.890 --> 00:06:59.970
Now for my trunks I'm ok with that, right?

131
00:06:59.970 --> 00:07:05.110
Remember when I did a show spanning
tree for VLAN 16 I saw the ports 23 and

132
00:07:05.110 --> 00:07:08.310
24 for participating in VLAN 16 and
that's because their trunks.

133
00:07:08.310 --> 00:07:09.769
So if I do a show interface trunk.

134
00:07:10.920 --> 00:07:13.740
I'll see those guys
are both carrying VLAN 16,

135
00:07:13.740 --> 00:07:17.740
but trunks don't show up
in the show VLAN output.

136
00:07:17.740 --> 00:07:20.030
When you run show VLAN
trunks are left out, right?

137
00:07:20.030 --> 00:07:24.550
So anytime you see a port missing from
show VLAN, it's either been converted to

138
00:07:24.550 --> 00:07:29.320
a layer three port instead of a switch
port or it is a trunk, one or the other.

139
00:07:29.320 --> 00:07:31.920
In this case they're trunked,
so I know they're okay, but

140
00:07:31.920 --> 00:07:37.812
what I'm not seeing is the port that
PLABCISCO 01 is plugged into, right.

141
00:07:37.812 --> 00:07:40.590
PLABCISCO 01 is supposed to be on vlan16,
it's plugged.

142
00:07:41.825 --> 00:07:46.355
Plugged into port 1, I expect to see
port 1 in the show VLAN output for

143
00:07:46.355 --> 00:07:48.155
VLAN 16 and I didn't see it.

144
00:07:48.155 --> 00:07:50.375
So while I wasn't intending
to find the problem that way,

145
00:07:50.375 --> 00:07:51.845
it certainly worked out, didn't it?

146
00:07:51.845 --> 00:07:58.215
So, if I do a show VLAN again, I can just
verify VLAN 16 and port 1 is not there.

147
00:07:58.215 --> 00:08:02.760
In fact, port 1 is right here On VLAN10.

148
00:08:02.760 --> 00:08:04.970
On the wrong VLAN.

149
00:08:04.970 --> 00:08:08.802
And I can verify that again by
doing a show running-config for

150
00:08:08.802 --> 00:08:13.120
interface fa0/1 and
sure enough, VLAN10, right?

151
00:08:14.750 --> 00:08:17.580
So that's what I'm gonna need to fix,
is I'm gonna need to jump in there and

152
00:08:17.580 --> 00:08:18.590
move it to the right VLAN.

153
00:08:18.590 --> 00:08:24.600
So I'll just get into fa0/1 and
say switch-port access vlan 16.

154
00:08:24.600 --> 00:08:29.020
That will move that over and
that should solve our problem.

155
00:08:29.020 --> 00:08:31.700
Now to test that out, what can I do?

156
00:08:31.700 --> 00:08:34.500
Well I can jump back to the original
server and I can test from here, or

157
00:08:34.500 --> 00:08:38.230
I could test from the gateway really, but
I'll test from here just to make sure that

158
00:08:38.230 --> 00:08:41.970
I'm in line with what the question
was originally asking me to do.

159
00:08:41.970 --> 00:08:46.430
So I'm gonna try and ping my default
gateway, 192.168.16.1 and now we succeed.

160
00:08:46.430 --> 00:08:51.310
All right, so
this one turned out to be not so bad.

161
00:08:51.310 --> 00:08:54.550
I was running through my standard
troubleshooting process and just happened

162
00:08:54.550 --> 00:08:58.150
to find the problem before I actually got
to the information I was even looking for.

163
00:08:58.150 --> 00:08:58.920
That's kinda nice, right?

164
00:08:58.920 --> 00:09:01.850
It makes for a quick and easy answer and
we move onto the next question and

165
00:09:01.850 --> 00:09:02.490
we're in business.

166
00:09:02.490 --> 00:09:06.680
So in this case, it just came down to
the port the host was plugged into

167
00:09:06.680 --> 00:09:08.260
was assigned to the wrong VLAN.

168
00:09:08.260 --> 00:09:11.852
Moved him to the right VLAN,
connectivity restored and then we're done.

169
00:09:11.852 --> 00:09:13.630
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed that one.

170
00:09:13.630 --> 00:09:17.712
Stay tuned, we got more troubleshooting
issues for set number three coming up.

171
00:09:17.712 --> 00:09:25.524
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #2` from set #3. The trouble ticket states that "You are unable to create VLANs on NYCORE1, you should be able to create VLANs on both NYCORE1 and NYCORE2 "
episodes.title: Set 3 Issue 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.102 --> 00:00:08.714
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.714 --> 00:00:12.801
In this video we're gonna tackle Set 3,
Issue 2.

3
00:00:12.801 --> 00:00:15.830
And once again we've got
another issue on our switches.

4
00:00:15.830 --> 00:00:18.430
This one looks to be more switch
related than server related though, so

5
00:00:18.430 --> 00:00:19.810
we get to mix things up a bit.

6
00:00:19.810 --> 00:00:21.680
The trouble ticket we've
got reads like this.

7
00:00:21.680 --> 00:00:26.790
It says your are unable to
create VLANs on NYCORE1.

8
00:00:26.790 --> 00:00:32.190
You should be able to create a VLANs
on both, NYCORE1 and NYCORE2.

9
00:00:32.190 --> 00:00:35.410
Well this one actually sounds like
a pretty straightforward problem.

10
00:00:35.410 --> 00:00:39.470
There's really only a couple of things
that can stop you from creating VLANs on

11
00:00:39.470 --> 00:00:40.350
a switch.

12
00:00:40.350 --> 00:00:44.010
For example you might have a switch
that doesn't support VLANs, right?

13
00:00:44.010 --> 00:00:47.390
Which pretty much every
single Cisco switch does so

14
00:00:47.390 --> 00:00:49.130
that's more than likely not the case.

15
00:00:49.130 --> 00:00:52.184
We could be out of VLAN numbers, right?

16
00:00:52.184 --> 00:00:55.240
You've only gotten one through
4,094 on most switches, so

17
00:00:55.240 --> 00:00:58.530
if we've gone beyond that, then we
might not be able create VLANs there.

18
00:00:58.530 --> 00:01:02.810
And then, a third thing might be that
we're in the VTP client mode, right?

19
00:01:02.810 --> 00:01:07.270
Client mode can't create VLANs,
server mode, and transfer mode can.

20
00:01:07.270 --> 00:01:09.480
Any one of those could be the problem.

21
00:01:09.480 --> 00:01:12.500
After that,
I'm hard pressed to think of anything

22
00:01:12.500 --> 00:01:14.800
that could stop us from
creating a VLAN on a switch.

23
00:01:14.800 --> 00:01:17.980
So, we should be pretty well set and
taken care of, we just have to jump in and

24
00:01:17.980 --> 00:01:19.049
check for those things.

25
00:01:19.049 --> 00:01:22.664
They're telling me that NYCORE1 is
the problem, let's just jump to CORE1 and

26
00:01:22.664 --> 00:01:23.684
see what's going on.

27
00:01:23.684 --> 00:01:27.965
So if I look at my topology, NYCORE1 and
NYCORE2, that's these two switches right

28
00:01:27.965 --> 00:01:32.305
here, they've got a trunk in between them
that's some kind of port channel, right,

29
00:01:32.305 --> 00:01:34.340
so there's bonding interfaces.

30
00:01:34.340 --> 00:01:39.030
So they're up and they're communicating,
and because we've got that port channel

31
00:01:39.030 --> 00:01:41.960
there, if it's configured as a trunk,
this is a great scenario for running VTP.

32
00:01:41.960 --> 00:01:45.860
So that's more than likely gonna
be our issue, we'll verify, right.

33
00:01:45.860 --> 00:01:48.650
The easiest way to verify this one is
gonna be to jump to NYCORE1 and just

34
00:01:48.650 --> 00:01:52.750
try and create a VLAN, cuz the odds are if
we can't create a VLAN, it'll tell us why.

35
00:01:52.750 --> 00:01:55.240
It'll just say it and
that'll solve that problem, right.

36
00:01:55.240 --> 00:01:58.810
So let's jump over to CORE1 and
see what it tells us.

37
00:01:58.810 --> 00:02:01.360
So I'm gonna jump over to this switch.

38
00:02:01.360 --> 00:02:03.380
Let me just see if I
can't get into it first.

39
00:02:05.050 --> 00:02:08.110
And we'll just jump in and try and
create a VLAN and see what happens.

40
00:02:08.110 --> 00:02:12.930
So if I do a show VLAN, I can look right
here and see what VLANs I have already.

41
00:02:12.930 --> 00:02:14.770
I've got one and ten through 16.

42
00:02:14.770 --> 00:02:16.110
Maybe I'll create VLAN17.

43
00:02:16.110 --> 00:02:20.450
So I'm gonna jump into configuration and
I'll just type VLAN17.

44
00:02:20.450 --> 00:02:25.230
All right, and sure enough it
tells us exactly why it won't.

45
00:02:25.230 --> 00:02:29.640
VTP VLAN configuration not allowed
when device is in client mode.

46
00:02:29.640 --> 00:02:31.650
All right, so that's gonna be our problem,

47
00:02:31.650 --> 00:02:35.100
when you're in client mode
you can create any VLANs.

48
00:02:35.100 --> 00:02:36.558
So, the solution to this.

49
00:02:36.558 --> 00:02:38.804
Well, here's where things get
a little bit tricky, right.

50
00:02:38.804 --> 00:02:41.510
The solution is actually easy.

51
00:02:41.510 --> 00:02:45.970
I can switch to VTP server mode,
or VTP transparent, right.

52
00:02:45.970 --> 00:02:48.891
VTP transparent is effective
gonna break VTP for this switch.

53
00:02:48.891 --> 00:02:51.933
It's not gonna really
participate in VTP anymore.

54
00:02:51.933 --> 00:02:54.611
They said in the question that I
should be able to create VLANs

55
00:02:54.611 --> 00:02:55.830
on both CORE1 and CORE2.

56
00:02:55.830 --> 00:02:58.760
So that means I more than likely
need to be in server mode and

57
00:02:58.760 --> 00:03:01.520
core2 needs to be in server mode also,
right?

58
00:03:01.520 --> 00:03:04.220
CORE2 is not causing us any problems,
I'll bet it's already in server mode but

59
00:03:04.220 --> 00:03:06.440
we'll verify that before
we wrap this question up.

60
00:03:06.440 --> 00:03:10.310
Now where I say things get tricky,
this is in client mode.

61
00:03:10.310 --> 00:03:15.560
So right now I can't make new VLANs, but
I can still advertise them out, right?

62
00:03:15.560 --> 00:03:17.520
I can advertise out to other switches, and

63
00:03:17.520 --> 00:03:20.360
if I switched to server
mode what's gonna happen?

64
00:03:20.360 --> 00:03:23.370
Well I continue to advertise out
right I can still create things.

65
00:03:23.370 --> 00:03:27.360
But if there was a VTP problem, something
like a password problem or whatever,

66
00:03:27.360 --> 00:03:32.900
my revision number might make it where I
could overwrite other people's settings.

67
00:03:32.900 --> 00:03:34.860
And so
we can run into some problems there.

68
00:03:34.860 --> 00:03:37.890
Switching between transparent mode and
server mode, or transparent mode and

69
00:03:37.890 --> 00:03:39.410
client mode will fix that.

70
00:03:39.410 --> 00:03:42.470
Usually going from client mode to
server mode is pretty safe though.

71
00:03:42.470 --> 00:03:45.759
My revision number in my database should
be the same as the other switches that

72
00:03:45.759 --> 00:03:47.638
are out there but
it doesn't hurt to check.

73
00:03:47.638 --> 00:03:51.894
So I'm gonna do a quick show VTP status
just to make sure that I'm receiving

74
00:03:51.894 --> 00:03:56.762
communications from somebody else, and I
do have configuration last modified by and

75
00:03:56.762 --> 00:04:01.520
we don't know the IP, but we did get a
modification, and I've got my seven VLANs.

76
00:04:01.520 --> 00:04:05.320
My revision number is seven,
not the number of VLANs.

77
00:04:05.320 --> 00:04:09.204
I've actually got 12 VLANs, but if we
take away the reserved ones, we've got,

78
00:04:09.204 --> 00:04:11.716
what is it, eight or
nine actual VLANs on our system.

79
00:04:11.716 --> 00:04:15.407
So revision number is seven, I'm just
gonna double check against CORE2 and

80
00:04:15.407 --> 00:04:17.791
make sure it's got the same
revision number, and

81
00:04:17.791 --> 00:04:21.790
that way I don't have to run the risk
of overriding anything too crazy.

82
00:04:21.790 --> 00:04:26.590
So, on this guy,
I'm gonna do a show VTP status, and

83
00:04:26.590 --> 00:04:30.540
this one, if I kinda look at it here,
it's operating mode is set to server, so

84
00:04:30.540 --> 00:04:32.960
I'm okay there and
its revision number is seven.

85
00:04:32.960 --> 00:04:35.500
So, we're okay,
these guys should be the same.

86
00:04:35.500 --> 00:04:39.106
I should just be able to flip from client
over to server, no big deal there, right?

87
00:04:39.106 --> 00:04:42.090
So I'm gonna take CORE1 and I'll just say,

88
00:04:42.090 --> 00:04:46.240
VTP mode server and
now I'm in server mode, okay.

89
00:04:46.240 --> 00:04:49.460
And once I'm in server mode,
now I should be able to create VLANs.

90
00:04:49.460 --> 00:04:53.190
And so if I go back and
I do VLAN17, I can give it a name.

91
00:04:53.190 --> 00:04:59.810
I'll just call this my test VLAN and
I'll get out.

92
00:04:59.810 --> 00:05:01.466
And there we go, all right.

93
00:05:01.466 --> 00:05:03.390
It let me create it this time so
it didn't stop me.

94
00:05:03.390 --> 00:05:05.250
Let's just make sure that VTP is working.

95
00:05:05.250 --> 00:05:10.720
I created the VLAN here,
I'm gonna jump over to CORE2 and

96
00:05:10.720 --> 00:05:13.500
the VLAN should get learned here.

97
00:05:13.500 --> 00:05:19.378
So if I do a show VLAN, I should
see VLAN 17, Test VLAN, all right.

98
00:05:19.378 --> 00:05:21.390
Now technically we're done, right?

99
00:05:21.390 --> 00:05:26.301
The problem was that we couldn't create
VLANs on CORE1, it was in client mode.

100
00:05:26.301 --> 00:05:28.518
We flipped it to the server mode,
problem solved.

101
00:05:28.518 --> 00:05:31.881
But, they did say right at the last
little part of that sentence,

102
00:05:31.881 --> 00:05:35.700
you should be able to create VLANs
on both on NYCORE1 and NYCORE2.

103
00:05:35.700 --> 00:05:39.470
So, just to be on the safe side I'm
gonna create another VLAN here on CORE2,

104
00:05:39.470 --> 00:05:41.743
and make sure that it syncs back again,
right?

105
00:05:41.743 --> 00:05:43.740
That we've got two way
synchronization here.

106
00:05:43.740 --> 00:05:46.600
Just in case, right, this problem
could be bigger than we think.

107
00:05:46.600 --> 00:05:52.230
So, I'm gonna create VLAN18 which I'll
call test VLAN 2, which I probably

108
00:05:52.230 --> 00:05:57.770
need to use the name command to set, there
we go and so now I've got that extra VLAN.

109
00:05:59.420 --> 00:06:01.950
I'll just do a show VLAN to make
sure it's there on my database.

110
00:06:01.950 --> 00:06:03.530
Now I've got test VLAN and test VLAN 2 and

111
00:06:03.530 --> 00:06:08.780
I'm gonna switch over to CORE1 and
just make sure it shows up here.

112
00:06:08.780 --> 00:06:10.560
If it shows up here, then we're done.

113
00:06:10.560 --> 00:06:11.740
Pretty straightforward problem.

114
00:06:12.800 --> 00:06:15.370
If it doesn't show up here,
then we start troubleshooting that.

115
00:06:15.370 --> 00:06:18.120
But it does, I've got both test VLANs.

116
00:06:18.120 --> 00:06:21.700
So now I'm able to create VLANs on
both switches and we're in business.

117
00:06:21.700 --> 00:06:24.940
In this case, it simply turned out
to be that one of them was set for

118
00:06:24.940 --> 00:06:27.570
client mode and not server mode and
couldn't create VLANs.

119
00:06:27.570 --> 00:06:29.380
So pretty straightforward on that one.

120
00:06:29.380 --> 00:06:30.952
We've knocked it out and now it's done.

121
00:06:30.952 --> 00:06:32.920
All right,
well that was any easy one for us.

122
00:06:32.920 --> 00:06:34.547
We'll see if we get some
harder ones coming up.

123
00:06:34.547 --> 00:06:35.767
Definitely stay tuned for

124
00:06:35.767 --> 00:06:38.881
that cuz we got more troubleshooting
issues coming down the line.

125
00:06:38.881 --> 00:06:41.161
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #3` from set #3. The trouble ticket states that "The etherchannel between NYCORE1 and NYCORE2 is not operating correctly as shown by the output of the following command: show interface port-channel 1 etherchannel"
episodes.title: Set 3 Issue 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.171
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.171 --> 00:00:09.840
It is time for next issue.

3
00:00:09.840 --> 00:00:12.870
We're gonna be jumping into
issue three for set three, and

4
00:00:12.870 --> 00:00:16.280
it looks like we've got some
problems with our switches again.

5
00:00:16.280 --> 00:00:19.960
In the middle of our network we've got
these two switches that are providing

6
00:00:19.960 --> 00:00:22.760
gateway services for some of our clients,
these guys right here.

7
00:00:22.760 --> 00:00:26.010
And I know we've seen in our topology
that we've got that port channel running

8
00:00:26.010 --> 00:00:28.500
between them, and that's what
this trouble ticket surrounds it.

9
00:00:28.500 --> 00:00:30.200
Let me just read the ticket to us here.

10
00:00:30.200 --> 00:00:35.430
It says the EtherChannel between
NYCORE1 and NYCORE2 is not

11
00:00:35.430 --> 00:00:39.050
operating correctly as shown by
the output of the following command, and

12
00:00:39.050 --> 00:00:43.380
then it gives us a command, show
interface port-channel 1 ether channel.

13
00:00:44.410 --> 00:00:48.050
So they're giving us a specific command
that we need to run to see the output of,

14
00:00:48.050 --> 00:00:50.280
so we can see what an issue happens to be.

15
00:00:50.280 --> 00:00:51.870
And then based on
the output of that command,

16
00:00:51.870 --> 00:00:53.560
we need to come up with a solution.

17
00:00:53.560 --> 00:00:56.230
So well we need to go and check that out.

18
00:00:56.230 --> 00:01:00.760
So this is the link here that there
showing us we should have ports 23 and

19
00:01:00.760 --> 00:01:04.990
24 bonded together into a single link,
it should be a port channel and

20
00:01:04.990 --> 00:01:05.870
it should be up and going.

21
00:01:05.870 --> 00:01:08.520
And in the syntax here where they give
us the command, they tell us to run in

22
00:01:08.520 --> 00:01:12.160
NYCORE 2, so we'll start our
troubleshooting right there in NYCORE 2.

23
00:01:12.160 --> 00:01:14.840
So I'm gonna jump over to that switch.

24
00:01:16.270 --> 00:01:17.961
And just get logged in to it.

25
00:01:21.712 --> 00:01:24.900
And well, I guess I should start off with
running the command that they gave us.

26
00:01:24.900 --> 00:01:25.480
They gave it to us for a reason.

27
00:01:25.480 --> 00:01:32.237
So I'm gonna run show interface
port-channel 1 etherchannel.

28
00:01:32.237 --> 00:01:36.810
That's the command they gave us
in the problem, gonna run it and

29
00:01:36.810 --> 00:01:37.730
see if we have a problem.

30
00:01:37.730 --> 00:01:39.360
And so, here I can look at it and

31
00:01:39.360 --> 00:01:44.170
it's telling me that we've got
an etherchannel, one does exist.

32
00:01:44.170 --> 00:01:45.290
It's been up for 51 minutes, so

33
00:01:45.290 --> 00:01:49.650
mine's been up almost an hour now,
I've got number of ports one.

34
00:01:50.730 --> 00:01:53.160
Well, I kind of expected
to see number of ports two.

35
00:01:53.160 --> 00:01:58.710
I should see ports 23 and 24 and as I look
down here, I've got the port channels up.

36
00:01:58.710 --> 00:02:01.090
It's using port aggregation protocol or
PAGP.

37
00:02:01.090 --> 00:02:05.550
I can see that port 24 is up and

38
00:02:05.550 --> 00:02:10.090
desirable and,
port 23 is not even on the list.

39
00:02:10.090 --> 00:02:13.880
So, it looks like my problem here
is that I'm missing a port and

40
00:02:13.880 --> 00:02:15.260
why am I missing it?

41
00:02:15.260 --> 00:02:17.450
Well, maybe it never got
added to the port channel,

42
00:02:17.450 --> 00:02:19.810
we need to look at the configuration and
see.

43
00:02:19.810 --> 00:02:22.360
There's a few different
ways we can go about this.

44
00:02:22.360 --> 00:02:24.410
This command that they gave us,
it's not one of my favorites,

45
00:02:24.410 --> 00:02:27.540
this one show interface
port-channel 1 etherchannel.

46
00:02:27.540 --> 00:02:28.940
It give you some information but

47
00:02:28.940 --> 00:02:32.390
it's not as forthcoming with the data
as some of the other commands.

48
00:02:32.390 --> 00:02:36.080
So for example I like to run,
show eitherchannel summary.

49
00:02:37.160 --> 00:02:39.730
Show eitherchannel summary
gives you a nice breakdown and

50
00:02:39.730 --> 00:02:42.740
you see basically the same information.

51
00:02:42.740 --> 00:02:45.970
But it shows us one thing
the other one doesn't.

52
00:02:45.970 --> 00:02:50.060
The command they gave us doesn't show
us when you've got problem interfaces.

53
00:02:50.060 --> 00:02:52.280
You have to know that they're missing.

54
00:02:52.280 --> 00:02:56.490
I knew from our diagram that port 23 and
24 should have been that channel, but

55
00:02:56.490 --> 00:02:58.010
it wasn't there.

56
00:02:58.010 --> 00:02:59.580
I knew that cuz they gave
me that information, but

57
00:02:59.580 --> 00:03:02.470
if they hadn't given me the information,
I wouldn't necessarily know that.

58
00:03:02.470 --> 00:03:05.690
But here, see I've got port channel 1 and

59
00:03:05.690 --> 00:03:10.080
it's got a status of SU which is it's
layer2 and it's in use that's good.

60
00:03:10.080 --> 00:03:15.150
And then over here I can see the ports and
it shows port 24 with

61
00:03:15.150 --> 00:03:19.730
a P which let's me know that it's bundled
in the port channel right, so it's good.

62
00:03:19.730 --> 00:03:22.490
But it's also got port 23,
it's got a bad port and

63
00:03:22.490 --> 00:03:24.128
that's something we didn't
see in the other command.

64
00:03:24.128 --> 00:03:31.300
So with Fa1/0/23(s) it's got a lower case
S and if I look up here it's suspended.

65
00:03:31.300 --> 00:03:35.010
Now all that really tells me, you know
that I didn't get with the other command,

66
00:03:35.010 --> 00:03:38.700
is that it is actually
joined to the port channel.

67
00:03:38.700 --> 00:03:40.390
It's just not coming up.

68
00:03:40.390 --> 00:03:43.280
And there's usually really
just two reasons for that.

69
00:03:44.450 --> 00:03:49.760
One reason might be that port 24
has a higher speed than port 23,

70
00:03:49.760 --> 00:03:50.790
and that's not the case here.

71
00:03:50.790 --> 00:03:52.210
See how both of mine are FAs.

72
00:03:52.210 --> 00:03:53.330
They're fast ethernet.

73
00:03:53.330 --> 00:03:53.830
They're 100 megabit.

74
00:03:54.900 --> 00:03:58.910
But, if one was a gigabit and
the other one was 100 megabit.

75
00:03:58.910 --> 00:04:03.280
And I would expect to see the gigabit
ports go active in the bundle and

76
00:04:03.280 --> 00:04:06.600
the 100 megs go suspended and
wait until all the gigs fail.

77
00:04:06.600 --> 00:04:07.350
That's the way that, that works.

78
00:04:07.350 --> 00:04:09.130
You're not supposed to
mix bandwidth like that.

79
00:04:09.130 --> 00:04:10.100
That's not what's going on here.

80
00:04:11.560 --> 00:04:15.130
The other option is that
it's misconfigured.

81
00:04:15.130 --> 00:04:17.090
When you bond ports
together in a port channel,

82
00:04:17.090 --> 00:04:18.880
their configuration needs to be the same.

83
00:04:18.880 --> 00:04:23.870
And so, in the switch shows we kinda told
you guys about how you should really

84
00:04:23.870 --> 00:04:26.970
use the range command anytime you're
configuring interfaces in a bundle,

85
00:04:26.970 --> 00:04:28.980
to make sure they all get
the same configuration.

86
00:04:28.980 --> 00:04:31.760
Or, put the config on the port-channel,
and

87
00:04:31.760 --> 00:04:34.730
it'll apply to the interfaces underneath.

88
00:04:34.730 --> 00:04:37.670
In this case, I'll bet we've just got
some kind of different configuration, and

89
00:04:37.670 --> 00:04:39.910
fortunately that's a really
easy one to troubleshoot.

90
00:04:39.910 --> 00:04:42.268
We just have to look at
the configuration of the good port and

91
00:04:42.268 --> 00:04:44.211
compare it to the configuration
of the bad port.

92
00:04:44.211 --> 00:04:51.004
So if I do a show running-config for
fa1/0/24 that's the good port, right.

93
00:04:51.004 --> 00:04:53.860
And, well, it's not the good command here,
I forgot interface.

94
00:04:53.860 --> 00:04:54.670
There we go.

95
00:04:54.670 --> 00:04:58.070
So, here's a good one,
switchport trunk encapsulation dot1q,

96
00:04:58.070 --> 00:05:01.030
switchport trunk allowed
vlan 10 through 16,

97
00:05:01.030 --> 00:05:04.870
switchport mode trunk,
channel-group 1 mode desirable.

98
00:05:04.870 --> 00:05:07.340
So, there's the configuration
we have on our good port.

99
00:05:07.340 --> 00:05:09.860
Now let's look at
a configuration on the bad port.

100
00:05:09.860 --> 00:05:13.650
And when I bring that one up, all I
have to do is look for the differences.

101
00:05:13.650 --> 00:05:16.520
It's encapsulating dot1q,
it's supporting VLANs 10 through 16.

102
00:05:16.520 --> 00:05:18.860
Oh here's a winner.

103
00:05:18.860 --> 00:05:21.520
Switchport mode access.

104
00:05:21.520 --> 00:05:24.230
The good port is set to trunk,
switchport mode trunk.

105
00:05:24.230 --> 00:05:27.190
This one is set to access,
switchport mode access.

106
00:05:27.190 --> 00:05:29.110
And then we've got channel
group 1 mode desirable.

107
00:05:29.110 --> 00:05:31.660
We just looked for the difference,
we found the difference.

108
00:05:31.660 --> 00:05:33.750
If we fix the difference,
that'll likely fix the problem.

109
00:05:33.750 --> 00:05:36.020
Now let me give you
guys a word of caution.

110
00:05:36.020 --> 00:05:38.790
Port channels can be a little finicky
sometimes when you start messing with

111
00:05:38.790 --> 00:05:40.720
the individual ports underneath it.

112
00:05:40.720 --> 00:05:43.350
So anytime you change
a port's configuration,

113
00:05:43.350 --> 00:05:46.170
I recommend you shut
the interface down first.

114
00:05:46.170 --> 00:05:49.290
And so that's what I'm gonna do is
I'm gonna jump into my configuration.

115
00:05:49.290 --> 00:05:50.690
I'm gonna get into fa1/0/23 and

116
00:05:50.690 --> 00:05:53.260
the first thing I'm gonna do
is I'm gonna shut it down.

117
00:05:54.480 --> 00:05:57.930
Because right now it's suspended,
but it's trying to go active.

118
00:05:57.930 --> 00:06:01.360
And as I start making changes,
if I have to make more than one change,

119
00:06:01.360 --> 00:06:04.700
it can really get things a little wonky
and potentially bring the line down.

120
00:06:04.700 --> 00:06:05.660
So you gotta be careful with that.

121
00:06:05.660 --> 00:06:07.110
So I'm gonna shut it down first,

122
00:06:07.110 --> 00:06:10.670
which is gonna stop it from
trying to join the port channel.

123
00:06:10.670 --> 00:06:14.730
Then I can say switchport mode trunk so

124
00:06:14.730 --> 00:06:17.610
that it's now set just
like the other port.

125
00:06:17.610 --> 00:06:20.660
The two ports should have a near
identical configuration at this point

126
00:06:20.660 --> 00:06:22.580
which we can verify.

127
00:06:22.580 --> 00:06:25.850
Here's our good port and
here's our bad port.

128
00:06:25.850 --> 00:06:28.580
And I say they are near identical,
they should be actually identical

129
00:06:28.580 --> 00:06:31.830
between the two now except for
that shut down command.

130
00:06:31.830 --> 00:06:36.360
And so, now that's in business I can do
a no shut down, and it should come up and

131
00:06:36.360 --> 00:06:38.700
try to rejoin the core port channel.

132
00:06:38.700 --> 00:06:42.490
And since they're identical,
it shouldn't have any problems.

133
00:06:42.490 --> 00:06:46.890
Now I'm gonna wait for just a moment and
I can continue to do some

134
00:06:46.890 --> 00:06:49.590
show ether channel summary,
which is a command I like.

135
00:06:50.770 --> 00:06:52.040
And we can run that.

136
00:06:52.040 --> 00:06:53.720
And I'm waiting for port 23 and

137
00:06:53.720 --> 00:06:57.169
24 both to go with a capital P letting me
know they're active and in the bundle.

138
00:06:58.230 --> 00:07:03.070
And then, I can go back to the command
they gave us originally, which I'm sure is

139
00:07:03.070 --> 00:07:08.330
in my command history here somewhere, show
interface port-channel 1 etherchannel.

140
00:07:08.330 --> 00:07:10.840
And what I should see is that
I now have the two ports

141
00:07:10.840 --> 00:07:13.210
participating right in there.

142
00:07:13.210 --> 00:07:16.340
You'll find that etherchannel
is pretty easy to troubleshoot

143
00:07:16.340 --> 00:07:19.920
cuz as long as you have one good port, you
can just look at it's config and compare.

144
00:07:21.290 --> 00:07:25.540
Be aware though, that the configuration
could actually be wrong between the ports

145
00:07:25.540 --> 00:07:26.820
and the port channel.

146
00:07:26.820 --> 00:07:32.070
So, if I still have problems I would wanna
take a look at that configuration for

147
00:07:32.070 --> 00:07:33.980
the port channel itself.

148
00:07:33.980 --> 00:07:37.980
And look there and make sure that my
hardware ports are matching this virtual

149
00:07:37.980 --> 00:07:41.530
ports configuration cuz if those don't
match they won't go active either.

150
00:07:41.530 --> 00:07:44.220
But in that scenario, I probably would
have had all of my physical interfaces

151
00:07:44.220 --> 00:07:46.030
suspended and not just the one.

152
00:07:46.030 --> 00:07:48.450
In this case it's fixed, it's up and

153
00:07:48.450 --> 00:07:50.940
now the port channel is working
the way that it needed to.

154
00:07:50.940 --> 00:07:55.270
The other thing is I fixed it
on one side of the port channel,

155
00:07:55.270 --> 00:07:58.390
maybe I'm having a problem on the other
side of the port channel also.

156
00:07:58.390 --> 00:07:59.940
The mistake was made here.

157
00:07:59.940 --> 00:08:01.860
It makes sense it could have
happened on the other side.

158
00:08:01.860 --> 00:08:04.400
Now I doubt that's the case,
cuz these did come up in bond,

159
00:08:04.400 --> 00:08:08.730
and they are set to desirable,
so they're trying to bond.

160
00:08:08.730 --> 00:08:13.520
It's still auto though, so
if it failed then they could go back to

161
00:08:13.520 --> 00:08:16.250
not being in the bundle, and that
didn't happen, they're not standalone.

162
00:08:16.250 --> 00:08:18.620
So we should be good, but
just to be on the safe side,

163
00:08:18.620 --> 00:08:23.880
I'm gonna jump over to CORE1 and verify
the configuration on that switch too and

164
00:08:23.880 --> 00:08:26.880
just make sure that it's showing
a healthy bundle on its side.

165
00:08:26.880 --> 00:08:28.690
So I'll just do a show
either channel summary.

166
00:08:30.360 --> 00:08:34.610
And ports 23 and
24 are both active in the bundle.

167
00:08:34.610 --> 00:08:35.830
Looks like we're good.

168
00:08:35.830 --> 00:08:38.420
All right so in this case it simply
came down to one port having

169
00:08:38.420 --> 00:08:41.430
a different configuration for
a another port in the same port channel.

170
00:08:41.430 --> 00:08:44.280
And the lower port number one,
it's the one that went active.

171
00:08:44.280 --> 00:08:46.640
The other one or actually it was
a higher one that won in this case,

172
00:08:46.640 --> 00:08:48.570
it was the one that went active and
trunking,.

173
00:08:48.570 --> 00:08:51.890
The other was in access mode and
it was suspended at the end of the day.

174
00:08:51.890 --> 00:08:55.770
The reason the higher port one is it
matched the port channel configuration.

175
00:08:55.770 --> 00:08:59.930
And once we got all that squared away, it
was up, it was running and now we're done.

176
00:08:59.930 --> 00:09:01.600
And that wraps it up for
this troubleshooting question.

177
00:09:01.600 --> 00:09:03.120
Stay tuned we've got more coming up.

178
00:09:03.120 --> 00:09:05.005
We'll do issue number four next for
set number three.

179
00:09:05.005 --> 00:09:06.120
Stay tuned for that.

180
00:09:08.860 --> 00:09:11.591
More troubleshooting adventures coming up.

181
00:09:11.591 --> 00:09:12.630
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #4` from set #3. The trouble ticket states that "You are unable to communicate from PLABCSCO01 to 172.16.16.2 "
episodes.title: Set 3 Issue 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.160 --> 00:00:08.881
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.881 --> 00:00:12.192
In this video we're gonna take
a look at Set 3, Issue 4, yet

3
00:00:12.192 --> 00:00:15.632
another problem with our Cisco
topology here, and on this one,

4
00:00:15.632 --> 00:00:19.220
we've got another server can't
ping an IP type problem, right?

5
00:00:19.220 --> 00:00:21.190
So the troubleshooting ticket
reads like this, it says.

6
00:00:21.190 --> 00:00:24.300
You are unable to communicate
from PLABCISCO01,

7
00:00:24.300 --> 00:00:30.280
which is our server that we've
used before, to 172.16.16.2.

8
00:00:30.280 --> 00:00:32.450
So just some random IP out there.

9
00:00:32.450 --> 00:00:34.317
Let's start by taking
a look at our topology and

10
00:00:34.317 --> 00:00:36.290
see if we can't figure out
where that problem is.

11
00:00:36.290 --> 00:00:37.791
Now, our server, I know that one,

12
00:00:37.791 --> 00:00:40.103
we've worked with it in
a number of problems, right?

13
00:00:40.103 --> 00:00:43.400
192.168.16.10, that one
hasn't changed much.

14
00:00:45.160 --> 00:00:49.090
But the other network that I'm
trying to get to, 172.16.16.2,

15
00:00:49.090 --> 00:00:51.000
I'm not familiar with that.

16
00:00:51.000 --> 00:00:54.652
So we might need to zoom out a bit and
try and find out where that topology is.

17
00:00:54.652 --> 00:00:56.720
I'm gonna look at some of
these external networks, and

18
00:00:56.720 --> 00:00:58.990
I don't see it in that list over here and

19
00:00:58.990 --> 00:01:03.190
I don't see it in this list over here,
there we go, there's our culprit.

20
00:01:03.190 --> 00:01:08.104
So, way out here in-between NYWAN1 and
this external network NWRKWAN1,

21
00:01:08.104 --> 00:01:13.481
we don't have access to that system,
that's out on our fake, kind of, Internet.

22
00:01:13.481 --> 00:01:14.540
I can't get to that, right?

23
00:01:14.540 --> 00:01:21.780
So, my server PLABCISCO1 way down here,
can't get to this network out here.

24
00:01:21.780 --> 00:01:23.750
Now, that's a big jump.

25
00:01:23.750 --> 00:01:25.830
If you look at the topology here,

26
00:01:25.830 --> 00:01:29.760
I know that PLABCISCO1 has to go to
Access1 because it's plugged into it.

27
00:01:29.760 --> 00:01:34.550
And I know that NYCORE2 is active for
HSRP so that's my default gateway, so

28
00:01:34.550 --> 00:01:35.900
I've got to go to it.

29
00:01:35.900 --> 00:01:40.090
And then it's gonna send me to CORE1
