permits my host or everybody else and then
we can even leave that in if we wanted.

245
00:13:58.600 --> 00:14:01.489
Maybe I'll go that route, we got more
than one solution to our problem.

246
00:14:02.890 --> 00:14:07.050
All right so, whoops, [LAUGH] I'm gonna
exit the router, that's all of my plan.

247
00:14:07.050 --> 00:14:08.171
I'm gonna get into my configuration.

248
00:14:08.171 --> 00:14:12.952
I'll do an ip access-list extended and

249
00:14:12.952 --> 00:14:16.190
the list was called NATME.

250
00:14:16.190 --> 00:14:19.390
And actually I don't remember if
it had a space in its name or not.

251
00:14:19.390 --> 00:14:20.310
I don't think it did.

252
00:14:21.750 --> 00:14:24.879
I guess we can verify that real quick.

253
00:14:24.879 --> 00:14:28.830
Let me just do a, show access-list,
make sure I didn't create a new one.

254
00:14:28.830 --> 00:14:33.320
Yeah, it was just called NATME an I could
remove line 10 and just add another one.

255
00:14:33.320 --> 00:14:38.890
So I could say, no 10, and get 10 out of
there, and then put in a new line 10.

256
00:14:38.890 --> 00:14:43.010
So I could say permit ip any any,

257
00:14:43.010 --> 00:14:48.350
and now I've got it with no crazy
time range, it's just removed.

258
00:14:48.350 --> 00:14:52.979
And if I get out of that,
I can do a show access-list, whoops,

259
00:14:52.979 --> 00:14:54.870
which I might be able to spell.

260
00:14:57.060 --> 00:14:59.520
And now I've got that NATME set up

261
00:14:59.520 --> 00:15:03.510
where it'll permit everybody through to
get NATed, no time applied to it anymore.

262
00:15:03.510 --> 00:15:05.710
All right, so
that's more than likely our problem.

263
00:15:05.710 --> 00:15:06.610
We could stop right here.

264
00:15:06.610 --> 00:15:09.350
But we definitely need to test it because
there's other things that could be

265
00:15:09.350 --> 00:15:10.310
a problem, too.

266
00:15:10.310 --> 00:15:13.260
I fixed NAT, maybe there's
something else going on, right?

267
00:15:13.260 --> 00:15:17.100
I do see there's another access list
up here that's doing something and

268
00:15:17.100 --> 00:15:18.270
I haven't seen that one.

269
00:15:18.270 --> 00:15:22.490
Although it's got a big fat permit ip any
any, so I'm probably safe with this one.

270
00:15:22.490 --> 00:15:28.060
But you never know, so let's go and test
it out, I'm gonna jump over to PLABCISCO01

271
00:15:28.060 --> 00:15:33.240
and we'll just retest that
ping from the very beginning.

272
00:15:33.240 --> 00:15:36.080
And now we can get there, all right?

273
00:15:36.080 --> 00:15:41.970
So this one turned out to be
NAT which was actually caused

274
00:15:41.970 --> 00:15:46.250
by an ACL which was actually caused by
a time range assigned to a particular ACE,

275
00:15:46.250 --> 00:15:48.230
an access control entry, on that list.

276
00:15:48.230 --> 00:15:50.270
So kind of a cascading problem, right?

277
00:15:50.270 --> 00:15:51.290
Each one was a symptom,

278
00:15:51.290 --> 00:15:55.330
the actual cause being that the time
range was set to the wrong year.

279
00:15:55.330 --> 00:15:58.060
And that made this ACL not apply,
and we weren't getting that.

280
00:15:58.060 --> 00:16:00.270
And now we are, and
we're up and we're going and

281
00:16:00.270 --> 00:16:02.820
we're communicated so
that kind of solves this one.

282
00:16:02.820 --> 00:16:04.690
A little bit trickier
because we had to dig deep.

283
00:16:04.690 --> 00:16:07.850
Fortunately, we used traceroute to
find the source of the problem, right?

284
00:16:07.850 --> 00:16:08.884
To get right to that point and

285
00:16:08.884 --> 00:16:11.590
not have to look at a bunch of
equipment that wasn't involved.

286
00:16:11.590 --> 00:16:14.790
And then we were able to troubleshoot it
from there and kind of locate that issue.

287
00:16:14.790 --> 00:16:17.650
Doing a show running dash config was
really useful here because there were so

288
00:16:17.650 --> 00:16:19.370
many different possible problems.

289
00:16:19.370 --> 00:16:21.770
It just allow us to skim
over the config and look for

290
00:16:21.770 --> 00:16:23.820
the issues that kind of
jump right out at us.

291
00:16:23.820 --> 00:16:25.840
All right, well,
that knocks this problem out.

292
00:16:25.840 --> 00:16:26.390
Stayed tuned,

293
00:16:26.390 --> 00:16:28.910
we've got more troubleshooting issues
before we're done with set three.

294
00:16:28.910 --> 00:16:35.015
So I hope to see you then, otherwise,
good luck with your troubleshooting.

295
00:16:35.015 --> 00:16:39.874
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #5` from set #3. The trouble ticket states that "NYCORE1 is the active HSRP member for VLAN 14, this should be NYCORE2 "
episodes.title: Set 3 Issue 5
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:04.206
[SOUND] All right,

2
00:00:04.206 --> 00:00:11.180
it is time for Set 3 Issue 5.

3
00:00:11.180 --> 00:00:12.754
And we've got a winner on this one.

4
00:00:12.754 --> 00:00:16.021
It's gonna be a nice complex one if you
got used to some of the easy I can't

5
00:00:16.021 --> 00:00:16.620
ping stuff.

6
00:00:16.620 --> 00:00:17.790
Now we get some fun.

7
00:00:17.790 --> 00:00:22.230
This one, it's sounds like a pretty easy
one, but it's actually pretty difficult.

8
00:00:22.230 --> 00:00:27.593
What we're dealing with here is an HSRP
issue and the ticket reads like this,

9
00:00:27.593 --> 00:00:32.890
NYCORE1 is the active HSRP member for
VLAN 14, this should be NYCORE2.

10
00:00:32.890 --> 00:00:35.060
Sounds easy enough, right?

11
00:00:35.060 --> 00:00:37.900
Got HSRP configured between
these two switches.

12
00:00:37.900 --> 00:00:40.440
One's supposed to be active,
one's supposed to be standby and for

13
00:00:40.440 --> 00:00:41.550
some reason it's backwards.

14
00:00:41.550 --> 00:00:45.660
In my mind I'm listening to that and
I'm thinking, all right well one node must

15
00:00:45.660 --> 00:00:49.890
be down or one node has the wrong
priority, this will be an easy fix.

16
00:00:49.890 --> 00:00:52.130
But if we take a look
at that configuration,

17
00:00:52.130 --> 00:00:54.180
we'll actually see that
that's not the case.

18
00:00:54.180 --> 00:00:57.740
So we're gonna have to do a little work
on this to figure out why that is.

19
00:00:57.740 --> 00:01:00.070
Let's take a look at our
topology before we get started.

20
00:01:00.070 --> 00:01:04.110
The two switches in question are these
guys right here, NYCORE1 and NYCORE2.

21
00:01:04.110 --> 00:01:08.330
They have an ether
channel in between them.

22
00:01:08.330 --> 00:01:10.940
Two bonded connections,
they're just 100 megabit connections, so

23
00:01:10.940 --> 00:01:13.110
it's got a 200 megabit
connection between them.

24
00:01:13.110 --> 00:01:16.270
And should be up, should be healthy,
they should see each other.

25
00:01:16.270 --> 00:01:24.390
And for VLAN 14, we expect NYCORE2 to be
active but instead, NYCORE1 is active.

26
00:01:24.390 --> 00:01:27.600
All right, so
I wanna start by looking at NYCORE2.

27
00:01:27.600 --> 00:01:30.100
It's the one that's supposed to be active.

28
00:01:30.100 --> 00:01:32.980
So if it's got a downed interface or
something like that,

29
00:01:32.980 --> 00:01:34.880
that's where the problem's
gonna be evident.

30
00:01:34.880 --> 00:01:37.980
This guy over here, NYCORE1,
is probably just doing its job.

31
00:01:37.980 --> 00:01:42.280
It's probably, hey there's a failure on
CORE2 so CORE1 steps up and takes over.

32
00:01:42.280 --> 00:01:43.820
So that's more than likely what we have.

33
00:01:43.820 --> 00:01:46.610
It could be though,
that CORE1 is configured wrong.

34
00:01:46.610 --> 00:01:50.010
CORE1 could have a higher priority
than it's supposed to and

35
00:01:50.010 --> 00:01:52.780
then that would make it take over,
and the problem could be over here.

36
00:01:52.780 --> 00:01:57.450
So I don't wanna ignore that one, but
assuming that HSRP is working the way that

37
00:01:57.450 --> 00:02:00.600
it's supposed to CORE2 more
than like like has an issue and

38
00:02:00.600 --> 00:02:03.420
that's more than likely why it's
not active when it should be.

39
00:02:03.420 --> 00:02:04.930
So that's why I'm gonna start on CORE2.

40
00:02:04.930 --> 00:02:07.740
The reality is you could start on
either one, it really wouldn't matter.

41
00:02:07.740 --> 00:02:09.830
Just you rule one out,
you move to the other.

42
00:02:09.830 --> 00:02:11.960
I'm gonna start on the most likely one,
which is CORE2.

43
00:02:11.960 --> 00:02:17.570
So, over on CORE2, the first thing I
wanna look at really are the interfaces.

44
00:02:17.570 --> 00:02:21.530
An interface going down is the most
common reason for HSRP to fail over.

45
00:02:21.530 --> 00:02:24.520
So, I'm just gonna do a quick
show IP interface brief.

46
00:02:24.520 --> 00:02:29.430
Now where this gets tricky is that on
a switch you've got tons of interfaces,

47
00:02:29.430 --> 00:02:31.680
virtual interfaces and
physical interfaces.

48
00:02:31.680 --> 00:02:32.860
This is VLAN 14.

49
00:02:32.860 --> 00:02:36.400
So, HSRP is actually tied
to the VLAN interface.

50
00:02:36.400 --> 00:02:40.020
So as long as that VLAN interface is up,
we should be in good shape.

51
00:02:40.020 --> 00:02:44.210
And so, what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna
filter this to only include ports

52
00:02:44.210 --> 00:02:48.450
that have IP addresses, so
I'll just exclude in the unassigned ports.

53
00:02:48.450 --> 00:02:51.620
So I can see VLAN 14 right here.

54
00:02:51.620 --> 00:02:54.260
And what I'm looking for
is the status of that port.

55
00:02:54.260 --> 00:02:56.550
I want to make sure that
it shows us up up, and

56
00:02:56.550 --> 00:02:58.280
sure enough I can see that it does.

57
00:02:58.280 --> 00:03:00.320
The interface is up.

58
00:03:00.320 --> 00:03:01.850
If all of my interface,

59
00:03:01.850 --> 00:03:05.840
my physical interfaces on VLAN 14 are
down, this VLAN interface would go down.

60
00:03:05.840 --> 00:03:08.660
Or if my trunks were down,
this would go down.

61
00:03:08.660 --> 00:03:13.500
But it's up, so that tells me that at a
minimum I've got at least one port in VLAN

62
00:03:13.500 --> 00:03:14.500
14 that's working.

63
00:03:14.500 --> 00:03:17.300
And at a minimum, I probably have
at least one trunk that's working.

64
00:03:17.300 --> 00:03:19.250
We could actually find
that out really easy.

65
00:03:19.250 --> 00:03:24.340
If we do a show VLAN, I can look for VLAN
14, and it doesn't look like I have any

66
00:03:24.340 --> 00:03:30.340
access ports in VLAN 14, but if I do
a show interface trunk, there we go.

67
00:03:30.340 --> 00:03:33.110
I can see that I've actually got
two trunks carrying VLAN 14.

68
00:03:33.110 --> 00:03:38.150
I've got a trunk on port 22 and
a trunk on PO 1, that port channel, right?

69
00:03:38.150 --> 00:03:40.810
They're both carrying VLAN 14.

70
00:03:40.810 --> 00:03:44.070
So they're up and my VLAN interface is up.

71
00:03:44.070 --> 00:03:48.610
So if this guy is set to be the active
HSRP router, interfaces are up,

72
00:03:48.610 --> 00:03:50.240
it should be good to go.

73
00:03:50.240 --> 00:03:51.380
Let's take a look at that.

74
00:03:51.380 --> 00:03:54.020
I'm gonna do a show standby for VLAN 14.

75
00:03:54.020 --> 00:04:00.160
I should be active, but
when I look my state is listen.

76
00:04:00.160 --> 00:04:02.850
Now that's a really interesting
state to have, listen.

77
00:04:02.850 --> 00:04:05.960
I'm not active and I'm not standby.

78
00:04:05.960 --> 00:04:06.890
I'm listen.

79
00:04:06.890 --> 00:04:08.330
What the heck is that all about?

80
00:04:08.330 --> 00:04:11.690
Well, they told me
NYCORE1 should be active.

81
00:04:11.690 --> 00:04:13.320
NYCORE2 should be standby.

82
00:04:13.320 --> 00:04:15.700
They didn't say anybody should be listen.

83
00:04:15.700 --> 00:04:18.270
Right?
Listen is technically the other state

84
00:04:18.270 --> 00:04:18.850
in HSRP.

85
00:04:18.850 --> 00:04:23.550
You can have an HSRP cluster with
16 routers in it if you want.

86
00:04:23.550 --> 00:04:24.950
One will go active.

87
00:04:24.950 --> 00:04:26.410
Another will go standby.

88
00:04:26.410 --> 00:04:30.570
And the other 14 will go into
the other state, which is listen.

89
00:04:30.570 --> 00:04:32.130
And that's what I'm seeing here.

90
00:04:32.130 --> 00:04:34.630
So I'm not active or
standby, which is odd.

91
00:04:34.630 --> 00:04:40.066
And if I look down here I can see I've
got an active router, 192.168.14.2,

92
00:04:40.066 --> 00:04:43.922
and I've got a standby router,
192.168.14.4.

93
00:04:43.922 --> 00:04:50.508
Well, those IPs, if you remember them from
the other sets, that is CORE1 and EDGE1.

94
00:04:50.508 --> 00:04:53.860
EDGE1 is a part of this HSRP cluster also.

95
00:04:53.860 --> 00:04:57.800
And so NYCORE1 has gone active.

96
00:04:57.800 --> 00:05:00.180
NYEDGE1 has gone standby.

97
00:05:00.180 --> 00:05:01.360
And I'm even lower than that.

98
00:05:01.360 --> 00:05:02.550
All right?

99
00:05:02.550 --> 00:05:06.140
Now that's a big red flag for
me because that means that either my

100
00:05:06.140 --> 00:05:11.110
priority is set really low, or
I've got a true fault on this system and

101
00:05:11.110 --> 00:05:13.120
that's making the other
two guys take over for me.

102
00:05:13.120 --> 00:05:15.480
I'm not even good enough
to be stand by right now.

103
00:05:15.480 --> 00:05:18.240
So there's more than likely going to
be an issue right here on CORE2, so

104
00:05:18.240 --> 00:05:21.580
we are in the right place I think for
finding this program.

105
00:05:21.580 --> 00:05:22.110
Right.

106
00:05:22.110 --> 00:05:23.670
Now as I look at it.

107
00:05:23.670 --> 00:05:28.370
I can see the active
router is 192.168.14.2.

108
00:05:28.370 --> 00:05:29.610
And it's priority is 90.

109
00:05:29.610 --> 00:05:32.520
Now the default priority in HRSP is 100.

110
00:05:32.520 --> 00:05:35.480
It's a good thing to have memorized for
the exam.

111
00:05:35.480 --> 00:05:38.830
Default is 100 and the higher number wins.

112
00:05:38.830 --> 00:05:42.550
This one's set to 90, so somebody
has purposefully lowered it by ten.

113
00:05:42.550 --> 00:05:46.530
I can see the standby router,
which is NYEDGE1 has a priority of 85.

114
00:05:46.530 --> 00:05:50.650
So somebody has purposely
lowered it by 15.

115
00:05:50.650 --> 00:05:54.880
But then when I look at my priority,
my priority is 70.

116
00:05:54.880 --> 00:05:57.950
So I've got a lower priority
than the other guys,

117
00:05:57.950 --> 00:06:00.620
so that's gonna make me
go into the listen mode.

118
00:06:00.620 --> 00:06:05.270
So this may be as simple as changing that,
except it's not quite that simple.

119
00:06:05.270 --> 00:06:09.450
Notice the next line,
this is what makes this a complex problem.

120
00:06:09.450 --> 00:06:12.700
If it were just a matter of changing
priority, this would be super easy.

121
00:06:12.700 --> 00:06:15.362
I could go and set my priority to 91 or
higher, right?

122
00:06:15.362 --> 00:06:17.630
255 is the highest number,
100 is the default.

123
00:06:17.630 --> 00:06:20.690
So I could myself back to default and
I'd become active.

124
00:06:20.690 --> 00:06:26.528
But the very next line tells me,
track object 14 state Down decrement 30.

125
00:06:26.528 --> 00:06:30.410
All right,
that's telling me that my default is 100.

126
00:06:30.410 --> 00:06:31.520
I am set to 100.

127
00:06:31.520 --> 00:06:36.090
But I'm tracking an object and
the track object is down.

128
00:06:36.090 --> 00:06:39.100
And when it went down it set to decrement
me 30 and that's why I'm at 70.

129
00:06:39.100 --> 00:06:43.380
So I've got a fault on my network,
my track object is failing.

130
00:06:43.380 --> 00:06:47.517
And as long as it's failing my
priority was deducted by 30.

131
00:06:47.517 --> 00:06:50.320
Now I could,
[LAUGH] we could cheat, right.

132
00:06:50.320 --> 00:06:54.340
We could set our priority to 130 and
then it'll decrement us by 31 but

133
00:06:54.340 --> 00:06:55.980
100 will stay active.

134
00:06:55.980 --> 00:06:57.540
But that doesn't really fix the problem.

135
00:06:57.540 --> 00:06:59.430
The problem here is that our
track object is failing,

136
00:06:59.430 --> 00:07:01.480
we need to find out why and get it fixed.

137
00:07:01.480 --> 00:07:05.970
Cuz as soon as we fix that track object
our priority will go up 30 points, and

138
00:07:05.970 --> 00:07:07.460
now we should be active again.

139
00:07:07.460 --> 00:07:08.040
Okay.

140
00:07:08.040 --> 00:07:11.540
So while it was described as
an HSRP problem in the ticket,

141
00:07:11.540 --> 00:07:13.780
it really isn't an HSRP problem, is it?

142
00:07:13.780 --> 00:07:16.690
It's really figuring
out this track object.

143
00:07:16.690 --> 00:07:21.700
If I do a show track, I can get
an idea of what that track object is,

144
00:07:21.700 --> 00:07:26.460
and I can see that we've got track 14 and
it's set to monitor for a route.

145
00:07:26.460 --> 00:07:30.517
It's looking for
route 192.168.224.0, all right?

146
00:07:30.517 --> 00:07:31.936
And it's tracking reachability.

147
00:07:31.936 --> 00:07:35.430
So can we do a routing table lookup for
that route?

148
00:07:35.430 --> 00:07:37.950
If we can, great, this passes.

149
00:07:37.950 --> 00:07:39.840
If we can't, it fails, all right?

150
00:07:39.840 --> 00:07:42.870
And I can see right now my reachability
is down, I've got no route.

151
00:07:42.870 --> 00:07:48.339
And if I don't trust it I can always
do a show ip route 192.168.224.0.

152
00:07:48.339 --> 00:07:50.430
And network not in table.

153
00:07:50.430 --> 00:07:54.675
Okay, so, my priority is being
directly affected by that.

154
00:07:54.675 --> 00:07:57.170
And if I do a show run for
interface VLAN 14,

155
00:07:57.170 --> 00:07:59.748
I should be able to see
where that's defined.

156
00:07:59.748 --> 00:08:00.433
Right here.

157
00:08:00.433 --> 00:08:04.787
Standby 14 track 14 decrement 30, right.

158
00:08:04.787 --> 00:08:09.559
So, when that route came out of my routing
table, then we decremented by 30, and

159
00:08:09.559 --> 00:08:14.740
now we're not active or standby, the other
routers are better than us, all right.

160
00:08:14.740 --> 00:08:18.160
So we need to find out why that
route is not in our routing table.

161
00:08:18.160 --> 00:08:21.290
Well, the first piece of that puzzle is
gonna be to figure out where that route

162
00:08:21.290 --> 00:08:22.360
even comes from, right.

163
00:08:22.360 --> 00:08:27.027
192.168.224 is not a network I'm familiar
with so I'm gonna assume that it's coming

164
00:08:27.027 --> 00:08:30.753
from one of these outside networks and
sure enough, we've got it right here.

165
00:08:30.753 --> 00:08:37.840
192.168.224 is a network coming from
outside, right, it's coming from beyond.

166
00:08:37.840 --> 00:08:42.300
And it's in EIGRP autonomous system 800,
which is kind of like our Internet or

167
00:08:42.300 --> 00:08:43.810
external network.

168
00:08:43.810 --> 00:08:47.315
The first router that I control is NYWAN1.

169
00:08:47.315 --> 00:08:50.090
NYWAN1 should know about that network.

170
00:08:50.090 --> 00:08:53.011
And if I want my internal
routers to know about it,

171
00:08:53.011 --> 00:08:56.572

00:19:58.090 --> 00:20:01.610

00:20:27.220 --> 00:20:30.780
We made sure the desired route was

00:20:30.780 --> 00:20:34.570

00:20:34.570 --> 00:20:37.720

00:20:37.720 --> 00:20:40.740
So it looked like an HSRP

00:20:50.790 --> 00:20:54.040
But for this one, we can go ahead and
call this one done, it is wrapped up.

390
00:20:54.040 --> 00:20:55.366
But stay tuned,

391
00:20:55.366 --> 00:21:01.250
we've got a few more troubleshooting
issues before we wrap up set three.

392
00:21:01.250 --> 00:21:03.230
I hope to see you then.

393
00:21:03.230 --> 00:21:07.410
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #6` from set #3. The trouble ticket states that "The path from PLABCSCO01 to 192.168.100.1 is going via NYEDGE1 and not directly via NYEDGE2 from NYCORE2 "
episodes.title: Set 3 Issue 6
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.087 --> 00:00:08.545
[SOUND]
Welcome back,

2
00:00:08.545 --> 00:00:12.860
and it looks like we've got another
reachability issue for set 3 issue 6.

3
00:00:12.860 --> 00:00:16.340
We've got a bit of a routing
problem that's going on here.

4
00:00:16.340 --> 00:00:20.480
So it's not so much reachability as
that we can get to where we want to go,

5
00:00:20.480 --> 00:00:21.620
we're just going the wrong way.

6
00:00:21.620 --> 00:00:27.070
The troubleshooting ticket reads like
this, it says the path from P Lab Cisco 01

7
00:00:27.070 --> 00:00:33.660
to the destination of 192.168.100.1
is going via NY edge 1 and

8
00:00:33.660 --> 00:00:39.430
not directly via NY edge 2 from CORE2,
so we need to find out why.

9
00:00:39.430 --> 00:00:42.646
Now a lot of it doesn't make any
sense unless we see our diagram, so

10
00:00:42.646 --> 00:00:46.797
let's jump over to our network diagram and
kinda put this into perspective, right?

11
00:00:46.797 --> 00:00:51.560
So our server, that's this guy way down
here at the bottom, PLABCISCO01, and

12
00:00:51.560 --> 00:00:56.754
we're trying to get to a network,
192.168.100., what did it say, .1.

13
00:00:56.754 --> 00:01:00.193
All right, so that's the host
that I'm trying to get to, and

14
00:01:00.193 --> 00:01:03.280
it's saying that I should
be going to Core2.

15
00:01:03.280 --> 00:01:06.200
Which I know it's running
HHRP it's the active node.

16
00:01:06.200 --> 00:01:08.190
I should be going to that
as my default gateway.

17
00:01:08.190 --> 00:01:10.120
I should be going to Core2 and

18
00:01:10.120 --> 00:01:14.980
then directly to Edge 2 which will
directly connect me to this other network.

19
00:01:14.980 --> 00:01:18.940
The other networks apparently
out there in OSPF Area 61.

20
00:01:18.940 --> 00:01:25.040
But it's telling me instead of doing that,
I'm going through EDGE 1 and

21
00:01:25.040 --> 00:01:28.240
then to EDGE2 and out to the network.

22
00:01:28.240 --> 00:01:30.980
So I'm going through what's
called a sub-optimal path.

23
00:01:30.980 --> 00:01:33.550
I can get there,
I can still get routed out, but

24
00:01:33.550 --> 00:01:37.770
I'm just not going the way that I
really intend to go, that I want to go.

25
00:01:37.770 --> 00:01:41.670
So I need to find out why and
see if I can get that corrected, okay?

26
00:01:41.670 --> 00:01:44.980
This is more than likely just
a routing issue, we probably have some

27
00:01:44.980 --> 00:01:49.150
Some invalid metrics defined or
a route that's not being advertised.

28
00:01:49.150 --> 00:01:51.330
Somebody's not participating in routing
protocols, something like that.

29
00:01:51.330 --> 00:01:53.840
Those are different things that
could pop up that could cause this.

30
00:01:53.840 --> 00:01:56.180
But it's more than likely
gonna be a routing issue.

31
00:01:56.180 --> 00:01:58.690
Could be, could be ACLs,
could be route maps,

32
00:01:58.690 --> 00:02:00.420
could be all sorts of other crazy things.

33
00:02:00.420 --> 00:02:03.680
But usually the simpler problems
are a little more More accurate, for

34
00:02:03.680 --> 00:02:06.540
example, it could just be
these interfaces here or down.

35
00:02:06.540 --> 00:02:08.940
If these link were down between CORE2 and
EDGE2,

36
00:02:08.940 --> 00:02:14.030
then I would expect to go up to
EDGE1 over to EDGE2 and then out.

37
00:02:14.030 --> 00:02:16.890
So it could be as simple
as an interface shut down.

38
00:02:16.890 --> 00:02:21.030
But before I start diving into all that
Let's do a traceroute to make sure that

39
00:02:21.030 --> 00:02:24.710
we're actually seeing what they say,
they're saying that if I were to do

40
00:02:24.710 --> 00:02:29.720
a traceroute from this server,
I should go to Core 2, I should then go

41
00:02:29.720 --> 00:02:34.900
up to edge 1 over to Edge 2 and
then out, okay?

42
00:02:34.900 --> 00:02:38.530
So let's see if that's happening,
I'm going to jump over to that server And

43
00:02:38.530 --> 00:02:41.910
we're just gonna do a quick trace
route to see if we can get to it.

44
00:02:41.910 --> 00:02:44.780
I'm just gonna start with a ping
to see if I can even ping that IP

45
00:02:44.780 --> 00:02:46.220
they're telling me about.

46
00:02:46.220 --> 00:02:48.990
And I can so at least we've got that.

47
00:02:48.990 --> 00:02:51.850
And then I'll do my trace
route to the same IP.

48
00:02:52.980 --> 00:02:54.760
looking at the path that we follow.

49
00:02:54.760 --> 00:02:58.710
So, I expect to hit Core2,
which is 192.168.16.3.

50
00:02:58.710 --> 00:03:01.920
My default gateway is .1, but it's HSRP.

51
00:03:01.920 --> 00:03:03.360
So, I'll see that unique IP.

52
00:03:03.360 --> 00:03:04.390
There it is.

53
00:03:04.390 --> 00:03:08.110
And then they're saying I'm gonna
jump over to Edge1, which is .4.

54
00:03:08.110 --> 00:03:10.160
So, there we go, 192.168.16.4.

55
00:03:10.160 --> 00:03:11.140
We went to Edge1.

56
00:03:11.140 --> 00:03:15.860
From edge 1,
it should jump us over to edge 2.

57
00:03:15.860 --> 00:03:18.490
Which is apparently where
192.168.100.1 resides

58
00:03:18.490 --> 00:03:21.080
because that's where it terminated.

59
00:03:21.080 --> 00:03:24.540
So I see that I'm kind of going
the wrong way about things.

60
00:03:24.540 --> 00:03:25.800
I need to fix that.

61
00:03:25.800 --> 00:03:29.330
Well, I need to look at some routing
tables to figure out why that happened.

62
00:03:29.330 --> 00:03:31.120
And if you think about
the routing tables here,

63
00:03:31.120 --> 00:03:33.450
we can actually locate
the problem pretty easy.

64
00:03:33.450 --> 00:03:36.760
Because, the route only had three hops.

65
00:03:36.760 --> 00:03:42.340
The first hop was core two, the second hop
was edge one, and the third hop was our

66
00:03:42.340 --> 00:03:46.000
destination, edge two, that that IP must
be a loop back interface on that router or

67
00:03:46.000 --> 00:03:48.510
something, something directly plugged
into it, cause it didn't go very far.

68
00:03:48.510 --> 00:03:53.250
So,if I've only got three hops,
and edge one is

69
00:03:53.250 --> 00:03:57.360
already passed my mistake then that person
who's making that decision is Core2.

70
00:03:57.360 --> 00:04:02.780
Core 2 is actively making a decision not
to go to Edge2 and instead to go to Edge1.

71
00:04:02.780 --> 00:04:05.930
So let's jump over to Core2 and
find out why it's making that decision.

72
00:04:05.930 --> 00:04:08.080
Right.
What's influencing it?

73
00:04:08.080 --> 00:04:12.220
So if I jump over to Core2,
we can take a look at its routing table.

74
00:04:14.130 --> 00:04:15.390
And I'm gonna do a show IP route and

75
00:04:15.390 --> 00:04:18.850
I'm just going to just filter
that down from 192.68.100.

76
00:04:18.850 --> 00:04:19.350
Whoops.

77
00:04:21.060 --> 00:04:22.250
There we go.

78
00:04:22.250 --> 00:04:23.030
And sure enough,

79
00:04:23.030 --> 00:04:26.100
I've got that route and it's telling
me I can get there via 192.168.16.4.

80
00:04:26.100 --> 00:04:30.640
So I can get to it via that network.

81
00:04:30.640 --> 00:04:34.330
And .4 that's Edge1.

82
00:04:34.330 --> 00:04:37.220
So I'm going to edge one
instead of edge two.

83
00:04:37.220 --> 00:04:40.410
Now edge two,
I actually don't remember its IP address.

84
00:04:40.410 --> 00:04:43.420
I want to say it doesn't
have an IP on Vlan16.

85
00:04:43.420 --> 00:04:45.400
I think its on Vlan12 if I remember it.

86
00:04:45.400 --> 00:04:46.240
Let's find out.

87
00:04:46.240 --> 00:04:51.910
So, if I jump over to edge two, I'm gonna

88
00:04:51.910 --> 00:04:57.010
just do a quick show IP interface brief
here to see what I've got working here.

89
00:04:57.010 --> 00:04:59.820
And yeah, it's 192.162.12.5 so

90
00:04:59.820 --> 00:05:04.200
it's on this different network
than the other ones right.

91
00:05:04.200 --> 00:05:06.080
It doesn't have one on V-LAN 16,
it's on V-LAN 12.

92
00:05:06.080 --> 00:05:09.350
It's not a big deal,
I should still be communicating with it.

93
00:05:09.350 --> 00:05:13.890
So let's find out where my problem is,
now if I go back to my topology here

94
00:05:15.130 --> 00:05:18.740
everybody, all four of these
guys are in OSPF Area 0.

95
00:05:18.740 --> 00:05:22.480
So we should all be exchanging and
learning routes the same way.

96
00:05:22.480 --> 00:05:24.800
I'm learning a route to
192.168.100 via NYEDGE1 via OSPF.

97
00:05:24.800 --> 00:05:33.080
I should be learning a route from
NYEDGE2 via OSPF also all right?

98
00:05:33.080 --> 00:05:36.920
But I'm not, or maybe I am and
the metric is not as good.

99
00:05:36.920 --> 00:05:38.300
Now that doesn't make any sense.

100
00:05:38.300 --> 00:05:40.790
If I am learning the route
from NYEDGE2 directly,

101
00:05:40.790 --> 00:05:44.560
that metric should be better than a metric
that I'm learning through somebody else

102
00:05:44.560 --> 00:05:47.910
especially since there's a serial line,
this is 100 mega line.

103
00:05:47.910 --> 00:05:50.650
But maybe somebody's overwritten
the bandwidth setting on the line and

104
00:05:50.650 --> 00:05:52.130
I think this is worse.

105
00:05:52.130 --> 00:05:56.070
Then, if I go through the other side,
remember OSPFs metric is cost.

106
00:05:56.070 --> 00:05:58.880
And cost is calculated based on bandwidth,
right?

107
00:05:58.880 --> 00:06:01.050
It takes the reference
bandwidth of 100 megabit,

108
00:06:01.050 --> 00:06:04.130
then divides that by whatever your
actual bandwidth is to get your cost.

109
00:06:04.130 --> 00:06:06.620
And that's the metric that OSPF uses.

110
00:06:06.620 --> 00:06:08.090
So maybe that's been manipulated.

111
00:06:08.090 --> 00:06:10.620
Maybe I do have a downed interface or
something.

112
00:06:10.620 --> 00:06:13.800
A downed interface is easy to spot, cuz
you won't have a neighbor relationship.

113
00:06:13.800 --> 00:06:15.730
Let's see if we have
a neighbor relationship.

114
00:06:15.730 --> 00:06:18.320
Edge2 should be talking to Core2.

115
00:06:18.320 --> 00:06:19.650
Maybe it isn't, right?

116
00:06:19.650 --> 00:06:23.890
So if I jump back over to CORE2,
I'm gonna do

117
00:06:23.890 --> 00:06:28.690
a show ip ospf neighbor and
just to see what I've got on this one.

118
00:06:30.230 --> 00:06:34.760
And see if I do have a neighbor with it,
okay?

119
00:06:34.760 --> 00:06:38.630
And I see I've got two neighbors,
192.168.16.2, that's NYCORE1.

120
00:06:38.630 --> 00:06:40.520
And, 192.168.255.4, that's NYEDGE1,

121
00:06:40.520 --> 00:06:45.840
I don't have a neighbor
relationship with NYCORE2.

122
00:06:45.840 --> 00:06:47.600
I mean, NYEDGE2.

123
00:06:47.600 --> 00:06:50.850
So, if I don't have a neighbor
relationship with Edge2,

124
00:06:50.850 --> 00:06:52.700
I'm not learning its routes.

125
00:06:52.700 --> 00:06:56.130
And, I'm gonna learn the route through
Edge1, and that's the end of the story.

126
00:06:56.130 --> 00:06:59.300
I don't have a neighbor
relationship with that one router.

127
00:06:59.300 --> 00:07:00.760
Why is that?

128
00:07:00.760 --> 00:07:04.030
Okay, well in this case, I'm not sure.

129
00:07:04.030 --> 00:07:05.350
I'm not sure why that is.

130
00:07:05.350 --> 00:07:08.420
There's more than likely some
kind of issue with my adjacency.

131
00:07:08.420 --> 00:07:11.300
I'm just gonna do a quick double check,
a real common cause for

132
00:07:11.300 --> 00:07:12.510
this is authentication.

133
00:07:12.510 --> 00:07:13.090
Right?

134
00:07:13.090 --> 00:07:17.460
And so I can do a show run and look for

135
00:07:17.460 --> 00:07:23.080
the OSPF section and, oh, apparently that
command is not supported in this iOS.

136
00:07:23.080 --> 00:07:25.800
Not every iOS supports
the section command, so

137
00:07:25.800 --> 00:07:29.630
I'll just do a show run and
I'll begin with the keyword ospf.

138
00:07:29.630 --> 00:07:34.090
And I'm just gonna look and
see that ospf configuration,

139
00:07:34.090 --> 00:07:36.170
I'm looking to see if
authentication is turned on.

140
00:07:36.170 --> 00:07:40.040
Because if I've got a bad
password in between Core2 and

141
00:07:40.040 --> 00:07:42.320
Edge2 then that's gonna
stop that adjacency.

142
00:07:42.320 --> 00:07:46.430
But I don't see any passwords I
do have passive interface default

143
00:07:46.430 --> 00:07:48.650
which could be a problem.

144
00:07:48.650 --> 00:07:51.770
Except I got no passive
interface vland 12.

145
00:07:51.770 --> 00:07:55.930
And I know that edge 2 is on vland 12 so
that should be okay.

146
00:07:55.930 --> 00:08:00.660
So, I should be able to talk to it, and
i've got that network 192.168.12.0,

147
00:08:00.660 --> 00:08:05.620
its added into my OSBF process, so
I should be able to communicate.

148
00:08:05.620 --> 00:08:08.090
I am redistributing some routes but
there's no filters there either.

149
00:08:08.090 --> 00:08:09.660
So I'm not too worried about that.

150
00:08:09.660 --> 00:08:11.930
And it looks good, right.

151
00:08:11.930 --> 00:08:16.090
I'm gonna double check that vlan interface
just to see if there's any ACLs cuz you

152
00:08:16.090 --> 00:08:18.550
can write an ACL to
block OSPF if you want.

153
00:08:18.550 --> 00:08:22.290
Not a whole lot of need for
that, but some people do.

154
00:08:22.290 --> 00:08:24.744
So I'm gonna do a show run for
interface vlan 12.

155
00:08:25.890 --> 00:08:27.330
And nothing exciting there.

156
00:08:27.330 --> 00:08:30.490
I do have HSRP configured,
but no big deal.

157
00:08:30.490 --> 00:08:33.790
OSPF will continue to run regardless
of whether we're active or standby.

158
00:08:33.790 --> 00:08:36.870
Cuz we need to know the routes
if we do become active, right.

159
00:08:36.870 --> 00:08:38.080
So that's gonna be running.

160
00:08:38.080 --> 00:08:40.230
So I don't see an OSPF problem here.

161
00:08:40.230 --> 00:08:42.230
At least not one that's jumping out at me.

162
00:08:42.230 --> 00:08:44.330
But I know that OSPF isn't working.

163
00:08:44.330 --> 00:08:46.030
So What do I do?

164
00:08:46.030 --> 00:08:48.730
Well, I could do a debug, right?

165
00:08:48.730 --> 00:08:53.110
OSPF actually has several debugs that
we can do, and you'll see debug events,

166
00:08:53.110 --> 00:08:55.440
debug packet, and so on.

167
00:08:55.440 --> 00:08:57.580
When you're dealing with
neighbor relationships,

168
00:08:57.580 --> 00:09:03.400
one of the easier ones to do is debugging
adjacencies, adj, and packet, right?

169
00:09:03.400 --> 00:09:05.950
I wanna see the packets and
the adjacencies.

170
00:09:05.950 --> 00:09:09.930
The bigger your network, though, the more
of these messages you're going to see.

171
00:09:09.930 --> 00:09:13.900
So oftentimes you might need
to apply a filter to debug so

172
00:09:13.900 --> 00:09:15.900
that you don't get overwhelmed with data.

173
00:09:15.900 --> 00:09:20.240
So for example when you do a debug if you
do a question mark there you'll see that

174
00:09:20.240 --> 00:09:24.140
you can actually do
a debug Interface command.

175
00:09:24.140 --> 00:09:27.040
And when you look at it,
let me just get to where it shows,

176
00:09:27.040 --> 00:09:29.560
right here, debug interface.

177
00:09:29.560 --> 00:09:32.240
We can actually start to put
kind of limits in place to

178
00:09:32.240 --> 00:09:36.510
filter how much data we're gonna get back
and tie it to a particular interface or

179
00:09:36.510 --> 00:09:40.040
something of that nature to create
constraints on the amount of data.

180
00:09:40.040 --> 00:09:41.300
This network's pretty small though, so

181
00:09:41.300 --> 00:09:43.700
I should just be able
to a debug ip ospf adj.

182
00:09:44.880 --> 00:09:47.040
And the debug ip ospf packet.

183
00:09:48.600 --> 00:09:52.680
So then I can see that information and I
immediately start getting some information

184
00:09:53.710 --> 00:09:56.900
and if I, let me zoom out of it so
I can see the whole thing.

185
00:09:56.900 --> 00:10:00.958
I can see that I am receiving
some communications from

186
00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.120
192.168.12.5 all right.

187
00:10:03.120 --> 00:10:07.160
So I'm receiving messages From that host.

188
00:10:07.160 --> 00:10:10.750
And we should be building
up an adjacency then.

189
00:10:10.750 --> 00:10:14.270
192.168.12.5 is NYEDGE2.

190
00:10:14.270 --> 00:10:15.580
We can verify that real quick.

191
00:10:15.580 --> 00:10:19.810
I'm just gonna jump over to edge
two where we had done a show IP

192
00:10:19.810 --> 00:10:24.090
interface brief earlier, and I can see
that it is 192 dot 168 dot 12 dot five.

193
00:10:24.090 --> 00:10:28.530
So, on Core 2 I'm receiving
OSPF hello] messages, but

194
00:10:28.530 --> 00:10:30.760
I'm not building the adjacency.

195
00:10:30.760 --> 00:10:32.610
Why would that happen?

196
00:10:32.610 --> 00:10:36.370
Well, I could have incorrect area numbers.

197
00:10:36.370 --> 00:10:40.880
I could be Area5 and it could be Area6 and
we're not gonna build them [adjacency?].

198
00:10:40.880 --> 00:10:41.910
Area numbers have to match.

199
00:10:41.910 --> 00:10:43.910
In fact, when you send hellos,

200
00:10:43.910 --> 00:10:46.810
there's actually a number of criteria
in there that have to match.

201
00:10:46.810 --> 00:10:51.920
Password, area number,
we've got hello and dead intervals.

202
00:10:51.920 --> 00:10:53.820
Those have to match, what else is there.

203
00:10:53.820 --> 00:10:57.960
There's several other, oh area type,
I might be sent to a stub and

204
00:10:57.960 --> 00:10:58.750
it might not be.

205
00:10:58.750 --> 00:11:01.910
Those are all things that can
this adjacency not to build.

206
00:11:01.910 --> 00:11:03.880
And in this case I see I'm
getting the hellos but

207
00:11:03.880 --> 00:11:07.290
I'm not getting any messages
about the adjacency not building.

208
00:11:07.290 --> 00:11:10.780
Now the problem here is this has
probably been down a little while.

209
00:11:10.780 --> 00:11:14.180
And so I'm not necessarily gonna get
all the messages that I want to see.

210
00:11:14.180 --> 00:11:18.580
So I might need to clear my OSPF process
to get it to retry everything and

211
00:11:18.580 --> 00:11:21.180
see if it actually builds something up and
gives me some good errors.

212
00:11:21.180 --> 00:11:25.320
But I don't wanna down this guy because
he's kinda in the middle of my network, so

213
00:11:25.320 --> 00:11:27.270
I might choose to down the other router.

214
00:11:27.270 --> 00:11:29.380
But, honestly,
something that might be a little better,

215
00:11:29.380 --> 00:11:33.160
let me do an un-debug all here real
quick and get all that turned off.

216
00:11:35.010 --> 00:11:36.590
And there we go.

217
00:11:36.590 --> 00:11:39.340
And I'm just gonna take a look at
the configuration on the other side.

218
00:11:39.340 --> 00:11:43.590
I checked this guy for passwords, and
I checked with this guy for filters,

219
00:11:43.590 --> 00:11:45.260
route maps, but
I never checked the other side.

220
00:11:45.260 --> 00:11:47.940
So let me go check EDGE1, and
maybe we can save, I mean EDGE2,

221
00:11:47.940 --> 00:11:51.940
and maybe we can save ourselves
resetting an OSPF process.

222
00:11:51.940 --> 00:11:55.065
It's a lab, so it's really not a big deal,
but in real life and,

223
00:11:55.065 --> 00:11:57.775
you don't wanna reset an ospf process
unless you absolutely have to,

224
00:11:57.775 --> 00:12:01.165
cuz you're gonna dump your routing table,
which means you're gonna create downtime.

225
00:12:01.165 --> 00:12:03.205
And, so we do wanna avoid that,
if possible.

226
00:12:03.205 --> 00:12:07.485
So, on this guy, I'm just gonna do
a show run, and we'll begin with ospf,

227
00:12:07.485 --> 00:12:08.895
like before.

228
00:12:08.895 --> 00:12:12.115
And, oops, looks like we have some
per-interface configurations.

229
00:12:12.115 --> 00:12:14.895
So, I've got an interface where
it's statically set to area 0.

230
00:12:14.895 --> 00:12:17.090
So, that's not a big deal.

231
00:12:17.090 --> 00:12:21.030
So we'll kinda continue these guys.

232
00:12:21.030 --> 00:12:22.290
I see a problem right there.

233
00:12:22.290 --> 00:12:26.240
With OSPF you can set configurations
globally in the router OSPF command.

234
00:12:26.240 --> 00:12:28.040
Or you can set them on the interfaces.

235
00:12:28.040 --> 00:12:30.180
Like here they're setting
this one to area 16.

236
00:12:30.180 --> 00:12:35.030
And just in scanning here,
we can see this guy.

237
00:12:35.030 --> 00:12:39.090
Where it's got custom, dead intervals,
and hello intervals defined.

238
00:12:39.090 --> 00:12:39.590
Right?

239
00:12:39.590 --> 00:12:40.360
Remember when I said for

240
00:12:40.360 --> 00:12:44.260
an ospf adjacency to build up is
a lot of stuff that has to match.

241
00:12:44.260 --> 00:12:46.270
Dead interval and
hello interval is one of those things,

242
00:12:46.270 --> 00:12:48.560
or are two of those things
that have to match.

243
00:12:48.560 --> 00:12:52.370
This is on gigabit 0/0,
if I look at my topology,

244
00:12:53.570 --> 00:12:56.770
that's this interface right
here pointing to Core2.

245
00:12:56.770 --> 00:12:57.450
All right.

246
00:12:57.450 --> 00:13:00.560
So Core2 didn't have those settings.

247
00:13:00.560 --> 00:13:03.520
It didn't have them and
I could double check like Fas1/0/1 but

248
00:13:03.520 --> 00:13:06.220
that's not a routed port, right?

249
00:13:06.220 --> 00:13:09.340
That's a layer two port so
it had to be on the VLAN interface.

250
00:13:09.340 --> 00:13:11.540
And I could go and
set that if I really wanted to.

251
00:13:11.540 --> 00:13:13.860
But in this case I have
to make a decision.

252
00:13:13.860 --> 00:13:17.900
I can fix Core2 to match
the intervals of Edge2 Or

253
00:13:17.900 --> 00:13:20.750
I can fix edge two,
to match the intervals of core two.

254
00:13:20.750 --> 00:13:24.050
And in this case, I got to imagine fixing
edge two is gonna be our better solution.

255
00:13:24.050 --> 00:13:26.670
We just need to remove the custom
hello and dead intervals, so

256
00:13:26.670 --> 00:13:27.930
they go back to the default.

257
00:13:27.930 --> 00:13:31.020
So if I jump over to NY edge two,
we can do that.

258
00:13:32.250 --> 00:13:35.940
By basically removing those
commands that we see right there.

259
00:13:35.940 --> 00:13:39.400
So I'm gonna get into
interface GI0/0 Whoops,

260
00:13:39.400 --> 00:13:43.130
I guess I'll get into Config first,
alright, and

261
00:13:43.130 --> 00:13:47.190
then all we have to do is do some nos
on these for the dead interval and

262
00:13:47.190 --> 00:13:53.820
hello interval, so I'll say no ip ospf
dead-interval, and the hello-interval.

263
00:13:53.820 --> 00:13:56.700
I don't even need to type the number,
if you just leave that off it will put it

264
00:13:56.700 --> 00:14:00.589
back to the default, and so
now if I take a look at that interface

265
00:14:01.760 --> 00:14:06.280
It's still enabled but it doesn't have
those custom intervals on it, all right?

266
00:14:06.280 --> 00:14:11.030
So that should take care of that,
and we may have fixed our problem.

267
00:14:11.030 --> 00:14:13.560
I guess I could do a show
ip ospf neighbor here and

268
00:14:13.560 --> 00:14:18.740
see if we've got a neighbor relationship
with the other switch, which we do.

269
00:14:18.740 --> 00:14:25.190
And I can jump over to that other switch,
Core2, and I see its got a new adjacency.

270
00:14:28.490 --> 00:14:29.220
And there it is 192.168.12.5.

271
00:14:29.220 --> 00:14:32.690
So now we have an adjacency.

272
00:14:32.690 --> 00:14:37.150
And if I do a show IP route for
192.168.100.0,

273
00:14:37.150 --> 00:14:41.190
I've got a routing entry
straight through Vlan12.

274
00:14:41.190 --> 00:14:44.530
All right, so now we're learning
the route that we're supposed to learn.

275
00:14:44.530 --> 00:14:48.520
Now core two knows that it can get to that
number by going right up to edge two.

276
00:14:48.520 --> 00:14:51.690
And if we jump back to our server
we should be able to verify that,

277
00:14:51.690 --> 00:14:52.500
that's working.

278
00:14:55.350 --> 00:14:58.010
So I've got the tracer out from before
still right here on the screen.

279
00:14:58.010 --> 00:15:01.440
I'm gonna run a new tracer out,
really just the same tracer out again.

280
00:15:01.440 --> 00:15:04.550
And so we'll run it, and what we should
see is a shorter path this time.

281
00:15:04.550 --> 00:15:09.620
That we go to CORE2 and then we go right
up to EDGE2 and we get to our destination.

282
00:15:09.620 --> 00:15:12.110
So I expected to see .3 first,
which we do.

283
00:15:12.110 --> 00:15:16.214
And then hopefully we see 12.5 or 100.1.

284
00:15:16.214 --> 00:15:18.400
There we go, 100.1.

285
00:15:18.400 --> 00:15:21.060
Went right to it, and
now we're in business, right?

286
00:15:21.060 --> 00:15:23.760
So, now we're following
the optimal routing path.

287
00:15:23.760 --> 00:15:26.650
In this case, it wasn't that
the metrics were messed with,

288
00:15:26.650 --> 00:15:28.040
it wasn't that the interface was down.

289
00:15:28.040 --> 00:15:31.230
Although, those are all possible causes,
this time, it just turned out to be,

290
00:15:31.230 --> 00:15:32.120
there was no adjacency.

291
00:15:32.120 --> 00:15:35.390
There was no way for us to learn
the route that was supposed to be there.

292
00:15:35.390 --> 00:15:37.400
As soon as we fix that, problem resolved.

293
00:15:37.400 --> 00:15:39.860
We are now following the path as for
on the ticket.

294
00:15:39.860 --> 00:15:43.570
So this one turned out not to be so bad,
we really already knew that it was gonna

295
00:15:43.570 --> 00:15:47.090
be down to two host just because
of the path they were discussing.

296
00:15:47.090 --> 00:15:49.930
We got in there and fixed the problem and
it's solved, right?

297
00:15:49.930 --> 00:15:51.950
That's kind of all we can ask for
with the troubleshooting ticket.

298
00:15:51.950 --> 00:15:53.680
All right, well that wraps this one up.

299
00:15:53.680 --> 00:15:56.067
Stay tuned, we've got one more
troubleshooting ticket for

300
00:15:56.067 --> 00:15:58.421
set three so you'll definitely
wanna stay tuned for that.

301
00:15:58.421 --> 00:16:00.670
And I look forward to seeing you then.

302
00:16:00.670 --> 00:16:06.789
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #7` from set #3. The trouble ticket states that "You are unable to ping 10.61.1.1 from any device "
episodes.title: Set 3 Issue 7
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.383
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.383 --> 00:00:11.103
It's time for the final troubleshooting
issue we have for Set 3,

3
00:00:11.103 --> 00:00:12.530
this is Issue number 7.

4
00:00:12.530 --> 00:00:15.220
And we've got another
route reachability issue.

5
00:00:15.220 --> 00:00:20.000
So the troubleshooting ticket for
this one says you are unable

6
00:00:20.000 --> 00:00:22.620
to ping 10.61.1.1 from any device, right?

7
00:00:22.620 --> 00:00:24.160
This is a big scope on this on.

8
00:00:24.160 --> 00:00:26.780
None of our devices can
ping this particular IP.

9
00:00:26.780 --> 00:00:29.730
So it looks like there's a route for
a network that's just missing and

10
00:00:29.730 --> 00:00:30.770
we don't have a way to get there.

11
00:00:30.770 --> 00:00:32.070
Now, I assume that's it.

12
00:00:32.070 --> 00:00:34.930
I guess there could be some ACLs or
other things in place, but

13
00:00:34.930 --> 00:00:36.680
it sounds more like a routing issue to me.

14
00:00:36.680 --> 00:00:40.120
So let's dive in and
see if we can't find out why that is.

15
00:00:40.120 --> 00:00:43.140
I'm gonna start just by looking
at a node on our system.

16
00:00:43.140 --> 00:00:46.590
Now, it's nice they told us
on any device on our network.

17
00:00:46.590 --> 00:00:50.790
So 10.61.1.1's the destination, but
the source could really be anybody.

18
00:00:50.790 --> 00:00:52.790
That means I don't have to mess
with a Windows server this time.

19
00:00:52.790 --> 00:00:55.000
I can just pick one of my other devices.

20
00:00:55.000 --> 00:00:56.695
Like I'll take CORE2.

21
00:00:56.695 --> 00:00:59.889
CORE2's that switch that's kind of the
active gateway for most of our networks.

22
00:00:59.889 --> 00:01:05.416
And if I use that guy as my tester,
it needs to be able to get to 10.61.1.1.

23
00:01:05.416 --> 00:01:08.090
Well, where is that network?

24
00:01:08.090 --> 00:01:09.860
If I look around on my topology map here,

25
00:01:09.860 --> 00:01:14.352
I can actually spot it right here,
10.61.1.1.

26
00:01:14.352 --> 00:01:16.960
It's a /32.
It's a single IP.

27
00:01:16.960 --> 00:01:19.111
And it's up here in OSPF Area 61, so

28
00:01:19.111 --> 00:01:22.894
that means it exists in this network
up here that I don't control.

29
00:01:22.894 --> 00:01:24.702
I don't control ISP1 or ISP2.

30
00:01:24.702 --> 00:01:25.950
I can't get to those routers.

31
00:01:25.950 --> 00:01:27.470
I can't even look at their configs.

32
00:01:27.470 --> 00:01:29.130
It's completely invisible to me.

33
00:01:29.130 --> 00:01:31.242
But NYEDGE2, I do control.

34
00:01:31.242 --> 00:01:33.591
It should be learning about that route and

35
00:01:33.591 --> 00:01:36.686
it should be advertising
that route into OSPF Area 0.

36
00:01:36.686 --> 00:01:38.048
So that's how we should be learning it.

37
00:01:38.048 --> 00:01:43.758
So if I'm missing the route, I expect
it to be EDGE2 that's the problem.

38
00:01:43.758 --> 00:01:45.807
If it's an ACL that's blocking access,

39
00:01:45.807 --> 00:01:49.914
because they said I can't ping it from any
device, I expect the ACL to be on EDGE2.

40
00:01:49.914 --> 00:01:53.305
So it looks like everything points
to EDGE2 as being the source of our

41
00:01:53.305 --> 00:01:54.420
problem here.

42
00:01:54.420 --> 00:01:57.740
Although could just be that IP is
down out there on a remote network.

43
00:01:57.740 --> 00:02:00.060
I can't fix that, so
I doubt that's the case.

44
00:02:00.060 --> 00:02:03.326
All right, well, just to start,
I'm gonna use CORE2 as my tester.

45
00:02:03.326 --> 00:02:04.686
So I'm gonna connect to it.

46
00:02:04.686 --> 00:02:07.100
I'm gonna try and ping the IP and
make sure it doesn't work, and

47
00:02:07.100 --> 00:02:09.610
I'm gonna check my routing table
to see if I know the route.

48
00:02:09.610 --> 00:02:13.675
So let me jump over to CORE2 and
we'll start our test right there.

49
00:02:13.675 --> 00:02:19.703
All right, so on CORE2,
I'm gonna do a ping to 10.61.1.1,

50
00:02:19.703 --> 00:02:23.225
just to see if I can even get to it,
right?

51
00:02:23.225 --> 00:02:27.260
If I can get to it, this troubleshooting
ticket might be over, easy problem, right?

52
00:02:27.260 --> 00:02:28.910
So I sent out my ping.

53
00:02:28.910 --> 00:02:30.310
Yeah, it's not looking so good.

54
00:02:30.310 --> 00:02:31.885
All right, so I can't get there.

55
00:02:31.885 --> 00:02:38.060
Then I'm gonna do a show ip route for
10.61.1.1, and network not in table.

56
00:02:38.060 --> 00:02:39.604
So I don't know how to get there.

57
00:02:39.604 --> 00:02:43.240
Now, don't act too hasty there,
I get network not in table.

58
00:02:43.240 --> 00:02:44.250
That's fine.

59
00:02:44.250 --> 00:02:48.240
But I could still have a gateway of
last resort or a default gateway.

60
00:02:48.240 --> 00:02:50.240
So I'm gonna do a show IP route, and

61
00:02:50.240 --> 00:02:53.080
just look to see if I have a gateway
of last resort, and I don't.

62
00:02:53.080 --> 00:02:58.210
Okay, so I need a specific route for
10.61 or I need a gateway of last resort.

63
00:02:58.210 --> 00:03:00.530
One or the other, to be able to try and
get to this other network.

64
00:03:00.530 --> 00:03:03.676
But right now I don't have either, and so
there's no way I can get to the network.

65
00:03:03.676 --> 00:03:06.668
So if EDGE2 is suppose to be
learning on that network and

66
00:03:06.668 --> 00:03:10.230
advertising it to us,
it's apparently failing, right?

67
00:03:10.230 --> 00:03:14.940
And if I do a show IP OSPF neighbor.

68
00:03:14.940 --> 00:03:17.900
You'll remember from the last
troubleshooting ticket that we did,

69
00:03:17.900 --> 00:03:21.250
we have a neighbor relationship
built with EDGE2 right there.

70
00:03:21.250 --> 00:03:25.760
So we should be learning routes from it,
it's just not telling us the route.

71
00:03:25.760 --> 00:03:26.891
So let's go found out why.

72
00:03:26.891 --> 00:03:32.658
I'm gonna go look at EDGE2, and I am gonna
start with EDGE2's OSPF configuration.

73
00:03:32.658 --> 00:03:34.120
So let's get in here.

74
00:03:35.540 --> 00:03:37.193
And we'll enable.

75
00:03:37.193 --> 00:03:42.516
And I'm just gonna do a show run and
I'm gonna look for router OSPF.

76
00:03:42.516 --> 00:03:44.283
I wanna see the OSPF configuration.

77
00:03:44.283 --> 00:03:45.740
All right, and there it is.

78
00:03:45.740 --> 00:03:49.620
I can see that we've got OSPF 100
which is just our process ID.

79
00:03:49.620 --> 00:03:54.578
And then I've got a network 192.168.12.0,
which is set to area 0.

80
00:03:54.578 --> 00:03:58.620
And 192.168.255.0, which is set to area 0.

81
00:03:58.620 --> 00:04:03.190
Those two networks, if I go back to
my topology, that's this network and

82
00:04:03.190 --> 00:04:05.490
this network, the LAN interfaces.

83
00:04:05.490 --> 00:04:07.020
These guys are set to area 0.

84
00:04:07.020 --> 00:04:08.440
That's what I expect to see.

85
00:04:08.440 --> 00:04:11.480
And I know I've got an adjacency
over here so I know that's working.

86
00:04:11.480 --> 00:04:16.750
All right, but we're also supposed to be
participating in OSPF area 61, aren't we?

87
00:04:17.990 --> 00:04:21.000
Well, when I looked at that config,
I didn't see it.

88
00:04:21.000 --> 00:04:23.561
And that's because there's two
ways to configure OSPF, right?

89
00:04:23.561 --> 00:04:26.060
One way is to configure it here
with the global commands, but

90
00:04:26.060 --> 00:04:29.648
there's another way which is where we can
configure it on the individual interfaces.

91
00:04:29.648 --> 00:04:33.100
And if you remember the last ticket we
saw, that is actually what's done here.

92
00:04:33.100 --> 00:04:34.920
So that's why I don't see those commands.

93
00:04:34.920 --> 00:04:37.550
I can do a quick show IP protocols.

94
00:04:39.032 --> 00:04:40.658
And I'll see it in there.

95
00:04:40.658 --> 00:04:42.954
So I've got OSPF 100.

96
00:04:42.954 --> 00:04:44.790
These guys are separate area 0.

97
00:04:44.790 --> 00:04:45.690
That's exciting.

98
00:04:45.690 --> 00:04:49.020
And I kind of expected
to see a little more.

99
00:04:49.020 --> 00:04:52.638
I expected to see either
another OSPF process or

100
00:04:52.638 --> 00:04:56.715
other interfaces that were in area 16 or
area 61.

101
00:04:56.715 --> 00:04:57.995
And I don't see that.

102
00:04:57.995 --> 00:04:59.940
So that's interesting.

103
00:04:59.940 --> 00:05:01.650
So let's find out what's going on there.

104
00:05:01.650 --> 00:05:05.010
So if I do a,
let's just do a show run, and

105
00:05:05.010 --> 00:05:07.480
we'll take a look at
those other interfaces.

106
00:05:07.480 --> 00:05:12.390
And as we scan down the interfaces,
what we see are here's some

107
00:05:12.390 --> 00:05:17.710
serial interfaces, and then we get
to our gigabit interfaces back here.

108
00:05:17.710 --> 00:05:18.990
Here we go, all right.

109
00:05:18.990 --> 00:05:24.780
So I've got 172.14.0.2, and
if I go to my topology,

110
00:05:24.780 --> 00:05:28.060
I can see that's the one that's
supposed to be in OSPF area 61.

111
00:05:28.060 --> 00:05:34.130
And if we look on the interface, IP OSPF
100, area 61, so we've got it right there.

112
00:05:34.130 --> 00:05:36.950
It's defined, and it's not working.

113
00:05:36.950 --> 00:05:41.090
When I do a show IP protocols,
I'm not seeing that area,

114
00:05:41.090 --> 00:05:42.212
which is pretty interesting.

115
00:05:42.212 --> 00:05:46.180
Now, what would cause
an area not to show up

116
00:05:46.180 --> 00:05:48.430
if it's actually defined right
there in the configuration?

117
00:05:49.510 --> 00:05:51.580
Well, if we have no adjacencies.

118
00:05:51.580 --> 00:05:55.015
If you have absolutely no adjacencies, the
process fails, and it won't show up here.

119
00:05:55.015 --> 00:05:57.048
That's more than likely what I'm seeing.

120
00:05:57.048 --> 00:06:00.753
Now, if it were a separate process,
I would see that in the config,

121
00:06:00.753 --> 00:06:03.130
and I didn't see that in the config.

122
00:06:03.130 --> 00:06:05.720
So it's running as part of this process,

123
00:06:05.720 --> 00:06:09.280
it's just not showing up
here as being routed.

124
00:06:09.280 --> 00:06:11.550
So I could have a downed interface, right?

125
00:06:11.550 --> 00:06:12.910
Which I doubt is the case here.

126
00:06:12.910 --> 00:06:16.060
We could do a show IP interface brief and
figure that out.

127
00:06:16.060 --> 00:06:18.855
Or, I could just not have
an interface configured.

128
00:06:18.855 --> 00:06:20.126
But I saw that I did, right?

129
00:06:20.126 --> 00:06:20.950
I had one.

130
00:06:20.950 --> 00:06:25.078
When I look at this I've got
that interface right here, and

131
00:06:25.078 --> 00:06:29.453
it does show as up up, and
when I looked at that configuration,

132
00:06:29.453 --> 00:06:31.366
I saw that it was set [LAUGH].

133
00:06:31.366 --> 00:06:35.460
All right, I saw that it was set for
area 61, right?

134
00:06:35.460 --> 00:06:36.554
Well, this is it again.

135
00:06:36.554 --> 00:06:37.978
A symptom of moving too fast.

136
00:06:37.978 --> 00:06:41.063
So I skimmed over it really quickly.

137
00:06:41.063 --> 00:06:43.359
And said, oh yeah, it's set for area 61.

138
00:06:43.359 --> 00:06:45.309
But it's not set for area 61.

139
00:06:45.309 --> 00:06:48.154
It's set for area 16.

140
00:06:48.154 --> 00:06:51.590
Well, 16, it's 61 transposed,
and when I saw 16,

141
00:06:51.590 --> 00:06:55.550
I just kinda registered that as 61,
not thinking about it.

142
00:06:55.550 --> 00:06:56.260
But that's wrong.

143
00:06:56.260 --> 00:06:57.610
That's the wrong area number.

144
00:06:57.610 --> 00:06:59.900
So if I do a show IP OSPF neighbor,

145
00:07:01.340 --> 00:07:04.220
I don't have any adjacencies
with the 172 network.

146
00:07:04.220 --> 00:07:06.130
This network that's up here.

147
00:07:06.130 --> 00:07:08.960
The ISP's,
I don't have any adjacencies up here.

148
00:07:08.960 --> 00:07:11.130
So I'm not learning any of these networks.

149
00:07:11.130 --> 00:07:13.311
I bet that network's not
even in my routing table.

150
00:07:13.311 --> 00:07:15.933
Even though I'm supposed to
have a direct connection to it.

151
00:07:15.933 --> 00:07:23.820
If I do a show IP route for 10.61.1.1,
I don't have a route for it.

152
00:07:23.820 --> 00:07:26.550
I can't tell the rest of the network
about a route that I don't even have

153
00:07:26.550 --> 00:07:27.380
a route for.

154
00:07:27.380 --> 00:07:30.580
And, in this case, it looks like I don't
have a route because I'm configured for

155
00:07:30.580 --> 00:07:32.000
the wrong area.

156
00:07:32.000 --> 00:07:33.320
So I'm gonna fix that.

157
00:07:33.320 --> 00:07:37.982
We'll get into,
what interface was that, gi0/1.

158
00:07:37.982 --> 00:07:44.138
And we'll say IP OSPF 100,
area 61, instead of area 16.

159
00:07:44.138 --> 00:07:47.380
And as soon as we do that,
our area number changes, and

160
00:07:47.380 --> 00:07:50.212
I kind of expect to see
some adjacencies pop up.

161
00:07:50.212 --> 00:07:51.331
They'll pop up eventually.

162
00:07:51.331 --> 00:07:56.165
I can do a show IP OSPF, sorry, neighbor.

163
00:07:56.165 --> 00:07:58.705
There we go.

164
00:07:58.705 --> 00:07:59.681
And wait for those to pop up.

165
00:07:59.681 --> 00:08:02.820
There we go.
We've got the 172.14's are appearing.

166
00:08:02.820 --> 00:08:04.500
Those are the two ISPs that are out there.

167
00:08:04.500 --> 00:08:06.127
I should start learning routes.

168
00:08:06.127 --> 00:08:11.693
And if I do a show IP route for
10.61.1.1, I now have a route.

169
00:08:11.693 --> 00:08:15.230
And if I start to look at my other nodes,
they should be learning that too.

170
00:08:15.230 --> 00:08:18.600
So if I jump back to CORE2,
the one I kind of designated as my tester.

171
00:08:19.610 --> 00:08:23.290
When I come over to this guy,
I should be able to do

172
00:08:24.430 --> 00:08:27.810
a show IP route for 10.61.1.1,
and I do have a route.

173
00:08:27.810 --> 00:08:32.740
And, if I try and ping it,
I can get to it, right?

174
00:08:32.740 --> 00:08:35.442
So, this turned out to simply
be a wrong area number.

175
00:08:35.442 --> 00:08:40.094
When we look at our topology,
right up here, we've got area 61.

176
00:08:40.094 --> 00:08:41.862
These two guys were in area 61.

177
00:08:41.862 --> 00:08:44.687
This guy was configured for area 16.

178
00:08:44.687 --> 00:08:47.360
The area numbers do not match,
and it fails.

179
00:08:47.360 --> 00:08:50.220
It's really the same kind of problem
we saw in the last issue where we had

180
00:08:50.220 --> 00:08:52.330
hello and dead timers that didn't match.

181
00:08:52.330 --> 00:08:54.900
If those don't match,
you can't build an adjacency.

182
00:08:54.900 --> 00:08:58.370
Here the area number didn't match,
and so we couldn't build an adjacency.

183
00:08:58.370 --> 00:09:01.340
It's not like other routing protocols
where you don't have to worry about that,

184
00:09:01.340 --> 00:09:04.470
with OSPF, your area numbers have to
match, or you don't exchange routes.

185
00:09:04.470 --> 00:09:08.210
So that was our problem, once we fixed it,
we now learned about the route and

186
00:09:08.210 --> 00:09:09.470
we're able to ping.

187
00:09:09.470 --> 00:09:12.371
So on this one we started out with
a route missing from our routing table,

188
00:09:12.371 --> 00:09:14.390
it turned out to be an adjacency problem.

189
00:09:14.390 --> 00:09:17.080
The adjacency turned out to be
a misconfigured area number.

190
00:09:17.080 --> 00:09:19.090
Once we resolved that, routers came up.

191
00:09:19.090 --> 00:09:22.180
We learned the route, now we've got
the connectivity we were looking for.

192
00:09:22.180 --> 00:09:23.622
Problem solved and we moved on.

193
00:09:23.622 --> 00:09:25.610
Now, that wraps up Set number 3.

194
00:09:25.610 --> 00:09:29.460
We've got more troubleshooting sets coming
up, and we've been moving kinda slow on

195
00:09:29.460 --> 00:09:31.930
these as we go through our
basic troubleshooting steps.

196
00:09:31.930 --> 00:09:34.600
Starting with Set number 4, we're gonna
start moving a little bit faster,

197
00:09:34.600 --> 00:09:37.990
as we dial in and get to that
information as quickly as possible

198
00:09:37.990 --> 00:09:39.950
to solve the problems,
and move forward with it.

199
00:09:39.950 --> 00:09:43.160
But we've seen a lot of great examples
here of ways to troubleshoot and

200
00:09:43.160 --> 00:09:45.740
isolate an issue, solve it,
and then move on, right?

201
00:09:45.740 --> 00:09:47.120
Which is what the exam is all about.

202
00:09:47.120 --> 00:09:48.920
You gotta solve those problems and
get moving, so

203
00:09:48.920 --> 00:09:50.792
you can get through it in
the amount of time that you have.

204
00:09:50.792 --> 00:09:52.210
All right, well,
I hope you guys enjoyed it.

205
00:09:52.210 --> 00:09:54.535
Stay tuned, we've got Set 4 coming up.

206
00:09:54.535 --> 00:10:00.189
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #1` from set #4. The trouble ticket states that "An error keeps appearing on the console of NYACCESS1 that needs resolving "
episodes.title: Set 4 Issue 1
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.510
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.510 --> 00:00:12.200
All right it's time to kick off
an all new troubleshooting set and

3
00:00:12.200 --> 00:00:14.559
we're ready to jump into Set 4 Issue 1.

4
00:00:14.559 --> 00:00:16.670
And it looks like we gotta
fun one this time around.

5
00:00:16.670 --> 00:00:18.300
The troubleshooting
ticket reads like this.

6
00:00:18.300 --> 00:00:24.780
It says, an error keeps appearing on the
console of NYACCESS1 that needs resolving.

7
00:00:24.780 --> 00:00:28.110
So that's a pretty real
world example right there.

8
00:00:28.110 --> 00:00:29.200
You log into a router and

9
00:00:29.200 --> 00:00:31.860
you see that you're starting to get
these on-screen error messages.

10
00:00:31.860 --> 00:00:34.170
You gotta figure out what it means and
resolve it.

11
00:00:34.170 --> 00:00:37.590
So let's just jump over and take a look at
that router and see what we can find, or

12
00:00:37.590 --> 00:00:40.960
it said NY access one,
which in our topology is a switch.

13
00:00:40.960 --> 00:00:43.510
In fact, let's review that
topology real quick just so

14
00:00:43.510 --> 00:00:45.560
we can remember what we're dealing with.

15
00:00:45.560 --> 00:00:48.920
The topology in set four is very
similar to the previous sets,

16
00:00:48.920 --> 00:00:50.670
it hasn't changed all that much.

17
00:00:50.670 --> 00:00:53.420
But there's a few little differences
that we need to be aware of so let's

18
00:00:53.420 --> 00:00:57.740
take a look at the map here on my computer
and you'll see that we basically have that

19
00:00:57.740 --> 00:01:02.310
same kind of hardware layout looks like
we've introduced some elements up here

20
00:01:02.310 --> 00:01:07.180
with it looks like HSRP 100 running
between these routers up top so we might

21
00:01:07.180 --> 00:01:10.890
not be running HSRP between these switches
down here anymore we'll have to see.

22
00:01:10.890 --> 00:01:14.470
But in our case, the troubleshooting
ticket centers around this guy right here,

23
00:01:14.470 --> 00:01:17.620
NYACCESS1, and
it's getting an on screen error.

24
00:01:17.620 --> 00:01:20.700
So let's just jump over to that one and
see what we've got.

25
00:01:20.700 --> 00:01:23.810
And sure enough,
when I pull up the console of that system,

26
00:01:23.810 --> 00:01:27.320
I am seeing a few errors
sitting there on my screen.

27
00:01:27.320 --> 00:01:30.030
Let's zoom in on that and
see if we can't see what it's telling us.

28
00:01:30.030 --> 00:01:34.560
It's telling us here
CDP-4-Native_VLAN_mismatch.

29
00:01:34.560 --> 00:01:36.640
Native VLAN mismatch discovered on FA0-24.

30
00:01:36.640 --> 00:01:44.730
And then it just says here with
NYCORE1 FastEthernet 1/0/22.

31
00:01:44.730 --> 00:01:48.560
All right well that is an extremely
detailed error message I don't think we're

32
00:01:48.560 --> 00:01:50.400
gonna have to do a lot of
hunting around on this one.

33
00:01:50.400 --> 00:01:54.650
It's telling us our local port and
the remote port of this connection and

34
00:01:54.650 --> 00:01:55.640
what the problem is.

35
00:01:55.640 --> 00:01:57.470
Right here the native VLAN mismatch.

36
00:01:57.470 --> 00:01:58.220
So this is this is

37
00:01:58.220 --> 00:02:00.590
probably gonna be one of the easier
ones that we have to deal with.

38
00:02:00.590 --> 00:02:01.800
Looking at our topology,

39
00:02:03.150 --> 00:02:08.360
the error that it's reporting
is in between ACCESS1 and CORE1.

40
00:02:08.360 --> 00:02:11.900
And thanks to Cisco Discovery Protocol,
it knows the names of the devices and

41
00:02:11.900 --> 00:02:15.440
it's telling us that and it's telling
us the port numbers that are involved.

42
00:02:15.440 --> 00:02:19.330
It's port 24 here on ACCESS1 and
port 22 up there on CORE1.

43
00:02:19.330 --> 00:02:22.630
And if I've got a native VLAN mismatch,

44
00:02:22.630 --> 00:02:27.060
all I've gotta do is take a look at this
trunk and figure out how they're set.

45
00:02:27.060 --> 00:02:28.440
One of them's right, one of them's wrong.

46
00:02:28.440 --> 00:02:30.050
I just need to make them match and
we'll be in business.

47
00:02:30.050 --> 00:02:34.913
Now, if you don't remember native VLANs,
when you have an 802.1Q trunk,

48
00:02:34.913 --> 00:02:39.440
you have to pick one VLAN to be
represented by traffic that has no tags.

49
00:02:39.440 --> 00:02:44.750
So, if on one side it's VLAN1 and
on the other side it's VLAN5

50
00:02:44.750 --> 00:02:48.360
since they're not being tagged, the system
doesn't know that they're different, and

51
00:02:48.360 --> 00:02:50.930
you'd have traffic jumping
from one VLAN to another.

52
00:02:50.930 --> 00:02:52.750
And so
that can cause all sorts of problems.

53
00:02:52.750 --> 00:02:54.180
We need to get it fixed.

54
00:02:54.180 --> 00:02:55.440
CDP tests for that.

55
00:02:55.440 --> 00:02:58.830
If you're not running CDP it's a lot
harder to recognize this problem.

56
00:02:58.830 --> 00:03:00.290
We have to work a lot harder to spot it.

57
00:03:00.290 --> 00:03:02.070
But a CDP tells us right away.

58
00:03:02.070 --> 00:03:03.040
And we can solve it.

59
00:03:03.040 --> 00:03:06.380
So, I'll just start right here on
this switch, and see how it's set up.

60
00:03:06.380 --> 00:03:10.290
And it was telling me right here,
the mismatch was discovered on fa0/24.

61
00:03:10.290 --> 00:03:15.570
So I already know the port to look at and
everything, that really saves some time.

62
00:03:15.570 --> 00:03:18.290
So, let's jump in and take a look at that.

63
00:03:18.290 --> 00:03:22.970
So I'm gonna do a show run,
for interface fa0/24.

64
00:03:22.970 --> 00:03:27.260
And I can see that I really don't have
anything too special set up here, right.

65
00:03:27.260 --> 00:03:29.470
It says switchport trunk
allowed vlan 16 so

66
00:03:29.470 --> 00:03:35.230
I'm only carrying one vlan, switchport
mode trunk so I'm trunking and that's it.

67
00:03:35.230 --> 00:03:39.710
Now on this switch,
is it defaulting to 802.1Q trunking or

68
00:03:39.710 --> 00:03:40.760
is it defaulting to ISL?

69
00:03:41.780 --> 00:03:42.290
I don't know.

70
00:03:42.290 --> 00:03:43.700
Well actually I kinda do know.

71
00:03:43.700 --> 00:03:46.480
ISL doesn't have a native VLAN.

72
00:03:46.480 --> 00:03:49.820
ISL it encapsulates and
it encapsulates everything.

73
00:03:49.820 --> 00:03:51.820
So there is no native VLAN with ISL.

74
00:03:51.820 --> 00:03:54.020
And because I'm getting
a native VLAN error,

75
00:03:54.020 --> 00:03:56.040
I know that this is
actually running 802.1Q.

76
00:03:56.040 --> 00:03:59.640
And it's set for VLAN 16 and
it's set to trunk.

77
00:03:59.640 --> 00:04:03.800
And there's no native VLAN defined here
which means that it's the default.

78
00:04:03.800 --> 00:04:05.760
And the default native VLAN for 802.1Q.

79
00:04:05.760 --> 00:04:06.270
Is VLAN 1, right?

80
00:04:06.270 --> 00:04:10.580
Now VLAN 1 is not being allowed on this
trunk, but that's not a big deal for

81
00:04:10.580 --> 00:04:11.970
the sake of this example.

82
00:04:11.970 --> 00:04:16.930
So I'm not too worried about that,
but I am sending untagged traffic for

83
00:04:16.930 --> 00:04:18.880
VLAN 1 across this link.

84
00:04:18.880 --> 00:04:20.500
Let's go take a look at the other side.

85
00:04:20.500 --> 00:04:24.180
The other side is NYCORE1 Port FA1/0/22.

86
00:04:24.180 --> 00:04:33.020
So I'm going to jump over to core one and
we'll see how it's set on that port.

87
00:04:33.020 --> 00:04:37.211
So I'm going to jump over into that
port and just look at its configuration.

88
00:04:40.322 --> 00:04:45.787
And here I can see switchport
trunk native vlan 16,

89
00:04:45.787 --> 00:04:48.720
spanning-tree guard too.

90
00:04:48.720 --> 00:04:53.660
All right, now this one is not even, it's
not even set for switchport mode trunk.

91
00:04:53.660 --> 00:04:55.320
Right, so is it trunking?

92
00:04:55.320 --> 00:04:55.930
Well probably.

93
00:04:55.930 --> 00:04:58.330
It's probably doing dynamic negotiation,
right.

94
00:04:58.330 --> 00:05:00.770
So, negotiating a trunk
to come up that way.

95
00:05:00.770 --> 00:05:06.410
But when it does, If it's coming up 8
to 2 at queue, the native VLAN is 16.

96
00:05:06.410 --> 00:05:08.840
So untag traffic on VLAN 16.

97
00:05:08.840 --> 00:05:13.590
So, that could be a problem in this case,
if I'm sending VLAN 16 traffic with no

98
00:05:13.590 --> 00:05:18.390
tag and it gets to the other side and
it's gonna assume that's on VLAN 1.

99
00:05:18.390 --> 00:05:20.840
VLAN 1 is not allowed on
the trunk in the other side and so

100
00:05:20.840 --> 00:05:21.720
it's just gonna get drop.

101
00:05:21.720 --> 00:05:23.880
The traffic is not gonna
make it to the other side.

102
00:05:23.880 --> 00:05:25.970
But it technically makes it to the other
side, it just gets thrown away.

103
00:05:25.970 --> 00:05:31.210
So if I want to verify this as trunking,
I can do a show interface trunk, and

104
00:05:31.210 --> 00:05:37.190
I should be able to spot in here
that Fa1/0/22 is trunking and

105
00:05:37.190 --> 00:05:39.100
that's our trouble port here.

106
00:05:39.100 --> 00:05:42.730
So it is trunking, it did negotiate and
it negotiated 802.1q.

107
00:05:42.730 --> 00:05:43.300
All right,

108
00:05:43.300 --> 00:05:47.060
this is also a good command because I
can see who the native Vlan is up here.

109
00:05:47.060 --> 00:05:48.310
Native Vlan is 16.

110
00:05:48.310 --> 00:05:50.080
All right, so
I need to fix the problem, and

111
00:05:50.080 --> 00:05:52.720
there's two ways I can fix this problem,
right?

112
00:05:52.720 --> 00:05:57.880
One way, I can put this one, NYCORE1,
back to having the default native VLAN

113
00:05:57.880 --> 00:06:02.330
of 1, or I can go to the other side and
change its native Vlan to 16.

114
00:06:02.330 --> 00:06:05.570
The important part is they just need
to match, and so you can go either way,

115
00:06:05.570 --> 00:06:06.550
all right?

116
00:06:06.550 --> 00:06:11.110
Now on a modern switch there's really no
difference between the two solutions.

117
00:06:11.110 --> 00:06:13.470
I could go either way on this one,
it would get the same result,

118
00:06:13.470 --> 00:06:15.600
it'll fix the problem, we'll be done.

119
00:06:15.600 --> 00:06:20.220
But on older switches the hardware on
the older switches wasn't as good and

120
00:06:20.220 --> 00:06:24.530
so the act of tagging a frame before
sending it took a little work, we had to

121
00:06:24.530 --> 00:06:29.350
recalculate a CRC If we had untagged
frames, it actually moved a little faster.

122
00:06:29.350 --> 00:06:30.640
So a little faster.

123
00:06:30.640 --> 00:06:33.700
Stuff that we as humans wouldn't
notice but the switch would.

124
00:06:33.700 --> 00:06:38.840
So what you used to do is you would pick
the VLAN that carried the most traffic and

125
00:06:38.840 --> 00:06:41.390
that's the one you'd set
to be the native VLAN.

126
00:06:41.390 --> 00:06:44.880
Well, on the other side of this
trunk we're only allowing VLAN16.

127
00:06:45.890 --> 00:06:47.620
And here you'll see it's
allowing a lot more but

128
00:06:47.620 --> 00:06:50.000
on the other side it's
only allowing VLAN16.

129
00:06:50.000 --> 00:06:53.820
And since it's just pushing VLAN 16 and
that's it,

130
00:06:53.820 --> 00:06:59.150
we can make that untagged and now no
traffic on that link would be tagged.

131
00:06:59.150 --> 00:07:01.890
And that means that it would get
better performance out of that link.

132
00:07:01.890 --> 00:07:05.460
So the better option here might be to
leave this one with the native VLAN 16 and

133
00:07:05.460 --> 00:07:07.320
then go to other side and

134
00:07:07.320 --> 00:07:11.840
basically issue the same command,
switchport trunk native VLAN 16.

135
00:07:11.840 --> 00:07:13.850
And then we'll be in business, right.

136
00:07:13.850 --> 00:07:15.240
Let's go do that.

137
00:07:15.240 --> 00:07:19.870
So solution one would be to go into
this interface here on NYCORE1 and

138
00:07:19.870 --> 00:07:22.370
just do a no,
switchport trunk native vlan 16.

139
00:07:22.370 --> 00:07:25.180
And that would remove it and
put it back in the default of one.

140
00:07:25.180 --> 00:07:27.130
Or you could save switchport
trunk native vlan 1.

141
00:07:27.130 --> 00:07:29.040
That would do the same thing, all right.

142
00:07:29.040 --> 00:07:30.510
So that's solution one.

143
00:07:30.510 --> 00:07:33.180
Solution two is to go to the other side.

144
00:07:33.180 --> 00:07:34.660
Go to access one.

145
00:07:34.660 --> 00:07:36.570
And just set its native VLAN to match.

146
00:07:36.570 --> 00:07:39.480
So make its native VLAN to be
VLAN 16 on that interface.

147
00:07:39.480 --> 00:07:40.840
And so that's what I'm gonna do.

148
00:07:41.890 --> 00:07:46.925
I'm gonna get into fa0/24 and

149
00:07:46.925 --> 00:07:54.760
I'll say, switchport trunk native VLAN 16.

150
00:07:54.760 --> 00:07:55.530
All right and

151
00:07:55.530 --> 00:08:00.300
as soon as I issue that now I'm gonna
send untagged traffic across the link

152
00:08:00.300 --> 00:08:03.530
they're going to send untag traffic across
the link and their both set for VLAN 16.

153
00:08:03.530 --> 00:08:08.290
And because we're running CDP,
CDP will start exchanging information and

154
00:08:08.290 --> 00:08:10.500
it will recognize that we're
on the right VLAN's and

155
00:08:10.500 --> 00:08:14.140
that error message should stop coming
up now with any message like this

156
00:08:14.140 --> 00:08:18.500
we do have to pay attention to how often
its coming up And so if I do a show log,

157
00:08:18.500 --> 00:08:22.580
I can kinda get an idea of how far
apart those error messages are, right.

158
00:08:22.580 --> 00:08:26.770
So if I look at the times on these,
it looks like it's about every.

159
00:08:26.770 --> 00:08:29.120
Is it once a minute?

160
00:08:29.120 --> 00:08:33.890
So, you know, looking at this you've
got hours, then minutes, then seconds.

161
00:08:33.890 --> 00:08:35.800
And so see how they all end in 53 seconds?

162
00:08:35.800 --> 00:08:38.370
So it looks like it's
about a minute apart.

163
00:08:38.370 --> 00:08:42.060
So, really to be certain
that this was corrected,

164
00:08:42.060 --> 00:08:44.920
I would need to wait a full minute.

165
00:08:44.920 --> 00:08:45.820
Right.
60 seconds.

166
00:08:45.820 --> 00:08:48.680
Just to make sure I don't get that
error message popped back up again.

167
00:08:48.680 --> 00:08:49.830
I know it's fixed.

168
00:08:49.830 --> 00:08:54.520
I could just move on, but it's usually
better safe than sorry on this stuff.

169
00:08:54.520 --> 00:08:57.640
And if we do a little show clock here,

170
00:08:57.640 --> 00:09:02.640
I can see that I'm already at 29:58, so I
should have gotten another error at 29:53,

171
00:09:02.640 --> 00:09:07.640
and I can see that I'm at 29:58,
so I'm fine, right?

172
00:09:07.640 --> 00:09:10.530
I'm not getting that error message,
we've solved the problem, and

173
00:09:10.530 --> 00:09:11.340
we're ready to move on.

174
00:09:11.340 --> 00:09:16.940
So, when a troubleshooting ticket
that surrounds a error on screen.

175
00:09:16.940 --> 00:09:20.350
Kind of counted as an easy one cuz the air
is usually fairly detailed as far as

176
00:09:20.350 --> 00:09:21.960
telling you what the problem is.

177
00:09:21.960 --> 00:09:25.190
Sometimes they're not but in this case,
it told us exactly what we needed.

178
00:09:25.190 --> 00:09:28.160
