We got in, we fixed it and now we're
ready to move on to the next set.

179
00:09:28.160 --> 00:09:30.860
So, that wraps up this one
pretty straightforward issue.

180
00:09:30.860 --> 00:09:34.351
Stay tuned, though,
we've got more troubleshooting issues for

181
00:09:34.351 --> 00:09:35.297
set 4 coming up.

182
00:09:35.297 --> 00:09:40.939
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #2` from set #4. The trouble ticket states that "PLABCSCO01 is unable to ping 192.168.16.2, and NYCORE1 is the active router for VLAN16, NYCORE2 should be the active router. "
episodes.title: Set 4 Issue 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.648
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.648 --> 00:00:11.414
In this video,
we're gonna be taking a look at Set 4,

3
00:00:11.414 --> 00:00:14.620
Issue 2, another troubleshooting
problem in our topology.

4
00:00:14.620 --> 00:00:18.120
And the ticket for this one, well,
it indicates a couple of problems for us.

5
00:00:18.120 --> 00:00:22.460
First off, it's telling us that the server
PLABCSCO01 is unable to ping 192.168.16.2,

6
00:00:22.460 --> 00:00:27.500
so we've got some kind of
connectivity issue there.

7
00:00:27.500 --> 00:00:32.892
And then it says also,
NYCORE1 is the active router for

8
00:00:32.892 --> 00:00:38.020
VLAN 16,
when NYCORE2 should be the active router.

9
00:00:38.020 --> 00:00:43.040
Well, if you remember from the previous
set, NYCORE1 and NCORE2 are running HSRP,

10
00:00:43.040 --> 00:00:47.810
and apparently for this particular VLAN,
NYCORE1 is not supposed to be active.

11
00:00:47.810 --> 00:00:49.790
But it is, and we need to find out why.

12
00:00:49.790 --> 00:00:53.620
So, we've got two different
problems here in the same question.

13
00:00:53.620 --> 00:00:57.160
They're probably related, but
we can't make assumptions on that.

14
00:00:57.160 --> 00:00:59.580
It's not beyond Cisco to add more than one

15
00:00:59.580 --> 00:01:02.660
kinda separate problem to the same
question, make you do more work.

16
00:01:02.660 --> 00:01:05.270
So let's dive in here and
take a look at what we've got.

17
00:01:05.270 --> 00:01:09.820
Now our server that's complaining
is this guy down here, PLABCSCO01.

18
00:01:09.820 --> 00:01:14.531
And we know from the previous
ones that it's 192.168.16.10.

19
00:01:14.531 --> 00:01:20.180
And they're telling me that
it can't ping 192.168.16.2.

20
00:01:20.180 --> 00:01:27.273
Well, again, if we remember from
previous sets, NYCORE1 is 192.168.16.2.

21
00:01:27.273 --> 00:01:31.001
NYCORE2 is 192.168.16.3.

22
00:01:31.001 --> 00:01:33.079
So, you've got .2 and .3 right here.

23
00:01:33.079 --> 00:01:35.945
They've got a port channel between them,
and

24
00:01:35.945 --> 00:01:40.439
they're running HSRP with
a virtual IP of 192.168.16.1.

25
00:01:40.439 --> 00:01:45.090
Now in the troubleshooting ticket, it told
me that this server could not ping .2,

26
00:01:45.090 --> 00:01:47.960
which means it can't ping this switch.

27
00:01:47.960 --> 00:01:53.960
It also told me that NYCORE1 was
active for HSRP when it shouldn't be.

28
00:01:53.960 --> 00:01:57.620
So at first, I might think, well if I
can't ping it, maybe that switch is down.

29
00:01:57.620 --> 00:02:00.320
Maybe it's offline, but if it's gone
active, that means the switch is up and

30
00:02:00.320 --> 00:02:02.530
running, and for some reason,
I'm not getting there.

31
00:02:02.530 --> 00:02:05.360
Now the challenge here is I've
got two ways to get there.

32
00:02:05.360 --> 00:02:08.740
My workstation is gonna go to ACCESS1,
and from here,

33
00:02:08.740 --> 00:02:10.730
I could go straight up to CORE1.

34
00:02:10.730 --> 00:02:13.370
Or I could go over this way through CORE2.

35
00:02:13.370 --> 00:02:15.610
Two different ways to get
to the same destination.

36
00:02:15.610 --> 00:02:19.910
But either way, I should be able
to get there and maybe I'm not.

37
00:02:19.910 --> 00:02:23.820
Now, I don't know which way I'm going on
my journey over to that other system.

38
00:02:23.820 --> 00:02:25.090
So I need to take a look at that.

39
00:02:25.090 --> 00:02:27.510
And I know that spanning tree
is running in this environment,

40
00:02:27.510 --> 00:02:28.710
cuz I've got a loop here, right?

41
00:02:28.710 --> 00:02:29.840
I assume it is.

42
00:02:29.840 --> 00:02:33.070
It's possible these links are in different
VLANs, so we might not have a loop at all.

43
00:02:33.070 --> 00:02:36.660
But I need to get a handle on that
topology before I can really jump in and

44
00:02:36.660 --> 00:02:37.522
figure out what's going on, all right.

45
00:02:38.628 --> 00:02:42.460
I also wanna take a look at NYCORE1 and
just kind of see what it's seeing.

46
00:02:42.460 --> 00:02:45.850
They're telling me that NYCORE1
has gone active for the VLAN, and

47
00:02:45.850 --> 00:02:47.550
it shouldn't be active.

48
00:02:47.550 --> 00:02:50.630
So if it went active, that means that for

49
00:02:50.630 --> 00:02:53.490
some reason it's no
longer able to see CORE2.

50
00:02:53.490 --> 00:02:56.740
Now, that makes me think the problem
is here on the port channel.

51
00:02:56.740 --> 00:02:59.120
We should be able to see CORE2
right on the port channel.

52
00:02:59.120 --> 00:03:02.910
And if spanning tree is available,
it's gonna be shutting down interfaces.

53
00:03:02.910 --> 00:03:06.164
But it'll shut down lower bandwidth
links before it'll shut down higher

54
00:03:06.164 --> 00:03:07.010
bandwidth links.

55
00:03:07.010 --> 00:03:09.760
So I expect this link to be up,
which means CORE1 and

56
00:03:09.760 --> 00:03:12.050
CORE2 should be directly connected,
all right?

57
00:03:12.050 --> 00:03:17.230
And if they are, CORE2 should be active
for HSRP and CORE1 should be standby.

58
00:03:17.230 --> 00:03:20.690
So that's making me think our
problem is right here on the link.

59
00:03:20.690 --> 00:03:22.950
And that's an important skill when
you're troubleshooting in the exam,

60
00:03:22.950 --> 00:03:25.880
is you've gotta kind of formulate
where you think the problem is so

61
00:03:25.880 --> 00:03:28.730
you don't waste time
looking at other devices.

62
00:03:28.730 --> 00:03:31.550
So I'm gonna start from CORE1 and
just look at its kind of point of view,

63
00:03:31.550 --> 00:03:34.490
and then we'll start to look at the other
switches and figure out things from there.

64
00:03:34.490 --> 00:03:35.996
So if I jump over to CORE1,

65
00:03:35.996 --> 00:03:40.326
the first thing I wanna do is I wanna
verify that they're telling me the truth.

66
00:03:40.326 --> 00:03:44.968
I wanna make sure that it is
actually active for VLAN 16.

67
00:03:44.968 --> 00:03:48.728
So I'm gonna do a show standby for

68
00:03:48.728 --> 00:03:52.632
VLAN 16 and I see that it's not.

69
00:03:52.632 --> 00:03:54.300
Its state is Init.

70
00:03:54.300 --> 00:03:56.050
It says interface down.

71
00:03:56.050 --> 00:03:57.790
It's not active for VLAN 16 at all.

72
00:03:57.790 --> 00:03:58.930
But in the troubleshooting question,

73
00:03:58.930 --> 00:04:02.638
it said, NYCORE1 is the active router for
VLAN 16.

74
00:04:04.340 --> 00:04:05.130
It's not, right?

75
00:04:05.130 --> 00:04:08.240
I've got that it's in an Init state,
interface down.

76
00:04:08.240 --> 00:04:11.050
So, I've got something that's a little
bit different than what they're

77
00:04:11.050 --> 00:04:11.620
warning me about.

78
00:04:11.620 --> 00:04:14.700
And they're saying NYCORE2
should be the active router.

79
00:04:14.700 --> 00:04:16.330
And in theory, this should be the standby.

80
00:04:16.330 --> 00:04:19.240
Well, this guy isn't active or
standby, it's not seeing anybody.

81
00:04:19.240 --> 00:04:20.190
There's no active router.

82
00:04:20.190 --> 00:04:21.135
There's no standby router.

83
00:04:21.135 --> 00:04:22.890
And that's really, really weird.

84
00:04:24.850 --> 00:04:29.280
If I don't see an active or
a standby, shouldn't I become active?

85
00:04:29.280 --> 00:04:31.170
I should, but I'm not.

86
00:04:31.170 --> 00:04:34.240
Well what's a scenario that would cause

87
00:04:34.240 --> 00:04:38.770
HSRP on this guy to not come up even
though I can't see an active or standby?

88
00:04:38.770 --> 00:04:42.235
Well, if my interface is down,
which is what it's telling me,

89
00:04:42.235 --> 00:04:46.100
and this is for VLAN 16, I may not
have a valid interface on VLAN 16.

90
00:04:47.160 --> 00:04:50.710
That's pretty unlikely, but
it's certainly possible.

91
00:04:50.710 --> 00:04:53.090
So let's go in and
see if we can figure that out.

92
00:04:53.090 --> 00:04:56.250
Why don't I have an interface
that's active for VLAN 16?

93
00:04:56.250 --> 00:05:00.118
If I do a show vlan, I can look and
see if I can spot VLAN 16.

94
00:05:02.620 --> 00:05:06.538
There it is, and it shows as active,
but it's got no ports assigned.

95
00:05:06.538 --> 00:05:09.498
But that's not the end of
the journey here, right?

96
00:05:09.498 --> 00:05:10.799
We could still have a trunk.

97
00:05:10.799 --> 00:05:13.178
So I'll do a show interface trunk.

98
00:05:13.178 --> 00:05:18.395
And when I look at my trunks,
I've got Fa1/0/22, with VLANs 1 and

99
00:05:18.395 --> 00:05:23.459
10 through 16 allowed and
active in the management domain, okay.

100
00:05:24.490 --> 00:05:28.393
So, VLAN 16 should be active
right there on port 22.

101
00:05:28.393 --> 00:05:30.470
The VLAN interface should be up.

102
00:05:30.470 --> 00:05:31.660
Let's see if it is.

103
00:05:31.660 --> 00:05:33.480
I'll do a show IP interface brief.

104
00:05:33.480 --> 00:05:37.887
And I'm just gonna exclude any
interface that doesn't have an IP, and

105
00:05:37.887 --> 00:05:42.710
I'll find VLAN 16 right there and
VLAN 16 is showing as up down.

106
00:05:42.710 --> 00:05:48.240
Now, that's kinda odd that it would show
as up down when I just looked up here,

107
00:05:48.240 --> 00:05:52.115
and I saw where it says I'm
carrying VLANs over that interface.

108
00:05:52.115 --> 00:05:53.105
Well, did I, oh, you know what?

109
00:05:53.105 --> 00:05:56.230
Actually I think I, nope, all right.

110
00:05:56.230 --> 00:05:58.240
Sorry, I thought I had screwed
up my interface numbers.

111
00:05:58.240 --> 00:06:05.150
Now if we look up here, I've got VLAN1 and
10 through 16 as allowed and active.

112
00:06:05.150 --> 00:06:08.910
But on the very next line, VLANs in
spanning tree forwarding state and

113
00:06:08.910 --> 00:06:10.560
not pruned.

114
00:06:10.560 --> 00:06:13.425
Notice that I've only got 1 and
10 through 15.

115
00:06:13.425 --> 00:06:16.290
16 is actually being
pruned off of that trunk.

116
00:06:16.290 --> 00:06:18.300
So while it was allowed and active,

117
00:06:18.300 --> 00:06:22.128
it's not actually active because
spanning tree is pruning it off.

118
00:06:22.128 --> 00:06:27.978
And so we can verify that with
a show spanning-tree vlan 16.

119
00:06:27.978 --> 00:06:31.932
And when I look at it,
there it is, port 22.

120
00:06:31.932 --> 00:06:34.050
It's a designated port and it's blocking.

121
00:06:34.050 --> 00:06:37.727
And how many other ports
do I have in VLAN 16?

122
00:06:37.727 --> 00:06:38.460
None.

123
00:06:38.460 --> 00:06:40.890
I don't have any other ports
that this one's blocking.

124
00:06:40.890 --> 00:06:42.060
Why is it blocking?

125
00:06:42.060 --> 00:06:43.050
That's odd.

126
00:06:43.050 --> 00:06:47.410
Well if you look at it, it'll actually
tell us why it's blocking right over here.

127
00:06:47.410 --> 00:06:49.820
ROOT inconsistent.

128
00:06:49.820 --> 00:06:50.540
I've got a problem.

129
00:06:53.150 --> 00:06:57.280
Route inconsistent, that's root guard,
right, so I've got root guard configured

130
00:06:57.280 --> 00:07:01.810
on this interface and the switch on
the other side has tried to go as root.

131
00:07:01.810 --> 00:07:04.620
And I blocked it, and so
that's stopping that link from coming up.

132
00:07:04.620 --> 00:07:05.700
So, that's a problem.

133
00:07:05.700 --> 00:07:07.150
That's stopping this link from coming up.

134
00:07:07.150 --> 00:07:10.560
But there's another problem that I'm not
seeing here, which is, remember in my

135
00:07:10.560 --> 00:07:16.800
topology, I've got this link between
CORE1 and CORE2 on this port channel.

136
00:07:16.800 --> 00:07:19.020
I'm not seeing that port
channel in any of this stuff.

137
00:07:19.020 --> 00:07:22.958
I'm not seeing it in my list of trunks,
I'm not seeing it in spanning tree for

138
00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.360
VLAN 16, it's not showing up.

139
00:07:25.360 --> 00:07:28.720
This port channel, if it's there,
it must not be configured as a trunk.

140
00:07:29.840 --> 00:07:31.870
Which means that it would be
configured as an access port.

141
00:07:31.870 --> 00:07:35.180
And if it's an access port,
it's on some VLAN other than VLAN 16.

142
00:07:35.180 --> 00:07:40.020
So if I'm blocking this port for
VLAN 16 because of a loop, and

143
00:07:40.020 --> 00:07:44.810
I'm not allowing VLAN 16 to pass over this
link, then I'm losing sight of that VLAN.

144
00:07:44.810 --> 00:07:49.576
And if I lose site of that VLAN,
I've got no other interfaces in VLAN 16.

145
00:07:49.576 --> 00:07:52.470
HSRP is not gonna to see an active or
a standby, but

146
00:07:52.470 --> 00:07:55.770
it's not gonna go active itself because
because no interface is functionable.

147
00:07:55.770 --> 00:07:56.340
All right.

148
00:07:56.340 --> 00:08:00.410
So I've got a couple of problems here and
I can fix it a few different ways.

149
00:08:00.410 --> 00:08:03.610
First off, root guard is what's
holding this interface down.

150
00:08:03.610 --> 00:08:08.320
So if I go in and
turn root guard off, or I stop this

151
00:08:08.320 --> 00:08:12.080
switch down here from trying to become
root, then that would solve that problem.

152
00:08:12.080 --> 00:08:15.030
It would bring this link up, and
assuming that that traffic can

153
00:08:15.030 --> 00:08:17.740
pass over to the other switch,
then I should be in good shape, right?

154
00:08:17.740 --> 00:08:20.520
It's a couple of assumptions there,
but that's one solution.

155
00:08:20.520 --> 00:08:23.160
The other solution is I could
get this port channel up and

156
00:08:23.160 --> 00:08:25.280
trunking like it's probably supposed to.

157
00:08:25.280 --> 00:08:26.400
I say probably.

158
00:08:26.400 --> 00:08:30.650
Why would I have NYCORE1 go to
NYCORE2 through this access switch,

159
00:08:30.650 --> 00:08:32.533
when I've got a direct
port channel between them?

160
00:08:32.533 --> 00:08:36.280
Right, so, while I could fix it
by fixing this link down here,

161
00:08:36.280 --> 00:08:39.230
I think the better solution
is to fix it across the top.

162
00:08:39.230 --> 00:08:41.250
At the end of the day, it doesn't
really matter which one I choose.

163
00:08:41.250 --> 00:08:43.660
I just need to get it fixed for the exam.

164
00:08:43.660 --> 00:08:45.800
But in real life land,
we wanna choose the best solution.

165
00:08:45.800 --> 00:08:48.520
And here the best solution is gonna
be to get this port channel trunking.

166
00:08:48.520 --> 00:08:52.060
Let's take a look at its configuration and
see what it's set up for right now.

167
00:08:52.060 --> 00:08:56.280
So I'm gonna do a show run for
interface po1.

168
00:08:56.280 --> 00:09:00.190
That's our port channel,
and incomplete command,

169
00:09:00.190 --> 00:09:02.030
that's a little different, isn't it.

170
00:09:02.030 --> 00:09:04.720
So, why is it doing that?

171
00:09:04.720 --> 00:09:08.280
So, if I do a show running-config for

172
00:09:08.280 --> 00:09:13.860
interface port-channel 1,
doesn't seem to like that.

173
00:09:13.860 --> 00:09:15.990
So let me see if I've
even got a port channel.

174
00:09:15.990 --> 00:09:19.120
So I'm assuming the document is
giving me accurate information here.

175
00:09:19.120 --> 00:09:21.460
I'm going to do a show
etherChannel summary and

176
00:09:21.460 --> 00:09:25.530
see if I even have a port channel,
and I don't.

177
00:09:25.530 --> 00:09:27.350
Well, that's pretty interesting.

178
00:09:27.350 --> 00:09:30.456
It's kind of in the documentation that I
have a port channel between these guys,

179
00:09:30.456 --> 00:09:31.790
and if I look at it here, I don't.

180
00:09:31.790 --> 00:09:33.990
Let's look at the configuration
on those ports.

181
00:09:33.990 --> 00:09:38.941
If I look at fa1/0/23 and 24,
okay, these two are supposed to be

182
00:09:38.941 --> 00:09:43.910
in a port channel between the switches
according to the documentation.

183
00:09:43.910 --> 00:09:46.428
And when I look at it, they're not, right?

184
00:09:46.428 --> 00:09:48.631
They're here, I've got the interface.

185
00:09:48.631 --> 00:09:51.660
In fact,
port 24 is configured to be a trunk.

186
00:09:51.660 --> 00:09:55.990
It's configured for encapsulation dot1q,
allowing VLANs 10 though 16.

187
00:09:55.990 --> 00:09:59.780
It's set up as an access port.

188
00:09:59.780 --> 00:10:01.510
So all that trunk stuff doesn't matter.

189
00:10:01.510 --> 00:10:02.990
It's set up as an access port.

190
00:10:02.990 --> 00:10:06.460
And looking at the other one,
the other one is set up as a layer 3 port.

191
00:10:06.460 --> 00:10:08.750
It's not even a switch port anymore.

192
00:10:08.750 --> 00:10:12.160
And so, it's not participating in
spanning tree and all those other things.

193
00:10:12.160 --> 00:10:14.140
It's its own kind of separate entity.

194
00:10:14.140 --> 00:10:17.750
So I've really got some crazy
stuff going on here on this link.

195
00:10:17.750 --> 00:10:20.520
It's definitely not what I expected
to see from the documentation.

196
00:10:20.520 --> 00:10:22.850
Let's look at CORE2 and
see if it's all screwed up like this too.

197
00:10:24.740 --> 00:10:26.221
So if I jump over to CORE2.

198
00:10:28.101 --> 00:10:33.200
On this one,
I want to do a show etherchannel summary.

199
00:10:33.200 --> 00:10:36.170
Let's just see if it's got
any port channels defined.

200
00:10:36.170 --> 00:10:37.720
It doesn't look like it does.

201
00:10:37.720 --> 00:10:41.600
And I'll take a look at its ports.

202
00:10:41.600 --> 00:10:44.270
And I can see that it's got
a layer three port also, and

203
00:10:44.270 --> 00:10:46.580
it's got port 24 configured as a trunk.

204
00:10:46.580 --> 00:10:50.040
So it looks like they're using port 23 for
something else.

205
00:10:50.040 --> 00:10:51.540
The port channel's not here.

206
00:10:51.540 --> 00:10:53.480
Port 24 is configured as a trunk.

207
00:10:53.480 --> 00:10:56.090
It is carrying VLANs 10 through 16.

208
00:10:56.090 --> 00:11:01.840
But it's set to be a trunk, and it's
set to be able to do that all the time.

209
00:11:01.840 --> 00:11:02.940
See this nonegotiate?

210
00:11:02.940 --> 00:11:04.450
So it won't even come
up as an access port.

211
00:11:04.450 --> 00:11:05.960
It's either trunk or nothing.

212
00:11:05.960 --> 00:11:07.410
So that's what's stopping
me from trunking.

213
00:11:07.410 --> 00:11:10.790
Now, I don't know because they didn't
say in the question whether or

214
00:11:10.790 --> 00:11:12.980
not I need to fix that port channel or
not.

215
00:11:12.980 --> 00:11:14.710
But at a minimum,

216
00:11:14.710 --> 00:11:18.640
port 24 should be trunking between
these guys to carry the extra VLANs.

217
00:11:18.640 --> 00:11:20.710
And that'll more than
likely solve our problem.

218
00:11:20.710 --> 00:11:22.250
So let's see if that'll
take care of it for us.

219
00:11:22.250 --> 00:11:24.830
We'll jump over to CORE1, and
we'll get that squared away.

220
00:11:24.830 --> 00:11:26.872
So I'm gonna jump into CORE1.

221
00:11:26.872 --> 00:11:31.924
And what I'm gonna do is I'm just
gonna jump into interface fa1/0/24,

222
00:11:31.924 --> 00:11:34.870
and I shouldn't have to change much here.

223
00:11:34.870 --> 00:11:38.658
It's got switchport mode access, so
I'm just gonna say switchport mode trunk.

224
00:11:38.658 --> 00:11:40.330
So that it flips over for that.

225
00:11:40.330 --> 00:11:44.387
It's already set for dot1q,
it's already allowing VLANS 10 through 16.

226
00:11:44.387 --> 00:11:45.530
That should kick over.

227
00:11:45.530 --> 00:11:48.357
And just to be sure,
I'm gonna do a shutdown and

228
00:11:48.357 --> 00:11:51.680
let that sit for a second and
then do a no shutdown.

229
00:11:51.680 --> 00:11:53.470
Looks like I've got console
logging turned off, so

230
00:11:53.470 --> 00:11:55.170
I'm not getting any pop ups on that.

231
00:11:55.170 --> 00:11:56.339
But that's gonna make this one trunk.

232
00:11:57.600 --> 00:12:00.360
And so now,
when I do a show interface trunk,

233
00:12:01.370 --> 00:12:03.710
I can see that additional port in there.

234
00:12:03.710 --> 00:12:07.130
And down here, VLANs in spanning tree
forwarding state and not pruned says none,

235
00:12:07.130 --> 00:12:08.100
which is bad.

236
00:12:08.100 --> 00:12:10.940
But that's because spanning tree is
more than likely doing the listening and

237
00:12:10.940 --> 00:12:11.530
the learning.

238
00:12:11.530 --> 00:12:16.264
And so, if I do show spanning-tree for
VLAN 16, I expect to see listening and

239
00:12:16.264 --> 00:12:16.980
learning.

240
00:12:16.980 --> 00:12:18.580
It only does that for 30 seconds.

241
00:12:18.580 --> 00:12:20.000
There it is, it's learning.

242
00:12:20.000 --> 00:12:24.640
And so 15 seconds listening, 15 seconds
learning, and as soon as that's done,

243
00:12:24.640 --> 00:12:27.420
one of them will hopefully
go to forwarding.

244
00:12:27.420 --> 00:12:29.573
The other one might go to
blocking if there's a loop.

245
00:12:29.573 --> 00:12:30.584
And there we go.

246
00:12:30.584 --> 00:12:33.271
I can see port 24 just went to forwarding.

247
00:12:33.271 --> 00:12:36.740
And so if I do a show interface trunk,
there we go.

248
00:12:36.740 --> 00:12:41.390
Now I can see port 24 is carrying all
those VLANs not being pruned, all right?

249
00:12:41.390 --> 00:12:44.530
And notice that port 22 is
not pruning VLAN 16 any more.

250
00:12:44.530 --> 00:12:46.230
It's probably still in the learning phase.

251
00:12:46.230 --> 00:12:49.590
It'll probably start pruning it again here
in just a moment if we give it some time.

252
00:12:49.590 --> 00:12:54.060
But in the meantime,
if I do a show ip interface brief again,

253
00:12:55.330 --> 00:12:59.570
I should see that the interface for
VLAN 16 is now up up, which it is.

254
00:13:01.140 --> 00:13:05.582
And given enough time,
we'll probably see HSRP react to that.

255
00:13:05.582 --> 00:13:09.200
And so I'll do a quick show standby on it.

256
00:13:09.200 --> 00:13:13.690
And I can see that I've gone into standby
mode, which is what I'm supposed to be.

257
00:13:13.690 --> 00:13:16.240
And NYCORE2 is supposed to be active.

258
00:13:16.240 --> 00:13:20.625
And so down here,
I can see active router is 192.168.16.3,

259
00:13:20.625 --> 00:13:25.310
which is NYCORE2, so
that just fixed our HSRP problem, right?

260
00:13:25.310 --> 00:13:26.020
But we're not done.

261
00:13:26.020 --> 00:13:28.090
Remember, this question
was made up of two pieces.

262
00:13:28.090 --> 00:13:32.340
The original problem was that
PLABCSCO01 could not ping us.

263
00:13:32.340 --> 00:13:36.500
Which makes sense cuz there was no way for
VLAN 16 to get to this switch until now.

264
00:13:36.500 --> 00:13:38.920
So we probably fixed that
problem at the same time.

265
00:13:38.920 --> 00:13:43.030
So let's jump over to our server and
see if that is truly fixed.

266
00:13:43.030 --> 00:13:44.810
I'm gonna fire up the old
command prompt here.

267
00:13:46.820 --> 00:13:53.260
And we'll just do a quick
ping to 192.168.16.2.

268
00:13:53.260 --> 00:13:53.760
And there we go.

269
00:13:53.760 --> 00:13:58.120
All right, now like I said, there was
more than one way to solve this problem.

270
00:13:58.120 --> 00:14:01.840
The other solutions kind of
center around different things.

271
00:14:01.840 --> 00:14:07.130
For example,
I could have fixed VLAN 16 on this trunk,

272
00:14:07.130 --> 00:14:09.690
and checked to make sure that
it was working on this trunk.

273
00:14:09.690 --> 00:14:13.070
And then CORE1 would have
seen CORE through ACCESS1.

274
00:14:13.070 --> 00:14:16.720
But it's pretty obvious in a network like
this that's not the intended behavior.

275
00:14:16.720 --> 00:14:18.890
So it came down to fixing
this link up here.

276
00:14:18.890 --> 00:14:21.028
We fixed port 24 to make it trunk.

277
00:14:21.028 --> 00:14:26.400
We could have also gone in and reset
port 23, made it a switch port again,

278
00:14:26.400 --> 00:14:29.130
created a port channel, and
gone through all that extra work.

279
00:14:29.130 --> 00:14:31.620
But at the end of the day, the question
didn't really ask us for that.

280
00:14:31.620 --> 00:14:35.474
It just wanted us to make sure
that CSCO1 could ping CORE1,

281
00:14:35.474 --> 00:14:40.810
which we did, and to make sure that
CORE1 was standby and CORE2 was active.

282
00:14:40.810 --> 00:14:41.520
Our solution did it.

283
00:14:41.520 --> 00:14:43.570
And technically, we did it in one command.

284
00:14:43.570 --> 00:14:47.820
We went into port 24 on CORE1 and
said switchport mode trunk.

285
00:14:47.820 --> 00:14:50.290
And that was what took care of it,
got VLAN 16 up, and

286
00:14:50.290 --> 00:14:52.270
got us working with the least
administrative effort.

287
00:14:52.270 --> 00:14:55.440
So that's a good solution right there and
that solves this problem.

288
00:14:55.440 --> 00:14:57.760
All right, well,
that wraps it up for this one.

289
00:14:57.760 --> 00:14:59.790
Turned out to be just
a trunking issue in our case,

290
00:14:59.790 --> 00:15:02.380
but one with a lot of possible
alternative solutions.

291
00:15:02.380 --> 00:15:04.070
So always be on the look out for those.

292
00:15:04.070 --> 00:15:04.990
But that'll wrap this one up.

293
00:15:04.990 --> 00:15:06.140
Hope you guys enjoyed it.

294
00:15:06.140 --> 00:15:09.465
Stay tuned,
we've got more troubleshooting coming up.

295
00:15:09.465 --> 00:15:16.099
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #3` from set #4. The trouble ticket states that "An interface on NYCORE2 is showing an err-disable state, this needs to be resolved "
episodes.title: Set 4 Issue 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.991
[SOUND].
So now we're going to move on to Set 4

2
00:00:04.991 --> 00:00:11.045
Issue 3,
the next troubleshooting problem for

3
00:00:11.045 --> 00:00:14.190
this particular set.

4
00:00:14.190 --> 00:00:17.300
And on this one we've got another
error that we need to resolve.

5
00:00:17.300 --> 00:00:19.070
So it's going to be localized
to a single switch.

6
00:00:19.070 --> 00:00:21.120
These are always nice questions,
cuz you don't have to hunt around for

7
00:00:21.120 --> 00:00:22.170
where the problem is.

8
00:00:22.170 --> 00:00:26.070
So this one says on
an interface on NYCORE2,

9
00:00:26.070 --> 00:00:28.540
we're showing the error disabled state.

10
00:00:28.540 --> 00:00:30.260
This needs to be resolved.

11
00:00:30.260 --> 00:00:32.110
They don't give us a ton of details here,

12
00:00:32.110 --> 00:00:36.250
just there is a port,
some port, on NYCORE2.

13
00:00:36.250 --> 00:00:39.600
It's error disabled,
we need to find out why and fix it.

14
00:00:39.600 --> 00:00:42.450
And there's a lot of different things
that can cause a port to go into

15
00:00:42.450 --> 00:00:43.052
error disabled.

16
00:00:43.052 --> 00:00:48.800
Things like root guard, BPDU guard,

17
00:00:48.800 --> 00:00:53.630
port security,
UDLD can even do it in some scenarios.

18
00:00:54.840 --> 00:00:55.710
Port mirroring, or

19
00:00:55.710 --> 00:00:58.250
SPAN that's misconfigured can
cause a port to go error disabled.

20
00:00:58.250 --> 00:01:00.120
There's a lot of stuff
that can cause that.

21
00:01:00.120 --> 00:01:02.270
We need to find out what it is and fix it.

22
00:01:02.270 --> 00:01:05.710
So let's jump on over to NYCORE2 and
see if we can't figure that out.

23
00:01:05.710 --> 00:01:08.251
We don't even need to mess with our
topology on this one cuz it's all

24
00:01:08.251 --> 00:01:09.240
localized to one switch.

25
00:01:09.240 --> 00:01:14.070
This guy right here, which we've already
worked on in some previous sets.

26
00:01:14.070 --> 00:01:17.060
So if we jump in here, the first
thing we need to do is figure out

27
00:01:17.060 --> 00:01:18.790
what port they're talking about, right?

28
00:01:18.790 --> 00:01:23.470
And there's a few different ways you
can spot the port that's kinda damaged.

29
00:01:23.470 --> 00:01:26.820
If you do a show ip interface brief,
you don't always see it, right?

30
00:01:26.820 --> 00:01:29.190
So when you do a show ip interface brief,
you can run down and

31
00:01:29.190 --> 00:01:31.620
you can see ports that are up,
ports that are down.

32
00:01:31.620 --> 00:01:33.270
And as you scroll through,

33
00:01:33.270 --> 00:01:36.840
it doesn't really say whether
one's error disabled or not.

34
00:01:36.840 --> 00:01:39.790
And if most of the ports are down,
it's really easy to overlook that and

35
00:01:39.790 --> 00:01:41.830
just not even be able to see it.

36
00:01:41.830 --> 00:01:46.130
So if we wanna try and figure out
which it is that is err-disabled,

37
00:01:46.130 --> 00:01:49.080
well, show interface is one
of the best ways to do it,

38
00:01:49.080 --> 00:01:51.380
because it'll be in the interface output.

39
00:01:51.380 --> 00:01:57.830
The problem is you get a lot of
information when you run show interface.

40
00:01:57.830 --> 00:02:01.290
And so what I like to do is
a quick show interface, and

41
00:02:01.290 --> 00:02:03.280
filter that to include a few lines.

42
00:02:03.280 --> 00:02:06.110
I like to include lines
with line protocol,

43
00:02:06.110 --> 00:02:08.360
cuz that's where it gives me
the name of the interface.

44
00:02:08.360 --> 00:02:11.155
And then I'm gonna look for disabled.

45
00:02:11.155 --> 00:02:15.750
And that's gonna help me to jump through
and spot which one is err-disabled.

46
00:02:15.750 --> 00:02:19.260
And as you go down the line of what comes
out, we can start to see these interfaces.

47
00:02:19.260 --> 00:02:23.110
I get their interface names and
it's keying off of that line protocol.

48
00:02:23.110 --> 00:02:25.480
And then I can see not connected,
not connected.

49
00:02:25.480 --> 00:02:29.235
And then when I get down to port 12,
right here, this guy.

50
00:02:29.235 --> 00:02:35.930
FastEthernet1/0/12 is down,
line protocol is down, (err-disabled).

51
00:02:35.930 --> 00:02:39.500
So there's the one that's err-disabled,
we spotted it, we kind of found it.

52
00:02:39.500 --> 00:02:40.240
And that command,

53
00:02:40.240 --> 00:02:44.510
again, I just did show interface,
which gives me way too much data.

54
00:02:44.510 --> 00:02:49.570
And then I said, only include lines
that have the word, line protocol.

55
00:02:49.570 --> 00:02:52.640
Because line protocol,
that's where we get the name of the port.

56
00:02:52.640 --> 00:02:54.340
And then I looked for the word, disabled.

57
00:02:54.340 --> 00:02:57.096
I did an or disabled, and so
that's why I got kinda both,

58
00:02:57.096 --> 00:02:59.000
I guess I could've left that part out.

59
00:02:59.000 --> 00:03:02.420
But now I get it, and we kinda spot
that and see which one is disabled.

60
00:03:02.420 --> 00:03:05.110
Now that we know that it's that port,

61
00:03:05.110 --> 00:03:08.260
we can start to take a look
at why it's err-disabled.

62
00:03:08.260 --> 00:03:10.245
And I'll do a show interface fa1/0/12.

63
00:03:10.245 --> 00:03:12.711
Looking at the port specifically,

64
00:03:12.711 --> 00:03:16.500
sometimes we can get a little
extra information on it.

65
00:03:16.500 --> 00:03:18.360
Sometimes you can, sometimes you can't.

66
00:03:18.360 --> 00:03:22.430
And so, in my case, I can see here's
the port, it is err-disabled.

67
00:03:22.430 --> 00:03:25.665
As I start to look down the rest
of it here, what I can look for

68
00:03:25.665 --> 00:03:31.405
are things like UDLD errors and stuff
that might come up here in our inputs.

69
00:03:31.405 --> 00:03:35.515
And as I scan across this I'm not,
actually just seeing a bunch of 0s for

70
00:03:35.515 --> 00:03:39.715
my errors and things, so
nothing too crazy popping up there.

71
00:03:39.715 --> 00:03:43.875
And I'm really not seeing anything
here that would be a red flag for me.

72
00:03:43.875 --> 00:03:47.570
This is all just normal, kinda run of
the mill stuff, what we'd expect to see.

73
00:03:48.850 --> 00:03:53.760
There's another command that we can run,
which is show interface status.

74
00:03:53.760 --> 00:03:56.450
And that'll show us additional
information about the interface.

75
00:03:56.450 --> 00:03:59.420
And you'll see that you
can specify err-disabled,

76
00:03:59.420 --> 00:04:01.550
which will show us the interfaces
that are in that error.

77
00:04:01.550 --> 00:04:06.330
So I'll go ahead and do that,
show interface status err-disabled.

78
00:04:06.330 --> 00:04:09.250
And now I can look at it, and
this is a little bit better for me,

79
00:04:09.250 --> 00:04:15.540
because it tells me the port, that it's
err-disabled, and why it's err-disabled.

80
00:04:15.540 --> 00:04:17.860
And that's exactly what I needed to know.

81
00:04:17.860 --> 00:04:21.970
So, show interface status err-disabled
got me right to where I needed,

82
00:04:21.970 --> 00:04:26.780
and it gave me this little clue
right here, psecure-violation.

83
00:04:26.780 --> 00:04:28.710
What is psecure?

84
00:04:28.710 --> 00:04:30.340
Port security, right?

85
00:04:30.340 --> 00:04:33.430
Port security is how we can limit
the MAC addresses on a port,

86
00:04:33.430 --> 00:04:34.770
we can limit other resources.

87
00:04:34.770 --> 00:04:36.460
And in this case,

88
00:04:36.460 --> 00:04:39.060
apparently I've violated whatever
that limit was that was implemented.

89
00:04:39.060 --> 00:04:40.620
So we need to take a look at that.

90
00:04:40.620 --> 00:04:45.061
And you can do a show port-security.

91
00:04:46.290 --> 00:04:49.490
And we can look at the ports that
are in violation and kinda get an idea.

92
00:04:49.490 --> 00:04:56.200
And sure enough, here's port Fa1/0/12,
it's got a maximum mac address count of 1.

93
00:04:56.200 --> 00:05:00.256
It's currently got 1, but
it's in a security violation of 1,

94
00:05:00.256 --> 00:05:03.690
that means that a second one came along.

95
00:05:03.690 --> 00:05:08.344
Now, you might ask yourself, if it says
current of 1 and max 1, isn't that equal,

96
00:05:08.344 --> 00:05:09.630
aren't I okay?

97
00:05:09.630 --> 00:05:12.440
Well, it depends on the way
port-security is set up.

98
00:05:12.440 --> 00:05:16.640
If it's set to enforcing,
then what it's gonna do is it's gonna stop

99
00:05:16.640 --> 00:05:20.300
the second address from being added,
and put us into err-disabled.

100
00:05:20.300 --> 00:05:22.679
Which is exactly what it's done,
that's why we're shut down right here.

101
00:05:23.710 --> 00:05:25.880
If it's just set to alerting though,

102
00:05:25.880 --> 00:05:29.970
then it'll let the current address
count exceed what the maximum is.

103
00:05:29.970 --> 00:05:31.650
And then you get your
violation count over here.

104
00:05:31.650 --> 00:05:33.260
So that's why we have those columns.

105
00:05:33.260 --> 00:05:39.030
But this one looks like it's going
to boil down to port-security.

106
00:05:39.030 --> 00:05:41.551
So if I do a show run for
interface fa1/0/12,

107
00:05:41.551 --> 00:05:45.560
I expect to see a port-security
configuration, and there it is, right?

108
00:05:45.560 --> 00:05:48.156
So we've got switchport port-security,

109
00:05:48.156 --> 00:05:51.251
switchport port-security
mac-address sticky.

110
00:05:51.251 --> 00:05:53.520
So, by default when you
turn on port security,

111
00:05:53.520 --> 00:05:56.260
the default limit is one mac-address,
all right?

112
00:05:56.260 --> 00:05:59.250
If there was a count assigned,
then it could be something higher,

113
00:05:59.250 --> 00:06:02.065
but right now it's just set
to the defaults, which is 1.

114
00:06:02.065 --> 00:06:07.010
mac-address sticky is, it learned whatever
the first MAC address was that it saw.

115
00:06:07.010 --> 00:06:09.710
And the very next line I
can see what it learned.

116
00:06:09.710 --> 00:06:11.270
It learned this mac-address right here,
0001.12ad.45a1.

117
00:06:11.270 --> 00:06:14.120
So it learned that one,

118
00:06:14.120 --> 00:06:18.970
that's what's assigned on it, okay.

119
00:06:18.970 --> 00:06:23.438
Now, as long as I plug a computer into
this port that matches that mac-address,

120
00:06:23.438 --> 00:06:24.370
it'll be fine.

121
00:06:24.370 --> 00:06:29.380
But if some other mac-address comes along,
I'll get a violation, all right?

122
00:06:29.380 --> 00:06:31.170
That's more than likely what happened.

123
00:06:31.170 --> 00:06:36.056
If I do a show mac address table,
and I filter that for 1/0/12,

124
00:06:36.056 --> 00:06:41.200
well, actually I'm not really
showing anything in there, am I?

125
00:06:41.200 --> 00:06:44.660
So, I kind of expected to
see a mac address in there.

126
00:06:44.660 --> 00:06:46.410
At least one, right?

127
00:06:46.410 --> 00:06:47.800
We've got the static assignment.

128
00:06:47.800 --> 00:06:53.420
And, oh, sorry, the default is that
the action that we're taking is enforcing.

129
00:06:53.420 --> 00:06:55.820
So it's stopping that second one from
even making it into the MAC address.

130
00:06:55.820 --> 00:06:58.812
So whatever's plugged into the other
end of this line is more than likely

131
00:06:58.812 --> 00:06:59.410
still there.

132
00:06:59.410 --> 00:07:02.010
But it's not even allows to make
it into the MAC address table.

133
00:07:02.010 --> 00:07:07.550
So we could temporarily turn off port
security to see that MAC address appear.

134
00:07:07.550 --> 00:07:11.710
This is gonna boil down to whether the
thing on the other end of this is good or

135
00:07:11.710 --> 00:07:12.790
bad, right?

136
00:07:12.790 --> 00:07:14.390
I've got something plugged in to port 12.

137
00:07:14.390 --> 00:07:18.040
Is it an approved device or
not an approved device?

138
00:07:18.040 --> 00:07:20.510
If it's not an approved device,
I don't want to fix this problem.

139
00:07:20.510 --> 00:07:22.970
We're blocking it,
that's exactly what we want, right?

140
00:07:22.970 --> 00:07:25.580
So I need to go to the physical
location and find that.

141
00:07:25.580 --> 00:07:30.210
But if it is an approved device,
maybe somebody's computer failed, and

142
00:07:30.210 --> 00:07:31.480
they had to get a replacement.

143
00:07:31.480 --> 00:07:32.940
So the MAC address changed.

144
00:07:32.940 --> 00:07:37.820
Or maybe their computer is now
plugged in to a VoIP phone, and

145
00:07:37.820 --> 00:07:39.290
the VoIP phone is plugged into the wall.

146
00:07:39.290 --> 00:07:40.530
Right, so we're kinda daisy chaining.

147
00:07:40.530 --> 00:07:43.600
So now there's two MAC addresses
on this port instead of one.

148
00:07:43.600 --> 00:07:45.240
And I know that and I'm okay with it.

149
00:07:45.240 --> 00:07:46.760
Then I just need to come in here and
adjust it.

150
00:07:46.760 --> 00:07:48.340
So how do I adjust it?

151
00:07:48.340 --> 00:07:50.000
One, I could turn off port security.

152
00:07:50.000 --> 00:07:51.566
It's probably not what we want.

153
00:07:51.566 --> 00:07:54.010
Two, I could increase the MAC
address count to two, and

154
00:07:54.010 --> 00:07:56.324
that would allow the second
MAC address on the port.

155
00:07:56.324 --> 00:08:01.990
Three, I could switch it from
enforcing to just alerting,

156
00:08:01.990 --> 00:08:04.820
and then that way it'd let the MAC
address count go a little bit higher.

157
00:08:04.820 --> 00:08:05.800
That would work too.

158
00:08:05.800 --> 00:08:07.257
So, few different solutions that,

159
00:08:07.257 --> 00:08:09.330
I could actually think of
a few other solutions too.

160
00:08:09.330 --> 00:08:13.790
But of those, I just need to
kind of understand the scenario.

161
00:08:13.790 --> 00:08:16.680
If this new MAC address is gonna
be replacing the existing one,

162
00:08:16.680 --> 00:08:20.480
like somebody got a replacement computer,
then I just need to clear the sticky MAC.

163
00:08:20.480 --> 00:08:21.940
And then it'll learn the new MAC, and

164
00:08:21.940 --> 00:08:24.330
that'll become the new one
that's approved on the port.

165
00:08:24.330 --> 00:08:27.120
Since they didn't really tell us in
the question, they just say hey,

166
00:08:27.120 --> 00:08:30.110
it's err-disabled,
we need to resolve it, let's just assume

167
00:08:30.110 --> 00:08:33.780
that this is a replacement computer and
the new MAC address is the one I want.

168
00:08:33.780 --> 00:08:37.400
All I've gotta do is clear out
the existing MAC and reset the port.

169
00:08:37.400 --> 00:08:39.760
It'll learn the new MAC and
then we'll be in business.

170
00:08:39.760 --> 00:08:41.900
So, let's do that.

171
00:08:41.900 --> 00:08:47.277
I'm going to do a show run for
interface 1/0/12 again.

172
00:08:47.277 --> 00:08:52.895
And I will jump into configuration,
get into fa1/0/12,

173
00:08:52.895 --> 00:08:58.625
and I'm gonna do a no switchport
port-security mac-address.

174
00:08:58.625 --> 00:09:05.124
And then I'm gonna feed in that
address to get it out of there.

175
00:09:05.124 --> 00:09:10.560
And let's see, 12ad.45a1, yyping
mac-addresses is always a good time.

176
00:09:12.050 --> 00:09:15.540
There we go, and so I'm just gonna
get rid of that mac-address.

177
00:09:15.540 --> 00:09:20.530
And if I look at my configuration again,
see how I still have that sticky port.

178
00:09:20.530 --> 00:09:23.332
And I'm gonna do a shutdown
to turn the port off, and

179
00:09:23.332 --> 00:09:25.060
a no shutdown to turn it back on.

180
00:09:25.060 --> 00:09:29.050
And I'm doing that because that
will clear the err-disabled state.

181
00:09:29.050 --> 00:09:31.590
If I wait, we might have
err-disable recovery turned on, and

182
00:09:31.590 --> 00:09:32.510
it might recover on it's own.

183
00:09:32.510 --> 00:09:34.650
But I'm in a hurry so I'll just
shut it down and no shut it down.

184
00:09:34.650 --> 00:09:38.610
That'll bring it back up, and
we should learn the new mac-address.

185
00:09:38.610 --> 00:09:41.030
The mac-address sticky
command is still there, so

186
00:09:41.030 --> 00:09:43.840
it's gonna learn the next mac-address and
repopulate it.

187
00:09:43.840 --> 00:09:44.720
Now, in this lab,

188
00:09:44.720 --> 00:09:48.190
I don't actually know if there's
anything plugged into port 12 or not.

189
00:09:48.190 --> 00:09:53.500
But if there is, we'll know it cuz a new
mac-address should show up in here.

190
00:09:53.500 --> 00:09:58.110
And I'm thinking that there isn't
anything plugged into it, so

191
00:09:58.110 --> 00:10:02.490
let's take a look at
whether it's turning up.

192
00:10:02.490 --> 00:10:05.850
The port is up up, so
there is something plugged into it.

193
00:10:05.850 --> 00:10:08.440
We just haven't learned
whatever it is yet.

194
00:10:08.440 --> 00:10:10.730
Whatever it is isn't talking, apparently.

195
00:10:10.730 --> 00:10:13.060
And that's a common problem
with this kind of stuff.

196
00:10:13.060 --> 00:10:15.840
Sometimes the devices just
don't want to chatter, and so

197
00:10:15.840 --> 00:10:19.790
you end up kinda waiting a long time
to verify that something is working.

198
00:10:19.790 --> 00:10:20.970
Yeah, it's not talking.

199
00:10:20.970 --> 00:10:24.320
So, what I'm doing here is just show
Mac address-table, and I'm looking for

200
00:10:24.320 --> 00:10:25.220
port 1/0/12.

201
00:10:25.220 --> 00:10:29.981
And I never type the speed of the port cuz
I can never remember if it's a capital F

202
00:10:29.981 --> 00:10:34.430
or lowercase f, is it fa, or
fast Ethernet, how is it written out?

203
00:10:34.430 --> 00:10:39.220
So I'm just trying make sure this command
works, regardless of which case it is.

204
00:10:39.220 --> 00:10:43.020
But whatever device is plugged into
there should chat at some point.

205
00:10:43.020 --> 00:10:46.210
And as soon as it does, it should
show up here in my Mac Address table.

206
00:10:46.210 --> 00:10:50.160
And as soon as that Mac Address shows up,
the sticky Mac should learn it, and

207
00:10:50.160 --> 00:10:52.490
it should now get entered in and
put into the system.

208
00:10:52.490 --> 00:10:55.490
And now that'll become
the new single port.

209
00:10:55.490 --> 00:10:58.650
But I can go all the way back
to show interface status.

210
00:11:03.160 --> 00:11:06.180
If I can type it.

211
00:11:06.180 --> 00:11:10.620
Let's see, status err-disabled.

212
00:11:10.620 --> 00:11:15.140
And now I don't have any
interfaces that are err-disabled.

213
00:11:15.140 --> 00:11:17.401
I can do a show interface fa1/0/12.

214
00:11:17.401 --> 00:11:23.920
And on it, I'm now showing that it's
up and connected, and not err-disabled.

215
00:11:23.920 --> 00:11:28.188
And if I do a show port-security,
I can see that

216
00:11:28.188 --> 00:11:33.315
fa1/0/12 still has that
maximum mac address set,

217
00:11:33.315 --> 00:11:38.020
and security violation is set to 0,
all right?

218
00:11:38.020 --> 00:11:41.140
Now it says a current address count of 1,
which is interesting.

219
00:11:41.140 --> 00:11:43.170
So let's see if it finally learned that,

220
00:11:43.170 --> 00:11:46.330
maybe while I was talking there
whatever devices on it chatted.

221
00:11:46.330 --> 00:11:47.230
Yep, it sure did.

222
00:11:47.230 --> 00:11:51.260
Yep, so at some point while I was
rambling on there, it started to chat and

223
00:11:51.260 --> 00:11:53.890
I can see the new mac-address
has been learned.

224
00:11:53.890 --> 00:11:57.476
And so it's in there,
apparently just took its time.

225
00:11:57.476 --> 00:12:00.740
And there it is in the mac address-table.

226
00:12:00.740 --> 00:12:03.610
So now we've learned it,
we've cleared the problem, and we move on.

227
00:12:03.610 --> 00:12:05.830
Now if I was supposed to
have two MAC addresses,

228
00:12:05.830 --> 00:12:08.290
this problem isn't technically solved,
but they didn't tell me that.

229
00:12:08.290 --> 00:12:11.470
So I only see one other one,
we're clear, and we're ready to move on.

230
00:12:11.470 --> 00:12:14.230
So, couple of neat commands
that helped us there.

231
00:12:14.230 --> 00:12:17.370
I used show interfaces first with the
little filter command because that's what

232
00:12:17.370 --> 00:12:18.360
I kinda like to do.

233
00:12:18.360 --> 00:12:22.290
But also show interface status was a good
one to let us find the err-disabled port.

234
00:12:22.290 --> 00:12:24.520
Show port-security let us find it too.

235
00:12:24.520 --> 00:12:28.330
But at the end of the day, it was really
show running config that solved it for us.

236
00:12:28.330 --> 00:12:31.450
Right, we looked at the configuration
of that interface, cleared out the MAC

237
00:12:31.450 --> 00:12:33.970
address, let it relearn the new one,
and we were in business.

238
00:12:33.970 --> 00:12:37.280
So that resolved this error, and now
we're ready to move on to the next one.

239
00:12:37.280 --> 00:12:38.380
So hope you guys enjoyed it.

240
00:12:38.380 --> 00:12:43.814
Stay tuned, we've got another
troubleshooting issue coming up.

241
00:12:43.814 --> 00:12:48.719
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #4` from set #4. The trouble ticket states that "All of the standby groups on NYEDGE1 are active, when these should be active on NYCORE1 and NYCORE2, NYEDGE1 is the last resort router. "
episodes.title: Set 4 Issue 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.714
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.714 --> 00:00:11.430
All right,
let's move on to set 4, issue 4.

3
00:00:11.430 --> 00:00:13.880
Looks like we've got
an HSSRP problem again.

4
00:00:13.880 --> 00:00:15.120
So let's take a look at this one.

5
00:00:15.120 --> 00:00:16.770
The troubleshooting
ticket reads like this.

6
00:00:16.770 --> 00:00:22.160
It says, all of the standby
groups on NYEDGE1 are active

7
00:00:22.160 --> 00:00:25.810
When these should be active on NYCORE1 and
NYCORE2.

8
00:00:25.810 --> 00:00:29.570
NYEDGE1 is the last resort router.

9
00:00:29.570 --> 00:00:32.670
So, you might remember from some of
the previous sets that we have HSSRP

10
00:00:32.670 --> 00:00:36.485
running between NYCORE1,
NYCORE2 and NYEDGE1.

11
00:00:36.485 --> 00:00:39.500
And NYCORE 1 and NYCORE 2,

12
00:00:39.500 --> 00:00:44.360
they're kinda dividing up seven VLANs
where one of them is active for

13
00:00:44.360 --> 00:00:47.890
the odd number VLANs and the other
is active for the even number VLANs.

14
00:00:47.890 --> 00:00:50.940
So they're standby and
active, kind of an even mix.

15
00:00:50.940 --> 00:00:55.650
But NY edge 1,
it's supposed to be third place router.

16
00:00:55.650 --> 00:00:58.840
Not active, not standby, just listening.

17
00:00:58.840 --> 00:01:00.490
It's called the other state.

18
00:01:00.490 --> 00:01:02.460
And so it's supposed to be
in that other state for

19
00:01:02.460 --> 00:01:06.310
HSRP, and just serving as a backup
if the other guys fail and

20
00:01:06.310 --> 00:01:08.170
normally the way we achieve
that is with priority.

21
00:01:08.170 --> 00:01:12.062
So you'll have somebody at priority 100,
somebody at priority 90, somebody at

22
00:01:12.062 --> 00:01:16.810
priority 80 And NYEDGE1 would be the one
at priority 80, the lowest priority.

23
00:01:16.810 --> 00:01:19.930
It should only come active if
the other two routers are gone.

24
00:01:19.930 --> 00:01:21.860
Well in this scenario that's
what's happened, right.

25
00:01:21.860 --> 00:01:23.910
NYEDGE1 has gone active.

26
00:01:23.910 --> 00:01:28.850
So either NYCORE1 and NYCORE2 are down,
or I got some other kind of problem.

27
00:01:28.850 --> 00:01:30.820
So let's dive in and take a look.

28
00:01:30.820 --> 00:01:35.370
Now looking at our topology, these are the
three devices that are in the mix, right?

29
00:01:35.370 --> 00:01:37.360
We've got CORE1, CORE2 and

30
00:01:37.360 --> 00:01:41.500
EDGE1 and I know the problem is more
than likely on EDGE1 cuz it's active for

31
00:01:41.500 --> 00:01:45.510
everything when it shouldn't be,
but just to be sure, I want to take

32
00:01:45.510 --> 00:01:50.490
a quick look at these other switches, just
to make sure they're working right, okay?

33
00:01:50.490 --> 00:01:55.220
CORE1 should be active for the odd
networks and CORE2 should be active for

34
00:01:55.220 --> 00:01:56.550
the even networks.

35
00:01:56.550 --> 00:02:00.830
I wanna see if they are because this could
be as simple as this link being down.

36
00:02:00.830 --> 00:02:04.430
If the link between CORE1 and
EDGE1 is down, EDGE1 won't be able to see

37
00:02:04.430 --> 00:02:07.880
either of the CORE switches and
it would go active for everything.

38
00:02:07.880 --> 00:02:11.490
But if that's the case,
then these guys would still be active for

39
00:02:11.490 --> 00:02:15.200
their associated VLANs, and
that kinda tells us where that problem is.

40
00:02:15.200 --> 00:02:16.920
It lets us know to go up to EDGE1,

41
00:02:16.920 --> 00:02:19.880
but I just wanna verify that before
I get too deep into this problem.

42
00:02:19.880 --> 00:02:23.780
So I'm gonna jump down to Core 1 and
on Core 1,

43
00:02:23.780 --> 00:02:25.820
I'm just gonna do a quick show standby.

44
00:02:25.820 --> 00:02:27.360
Now I see a quick one.

45
00:02:27.360 --> 00:02:30.960
The show standby command actually
shows you a lot of information, right?

46
00:02:30.960 --> 00:02:35.570
And when you're running standby for more
than one VLAN, it can quite a bit, right?

47
00:02:35.570 --> 00:02:39.880
You can get a little overwhelmed with it
all and so I normally only do show standby

48
00:02:39.880 --> 00:02:42.770
when I'm specifying a particular VLAN,
but I wanna see them all.

49
00:02:42.770 --> 00:02:44.160
So there's a variation of that command,

50
00:02:44.160 --> 00:02:48.800
show standby brief, that's kinda nice when
you want to get a great big overview.

51
00:02:48.800 --> 00:02:54.180
And what I can see looking down
the line Is that I'm active for

52
00:02:54.180 --> 00:02:58.580
Vlan11 and I'm active for Vlan13 and
I'm active for Vlan15, right?

53
00:02:58.580 --> 00:03:02.970
See it says local is active that's me and

54
00:03:02.970 --> 00:03:07.325
then I can see that
192.168.something.3 is active for

55
00:03:07.325 --> 00:03:11.270
Vlan10,12,14 and 16 that's in my corp too.

56
00:03:11.270 --> 00:03:14.620
And I can see that I'm
the standby in those scenarios.

57
00:03:14.620 --> 00:03:18.440
So looking at this, NY Core 1, and

58
00:03:18.440 --> 00:03:21.800
by association NY Core 2,
they're showing the right stuff.

59
00:03:21.800 --> 00:03:23.450
Things are running the right way.

60
00:03:23.450 --> 00:03:26.700
So as far as these guys are concerned,
HSRP is working fine.

61
00:03:26.700 --> 00:03:30.000
We've got a priority of 100 for
the active router and a priority of 90 for

62
00:03:30.000 --> 00:03:30.580
the standby.

63
00:03:31.740 --> 00:03:35.890
It could be that NYEDGE1
has a higher priority, but

64
00:03:35.890 --> 00:03:39.860
that would affect these guys and
I'm not seeing that here, right?

65
00:03:39.860 --> 00:03:44.170
So that's what's gonna tell me we more
than likely have a link issue here.

66
00:03:44.170 --> 00:03:48.270
That the link between NYCORE1 and
NYEDGE1 is probably down and

67
00:03:48.270 --> 00:03:53.400
if it's down then that's why I'm not
going to be able to communicate over.

68
00:03:53.400 --> 00:03:56.000
And this one's going to go active,
but let's go see if it's active.

69
00:03:56.000 --> 00:03:59.790
I'm going to go to NYEDGE1,
maybe it isn't active, right?

70
00:03:59.790 --> 00:04:04.150
Maybe it's in the other state already and
the question's just wrong.

71
00:04:04.150 --> 00:04:05.730
So, I'm going to get in here and

72
00:04:05.730 --> 00:04:10.150
just do that same show standby
brief to get my summary.

73
00:04:10.150 --> 00:04:13.600
Well, unfortunately the question
is right this time, I can see.

74
00:04:13.600 --> 00:04:17.510
It is active for
every one of these networks.

75
00:04:17.510 --> 00:04:21.290
Now NY Core 1 and Core 2 are switches, and
so they were doing everything off of their

76
00:04:21.290 --> 00:04:24.570
vlan interfaces, but
NY Edge 1 is a router.

77
00:04:24.570 --> 00:04:29.530
And so it's got virtual interfaces,
it's doing router on a stick and

78
00:04:29.530 --> 00:04:34.420
so I see GI0/0, 10, 11, 12 and
so on, one for each vlan.

79
00:04:34.420 --> 00:04:36.980
And it has gone active on
every single one of them.

80
00:04:36.980 --> 00:04:39.090
Standby is unknown.

81
00:04:39.090 --> 00:04:42.050
It's not seeing NYCORE1 or NYCORE2.

82
00:04:42.050 --> 00:04:46.096
So again, I'm thinking interface problem,
all right?

83
00:04:46.096 --> 00:04:47.730
So let's verify that.

84
00:04:47.730 --> 00:04:49.070
Let's take a look at the interface.

85
00:04:49.070 --> 00:04:53.380
I'm gonna do a show ip interface brief and

86
00:04:53.380 --> 00:04:57.970
take a look at my interfaces, and I can
see that gi0/0, that's the interface.

87
00:04:57.970 --> 00:04:59.760
I saw that in the topology, right?

88
00:04:59.760 --> 00:05:01.800
That's this interface here.

89
00:05:01.800 --> 00:05:05.160
It is showing as up, up,
which is good, right?

90
00:05:05.160 --> 00:05:09.060
If it was down, then we'd kind of have our
problem right there, but it is showing as

91
00:05:09.060 --> 00:05:13.270
up, up, so we're in good shape there,
but that doesn't help me, right?

92
00:05:13.270 --> 00:05:14.910
All these interfaces are up, up.

93
00:05:14.910 --> 00:05:17.360
So it thinks that it's up.

94
00:05:17.360 --> 00:05:21.120
I could try and do a quick ping, right.

95
00:05:21.120 --> 00:05:22.500
I've got an ip 192.168.16.4.

96
00:05:22.500 --> 00:05:24.800
The other switches are 192.168.16.2 and
.3.

97
00:05:24.800 --> 00:05:27.090
Let's see if I can ping those.

98
00:05:27.090 --> 00:05:31.080
So I'm just gonna test
some basic connectivity.

99
00:05:32.220 --> 00:05:35.650
Trying to ping .2 and
I'll let the first one fail.

100
00:05:35.650 --> 00:05:37.440
Well, and then the second one,
that's that.

101
00:05:38.500 --> 00:05:40.460
Let me try .3 and
see if I get the same result.

102
00:05:40.460 --> 00:05:44.350
All right, so it looks like we
definitely have a connectivity issue but

103
00:05:44.350 --> 00:05:48.170
it's not player one, because my
interface shows as up-up, right?

104
00:05:48.170 --> 00:05:51.410
So my interface isn't showing as down,
I should be good there.

105
00:05:51.410 --> 00:05:53.750
We had some error disabled
stuff in another episode, so

106
00:05:53.750 --> 00:05:59.210
maybe I'll do a show interface status for
gi0/0 and,

107
00:05:59.210 --> 00:06:06.250
let's see Is it not gonna let me see that?

108
00:06:06.250 --> 00:06:08.410
Oh here, we'll do it like err-disabled,
there we go.

109
00:06:08.410 --> 00:06:11.690
So I don't have anything err-disabled, so
that's fine, and if I do a show int gi0/0,

110
00:06:11.690 --> 00:06:18.300
all it shows is up up, it seems healthy.

111
00:06:18.300 --> 00:06:21.570
Look at my errors down here,
we'll see if we got any errors.

112
00:06:21.570 --> 00:06:22.800
Not really seeing any errors.

113
00:06:22.800 --> 00:06:25.620
I got one interface reset, but
that's not necessarily a big deal.

114
00:06:25.620 --> 00:06:27.040
The interface is up now.

115
00:06:27.040 --> 00:06:29.760
So I'm not really seeing anything
jump out on the interface, but

116
00:06:29.760 --> 00:06:32.670
I'm definitely having some
connectivity issues, and

117
00:06:32.670 --> 00:06:34.790
I'm probably having them on all the VLANs,
right?

118
00:06:34.790 --> 00:06:37.650
So if I kinda,
I'll just single out NYCORE2.

119
00:06:37.650 --> 00:06:41.800
So I'm gonna try and ping NYCORE2 and
I tried it on VLAN16.

120
00:06:43.140 --> 00:06:47.490
I'm just gonna try a few other vlans, now,
where this gets challenging is it's really

121
00:06:47.490 --> 00:06:53.100
hard to troubleshoot vlans on a router
because it doesn't know about the vlans.

122
00:06:53.100 --> 00:06:55.370
So, it just sees these
as subinterfaces and

123
00:06:55.370 --> 00:06:57.720
the tagging is kind of
happening on the back end.

124
00:06:57.720 --> 00:07:02.130
So, normally I could do like
a show interface trunk, right?

125
00:07:02.130 --> 00:07:08.260
That would work on a switch, but
on a router I get nothing back, okay?

126
00:07:08.260 --> 00:07:11.230
But I know this should be trunk,
because this is router on a stick.

127
00:07:11.230 --> 00:07:15.840
I've got multiple sub-interfaces tied
to VLans, it should be trunking, but

128
00:07:15.840 --> 00:07:17.640
I don't have my normal
troubleshooting commands.

129
00:07:17.640 --> 00:07:19.910
So, I'm just gonna do
a show running-config.

130
00:07:19.910 --> 00:07:22.730
Sometimes looking at the running-config
is the best way, and

131
00:07:22.730 --> 00:07:25.180
I wanna look at how that
interface is set up.

132
00:07:25.180 --> 00:07:28.100
Remembering how router on a stick
is supposed to be configured.

133
00:07:28.100 --> 00:07:31.490
With router on a stick
your parent interface, so

134
00:07:31.490 --> 00:07:35.610
in my case Gi0/0,
that's the native VLAN, all right?

135
00:07:35.610 --> 00:07:38.750
And I've got no ip address,
it's not turned on, I mean,

136
00:07:38.750 --> 00:07:43.540
it is turned on, I'm not using it for
IPV4, and so it just sits there.

137
00:07:43.540 --> 00:07:45.289
So I affectively am not
using my native VLAN.

138
00:07:46.300 --> 00:07:51.660
After that, I've got all the other vlans,
dot 10, 11, 12 and so on.

139
00:07:51.660 --> 00:07:55.250
And they've got encapsulation.dot1Q10.

140
00:07:55.250 --> 00:07:57.980
So as far as being a trunk,
they're set up right?

141
00:07:57.980 --> 00:08:00.210
Well at least the ones on
my screen are set up right.

142
00:08:00.210 --> 00:08:03.100
There might be ones with problems down
the road, but I'm having a problem with

143
00:08:03.100 --> 00:08:06.950
every one of my vlans so
I'm just gonna look at a couple of them.

144
00:08:06.950 --> 00:08:09.480
So I see 10, I see 11, I see 12.

145
00:08:09.480 --> 00:08:11.160
They've got their IP addresses.

146
00:08:11.160 --> 00:08:15.390
Priority is 85, so I do have
the lowest priority of the 3 devices.

147
00:08:15.390 --> 00:08:17.020
That should put me in the right state,

148
00:08:17.020 --> 00:08:20.400
and I'm set to preempt, but
that's not really gonna affect us here.

149
00:08:20.400 --> 00:08:24.750
So everything looks good here and
if everything looks good here,

150
00:08:24.750 --> 00:08:27.210
then where do I go from here?

151
00:08:27.210 --> 00:08:31.000
Well it could be that the problem
isn't actually on this end, right?

152
00:08:31.000 --> 00:08:32.640
A trunk has two ends.

153
00:08:32.640 --> 00:08:35.810
When I look at this cable here
that I said could be our problem,

154
00:08:35.810 --> 00:08:39.710
the problem could be on the router side or
it could be on the switch side.

155
00:08:39.710 --> 00:08:43.540
When you set up router on a stick you
create all your sub-interfaces here and

156
00:08:43.540 --> 00:08:47.970
you tag them for the v-lens.The other
side has to be set up to handle that too.

157
00:08:47.970 --> 00:08:49.400
So let's go take a look and
see if it's got it.

158
00:08:50.590 --> 00:08:56.380
So I'm gonna go back over to CORE1 and on
CORE1, I wanna look at the configuration

159
00:08:56.380 --> 00:09:01.420
for this interface right here,
Fas1/0/1, and see what it's got.

160
00:09:01.420 --> 00:09:05.720
So if I jump into that fa1/0/1.

161
00:09:05.720 --> 00:09:10.580
I can see switchport mode trunk,
encapsulation dot1q, so it's using

162
00:09:10.580 --> 00:09:15.095
the same encapsulation, switchport trunk
allowed vlan 10-16, so that's good.

163
00:09:15.095 --> 00:09:18.820
Switch-port mode access,
all right, that's a problem.

164
00:09:18.820 --> 00:09:22.720
When we go into switchport mode access,
now, we're only moving the native VLAN,

165
00:09:22.720 --> 00:09:26.110
in this case, VLAN one, since we're
not really assigned to a VLAN here.

166
00:09:26.110 --> 00:09:28.650
So only VLAN 1 is crossing a line.

167
00:09:28.650 --> 00:09:30.790
All the other VLANs are being trimmed off.

168
00:09:30.790 --> 00:09:35.190
And since they're being trimmed off,
H S R P can't communicate over it and

169
00:09:35.190 --> 00:09:37.870
that's why H S R P is going
active on the other side.

170
00:09:37.870 --> 00:09:41.412
If we fix this,
if we just get into fa1/0/1 and

171
00:09:41.412 --> 00:09:47.120
switch-port mode trunk,
the interface should start trunking.

172
00:09:47.120 --> 00:09:51.320
HSRP should see that and
then start to take action, and

173
00:09:51.320 --> 00:09:56.750
if I do a show interface trunk, I should
see that 1/0/1 is now trunking for

174
00:09:56.750 --> 00:10:01.300
VLANs 10 through 16, and I'll bet that
spanning-tree is still holding it down.

175
00:10:02.810 --> 00:10:05.680
So, let's just take a look
at one of these VLANs.

176
00:10:05.680 --> 00:10:09.410
And, yeah, so I've got 1/0/1 right
there is learning right now.

177
00:10:09.410 --> 00:10:12.880
We gotta give it 15 seconds for
listening, 15 seconds for learning, and

178
00:10:12.880 --> 00:10:14.150
then the port will come up.

179
00:10:14.150 --> 00:10:18.080
And then we've gotta give it up to 10
seconds for HSRP to recognize it, and

180
00:10:18.080 --> 00:10:20.940
start to adjust HSRP.

181
00:10:20.940 --> 00:10:24.190
So all that's kinda going on
in the background here, and

182
00:10:24.190 --> 00:10:25.180
I'm just gonna wait a second.

183
00:10:25.180 --> 00:10:27.530
There we go, just transitioned to forward.

184
00:10:27.530 --> 00:10:30.390
And so now, I'll jump up to NYEDGE1 and

185
00:10:30.390 --> 00:10:35.260
on this guy, I'm just gonna give
it a few moments and then I'm

186
00:10:35.260 --> 00:10:40.390
gonna run that show standby brief command
again, so I can see all my standby zones.

187
00:10:40.390 --> 00:10:45.090
And what I'm hoping to see is that I
switch from active to listen and that

188
00:10:45.090 --> 00:10:51.970
the active and standby router show up as
NY core one and NY core two which they do.

189
00:10:51.970 --> 00:10:56.100
So now,
I've gone into that listening state.

190
00:10:56.100 --> 00:11:00.240
I'm not active for any of those,
I am actually active on GIs 0/1 but

191
00:11:00.240 --> 00:11:02.050
that's a different problem, right.

192
00:11:02.050 --> 00:11:08.630
If we go back to our topology That's this
HSRP up here out connecting to our ISP.

193
00:11:08.630 --> 00:11:12.050
So that's not on the inside, so
that's a problem for another day, but

194
00:11:12.050 --> 00:11:17.010
as far as the internal side,
I see the output that I expect to see.

195
00:11:17.010 --> 00:11:18.280
We're not active.

196
00:11:18.280 --> 00:11:21.980
We are the last resort router for
HSRP, and our problem is solved.

197
00:11:21.980 --> 00:11:25.830
So just because you've got router on a
stick, just because you've got one router

198
00:11:25.830 --> 00:11:29.270
that's not behaving right doesn't mean
that router's the one that's at fault.

199
00:11:29.270 --> 00:11:31.960
In this case the problem actually
turned out to be on NYCORE1 with

200
00:11:31.960 --> 00:11:33.170
a mis-configured trunk.

201
00:11:33.170 --> 00:11:36.350
We got the other end of the line fixed and
now, we're communicating and

202
00:11:36.350 --> 00:11:37.160
everybody's happy.

203
00:11:37.160 --> 00:11:38.620
So, not so bad on that one.

204
00:11:38.620 --> 00:11:42.070
We just had to kind of isolate the
problem, resolve it, and then we move on.

205
00:11:42.070 --> 00:11:43.340
So I hope you guys enjoyed that.

206
00:11:43.340 --> 00:11:46.288
Stayed tuned.
We've got more issues from set

207
00:11:46.288 --> 00:11:47.629
four coming up.

208
00:11:47.629 --> 00:11:52.379
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #5` from set #4. The trouble ticket states that "Another HSRP issue exists, this time between NYEDGE1 and NYEDGE2. It appears that both routers are active for group 100 "
episodes.title: Set 4 Issue 5
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.378
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.378 --> 00:00:11.351
All right, welcome to Set 4 Issue 5, and

3
00:00:11.351 --> 00:00:14.580
we're gonna continue
with our HSRP debacle.

4
00:00:14.580 --> 00:00:16.980
We've got another HSRP problem
to work on in this one.

5
00:00:16.980 --> 00:00:19.340
The troubleshooting
ticket reads like this.

6
00:00:19.340 --> 00:00:22.760
It says another HSRP issue exist,
surprise, surprise.

7
00:00:22.760 --> 00:00:25.810
This time between ny edge 1 and ny edge 2.

8
00:00:25.810 --> 00:00:30.440
It appears that both routers
are active for group 100.

9
00:00:30.440 --> 00:00:34.046
Well lets take a look at our topology and
see what they're talking about here.

10
00:00:34.046 --> 00:00:38.220
So edge 1 and edge 2, their two routers
are up at the top of out topology, right?

11
00:00:38.220 --> 00:00:41.629
So this is kind off to the area
we haven't messed with too much.

12
00:00:41.629 --> 00:00:43.380
It's facing some ISPs.

13
00:00:43.380 --> 00:00:46.463
And it looks like they're
running HHRP between each other.

14
00:00:46.463 --> 00:00:47.880
On this pubic network.

15
00:00:47.880 --> 00:00:49.690
Now it's kind of hard
to tell on the diagram.

16
00:00:49.690 --> 00:00:51.480
They could be running on
this serial interface.

17
00:00:51.480 --> 00:00:53.230
We'll have to look at that and see, or

18
00:00:53.230 --> 00:00:55.440
they could be running it
on this gigabit interface.

19
00:00:55.440 --> 00:01:00.380
But either way that HSRP group 100,
and they're both active for

20
00:01:00.380 --> 00:01:03.460
that group when really only
one of them should be active.

21
00:01:03.460 --> 00:01:04.546
One of them should be standby.

22
00:01:04.546 --> 00:01:06.550
So let's go and found out.

23
00:01:06.550 --> 00:01:10.790
So I'm gonna start on NYEDGE1 since we've
kind of worked on that one a few times

24
00:01:10.790 --> 00:01:12.330
this series.

25
00:01:12.330 --> 00:01:14.255
And we'll just kind of see what we spot.

26
00:01:14.255 --> 00:01:16.276
Now because I don't know
what interface it's on,

27
00:01:16.276 --> 00:01:18.270
I could go hunting through the config.

28
00:01:18.270 --> 00:01:22.320
But this is another area where
show standby brief comes in handy,

29
00:01:22.320 --> 00:01:24.400
cuz we can just see all
the standby groups.

30
00:01:24.400 --> 00:01:26.330
And we can spot where group 100 is.

31
00:01:26.330 --> 00:01:27.670
Here's group 100.

32
00:01:27.670 --> 00:01:30.540
And it's on GI0/1, all right.

33
00:01:30.540 --> 00:01:35.354
Now the reason I wanted to do that is
I can, from here do a show standby for

34
00:01:35.354 --> 00:01:40.670
GI0/1, and I can see the detailed
information about just that interface.

35
00:01:40.670 --> 00:01:45.230
I can see its state is active, so
we are active like the problem described.

36
00:01:45.230 --> 00:01:50.100
I can see that I've got this
virtual IP of 172.14.0.1.

37
00:01:50.100 --> 00:01:54.600
I can see that, I'm the active router,
and that the standby router is unknown.

38
00:01:54.600 --> 00:01:55.680
All right.

39
00:01:55.680 --> 00:01:59.610
So, I can't see the standby router,
whoever that happens to be.

40
00:01:59.610 --> 00:02:01.860
Right.
Which is NY edge two.

41
00:02:01.860 --> 00:02:07.631
Now, I see that,
that virtual IP is 172.14.0.1.

42
00:02:07.631 --> 00:02:12.503
If I do a show run for interface gi0/1

43
00:02:12.503 --> 00:02:17.087
I can see that my unique IP is .10.

44
00:02:17.087 --> 00:02:20.575
Now the reason I want to note that is, I'm
about to go to the other router and just

45
00:02:20.575 --> 00:02:24.470
see if I have connectivity, see if I can
ping between them using their unique IPs.

46
00:02:24.470 --> 00:02:26.650
And then if I can, I'll go from there.

47
00:02:26.650 --> 00:02:29.420
Now, while I'm looking at the interface,
I'm going to note a few things.

48
00:02:29.420 --> 00:02:31.140
First off,
I'm gonna take my trusty pen, and

49
00:02:31.140 --> 00:02:33.560
I'm gonna write that IP down
cuz I doubt I'll remember it.

50
00:02:33.560 --> 00:02:42.046
So this is 172.14.0.10 is the unique
IP and .1 is the shared IP.

51
00:02:42.046 --> 00:02:47.280
Now, as I look at it, I can see that
priority is not defined on this, right.

52
00:02:47.280 --> 00:02:49.740
So that means I've got
a default priority of 100.

53
00:02:49.740 --> 00:02:52.000
They didn't really tell me who
was supposed to be active, and

54
00:02:52.000 --> 00:02:53.580
who was supposed to be standby.

55
00:02:53.580 --> 00:02:55.270
They just said that both were active and
that's bad.

56
00:02:55.270 --> 00:02:58.379
So I don't know if lab priority on
the other one or not, we'll have to see.

57
00:02:58.379 --> 00:03:02.870
I see preemption is turned on but
I also see authentication is turned on.

58
00:03:02.870 --> 00:03:04.180
All right?

59
00:03:04.180 --> 00:03:05.796
Authentication could
cause this problem too.

60
00:03:05.796 --> 00:03:08.410
It might be that I can
see the other router.

61
00:03:08.410 --> 00:03:11.180
But that it's failing authentication and
you know it kinda makes sense that

62
00:03:11.180 --> 00:03:14.990
authentication would be turned on
here because this is an ISP network.

63
00:03:14.990 --> 00:03:18.900
So maybe we don't trust the ISP so
when we configure HSRP here,

64
00:03:18.900 --> 00:03:22.130
we configure it with authentication
to make sure that somebody

65
00:03:22.130 --> 00:03:25.410
else couldn't jump in and
start to take over our virtual IP.

66
00:03:25.410 --> 00:03:27.860
So, that does make a little
bit of sense I suppose.

67
00:03:27.860 --> 00:03:30.380
More sense would be not to use this, but
to use something else for load balancing,

68
00:03:30.380 --> 00:03:31.610
but we'll set that aside.

69
00:03:31.610 --> 00:03:37.080
So we've got a key-chain to find, and
the key-chain is called HSRP-AUTH.

70
00:03:37.080 --> 00:03:41.910
And so if I do a show running config,
we can find that key-chain.

71
00:03:41.910 --> 00:03:44.836
And what I need to note in the key chain,

72
00:03:44.836 --> 00:03:48.670
here we go Is the key number and
key string, right.

73
00:03:48.670 --> 00:03:51.295
I've got key number 1, so
I don't have more than one key.

74
00:03:51.295 --> 00:03:54.212
And I've got a string of AUTHME.

75
00:03:54.212 --> 00:03:57.195
I'm gonna write that down too,
it's just all capitalized.

76
00:03:57.195 --> 00:04:00.170
A-U-T-H-M-E.

77
00:04:00.170 --> 00:04:00.797
AUTHME.

78
00:04:00.797 --> 00:04:02.610
Got it.
All right,

79
00:04:02.610 --> 00:04:06.060
the reason I'm writing that down, is I
need to make sure that the password's set

80
00:04:06.060 --> 00:04:08.780
the same on the other side or
this is all gonna fail.

81
00:04:08.780 --> 00:04:10.290
So then I'm gonna jump over to EDGE2.

82
00:04:10.290 --> 00:04:13.810
And we'll kind of just repeat
the same process over hear on EDGE2.

83
00:04:13.810 --> 00:04:16.910
I'm gonna do a show standby brief

84
00:04:18.320 --> 00:04:22.210
just to make sure the interface number
is the same and it is, Gi0/1 is Grp 100.

85
00:04:22.210 --> 00:04:30.090
And if I do a show run int gi0/1 Oh, and
I can see that it was active up there.

86
00:04:30.090 --> 00:04:32.740
That was the other thing, is we need
to make sure they were both active.

87
00:04:32.740 --> 00:04:35.940
And I can see that this one's
actually .11 for its unique IP, so

88
00:04:35.940 --> 00:04:37.250
I'm just gonna write that down.

89
00:04:38.450 --> 00:04:42.970
And I've got a standby IP that's that
virtual IP, I've got preemption turned on.

90
00:04:42.970 --> 00:04:45.120
No priority defined, so
this guy is a priority of 100 also.

91
00:04:45.120 --> 00:04:49.090
That means if there's a tie, and
since preemption is turned on,

92
00:04:49.090 --> 00:04:52.140
this one's gonna boil down to Mac
address as it kind of negotiates

93
00:04:52.140 --> 00:04:55.660
who's gonna be the winner on this one,
to determine who's gonna pick it up.

94
00:04:55.660 --> 00:05:00.597
I see that authentication is turned on,
and it's got HSRP-AUTH as that key chain.

95
00:05:00.597 --> 00:05:03.080
The key chain name doesn't have to match.

96
00:05:03.080 --> 00:05:06.080
I just needed to make sure that
there was a key chain, and so

97
00:05:06.080 --> 00:05:10.920
I just need to verify that key chain
actually has a matching password.

98
00:05:10.920 --> 00:05:17.400
And so I'll do a show running-config,
and I'll find that key chain.

99
00:05:17.400 --> 00:05:18.560
Here it is.

100
00:05:18.560 --> 00:05:20.800
Oh, well, this is gonna turn
out to be another easy problem.

101
00:05:20.800 --> 00:05:23.500
And I can see right here, the key chain.

102
00:05:23.500 --> 00:05:25.560
Has a wrong password, right?

103
00:05:25.560 --> 00:05:28.890
It's AUTHM3 instead of AUTHME.

104
00:05:28.890 --> 00:05:31.980
If the password doesn't match,
this is going to fail, right?

105
00:05:31.980 --> 00:05:35.320
So pretty easy to jump in here and
spot that, now we need to fix that, so

106
00:05:35.320 --> 00:05:39.825
I'm going to jump into configuration and
I'll say key chain

107
00:05:39.825 --> 00:05:44.770
HSRP-AUTH, that's the name
of the key chain.

108
00:05:44.770 --> 00:05:46.050
And I'm gonna say no key 1.

109
00:05:46.050 --> 00:05:50.630
And then I'm gonna recreate key 1, so
I need to get back into my key chain.

110
00:05:50.630 --> 00:05:53.550
Since that was the only key,
it just kicked me out of the key chain.

111
00:05:53.550 --> 00:05:55.040
So I'm gonna get back into it.

112
00:05:55.040 --> 00:05:59.710
And I'll do key 1, key-string and

113
00:05:59.710 --> 00:06:05.120
then I'm gonna give it AUTHME so
it matches the other side.

114
00:06:05.120 --> 00:06:09.590
All right, now, HSRP will likely
correct itself and come up

115
00:06:09.590 --> 00:06:13.700
here on it's own in a few moments, but if
you get impatient like I do, sometimes it

116
00:06:13.700 --> 00:06:17.490
helps to just shut the interface down, and
wait a second and then turn it back on.

117
00:06:17.490 --> 00:06:21.780
That'll kind of give HSRP a kick in the
butt and make it renegotiate right away.

118
00:06:21.780 --> 00:06:25.070
If you're trying to avoid down time that's
a bad idea, but we probably already have

119
00:06:25.070 --> 00:06:27.930
down time right now anyway cuz we have
two systems active for the same IP.

120
00:06:29.110 --> 00:06:29.837
All right.

121
00:06:29.837 --> 00:06:33.293
Hopefully this will resolve the
authentication issue, then the two devices

122
00:06:33.293 --> 00:06:37.160
should see each other, and one should go
active, and the other should go stand-by.

123
00:06:37.160 --> 00:06:39.620
I don't know which one because I
haven't looked at MAC addresses yet

124
00:06:39.620 --> 00:06:41.760
but that's hopefully what we'll see.

125
00:06:41.760 --> 00:06:42.640
All right.

126
00:06:42.640 --> 00:06:46.837
That might not be our only problem but
it certainly was a problem.

127
00:06:46.837 --> 00:06:48.650
Now we resolved it and
we should be good there.

128
00:06:48.650 --> 00:06:51.341
Now, what I was actually setting out to do
when I came over here before we stumbled

129
00:06:51.341 --> 00:06:53.258
on that problem,
is I was just gonna test connectivity.

130
00:06:53.258 --> 00:06:58.360
This guy is 172.14.0.11 and

131
00:06:58.360 --> 00:07:03.480
the other switch is 172.14.0.

132
00:07:03.480 --> 00:07:04.770
10.
And so

133
00:07:04.770 --> 00:07:07.350
I was just gonna see if I could
ping across to the other guy.

134
00:07:07.350 --> 00:07:09.920
If I can't ping across, then I'm not
gonna be able to communicate at all.

135
00:07:09.920 --> 00:07:12.320
But I can see that I am
able to ping across.

136
00:07:12.320 --> 00:07:14.000
Sometimes you might wanna
be careful with this ping,

137
00:07:14.000 --> 00:07:15.980
cuz you have a virtual IP in the mix.

138
00:07:15.980 --> 00:07:20.580
And so you might wanna specify a source
for where to ping it from, and

139
00:07:20.580 --> 00:07:24.880
give it the particular IP address,
instead of relying on the interface.

140
00:07:24.880 --> 00:07:29.176
So if I wanted to try and ping from
172.14.0.11, or if I wanted to ping

141
00:07:29.176 --> 00:07:33.680
from the virtual IP,
I could try it that way.

142
00:07:33.680 --> 00:07:34.960
So source is kind of helpful.

143
00:07:34.960 --> 00:07:37.920
And that's what I had intended to
do when I came over to this router.

144
00:07:37.920 --> 00:07:39.660
But we may have already found the problem.

145
00:07:39.660 --> 00:07:44.645
So let's go ahead and
take a look at show standby for gi0/1, and

146
00:07:44.645 --> 00:07:47.504
I can see that my state is now standby.

147
00:07:47.504 --> 00:07:50.660
The active router is 172.14.0.10.

148
00:07:50.660 --> 00:07:52.920
The standby router is local.

149
00:07:52.920 --> 00:07:55.970
