That's me and now it looks like
things are working properly.

150
00:07:55.970 --> 00:07:59.504
If I jump over NYEDGE1 I can verify
that it's seeing the same thing.

151
00:08:01.940 --> 00:08:04.920
And so I'll pull up that show standby.

152
00:08:04.920 --> 00:08:05.570
And i'll look at that one.

153
00:08:05.570 --> 00:08:09.660
I can see that it is active and
it's got a standby router of .11.

154
00:08:09.660 --> 00:08:12.580
So in this case it looks like
we just had a bad password.

155
00:08:12.580 --> 00:08:13.920
Pretty easy to spot that one.

156
00:08:13.920 --> 00:08:15.070
Get it resolved.

157
00:08:15.070 --> 00:08:15.711
And now it's up an running.

158
00:08:15.711 --> 00:08:19.470
So HHRP is safe once more and
we can move onto our next issue.

159
00:08:19.470 --> 00:08:20.530
Hope you guys enjoyed it.

160
00:08:20.530 --> 00:08:24.045
Stay tuned.
We've got issue six coming up next.

161
00:08:24.045 --> 00:08:30.299
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #6` from set #4. The trouble ticket states that "NYEDGE1 and NYEDGE2 are not forming an OSPF adjacency between them. "
episodes.title: Set 4 Issue 6
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.782
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.782 --> 00:00:09.500
All right.

3
00:00:09.500 --> 00:00:13.790
For Issue 6, it looks like we're
gonna move away from HSRP and

4
00:00:13.790 --> 00:00:16.120
get a chance to look
at some OSPF problems.

5
00:00:16.120 --> 00:00:19.981
So, our troubleshooting ticket for
Issue 6 is NYEDGE1 and

6
00:00:19.981 --> 00:00:23.790
NYEDGE2 are not forming an OSPF
adjacency between them.

7
00:00:23.790 --> 00:00:26.290
So, OSPF's not happy, let's find out why.

8
00:00:26.290 --> 00:00:29.760
Now if we look at our topology,
NYEDGE1 and NYEDGE2,

9
00:00:29.760 --> 00:00:33.320
they've got a dedicated serial
link between each other.

10
00:00:33.320 --> 00:00:37.060
So an OSPF adjacency should be
pretty easy to build, right?

11
00:00:37.060 --> 00:00:39.430
As long as these networks
are a part of the OSPF process,

12
00:00:39.430 --> 00:00:43.050
they should see each other, and we should
have a neighbor relationship built up.

13
00:00:43.050 --> 00:00:47.580
If not, we may still have an adjacency
through other means, right?

14
00:00:47.580 --> 00:00:50.850
EDGE1 is connected to OSPF Area 0.

15
00:00:50.850 --> 00:00:52.190
EDGE2 is connected to OSPF Area 0.

16
00:00:52.190 --> 00:00:55.530
They should be able to see each
other through these other links, and

17
00:00:55.530 --> 00:00:57.620
we can learn the routes
through our neighbors, right?

18
00:00:57.620 --> 00:01:00.510
So, there should be plenty of different
ways that we can see that that

19
00:01:00.510 --> 00:01:01.810
router exists.

20
00:01:01.810 --> 00:01:04.450
Worst case scenario,
we could go across the WAN link here, but

21
00:01:04.450 --> 00:01:06.010
I doubt that's gonna be configured.

22
00:01:06.010 --> 00:01:08.680
I'm gonna start with this serial link
cuz that should be the most obvious.

23
00:01:08.680 --> 00:01:11.410
Now at a minimum, we should have
a neighbor relationship there.

24
00:01:11.410 --> 00:01:14.330
And if we don't, well,
we can just create one,

25
00:01:14.330 --> 00:01:16.560
and that'll probably solve this
problem and we'll be done.

26
00:01:16.560 --> 00:01:18.200
So, I'm gonna start over on NYEDGE1,

27
00:01:18.200 --> 00:01:21.592
and the first thing I wanna do is
just verify OSPF's configuration.

28
00:01:21.592 --> 00:01:24.650
So, on EDGE1, I guess

29
00:01:25.680 --> 00:01:29.260
the first thing I really need to know are
what the IP address are on these systems.

30
00:01:29.260 --> 00:01:31.470
With OSPF, it can be a little
hard to troubleshoot sometimes.

31
00:01:31.470 --> 00:01:36.540
Cuz if you do like a show ip ospf
neighbor, you see your neighbors.

32
00:01:36.540 --> 00:01:40.000
But if you don't know the router ID for
each neighbor,

33
00:01:40.000 --> 00:01:41.480
it gets to be a little bit challenging.

34
00:01:41.480 --> 00:01:46.230
So I see that I've got
a relationship with 192.168.255.2.

35
00:01:46.230 --> 00:01:47.460
Who is that?

36
00:01:47.460 --> 00:01:49.000
I don't really know, okay.

37
00:01:49.000 --> 00:01:53.320
So what I'm going to do is on NYEDGE1,
I'm going to do a show ip protocols.

38
00:01:55.080 --> 00:01:57.490
And I'm gonna look for
my OSPF configuration, and

39
00:01:57.490 --> 00:01:59.450
remember you might be running
more than one protocol.

40
00:01:59.450 --> 00:02:01.610
I can see here's the IGRP.

41
00:02:01.610 --> 00:02:05.550
And then after that I've got OSPF, here we
go, so OSPF 100, and what I'm looking for

42
00:02:05.550 --> 00:02:06.830
is my router ID.

43
00:02:06.830 --> 00:02:09.690
And I'm gonna take my best
troubleshooting tool, this pen, and

44
00:02:09.690 --> 00:02:11.359
I'm gonna write down that router ID.

45
00:02:11.359 --> 00:02:19.140
So, EDGE1 has a router
ID of 192.168.255.4.

46
00:02:19.140 --> 00:02:20.100
All right.

47
00:02:20.100 --> 00:02:22.520
And then I'm gonna jump over to EDGE2,
the one

48
00:02:22.520 --> 00:02:26.140
we're supposed to be forming an adjacency
with, and I'm gonna do the same thing.

49
00:02:26.140 --> 00:02:28.460
Just to show ip protocols.

50
00:02:28.460 --> 00:02:32.220
And if I spell it right, we'll
actually get the output that we want.

51
00:02:32.220 --> 00:02:39.470
And there's OSPF 100, and
I can see my router ID is 192.168.255.2.

52
00:02:39.470 --> 00:02:43.210
So now what that information does

53
00:02:43.210 --> 00:02:48.010
is it gives me the router IDs so
that when I jump back over to NYEDGE1.

54
00:02:48.010 --> 00:02:53.170
And I run that show ip ospf neighbor,

55
00:02:54.170 --> 00:02:57.410
now I see that I've got
a neighbor of 192.168.255.2.

56
00:02:57.410 --> 00:03:00.380
And I know that that's EDGE2, all right?

57
00:03:00.380 --> 00:03:03.430
So, I'm not forming
an adjacency with EDGE2.

58
00:03:03.430 --> 00:03:05.365
It could be connectivity, right?

59
00:03:05.365 --> 00:03:07.460
I could have a bad connection
to the other side, but

60
00:03:07.460 --> 00:03:12.330
in this case,
what I see is the state as initializing.

61
00:03:12.330 --> 00:03:15.520
And I see that router ID right there,
now that's interesting.

62
00:03:15.520 --> 00:03:17.359
What this is gonna tell
me is one of two things.

63
00:03:17.359 --> 00:03:21.208
Either one, I've statically defined a
neighbor, and that's how I know about it.

64
00:03:21.208 --> 00:03:24.460
But I've got a connectivity issue,
and I can't see them.

65
00:03:24.460 --> 00:03:28.950
Or two, I do have connectivity with
that router, I am able to see it, but

66
00:03:28.950 --> 00:03:32.120
I'm not just building
the rest of the adjacency.

67
00:03:32.120 --> 00:03:35.630
Okay, so what the heck is going on there?

68
00:03:35.630 --> 00:03:37.615
And we could do debugs on this and
try and find it.

69
00:03:37.615 --> 00:03:39.720
But let's just start by
looking at the configuration.

70
00:03:39.720 --> 00:03:42.070
Maybe we can save digging
through a bunch of debug output.

71
00:03:42.070 --> 00:03:45.330
On the exam, debug output just takes
a long time to read through, so

72
00:03:45.330 --> 00:03:47.720
any time we can avoid that we should.

73
00:03:47.720 --> 00:03:51.960
I know that I've got OSPF configured so
I'm gonna do a show run.

74
00:03:51.960 --> 00:03:54.050
And I'm just gonna begin on
the first line with OSPF and

75
00:03:54.050 --> 00:03:56.210
kind of take a look at
what I've got on here.

76
00:03:56.210 --> 00:04:00.400
So here I've got Router OSPF100,
we're doing some route redistribution.

77
00:04:00.400 --> 00:04:02.990
I've got network
192.168.255.0 configured so

78
00:04:02.990 --> 00:04:08.150
the serial interface is
in the OSPF process.

79
00:04:08.150 --> 00:04:12.780
It's set for area 0, and what I'm looking
for are things that might be a problem.

80
00:04:12.780 --> 00:04:15.690
Like hello and
dead intervals that might not match,

81
00:04:15.690 --> 00:04:17.780
or area numbers that might not match.

82
00:04:17.780 --> 00:04:20.910
Authentication that's turned
on that might be blocking this

83
00:04:20.910 --> 00:04:21.790
adjacency from building up.

84
00:04:21.790 --> 00:04:23.510
Those are all different
things that I'm looking for.

85
00:04:23.510 --> 00:04:25.345
I don't really care about redistributes,

86
00:04:25.345 --> 00:04:28.970
cuz that's not gonna stop
an adjacency from building, right?

87
00:04:28.970 --> 00:04:31.930
I'm looking for statically defined
neighbors, which I don't see any.

88
00:04:31.930 --> 00:04:35.650
And I really need to look at that
interface which, what interface was that?

89
00:04:35.650 --> 00:04:36.650
It was Serial0/0/0.

90
00:04:36.650 --> 00:04:39.880
So I need to look at that interface and
make sure that it's okay.

91
00:04:42.356 --> 00:04:45.450
And so far I'm seeing just normal stuff.

92
00:04:45.450 --> 00:04:48.890
Looks like I do have PPP authentication,
but

93
00:04:48.890 --> 00:04:51.050
if that fails,
the line itself won't come up.

94
00:04:51.050 --> 00:04:54.360
And I see this neighbor,
at least I think I see the neighbor.

95
00:04:54.360 --> 00:04:56.790
And so I don't think that's the case.

96
00:04:56.790 --> 00:05:02.280
Now, I could try and
ping across the line, I'm 192.168.255.1.

97
00:05:02.280 --> 00:05:07.470
On the other side, because it's a slash 30
network, I know that it has to be dot two.

98
00:05:07.470 --> 00:05:13.207
So if I ping 192.168.255.2,
do I have connectivity to it, okay?

99
00:05:13.207 --> 00:05:17.710
And I'm gonna try and ping it,
and that's interesting.

100
00:05:17.710 --> 00:05:19.560
I'm getting a destination unreachable.

101
00:05:19.560 --> 00:05:23.360
Now unreachable is an odd one,
cuz it normally means that

102
00:05:23.360 --> 00:05:26.120
I didn't have a direct connection so
I went through some kind of router.

103
00:05:26.120 --> 00:05:27.270
Well, I am the router.

104
00:05:27.270 --> 00:05:30.670
And so that means that I didn't
have a route to get there.

105
00:05:30.670 --> 00:05:31.740
Well, that's odd.

106
00:05:31.740 --> 00:05:33.380
I'm directly connected, aren't I?

107
00:05:33.380 --> 00:05:40.550
If I do a show ip route, 192.168.255.2,
I've got a route for it.

108
00:05:40.550 --> 00:05:42.430
And it says I'm directly connected, so

109
00:05:42.430 --> 00:05:45.030
I should be able to cross
right over that link.

110
00:05:45.030 --> 00:05:48.407
And I'm directly connected
via Serial0/0/0.

111
00:05:48.407 --> 00:05:50.215
I should be good, right?

112
00:05:50.215 --> 00:05:52.550
That interface is up, isn't it?

113
00:05:52.550 --> 00:05:56.670
If I do a show ip interface brief,
that interface should be up.

114
00:05:56.670 --> 00:05:58.420
If it were down I wouldn't see the route.

115
00:05:58.420 --> 00:06:01.760
And so here it is,
I kinda see it in my list.

116
00:06:01.760 --> 00:06:04.310
And if I look at its status
it's showing as up up.

117
00:06:05.610 --> 00:06:08.520
So it's up up, but I can't ping across it?

118
00:06:08.520 --> 00:06:11.740
That really does seem odd, so
let's look at that configuration again.

119
00:06:13.490 --> 00:06:14.060
Serial0/0/0.

120
00:06:14.060 --> 00:06:20.315
And it is 192.168.255.1 is my IP,
and I've got that subnet mask.

121
00:06:20.315 --> 00:06:23.580
I'm gonna check the other side, make
sure they've got the same subnet mask.

122
00:06:23.580 --> 00:06:26.265
I also need to verify that
my authentication is good.

123
00:06:26.265 --> 00:06:28.580
Now, I'm certain
the authentication is good,

124
00:06:28.580 --> 00:06:31.820
because if it isn't,
the interface would be up down, right?

125
00:06:31.820 --> 00:06:34.730
So, in this case it's up up so
it should be fine.

126
00:06:34.730 --> 00:06:36.850
But you can see my username and password.

127
00:06:36.850 --> 00:06:41.910
And I just need to verify that username
is actually set with a password of cisco,

128
00:06:41.910 --> 00:06:42.910
which it is.

129
00:06:42.910 --> 00:06:45.010
And then I'll go double
check the other side.

130
00:06:45.010 --> 00:06:46.989
So I'm gonna jump over to EDGE2.

131
00:06:46.989 --> 00:06:51.770
And I'm gonna run through that same
troubleshooting process I just did

132
00:06:51.770 --> 00:06:54.700
on EDGE1 to basically verify this guy.

133
00:06:54.700 --> 00:06:58.217
So I want to do a show int s0/0/0.

134
00:07:00.140 --> 00:07:02.520
Oops, well I guess I can start here.

135
00:07:02.520 --> 00:07:06.980
I meant to do a show running config,
but I can see that it's up up.

136
00:07:06.980 --> 00:07:09.610
I can get that information while
I'm in here, so that looks fine.

137
00:07:09.610 --> 00:07:13.770
And I don't see any crazy input errors,
so that's fine.

138
00:07:13.770 --> 00:07:20.036
If I do a show running-config s0/0/0 or

139
00:07:20.036 --> 00:07:23.970
int s0/0/0, I can look at the config.

140
00:07:23.970 --> 00:07:25.450
And I see it's 192.168.255.2,

141
00:07:25.450 --> 00:07:30.500
which is what I want with
a subnet mask that's correct.

142
00:07:30.500 --> 00:07:34.400
I've got PPP and CHAP,
I think I might see what our issue is.

143
00:07:34.400 --> 00:07:38.460
I see PPP and CHAP are turned on,
it's got cisco as that password.

144
00:07:38.460 --> 00:07:39.940
And if I do a show run and

145
00:07:39.940 --> 00:07:44.100
include username,
I can verify that password is cisco also.

146
00:07:44.100 --> 00:07:46.480
So authentication looks like it's good and
set up there.

147
00:07:46.480 --> 00:07:50.000
But I got this one extra
line creeping up right here.

148
00:07:50.000 --> 00:07:52.560
Looks like there's an access
list on the interface, okay.

149
00:07:52.560 --> 00:07:55.330
So, I've got an access group
that's saying LIMITWAN in, so

150
00:07:55.330 --> 00:07:57.510
there's an incoming ACL here.

151
00:07:57.510 --> 00:08:02.330
If you ever have an interface that's up,
like mine is, and you start doing pings

152
00:08:02.330 --> 00:08:05.705
and other things and it's not working and
you're kind of scratching your head.

153
00:08:05.705 --> 00:08:08.520
ACLs are a great way to
interfere with traffic.

154
00:08:08.520 --> 00:08:10.760
So it could be that the interface
is up and happy, but

155
00:08:10.760 --> 00:08:12.000
we're blocking traffic on it.

156
00:08:12.000 --> 00:08:14.000
Which is why I would get
those unreachable messages,

157
00:08:14.000 --> 00:08:18.670
or why I think the interface looks
good but I'm not able to communicate.

158
00:08:18.670 --> 00:08:21.750
So let's take a look at that ACL and
see if we can figure out what it is or

159
00:08:21.750 --> 00:08:22.940
what it's doing.

160
00:08:22.940 --> 00:08:25.010
So I'm gonna do a show access-list.

161
00:08:25.010 --> 00:08:26.880
And here's the LIMITWAN ACL.

162
00:08:26.880 --> 00:08:28.730
Now going back to my diagram,

163
00:08:28.730 --> 00:08:33.000
this is incoming traffic
on Serial0/0/0 right here.

164
00:08:33.000 --> 00:08:35.400
So when I did a ping
from EDGE1 over to EDGE2,

165
00:08:35.400 --> 00:08:38.560
it was incoming on this interface and
it died.

166
00:08:38.560 --> 00:08:42.030
And my neighbor relationship,
I see the other router, so

167
00:08:42.030 --> 00:08:44.130
it might be advertising to me.

168
00:08:44.130 --> 00:08:48.190
But then when I try and
go two-way with it, it fails, right?

169
00:08:48.190 --> 00:08:51.880
I stay in init, I never go to two-way
which means I never get to x-start.

170
00:08:51.880 --> 00:08:56.100
Which means I never get to a full
adjacency, the OSPF negotiation process.

171
00:08:56.100 --> 00:09:00.754
So it might be that I can't talk to it but
it's talking to me and ACL can do that, so

172
00:09:00.754 --> 00:09:03.480
let's see if this one is doing it.

173
00:09:03.480 --> 00:09:08.400
So looking at the ACL here, we've got
that we're permitting some TCP traffic

174
00:09:08.400 --> 00:09:12.508
from a particular address 100.10.40.0.

175
00:09:12.508 --> 00:09:13.870
I'm going to skip that line.

176
00:09:13.870 --> 00:09:15.740
Remember that NYEDGE1 is 192.168.255.1 so

177
00:09:15.740 --> 00:09:21.750
any line that doesn't match that I
really don't care about right now.

178
00:09:21.750 --> 00:09:24.160
So I see I'm permitting some other host.

179
00:09:24.160 --> 00:09:28.100
I'm permitting another host,
another host, nothing too exciting here.

180
00:09:28.100 --> 00:09:31.730
Oh, these are promising, line 60 and 70.

181
00:09:31.730 --> 00:09:37.420
Permit ip host 224.0.0.5 to any.

182
00:09:37.420 --> 00:09:40.202
And permit ip host 224.0.0.6 to any.

183
00:09:40.202 --> 00:09:42.320
Why is that interesting?

184
00:09:42.320 --> 00:09:46.450
Well OSPF uses multicast to
communicate between routers and

185
00:09:46.450 --> 00:09:49.930
it uses 224.0.0.5 and .6.

186
00:09:49.930 --> 00:09:54.620
It uses one to talk to any old
neighbor for routing updates, and

187
00:09:54.620 --> 00:09:58.330
it uses the other for
talking to a designated router.

188
00:09:58.330 --> 00:10:01.977
If you're on a multiaccess network
you'll have a DR and a BDR.

189
00:10:01.977 --> 00:10:06.330
And you talk to the DR and the BDR through
their dedicated multicast address.

190
00:10:06.330 --> 00:10:08.460
So there's the multicast addresses for
OSPF.

191
00:10:08.460 --> 00:10:09.990
And I can see they're being allowed.

192
00:10:09.990 --> 00:10:13.290
I'm permitting that OSPF
traffic to go through, right?

193
00:10:13.290 --> 00:10:15.590
Well, not so much.

194
00:10:15.590 --> 00:10:19.660
If I was, I would see some match
commands over here, or match numbers.

195
00:10:19.660 --> 00:10:21.210
And I don't.
See down here on the deny,

196
00:10:21.210 --> 00:10:24.320
deny ip any any, 847 matches.

197
00:10:24.320 --> 00:10:26.720
It's blocking a lot of
traffic on this link, but

198
00:10:26.720 --> 00:10:29.660
these permits aren't matching anything.

199
00:10:29.660 --> 00:10:30.470
Why is that?

200
00:10:30.470 --> 00:10:33.360
If I know that OSPF is using
these multicast addresses,

201
00:10:33.360 --> 00:10:35.040
shouldn't I see some matches here?

202
00:10:35.040 --> 00:10:39.890
Well, when you say permit IP,
Cisco gets really literal.

203
00:10:39.890 --> 00:10:44.250
They're actually talking
about standard IP traffic.

204
00:10:44.250 --> 00:10:50.450
OSPF is an IP routing protocol, and Cisco
doesn't count that as standard IP traffic.

205
00:10:50.450 --> 00:10:54.940
So while this line looks right,
it's actually not right.

206
00:10:54.940 --> 00:10:57.000
It's not matching that OSPF traffic.

207
00:10:57.000 --> 00:10:59.300
And we actually have
a different command we can use.

208
00:10:59.300 --> 00:11:03.570
We can say permit OSPF host blah,
blah, blah.

209
00:11:03.570 --> 00:11:09.260
You can permit OSPF specifically, and
that is what we have to do, not IP.

210
00:11:09.260 --> 00:11:12.199
So these two lines look right,
but they're actually not.

211
00:11:12.199 --> 00:11:16.931
And this next line,
permit ip 224.0.0.0 0.0.0.225,

212
00:11:16.931 --> 00:11:20.860
that's permitting all sorts
of multicast addresses.

213
00:11:20.860 --> 00:11:23.874
But again, no matches on it,
it's not working.

214
00:11:23.874 --> 00:11:28.960
So OSPF is being blocked, ping is
kind of falling into this same range.

215
00:11:28.960 --> 00:11:33.520
I can do permit ICMP blah, blah,
blah, to allow ping through, and

216
00:11:33.520 --> 00:11:36.320
that's not done on any of these, right?

217
00:11:36.320 --> 00:11:41.460
Now, a permit ip any any will actually
include ICMP, Cisco does that.

218
00:11:41.460 --> 00:11:45.430
But I've just got a deny ip any any,
and it's logging it which is good.

219
00:11:45.430 --> 00:11:48.560
So, I should be able to look in the logs
and see what's being blocked, right?

220
00:11:48.560 --> 00:11:52.360
So if I do a show log and
kinda jump down to the end of it,

221
00:11:52.360 --> 00:11:54.816
which I'm gonna have 847 entries.

222
00:11:54.816 --> 00:11:59.360
We got some HSRP authentication errors,

223
00:11:59.360 --> 00:12:01.809
which was a previous
troubleshooting problem.

224
00:12:01.809 --> 00:12:05.790
But as I look down here I can
start to see where here's

225
00:12:05.790 --> 00:12:10.090
that access list LIMITWAN denied ospf,
denied icmp.

226
00:12:10.090 --> 00:12:12.220
See how they're being treated separately?

227
00:12:12.220 --> 00:12:16.840
It's not blocking IP,
it's blocking OSPF, it's blocking ICMP.

228
00:12:16.840 --> 00:12:18.810
So I need to fix that to allow it through.

229
00:12:18.810 --> 00:12:22.640
Now, technically I don't need to fix ICMP,
that's not what my problem is.

230
00:12:22.640 --> 00:12:25.550
The troubleshooting ticket
specifically just says OSPF.

231
00:12:25.550 --> 00:12:27.470
So I need to fix that, all right.

232
00:12:27.470 --> 00:12:31.400
So if I do a show access-list,

233
00:12:31.400 --> 00:12:34.068
I need to take lines 60 and
70 and get them out of there.

234
00:12:34.068 --> 00:12:38.400
Now line 80, I don't know if
that one needs to stay or not.

235
00:12:38.400 --> 00:12:41.280
Line 80, that might be applying to
some other multicast traffic for

236
00:12:41.280 --> 00:12:43.410
some other program, so
I'm gonna leave it alone.

237
00:12:43.410 --> 00:12:46.780
But line 60 and 70 specifically apply
to OSPF and they're just wrong.

238
00:12:46.780 --> 00:12:47.730
So I'm gonna get rid of them, and

239
00:12:47.730 --> 00:12:52.150
I'm gonna replace them with
a line that will work for OSPF.

240
00:12:52.150 --> 00:12:54.919
So, I'm gonna get into my configuration,
and we'll get that set.

241
00:12:54.919 --> 00:12:58.869
So I'll start by saying ip

242
00:12:58.869 --> 00:13:04.265
access-list extended LIMITWAN.

243
00:13:04.265 --> 00:13:11.270
And then I'm gonna do a no 60 and a no 70,
I'm just gonna wipe those two lines out.

244
00:13:11.270 --> 00:13:16.250
And I'm gonna put in a new line 60,
where I will permit ospf.

245
00:13:16.250 --> 00:13:21.710
And then I could say a particular host or
whatever if I wanted to.

246
00:13:21.710 --> 00:13:23.880
But the reality is this
is a point to point link.

247
00:13:23.880 --> 00:13:26.352
So I'm just gonna say,
permit ospf any any, right?

248
00:13:26.352 --> 00:13:30.010
I don't need to get any more specific
than that cuz it's point to point.

249
00:13:30.010 --> 00:13:31.840
And there's nobody else on
the other end of the line.

250
00:13:31.840 --> 00:13:34.768
And that should match the OSPF traffic.

251
00:13:34.768 --> 00:13:39.740
Now, the ticket's not asking me to do it,
but if I really wanted to I could do

252
00:13:39.740 --> 00:13:44.180
a 70 permit icmp any any, and
that would let my pings go through.

253
00:13:44.180 --> 00:13:47.120
On the exam I wouldn't do that,
because it's not asking me to fix that.

254
00:13:47.120 --> 00:13:48.820
I don't want to do more than I have to.

255
00:13:48.820 --> 00:13:50.000
But in real life I probably would.

256
00:13:50.000 --> 00:13:52.720
So I'll go ahead and put that in there,
just so I can test the link and

257
00:13:52.720 --> 00:13:53.610
make sure that it's working.

258
00:13:54.820 --> 00:13:56.870
Now that that's done,
I can jump back to EDGE1.

259
00:13:58.018 --> 00:14:03.270
And on EDGE1 I can try and ping the other
side which wasn't working for me earlier.

260
00:14:04.510 --> 00:14:07.090
And now if I try and ping, it does.

261
00:14:07.090 --> 00:14:11.660
And if I do a show ip opsf neighbor,
I saw the neighbor earlier,

262
00:14:11.660 --> 00:14:15.060
it's just stuck in the init state,
now it's gone full.

263
00:14:15.060 --> 00:14:17.284
So in this case it looks like that
access list was what was blocking us.

264
00:14:17.284 --> 00:14:19.890
Now that that's fixed, we're in business.

265
00:14:19.890 --> 00:14:21.070
So we just had to remember,

266
00:14:21.070 --> 00:14:25.560
hey, it's great that they approved
those multicast addresses specifically.

267
00:14:25.560 --> 00:14:27.310
But ACLs don't treat OSPF that way, and

268
00:14:27.310 --> 00:14:29.650
they don't treat the other routing
protocols that way either.

269
00:14:29.650 --> 00:14:33.890
EIGRP, RIP, BGP,
they all have access list names,

270
00:14:33.890 --> 00:14:36.770
protocol names that you can use, and
you need to to allow them through.

271
00:14:36.770 --> 00:14:39.670
Once that was fixed, now we've got
our adjacency and we're in business.

272
00:14:39.670 --> 00:14:42.310
So troubleshooting ticket number six,
resolved.

273
00:14:42.310 --> 00:14:43.750
Put a check mark on it.

274
00:14:43.750 --> 00:14:45.755
And we're ready to move
on to number seven.

275
00:14:45.755 --> 00:14:53.759
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #7` from set #4. The trouble ticket states that "You are unable to ping 172.16.16.1 from PLABCSCO01 "
episodes.title: Set 4 Issue 7
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:04.796
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.796 --> 00:00:13.130
In this video,
we're gonna take a look at Set 4 Issue 7.

3
00:00:13.130 --> 00:00:16.129
And it looks like we've got a reachability
issue on this one, those are always fun.

4
00:00:16.129 --> 00:00:19.678
The troubleshooting
ticket reads like this,

5
00:00:19.678 --> 00:00:25.504
it says you are unable to ping
172.16.16.1 from PLABCSCO01.

6
00:00:25.504 --> 00:00:28.284
Well, before we dive into troubleshooting
that, let's look at our topology and

7
00:00:28.284 --> 00:00:30.110
get a handle on what we're talking about.

8
00:00:30.110 --> 00:00:35.795
The server in question is our good old
trusty PLABCSCO01 right down here,

9
00:00:35.795 --> 00:00:40.410
192.168.16.10, and
the network in question that we're

10
00:00:40.410 --> 00:00:45.750
trying to get to is 172.16.16.1,
which is this guy right up here.

11
00:00:45.750 --> 00:00:48.346
And in fact,
if you remember from the previous sets,

12
00:00:48.346 --> 00:00:55.010
172.16.16.1 is actually
the external IP of NYWAN1.

13
00:00:55.010 --> 00:00:59.440
So it's saying that I'm crossing my
network, jumping through all these devices

14
00:00:59.440 --> 00:01:02.880
on the way over, and I'm not able
to ping the external interface.

15
00:01:02.880 --> 00:01:06.260
Now, we've seen troubleshooting
tickets like this in other sets, and

16
00:01:06.260 --> 00:01:10.440
remember that there's more than one
possible cause for something like this.

17
00:01:10.440 --> 00:01:12.690
We could have access control
lists that are blocking us,

18
00:01:12.690 --> 00:01:15.095
we could have bad nat rolls in place,

19
00:01:15.095 --> 00:01:18.360
we could be missing routes,
we could have routes we shouldn't have,

20
00:01:18.360 --> 00:01:21.425
static routes go in the wrong direction,
we could have interfaces being down.

21
00:01:21.425 --> 00:01:24.600
There's a whole ton of things
that could cause a problem.

22
00:01:24.600 --> 00:01:28.520
And so, when I deal with a troubleshooting
issue like this, one that covers multiple

23
00:01:28.520 --> 00:01:31.950
devices, this is where I normally
start with that trace route.

24
00:01:31.950 --> 00:01:35.450
I do a trace route to find out
where my traffic stops, and

25
00:01:35.450 --> 00:01:38.720
then I can troubleshoot from there, and
kind of figure out where the problem is.

26
00:01:38.720 --> 00:01:39.862
So, let's do that.

27
00:01:39.862 --> 00:01:41.730
I'm gonna jump over to PLABCSCO01, and

28
00:01:41.730 --> 00:01:45.350
I'm gonna do a trace route to
the external IP on NYWAN1.

29
00:01:45.350 --> 00:01:46.680
And we'll see what happens.

30
00:01:46.680 --> 00:01:48.921
Actually, you know what,
I'm gonna backtrack.

31
00:01:48.921 --> 00:01:52.004
Just to be safe,
because we are in set number four,

32
00:01:52.004 --> 00:01:56.254
I wanna make sure that this
guy is actually 172.16.16.1.

33
00:01:56.254 --> 00:01:57.277
I'm pretty sure it is, but

34
00:01:57.277 --> 00:01:59.462
I'm gonna verify that first
before we do the trace route.

35
00:01:59.462 --> 00:02:03.993
So, let me jump over to NYWAN1,
and on this router,

36
00:02:03.993 --> 00:02:08.046
I'm just gonna do a quick show_ip_int_br.

37
00:02:08.046 --> 00:02:12.921
And I'm looking for that 172.16.16.1
address that's right there, so we're good.

38
00:02:12.921 --> 00:02:15.540
All right, now I'm gonna go do that
trace route I was talking about.

39
00:02:15.540 --> 00:02:19.480
So I'm gonna jump over to this Windows
server, and I'll just fire open a Cmd

40
00:02:19.480 --> 00:02:24.270
prompt here, and let's do a little trace
route action and see what we can find.

41
00:02:24.270 --> 00:02:29.870
So I'll do a quick trace
route to 172.16.16.1,

42
00:02:29.870 --> 00:02:32.080
and we're gonna see where it stops, right?

43
00:02:32.080 --> 00:02:34.420
It's gonna start passing
through our equipment and

44
00:02:34.420 --> 00:02:35.970
we'll see where our dead end is.

45
00:02:35.970 --> 00:02:38.620
The first hop should be my default
gateway, which is 192.168.16.1, but

46
00:02:38.620 --> 00:02:42.470
remember that's an HSRP address.

47
00:02:42.470 --> 00:02:46.850
So, what I'll see here is the unique
IP of the router that I got to,

48
00:02:46.850 --> 00:02:48.400
in this case is .3.

49
00:02:48.400 --> 00:02:49.550
That's NYCORE2.

50
00:02:49.550 --> 00:02:53.510
And then after that,
I get a response from 192.168.16.3,

51
00:02:53.510 --> 00:02:56.970
Destination host unreachable, all right.

52
00:02:58.130 --> 00:03:01.080
So, we stopped pretty
early in our journey.

53
00:03:01.080 --> 00:03:05.670
Basically, I jumped from my
server over to NYACCESS1, and

54
00:03:05.670 --> 00:03:08.670
from NYACCESS1 I jumped up to NYCORE2,
right?

55
00:03:08.670 --> 00:03:12.330
And then NYCORE2 is the one that
reported to me that it couldn't get to

56
00:03:12.330 --> 00:03:12.940
the destination.

57
00:03:12.940 --> 00:03:15.480
So that's where I'm gonna
start my examination.

58
00:03:15.480 --> 00:03:19.070
Now, understand that
when a trace route fails,

59
00:03:19.070 --> 00:03:21.630
it's really just narrowing
you down to two devices.

60
00:03:21.630 --> 00:03:25.980
Either the device it's stopped at or
whoever's the next hop.

61
00:03:25.980 --> 00:03:28.240
Well, I don't know who the next hop is for
NYCORE2.

62
00:03:28.240 --> 00:03:32.430
It could be to go up here to NYEDGE2 and
over that way.

63
00:03:32.430 --> 00:03:35.200
It could be that it goes
directly to NYEDGE1 and over.

64
00:03:35.200 --> 00:03:38.360
So, either of these edge
routers can be involved.

65
00:03:38.360 --> 00:03:40.190
So to make things easy,
I just won't pick either, [LAUGH] and

66
00:03:40.190 --> 00:03:43.500
I'll start with NYCORE2 and I'll look
there and see what I can find out, and

67
00:03:43.500 --> 00:03:45.240
we'll figure out the next hop from there.

68
00:03:45.240 --> 00:03:46.070
All right.
So

69
00:03:46.070 --> 00:03:51.020
I'll jump over to NYCORE2, and
we'll take a look at what's going on.

70
00:03:51.020 --> 00:03:53.220
It's saying,
Destination host unreachable, so

71
00:03:53.220 --> 00:03:55.380
that's kind of
an interesting error to get.

72
00:03:55.380 --> 00:03:58.879
It means that it had no way to get there,
right.

73
00:03:58.879 --> 00:04:03.567
So, on this guy,
if I do a show_ip_route for

74
00:04:03.567 --> 00:04:08.630
172.16.16.1, no network in table.

75
00:04:08.630 --> 00:04:12.794
So, my default gateway doesn't have
a route to get there, so traffic dies

76
00:04:12.794 --> 00:04:16.840
in line, I don't get anywhere,
unless I have a gateway of last resort.

77
00:04:16.840 --> 00:04:18.640
So let me do a show_ip_route and

78
00:04:18.640 --> 00:04:20.840
see if I have a gateway of last resort,
and I don't.

79
00:04:20.840 --> 00:04:25.850
Gateway of last resort not set, so I don't
have a route, this is where we stop.

80
00:04:25.850 --> 00:04:28.588
So remember how I said I don't
know who the next hop is?

81
00:04:28.588 --> 00:04:29.461
Well, I don't.

82
00:04:29.461 --> 00:04:32.744
I don't know who the next hop is, and I'm
not gonna find out from here either cuz

83
00:04:32.744 --> 00:04:35.270
this router doesn't know
who the next hop is either.

84
00:04:35.270 --> 00:04:37.820
So now I kind of have
to guess a little bit.

85
00:04:37.820 --> 00:04:40.070
So let's go back to the topology, and

86
00:04:40.070 --> 00:04:44.530
looking at the topology here,
who do we think the next hop should be?

87
00:04:44.530 --> 00:04:48.740
Well, I've got NYCORE2,
NYCORE1, and NYEDGE1.

88
00:04:48.740 --> 00:04:52.450
You will remember from the previous sets,
they're all running HSRP.

89
00:04:52.450 --> 00:04:57.129
They all have interfaces
on the 192.168.16 network.

90
00:04:57.129 --> 00:05:00.170
They've actually got interfaces
on several different VLANs.

91
00:05:00.170 --> 00:05:04.700
They should be seeing each other and
they should all be in OSPF Area 0.

92
00:05:04.700 --> 00:05:08.420
Assuming that's true,
they should be learning about

93
00:05:08.420 --> 00:05:13.720
the 172.16.16 network from NYEDGE1,
since it's sitting on the border.

94
00:05:13.720 --> 00:05:16.370
Regardless of whether I learned
it through EDGE2 like that or

95
00:05:16.370 --> 00:05:19.130
just straight from EDGE1,
which is how it should be, either way,

96
00:05:19.130 --> 00:05:21.710
I should be learning
that route from NYEDGE1.

97
00:05:21.710 --> 00:05:23.300
Let's see if NYEDGE1 has the route.

98
00:05:23.300 --> 00:05:25.170
Maybe it doesn't have the route either and

99
00:05:25.170 --> 00:05:26.970
we might need to go further
out of our networks.

100
00:05:26.970 --> 00:05:31.587
So I'm gonna jump to NYEDGE1, and
let's see what we've got there.

101
00:05:31.587 --> 00:05:37.587
So on NYEDGE1, I'm gonna start with just
show_ip_route for that missing network.

102

323
00:17:56.630 --> 00:18:00.670
in, right, these D EXs, those are ones
that are coming from an external source,

324
00:18:00.670 --> 00:18:03.310
and I see the ones that
are coming from my ISPs.

325
00:18:03.310 --> 00:18:07.910
When I look for 192.168 networks I
don't see any of those VLANs being

326
00:18:07.910 --> 00:18:12.750
represented here, you know the 192.168
.10, .11, .12 all the way through .16.

327
00:18:12.750 --> 00:18:18.530
None of those are being represented here
so they're not making it to this side.

328
00:18:18.530 --> 00:18:23.458
All right, so, let's go back and
jump back over to NYEDGE1 and

329
00:18:23.458 --> 00:18:27.120
we're just gonna revisit this guy.

330
00:18:27.120 --> 00:18:30.930
And when I look at its routing table,
I wanna make sure that it has routes for

331
00:18:30.930 --> 00:18:31.760
all of those networks.

332
00:18:31.760 --> 00:18:34.308
I'm pretty certain it does, but
it's a good idea to check and

333
00:18:34.308 --> 00:18:36.220
see if it's got all
those VLANs represented.

334
00:18:36.220 --> 00:18:40.333
And at a minimum, I see 192.168.10 right
there, but I see .11, .12, .13, 14,

335
00:18:40.333 --> 00:18:40.918
15, 16.

336
00:18:40.918 --> 00:18:43.900
They're all there, and

337
00:18:43.900 --> 00:18:49.221
they're all directly connected, all right?

338
00:18:49.221 --> 00:18:51.190
Now why is that important?

339
00:18:51.190 --> 00:18:53.570
Well, look at how we redistributed, right?

340
00:18:53.570 --> 00:18:57.100
Remember when I did
the show run section EIGRP,

341
00:18:57.100 --> 00:19:02.600
and I looked at EIGRP 500,
what were we redistributing?

342
00:19:02.600 --> 00:19:07.690
We were redistributing our OSPF routes,
OSPF 100 into EIGRP.

343
00:19:07.690 --> 00:19:13.810
And if I go out to my topology, OSPF
100 is the process but it's Area Zero.

344
00:19:13.810 --> 00:19:19.500
We're redistributing OSPF routes in the
EIGRP, but the administrative distance for

345
00:19:19.500 --> 00:19:23.330
our directly connected routes
is lower than the OSPF routes.

346
00:19:23.330 --> 00:19:25.810
OSPF routes have an admin distance of 110,

347
00:19:25.810 --> 00:19:28.930
directly connected has
an admin distance of one.

348
00:19:28.930 --> 00:19:30.670
So what makes it into the routing table?

349
00:19:30.670 --> 00:19:32.270
The directly connected.

350
00:19:32.270 --> 00:19:37.100
And you will only redistribute routes
that are active in your routing table.

351
00:19:37.100 --> 00:19:41.330
So it doesn't matter that I learned
about all these other networks via OSPF,

352
00:19:41.330 --> 00:19:45.130
because I have a better route in my
routing table, I won't put them in.

353
00:19:45.130 --> 00:19:49.850
And so I'm not redistributing those and
that's why I'm not seeing them in EIGRP.

354
00:19:49.850 --> 00:19:53.180
So I've got two choices about
how I want to handle this.

355
00:19:53.180 --> 00:19:56.890
Choice number one, I can redistribute
the connected routes into EIGRP,

356
00:19:56.890 --> 00:19:58.000
that's probably going to be the best.

357
00:19:59.000 --> 00:20:02.730
Option number two,
is I can use the network command and

358
00:20:02.730 --> 00:20:05.990
I can specify each of those subnets and
put them into EIGRP also.

359
00:20:05.990 --> 00:20:08.060
I can have an interface in both EIGRP and
OSPF.

360
00:20:08.060 --> 00:20:13.230
What it's going to boil down to is how
many interfaces I wanna advertise.

361
00:20:13.230 --> 00:20:16.480
I might not want to advertise
these internet interfaces up here,

362
00:20:16.480 --> 00:20:17.700
these guys in OSPF Area 61.

363
00:20:17.700 --> 00:20:21.850
I might wanna be a little more specific,
and if I don't wanna do route maps and

364
00:20:21.850 --> 00:20:24.710
all that stuff, the network commands
will be more convenient, and so

365
00:20:24.710 --> 00:20:26.980
I can put those in and
that'll save some time, but

366
00:20:26.980 --> 00:20:31.190
if I wanna do all of my interfaces, it'll
be easier just to redistribute connected.

367
00:20:31.190 --> 00:20:33.930
And so I could just take that command
where we're redistributing OSPF and

368
00:20:33.930 --> 00:20:37.200
change it to redistribute connected,
and pump those routes in there and

369
00:20:37.200 --> 00:20:38.550
then we'll have it, right?

370
00:20:38.550 --> 00:20:40.430
But, just to keep it simple,
I'll go ahead and

371
00:20:40.430 --> 00:20:45.090
use the network command to push those
into EIGRP, and that'll solve that too.

372
00:20:45.090 --> 00:20:49.570
I can use the network command because I
am directly connected to those networks.

373
00:20:49.570 --> 00:20:56.533
So if I go back to NYEDGE1 I
can jump into EIGRP for

374
00:20:56.533 --> 00:21:02.767
AS500, so I'm gonna say Conf T
router EIGRP EIGRP_INTERNAL.

375
00:21:05.070 --> 00:21:10.409
And we can specify the address family,
this is good old IPV4 Unicast.

376
00:21:11.980 --> 00:21:14.190
Autonomous system 500.

377
00:21:14.190 --> 00:21:18.480
And once I'm in autonomous system 500,
then I've got a choice.

378
00:21:18.480 --> 00:21:21.110
If I wanted to redistribute connected,
I would come in here and

379
00:21:21.110 --> 00:21:26.200
I would say topology base, and
then I would do redistribute connected.

380
00:21:26.200 --> 00:21:28.230
And then go on and specify the metric,

381
00:21:28.230 --> 00:21:31.230
and then that would bring all those
connected ones in in one command.

382
00:21:31.230 --> 00:21:35.700
But if you wanna do network,
you don't need to be in the topology base,

383
00:21:35.700 --> 00:21:42.373
you can just be right here in the address
family, and you can say network

384
00:21:42.373 --> 00:21:48.460
192.168.10.0, along with a wildcard
mask for it, and then 11, and so on.

385
00:21:48.460 --> 00:21:51.390
And so I'm basically moving
these guys directly into EIGRP.

386
00:21:51.390 --> 00:21:54.480
Now on a positive side,
that's gonna bring the routes in.

387
00:21:54.480 --> 00:21:57.470
On a negative side I'm now advertising
EIGRP on those networks and

388
00:21:57.470 --> 00:21:58.520
I might not want that.

389
00:21:58.520 --> 00:22:00.770
Redistributing connected would
have been a more effective there.

390
00:22:00.770 --> 00:22:02.690
They didn't really give me any
direction in the question,

391
00:22:02.690 --> 00:22:04.760
so no preference either way.

392
00:22:04.760 --> 00:22:07.660
So I'm going this route just to make
sure that I don't advertise any networks

393
00:22:07.660 --> 00:22:08.300
that I don't want.

394
00:22:08.300 --> 00:22:10.140
This will be a little more specific.

395
00:22:10.140 --> 00:22:11.590
Although I do have to run seven commands,

396
00:22:11.590 --> 00:22:14.860
which is a little heavy on
the command side but it'll work.

397
00:22:14.860 --> 00:22:16.270
So we'll go ahead and
get these punched in.

398
00:22:17.470 --> 00:22:22.040
And as soon as they're there, then NYWAN1
should have the return route to be

399
00:22:22.040 --> 00:22:26.390
able to get back to us and
we should be in good shape, all right?

400
00:22:26.390 --> 00:22:29.050
So all of those are in there now.

401
00:22:29.050 --> 00:22:31.410
I guess I could have adjusted
the wildcard mask, but

402
00:22:31.410 --> 00:22:34.375
I didn't wanna calculate out the binary
bits there, it takes too much time.

403
00:22:34.375 --> 00:22:38.960
[LAUGH] So actually I don't think I could
have gotten a good binary wildcard mask

404
00:22:38.960 --> 00:22:42.180
that would have covered just those ranges,
that would have been hard to do.

405
00:22:42.180 --> 00:22:46.400
All right, so let's go ahead and jump over
to NYWAN1, and see what it's getting now.

406
00:22:46.400 --> 00:22:51.380
The EIGRP is really fast so it'll
learn those routes pretty quickly, and

407
00:22:51.380 --> 00:22:56.330
if I do a Show IP route from
192.168.16.10, I've got a route now.

408
00:22:58.140 --> 00:23:02.820
And if I do a Show IP route EIGRP and

409
00:23:02.820 --> 00:23:08.660
I'll filter that for
192.168, I should see.

410
00:23:08.660 --> 00:23:09.500
There they all are, right?

411
00:23:09.500 --> 00:23:12.100
There's all those routes
that just came in via EIGRP.

412
00:23:12.100 --> 00:23:14.280
So now I've got those return routes,
all right?

413
00:23:14.280 --> 00:23:18.400
So I know how to get back to the network,
let's see if that fixed it, all right?

414
00:23:18.400 --> 00:23:22.530
So if I jump all the way
back to PLab Cisco 01,

415
00:23:22.530 --> 00:23:27.190
I can retry that ping,
and now we're successful.

416
00:23:27.190 --> 00:23:29.610
All right, so
a few different solutions for this one.

417
00:23:29.610 --> 00:23:31.246
Few different problems for it, right?

418
00:23:31.246 --> 00:23:34.800
The first problem we had
to solve was that NYWAN1

419
00:23:34.800 --> 00:23:39.800
was not advertising
the 172.16.16 network into our

420
00:23:39.800 --> 00:23:43.600
internal environment because the EIGRP
autonomous system number was wrong.

421
00:23:43.600 --> 00:23:46.790
So we fixed that and
now we've started advertising it, right?

422
00:23:46.790 --> 00:23:51.430
The second problem that we had,
was that our routes weren't being

423
00:23:51.430 --> 00:23:56.290
advertised to NYWAN1 because of
an administrative distance miscalculation.

424
00:23:56.290 --> 00:24:00.320
I solved that by using network statements
and advertising them right into the EIGRP.

425
00:24:00.320 --> 00:24:02.290
We could have redistributed connected.

426
00:24:02.290 --> 00:24:03.880
We could have also done some NAT.

427
00:24:03.880 --> 00:24:06.760
I could have NATed that
traffic on this guy to

428
00:24:06.760 --> 00:24:08.650
an IP that NYWAN1 already knew about.

429
00:24:08.650 --> 00:24:10.580
That's another solution,
that would have worked.

430
00:24:10.580 --> 00:24:13.060
Little heavy on the config there,
but it certainly would have worked.

431
00:24:13.060 --> 00:24:15.010
So more than one way
to solve that problem.

432
00:24:15.010 --> 00:24:18.150
But in this case, now we've got our
dynamic routing protocols doing

433
00:24:18.150 --> 00:24:19.700
what they're supposed to be doing.

434
00:24:19.700 --> 00:24:21.110
They're learning about the routes.

435
00:24:21.110 --> 00:24:23.920
They know the topology, and
now they can make intelligent decisions.

436
00:24:23.920 --> 00:24:27.680
So with that in place, we're good
to go and that solves this problem.

437
00:24:27.680 --> 00:24:32.040
So, it was one problem with
a multi-part solution.

438
00:24:32.040 --> 00:24:32.820
We gotta watch out for those.

439
00:24:32.820 --> 00:24:36.080
Those are complex, but they're very
real and very possible on the exam.

440
00:24:36.080 --> 00:24:37.630
So definitely something
you want to remember.

441
00:24:37.630 --> 00:24:40.000
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed that one.

442
00:24:40.000 --> 00:24:40.550
Stay tuned,

443
00:24:40.550 --> 00:24:43.930
we've got one more issue in set four
before we move on to the next set.

444
00:24:43.930 --> 00:24:45.240
So stay tuned for that,
it's coming up next.

445
00:24:45.240 --> 00:24:54.000
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #8` from set #4. The trouble ticket states that "You are unable to ping 192.168.224.1 from PLABCSCO01 "
episodes.title: Set 4 Issue 8
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.036
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.036 --> 00:00:11.668
Welcome back to another
Cisco troubleshooting video.

3
00:00:11.668 --> 00:00:14.840
We're gonna take a look at set
four issue number eight, and

4
00:00:14.840 --> 00:00:17.642
we've got another reachability
issue on this one.

5
00:00:17.642 --> 00:00:20.246
The troubleshooting ticket reads,

6
00:00:20.246 --> 00:00:25.544
you are unable to ping
192.168.224.1 from PLABCISCO01.

7
00:00:25.544 --> 00:00:27.069
So we've got more reachability.

8
00:00:27.069 --> 00:00:29.319
Let's take a look at our
overall network diagram,

9
00:00:29.319 --> 00:00:30.949
get an idea of where this problem is.

10
00:00:30.949 --> 00:00:35.901
So we know our good old trusty PLABCISCO
server way down here at the bottom of

11
00:00:35.901 --> 00:00:38.344
the topology, that's the source.

12
00:00:38.344 --> 00:00:43.545
And when it's trying to get to
192.168.224.1 it's not getting there.

13
00:00:43.545 --> 00:00:46.552
So if I zoom back out we can find,
here we go.

14
00:00:46.552 --> 00:00:53.480
192.168.224.1, it's one of these
external networks up here in EIRGP 800.

15
00:00:53.480 --> 00:00:57.890
So it's telling me that we can't get
there and well, we need to find out why.

16
00:00:57.890 --> 00:01:01.668
Now as always, when we're dealing
with a big topology like this.

17
00:01:01.668 --> 00:01:03.652
When you've got a lot
of devices in the mix,

18
00:01:03.652 --> 00:01:05.428
a traceroute is a great place to start.

19
00:01:05.428 --> 00:01:09.146
So, I'm gonna jump back to that server and
that's where we'll start.

20
00:01:09.146 --> 00:01:13.147
We'll do a little traceroute and
see where our communication breaks down.

21
00:01:13.147 --> 00:01:22.087
So, I'll do a traceroute to
192.168.224.1 and here it goes.

22
00:01:22.087 --> 00:01:27.613
Now my first top should be the default
gateway, which for me is 192.168.16.1.

23
00:01:27.613 --> 00:01:30.804
I'll see the unique IP,
because that's an HSRP cluster.

24
00:01:30.804 --> 00:01:31.575
So there we go.

25
00:01:31.575 --> 00:01:34.561
We got dot three,
which is actually NY core two.

26
00:01:34.561 --> 00:01:37.486
So I just jumped over to
one of those switches,

27
00:01:37.486 --> 00:01:41.611
then we go up to NY edge 1,
which is 192.168.12.5.

28
00:01:41.611 --> 00:01:46.155
Then we go to NYWAN1,
which is 192.168.255.1 and

29
00:01:46.155 --> 00:01:49.799
then we're jumping to some
IPs I don't recognize.

30
00:01:49.799 --> 00:01:53.791
192.168.255.5, that one
must be outside and

31
00:01:53.791 --> 00:01:56.380
that's not what we expect to see is it.

32
00:01:56.380 --> 00:02:01.968
So then I get a nice little
response from 192.168.224.1.

33
00:02:01.968 --> 00:02:03.267
What's that all about?

34
00:02:03.267 --> 00:02:04.344
Well, let's try to ping.

35
00:02:04.344 --> 00:02:07.961
Remember, the troubleshooting tip it say,
we can't ping this one IP.

36
00:02:07.961 --> 00:02:12.430
Let's see what we get if we ping
over to it and we can ping it.

37
00:02:12.430 --> 00:02:16.169
Now, why can we ping this IP
when we're not suppose to?

38
00:02:16.169 --> 00:02:21.003
Well, that is a great question and I'm
gonna do something I don't normally do,

39
00:02:21.003 --> 00:02:23.645
which is look at the answer
to see [LAUGH] why.

40
00:02:23.645 --> 00:02:26.438
I try not to look at the answers
to these before I do them,

41
00:02:26.438 --> 00:02:28.112
because it kind of ruins the fun.

42
00:02:28.112 --> 00:02:30.084
So oh, jeez.

43
00:02:30.084 --> 00:02:33.720
Well, I guess I should have
looked at the answer on this one.

44
00:02:33.720 --> 00:02:39.777
So the problem here is we're supposed
to have a problem with EIGRP,

45
00:02:39.777 --> 00:02:44.041
but we already solved it
in issue number seven.

46
00:02:44.041 --> 00:02:47.089
In issue number seven,
we had a really similar problem.

47
00:02:47.089 --> 00:02:51.440
We had PLABCISCO01 was
unable to ping the outside

48
00:02:51.440 --> 00:02:54.891
interface of NYWAN1 and we fixed that.

49
00:02:54.891 --> 00:03:00.458
The problem was that EIGRP was set for
autonomous system 80 instead of 800.

50
00:03:00.458 --> 00:03:03.586
And you'll remember if you've watched that
one that I went through and fixed it.

51
00:03:03.586 --> 00:03:06.931
It was one of the first things we fixed
before we started fixing the other

52
00:03:06.931 --> 00:03:10.128
direction of the traffic to get
that kind of route advertised down.

53
00:03:10.128 --> 00:03:11.275
So we fixed that and

54
00:03:11.275 --> 00:03:15.309
then did a second correction to
get the internal traffic flowing.

55
00:03:15.309 --> 00:03:19.799
Well, in doing that, we've actually
fixed the problem here for issue eight.

56
00:03:19.799 --> 00:03:23.835
So if you're just starting with issue
eight, if you're kind of jumping around

57
00:03:23.835 --> 00:03:27.814
in the troubleshooting tickets, just
jump back and watch the solution set for

58
00:03:27.814 --> 00:03:30.486
issue seven and
it's the first thing that we fixed.

59
00:03:30.486 --> 00:03:33.654
That system number was wrong,
we had to get that corrected.

60
00:03:33.654 --> 00:03:34.529
We've put it back in place.

61
00:03:34.529 --> 00:03:38.977
But in this case, because we've already
fixed it, more gold and more able to pin.

62
00:03:38.977 --> 00:03:41.964
This troubleshooting ticket is
solved before it even began.

63
00:03:41.964 --> 00:03:43.853
One of the easiest ones we're gonna do.

64
00:03:43.853 --> 00:03:47.064
And with that,
that wraps up set number four.

65
00:03:47.064 --> 00:03:49.258
Stay tuned, we get set number
five coming down the road.

66
00:03:49.258 --> 00:03:52.915
I hope you guys have enjoyed this so
far and I look forward to seeing you then.

67
00:03:52.915 --> 00:03:59.769
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #1` from set #5. The trouble ticket states that "You are unable to ping 192.168.224.1 which is in the WAN connected to NYWAN1 from NYWAN1 itself "
episodes.title: Set 5 Issue 1
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:02.128
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:02.128 --> 00:00:06.589
[SOUND] Alright, welcome to another

3
00:00:06.589 --> 00:00:12.101
troubleshooting episode here on IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:12.101 --> 00:00:15.480
And in this episode we're
kicking off set five issue one.

5
00:00:15.480 --> 00:00:16.900
That means an all new set.

6
00:00:16.900 --> 00:00:18.450
We need to be on the lookout for

7
00:00:18.450 --> 00:00:22.690
any subtle changes in our infrastructure,
because the topology is now different.

8
00:00:22.690 --> 00:00:25.780
We're gonna kick off some slightly
more complex troubleshooting examples,

9
00:00:25.780 --> 00:00:26.950
we'll see a few different things here,

10
00:00:26.950 --> 00:00:30.920
which is always great for you know,
enhancing our troubleshooting skills.

11
00:00:30.920 --> 00:00:34.480
So let's take a look at this
troubleshooting ticket, and what it's

12
00:00:34.480 --> 00:00:39.410
telling us here is it says you
are unable to ping 192.168.224.1,

13
00:00:39.410 --> 00:00:42.727
which is in the WAN connected ,to NYWAN1,

14
00:00:42.727 --> 00:00:46.260
and we're failing to
ping from NYWAN1 itself.

15
00:00:46.260 --> 00:00:49.550
So, we've got an EDGE router
sitting on the Internet,

16
00:00:49.550 --> 00:00:53.140
and it's trying to ping an Internet
subnet, and it's not able to do it.

17
00:00:53.140 --> 00:00:54.670
So we need to find out why.

18
00:00:54.670 --> 00:00:56.580
So let's take a look at
what's going on there.

19
00:00:56.580 --> 00:01:00.270
I wanna start with our topology map,
and I'll just pull up the topology.

20
00:01:00.270 --> 00:01:02.770
You'll see it looks pretty similar to
what we've had in the previous sets, but

21
00:01:02.770 --> 00:01:04.180
things are a little bit different.

22
00:01:04.180 --> 00:01:09.720
Notice some of the OSPF regions are gone,
or areas are gone.

23
00:01:09.720 --> 00:01:11.050
IEGRP 500 is gone.

24
00:01:11.050 --> 00:01:13.710
So we definitely have some
routing topology changes.

25
00:01:13.710 --> 00:01:15.610
But I can put most of that out of my mind,

26
00:01:15.610 --> 00:01:19.220
because the problem as described
in the ticket is up here.

27
