248
00:12:46.280 --> 00:12:50.580
But the others should be 0 because they're
the ones that affect the other metrics.

249
00:12:50.580 --> 00:12:53.410
These are not the standard
metrics right here.

250
00:12:53.410 --> 00:12:56.710
Now, that may or may not be a problem,
I may want it this way.

251
00:12:56.710 --> 00:12:59.270
I may have manipulated this for
a specific reason, and

252
00:12:59.270 --> 00:13:03.110
the neighbors need to update theirs
to reflect my K values, all right?

253
00:13:03.110 --> 00:13:05.440
But the odds are,
this is not what's right, right?

254
00:13:05.440 --> 00:13:08.590
We probably want to have
the correct K values, so

255
00:13:08.590 --> 00:13:13.310
what I'm gonna do is just do a quick
#show run of the EIGRP section.

256
00:13:14.660 --> 00:13:17.150
And there we can see where the metric
weights have been overridden.

257
00:13:18.330 --> 00:13:20.150
And so I'm just gonna remove that command,

258
00:13:20.150 --> 00:13:26.400
and then we'll be able to hopefully see
some neighbor relationships come up.

259
00:13:26.400 --> 00:13:27.570
So I'm gonna get into EIGRP.

260
00:13:28.820 --> 00:13:34.370
I'll get into the ipv4 unicast family for
autonomous system 800.

261
00:13:34.370 --> 00:13:37.480
And then in here,

262
00:13:37.480 --> 00:13:42.040
I'm gonna say no metric weights, and
then we can specify the weights.

263
00:13:42.040 --> 00:13:45.270
Now, I just did the no metric weights and
I didn't bother specifying the rest of it,

264
00:13:45.270 --> 00:13:48.020
and that's because that should
reset me back to default.

265
00:13:48.020 --> 00:13:52.010
If I do a show run, and I filter that for

266
00:13:52.010 --> 00:13:55.530
the EIGRP section, you'll see
that the metric command is gone.

267
00:13:55.530 --> 00:14:00.130
And if I do a show IP protocols,
and I go in and

268
00:14:00.130 --> 00:14:05.930
take a look at EIGRP, I can see
the values are now 1, 0, 1, 0, 0, 0.

269
00:14:05.930 --> 00:14:10.730
The K values are set to the ones
that we expect them to be.

270
00:14:10.730 --> 00:14:14.730
One's for delay and bandwidth,
and zeros for everything else.

271
00:14:14.730 --> 00:14:18.737
And now that they're set that way,
assuming my neighbors are set that way,

272
00:14:18.737 --> 00:14:20.500
that should resolve that issue.

273
00:14:20.500 --> 00:14:23.180
And if I do a show ip eigrp nei,

274
00:14:23.180 --> 00:14:27.600
I now have some neighbor relationships,
that's a good sign.

275
00:14:27.600 --> 00:14:34.930
And if I do a show ip route 192.168.224.1
let's see if we learned it.

276
00:14:34.930 --> 00:14:40.320
I've got a route, and so
now I can try and ping, and there we go.

277
00:14:40.320 --> 00:14:41.590
Five successful pings.

278
00:14:41.590 --> 00:14:45.310
So in this case, my router wasn't able
to ping that I P because I didn't have

279
00:14:45.310 --> 00:14:49.990
a route and I didn't have a route because
the K values in EIGRP had been changed to

280
00:14:49.990 --> 00:14:53.580
a nonstandard value, and that caused the
neighboring adjacencies not to come up.

281
00:14:53.580 --> 00:14:54.870
We fixed the values.

282
00:14:54.870 --> 00:14:56.640
Now it's resolved, we can ping across.

283
00:14:56.640 --> 00:14:58.980
We're ready to move on to our
next troubleshooting question.

284
00:14:58.980 --> 00:15:00.530
So that wraps this one up.

285
00:15:00.530 --> 00:15:01.760
Hope you guys enjoyed it.

286
00:15:01.760 --> 00:15:04.662
Stay tuned,
we've got more troubleshooting coming up.

287
00:15:04.662 --> 00:15:12.499
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #2` from set #5. The trouble ticket states that "VRRP on NYEDGE2 is in a backup state, this should be the master "
episodes.title: Set 5 Issue 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.210 --> 00:00:07.188
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.188 --> 00:00:10.090
Welcome back to another
troubleshooting video here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:10.090 --> 00:00:12.860
And we're gonna be jumping into Set 5,
Issue 2.

4
00:00:12.860 --> 00:00:16.100
Looks like you've got some VRRP
troubles this time around.

5
00:00:16.100 --> 00:00:19.180
Let me read the support ticket to you and
we'll see what we've got to work with.

6
00:00:19.180 --> 00:00:26.782
Telling us here that VRRP on NYEDGE2 is in
a backup state, this should be the master.

7
00:00:26.782 --> 00:00:28.590
All right,
well let's look at our topology here and

8
00:00:28.590 --> 00:00:30.690
we'll kinda get an idea of
where this is coming from.

9
00:00:30.690 --> 00:00:35.560
So, it doesn't look like I have anything
on my diagram that indicates how VRRP is

10
00:00:35.560 --> 00:00:39.100
configured, so I don't know who's
the backup or anything like that.

11
00:00:39.100 --> 00:00:43.160
I just know that NYEDGE2 is running
VRRP cuz they told me that and

12
00:00:43.160 --> 00:00:44.890
I know it's supposed to be the master.

13
00:00:44.890 --> 00:00:47.660
But I don't really know anything about
the configuration beyond that so

14
00:00:47.660 --> 00:00:50.630
there's a lot of missing holes we're
gonna have to figure out here.

15
00:00:50.630 --> 00:00:54.990
And we're just gonna start on NYEDGE2 and
find out why this one isn't kicking up.

16
00:00:54.990 --> 00:00:59.780
In my mind, I'm trying to think of all the
different things that can cause VRRP not

17
00:00:59.780 --> 00:01:00.750
to function.

18
00:01:00.750 --> 00:01:03.870
I'm thinking about connectivity
with whoever the backup is.

19
00:01:03.870 --> 00:01:08.270
I'm thinking about priority levels and
preemption and all of those.

20
00:01:08.270 --> 00:01:10.220
Those are the things that we're
gonna have to keep an eye out for.

21
00:01:10.220 --> 00:01:13.970
But, for the most part VRRP is
fairly easy to troubleshoot.

22
00:01:13.970 --> 00:01:16.400
So if we just look at our configuration
we're more than likely spot what

23
00:01:16.400 --> 00:01:17.170
the problem is.

24
00:01:17.170 --> 00:01:20.820
So let's jump over to NYEDGE2 and
see what we can find.

25
00:01:20.820 --> 00:01:24.910
Maybe this will turn out to be an easy
one, and we'll be in and out on this one.

26
00:01:24.910 --> 00:01:27.420
All right, so jumping over to NYEDGE2 I'm

27
00:01:27.420 --> 00:01:32.570
gonna start just by doing
a quick show VRRP brief.

28
00:01:32.570 --> 00:01:36.270
Show VRRP brief will give me kind of the
basic information that I need to figure

29
00:01:36.270 --> 00:01:40.180
out how VRRP is configured without having
to hunt around on the router too much.

30
00:01:40.180 --> 00:01:45.090
I can see that I'm running VRRP
right here on GI0/1, so I'm only

31
00:01:45.090 --> 00:01:48.340
running in on one interface, again
trying to make my life a little easier.

32
00:01:48.340 --> 00:01:50.075
I can see that I'm configured for
group 10.

33
00:01:50.075 --> 00:01:52.234
My priority is 99.

34
00:01:52.234 --> 00:01:58.340
Now, I know the default for VRRP has a
priority of 100, this is not the default.

35
00:01:58.340 --> 00:02:04.160
So that tells me either somebody has
statically assigned the priority to 99 or

36
00:02:04.160 --> 00:02:06.590
I'm being decremented because
of some kinda track object.

37
00:02:06.590 --> 00:02:10.080
Those are the two times that
we see a nonstandard priority.

38
00:02:10.080 --> 00:02:12.640
And then as I look over here,
my state is Init.

39
00:02:12.640 --> 00:02:14.850
I should be the master, but I'm not.

40
00:02:14.850 --> 00:02:20.070
I'm in Init, and as I scroll over I can
see that that the master address is 0.0.0.

41
00:02:20.070 --> 00:02:24.250
So not only am I not the master,
if somebody else is the master,

42
00:02:24.250 --> 00:02:24.960
I don't know about them.

43
00:02:24.960 --> 00:02:26.040
I can't see them.

44
00:02:26.040 --> 00:02:29.810
So that makes me think connectivity issue,
that whoever is the standby,

45
00:02:29.810 --> 00:02:32.050
I might not be able to
see them on the network.

46
00:02:32.050 --> 00:02:35.350
But if that was the case,
I should become the master.

47
00:02:36.810 --> 00:02:39.650
Unless that interface being down is
what's actually decrementing my priority,

48
00:02:39.650 --> 00:02:43.850
cuz a lot of stuff then cascade with VRRP,
so I have to pay attention to that.

49
00:02:43.850 --> 00:02:50.340
But my group address is 172.14.0.10,
my individual IP on that interface I don't

50
00:02:50.340 --> 00:02:55.400
actually know, so let's just quickly take
a look at that interface configuration.

51
00:02:55.400 --> 00:03:01.110
And when we pull that up,
my IP is 172.14.0.12.

52
00:03:01.110 --> 00:03:03.386
And the shared IP is .10.

53
00:03:03.386 --> 00:03:08.800
And as I look at it, all right I'm
kinda seeing a few possible problems.

54
00:03:08.800 --> 00:03:11.410
This one's jumping out at
me pretty big right here.

55
00:03:11.410 --> 00:03:12.890
The interface is shutdown.

56
00:03:12.890 --> 00:03:16.360
If it's shutdown, I'm probably
not gonna become a VRRP master.

57
00:03:16.360 --> 00:03:19.160
So there's possible problem number one.

58
00:03:19.160 --> 00:03:23.080
Possible problem number two,
my priority is not of the default.

59
00:03:23.080 --> 00:03:29.480
It's 149 and there's a track object right
after it that says to decrement by 50.

60
00:03:29.480 --> 00:03:31.170
Well 149 minus 50 is 99,

61
00:03:31.170 --> 00:03:36.080
and I saw in show VRRP brief that
that's what my priority was at.

62
00:03:36.080 --> 00:03:39.570
So that means that not only
is my interface shutdown but

63
00:03:39.570 --> 00:03:43.910
my track object is failing also,
and so I'm being decremented 50.

64
00:03:43.910 --> 00:03:47.130
Now, my track object could be
tracking this interface, and

65
00:03:47.130 --> 00:03:49.720
this interface is down, so
they could be related, and

66
00:03:49.720 --> 00:03:52.890
doing a no shutdown might solve all
our problems, and this one goes away.

67
00:03:52.890 --> 00:03:54.650
So, let's see if that's the case.

68
00:03:54.650 --> 00:03:57.560
So, I'm gonna get into gi0/1, and

69
00:03:57.560 --> 00:04:00.100
see if this is gonna be the easiest
question we deal with today.

70
00:04:00.100 --> 00:04:03.620
I'll issue a no shutdown on it, and
then I'll give it just a moment.

71
00:04:03.620 --> 00:04:07.220
I'll do a show IP interface brief
to make sure that it goes up, up.

72
00:04:07.220 --> 00:04:10.480
Whenever you turn an interface on, you've
always gotta give it at least a moment to

73
00:04:10.480 --> 00:04:13.870
run because we might have spanning
tree doing calculations or whatever.

74
00:04:13.870 --> 00:04:14.670
All right, there we go.

75
00:04:14.670 --> 00:04:15.804
That interface is now up.

76
00:04:15.804 --> 00:04:23.745
And if I do a show VRRP brief I see
that I still have that priority of 99.

77
00:04:23.745 --> 00:04:27.495
And I might have to wait a moment,
I can do a full show VRRP and

78
00:04:27.495 --> 00:04:29.378
not the brief output.

79
00:04:29.378 --> 00:04:32.680
And just kinda see if any other errors
are jumping out at me here while I wait.

80
00:04:32.680 --> 00:04:37.765
Preemption is enabled, my priority is
still 99 even though I'm configured for

81
00:04:37.765 --> 00:04:38.450
149.

82
00:04:38.450 --> 00:04:41.830
My track object is still down, all right.

83
00:04:41.830 --> 00:04:47.310
So the track object is tracking something
other than the interface status of GI0/1,

84
00:04:47.310 --> 00:04:51.150
so I've got a bigger problem,
some kinda secondary issue.

85
00:04:51.150 --> 00:04:54.210
So, turning interface on,
that's obviously gonna help, and

86
00:04:54.210 --> 00:04:57.310
notice that my state is now Backup.

87
00:04:57.310 --> 00:04:58.527
I'm not init anymore.

88
00:04:58.527 --> 00:05:02.526
That means that somebody else has become
the master router, and I can see them,

89
00:05:02.526 --> 00:05:03.971
172.14.0.11.

90
00:05:03.971 --> 00:05:10.680
So I've solved part of my problem, VRRP
is now working, but I'm not the master.

91
00:05:10.680 --> 00:05:12.890
I'm supposed to be the master,
instead I'm the backup.

92
00:05:12.890 --> 00:05:15.690
And that's probably because
my priority is too low.

93
00:05:15.690 --> 00:05:19.311
If you look at this Master Router
its priority is 100.

94
00:05:19.311 --> 00:05:20.576
Mine is 99.

95
00:05:20.576 --> 00:05:23.768
If I can get this track object to come up,
my priority to go 149 and

96
00:05:23.768 --> 00:05:26.880
because preemption is enabled,
we'll become the master.

97
00:05:26.880 --> 00:05:30.230
So now our entire world rotates
around this track object,

98
00:05:30.230 --> 00:05:32.260
let's see what's going on there.

99
00:05:32.260 --> 00:05:37.090
Now, when I look at the config, I saw that
I was tracking a particular object and

100
00:05:38.100 --> 00:05:40.270
we saw that in the interface.

101
00:05:41.420 --> 00:05:44.540
Right here, so it's doing track 1.

102
00:05:44.540 --> 00:05:46.040
So I need to take a look at that one, so

103
00:05:46.040 --> 00:05:50.030
if I do show track 1 we can take
a look at what that's doing.

104
00:05:50.030 --> 00:05:53.276
It's monitoring a route,
so it's looking for

105
00:05:53.276 --> 00:06:00.250
a route 192.168.17.32 with
a 255.255.255.224 subnet mask.

106
00:06:00.250 --> 00:06:01.530
And it's just testing reachability,

107
00:06:01.530 --> 00:06:04.830
which means is that route
present in our routing table?

108
00:06:04.830 --> 00:06:07.270
And if it's not,
then the track object fails.

109
00:06:07.270 --> 00:06:08.870
And that's what it's telling me,
reachability is down,

110
00:06:08.870 --> 00:06:11.970
we don't have that route and
that's the end of it.

111
00:06:11.970 --> 00:06:13.080
So we're being decremented.

112
00:06:13.080 --> 00:06:15.300
So, why am I missing that route?

113
00:06:15.300 --> 00:06:19.684
Well, I guess first off I can verify
that I am missing that route.

114
00:06:19.684 --> 00:06:22.678
I mean I trust the track object,
it's not gonna lie to me, but

115
00:06:22.678 --> 00:06:26.321
we can see if we've got anything
that starts with 192.168.17.

116
00:06:26.321 --> 00:06:30.024
And I do have a couple of routes,
but I don't have this one.

117
00:06:30.024 --> 00:06:31.615
I don't have the .32.

118
00:06:31.615 --> 00:06:33.623
I've got .0 and .64.

119
00:06:33.623 --> 00:06:35.504
I don't have .32.

120
00:06:35.504 --> 00:06:39.170
All right, now where's that route
supposed to be coming from?

121
00:06:39.170 --> 00:06:40.720
Let's look at our topology here,

122
00:06:40.720 --> 00:06:44.870
cuz that network isn't striking me as
something that I'm familiar with, and so

123
00:06:44.870 --> 00:06:50.640
when we look for that 192.168.17,
where is that supposed to come from?

124
00:06:50.640 --> 00:06:57.875
Well, if I look at my tables here from
outside the network I don't see any

125
00:06:57.875 --> 00:07:01.760
192.168 addresses, so it must be coming
from inside of my network somewhere.

126
00:07:01.760 --> 00:07:05.690
And inside of my network I don't
have very good documentation.

127
00:07:05.690 --> 00:07:09.760
NYEDGE2, I see this little cloud here
which indicates I've got a dynamic routing

128
00:07:09.760 --> 00:07:12.910
protocol, but it's not really telling
me about that protocol at all.

129
00:07:12.910 --> 00:07:13.820
I don't know what it is.

130
00:07:13.820 --> 00:07:17.520
I could assume it's EIGRP cuz
the EIGRP is blue over here.

131
00:07:17.520 --> 00:07:19.700
But at this point,
I don't really trust this diagram at all.

132
00:07:19.700 --> 00:07:23.790
So let's just look at the router,
and we'll figure it out from here.

133
00:07:23.790 --> 00:07:26.940
You can trust your router,
a diagram is suspect.

134
00:07:26.940 --> 00:07:31.283
So I'm just gonna do a quick show IP
protocols to see what I'm running.

135
00:07:31.283 --> 00:07:37.801
And when I look at it, I can see that I
am running eigrp 800, and is that it?

136
00:07:37.801 --> 00:07:42.248
Let's see, yeah, so it looks like
we've got EIGRP 800 and that's it.

137
00:07:42.248 --> 00:07:43.559
And if I go back to my diagram,

138
00:07:43.559 --> 00:07:45.976
that's where this kinda
gets a little weird, right?

139
00:07:45.976 --> 00:07:51.502
I've got EIGRP 800 way out here, and
apparently it's extending over to NYEDGE2.

140
00:07:51.502 --> 00:07:57.280
So I'm in this EIGRP range and I guess
in theory I'm supposed to be learning

141
00:07:57.280 --> 00:08:02.522
this 192.168.17.32 network
from the EIGRP 800.

142
00:08:02.522 --> 00:08:04.750
It's gotta come from somewhere.

143
00:08:04.750 --> 00:08:08.790
And we could kinda verify that if we
look at the other 192.168.17 routes and

144
00:08:08.790 --> 00:08:10.570
where they're coming from.

145
00:08:10.570 --> 00:08:13.720
So, when I looked at my routing table and

146
00:08:13.720 --> 00:08:19.390
I did a show IP route, well here,
I can just pull it up on my history.

147
00:08:19.390 --> 00:08:23.030
So I have those two networks and
because they're external routes,

148
00:08:23.030 --> 00:08:25.120
the output is kind of obscuring it.

149
00:08:25.120 --> 00:08:27.820
Let me just do a full show IP route, and

150
00:08:27.820 --> 00:08:30.775
we can look in here and figure out
where those routes are coming from.

151
00:08:30.775 --> 00:08:35.020
And because 192.168.17.32 is
in-between the other two routes,

152
00:08:35.020 --> 00:08:38.540
it makes sense that it'll be
coming from the same area.

153
00:08:38.540 --> 00:08:44.726
So as I look at it, I can see they're
coming from somewhere outside of EIGRP and

154
00:08:44.726 --> 00:08:51.883
that we learned them via 192.168.16.1 and
via 192.168.15.1.

155
00:08:51.883 --> 00:08:57.200
In our previous sets,
we saw where 192.168.16.1

156
00:08:57.200 --> 00:09:02.917
was an HSRP address that was shared
between NYCORE1 and NYCORE2,

157
00:09:02.917 --> 00:09:09.254
and looking at my topology, NYCORE1 and
NYCORE2 are not a part of EIGRP.

158
00:09:09.254 --> 00:09:11.110
They're over here in OSPF.

159
00:09:12.120 --> 00:09:14.870
So if the routes
are originating from OSPF,

160
00:09:14.870 --> 00:09:19.050
then NYEDGE1 should be
learning those routes and

161
00:09:19.050 --> 00:09:23.860
then sharing them, redistributing them in
the EIGRP 800 so we get them from there.

162
00:09:23.860 --> 00:09:26.547
So let's see if NYEDGE1 has
the route that we're missing.

163
00:09:26.547 --> 00:09:30.587
So, we'll jump over to NYEDGE1 and
see what it's got.

164
00:09:30.587 --> 00:09:37.165
When I get into its routing table,
I'll just do a show IP route.

165
00:09:37.165 --> 00:09:41.425
And I'm gonna look for
those 192.168.17 routes.

166
00:09:41.425 --> 00:09:43.585
And particularly I'm looking for
the .32 one.

167
00:09:43.585 --> 00:09:46.858
And so when I look through here,

168
00:09:46.858 --> 00:09:51.346
we've got some 192.168.1s, and

169
00:09:51.346 --> 00:09:56.683
I am not seeing 192.168.17.anything,

170
00:09:56.683 --> 00:09:59.481
so that's not a good sign.

171
00:09:59.481 --> 00:10:04.452
I'm just gonna do a real quick show
IP route for 192.168.17.32, since

172
00:10:04.452 --> 00:10:09.930
that's the target network we're looking
for, and I don't have it here either.

173
00:10:09.930 --> 00:10:14.480
So, if neither of my edge routers have it,
then it's not like I can learn it,

174
00:10:14.480 --> 00:10:14.980
they don't have it.

175
00:10:14.980 --> 00:10:17.260
So I need to find out where
this route's originating from.

176
00:10:17.260 --> 00:10:20.381
So let's take a look at some of the other
devices and we'll see if we can spot it.

177
00:10:20.381 --> 00:10:24.210
I'm gonna jump over to one of my core
switches since this is where I was

178
00:10:24.210 --> 00:10:26.470
learning the other two routes, right?

179
00:10:26.470 --> 00:10:32.412
I learned 192.168.17.0 and .64.

180
00:10:32.412 --> 00:10:36.330
But I didn't learn .32 so
I'm just gonna see if .32 exists here.

181
00:10:36.330 --> 00:10:42.110
So I'll do a show IP route, and
I'm gonna skim through on this one and

182
00:10:42.110 --> 00:10:46.160
look for those 192.168.17 networks and
see if we can find them.

183
00:10:46.160 --> 00:10:50.830
We got a bunch of them, but no .17,
so it doesn't exist here either.

184
00:10:52.930 --> 00:10:56.720
And that seems odd cuz it
came from one of these guys.

185
00:10:56.720 --> 00:11:01.465
Let's see if we can find
any of these routes.

186
00:11:01.465 --> 00:11:02.457
All right, they're not there.

187
00:11:02.457 --> 00:11:05.210
I'm sorry, we might have
a head scratcher on this one.

188
00:11:05.210 --> 00:11:07.390
Let's jump over to CORE2 and double check.

189
00:11:07.390 --> 00:11:10.174
Now I am using an assumption here.

190
00:11:10.174 --> 00:11:16.408
I'm assuming that 192.168.16.1 is an HSRP
address shared between these guys.

191
00:11:16.408 --> 00:11:21.048
I guess I should check that and see,
cuz this is a new topology, and so

192
00:11:21.048 --> 00:11:24.419
it looks like it's not
an HSRP instance anymore.

193
00:11:24.419 --> 00:11:27.481
So that's where we have to be careful,
when you move from question to question,

194
00:11:27.481 --> 00:11:30.227
you can't assume what existed in one
topology still exists here, and so

195
00:11:30.227 --> 00:11:31.099
I can see this is gone.

196
00:11:31.099 --> 00:11:36.230
I need to find who is 192.168.16.1.

197
00:11:36.230 --> 00:11:40.428
Because on EDGE2 when I
learned those other routes,

198
00:11:40.428 --> 00:11:47.330
192.168.16.1 and 15.1,
those were the sources that I had.

199
00:11:47.330 --> 00:11:50.874
And I was learning them on
GigabitEthernet0/0.16 and

200
00:11:50.874 --> 00:11:54.218
.15 which I'll bet our router
on a stick interfaces.

201
00:11:54.218 --> 00:11:56.889
So that means they're tied to a VLAN.

202
00:11:56.889 --> 00:11:58.108
And that means they could be anywhere.

203
00:11:58.108 --> 00:12:01.696
And if I pull up those interfaces and
look at it,

204
00:12:01.696 --> 00:12:06.080
sure enough I see those
encapsulation commands.

205
00:12:06.080 --> 00:12:09.560
And those are going to
be tied to somebody.

206
00:12:09.560 --> 00:12:14.750
Now just looking in here, I happen to
notice we have an IP policy map on here,

207
00:12:14.750 --> 00:12:17.040
a route map, with policy-based routing.

208
00:12:17.040 --> 00:12:19.400
So there's some route
manipulation going on here.

209
00:12:19.400 --> 00:12:21.360
But before I can figure out
whether that's right or wrong,

210
00:12:21.360 --> 00:12:24.550
I still need to figure out who .1 is.

211
00:12:24.550 --> 00:12:27.210
And so to to help me out here,
actually you know what,

212
00:12:27.210 --> 00:12:29.580
let's see if we can cheat a little bit and
do a show CDP neighbor,

213
00:12:29.580 --> 00:12:33.450
and if we're running CDP it might be
able to help me figure out who that is.

214
00:12:34.570 --> 00:12:38.563
So if I do a show CDP entry for NYCORE2,

215
00:12:38.563 --> 00:12:43.860
let's see what IP I'm
picking that one up on.

216
00:12:43.860 --> 00:12:48.500
And It's 15.1, I'll bet it's 16.1 also.

217
00:12:48.500 --> 00:12:50.474
Good.
All right, so let's jump over to CORE2 and

218
00:12:50.474 --> 00:12:51.526
take a look at that guy.

219
00:12:51.526 --> 00:12:56.338
All right, so here's CORE2, and
on CORE2, if I do a show IP route,

220
00:12:56.338 --> 00:13:00.918
I'm expecting to find these
networks that I'm supposed to have.

221
00:13:00.918 --> 00:13:03.266
If they're not here, we're really
gonna have to do some searching.

222
00:13:03.266 --> 00:13:04.810
All right, there they go, good.

223
00:13:04.810 --> 00:13:07.980
All right, so here's 192.168.17,
so we finally found it.

224
00:13:07.980 --> 00:13:11.792
And I've got 192.168.17.1,

225
00:13:11.792 --> 00:13:16.431
I've got 17.32, and 17.64, all right.

226
00:13:16.431 --> 00:13:21.514
And in the routing table of NYEDGE2,
I had 192.168.17.0 and

227
00:13:21.514 --> 00:13:26.390
I had .64, I was missing .32,
which is in between them.

228
00:13:26.390 --> 00:13:28.300
All right, but I can see it right here.

229
00:13:28.300 --> 00:13:31.500
So this is the router where
those routes originate.

230
00:13:31.500 --> 00:13:32.630
And it's a switch.

231
00:13:32.630 --> 00:13:33.670
It's this guy right here,

232
00:13:33.670 --> 00:13:38.610
NYCORE2, and I should be learning
those routes on this link, right?

233
00:13:38.610 --> 00:13:39.940
Well, not necessarily.

234
00:13:39.940 --> 00:13:44.210
Notice how NYCORE2 is not showing as
being in any dynamic routing protocol.

235
00:13:44.210 --> 00:13:46.860
So I don't really know
how I'm learning those.

236
00:13:46.860 --> 00:13:48.390
Except I do.

237
00:13:48.390 --> 00:13:52.480
I saw them in EIGRP 800, and
I saw them as external routes.

238
00:13:52.480 --> 00:13:56.230
So EIGRP is not necessarily running here.

239
00:13:56.230 --> 00:14:00.510
It could be in OSPF Area 0 and
the diagram could just be wrong, right?

240
00:14:00.510 --> 00:14:02.880
Let's see if we've got any
routing protocols on this thing.

241
00:14:02.880 --> 00:14:09.970
So if I do a show IP protocols,
NYCORE2 is running a routing protocol.

242
00:14:09.970 --> 00:14:13.200
It's running EIGRP 800,
the stinking document is wrong.

243
00:14:13.200 --> 00:14:15.350
So, that's really gonna throw us for
a loop, right?

244
00:14:15.350 --> 00:14:20.440
This guy is actually in EIGRP 800,
and I'm in EIGRP 800.

245
00:14:20.440 --> 00:14:22.212
Let's see what interfaces are active for
it.

246
00:14:22.212 --> 00:14:27.088
So if I get down to the bottom here, I'll
see that I'm routing for 192.168.15 and

247
00:14:27.088 --> 00:14:27.600
.16.

248
00:14:27.600 --> 00:14:30.932
In fact, if I do a show IP,
EIGRP neighbor,

249
00:14:30.932 --> 00:14:36.621
I expect we've got a neighbor adjacency
built between these two systems.

250
00:14:36.621 --> 00:14:37.747
And we do.

251
00:14:37.747 --> 00:14:43.053
192.160.16.5 and 15.5, that's NYEDGE2.

252
00:14:43.053 --> 00:14:46.940
And I've got a neighbor relationship
built right up with it,

253
00:14:46.940 --> 00:14:49.070
right here on VLAN 15 and 16.

254
00:14:49.070 --> 00:14:52.400
So this problem should actually be an easy
one to solve, even though we've had to do

255
00:14:52.400 --> 00:14:55.070
a lot of research to figure
out where the problem is.

256
00:14:55.070 --> 00:14:59.240
We're running EIGRP right
across this link, and NYEDGE2,

257
00:14:59.240 --> 00:15:02.680
we've got a neighbor relationship, we
should be telling them about that network.

258
00:15:02.680 --> 00:15:05.860
Well, unless we forgot to
put it in the EIGRP process.

259
00:15:05.860 --> 00:15:06.928
Let's see if that's the case.

260
00:15:06.928 --> 00:15:11.743
When I do a show IP route and
found those interfaces,

261
00:15:11.743 --> 00:15:16.024
in fact,
we should be able to filter this one.

262
00:15:16.024 --> 00:15:19.948
If I look for 192.168.17, there we go.

263
00:15:19.948 --> 00:15:23.125
They're directly connected to
these VLAN interfaces, right?

264
00:15:23.125 --> 00:15:27.778
And, if I do a show run for
the EIGRP section,

265
00:15:27.778 --> 00:15:33.424
we can see the network
commands that are advertising.

266
00:15:33.424 --> 00:15:39.217
And then I've got a network 192.168.15,
and a network 192.168.16.

267
00:15:39.217 --> 00:15:45.430
I don't have a network for 192.168.17, so
they're not in the EIGRP process, right?

268
00:15:45.430 --> 00:15:48.240
Well, the very next thing
is redistribute connected.

269
00:15:48.240 --> 00:15:52.488
So it's redistributing the connected
routes into EIGRP, which would include all

270
00:15:52.488 --> 00:15:56.020
of these VLAN interfaces including
the network that I'm concerned with.

271
00:15:56.020 --> 00:16:00.780
But right at the end of that command
is a route map that says whether or

272
00:16:00.780 --> 00:16:05.730
not we're pushing certain routes, so
let's take a look at that route map.

273
00:16:05.730 --> 00:16:10.290
And see if we're listed, okay.

274
00:16:10.290 --> 00:16:12.150
Looks like we're matching an access list.

275
00:16:12.150 --> 00:16:15.320
So we've got access list
1 tied to that route map.

276
00:16:15.320 --> 00:16:20.767
And so if I do a show access list 1,
it's doing 192.160.17.0 and

277
00:16:20.767 --> 00:16:26.810
.64 the two that I'm getting, and
conveniently, .32 is left out, all right?

278
00:16:26.810 --> 00:16:28.350
So, there's gonna be our problem.

279
00:16:28.350 --> 00:16:32.240
It's not redistributing that
connected route in the EIGRP.

280
00:16:32.240 --> 00:16:35.090
So, I've got two ways to solve this.

281
00:16:35.090 --> 00:16:37.420
Method one, I could just add it
right here to this access list.

282
00:16:37.420 --> 00:16:38.149
And, that's probably the best.

283
00:16:38.149 --> 00:16:42.622
Method two, I could add that interface
right into the EIGRP process, but

284
00:16:42.622 --> 00:16:46.242
since they have this nice ACL
here we can just add on to that.

285
00:16:46.242 --> 00:16:47.310
So that's what I'm gonna do.

286
00:16:47.310 --> 00:16:55.238
So I'll say ip access-list
1 permit 192.168.17.32.

287
00:16:55.238 --> 00:17:00.342
And they've got a 31-bit
subnet mask on this one, so

288
00:17:00.342 --> 00:17:06.751
a really tight network, so
it's just gonna be 0.0.0.0.1,

289
00:17:06.751 --> 00:17:10.351
and it was access list 1, wasn't it?

290
00:17:10.351 --> 00:17:13.790
Let's see, you know what,
I did IP at the beginning.

291
00:17:13.790 --> 00:17:17.330
When you do the old style access list,
you don't need the IP keyword.

292
00:17:17.330 --> 00:17:20.050
So let me get rid of that,
and there we go.

293
00:17:20.050 --> 00:17:24.690
So now our route is a part of that access
list, and we should be good to go, right?

294
00:17:24.690 --> 00:17:27.100
So that'll start advertising
out usually pretty quick, so

295
00:17:27.100 --> 00:17:32.000
let's jump over to NYEDGE2 and
see if it's starting to get that route.

296
00:17:32.000 --> 00:17:39.130
So I had a route for the other ones and
I'm gonna filter for 192.168.17.

297
00:17:39.130 --> 00:17:42.020
And now I've got 32 in the network also.

298
00:17:42.020 --> 00:17:45.740
So going back to my original
troubleshooting ticket, it was telling me

299
00:17:45.740 --> 00:17:50.780
that we had VRRP failing because this
route wasn't in the routing table.

300
00:17:50.780 --> 00:17:53.090
I know it's been a long time
since we talked about VRRP.

301
00:17:53.090 --> 00:17:55.430
Now that the route is
in the routing table,

302
00:17:55.430 --> 00:17:59.500
if I look at that track object,
there we go.

303
00:17:59.500 --> 00:18:05.080
Now I can see reachability is up, learned
via EIGRP, so we should be good there.

304
00:18:05.080 --> 00:18:07.590
And, if I do a show VRRP,

305
00:18:07.590 --> 00:18:13.340
what I hope to see is that my priority
is now 149, and I'm the master.

306
00:18:13.340 --> 00:18:16.160
So we had a lot of exploration
to do on this one to solve what

307
00:18:16.160 --> 00:18:18.030
originally was a VRRP problem, right?

308
00:18:18.030 --> 00:18:19.630
We saw that we weren't the master.

309
00:18:19.630 --> 00:18:23.990
We saw that our priority was being
decremented because of a failed track.

310
00:18:23.990 --> 00:18:26.410
And then we had an interface down,
we fixed that.

311
00:18:26.410 --> 00:18:29.840
Then we had to figure out where that route
was coming from cuz the documentation

312
00:18:29.840 --> 00:18:30.690
didn't give it to us.

313
00:18:30.690 --> 00:18:32.140
So I had to do a little exploring.

314
00:18:32.140 --> 00:18:33.710
We did finally find that route.

315
00:18:33.710 --> 00:18:39.020
And once we found it we fixed the route
map that was filtering that route out,

316
00:18:39.020 --> 00:18:42.625
got it advertised back into EIGRP,
our track object went up.

317
00:18:42.625 --> 00:18:47.080
VRRP became happy, our priority went
back to 149 and we became the master.

318
00:18:47.080 --> 00:18:51.720
That was a series of events that
we had to kinda jump through and

319
00:18:51.720 --> 00:18:53.430
that was a pretty hard one, right?

320
00:18:53.430 --> 00:18:56.220
There was a moment there where I
didn't know if I was gonna be able to

321
00:18:56.220 --> 00:18:57.090
find that spot.

322
00:18:57.090 --> 00:18:59.442
You just keep digging, keep looking,
gathering information.

323
00:18:59.442 --> 00:19:03.967
At the end of the day we really only
made two changes, no shutdown on one

324
00:19:03.967 --> 00:19:08.282
interface and we added one line to
an ACL to add that extra network.

325
00:19:08.282 --> 00:19:12.690
So the fix was easy, but figuring out
what to do was actually pretty hard.

326
00:19:12.690 --> 00:19:15.410
So that was a fun problem right there,
I hope we get more like that.

327
00:19:15.410 --> 00:19:18.130
All right, well that wraps up this
particular troubleshooting issue.

328
00:19:18.130 --> 00:19:21.015
Stay tuned, we've got more
troubleshooting issues coming up.

329
00:19:21.015 --> 00:19:27.564
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #3` from set #5. The trouble ticket states that "The routes for the SVIs on NYCORE2 are not being propagated to NYWAN1 resulting in a failure to be able to ping 192.168.224.1 on PLABCSCO01 as there is no return path for the remote end point in its routing table "
episodes.title: Set 5 Issue 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.629
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.421 --> 00:00:12.160
All right, welcome back to another
troubleshooting episode here on IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:12.160 --> 00:00:16.170
We're going to be jumping into set five,
issue three, and I imagine we're in for

4
00:00:16.170 --> 00:00:19.660
a doozy on this one cuz it's a lot of
words in this troubleshooting ticket,

5
00:00:19.660 --> 00:00:20.690
most of them are one sentence.

6
00:00:20.690 --> 00:00:22.090
This one's got a little bit more.

7
00:00:22.090 --> 00:00:23.200
Let's take a look at the ticket.

8
00:00:23.200 --> 00:00:29.490
What it says is the routes for the SVIs
on NY Core 2 are not being propagated

9
00:00:29.490 --> 00:00:37.000
to NY WAN 1 resulting in a failure being
able to ping 192.168.224.1 On PLABCISCO01

10
00:00:37.000 --> 00:00:41.690
as there is no return path for
the remote end point in its routing table.

11
00:00:41.690 --> 00:00:43.560
That is a long sentence right there.

12
00:00:43.560 --> 00:00:45.920
All right, let's break this
down by what it actually means.

13
00:00:45.920 --> 00:00:49.040
I'm gonna bring up the topology here so
we can kinda get a handle on it.

14
00:00:49.040 --> 00:00:52.410
So, what they're telling me
is that we got a problem.

15
00:00:52.410 --> 00:00:54.820
Actually if we kinda read
the question backwards,

16
00:00:54.820 --> 00:00:56.240
it almost makes a little more sense.

17
00:00:56.240 --> 00:01:02.240
That PLABCISCO01, this server way down
here is trying to ping 192.168.224.0.

18
00:01:02.240 --> 00:01:07.530
That's a route way up here in
this external cloud, right?

19
00:01:07.530 --> 00:01:12.380
So, it's kind of traveling across
the network on its way out to get there.

20
00:01:12.380 --> 00:01:14.160
All right, but it's telling me...

21
00:01:15.960 --> 00:01:17.150
This is on a VLAN, right?

22
00:01:17.150 --> 00:01:19.840
P Lab Cisco 01 is on a VLAN 16.

23
00:01:19.840 --> 00:01:24.190
And NYCORE2 has a bunch
of VLAN interfaces,

24
00:01:24.190 --> 00:01:27.070
or SVI, switch virtual interfaces.

25
00:01:27.070 --> 00:01:32.810
And the SVIs are not being advertised
into eigrp for some reason.

26
00:01:32.810 --> 00:01:37.330
So, it's not advertising them,
and NYWAN1 is not learning them.

27
00:01:37.330 --> 00:01:42.100
And as a result, my traffic might
make it all the way to NYWAN1, but

28
00:01:42.100 --> 00:01:47.010
NYWAN1 doesn't have a return path
to get back to my server, right?

29
00:01:47.010 --> 00:01:52.910
So, I need to find out why NYWAN1 is not
learning about my internal networks.

30
00:01:52.910 --> 00:01:57.080
And looking at this topology,
NYCORE2 is way down here.

31
00:01:57.080 --> 00:01:59.370
So, for NYWAN1 to learn,

32
00:01:59.370 --> 00:02:04.710
NYCORE2 has to advertise out to NYCORE1 or
NYEDGE2 or both.

33
00:02:04.710 --> 00:02:11.380
They have to advertise to NYEDGE1 and
then NYEDGE1 has to advertise to NYWAN1.

34
00:02:11.380 --> 00:02:14.660
And so, somewhere along that line,
we've got a break down.

35
00:02:14.660 --> 00:02:17.170
Now, the break down is
more than likely not here

36
00:02:17.170 --> 00:02:20.320
on NYCORE2 since that's
where the routes originate.

37
00:02:20.320 --> 00:02:24.840
If the problem was here, nobody would
be able to get to those networks.

38
00:02:24.840 --> 00:02:27.370
We can test that pretty easily
with a quick trace route.

39
00:02:27.370 --> 00:02:30.290
A trace route will show us kind of where
the breakdown is and that is where we

40
00:02:30.290 --> 00:02:33.210
can go an start to look so
that is exactly where i'm going to start.

41
00:02:33.210 --> 00:02:39.300
I'm going to jump over to my server and
we'll fire up a command prompt here and

42
00:02:39.300 --> 00:02:42.870
i'm just going to do a quick trace
route to see where this one dies out.

43
00:02:42.870 --> 00:02:45.800
So, I'm gonna ping all the way to
192.168.224.1 which is the IP they gave

44
00:02:45.800 --> 00:02:49.490
me in the troubleshooting ticket.

45
00:02:49.490 --> 00:02:51.380
The first hop will be my default gateway.

46
00:02:51.380 --> 00:02:54.160
And the way they've described it in
the troubleshooting ticket that should be

47
00:02:54.160 --> 00:02:55.760
NYCORE2.

48
00:02:55.760 --> 00:02:57.520
And so, we'll see if that comes up.

49
00:02:57.520 --> 00:03:00.440
I got 192.168.16.1.
While this is running,

50
00:03:00.440 --> 00:03:06.520
I'm gonna jump over to NYCORE2 And
verify that I P exists right here.

51
00:03:06.520 --> 00:03:10.240
So, I'm just going to do
a show i p interface brief and

52
00:03:10.240 --> 00:03:12.470
I'll exclude the unassigned interfaces.

53
00:03:12.470 --> 00:03:13.920
And I'm expecting to see 192.168.16.1 and
I do.

54
00:03:13.920 --> 00:03:17.360
So there it is right on that interface,
all right.

55
00:03:18.850 --> 00:03:22.590
So from there it should move
on to the other routers.

56
00:03:22.590 --> 00:03:24.230
Except I can see here.

57
00:03:24.230 --> 00:03:25.850
That it didn't.

58
00:03:25.850 --> 00:03:30.250
I made it to 192.168.16.1 and
I didn't get anywhere past that.

59
00:03:30.250 --> 00:03:33.760
That switch said destination
host unreachable.

60
00:03:33.760 --> 00:03:37.890
Right?
So it couldn't get to that network.

00:16:02.770 --> 00:16:05.740
So, I'm gonna turn that off.

281
00:16:05.740 --> 00:16:09.110
And then if I take a look
at that configuration again

282
00:16:10.750 --> 00:16:12.480
see how that whole command disappeared?

283
00:16:12.480 --> 00:16:15.100
That EIGRP stub connected summary
command is completely gone.

284
00:16:15.100 --> 00:16:18.930
And that's because the connected and
summary those are the defaults, right.

285
00:16:18.930 --> 00:16:20.630
That's what it's normally gonna do.

286
00:16:20.630 --> 00:16:21.840
And so that one's out.

287
00:16:21.840 --> 00:16:23.610
And let's see if that
takes care of our problem.

288
00:16:23.610 --> 00:16:28.150
This could just be an issue of EDGE2
not wanting to transit those routes

289
00:16:28.150 --> 00:16:31.490
even though they were internal,
which is odd but certainly could happen.

290
00:16:33.030 --> 00:16:36.480
When you change the stub status of
a router, all of its adjacencies drop, so

291
00:16:36.480 --> 00:16:38.780
I expected to see all these
neighbor relationships drop.

292
00:16:38.780 --> 00:16:43.780
Let's see if it came back up,
which it should have, there we go.

293
00:16:43.780 --> 00:16:50.830
And let's see if we got a route for
that 224, and we did.

294
00:16:50.830 --> 00:16:54.270
All right, so in this case, it being
flagged as a stub was enough to stop us.

295
00:16:54.270 --> 00:16:57.880
Now, EIGRP, you really, OSPF too,

296
00:16:57.880 --> 00:17:00.190
when you have stubs they do
get a little bit sensitive.

297
00:17:00.190 --> 00:17:03.280
It's supposed to filter out the external
routes so we don't have transit traffic

298
00:17:03.280 --> 00:17:06.620
but when you have nodes that don't match,
you can end up with a problem there too.

299
00:17:06.620 --> 00:17:08.370
Now, EIGRP is normally resilient for
that but

300
00:17:08.370 --> 00:17:10.680
in this case,
that is what our problem was.

301
00:17:10.680 --> 00:17:14.000
So, now we are learning that route and
we're in business.

302
00:17:14.000 --> 00:17:17.420
But, Let's not lose sight of
what our original problem was.

303
00:17:17.420 --> 00:17:19.500
I'm still working on the forward path.

304
00:17:19.500 --> 00:17:22.830
I now have the forward path
to get to 192.168.244,

305
00:17:22.830 --> 00:17:26.930
but if we revisit the original question,
it was telling me that

306
00:17:26.930 --> 00:17:31.690
NYWAN1 didn't have a return
path back to my routes.

307
00:17:31.690 --> 00:17:34.960
And so, I wouldn't be surprised if
we're still failing to communicate.

308
00:17:34.960 --> 00:17:36.930
So, let's jump over to the server.

309
00:17:38.430 --> 00:17:42.680
And I'm gonna retry that trace route and
we'll see how far we get this time.

310
00:17:42.680 --> 00:17:45.880
I should get past my first hop,
because it now has another route.

311
00:17:45.880 --> 00:17:50.940
I should hit and then we should hit and

312
00:17:50.940 --> 00:17:53.700
from there,
we should go directly over to NYWAN1.

313
00:17:53.700 --> 00:17:57.360
And it looks like I am hitting and
then we should NYWAN1.

314
00:17:57.360 --> 00:18:02.630
And if NYWAN1 has a return path,
then I'll get its information and

315
00:18:02.630 --> 00:18:06.460
we do so it looks like we've got
that return path present now also.

316
00:18:06.460 --> 00:18:10.990
So, let's just test out a straight
up ping and make sure we can get

317
00:18:10.990 --> 00:18:15.310
to the IP in question and then I
think we're going to be in business.

318
00:18:15.310 --> 00:18:16.790
And, sure enough, we are.

319
00:18:16.790 --> 00:18:21.920
So, in this scenario,
our main problem was that NYEDGE2

320
00:18:21.920 --> 00:18:26.580
was flagged as a stub, and so
it wasn't pushing those networks across.

321
00:18:26.580 --> 00:18:29.880
And, like I said, normally that
would just apply to external routes.

322
00:18:29.880 --> 00:18:32.620
In this case it was an internal
route that it wasn't

323
00:18:32.620 --> 00:18:34.310
pushing through to stop
that transit traffic.

324
00:18:34.310 --> 00:18:36.330
So, when we removed the stub,
that solved it.

325
00:18:36.330 --> 00:18:37.310
And now we're in business.

326
00:18:37.310 --> 00:18:41.380
So, kind of an odd one there, hard one
to track down, but we've solved it and

327
00:18:41.380 --> 00:18:42.590
now we can move on to our next one.

328
00:18:42.590 --> 00:18:45.080
So, all right that wraps up
this troubleshooting question.

329
00:18:45.080 --> 00:18:46.270
Hope you guys enjoyed it.

330
00:18:46.270 --> 00:18:52.087
Stay tuned, we've got more coming up,
all inside of Set 5, I'll see you then.

331
00:18:52.087 --> 00:18:56.629
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #4` from set #5. The trouble ticket states that "You are unable to communicate to 10.1.1.1 from either PLABCSCO01 or NYCORE2 "
episodes.title: Set 5 Issue 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.373
[SOUND]
All right,

2
00:00:08.373 --> 00:00:11.059
welcome back to another troubleshooting
episode here on ITproTV.

3
00:00:11.059 --> 00:00:13.585
We're gonna be jumping into
set five 5 Issue 4, and

4
00:00:13.585 --> 00:00:15.784
looks like we got a simple
on this time around.

5
00:00:15.784 --> 00:00:21.761
It says we are unable to communicate
with 10.1.1.1 from either PLABCISCO01 or

6
00:00:21.761 --> 00:00:25.585
NYCORE2, so
they give me a couple of devices here.

7
00:00:25.585 --> 00:00:29.883
So it sounds like we got a reachability
problem with whoever 10.1.1.1 is.

8
00:00:29.883 --> 00:00:33.866
Now, our biggest challenge is gonna be,
if we look at our documentation,

9
00:00:33.866 --> 00:00:35.774
I don't know who 10.1.1 is.

10
00:00:35.774 --> 00:00:38.927
I've got a pretty big network at
this point and there's a couple of

11
00:00:38.927 --> 00:00:42.150
networks documented up at the top
right and top left of the diagram.

12
00:00:42.150 --> 00:00:46.933
There's a few networks that are scattered
about, but none of them are 10.1.1.1.

13
00:00:46.933 --> 00:00:51.978
All they're telling me is that PLABSCO1,
this server down here, and NYCORE2,

14
00:00:51.978 --> 00:00:57.183
this switch over here, are not able to
get to whoever it is that 10.1.1.1 is.

15
00:00:57.183 --> 00:00:59.790
Now where do we start?

16
00:00:59.790 --> 00:01:01.380
Well, I'm just gonna start at NYCORE2.

17
00:01:01.380 --> 00:01:04.320
I could go to the Windows station,
but again,

18
00:01:04.320 --> 00:01:08.820
I'm thinking on a Cisco exam they're not
gonna expect me to fix a Windows problem.

19
00:01:08.820 --> 00:01:11.610
So I'm gonna jump to NYCORE2 and
we'll troubleshoot it from there.

20
00:01:11.610 --> 00:01:13.060
And if we can resolve the issue there,

21
00:01:13.060 --> 00:01:15.830
I bet we'll find that
the server is resolved also.

22
00:01:15.830 --> 00:01:16.913
So I'm gonna jump to NYCORE2, and

23
00:01:16.913 --> 00:01:19.670
I'll just see if I have some kind
of routes to get to this and

24
00:01:19.670 --> 00:01:23.120
we can follow the interfaces back to
figure out which ever host this is.

25
00:01:23.120 --> 00:01:30.185
So if I go over here to NYCORE2,
I can just do a quick show IP route for

26
00:01:30.185 --> 00:01:34.920
10.1.1.1 and
I don't have a route in the routing table.

27
00:01:34.920 --> 00:01:38.060
So that's not too convenient.

28
00:01:38.060 --> 00:01:41.650
If I do a show ip int brief,

29
00:01:41.650 --> 00:01:46.570
let's see if maybe it's like an interface
right here that we've shut down.

30
00:01:46.570 --> 00:01:50.700
And you know, let me redo that and
exclude all these unassigned interfaces,

31
00:01:50.700 --> 00:01:52.570
otherwise we get a ton of data.

32
00:01:52.570 --> 00:01:55.320
There we go, and we got something close.

33
00:01:55.320 --> 00:01:58.220
So what I was looking for was wondering if
it was an interface here that maybe was

34
00:01:58.220 --> 00:02:00.976
shut down, but
instead I see this guy right here.

35
00:02:00.976 --> 00:02:06.550
Fast Ethernet 1/0/24 10.1.1.2,
now I don't care how

36
00:02:06.550 --> 00:02:10.340
you subnet this thing, that's gonna be
the same network as whoever 10.1.1.1 is

37
00:02:10.340 --> 00:02:14.660
unless they do a slash 32, which isn't
going to happen on a physical interface.

38
00:02:14.660 --> 00:02:18.930
So that's more than
likely one end of a cable

39
00:02:18.930 --> 00:02:21.030
that's running to the hose
that's in question.

40
00:02:21.030 --> 00:02:23.035
In fact, if I look at the diagram,

41
00:02:23.035 --> 00:02:28.169
it shows where I've got these two layer 3
connections between NYCORE2 and NYCORE1.

42
00:02:28.169 --> 00:02:33.404
It looks like in this scenario,
port 24 is 10.1.1.2.

43
00:02:33.404 --> 00:02:39.440
I think it's probably safe to assume that
port 24 over here is 10.1.1.1 on NYCORE1.

44
00:02:39.440 --> 00:02:41.380
So let's go take a look,
maybe we'll luck out and

45
00:02:41.380 --> 00:02:43.500
that interface will just be shut down,
right?

46
00:02:43.500 --> 00:02:48.399
I know it's up up on this end, and if it's
a directly connected cable I imagine it's

47
00:02:48.399 --> 00:02:51.716
up on the other side, but
let's just go see what we have.

48
00:02:51.716 --> 00:02:56.277
So on this one I'm gonna do
a show ip interface brief, and

49
00:02:56.277 --> 00:03:01.897
I'm looking for port 24, and
sure enough it is 10.1.1.1.

50
00:03:01.897 --> 00:03:04.997
Unfortunately, I can see that it is up up.

51
00:03:04.997 --> 00:03:06.980
It is one of the few
times it's unfortunate.

52
00:03:06.980 --> 00:03:10.120
I was hoping that it would be down down,
or administratively down, and

53
00:03:10.120 --> 00:03:12.130
this question would be
over before we started.

54
00:03:12.130 --> 00:03:15.750
But it's up, and my end is up on NYCORE2.

55
00:03:15.750 --> 00:03:19.680
But it told me that NYCORE2 couldn't
ping this guy, so what's that all about?

56
00:03:19.680 --> 00:03:25.410
Well, let me go to CORE2, and
I'm gonna do a ping to 10.1.1.1, and

57
00:03:25.410 --> 00:03:30.360
I'll let one fail for ARP, and
then sure enough, it's continuing to fail.

58
00:03:30.360 --> 00:03:32.820
So if this is a point to point link,

59
00:03:32.820 --> 00:03:35.650
if I'm directly connected
to that other switch and

60
00:03:35.650 --> 00:03:40.770
I'm getting a failure like this, the IP
addresses are right next to each other.

61
00:03:40.770 --> 00:03:43.280
It doesn't make a whole heck
of a lot of sense, right?

62
00:03:43.280 --> 00:03:44.660
And let's try the other direction.

63
00:03:44.660 --> 00:03:49.080
If I go over to NYCORE1, I would
imagine this direction would fail also.

64
00:03:49.080 --> 00:03:55.650
If I ping 10.1.1.2, and
sure enough it's failing there, okay.

65
00:03:55.650 --> 00:03:58.340
So what can cause this to fail?

66
00:03:58.340 --> 00:04:02.220
Well, the interface might be up up, but
there might be something else going on.

67
00:04:02.220 --> 00:04:06.800
We could be error disabled or
UDLD could be doing something crazy.

68
00:04:06.800 --> 00:04:09.160
We could have mismatched VLANs.

69
00:04:09.160 --> 00:04:11.900
One side could be on VLAN five
the other side could be on VLAN ten,

70
00:04:11.900 --> 00:04:13.570
and now they don't match.

71
00:04:13.570 --> 00:04:16.750
Except in this case they're routed ports,
they're layer three ports, so

72
00:04:16.750 --> 00:04:18.510
we don't have VLANs, do we?

73
00:04:18.510 --> 00:04:21.120
So that rules out a VLAN issue.

74
00:04:21.120 --> 00:04:22.605
It actually rules out
a lot of layer two issues,

75
00:04:22.605 --> 00:04:26.080
cuz this is just a straight
up layer three connection.

76
00:04:26.080 --> 00:04:30.620
There is the potential that they're not
showing it here in the diagram, but

77
00:04:30.620 --> 00:04:32.170
there could be a device in between here.

78
00:04:32.170 --> 00:04:35.540
It might not be a direct connection,
but let's just assume it is.

79
00:04:35.540 --> 00:04:37.369
Let's start by looking
at those interfaces.

80
00:04:37.369 --> 00:04:42.396
So it's port 24 on both switches, and
I'll start here on core one and just do

81
00:04:42.396 --> 00:04:47.878
a show run for interface fa1/0/24, and
I can see that it sent to no switchport,

82
00:04:47.878 --> 00:04:53.209
so it's layer three, and it's got an IP
address of 10.1.1.1 with a subnet

83
00:04:53.209 --> 00:04:58.040
mask of 255.255.255.252,
so that's a /30 network.

84
00:04:58.040 --> 00:05:02.997
That means the network
consists of 10.1.1.1 and

85
00:05:02.997 --> 00:05:06.040
10.1.1.2, so that all looks right.

86
00:05:06.040 --> 00:05:09.520
I don't have a shutdown command, there's
no fancy access lists or route maps,

87
00:05:09.520 --> 00:05:12.200
any craziness like that, no policies.

88
00:05:12.200 --> 00:05:13.650
It's just an IP on an interface.

89
00:05:13.650 --> 00:05:16.232
You can't realy ask for anything simpler.

90
00:05:16.232 --> 00:05:18.560
All right, let me jump over to CORE2 and

91
00:05:18.560 --> 00:05:21.120
we'll verify we've got that
same basic configuration.

92
00:05:22.330 --> 00:05:24.140
I was actually expecting
something a lot worse.

93
00:05:24.140 --> 00:05:27.160
We could have had a port channel,
we could have had trunks,

94
00:05:27.160 --> 00:05:30.370
could have all sorts of stuff,
but we didn't.

95
00:05:30.370 --> 00:05:33.190
Oh, actually, well this one is
gonna trounce me not so bad.

96
00:05:33.190 --> 00:05:36.879
So here on this side, I can see I'm
no switchport, so I'm layer three.

97
00:05:36.879 --> 00:05:41.384
I've got the IP address, 10.1.1.2, but
look at that subnet mask, all right?

98
00:05:41.384 --> 00:05:48.680
That is a /31 subnet mask,
255.255.255.254.

99
00:05:48.680 --> 00:05:54.616
With that subnet mask,
what IPs does 10.1.1.2 contain?

100
00:05:54.616 --> 00:05:58.331
Well, technically it's got .2 and
.3, and that's it.

101
00:05:58.331 --> 00:06:00.620
Those are the two IPs that are in it.

102
00:06:00.620 --> 00:06:03.240
It doesn't have .1 in it.

103
00:06:03.240 --> 00:06:06.839
And so as far as it's concerned, the
device on the other end is on a different

104
00:06:06.839 --> 00:06:08.651
subnet, and we're not able to talk.

105
00:06:08.651 --> 00:06:13.509
So it looks like we have an incorrect
subnet mask here, which we should be able

106
00:06:13.509 --> 00:06:18.098
to fix pretty easily if we just jump
in here and reassign that IP address.

107
00:06:18.098 --> 00:06:24.180
So I'm going to reassign it, and we'll
put that back to a 252 like it should be.

108
00:06:26.600 --> 00:06:28.270
And we'll get out of that.

109
00:06:28.270 --> 00:06:33.260
And now that that one's set, there we go.

110
00:06:34.800 --> 00:06:40.600
I should be able to ping across and
there we go,

111
00:06:40.600 --> 00:06:44.230
and just to be on the safe side,
I'm going to double check on NYCORE1 and

112
00:06:44.230 --> 00:06:49.600
make sure that it can ping across also,
and now I got some connectivity.

113
00:06:49.600 --> 00:06:53.520
Okay, looks like this one was
simple just a bad subnet mask, but

114
00:06:53.520 --> 00:06:55.630
let's wait a second here,
cuz in the troubleshooting question,

115
00:06:55.630 --> 00:07:02.282
it mentioned I couldn't ping that IP
from either NYCORE2, or PLABCISCO01.

116
00:07:02.282 --> 00:07:06.265
Now, PLABCISCO01,
if I look at the diagram,

117
00:07:06.265 --> 00:07:11.505
it's on a different VLAN 192.168.16.10,
so I'll just probably look really easy,

118
00:07:11.505 --> 00:07:14.475
I could still have routing issues
stopping me from getting that network,

119
00:07:14.475 --> 00:07:18.985
so let's see if we can ping from that
server, even I was trying to dodge it.

120
00:07:18.985 --> 00:07:22.745
To really be complete here,
we're gonna have to make sure we can, so

121
00:07:22.745 --> 00:07:27.390
I'm gonna try and ping to 10.1.1.1,
and hopefully we'll get there.

122
00:07:27.390 --> 00:07:29.550
If not, we'll have a little bit
of routing troubleshooting to do.

123
00:07:29.550 --> 00:07:31.940
And, it's not looking good.

124
00:07:31.940 --> 00:07:32.910
Let's give it a second.

125
00:07:32.910 --> 00:07:33.820
I'm holding out hope.

126
00:07:34.860 --> 00:07:35.810
Yeah, it's not looking good.

127
00:07:35.810 --> 00:07:39.014
All right, so we still can't get there
from here so our work is not done.

128
00:07:39.014 --> 00:07:42.984
Now we've got to find out why
this guy can't get to 10.1.1.1.

129
00:07:42.984 --> 00:07:45.829
And I want to start just by
looking at my default gateway.

130
00:07:45.829 --> 00:07:49.472
My default gateway should be NYCORE2, and

131
00:07:49.472 --> 00:07:54.199
so if look up here I am 192.168.16.10, and

132
00:07:54.199 --> 00:07:58.540
my default gateway is 192.168.16.1.

133
00:07:58.540 --> 00:08:04.020
That is NYCORE2 so I've got this out of
my gateway, I should be getting there.

134
00:08:04.020 --> 00:08:07.660
All right, but
once I get there I'm dying out, right?

135
00:08:07.660 --> 00:08:10.540
So if I do a trace route to my IP,

136
00:08:10.540 --> 00:08:14.360
I should see that I get to
the first hop and then die out.

137
00:08:14.360 --> 00:08:19.380
Now, if NYCORE2 is directly
plugged into this network,

138
00:08:19.380 --> 00:08:21.870
how can I be dying out right there?

139
00:08:21.870 --> 00:08:24.970
Well, what's more than likely happening is
we're getting to the other side of that

140
00:08:24.970 --> 00:08:28.360
link and it just doesn't have
a return path back to us, right?

141
00:08:28.360 --> 00:08:32.283
So, I'm probably getting
all the way to NYCORE1.

142
00:08:32.283 --> 00:08:37.375
We're probably passing from our
server to NYACCESS1 up to NYCORE2 and

143
00:08:37.375 --> 00:08:41.548
over to NYCORE1, but
now it has never returned path back to

144
00:08:41.548 --> 00:08:46.405
192.168.16.10, and
it probably doesn't have one.

145
00:08:46.405 --> 00:08:50.131
So we probably just need to educate it and
then it'll be able to get back, and

146
00:08:50.131 --> 00:08:51.760
that'll fix our problem.

147
00:08:51.760 --> 00:08:53.010
But, it could be something else.

148
00:08:53.010 --> 00:08:54.390
There could be an ACL blocking it.

149
00:08:54.390 --> 00:08:56.940
There could be other things, but
we need to continue to troubleshoot here.

150
00:08:56.940 --> 00:09:01.920
All right, so back at my server, yeah,
I can see it just dies out right there.

151
00:09:01.920 --> 00:09:03.790
And so, we'll stop that.

152
00:09:03.790 --> 00:09:06.140
And let's jump back over to CORE2.

153
00:09:07.480 --> 00:09:09.406
Let's jump over to CORE1 and
get an idea here.

154
00:09:09.406 --> 00:09:11.426
I wanna make sure I actually
don't have that route.

155
00:09:11.426 --> 00:09:16.405
So I'm gonna do a show IP route for
192.168.16.10 to see if I have a way back

156
00:09:16.405 --> 00:09:19.190
to get to that server,
and I don't, all right?

157
00:09:19.190 --> 00:09:21.200
So I need to get a route.

158
00:09:21.200 --> 00:09:22.270
There's a couple of ways I could that.

159
00:09:22.270 --> 00:09:24.222
I could do a static route,
that would be the easiest.

160
00:09:24.222 --> 00:09:26.930
Throw a static route need it to be done.

161
00:09:26.930 --> 00:09:29.590
Maybe we're running a dynamic routing
protocol and we can learn it that way.

162
00:09:29.590 --> 00:09:32.715
So I'll do show IP protocols and
we're see what we're running.

163
00:09:32.715 --> 00:09:34.642
I am running a routing protocol,
looks like I'm running two.

164
00:09:34.642 --> 00:09:38.490
So I've got ospf ten and
I've got eigrp 800.

165
00:09:38.490 --> 00:09:41.590
So I got two different routing protocols,
and

166
00:09:41.590 --> 00:09:47.710
if I do a show IP eigrp neighbor,
I don't have any eigrp neighbors.

167
00:09:47.710 --> 00:09:54.569
If I do a show ip ospf neighbor, I do have
an ospf neighbor, and it's 192.168.1.1.

168
00:09:54.569 --> 00:09:56.270
I don't really know who that is and

169
00:09:56.270 --> 00:09:58.860
my documentation hasn't
been too helpful on that.

170
00:09:58.860 --> 00:10:01.120
So, let me just see if
that happens to be CORE2.

171
00:10:01.120 --> 00:10:06.710
So I'm gonna pull off its
list of IP addresses,

172
00:10:06.710 --> 00:10:09.400
and oh, it's not CORE2, all right.

173
00:10:09.400 --> 00:10:11.140
So I got two different routing protocols,

174
00:10:11.140 --> 00:10:13.880
neither of which have
an adjacency with CORE2.

175
00:10:13.880 --> 00:10:17.270
And on CORE2,
let's see what protocols are running here.

176
00:10:17.270 --> 00:10:20.160
If we have some overlap I'll use that,
oh we do, this guy.

177
00:10:20.160 --> 00:10:26.380
So this guy's running routing protocol
eigrp 800, and that's it, just eigrp 800.

178
00:10:26.380 --> 00:10:28.850
And NYCORE1 was running eigrp 800.

179
00:10:28.850 --> 00:10:32.040
So, since they're both running
that routing protocol, if

180
00:10:32.040 --> 00:10:36.290
I build an adjacency between them, then we
should start learning these networks and

181
00:10:36.290 --> 00:10:37.530
be able to communicate across it.

182
00:10:37.530 --> 00:10:40.390
So that could solve our problem right
there, if we just bring that in.

183
00:10:40.390 --> 00:10:43.470
All right, now when I look at
my routing statements here,

184
00:10:43.470 --> 00:10:46.600
see how I'm already routing for 10.1.1.0?

185
00:10:46.600 --> 00:10:51.569
But I'm routing for it as a /31,
and that's not right.

186
00:10:51.569 --> 00:10:55.168
I'm a /30 on this one, right?

187
00:10:55.168 --> 00:11:00.330
And if I look at NYCORE1, and
we go back to its eigrp configuration,

188
00:11:00.330 --> 00:11:05.550
it shows that it's routing for
networks 10.1.1.0/30.

189
00:11:05.550 --> 00:11:10.170
So I've fixed the subnet mask
issue on that interface, but

190
00:11:10.170 --> 00:11:13.828
it looks like the subnet mask is
wrong in the routing protocol also.

191
00:11:13.828 --> 00:11:18.699
So that /31 carried over there,
so I need to fix that,

192
00:11:18.699 --> 00:11:22.869
and we can spot that in
our eigrp configuration.

193
00:11:22.869 --> 00:11:25.878
Sure enough, right here,
they've just got that network defined and

194
00:11:25.878 --> 00:11:28.534
the wildcard mask is wrong for
it, so we just need to fix that.

195
00:11:28.534 --> 00:11:33.984
So we can get into router eiqrp 800 and
I can do a no network

196
00:11:33.984 --> 00:11:39.870
10.1.1.0 0.0.0.1 to get
that one out of there.

197
00:11:39.870 --> 00:11:45.487
And then I can do a network 10.1.1.0
0.0.0.2 and that'll get us put,

198
00:11:45.487 --> 00:11:49.530
well actually wait a minute,

199
00:11:49.530 --> 00:11:54.150
that was a 252,
I need a .3 on that one, don't I?

200
00:11:55.820 --> 00:11:59.690
So, we can put that one in there, and
now I see an adjacency come up, so

201
00:11:59.690 --> 00:12:00.380
that's a good sign.

202
00:12:00.380 --> 00:12:02.580
And I just want to make sure
I didn't do bad math there.

203
00:12:02.580 --> 00:12:07.222
So I'm going to do show IP protocol make
sure I got a /30 on that network and I do.

204
00:12:07.222 --> 00:12:10.224
Good, all right, so,
we've got that /30 in place and

205
00:12:10.224 --> 00:12:12.875
we should be exchanging
routes with the other guy.

206
00:12:12.875 --> 00:12:18.232
So let's go see if NYCORE1 has
the route that it needs for

207
00:12:18.232 --> 00:12:23.820
192.168.16.10, and it's got a route.

208
00:12:23.820 --> 00:12:30.130
And I bet that'll solve our problem, let's
jump back to our server, and we'll see

209
00:12:30.130 --> 00:12:35.712
if we can ping now, so if I do that ping
to 10.1.1.1, sure enough, there we go.

210
00:12:35.712 --> 00:12:39.280
All right, so I had to fix the subnet
mask on the interface, and

211
00:12:39.280 --> 00:12:43.460
I had to fix the wildcard mask on the
route being advertised out in eqigrp, and

212
00:12:43.460 --> 00:12:47.840
once we had that fixed, now NYCORE1
had the routes it needed, NYCORE2

213
00:12:47.840 --> 00:12:52.860
was able to communicate with NYCORE1, And
PLABCISCO01 was able to ping through it.

214
00:12:52.860 --> 00:12:54.370
All of the issues on
the ticket are resolved,

215
00:12:54.370 --> 00:12:56.100
and that's going to wrap this one up.

216
00:12:56.100 --> 00:12:58.880
All right, well that's another
troubleshooting ticket under our belt.

217
00:12:58.880 --> 00:13:01.763
We still have a few more to tackle
before we're done with Set 5, so

218
00:13:01.763 --> 00:13:02.754
stay tuned for those.

219
00:13:02.754 --> 00:13:05.563
But that wraps this one up, and
I hope to see you next time.

220
00:13:05.563 --> 00:13:06.617
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #5` from set #5. The trouble ticket states that "You are unable to ping 172.88.88.1 which is a loopback on NYWAN1 from PLABCSCO01 "
episodes.title: Set 5 Issue 5
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.129
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.587 --> 00:00:11.004
All right, it's time for
set five, issue five.

3
00:00:11.004 --> 00:00:12.640
We've got another
troubleshooting ticket here.

4
00:00:12.640 --> 00:00:14.800
Let's dive into it and
see if we can cause or

5
00:00:14.800 --> 00:00:16.963
what kind of trouble
we can get into today.

6
00:00:16.963 --> 00:00:23.730
[LAUGH] We've got, you are unable to ping
172.88.88.1, that's a new IP for us.

7
00:00:23.730 --> 00:00:28.421
Which is a loopback on
NYWAN1 from PLABCSCO01.

8
00:00:28.421 --> 00:00:29.129
All right, good.

9
00:00:29.129 --> 00:00:30.856
Well at least they told us
where the IP was this time,

10
00:00:30.856 --> 00:00:32.129
we didn't have to hunt around for it.

11
00:00:32.129 --> 00:00:33.821
If we take a look at NYWAN1,

12
00:00:33.821 --> 00:00:38.890
it's gonna have an IP 172.88.88.1
on a loopback interface.

13
00:00:38.890 --> 00:00:42.090
And we've got PLABCSCO01, our server,
that just needs to be able to ping it and

14
00:00:42.090 --> 00:00:43.600
apparently that's not working.

15
00:00:43.600 --> 00:00:47.460
So if we look at our topology, we can kind
of get an idea of what we're looking at.

16
00:00:47.460 --> 00:00:50.990
Now from our previous troubleshooting
tickets here in set five,

17
00:00:50.990 --> 00:00:55.300
we know that we've got EIGRP 800 that's
running on most of this equipment.

18
00:00:55.300 --> 00:00:58.030
And so
when PLABCSCO hits its default gateway,

19
00:00:58.030 --> 00:01:03.370
NYCORE2, there should be a route for
the 172.88.88 network.

20
00:01:03.370 --> 00:01:08.198
And that should send us up to EDGE1, which
EDGE1 has an undocumented connection to

21
00:01:08.198 --> 00:01:10.649
WAN1 that we found in the earlier ticket.

22
00:01:10.649 --> 00:01:14.990
And then once we get to WAN1,
it's a loopback interface right there.

23
00:01:14.990 --> 00:01:19.360
So we should be able to do that,
right, assuming the route exists.

24
00:01:19.360 --> 00:01:22.170
Now because there's enough
devices in the mix here,

25
00:01:22.170 --> 00:01:25.250
I wanna use trace route to figure
out where this network is dying or

26
00:01:25.250 --> 00:01:27.010
missing and
where were having that problem.

27
00:01:27.010 --> 00:01:29.920
And so we'll kinda jump through the steps
here to figure out where that is.

28
00:01:29.920 --> 00:01:34.421
I'm gonna start down on my server,
where we can do the trace route.

29
00:01:34.421 --> 00:01:36.587
So I'm gonna start just by
doing a quick ping, right.

30
00:01:36.587 --> 00:01:41.683
I'm gonna ping 172.88.88.1, and
I get destination host unreachable,

31
00:01:41.683 --> 00:01:45.647
and I'm getting that
response from 192.168.16.1,

32
00:01:45.647 --> 00:01:48.660
that's my default gateway, that's NYCORE2.

33
00:01:48.660 --> 00:01:51.630
If I do a trace route to 127.88.88.1,
it's just gonna

34
00:01:53.160 --> 00:01:58.090
die off at that first hop,
I really didn't need to do a trace route

35
00:01:58.090 --> 00:02:01.350
here cuz I know I got that
reply from my gateway.

36
00:02:01.350 --> 00:02:03.930
All right, so
I'm dying right at my first hop.

37
00:02:03.930 --> 00:02:10.080
So NYCORE2 most likely doesn't have
a route to the 172.88.88 network.

38
00:02:10.080 --> 00:02:13.710
So now we need to start tracing that
back to figure out where the failure is.

39
00:02:13.710 --> 00:02:15.129
I can verify it doesn't have a route.

40
00:02:15.129 --> 00:02:20.892
If I jump over to NYCORE2,
and I do a show ip route,

41
00:02:20.892 --> 00:02:29.050
and I'll include 172.88.88,
and it's got nothing.

42
00:02:29.050 --> 00:02:34.180
Let me just punch it in like this,
we'll do it a slightly different way.

43
00:02:34.180 --> 00:02:35.330
There we go, subnet not in table.

44
00:02:35.330 --> 00:02:37.060
All right, so I don't have a route.

45
00:02:37.060 --> 00:02:41.010
And if I do a show ip eigrp neighbor,

46
00:02:41.010 --> 00:02:43.420
I can see those neighbor
relationships that I have.

47
00:02:43.420 --> 00:02:48.690
One with NYCORE1, but
the other ones are connections to NYEDGE2.

48
00:02:48.690 --> 00:02:50.490
So that's the connection
between NYCORE2 and

49
00:02:50.490 --> 00:02:52.610
EDGE2 that we fixed in an earlier ticket.

50
00:02:52.610 --> 00:02:54.410
And I know that EDGE2
is connected to WAN1,

51
00:02:54.410 --> 00:02:56.490
which we also fixed in an earlier ticket.

52
00:02:56.490 --> 00:02:58.360
So that's where I should
be learning the route from.

53
00:02:58.360 --> 00:03:01.220
Let's go see if EDGE2 has that route,
I doubt it does.

54
00:03:01.220 --> 00:03:05.552
So if I look at EDGE2,
we can get into this system and

55
00:03:05.552 --> 00:03:09.592
do a show ip route 172.88.88.1, and

56
00:03:09.592 --> 00:03:13.547
it doesn't have the route either,
all right.

57
00:03:13.547 --> 00:03:15.422
It might have a gateway of last resort,
I don't know, but

58
00:03:15.422 --> 00:03:18.430
it doesn't have that route and
that's what's important to me, all right.

59
00:03:18.430 --> 00:03:22.750
So if it doesn't have the route,
that takes us all the way back to NYWAN1.

60
00:03:22.750 --> 00:03:28.210
This interface is on NYWAN1,
it's supposed to be teaching us about it.

61
00:03:28.210 --> 00:03:32.670
Whoops and [LAUGH],
I'm gonna do a little typo there.

62
00:03:32.670 --> 00:03:38.820
See this is where you do the no IP domain
lookup, you kind of turn off that lookup.

63
00:03:38.820 --> 00:03:42.046
You don't have to sit here and
wait for this to error out.

64
00:03:42.046 --> 00:03:45.212
And Ctrl+Shift+6 is not working for
me today.

65
00:03:45.212 --> 00:03:47.660
Well, we'll give that a second
while it errors out, there we go.

66
00:03:47.660 --> 00:03:52.110
And I'm gonna do a quick
show IP interface brief,

67
00:03:52.110 --> 00:03:57.990
this guy is supposed to have 172.88.88.1
according to the troubleshooting ticket.

68
00:03:57.990 --> 00:04:01.910
And I see some that are close, it said it
was a loopback, so let's keep looking,

69
00:04:01.910 --> 00:04:03.570
and there it is.

70
00:04:03.570 --> 00:04:07.940
So we've got 172.88.88.1 right there.

71
00:04:07.940 --> 00:04:12.020
And if I keep looking
at my screen [LAUGH],

72
00:04:12.020 --> 00:04:15.740
this might be a really easy ticket for
us, it's administratively down.

73
00:04:15.740 --> 00:04:17.430
I don't care what routing
protocol you're running,

74
00:04:17.430 --> 00:04:21.250
we're not gonna advertise a route if
the interface is administratively down.

75
00:04:21.250 --> 00:04:22.670
This one appears to be shut down,

76
00:04:22.670 --> 00:04:25.710
I'll bet our problem is as
limited as that, all right.

77
00:04:25.710 --> 00:04:28.690
But before I turn that on, I'm just
gonna double check one other thing,

78
00:04:28.690 --> 00:04:32.370
I wanna look at my EIGRP configuration and

79
00:04:32.370 --> 00:04:36.910
just see if that network is even a part
of EIGRP and I can see that it is.

80
00:04:36.910 --> 00:04:39.640
So it's actively part of EIGRP so

81
00:04:39.640 --> 00:04:41.980
it should be advertised
out as long as it's up.

82
00:04:41.980 --> 00:04:44.940
What I was kind of expecting to find here
was like a redistribute connected with

83
00:04:44.940 --> 00:04:46.920
a route map to make it all complex.

84
00:04:46.920 --> 00:04:49.180
But this one, it's just right there.

85
00:04:49.180 --> 00:04:51.380
So if we get in and
turn that interface on,

86
00:04:51.380 --> 00:04:55.890
which I guess I should have looked at what
the loopback number was, it was Loopback1.

87
00:04:55.890 --> 00:04:58.820
So if I get into Loopback1 and
do a no shutdown,

88
00:04:58.820 --> 00:05:03.200
loopbacks are always up unless you issue
the shutdown command, which somebody did.

89
00:05:03.200 --> 00:05:06.040
So when I do a no shutdown,
that should come up.

90
00:05:06.040 --> 00:05:09.120
And I'm not getting any output
on my screen which means

91
00:05:09.120 --> 00:05:10.810
console logging is probably off.

92
00:05:10.810 --> 00:05:13.880
So let me do a show IP
interface brief again and

93
00:05:13.880 --> 00:05:18.730
just make sure that loopback interface did
come up and I can see that it is up up.

94
00:05:18.730 --> 00:05:19.752
So I'm good there.

95
00:05:19.752 --> 00:05:23.930
And EIGRP should run with that,
it should take it, advertise it out, and

96
00:05:23.930 --> 00:05:27.720
it should start passing across the lines
so I can follow the path back if I want.

97
00:05:27.720 --> 00:05:32.150
I get in to NYEDGE2 which didn't have
a route just a few moments ago and

98
00:05:32.150 --> 00:05:35.250
if I do a show ip route, now it does.

99
00:05:35.250 --> 00:05:40.480
And if I jump over to NYCORE2,
it didn't have a route either,

100
00:05:40.480 --> 00:05:45.400
and so, now if I do that show ip route
again, I can see it has a route.

101
00:05:45.400 --> 00:05:48.810
And if I jump all the way back to my
server that wasn't able to ping in

102
00:05:48.810 --> 00:05:52.720
the very beginning, now, I can ping.

103
00:05:52.720 --> 00:05:55.190
This actually turned out to be a pretty
straightforward troubleshooting

104
00:05:55.190 --> 00:05:56.230
ticket for us.

105
00:05:56.230 --> 00:05:58.831
So on this one,
we weren't able to ping an IP and

106
00:05:58.831 --> 00:06:03.324
it's because the interface where that
router originated from was shut down, and

107
00:06:03.324 --> 00:06:06.796
if it's shut down,
it's not going to be able to advertise it.

108
00:06:06.796 --> 00:06:10.452
Remember, the thing I always
remember is you'll never

109
00:06:10.452 --> 00:06:14.830
advertise a route unless it's
in your own routing table.

110
00:06:14.830 --> 00:06:17.660
So if I'm a router and
I've got 20 interfaces and

111
00:06:17.660 --> 00:06:20.740
I'm learning stuff, if I have routes
that I don't put in my own routing table

112
00:06:20.740 --> 00:06:22.110
I'm not gonna advertise them.

113
00:06:22.110 --> 00:06:23.850
So if interfaces are shut down or

114
00:06:23.850 --> 00:06:26.010
if administrative distances
override something.

115
00:06:26.010 --> 00:06:30.970
If I use a policy based routing,
or whatever, to remove a route,

116
00:06:30.970 --> 00:06:34.270
any of that kind of stuff will
affect what I'm gonna advertise out.

117
00:06:34.270 --> 00:06:35.910
So in this case, it was that simple.

118
00:06:35.910 --> 00:06:38.730
We did a no shut down on the interface,
the interface came healthy and

119
00:06:38.730 --> 00:06:42.370
went into that router's routing table,
now it advertised it out,

120
00:06:42.370 --> 00:06:43.828
everybody else learned it, and we're done.

121
00:06:43.828 --> 00:06:47.290
So it's straightforward, knocked it out,
and we can wrap this one up.

122
00:06:47.290 --> 00:06:49.330
All right, so
that takes care of issue number five.

123
00:06:49.330 --> 00:06:51.990
We still have two more issues with set
five, they're gonna come up next, so

124
00:06:51.990 --> 00:06:53.750
definitely stay tuned for that.

125
00:06:53.750 --> 00:06:58.712
Hope you guys enjoyed this one and
I'll see you for the next.

126
00:06:58.712 --> 00:07:03.739
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #6` from set #5. The trouble ticket states that "You are unable to ping from PLABCSCO01 to 150.100.50.1, also a loopback on NYWAN1 "
episodes.title: Set 5 Issue 6
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.058 --> 00:00:05.100
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.475 --> 00:00:12.222
All right welcome back to another
troubleshooting episode here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.222 --> 00:00:15.490
We're gonna be jumping into
set five issue number six.

4
00:00:15.490 --> 00:00:17.460
We're kind of getting down
to the end of set five.

5
00:00:17.460 --> 00:00:20.260
And we've got a troubleshooting
ticket that's actually eerily

6
00:00:20.260 --> 00:00:22.740
similar to issue number five.

7
00:00:22.740 --> 00:00:27.898
This one says,
you are unable to ping from PLABCISCO01 to

8
00:00:27.898 --> 00:00:33.380
150.100.50.1, which is
a loopback on NYWAN1.

9
00:00:33.380 --> 00:00:36.569
Well the last issue was that we
couldn't ping a loopback on NYWAN1, and

10
00:00:36.569 --> 00:00:38.046
it turned out to be easy, right?

11
00:00:38.046 --> 00:00:39.930
The interface was shut down.

12
00:00:39.930 --> 00:00:41.357
Maybe we get lucky on this one, right?

13
00:00:41.357 --> 00:00:44.748
In fact, let's just jump and double-check
that before we dive too deep into this.

14
00:00:44.748 --> 00:00:47.607
I'm gonna go and
pull up NYWAN1 real quick.

15
00:00:47.607 --> 00:00:52.214
And I just wanna verify that,
that interface is on.

16
00:00:52.214 --> 00:00:59.328
So I'm gonna do show IP interface brief,
and find Loopback0 is 150.100.50.1.

17
00:00:59.328 --> 00:01:01.140
And well, it's up, up.

18
00:01:01.140 --> 00:01:04.230
All right so, it's not as simple as
an interface being shut down this time,

19
00:01:04.230 --> 00:01:06.320
we're gonna have a little
bit more work to do.

20
00:01:06.320 --> 00:01:10.795
So what they're telling us is
that PLABCISCO01 is unable

21
00:01:10.795 --> 00:01:15.008
to ping this loop back
interface right here on NYWAN1.

22
00:01:15.008 --> 00:01:18.366
And if we remember from our
previous tickets here in set five,

23
00:01:18.366 --> 00:01:23.270
the path that we follow PLABCISCO01
has a default gateway of NYCORE2.

24
00:01:23.270 --> 00:01:28.208
NYCORE2 is using EIGRP to
exchange routes with NYEDGE2.

25
