I'll do a route-map PBR permit 10, so

244
00:13:36.381 --> 00:13:41.576
I'm going to edit line 10,
and I'm going to say set

245
00:13:41.576 --> 00:13:47.367
ip next-hop 172.16.1.2, instead of 1.1.

246
00:13:47.367 --> 00:13:51.810
All right, now this should override
the existing next-hop command.

247
00:13:51.810 --> 00:13:53.740
But just to be sure,

248
00:13:53.740 --> 00:13:59.450
I'm gonna do a show route-map PBR and
make sure that took effect.

249
00:13:59.450 --> 00:14:02.410
And I'm glad I checked
because see what it's doing?

250
00:14:02.410 --> 00:14:06.899
It's now got two next-hops, and
that can cause some problems, so

251
00:14:06.899 --> 00:14:08.648
I actually need to do a no.

252
00:14:12.428 --> 00:14:13.972
And let's remove that one and

253
00:14:13.972 --> 00:14:17.320
make sure the route map actually
updated to reflect what I want.

254
00:14:17.320 --> 00:14:17.890
There we go.

255
00:14:17.890 --> 00:14:20.878
Now it's just got a next-hop of .2.

256
00:14:20.878 --> 00:14:23.876
All right, so once that's in place,
now all our traffic should be getting sent

257
00:14:23.876 --> 00:14:26.710
to the right direction,
let's see if that solved our problem.

258
00:14:26.710 --> 00:14:31.740
I'm gonna go all the way back to our
server from the very beginning, and

259
00:14:31.740 --> 00:14:35.500
I'll try to ping that IP,
and now we've got a success.

260
00:14:35.500 --> 00:14:38.470
So in this case, we had a policy based
route that was influencing it, and

261
00:14:38.470 --> 00:14:39.320
kind of damaging things.

262
00:14:39.320 --> 00:14:43.120
Now, in real life land I probably would
have just set up a dynamic routing

263
00:14:43.120 --> 00:14:46.180
protocol and taken care of this, but
because the question told us not to mess

264
00:14:46.180 --> 00:14:49.580
with any static routes, I mean mess with
the routing table, I couldn't do that.

265
00:14:49.580 --> 00:14:52.850
And that's what got me on the line of
thinking PBR, the policy-based routing.

266
00:14:52.850 --> 00:14:55.980
We found a bad route in there, fixed it,
and now the problem is solved.

267
00:14:55.980 --> 00:14:58.440
So that wraps this one up,
a little bit convoluted,

268
00:14:58.440 --> 00:15:01.330
there was more than one way to solve
that problem, that's for certain.

269
00:15:01.330 --> 00:15:03.480
But I think we solved it in
the spirit of the question and

270
00:15:03.480 --> 00:15:05.630
kind of got it solved
the way they wanted it to.

271
00:15:05.630 --> 00:15:07.310
So that kind of took care of that one.

272
00:15:07.310 --> 00:15:09.990
And now, we're ready to move on to
our final troubleshooting question.

273
00:15:09.990 --> 00:15:11.298
So that wraps up issue six.

274
00:15:11.298 --> 00:15:15.958
Stay tuned, we've got issue
number seven coming up next.

275
00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:22.509
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #7` from set #5. The trouble ticket states that "There are no routes for the connected interfaces on NYCORE1 across the network. Therefore we are unable to communicate to hosts on those VLANs, for example you are unable to ping 192.168.5.1 which is SVI 5 on NYCORE1 from PLABCSCO01 "
episodes.title: Set 5 Issue 7
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.984
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.381 --> 00:00:11.620
Welcome back to another troubleshooting
ticket here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.620 --> 00:00:15.510
We're gonna be jumping into Set 5,
Issue 7, the final issue for Set 5.

4
00:00:15.510 --> 00:00:19.320
And once this is done,
our Set 5 topology should be perfect and

5
00:00:19.320 --> 00:00:21.370
everything running nice and smoothly.

6
00:00:21.370 --> 00:00:23.270
Let's look at this troubleshooting ticket.

7
00:00:23.270 --> 00:00:25.830
This one says, there are no routes for

8
00:00:25.830 --> 00:00:29.610
the connected interfaces on
NYCORE1 around the network.

9
00:00:29.610 --> 00:00:32.090
So, we've got some
connected interfaces there.

10
00:00:32.090 --> 00:00:34.530
It's a switch so
there'd be VLAN interfaces, and

11
00:00:34.530 --> 00:00:36.870
none of the other devices
seem to know about it.

12
00:00:36.870 --> 00:00:39.730
Therefore, we are unable to
communicate to host on those VLANs.

13
00:00:39.730 --> 00:00:43.910
For example,
you are unable to ping 192.168.5.1.

14
00:00:43.910 --> 00:00:48.930
Which is one of the SVI's on
NYCORE1 from PLABCISCO01.

15
00:00:48.930 --> 00:00:50.770
So, this sounds cut and dry.

16
00:00:50.770 --> 00:00:53.980
Sounds like I've got some interfaces
that are on networks that are not being

17
00:00:53.980 --> 00:00:57.140
advertised into my routing protocol and
we can go and figure that out and

18
00:00:57.140 --> 00:00:58.160
see pretty quick.

19
00:00:58.160 --> 00:01:02.040
Looking at our topology, let's pull
this up, our topology doesn't show it,

20
00:01:02.040 --> 00:01:06.610
but we've seen through all of our
earlier tickets that NYCORE1, NYCORE2,

21
00:01:06.610 --> 00:01:09.090
EDGE1, EDGE2, NYWAN1.

22
00:01:09.090 --> 00:01:11.210
They're all in EIGRP 800.

23
00:01:11.210 --> 00:01:15.620
So, they're all operating in
that same autonomous system,

24
00:01:15.620 --> 00:01:17.360
they should know about
each other's routes.

25
00:01:17.360 --> 00:01:20.480
And we know we're exchanging routes again
from some of the earlier tickets where

26
00:01:20.480 --> 00:01:21.970
we've solved those problems.

27
00:01:21.970 --> 00:01:26.200
So, we should be learning about all
the routes, but we aren't, right?

28
00:01:26.200 --> 00:01:30.190
So, what's more than likely happening
is either NYCORE1 is not advertising

29
00:01:30.190 --> 00:01:34.740
the routes, that would do it,
or we've got some kind of

30
00:01:34.740 --> 00:01:38.200
filters that are blocking the routes from
propagating to the rest of the network.

31
00:01:38.200 --> 00:01:42.060
There's a few different scenarios there
that could occur, so let's go in and see.

32
00:01:42.060 --> 00:01:44.940
I'm just gonna jump right into NYCORE1
cuz I feel like that's more than

33
00:01:44.940 --> 00:01:46.730
likely gonna be our issue.

34
00:01:46.730 --> 00:01:48.990
So, looking at NYCORE1,

35
00:01:48.990 --> 00:01:54.980
what I wanna do is I wanna get a handle on
the networks that they're taking about.

36
00:01:54.980 --> 00:01:58.071
They said there's some directly
connected networks, so

37
00:01:58.071 --> 00:02:02.498
that means I should have them with IPs and
so I'm gonna do a show IP interface brief.

38
00:02:02.498 --> 00:02:04.080
And here's 192.168.5, 6, 7, 8, 9.

39
00:02:04.080 --> 00:02:08.886
All right, we've seen other VLANS,
VLANS 10 through 16,

40
00:02:08.886 --> 00:02:11.120
and those have been working.

41
00:02:11.120 --> 00:02:15.110
Those have been spread
throughout our network.

42
00:02:15.110 --> 00:02:18.350
But looking down this list I'm seeing
some that I haven't seen before.

43
00:02:18.350 --> 00:02:18.850
Right?

44
00:02:18.850 --> 00:02:19.930
And they are up, up.

45
00:02:19.930 --> 00:02:22.270
All of these are up, up and functioning.

46
00:02:22.270 --> 00:02:23.900
So it looks like they're healthy.

47
00:02:23.900 --> 00:02:28.360
And if I jump over to NYCORE2,
which is one of our neighbors.

48
00:02:28.360 --> 00:02:34.040
And I do a show IP route for
any of the 192s.

49
00:02:34.040 --> 00:02:36.560
Right?
So I'll just look for 192.168.

50
00:02:36.560 --> 00:02:41.448
If I look in here,
I can see 192.168.16 and .17, .226, but

51
00:02:41.448 --> 00:02:43.980
I don't see .5, .6, .7, .8.

52
00:02:43.980 --> 00:02:49.743
I don't see all those other networks
that they were talking about.

53
00:02:49.743 --> 00:02:53.905
So, what I need to do is find out
why I'm not getting those networks.

54
00:02:53.905 --> 00:02:55.935
And this could be a neighbor problem, or

55
00:02:55.935 --> 00:02:57.375
it could be that they're
not being advertised.

56
00:02:57.375 --> 00:03:01.085
I'm going to take a look at my
eigrp configuration real quick and

57
00:03:01.085 --> 00:03:03.505
just see if that's where our problem is.

58
00:03:03.505 --> 00:03:05.265
I expect to see those
networks be advertised.

59
00:03:05.265 --> 00:03:11.150
And when I look at it I can see eigrp 800,
I can see that it's up and going.

60
00:03:11.150 --> 00:03:15.020
It's routing for network 10.1.1.0, and

61
00:03:15.020 --> 00:03:19.896
it is passive-interface default,
the only non-passive-interface is port 24.

62
00:03:19.896 --> 00:03:26.020
Okay, well port 24, that's this
connection right here to NYCORE2 and

63
00:03:26.020 --> 00:03:29.730
that's where my neighbor should be so I
should have a neighbor relationship there.

64
00:03:29.730 --> 00:03:34.600
Let's just verify that there real
quick with a show IP eigrp neighbor.

65
00:03:36.920 --> 00:03:39.099
If I spell eigrp right, that'll help.

66
00:03:40.740 --> 00:03:41.750
There we go.

67
00:03:41.750 --> 00:03:43.520
And so I do have a neighbor, 10.1.1.2.

68
00:03:43.520 --> 00:03:46.220
And we saw in an earlier
ticket that that is NYCORE2.

69
00:03:46.220 --> 00:03:49.730
So I've got a neighbor, and
it's not a passive-interface so,

70
00:03:49.730 --> 00:03:53.080
I am talking with them and I'm only
doing network 10.1.1.0, all right.

71
00:03:53.080 --> 00:03:57.050
So it looks like this is
going to be a simple case of

72
00:03:57.050 --> 00:03:59.050
we're not advertising the networks right.

73
00:03:59.050 --> 00:04:01.200
So, how do I wanna advertise the networks?

74
00:04:01.200 --> 00:04:02.780
I gotta couple of choices, right.

75
00:04:02.780 --> 00:04:06.460
One I can add them directly into
eigrp with a network statement.

76
00:04:06.460 --> 00:04:08.820
So I can just say network blah,
blah, blah.

77
00:04:08.820 --> 00:04:12.790
Or I could redistribute them in,
redistribute connected routes into it.

78
00:04:12.790 --> 00:04:16.270
Now when I look at the question
it says there are no routes for

79
00:04:16.270 --> 00:04:19.610
the connected interfaces on NYCORE1.

80
00:04:19.610 --> 00:04:22.200
So, I can look at all
the connected interfaces and

81
00:04:22.200 --> 00:04:26.060
then put network a statement in for
each one, it would be a lot of commands.

82
00:04:26.060 --> 00:04:29.690
Redistributing it would be faster, so I'm
gonna be lazy and go the faster route and

83
00:04:29.690 --> 00:04:30.200
redistribute.

84
00:04:30.200 --> 00:04:34.090
Just say, take whatever's connected and
redistribute into eigrp 800.

85
00:04:34.090 --> 00:04:39.990
So I'm gonna jump into my configuration
and I'll do router eigrp 800, and

86
00:04:39.990 --> 00:04:46.460
i'm going to say redistribute connected
and then I need to tell it a metric.

87
00:04:46.460 --> 00:04:49.560
If you don't tell it a metric it's
not going to bring it in right.

88
00:04:49.560 --> 00:04:52.810
So I've got to set a metric, and if you
can't remember the metric on the exam it's

89
00:04:52.810 --> 00:04:55.740
no big deal because you can always use the
question mark to find out each one, right.

90
00:04:55.740 --> 00:04:59.370
Cause we've got bandwidth, delay,
load, reliability, and mtu and

91
00:04:59.370 --> 00:05:01.170
you got to specify each one.

92
00:05:01.170 --> 00:05:05.200
So the first one is bandwidth and
these links, they're SVIs.

93
00:05:05.200 --> 00:05:06.820
They're Switch Virtual Interfaces.

94
00:05:06.820 --> 00:05:09.370
I could say that it's
100 megabit if I wanted.

95
00:05:09.370 --> 00:05:14.450
It's actually done in kilobits though, so
I need to say 100,000 for that bandwidth.

96
00:05:14.450 --> 00:05:16.980
And this is going to be a long command,
so my head's gonna cover up part of it.

97
00:05:16.980 --> 00:05:19.630
We might need to go full-screen
on that one so we can see it all.

98
00:05:19.630 --> 00:05:24.760
But as I continue on my next metric
here that it wants is the delay.

99
00:05:24.760 --> 00:05:26.220
Lower number is better.

100
00:05:26.220 --> 00:05:28.410
Since these are SVIs,
I don't really have a delay on them, so

101
00:05:28.410 --> 00:05:30.040
I'm gonna set it to the lowest value,
which is one.

102
00:05:30.040 --> 00:05:34.180
You can actually set it to zero, but
one's the lowest that it expects.

103
00:05:34.180 --> 00:05:37.680
The reliability metric, 0 to 255,
where 255 is 100% reliable,

104
00:05:37.680 --> 00:05:39.930
so I'll go with that one.

105
00:05:39.930 --> 00:05:42.990
And then the effective bandwidth loading.

106
00:05:42.990 --> 00:05:44.720
This is 0 to 255 also, or 1 to 255.

107
00:05:44.720 --> 00:05:46.569
255 is 100% loaded, that's bad.

108
00:05:46.569 --> 00:05:49.140
I want 1, that's good.

109
00:05:49.140 --> 00:05:53.030
All right, and then the last
metric that I need is the MTU,

110
00:05:53.030 --> 00:05:58.080
the MTU gets ignored but I'll put 1500
in there because 1500 is my actual MTU.

111
00:05:58.080 --> 00:06:00.590
And so once I've got that, now

112
00:06:00.590 --> 00:06:05.580
I've got enough in there to redistribute
those connected routes into eigrp 800.

113
00:06:05.580 --> 00:06:11.360
And I review my configuration I'll
do a show run for section eigrp,

114
00:06:11.360 --> 00:06:15.600
and I can see that redistribute
command right there.

115
00:06:15.600 --> 00:06:19.760
So now all my connected interfaces are
coming into that eigrp autonomous system,

116
00:06:19.760 --> 00:06:21.450
and hopefully that'll solve our problem.

117
00:06:21.450 --> 00:06:25.827
I'm gonna look at CORE2, and
CORE2 didn't have those routes before,

118
00:06:25.827 --> 00:06:27.600
we'll see if it has them now.

119
00:06:27.600 --> 00:06:30.600
And what I'm looking for are those .5,
.6, .7, all those networks.

120
00:06:30.600 --> 00:06:34.820
And sure enough, there they are.

121
00:06:34.820 --> 00:06:39.020
Now because I redistributed them,
they're showing as external eigrp routes.

122
00:06:39.020 --> 00:06:41.910
If I had used network statements for
each one they would show as internal,

123
00:06:41.910 --> 00:06:43.440
it doesn't really matter to me.

124
00:06:43.440 --> 00:06:46.410
The question didn't tell me which it
prefers, at least I don't think it did.

125
00:06:46.410 --> 00:06:49.470
Let's see if we have any
rules to follow here.

126
00:06:49.470 --> 00:06:54.770
Oh it actually has a hint that says,
use redistribution on NYCORE1.

127
00:06:54.770 --> 00:06:55.970
Well that's exactly what I did.

128
00:06:55.970 --> 00:06:58.720
I redistributed and brought it in, so
we kind of lucked out on that one.

129
00:06:58.720 --> 00:07:00.580
The alternative was doing
the network statements.

130
00:07:00.580 --> 00:07:04.403
Those are there, and in the question
it actually mentioned pinging from

131
00:07:04.403 --> 00:07:06.982
P-lab Cisco 01 to 192.168.5.1.

132
00:07:06.982 --> 00:07:12.083
So let's go test that and see if that
works, and if it does then this question

133
00:07:12.083 --> 00:07:17.840
is done, so I'm gonna try and
ping 192.168.5.1 and we're successful.

134
00:07:17.840 --> 00:07:22.760
So in this case we just needed
to redistribute those routes in,

135
00:07:22.760 --> 00:07:24.720
now we've got them and we're in business.

136
00:07:24.720 --> 00:07:26.410
So this one wasn't so

137
00:07:26.410 --> 00:07:28.970
much about troubleshooting something that
wasn't working the way it was supposed to.

138
00:07:28.970 --> 00:07:31.880
We were troubleshooting something
that was completely missing.

139
00:07:31.880 --> 00:07:34.420
Nobody ever advertised those networks,
so we couldn't learn about them.

140
00:07:34.420 --> 00:07:35.460
We didn't know they route to get there.

141
00:07:35.460 --> 00:07:36.550
Now that we've done it.

142
00:07:36.550 --> 00:07:40.030
We've fixed it.
The network is stable and off it goes.

143
00:07:40.030 --> 00:07:43.957
All right, well, that issue solves all
of Set 5's trouble shooting issues so

144
00:07:43.957 --> 00:07:45.450
that wraps that one up.

145
00:07:45.450 --> 00:07:48.210
Stay tuned though cuz we
got set six coming up next.

146
00:07:48.210 --> 00:07:49.270
Definitely gonna be a fun one there.

147
00:07:49.270 --> 00:07:51.130
We got a lot more
troubleshooting to get through.

148
00:07:51.130 --> 00:07:59.624
I hope to see you then.
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #1` from set #6. The trouble ticket states that "The tunnel interface on NYEDGE2 is showing as down causing problems with routes being propagated throughout the network "
episodes.title: Set 6 Issue 1
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.474
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.474 --> 00:00:11.730
All right, welcome back to another
troubleshooting episode here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.730 --> 00:00:15.200
And we're gonna be kicking off
an all-new troubleshooting set,

4
00:00:15.200 --> 00:00:16.610
we're jumping into set number 6.

5
00:00:16.610 --> 00:00:21.220
We've got a new topology, and that means
new problems that we've got to sort out,

6
00:00:21.220 --> 00:00:23.800
so let's just dive right into it.

7
00:00:23.800 --> 00:00:25.130
We've got a troubleshooting ticket here.

8
00:00:25.130 --> 00:00:25.870
It looks like short one and

9
00:00:25.870 --> 00:00:31.830
it says the tunnel interface on N Y edge
two is showing as down which is causing

10
00:00:31.830 --> 00:00:34.970
problems with routes being propagated
throughout the network, all right.

11
00:00:34.970 --> 00:00:37.140
So we've got a tunnel interface.

12
00:00:37.140 --> 00:00:41.380
Not telling us if it's a V P N
like an encrypted V P N or

13
00:00:41.380 --> 00:00:42.850
just a G R E tunnel or anything like that.

14
00:00:42.850 --> 00:00:44.350
But we're going to have to sort that out,
but

15
00:00:44.350 --> 00:00:45.860
it looks like we've got
some tunnel issues.

16
00:00:45.860 --> 00:00:49.820
Now, let's look at our topology so we can
get an idea of where this is coming from.

17
00:00:49.820 --> 00:00:51.200
So our new topology for

18
00:00:51.200 --> 00:00:55.550
set six is a little bit simplified
from the topologies we've seen before.

19
00:00:55.550 --> 00:00:58.050
We've still got our switch
triangle down here, and

20
00:00:58.050 --> 00:01:02.990
it looks like we've got an ether channel,
like a bonded trunk here, or some sort.

21
00:01:02.990 --> 00:01:06.780
Actually, it says it's layer three, so
that's just a single port channel there.

22
00:01:06.780 --> 00:01:09.470
Our switches are running up to EDGE2.

23
00:01:09.470 --> 00:01:12.200
EDGE2 is running to EDGE1 just
like it has in previous sets.

24
00:01:12.200 --> 00:01:14.200
And we got NYWAN1 over here.

25
00:01:14.200 --> 00:01:18.150
But we've got the addition of
a little bit of extra infrastructure.

26
00:01:18.150 --> 00:01:21.850
We've got a tunnel running
between these two systems,

27
00:01:21.850 --> 00:01:27.320
between EDGE2 NYWAN1 and that's the tunnel
that's giving us some problems.

28
00:01:27.320 --> 00:01:31.574
Now looking at the diagram here I see
that I've got tunnel 0 and tunnel 0 and

29
00:01:31.574 --> 00:01:32.317
that's it.

30
00:01:32.317 --> 00:01:35.084
I don't actually see what physical
interface these are bonded on but

31
00:01:35.084 --> 00:01:36.763
we can probably make some guesses right.

32
00:01:36.763 --> 00:01:41.370
Here you've got Serial 000 and
here we have Serial 010.

33
00:01:41.370 --> 00:01:44.350
That's probably it but
we'll have to double check that too and

34
00:01:44.350 --> 00:01:47.430
see where that tunnel is coming from and
going to.

35
00:01:47.430 --> 00:01:48.640
Find out why it's wrong.

36
00:01:48.640 --> 00:01:49.640
But in the troubleshooting question,

37
00:01:49.640 --> 00:01:53.650
it tells us it's the tunnel
interface on NYEDGE2, so

38

41
00:02:02.610 --> 00:02:06.140
When you're dealing with a tunnel,
a tunnel's got two ends, and

42
00:02:06.140 --> 00:02:10.630

the infrastructure in-between the ends.

43
00:02:10.630 --> 00:02:13.070

00:02:13.070 --> 00:02:16.160

00:02:20.510 --> 00:02:23.840

00:02:23.840 --> 00:02:25.460

00:02:25.460 --> 00:02:29.820

00:02:34.120 --> 00:02:36.100

00:02:36.100 --> 00:02:41.150

00:02:41.150 --> 00:02:43.530
