257
00:14:10.250 --> 00:14:13.410
So now routes are propagating through the
network and I can check the other side.

258
00:14:13.410 --> 00:14:17.060
I know the other side will be fine but if
you've got the extra time on the exam you

259
00:14:17.060 --> 00:14:19.580
should definitely spend it
verifying your answers.

260
00:14:19.580 --> 00:14:21.450
So I'll go over here and just verify.

261
00:14:21.450 --> 00:14:24.020
I see the neighbor relationship
right here anyway.

262
00:14:24.020 --> 00:14:29.700
But I'll do a show ip eigrp neighbor,
and I've got two neighbors here.

263
00:14:29.700 --> 00:14:35.360
And if I do a show ip route and
I just ask for eigrp routes,

264
00:14:35.360 --> 00:14:40.780
I'll see I've got a few including
one that I'm learning from Tunnel0.

265
00:14:40.780 --> 00:14:44.050
So I am learning a route over Tunnel0,
and we are in good shape.

266
00:14:44.050 --> 00:14:45.910
So that's gonna knock this one out.

267
00:14:45.910 --> 00:14:49.620
So in this case, what our troubleshooting
ticket boiled down to is we

268
00:14:49.620 --> 00:14:54.140
had a tunnel that wasn't up and it really
just came down to the tunnel configuration

269
00:14:54.140 --> 00:14:56.330
not being the same on both ends.

270
00:14:56.330 --> 00:14:58.760
Once we corrected that,
it came up and we were in business.

271
00:14:58.760 --> 00:15:01.820
This is a great example as far as
troubleshooting methodology of just doing

272
00:15:01.820 --> 00:15:03.480
configuration comparisons.

273
00:15:03.480 --> 00:15:05.515
Tunnels, that's the easiest
way to troubleshoot them and

274
00:15:05.515 --> 00:15:07.438
that'll get you the answer
you need really quick.

275
00:15:07.438 --> 00:15:09.150
So here, this one's taken care of and

276
00:15:09.150 --> 00:15:10.590
now we're ready to move
on to the next question.

277
00:15:10.590 --> 00:15:11.091
So, I hope you guys enjoyed it.

278
00:15:11.091 --> 00:15:13.482
Stay tuned,
we've got issue two coming up next.

279
00:15:13.482 --> 00:15:21.439
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #2` from set #6. The trouble ticket states that "The routes that are being propagated from NYCORE1 are appearing as both external and internal "
episodes.title: Set 6 Issue 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.523
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.523 --> 00:00:09.190
All right.

3
00:00:09.190 --> 00:00:13.110
Welcome back to another Cisco
Troubleshooting show here on IT PRO TV.

4
00:00:13.110 --> 00:00:17.210
We're jumping right back into Set 6 and
we're ready for Issue number 2.

5
00:00:17.210 --> 00:00:19.530
And looks like we got
a routing issue on this one.

6
00:00:19.530 --> 00:00:23.025
The troubleshooting ticket reads
the routes that are being propagated from

7
00:00:23.025 --> 00:00:29.070
NYCORE1 are appearing as both external and
internal.

8
00:00:29.070 --> 00:00:32.570
And on this question they're actually
being very specific about what routes I

9
00:00:32.570 --> 00:00:33.380
should look out for.

10
00:00:33.380 --> 00:00:35.777
So they're telling me to
jump over to NYWAN1 and

11
00:00:35.777 --> 00:00:38.530
run a particular command to
see the routes in question.

12
00:00:38.530 --> 00:00:41.610
Before I do that, though,
Let's take a look at our topology and

13
00:00:41.610 --> 00:00:43.850
get an idea of the devices
that are involved in this.

14
00:00:43.850 --> 00:00:49.710
So, what they're telling me is that
I've got good old NYCORE1 down here,

15
00:00:49.710 --> 00:00:54.650
and it's propagating routes into EIGRP
800, and by the time they make it all

16
00:00:54.650 --> 00:00:59.550
the way down here to NYWAN1, some of
the routes are appearing as internal and

17
00:00:59.550 --> 00:01:01.370
some of them are appearing as external.

18
00:01:01.370 --> 00:01:03.910
Now that's a pretty weird problem to have.

19
00:01:03.910 --> 00:01:09.130
I normally expect to see external routes
if I'm somebody like here, EDGE1.

20
00:01:09.130 --> 00:01:12.980
EDGE1 has a connection in the EIGRP 800,
those are the internal routes, and

21
00:01:12.980 --> 00:01:14.870
it's got a connection to BGP, so

22
00:01:14.870 --> 00:01:18.550
if I'm redistributing BGP into EIGRP
those would show up as external.

23
00:01:18.550 --> 00:01:20.230
That's what I expect to see.

24
00:01:20.230 --> 00:01:23.950
But they're telling me the routes
that are originating from NYCORE1 and

25
00:01:23.950 --> 00:01:27.200
NYCORE1 is entirely in EIGRP 800.

26
00:01:27.200 --> 00:01:31.420
It has no interfaces in any
other autonomous system, so

27
00:01:31.420 --> 00:01:34.300
it really shouldn't really have
any external route, should it?

28
00:01:34.300 --> 00:01:36.820
Well there is one scenario where we might.

29
00:01:36.820 --> 00:01:40.140
If you're redistributing
connective routes, right?

30
00:01:40.140 --> 00:01:43.290
Sometimes it's easier than putting
the interfaces into the routing protocols.

31
00:01:43.290 --> 00:01:47.000
Now, if we redistribute connector routes
and we expect them to be external.

32
00:01:47.000 --> 00:01:49.010
But it's kinda all or nothing thing.

33
00:01:49.010 --> 00:01:51.100
I guess you could route maps and
get really complex with it but

34
00:01:51.100 --> 00:01:55.080
normally, either all your connector
routes be external or all of them will be

35
00:01:55.080 --> 00:01:58.610
internal depending on whether you
added them to the routing process or

36
00:01:58.610 --> 00:02:02.550
if you redistributed them into the routing
process that would make the decision.

37
00:02:02.550 --> 00:02:06.050
But here we're dealing with both,
some internal, some external.

38
00:02:06.050 --> 00:02:09.890
And so for the routes, they're telling
me to look at the NYWAN1, and so

39
00:02:09.890 --> 00:02:13.960
I'll jump over to NYWAN1, and they want
me to run a specific command here.

40
00:02:13.960 --> 00:02:17.213
So I'm gonna get in here, and

41
00:02:17.213 --> 00:02:21.638
they want me to run
show ip route EIGRP and

42
00:02:21.638 --> 00:02:26.207
to filter that for 192.168.1.

43
00:02:26.207 --> 00:02:31.110
All right, and here's four
routes that are originating from

44
00:02:31.110 --> 00:02:34.870
that other system, from NYCORE1.

45
00:02:34.870 --> 00:02:37.510
And they're telling me in
the instructions here the note it says,

46
00:02:37.510 --> 00:02:40.400
the first route should be left alone.

47
00:02:40.400 --> 00:02:41.891
So we don't want to mess with that one.

48
00:02:41.891 --> 00:02:45.041
But the remaining three are the trouble
routes that we need to resolve in

49
00:02:45.041 --> 00:02:45.682
this ticket.

50
00:02:45.682 --> 00:02:52.502
And sure enough if I look at the remaining
three, I've got 192.168.16.0/23,

51
00:02:52.502 --> 00:02:57.660
I've got 192.168.18.0 and 192.168.19.0.

52
00:02:57.660 --> 00:03:02.410
And the first one shows
us internal it's got a D.

53
00:03:02.410 --> 00:03:06.650
But the other two show up as external and
got a D EX and so

54
00:03:06.650 --> 00:03:08.280
there it is there's that mix.

55
00:03:08.280 --> 00:03:11.370
And if I look at where they came from,
well they came from tunnel zero.

56
00:03:11.370 --> 00:03:13.740
If I start following this back close and

57
00:03:13.740 --> 00:03:18.390
closer to the router I should be able to
find that those come from NYCORE1, right?

58
00:03:18.390 --> 00:03:21.690
This router NYWAN1,
if I look at my topology,

59
00:03:21.690 --> 00:03:25.380
it only has that connection that's on that
tunnel, I guess it's got the serial one,

60
00:03:25.380 --> 00:03:29.090
but it's not running EIGRP there,
so that's coming from NYEDGE1.

61
00:03:29.090 --> 00:03:34.260
If I go to NYCORE2, let's look there,
let's look a little closer to the problem.

62
00:03:34.260 --> 00:03:37.389
If I go to NYCORE2 and
I look at those same routes,

63
00:03:39.190 --> 00:03:44.040
what I should see is the same results
here that I saw on the other side.

64
00:03:44.040 --> 00:03:45.960
It really shouldn't be any different.

65
00:03:47.140 --> 00:03:49.020
And sure enough there they are.

66
00:03:49.020 --> 00:03:52.850
I've got D, right, so
this one is showing up as internal, and

67
00:03:52.850 --> 00:03:55.730
then ex is those guys
are showing up as external.

68
00:03:55.730 --> 00:03:58.930
And they're coming from my port channel,
Port-channel1.

69
00:03:58.930 --> 00:04:02.100
And if I go to the topology that's the
port channel that's connected in-between

70
00:04:02.100 --> 00:04:02.880
CORE2 and CORE1.

71
00:04:02.880 --> 00:04:05.270
So those are originating from CORE1.

72
00:04:05.270 --> 00:04:08.250
So lets go over to CORE1 and see where
these networks are actually coming from.

73
00:04:09.320 --> 00:04:15.300
And on CORE1, I'll bet they're just
assigned to VLAN interfaces, right?

74
00:04:15.300 --> 00:04:17.299
Because that's what we normally see for
something like this.

75
00:04:19.280 --> 00:04:21.280
And so
I'll do a show IP interface brief and

76
00:04:21.280 --> 00:04:24.640
I'm gonna exclude any unassigned
interfaces, and there we go.

77
00:04:24.640 --> 00:04:29.435
All right, so
when I looked at that routing table,

78
00:04:29.435 --> 00:04:34.570
I saw 192.168.16.0/23, right?

79
00:04:34.570 --> 00:04:37.195
If I jump back over to NYWAN1.

80
00:04:37.195 --> 00:04:42.102
192.168.16.0/23.

81
00:04:42.102 --> 00:04:44.702
The others are slash 24s, all right?

82
00:04:44.702 --> 00:04:48.222
Now, that slash 23, we'll have to verify,

83
00:04:48.222 --> 00:04:52.710
I'm pretty sure I'm wrong
because if I go back to NYCORE2,

84
00:04:52.710 --> 00:04:58.281
I've got 192.168.16.1, and 192.168.17.1.

85
00:04:58.281 --> 00:05:06.430
Now if 192.168.16.1, if that was a slash
23, then these two would overlap.

86
00:05:06.430 --> 00:05:10.760
And Cisco will not let you have
two interfaces on the same subnet,

87
00:05:10.760 --> 00:05:11.990
it's against the rules.

88
00:05:11.990 --> 00:05:12.540
Right.

89
00:05:12.540 --> 00:05:17.030
So in this scenario,
these have to be in different subnets.

90
00:05:17.030 --> 00:05:21.350
But I saw a /23 over there and so
I think that's going to be our problem.

91
00:05:21.350 --> 00:05:24.640
Then as I look down here
I've got VLAN 18 and 19.

92
00:05:24.640 --> 00:05:28.147
They're just 192.68.18.1 and 19.1.

93
00:05:28.147 --> 00:05:31.240
And so all of these are VLAN interfaces,
so they're my,

94
00:05:31.240 --> 00:05:33.670
my switch virtual interfaces, or SVIs.

95
00:05:33.670 --> 00:05:38.630
And they're probably being either
redistributed in the EIGRP or

96
00:05:38.630 --> 00:05:43.750
actually added to EIGRP which we can find
that our really easy by doing a show run

97
00:05:43.750 --> 00:05:45.640
and filter that for the EIGRP section.

98
00:05:45.640 --> 00:05:49.300
And when I look at my EIGRP config,

99
00:05:49.300 --> 00:05:52.120
well that came back a little
bit weird didn't it?

100
00:05:52.120 --> 00:05:53.600
But I can see a few things here.

101
00:05:53.600 --> 00:05:58.000
What I was really looking for was this
section right here, router EIGRP 800.

102
00:05:58.000 --> 00:06:03.570
And I can see network 192.168.1.0
which you know doesn't include 16,

103
00:06:03.570 --> 00:06:05.358
17, 18 and 19.0.

104
00:06:05.358 --> 00:06:08.053
And then I can see redistribute connected.

105
00:06:08.053 --> 00:06:10.020
So there's what I was
talking about earlier.

106
00:06:10.020 --> 00:06:14.700
That's why those routes are showing
up as external because we're

107
00:06:14.700 --> 00:06:19.837
redistributing them into EIGRP verses
just saying network 192.168.16.0,

108
00:06:19.837 --> 00:06:21.590
network 192.168.17.0 and so on.

109
00:06:21.590 --> 00:06:22.887
Here they're being redistributed.

110
00:06:22.887 --> 00:06:25.350
All right,
that's why they're showing up as external.

111
00:06:25.350 --> 00:06:26.702
And let's see if there's
a route map tacked onto that.

112
00:06:26.702 --> 00:06:27.260
Nope.

113
00:06:27.260 --> 00:06:32.233
No route map or anything so
all of the interfaces, VLAN 16, 17, 18,

114
00:06:32.233 --> 00:06:35.360
and 19, they're all being redistributed.

115
00:06:35.360 --> 00:06:37.580
They all should be external, alright?

116
00:06:38.840 --> 00:06:41.180
But that's not what's happening.

117
00:06:41.180 --> 00:06:42.240
16 and 17.

118
00:06:42.240 --> 00:06:44.360
Aren't showing up as external,
17s not showing up at all,

119
00:06:44.360 --> 00:06:49.400
and 16 is showing up as a slash 23, and
I get the big hint from that right here.

120
00:06:49.400 --> 00:06:54.280
When I did show run, and filtered that to
the EIGRP section, the command actually

121
00:06:54.280 --> 00:06:57.730
does something interesting, it doesn't
just show you the EIGRP section,

122
00:06:57.730 --> 00:07:01.790
it shows you every command in
the config that deals with EIGRP.

123
00:07:01.790 --> 00:07:05.056
And on one of my interfaces,
I've got a summary address and

124
00:07:05.056 --> 00:07:08.077
this explains why I'm seeing
that wrong subnet mask.

125
00:07:08.077 --> 00:07:12.699
I've got 192.168.16.0 is being

126
00:07:12.699 --> 00:07:17.446
summarized to 255.255.254.0.

127
00:07:17.446 --> 00:07:21.910
There's my slash 23, right?
It's not a slash 24, now it's a slash 23.

128
00:07:21.910 --> 00:07:25.900
And because it's summarizing,
what's it gonna do?

129
00:07:25.900 --> 00:07:30.560
It's gonna wrap up 16 and
17, so 192.168.16.0,

130
00:07:30.560 --> 00:07:35.910
the slash 24, and
192.168.17.0 the slash 24,

131
00:07:35.910 --> 00:07:41.980
you combine into 192.168.16.0 slash 23.

132
00:07:41.980 --> 00:07:45.350
Now here's the neat part about this,
these are external routes, right?

133
00:07:45.350 --> 00:07:51.430
But when I summarize them,
the summary is internal.

134
00:07:51.430 --> 00:07:55.720
You created the summary inside of your
EIGRP process so it becomes internal.

135
00:07:55.720 --> 00:08:02.350
So the summary route is internal, the ones
that aren't summarized are external.

136
00:08:02.350 --> 00:08:02.870
Okay.

137
00:08:02.870 --> 00:08:04.500
So that's why we're seeing a mix, and

138
00:08:04.500 --> 00:08:08.120
this is something you really
probably wouldn't want in real life.

139
00:08:08.120 --> 00:08:10.340
In real life land you'd want
it to be one or the other.

140
00:08:10.340 --> 00:08:12.130
And so we've gotta figure out
how we want to solve this.

141
00:08:12.130 --> 00:08:14.150
All right,
I can solve it two different ways.

142
00:08:15.310 --> 00:08:18.340
One solution is I can remove the summary.

143
00:08:18.340 --> 00:08:22.040
If I remove the summary,
they'll all become external.

144
00:08:22.040 --> 00:08:25.040
And you know, in the troubleshooting
question it just says the routes that

145
00:08:25.040 --> 00:08:30.130
are being propagating from NYCORE1 are
appearing as both external and internal.

146
00:08:30.130 --> 00:08:33.920
They don't really tell me which
one I should make it, right?

147
00:08:33.920 --> 00:08:36.290
Should I make them all internal or
make them all external?

148
00:08:36.290 --> 00:08:37.240
It doesn't say.

149
00:08:37.240 --> 00:08:38.640
So I've got a choice, right.

150
00:08:38.640 --> 00:08:42.570
If I turn off this summary then all
of those routes will go back to

151
00:08:42.570 --> 00:08:45.900
being advertised individually and
then 16, 17,

152
00:08:45.900 --> 00:08:50.810
18 and 19 will all be kind of just
listed as external and that's it, right?

153
00:08:51.880 --> 00:08:55.070
But somebody went through
the trouble of putting in a summary.

154
00:08:55.070 --> 00:08:55.980
It's a bad summary, but

155
00:08:55.980 --> 00:08:58.300
somebody went through the trouble
of putting it in there, right?

156
00:08:58.300 --> 00:09:01.740
So I imagine they were trying to
make their routing table smaller.

157
00:09:01.740 --> 00:09:05.790
So the alternative solution is, why don't
I just summarize the other routes, too?

158
00:09:05.790 --> 00:09:10.180
And when I do that,
now they all become internal.

159
00:09:10.180 --> 00:09:12.340
And I get the advantage of having
a smaller routing table, so

160
00:09:12.340 --> 00:09:13.790
either one's going to fix this.

161
00:09:13.790 --> 00:09:17.100
I either kill the summary or
I fix the summary.

162
00:09:17.100 --> 00:09:17.930
Killing the summary's easy.

163
00:09:17.930 --> 00:09:21.200
We just say go to the interface where it's
attached, which I guess we should find.

164
00:09:21.200 --> 00:09:25.600
Well it should be on the port channel,
it's really the only place it can be.

165
00:09:25.600 --> 00:09:29.850
And we can just do a no IP summary
address and wipe that one out, right?

166
00:09:29.850 --> 00:09:33.490
But if I want to fix it,
all I have to do is go in and

167
00:09:33.490 --> 00:09:37.670
figure out a subnet mask to use that
will encompass my four networks.

168
00:09:37.670 --> 00:09:39.430
Now fortunately my four
networks are all in a row.

169
00:09:39.430 --> 00:09:45.960
16, 17, 18, and 19 and I already know that
16 and 17 are wrapped up in this slash 23.

170
00:09:45.960 --> 00:09:51.680
So if I go to a slash 22,
that'll get 16, 17, 18, and 19.

171
00:09:51.680 --> 00:09:54.680
If I just add one more bit to the host ID,

172
00:09:54.680 --> 00:09:57.850
take away one more bit from the network
ID, that makes it a little bit bigger, and

173
00:09:57.850 --> 00:10:01.360
it'll grab all four of those networks and
roll them up into one summary.

174
00:10:01.360 --> 00:10:03.670
And that one summary will be internal,
right?

175
00:10:03.670 --> 00:10:04.660
So let's do that.

176
00:10:04.660 --> 00:10:08.260
First off, I'm gonna verify that this
summary is actually on Port-channel1,

177
00:10:08.260 --> 00:10:09.930
cuz I'm kind of assuming that right now.

178
00:10:11.240 --> 00:10:12.710
I can't imagine it's anywhere else.

179
00:10:12.710 --> 00:10:17.734
Yeah, there it is, and
I'll get into Port-channel1,

180
00:10:17.734 --> 00:10:21.537
and I'm gonna do a no IP summary, address.

181
00:10:21.537 --> 00:10:27.800
Whoops, I actually have
to tell it what it is.

182
00:10:27.800 --> 00:10:29.160
EIGRP 800 192.168.16.0.

183
00:10:29.160 --> 00:10:34.710
And then that crazy subnet mask that
is just a little too small, right?

184
00:10:34.710 --> 00:10:37.130
So I'll throw that in there
to knock that one out.

185
00:10:37.130 --> 00:10:41.430
And then I'm gonna put it back in, so
I'm just gonna get rid of the no at

186
00:10:41.430 --> 00:10:47.410
the beginning, and at the end of
that line we're gonna take that and

187
00:10:47.410 --> 00:10:54.030
change it from a 254 to something
a little bit smaller like a 252.

188
00:10:54.030 --> 00:10:55.430
Right?
So if I go to a 22 bit submit

189
00:10:55.430 --> 00:10:56.030
mask 255.255.252.

190
00:10:56.030 --> 00:11:01.537
Or actually wait a minute that wouldn't be
a 22 bit, that would be a let's see I was

191
00:11:01.537 --> 00:11:07.200
at a, I'm trying to consolidate class c's
so instead of a 24 we're going to go to a,

192
00:11:07.200 --> 00:11:11.654
oh no, that is a 22, shoot I should
have trusted my first number.

193
00:11:11.654 --> 00:11:13.652
So we'll go to that one.

194
00:11:13.652 --> 00:11:20.548
And now it should grab 192.168.16,
192.168.17,

195
00:11:20.548 --> 00:11:25.785
192.168.18, and 192.168.19.

196
00:11:25.785 --> 00:11:28.064
It should grab all four of those and

197
00:11:28.064 --> 00:11:33.580
summarize them into a single external
route, or a single internal route, right?

198
00:11:33.580 --> 00:11:34.810
Summaries are always internal.

199
00:11:34.810 --> 00:11:36.570
We're creating them from right here.

200
00:11:36.570 --> 00:11:38.430
Well, unless you redistribute a summary,
but that's,

201
00:11:38.430 --> 00:11:39.760
that starts to get really complex, so.

202
00:11:39.760 --> 00:11:43.010
For the sake of this, that summary
we just made is an internal route.

203
00:11:43.010 --> 00:11:45.720
Now I'm not going to see
much here on NYCORE1.

204
00:11:45.720 --> 00:11:50.320
I can verify the interface configuration.

205
00:11:50.320 --> 00:11:53.930
And I can see that summary address
right there, and then I can go and

206
00:11:53.930 --> 00:11:55.350
look at it on another router.

207
00:11:55.350 --> 00:12:00.350
I'm gonna jump over to NYCORE2, and I can
see my neighbor relationship is already

208
00:12:01.430 --> 00:12:06.320
readjusted and
I'm just gonna do a show ip route EIGRP

209
00:12:07.990 --> 00:12:12.780
and what I expect to see is
192.168.16.0 /22, there you go.

210
00:12:12.780 --> 00:12:15.230
It was a /22 after all.

211
00:12:15.230 --> 00:12:18.940
And I don't see .16, .17, .18, or .19.

212
00:12:18.940 --> 00:12:20.120
I don't see them at all.

213
00:12:20.120 --> 00:12:23.180
They've been rolled up here
into the summary route and

214
00:12:23.180 --> 00:12:24.330
the summary route is internal.

215
00:12:24.330 --> 00:12:26.550
So no more external routes
in my routing table.

216
00:12:26.550 --> 00:12:33.180
And if I jump over to NYWAN1,
which is all the way at the end of the, if

217
00:12:33.180 --> 00:12:37.770
I go back to the topology diagram, NYWAN1
is all the way at the end of this path.

218
00:12:37.770 --> 00:12:42.520
So we go NYCORE1 to CORE2, to EDGE2,
across the tunnel to WAN1.

219
00:12:43.640 --> 00:12:46.561
And if we take a look at its routing table

220
00:12:49.903 --> 00:12:57.520
I expect to see just 192.168.16.0/22, I
don't see the others, it's just internal.

221
00:12:57.520 --> 00:13:00.630
And we can test some basic
connectivity if I wanna try and

222
00:13:00.630 --> 00:13:05.750
ping out to each of those individual
subnets, just to be on the safe side.

223
00:13:05.750 --> 00:13:07.950
There's .16.1.
.17.1.18.1 and .19.1, I got full

224
00:13:09.070 --> 00:13:14.792
connectivity to all four networks,
and now we're in business.

225
00:13:14.792 --> 00:13:19.560
All right, so in this troubleshooting
scenario, what we have was

226
00:13:19.560 --> 00:13:22.200
some route showing is internal and
some route showing is external.

227
00:13:23.290 --> 00:13:26.530
The internal routes were showing as
external because of a summary address.

228
00:13:26.530 --> 00:13:28.850
The external routes were
just being redistributed in,

229
00:13:28.850 --> 00:13:30.030
and that's the way they are.

230
00:13:30.030 --> 00:13:32.730
So it wasn't really bad behavior,
it's just

231
00:13:32.730 --> 00:13:35.880
the summary route didn't encompass all
the networks that were in question.

232
00:13:35.880 --> 00:13:39.620
So I increased the size of that
summary address that would wrap up all

233
00:13:39.620 --> 00:13:41.730
four networks, and
now they're all internal.

234
00:13:41.730 --> 00:13:44.350
Alternative solution would have been
to just kill the summary address,

235
00:13:44.350 --> 00:13:46.990
and then I would have all
four networks as externals.

236
00:13:46.990 --> 00:13:47.930
Depending on what they wanna do,

237
00:13:47.930 --> 00:13:49.870
they didn't really tell
me which one they wanted.

238
00:13:49.870 --> 00:13:52.660
We just went with what would be
the most optimal solution right.

239
00:13:52.660 --> 00:13:56.450
Which is just to summarize them all but
that knocks out this ticket and

240
00:13:56.450 --> 00:13:57.620
we're ready to move onto the next one.

241
00:13:57.620 --> 00:13:59.439
I hope you guys enjoyed it and
I'll see you next time.

242
00:13:59.439 --> 00:14:07.339
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #3` from set #6. The trouble ticket states that "Logs from NYCORE1 should be sent to the Syslog server on PLABCSCO01 (192.168.16.10). Currently there are no logs being sent "
episodes.title: Set 6 Issue 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:04.517
[SOUND] It's that time again for

2
00:00:04.517 --> 00:00:12.123
another troubleshooting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.123 --> 00:00:15.246
On this one we're jumping into set six,
issue three, and

4
00:00:15.246 --> 00:00:17.620
we're going to a different area this time.

5
00:00:17.620 --> 00:00:21.390
Looks like we've got Syslog problem
on one of our router's switches.

6
00:00:21.390 --> 00:00:25.370
The troubleshooting ticket reads like
this, it says logs from NYCORE1,

7
00:00:25.370 --> 00:00:31.270
that's one of our switches, should be
sent to the Syslog server on PLABCISCO01,

8
00:00:31.270 --> 00:00:33.813
which is 192.168.16.10.

9
00:00:33.813 --> 00:00:36.760
Currently, there are no logs being sent.

10
00:00:37.770 --> 00:00:38.690
That's not good, right.

11
00:00:38.690 --> 00:00:40.650
So, we've got a logging server set up.

12
00:00:40.650 --> 00:00:41.720
Logs aren't making it.

13
00:00:41.720 --> 00:00:42.620
We need to find out why.

14
00:00:42.620 --> 00:00:45.940
Now, In our minds we need to be
thinking of possible causes so

15
00:00:45.940 --> 00:00:46.960
we can start to look for this.

16
00:00:46.960 --> 00:00:49.720
And let's take a look at
our topology to kind of see

17
00:00:49.720 --> 00:00:53.000
what some of the stuff is that
might actually be in the way.

18
00:00:53.000 --> 00:00:56.910
Now our main switch that's in
question here is NYCORE1, this guy.

19
00:00:56.910 --> 00:01:00.110
This is the one that is supposed
to be generating sys log messages.

20
00:01:00.110 --> 00:01:05.438
And it's supposed to be sending
them to PLABCSCO01 192.68.16.10.

21
00:01:05.438 --> 00:01:10.191
Now, we saw in earlier issues in this
set that NYCORE1 had a number of VLAN

22
00:01:10.191 --> 00:01:13.719
interfaces, but
I can't remember off hand whether or

23
00:01:13.719 --> 00:01:18.115
not I had an interface on
the 192.168.16 network or not.

24
00:01:18.115 --> 00:01:20.841
So we'll need to double check and I'm
pretty sure it did because I think that

25
00:01:20.841 --> 00:01:23.030
was one of the networks we just
summarized in the last issue.

26
00:01:23.030 --> 00:01:25.530
So I'm pretty sure it's
got an interface on that.

27
00:01:25.530 --> 00:01:28.830
But the reason I'm concerned about
that is we need to test connectivity.

28
00:01:28.830 --> 00:01:32.870
If we have an interface on the network,
can we see the server on it?

29
00:01:32.870 --> 00:01:35.690
Cause if we can't see the server the
Syslog messages aren't gonna get there.

30
00:01:35.690 --> 00:01:38.910
All right,
the other thing I need to think about is

31
00:01:38.910 --> 00:01:40.930
what could be stopping this in transit?

32
00:01:40.930 --> 00:01:45.060
I could have an ACL or
something like that here on NYACCESS1 if

33
00:01:45.060 --> 00:01:49.050
NYCORE1 is having to be
routed to get to 192.168.16,

34
00:01:49.050 --> 00:01:52.940
then whoever that router is could
be stopping that traffic, right?

35
00:01:52.940 --> 00:01:55.890
So, those are all different things
that'd be kinda getting involved in

36
00:01:55.890 --> 00:01:59.600
that communications flow and
could be stopping Syslog from working.

37
00:01:59.600 --> 00:02:04.370
But let's not overlook the easiest
possibility which is, maybe Syslog's not

38
00:02:04.370 --> 00:02:08.870
even configured, or it's just configured
wrong, right here on NYCORE1.

39
00:02:08.870 --> 00:02:13.170
So I wanna jump in there and just kinda
take a look at how Syslog is configured

40
00:02:13.170 --> 00:02:14.920
and get an idea of what's
supposed to be in place.

41
00:02:14.920 --> 00:02:18.130
Now, before I start making any tweaks,

42
00:02:18.130 --> 00:02:21.850
I need to make sure that I actually do
have a Syslog server set up on PLABCSCO01.

43
00:02:21.850 --> 00:02:24.430
It needs to be listening so
that I can see that it's working.

44
00:02:24.430 --> 00:02:28.110
So let me just jump over to PLABCSCO01 and
see what we've got.

45
00:02:28.110 --> 00:02:31.410
And sure enough we've got a Tftpd32.

46
00:02:31.410 --> 00:02:32.970
If you've never used it,

47
00:02:32.970 --> 00:02:37.570
that's an open source Tftp server
is the main thing that it does.

48
00:02:37.570 --> 00:02:41.030
But it also does DHCP's,
Syslog, and other things.

49
00:02:41.030 --> 00:02:45.850
So it's up and running on 192.168.16.10.

50
00:02:45.850 --> 00:02:49.170
And it's running as a Syslog server, and
sure enough I can see right here it's got

51
00:02:49.170 --> 00:02:53.550
no log messages in it, it's just sitting
here waiting to receive log messages.

52
00:02:53.550 --> 00:02:55.350
So we'll know if we get this thing fixed.

53
00:02:56.410 --> 00:03:01.995
All right, let's jump over to NYCORE1,
and I wanna take a look at a few things,

54
00:03:01.995 --> 00:03:05.195
just even before I get too
crazy into the hard stuff.

55
00:03:05.195 --> 00:03:07.185
Let's just see if we're dealing
with the connectivity issue,

56
00:03:07.185 --> 00:03:09.795
maybe I can't even get
to the Syslog server.

57
00:03:09.795 --> 00:03:14.431
If I do a show ip int br, and
I'll exclude the unassigned addresses.

58
00:03:14.431 --> 00:03:19.864
I have an IP on VLAN 16, 192.168.16.1.

59
00:03:19.864 --> 00:03:24.575
And the Syslog server is 192.168.16.10.

60
00:03:24.575 --> 00:03:25.715
So we're on the same network.

61
00:03:25.715 --> 00:03:29.415
That means we're not being routed and
ACLs are probably not an issue here.

62
00:03:29.415 --> 00:03:31.335
That's not a guarantee, right.

63
00:03:31.335 --> 00:03:35.065
Access controllers based on IP are not
going to be an issue because I'm not being

64
00:03:35.065 --> 00:03:38.097
routed so there's not really
anything to filter me here, right.

65
00:03:38.097 --> 00:03:41.207
But you can add an access control that's
based on a MAC address, couldn't you?

66
00:03:41.207 --> 00:03:44.037
And that could be taking affect,
or a VLAN ACL, right,

67
00:03:44.037 --> 00:03:47.987
they can really take affect here cuz they
apply even to traffic that's not routed.

68
00:03:47.987 --> 00:03:52.827
But, it's doubtful, but let's just
see if I can ping that other system.

69
00:03:52.827 --> 00:03:59.100
So I'm gonna ping 192.168.16.10 and
there we go, all right.

70
00:03:59.100 --> 00:04:00.330
Had me worried for a moment there.

71
00:04:00.330 --> 00:04:03.310
That first ping was waiting for
the ARP request to come back.

72
00:04:03.310 --> 00:04:05.210
But looks like we have
good connectivity there.

73
00:04:05.210 --> 00:04:07.120
So it's not gonna be something simple,

74
00:04:07.120 --> 00:04:10.580
there's gonna be something in
the configuration here that's wrong.

75
00:04:10.580 --> 00:04:15.770
All right, so next I wanna see am I
even generating log messages at all?

76
00:04:15.770 --> 00:04:20.270
Right, if you do a show log or
show logging, you'll get the logs of this

77
00:04:20.270 --> 00:04:26.250
system and I can see console logging
generation 46 messages, all right.

78
00:04:26.250 --> 00:04:27.130
Monitor logging,

79
00:04:27.130 --> 00:04:30.250
that would be terminal monitoring when
your mode in is zero, that's fine.

80
00:04:30.250 --> 00:04:31.660
Buffer logging is 46.

81
00:04:31.660 --> 00:04:36.440
So I've generated 46 messages and
I've displayed them on the console and

82
00:04:36.440 --> 00:04:37.810
saved them into memory.

83
00:04:37.810 --> 00:04:39.730
So we do have logging configured.

84
00:04:40.890 --> 00:04:43.360
And then as I look at
the rest of the log files,

85
00:04:43.360 --> 00:04:46.050
I'll see that there's actually
plenty of log messages in here.

86
00:04:46.050 --> 00:04:49.100
So we are generating log messages.

87
00:04:49.100 --> 00:04:52.240
Then I'm just gonna do
a show running-config and

88
00:04:52.240 --> 00:04:55.830
I'm gonna filter that for
the word logging, right.

89
00:04:55.830 --> 00:04:59.160
When you configure a Syslog server,
you use the logging command to do it.

90
00:04:59.160 --> 00:05:02.954
And when you configure the logging levels,
you use the login command.

91
00:05:02.954 --> 00:05:05.879
And so I'm just looking for any command
with the word logging in it and

92
00:05:05.879 --> 00:05:06.391
here it is.

93
00:05:06.391 --> 00:05:11.940
Logging host 192.168.16.11.

94
00:05:11.940 --> 00:05:15.934
I'm set to log to a Syslog
server that's not .10.

95
00:05:15.934 --> 00:05:18.950
Now you can log to multiple
Syslog servers if you want.

96
00:05:18.950 --> 00:05:22.919
It doesn't care about that, but
if I'm supposed to be sending logs to .10,

97
00:05:22.919 --> 00:05:26.130
I kind of expected to see that
server in here and I don't.

98
00:05:26.130 --> 00:05:30.635
So at a minimum I'm going to need to add
that in and so I can do logging host

99
00:05:30.635 --> 00:05:37.790
192.168.16.10 and we can just stop right
there and we'll send to the server or

100
00:05:37.790 --> 00:05:42.230
you can continue on and specify filters,
session ID's, and other things.

101
00:05:42.230 --> 00:05:44.159
Now, it will tell me that
here in the question,

102
00:05:44.159 --> 00:05:47.540
it just says we're supposed to be
sending logs to this IP and we're not.

103
00:05:47.540 --> 00:05:51.030
I think it's pretty obvious we're just
not configured to send to that server so

104
00:05:51.030 --> 00:05:56.390
I'm going to add that and
if I do a show running config and

105
00:05:56.390 --> 00:05:59.710
look for logging, I'm now setup for
two Syslog servers.

106
00:05:59.710 --> 00:06:05.230
Now, you might be tempted to remove .11
and I certainly could, but, it didn't

107
00:06:05.230 --> 00:06:08.300
tell me that it was a problem there,
I might actually have a Syslog server .11.

108
00:06:08.300 --> 00:06:10.610
It's just telling me I need
to be logged in to .10.

109
00:06:10.610 --> 00:06:14.110
So I'm gonna add that as a server and I'm
just gonna leave the other one in there.

110
00:06:14.110 --> 00:06:15.590
Because I just don't know.

111
00:06:15.590 --> 00:06:19.640
And I can see I got a status message here,
logginghost_startstop.

112
00:06:19.640 --> 00:06:25.980
And I want to generate a log message here
just to make sure that it's logging.

113
00:06:25.980 --> 00:06:30.020
And one of the easiest ways to do that is
if you go into config and then get out.

114
00:06:30.020 --> 00:06:32.580
Every time you exit config,
what do you get?

115
00:06:32.580 --> 00:06:35.020
You get a little message that
pops up on the screen that says,

116
00:06:35.020 --> 00:06:39.690
configured from console by console,
or configured by

117
00:06:40.860 --> 00:06:44.810
from VTY7, or whatever it is,
you'll get a message just like that.

118
00:06:44.810 --> 00:06:48.800
So that generates a message and
that should be sent to the Syslog server.

119
00:06:48.800 --> 00:06:52.770
And so now I can go look at the Syslog
server and see if it got that.

120
00:06:52.770 --> 00:06:55.970
And I'll jump down to PLABCSCO01 and

121
00:06:55.970 --> 00:06:59.690
sure enough I can see that it is now
receiving some of those messages.

122
00:06:59.690 --> 00:07:02.960
And we've got that logging host
where the logging was turned on and

123
00:07:02.960 --> 00:07:05.420
there's configured from
console by console.

124
00:07:05.420 --> 00:07:08.550
That's the message for my configuration
changes just a second ago.

125
00:07:08.550 --> 00:07:12.850
And so now Syslog is working, so this one
actually turned out to be really simple.

126
00:07:12.850 --> 00:07:16.350
Here we had we weren't logging to
a Syslog server, and we checked,

127
00:07:16.350 --> 00:07:18.800
and just IP address of
the Syslog server was wrong.

128
00:07:18.800 --> 00:07:22.390
We didn't have ACLs or anything crazy like
that, it could have been a lot of things.

129
00:07:22.390 --> 00:07:25.160
It could have been routing, it could
have been all sorts of neat stuff.

130
00:07:25.160 --> 00:07:26.340
In this case just wrong IP.

131
00:07:26.340 --> 00:07:30.040
So that knocks that one out, and takes
care of another troubleshooting issue.

132
00:07:30.040 --> 00:07:31.370
So that's issue three.

133
00:07:31.370 --> 00:07:33.080
We got a couple more for set six.

134
00:07:33.080 --> 00:07:38.595
Definitely stay tuned for that,
because they're coming up next.

135
00:07:38.595 --> 00:07:43.164
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #4` from set #6. The trouble ticket states that "NYEDGE2 and NYCORE2 are using LLDP, not CDP to exchange information between each other, however for some reason we cant see the capabilities of NYCORE2 when you look at the neighbors on NYEDGE2 "
episodes.title: Set 6 Issue 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.804
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.804 --> 00:00:12.110
All right welcome back for another
troubleshooting episode here on IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:12.110 --> 00:00:15.110
For this one we're jumping
into set six issue four,

4
00:00:15.110 --> 00:00:18.280
and boy have we got a mind bender
on the schedule for today.

5
00:00:18.280 --> 00:00:21.030
This one, get ready for the challenge.

6
00:00:21.030 --> 00:00:22.955
We've got LLDP not working right.

7
00:00:22.955 --> 00:00:25.580
[LAUGH] Troubleshooting
ticket reads like this.

8
00:00:25.580 --> 00:00:30.570
NYEDGE2 and NYCORE2 are using LLDP

9
00:00:30.570 --> 00:00:33.960
not CDP to exchange
information between each other.

10
00:00:33.960 --> 00:00:38.280
However for some reason we can't
see the capabilities of NYCORE2

11
00:00:38.280 --> 00:00:40.710
when you look at the neighbors on NYEDGE2.

12
00:00:40.710 --> 00:00:43.520
Now, I kinda make fun of
this question a little bit.

13
00:00:43.520 --> 00:00:47.730
I love these on the exam though cuz
the instant you see CDP or LLDP or

14
00:00:47.730 --> 00:00:49.960
really any Layer 2 protocol for
that matter.

15
00:00:49.960 --> 00:00:52.805
You can just kinda wipe your forehead and
say, [NOISE] This one's an easy one.

16
00:00:52.805 --> 00:00:54.960
We're gonna get some points and
move onto the next.

17
00:00:54.960 --> 00:00:58.700
Layer 2 protocols are awesome
because there's really only so

18
00:00:58.700 --> 00:01:00.180
much that can go wrong with them.

19
00:01:00.180 --> 00:01:03.680
The protocol itself Is pretty rock solid.

20
00:01:03.680 --> 00:01:07.230
So if you're having a layer 2 problem,
it's almost always just a missed

21
00:01:07.230 --> 00:01:10.680
configuration, and you can simply
look at the configs on both sides.

22
00:01:10.680 --> 00:01:13.560
Well, this one is a little
bit trickier than that,

23
00:01:13.560 --> 00:01:16.820
because it looks like LLDP is working,
it's working.

24
00:01:16.820 --> 00:01:19.060
It's exchanging information
between these systems, but

25
00:01:19.060 --> 00:01:21.210
it's missing some of its data.

26
00:01:21.210 --> 00:01:25.699
It says for some reason we can't
see the capabilities of NYCORE2

27
00:01:25.699 --> 00:01:28.725
when you look at the neighbors on NYEDGE2.

28
00:01:28.725 --> 00:01:30.687
Let's see what they're talking about.

29
00:01:30.687 --> 00:01:35.260
In my topology,
we're talking about NYCORE2 and NYEDGE2.

30
00:01:35.260 --> 00:01:37.670
They're directly plugged
into each other right here.

31
00:01:37.670 --> 00:01:40.870
So LLDP is running on this link.

32
00:01:40.870 --> 00:01:42.300
And exchanging data.

33
00:01:42.300 --> 00:01:44.600
And they're saying,
when I look on NYEDGE2,

34
00:01:44.600 --> 00:01:49.140
it sees NYCORE2 but
it can't see it's capabilities.

35
00:01:49.140 --> 00:01:50.350
What are capabilities?

36
00:01:50.350 --> 00:01:52.650
Where it detects it's a bridge or

37
00:01:52.650 --> 00:01:56.010
a router; where it detects that kind
of information and says what it is.

38
00:01:56.010 --> 00:01:59.080
Apparently we're missing that,
so let's go jump to EDGE2 and

39
00:01:59.080 --> 00:02:00.600
see if we can't replicate that.

40
00:02:01.920 --> 00:02:07.130
So one EDGE2 I'm just going to
do a quick show LLDP neighbor.

41
00:02:10.740 --> 00:02:15.960
And when I look at it, sure enough it sees
NYCORE2, it's on gigabit ethernet 0/0.

42
00:02:15.960 --> 00:02:17.220
It's got a hold time of 120.

43
00:02:17.220 --> 00:02:21.010
The capability is indeed blank.

44
00:02:21.010 --> 00:02:25.280
And then it's on port
ID Fa1/0/1 on the other side.

45
00:02:25.280 --> 00:02:28.010
So I'm missing some of the data.

46
00:02:28.010 --> 00:02:29.680
Now why am I missing data?

47
00:02:30.740 --> 00:02:33.520
With LLDP we normally just turn it on and
that's it,

48
00:02:33.520 --> 00:02:37.510
and it moves the information and
we really don't have to sweat it anymore.

49
00:02:37.510 --> 00:02:41.450
But in this case it is working,
it's just part of it is now missing.

50
00:02:41.450 --> 00:02:42.230
I should see some letters.

51
00:02:42.230 --> 00:02:43.190
See these letters up here?

52
00:02:43.190 --> 00:02:46.500
R for Router, B for Bridge,
I should at least see those here, because

53
00:02:46.500 --> 00:02:50.910
NYCORE2 is a layer three switch, so it
should show up as a bridge and a router.

54
00:02:50.910 --> 00:02:53.280
But it might also show up as
some of these other components,

55
00:02:53.280 --> 00:02:56.080
depending on how it's set up.

56
00:02:56.080 --> 00:02:57.720
But as it stands, I'm not, so

57
00:02:57.720 --> 00:03:01.170
that tells me right a way that we're
really just dealing with a LLDP problem.

58
00:03:01.170 --> 00:03:04.150
With LLDP you have a lot
more control than CDP.

59
00:03:04.150 --> 00:03:06.360
CDP you just turn on and
that's basically it.

60
00:03:06.360 --> 00:03:08.270
You can set some timers and you're done.

61
00:03:08.270 --> 00:03:13.510
With LLDP we can actually control
what information is being exchanged.

62
00:03:13.510 --> 00:03:18.310
And I bet we'll find that this is either
actively being blocked or just being

63
00:03:18.310 --> 00:03:21.930
left out of the config, and so we can
throw it back in to exchange capabilities.

64
00:03:21.930 --> 00:03:23.530
So let's go find out.

65
00:03:23.530 --> 00:03:25.160
The problem's not gonna be here on EDGE2.

66
00:03:25.160 --> 00:03:29.330
On EDGE2 you can't filter
the LLDP traffic coming in.

67
00:03:29.330 --> 00:03:30.490
You can block it.

68
00:03:30.490 --> 00:03:33.120
But you can't filter out just
one particular component.

69
00:03:33.120 --> 00:03:34.310
There's no way to do that.

70
00:03:34.310 --> 00:03:36.290
So I know the problem's not here.

71
00:03:36.290 --> 00:03:37.650
But if I jump over to NYCORE2,

72
00:03:37.650 --> 00:03:42.760
it's the one that's originating
the data and it can filter that.

73
00:03:42.760 --> 00:03:45.280
You can filter the data you send out.

74
00:03:45.280 --> 00:03:49.050
You just can't filter what's coming in,
other than blocking it outright.

75
00:03:49.050 --> 00:03:55.100
So, what I imagine we're gonna
see here is if I do a show run,

76
00:03:55.100 --> 00:03:57.590
and look for any command with LLDP.

77
00:03:57.590 --> 00:04:02.890
I'll bet we find our problem right in
here, and it's sure enough there is.

78
00:04:02.890 --> 00:04:05.650
LLDP run,
that's how I know it's turned on, right?

79
00:04:05.650 --> 00:04:08.110
So we are running LLDP,
we already knew that.

80
00:04:08.110 --> 00:04:14.200
But then right here,
no LLDP TLV-select system-capabilities.

81
00:04:14.200 --> 00:04:15.720
And so, what this is doing is the same.

82
00:04:15.720 --> 00:04:22.070
We're gonna exchange LLDP data but, we're
gonna filter out the system capabilities.

83
00:04:22.070 --> 00:04:22.850
And that's that.

84
00:04:22.850 --> 00:04:25.950
So, if I go in and
just turn that on, right?

85
00:04:25.950 --> 00:04:32.360
LLDP TLV-select,
System-capabilities and run that.

86
00:04:32.360 --> 00:04:33.990
That will turn it on, okay.

87
00:04:33.990 --> 00:04:36.180
But I do have to be a little
bit careful with this.

88
00:04:36.180 --> 00:04:41.630
There are some of these options that we
can turn on and when we turn them on.

89
00:04:41.630 --> 00:04:44.660
Now it's assuming that's the only
thing we want to send out, and

90
00:04:44.660 --> 00:04:47.000
it turns off everything else.

91
00:04:47.000 --> 00:04:49.770
And so instead of running it
like this I might have needed to

92
00:04:49.770 --> 00:04:52.260
remove the other command, I don't
think that's gonna be the case here.

93
00:04:52.260 --> 00:04:53.560
So we should be all right.

94
00:04:53.560 --> 00:04:56.110
And I'm just gonna do a quick show run and

95
00:04:56.110 --> 00:05:00.780
look for LLDP commands, and
I should just see the one command now.

96
00:05:00.780 --> 00:05:01.630
There we go.

97
00:05:01.630 --> 00:05:02.230
LLDP run.

98
00:05:02.230 --> 00:05:04.280
So now we should be
running the default and

99
00:05:04.280 --> 00:05:07.620
the default is to exchange
system capabilities.

100
00:05:07.620 --> 00:05:11.158
Now on one hand, I'm really glad when
I see layer two questions on the exam

101
00:05:11.158 --> 00:05:13.173
because I know they're going to be easy.

102
00:05:13.173 --> 00:05:17.410
On the other hand they can be
kind of bad sometimes because.

103
00:05:17.410 --> 00:05:19.130
The protocol's run on a timer.

104
00:05:19.130 --> 00:05:22.890
LLDP, it's exchanging it's information,
and you guys saw on the other one

105
00:05:22.890 --> 00:05:25.900
that we had a 120 second timer on it,
that's two minutes.

106
00:05:25.900 --> 00:05:29.610
That means I could have to wait up to two
minutes for this change to make it over.

107
00:05:29.610 --> 00:05:31.320
Let's hope that it happens really fast.

108
00:05:31.320 --> 00:05:34.200
If it takes too long, I could always do
something like shutting the interface down

109
00:05:34.200 --> 00:05:37.880
and bringing it back up, trying and kick
it in the butt and make it happen faster.

110
00:05:37.880 --> 00:05:40.510
But, let's see if it just happened for
us in that time.

111
00:05:40.510 --> 00:05:41.730
And it did.

112
00:05:41.730 --> 00:05:44.030
Now I can see I've got NYCORE2.

113
00:05:44.030 --> 00:05:49.870
It's up and running on GI0/0, hold down
time of 120 and then capability B and R.

114
00:05:49.870 --> 00:05:51.790
I can see that it's a bridge and a router.

115
00:05:51.790 --> 00:05:55.140
It's a layer three switch and
I've got the information I needed.

116
00:05:55.140 --> 00:05:58.000
So, turned out to be a pretty
easy one in this case.

117
00:05:58.000 --> 00:06:01.500
LLDP wasn't showing all of the information
that should have been there, and

118
00:06:01.500 --> 00:06:05.070
it turns out that the originating piece
of equipment was just excluding the data.

119
00:06:05.070 --> 00:06:07.040
We put it back in, and now we're covered.

120
00:06:07.040 --> 00:06:08.800
Pretty cut and dry, not a hard one for

121
00:06:08.800 --> 00:06:11.530
us there, and that wraps up
this troubleshooting question.

122
00:06:11.530 --> 00:06:13.845
Now we've got one more issue
available in set six, so

123
00:06:13.845 --> 00:06:15.348
we're gonna cover that one next.

124
00:06:15.348 --> 00:06:18.771
Stay tuned because it's coming up.

125
00:06:18.771 --> 00:06:25.239
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #5` from set #6. The trouble ticket states that "BGP is not working between NYEDGE1 and the ISP router, we are receiving no routes "
episodes.title: Set 6 Issue 5
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.067 --> 00:00:08.478
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.478 --> 00:00:12.038
All right it's time for
the final troubleshooting issue of Set 6.

3
00:00:12.038 --> 00:00:13.710
So we're gonna jump right back into it and

4
00:00:13.710 --> 00:00:17.010
get a chance to see what's going on in the
network, figure it out, and resolve it.

5
00:00:17.010 --> 00:00:18.980
For this one we've got a BGP issue,

6
00:00:18.980 --> 00:00:20.850
this is our first
troubleshooting ticket with BGP.

7
00:00:20.850 --> 00:00:27.170
It says here that BGP is not working
between NYEDGE1 and the ISP router.

8
00:00:27.170 --> 00:00:30.110
We are receiving no routes.

9
00:00:30.110 --> 00:00:32.050
Well, if I look at my topology,

10
00:00:32.050 --> 00:00:35.460
NYEDGE1 has a neighbor that's
defined with one of the ISPs.

11
00:00:35.460 --> 00:00:37.930
So I've got it kinda pulled up here.

12
00:00:37.930 --> 00:00:43.270
NYEDGE1 has a gigabit ethernet interface
that's pointing out to an ISP.

13
00:00:43.270 --> 00:00:47.030
The ISP is 172.14.0.3 and
we're not getting any routes.

14
00:00:47.030 --> 00:00:50.600
Now, I immediately start trying
to think of reasons why we might

15
00:00:50.600 --> 00:00:52.470
not be getting routes from the outside.

16
00:00:52.470 --> 00:00:55.760
Misconfiguration is more than
likely what it's gonna be.

17
00:00:55.760 --> 00:01:00.072
But it could be an authentication problem
right BGP does support authentication and

18
00:01:00.072 --> 00:01:02.450
for a WAN link like this
we'd probably use it.

19
00:01:02.450 --> 00:01:05.410
So that's probably
a really likely culprit.

20
00:01:05.410 --> 00:01:07.930
We could have a misconfiguration,
bad neighbor statements,

21
00:01:07.930 --> 00:01:10.390
we could have a bad autonomous
system number defined.

22
00:01:10.390 --> 00:01:12.840
A bad remote AS number defined.

23
00:01:12.840 --> 00:01:15.730
There's all sorts of different things
that cause us not to get any routes.

24
00:01:15.730 --> 00:01:17.750
We'll need to jump into that
system to find out why.

25
00:01:17.750 --> 00:01:21.410
Now before I do that again, I'm gonna take
my most important troubleshooting tool and

26
00:01:21.410 --> 00:01:24.895
I'm gonna write down the IP
address of that ISP.

27
00:01:24.895 --> 00:01:27.251
172.14.0.3.

28
00:01:27.251 --> 00:01:29.973
And the reason is I might have
more than one BGP neighbor.

29
00:01:29.973 --> 00:01:31.650
They don't tell me that in the question.

30
00:01:31.650 --> 00:01:36.380
But it's saying that we're not receiving
routes from, apparently the ISP router,

31
00:01:36.380 --> 00:01:37.420
which would be this guy.

32
00:01:37.420 --> 00:01:40.220
So I want to make sure that when I'm
troubleshooting that I'm actually

33
00:01:40.220 --> 00:01:44.010
troubleshooting this one's connections and
not a connection from some other router

34
00:01:44.010 --> 00:01:45.980
out there that's not
a part of this question.

35
00:01:45.980 --> 00:01:49.120
All right, so let's jump over to
NYEDGE1 and see what it's seeing.

36
00:01:49.120 --> 00:01:51.080
I don't have any access
to the ISP router so

37
00:01:51.080 --> 00:01:54.040
EDGE1's really the only place
we can troubleshoot from.

38
00:01:54.040 --> 00:01:58.570
And it looks like EDGE1's getting
a few errors on it's screen.

39
00:01:58.570 --> 00:02:00.920
Maybe just one or
two kinda popping up here.

40
00:02:00.920 --> 00:02:03.190
So lets look at what we're seeing.

41
00:02:03.190 --> 00:02:07.910
What I'm seeing here is security
alerts for an IP access list.

42
00:02:07.910 --> 00:02:11.120
And so it's logging these and
we've got some kind of protect

43
00:02:11.120 --> 00:02:15.470
statement that's going on saying
denied TCP from 172.14.0.3,

44
00:02:15.470 --> 00:02:21.830
that's that ISP router coming
to us 172.14.0.1 on port 179.

45
00:02:21.830 --> 00:02:26.680
Now what uses port 179?

46
00:02:26.680 --> 00:02:27.180
BGP.

47
00:02:29.150 --> 00:02:32.420
BGP builds all of it's
connections on TCP port 179.

48
00:02:32.420 --> 00:02:36.460
It's one of the few routing
protocols that uses just straight up

49
00:02:36.460 --> 00:02:41.020
unicast TCP communications,
because it's designed for the Internet.

50
00:02:41.020 --> 00:02:46.340
Remember that OSPF, EIGRP, RIP they all
use multi cast addresses to communicate.

51
00:02:46.340 --> 00:02:49.837
And so port numbers don't really matter to
them they're just multi casting it out on

52
00:02:49.837 --> 00:02:52.930
a particular address everybody
else listens on that address.

53
00:02:52.930 --> 00:02:57.110
BGP on the other hand uses
unicast TCP communications and

54
00:02:57.110 --> 00:03:00.060
it looks like we've got
an ACL that's blocking it.

55
00:03:00.060 --> 00:03:03.160
Now one of the issues we're gonna
have with troubleshooting this is,

56
00:03:03.160 --> 00:03:07.100
how annoying these messages can be,
cuz they're gonna continually pop up.

57
00:03:07.100 --> 00:03:11.967
So I'm just gonna jump up into my config

58
00:03:11.967 --> 00:03:17.133
real quick and say, no logging console.

59
00:03:17.133 --> 00:03:20.461
There we go, to try and stop those log
messages from popping up on my screen so

60
00:03:20.461 --> 00:03:22.100
that I can work on this thing.

61
00:03:22.100 --> 00:03:25.240
That is something important, you know
sometimes we just need those commands to

62
00:03:25.240 --> 00:03:28.350
stop, or the errors to stop so
we can work on it.

63
00:03:28.350 --> 00:03:31.360
The real problem here is somebody's
created an ACL and turned logging on for

64
00:03:31.360 --> 00:03:32.820
it, and left it on.

65
00:03:32.820 --> 00:03:35.140
And so we should really turn
that off in the access list,

66
00:03:35.140 --> 00:03:36.560
we can always sort that out later.

67
00:03:36.560 --> 00:03:38.120
But I'm just gonna turn that off.

68
00:03:38.120 --> 00:03:40.490
I do need to remember to turn
that back on when I'm done,

69
00:03:40.490 --> 00:03:43.430
cuz otherwise I might not see other
error messages that are coming up.

70
00:03:43.430 --> 00:03:46.930
The error messages are still occurring,
I'm just not gonna see them.

71
00:03:46.930 --> 00:03:50.760
All right, so now, I can jump in and
try and find out what this problem is.

72
00:03:50.760 --> 00:03:55.050
Apparently, I've got an access list,
and it's blocking BGP, so

73
00:03:55.050 --> 00:03:58.580
I wanna take a look at a few things
just before I dive too far into this.

74
00:03:58.580 --> 00:04:01.570
I'm gonna start with show ip bgp.

75
00:04:01.570 --> 00:04:03.810
They told me that I'm
not learning any routes.

76
00:04:03.810 --> 00:04:06.070
I wanna verify if that's true.

77
00:04:06.070 --> 00:04:09.660
You can do a show ip route but
the problem with BGP routes

78
00:04:09.660 --> 00:04:12.750
is they do get over ridden sometimes or
they're incomplete.

79
00:04:12.750 --> 00:04:14.280
They don't make it into the routing table.

80
00:04:14.280 --> 00:04:18.340
So I just wanna do a show ip bgp which
lets me see the routing table from its

81
00:04:18.340 --> 00:04:19.230
perspective.

82
00:04:19.230 --> 00:04:21.830
And when I look at it, it's empty right.

83
00:04:21.830 --> 00:04:25.490
And if I do a show ip route bgp
I imagine that's empty too.

84
00:04:25.490 --> 00:04:26.490
And it sure is.

85
00:04:26.490 --> 00:04:30.600
So I'm not seeing any BGP
routes either good or bad.

86
00:04:30.600 --> 00:04:33.420
The show IP route will only
show you BGP routes that made

87
00:04:33.420 --> 00:04:35.050
it into the routing table.

88
00:04:35.050 --> 00:04:38.090
Show ip bgp will show
you all of the routes

89
00:04:38.090 --> 00:04:40.000
regardless of whether they made
it in the routing table or not.

90
00:04:40.000 --> 00:04:41.960
So that's why I started with that command.

91
00:04:41.960 --> 00:04:45.120
I'm also gonna do a show ip bgp summary,

92
00:04:45.120 --> 00:04:47.260
which is a great way
to see your neighbors.

93
00:04:47.260 --> 00:04:51.170
And I can see I've got a neighbor,
172.14.0.3, that's the ISP.

94
00:04:51.170 --> 00:04:57.340
But as I look at the details, messages
sent zero, messages received zero.

95
00:04:57.340 --> 00:04:59.680
I've never talked to this person, right?

96
00:04:59.680 --> 00:05:01.630
And if I look at the InQ and

97
00:05:01.630 --> 00:05:05.830
OutQ, I have not learned any
routes from them, Up/Down, never.

98
00:05:05.830 --> 00:05:08.920
State is active, it's active,
I should be talking to it.

99
00:05:08.920 --> 00:05:11.610
But I've never actually
communicated to it.

100
00:05:11.610 --> 00:05:15.590
Which is in line with having
an access list blocking our traffic,

101
00:05:15.590 --> 00:05:18.610
that's kind of what I expected to see,
so that's what I've got here.

102
00:05:18.610 --> 00:05:22.170
So I more than likely just have
an ACL blocking this traffic.

103
00:05:22.170 --> 00:05:23.050
Let's look at that.

104
00:05:23.050 --> 00:05:28.650
If I look at my topology diagram, I'm
connected to it via this GI0/1 interface.

105
00:05:28.650 --> 00:05:30.770
So that's where the ACL would need to be.

106
00:05:30.770 --> 00:05:32.390
Let's see what we've got.

107
00:05:32.390 --> 00:05:36.740
So if I look at interface GI0/1's config,

108
00:05:36.740 --> 00:05:40.180
sure enough it's got an access
group called PROTECT.

109
00:05:40.180 --> 00:05:46.460
And if I do a show access-list PROTECT,
here it is.

110
00:05:46.460 --> 00:05:50.751
And I can see it's permitting some
email traffic, permitting web and SSL,

111
00:05:50.751 --> 00:05:52.302
permitting pop3 and DNS.

112
00:05:52.302 --> 00:05:55.875
And then blocking everything else with
a nice little log command which is a super

113
00:05:55.875 --> 00:05:58.914
way to annoy the heck out of
an administrator to generate too many log

114
00:05:58.914 --> 00:05:59.830
messages.

115
00:05:59.830 --> 00:06:06.290
So looking at this list I do not
see you know BGP in this list.

116
00:06:06.290 --> 00:06:10.180
I do not see that TCP port 179,
and so it's blocking it.

117
00:06:10.180 --> 00:06:13.700
So I just need to update this ACL to
include it and that'll fix that problem.

118
00:06:13.700 --> 00:06:15.790
We'll still have to make sure our
neighbor relationship comes up.

119
00:06:15.790 --> 00:06:19.300
We'll have to make sure we get our routes,
but this one looks like an ACL issue.

120
00:06:19.300 --> 00:06:21.980
So let's jump into our configuration.

121
00:06:21.980 --> 00:06:26.220
And I'm gonna do ip access-list.

122
00:06:26.220 --> 00:06:29.040
This is a extended access list.

123
00:06:29.040 --> 00:06:30.180
And it is called protect.

124
00:06:30.180 --> 00:06:35.970
And I'm gonna start by injecting
a new line before that deny,

125
00:06:35.970 --> 00:06:39.290
or actually I could remove the deny
to get rid of that log message.

126
00:06:39.290 --> 00:06:41.050
Or we could leave it in.

127
00:06:41.050 --> 00:06:45.270
The question isn't really asking for us
to fix this insane amount of logging, so

128
00:06:45.270 --> 00:06:46.590
I should probably leave it be.

129
00:06:46.590 --> 00:06:51.850
In real life land, I would delete line 60,
create a new line 60 allowing BGP,

130
00:06:51.850 --> 00:06:54.950
and then just not include a deny line.

131
00:06:54.950 --> 00:06:58.840
Cuz the implicit deny all will do
exactly what this line is doing, but

132
00:06:58.840 --> 00:07:00.060
without the logging.

133
00:07:00.060 --> 00:07:03.820
They're logging it here, which on a WAN
interface would generate tons of data,

134
00:07:03.820 --> 00:07:05.270
it's probably not a good idea.

135
00:07:05.270 --> 00:07:07.320
But they're not telling me to fix that,
so I'll leave it be,

136
00:07:07.320 --> 00:07:09.800
and I'm gonna inject a line in between.

137
00:07:09.800 --> 00:07:13.190
I'm gonna do, 55 permit TCP.

138
00:07:14.590 --> 00:07:18.630
And then, I can say any any,
if I want, because I just have this

139
00:07:18.630 --> 00:07:22.090
one neighbor to find, but
I can also be really restrictive, too.

140
00:07:22.090 --> 00:07:25.430
I could say allowing it from that host,

141
00:07:25.430 --> 00:07:29.650
from the ISP to me, so we can be as
restrictive or specific as we want.

142
00:07:29.650 --> 00:07:34.930
I'm just gonna go a little general on this
one and say, any any where the destination

143
00:07:34.930 --> 00:07:38.730
is equal to 179, TCP 179.

144
00:07:38.730 --> 00:07:44.970
And now, if I didn't know that port number
I'd have a hard time allowing this right?

145
00:07:44.970 --> 00:07:48.872
And sometimes we have some of
the protocols that are stored in here and

146
00:07:48.872 --> 00:07:50.158
you'll see BGP does.

147
00:07:50.158 --> 00:07:53.607
So even if you forget it you really
just have to remember that it's TCP

148
00:07:53.607 --> 00:07:54.270
and not UDP.

149
00:07:54.270 --> 00:07:58.550
And then there's a named alias for
BGP that we could use.

150
00:07:58.550 --> 00:08:02.520
Or again if we had forgotten it we could
have just looked at those logs, cuz every

151
00:08:02.520 --> 00:08:06.850
log message that was popping up was
telling us that it was on port 179 right.

152
00:08:06.850 --> 00:08:10.450
But now that I've got that in place,
if I pull up that ACL,

153
00:08:10.450 --> 00:08:14.650
I'll do a show access-list PROTECT.

154
00:08:16.450 --> 00:08:20.410
And if I spell that right that command
will work just a little bit better.

155
00:08:20.410 --> 00:08:21.410
There we go.

156
00:08:21.410 --> 00:08:24.310
And now I can see that I'm
permitting BGP traffic.

157
00:08:24.310 --> 00:08:26.530
I've already got seven matches on it.

158
00:08:26.530 --> 00:08:28.700
And now that traffic
should be getting through.

159
00:08:28.700 --> 00:08:31.080
Now I've suppressed
the logging on my console.

160
00:08:31.080 --> 00:08:32.800
So I don't see that happening.

161
00:08:32.800 --> 00:08:35.320
It's probably safe to go ahead and
turn that on.

162
00:08:35.320 --> 00:08:37.990
So I'll go ahead and say logging console.

163
00:08:37.990 --> 00:08:41.730
But it's probably too late for me to see
things like the adjacency coming up or

164
00:08:41.730 --> 00:08:42.670
any of that stuff.

165
00:08:42.670 --> 00:08:45.410
So I'll use my other
commands to view that.

166
00:08:45.410 --> 00:08:49.320
I'm gonna do a show ip bgp summary.

167
00:08:50.700 --> 00:08:55.340
And I already saw my neighbor, but
what I see now is not only do I have

168
00:08:55.340 --> 00:09:00.520
a neighbor but I've sent five messages and
received seven.

169
00:09:00.520 --> 00:09:07.080
And if I scroll over here,
I've received ten prefixes on this link.

170
00:09:07.080 --> 00:09:09.560
So I've actually learned networks.

171
00:09:09.560 --> 00:09:12.820
Now those networks may or may not make
it into my routing table, I don't know.

172
00:09:12.820 --> 00:09:17.115
But if I do a show ip bgp I'll
be able to see them, and so

173
00:09:17.115 --> 00:09:21.043
that's what I'm gonna do next,
is show ip bgp.

174
00:09:21.043 --> 00:09:24.207
And in the output for that command,
here's the routes that come in and

175
00:09:24.207 --> 00:09:26.296
remember routes that
have a star beside them,

176
00:09:26.296 --> 00:09:28.620
those are ones that made
it into the routing table.

177
00:09:28.620 --> 00:09:30.010
If there's no star, it didn't.

178
00:09:30.010 --> 00:09:32.870
Actually it looks like all the routes that
I learned made it into the routing table.

179
00:09:32.870 --> 00:09:37.570
So I've got several routes here that
are coming in from BGP from that neighbor.

180
00:09:37.570 --> 00:09:43.112
And if I do a show ip route bgp,
there they are active in my routing table.

181
00:09:43.112 --> 00:09:45.280
All right, and including a default route.

182
00:09:45.280 --> 00:09:47.000
So we're actually getting
some pretty good stuff there.

183
00:09:47.000 --> 00:09:50.588
So we've got all those routes,
we've learned them and now BFP is working.

184
00:09:50.588 --> 00:09:54.320
So it seemed like a BGP issue
according to the question but

185
00:09:54.320 --> 00:09:57.310
at the end of the day this was really
just an access-list issue right.

186
00:09:57.310 --> 00:10:01.380
When ACL that was a little too
restrictive blocking our BGP traffic.

187
00:10:01.380 --> 00:10:03.170
Once we approved it we were in business.

188
00:10:03.170 --> 00:10:07.890
Now I approved the BGP protocol itself,
I could've just removed the ACL,

189
00:10:07.890 --> 00:10:10.650
or I could've done a permit
ip any any in that ACL.

190
00:10:10.650 --> 00:10:13.440
I could've just gone crazy with it and
killed our security.

191
00:10:13.440 --> 00:10:18.170
But I was specific enough
to have proved the problem,

192
00:10:18.170 --> 00:10:20.000
get it fixed, and get this one in play.

193
00:10:20.000 --> 00:10:23.290
So again, more than one solution
to this type of problem and

194
00:10:23.290 --> 00:10:24.540
this one gets a pass list.

195
00:10:24.540 --> 00:10:28.950
We're fortunate here that we didn't have
any really deeper dive stuff into BGP.

196
00:10:28.950 --> 00:10:30.730
We could've had a bad neighbor command.

197
00:10:30.730 --> 00:10:32.235
The remote AS could've been wrong.

198
00:10:32.235 --> 00:10:35.740
There's a lot of other problems in BGP
that could've resulted in this same

199
00:10:35.740 --> 00:10:38.390
exact scenario, but
we knew to look at the ACL

200
00:10:38.390 --> 00:10:40.060
because the error message was
right there on the screen.

201
00:10:40.060 --> 00:10:41.990
It was popping up over and
over and over again.

202
00:10:41.990 --> 00:10:44.110
It really guided us right
to what that problem was.

203
00:10:44.110 --> 00:10:45.780
So that really does help out.

204
00:10:45.780 --> 00:10:48.840
But that wraps up this issue,
issue number five.

205
00:10:48.840 --> 00:10:52.090
And that's the last issue for
Set 6, so that one is done.

206
00:10:52.090 --> 00:10:57.144
But stay tuned,
cuz we've got set Set 7 coming up next.

207
00:10:57.144 --> 00:11:03.489
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #1` from set #7. The trouble ticket states that "Packets from PLABCSCO01 are not reaching NYCORE1 SVI VLAN 16. For example pings are failing "
episodes.title: Set 7 Issue 1
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.215 --> 00:00:05.723
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.540 --> 00:00:11.912
Welcome back to another troubleshooting
segment here on IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:11.912 --> 00:00:14.987
Today, we're kicking off
set number seven issue one,

4
00:00:14.987 --> 00:00:17.481
that means we got all
new topology to look at.

5
00:00:17.481 --> 00:00:18.800
And this one looks like a doozy.

6
00:00:18.800 --> 00:00:20.880
We've got a little bit of BGP,
a little IBGP,

7
00:00:20.880 --> 00:00:22.920
a couple of neat protocols mixed in there.

8
00:00:22.920 --> 00:00:25.713
That we haven't seen yet
in some of our troubleshooting episodes so

9
00:00:25.713 --> 00:00:27.431
I'm really excited to get into this one.

10
00:00:27.431 --> 00:00:28.894
And we'll start off
with ticket number one.

11
00:00:28.894 --> 00:00:29.666
It reads like this.

12
00:00:29.666 --> 00:00:35.540
It says, packets from Plab Cisco 01
are not reaching NY Core 1 SVI VLAN 16.

13
00:00:35.540 --> 00:00:40.660
We'll see how many abbreviations we
can get in one troubleshooting ticket.

14
00:00:40.660 --> 00:00:42.726
For example pings are failing.

15
00:00:42.726 --> 00:00:45.150
All right so
what do we take away from that statement?

16
00:00:45.150 --> 00:00:47.230
Well first, let's go ahead and
pull up our topology so

17
00:00:47.230 --> 00:00:49.770
we can get an idea of what
this is really talking about.

18
00:00:49.770 --> 00:00:52.570
Our topology for
set seven is a little bit different and

19
00:00:52.570 --> 00:00:55.040
we have a few less devices
to worry about here.

20
00:00:55.040 --> 00:00:58.850
Notice that we've still got our
three switches down here except,

21
00:00:58.850 --> 00:01:02.330
we've got a layer two link between
these switches and a layer three link.

22
00:01:02.330 --> 00:01:05.280
So that's a little bit different
than what we've seen in other sets.

23
00:01:05.280 --> 00:01:09.610
We've also got BGP up here on NY edge one,
and

24
00:01:09.610 --> 00:01:13.240
interior IBGP running between it and
core two.

25
00:01:13.240 --> 00:01:17.530
So a little bit of extra topology there,
we've got EIGRP800 in the mix,

26
00:01:17.530 --> 00:01:19.120
a few different routing protocols.

27
00:01:19.120 --> 00:01:20.749
All stuff we need to be aware of.

28
00:01:20.749 --> 00:01:26.310
Now, the troubleshooting ticket is
telling me that we've got packets failing

29
00:01:26.310 --> 00:01:31.460
from PLABCISCO01 right here and
going to NYCORE1 which is right here.

30
00:01:31.460 --> 00:01:34.770
Now, I don't necessarily know
the path of that traffic.

31
00:01:34.770 --> 00:01:38.010
One path, is that we could
be coming across to ACCESS1,

32
00:01:38.010 --> 00:01:41.059
going right up this link and
hitting CORE1, right?

33
00:01:41.059 --> 00:01:43.620
This is 192.168.16.10.

34
00:01:43.620 --> 00:01:48.590
They told me it's on VLAN 16 when
they said this is a S V I VLAN 16.

35
00:01:48.590 --> 00:01:51.781
And then I can see this
link is VLAN 16 and so

36
00:01:51.781 --> 00:01:54.896
I should just be able
to jump right across.

37
00:01:54.896 --> 00:01:55.940
But let's assume for

38
00:01:55.940 --> 00:01:59.080
a moment that maybe spanning tree
protocol shut this link down.

39
00:01:59.080 --> 00:02:02.630
The other path is I can
jump up here to NYCORE2.

40
00:02:02.630 --> 00:02:05.210
And cross one these links
to get to the other side.

41
00:02:05.210 --> 00:02:09.090
Probably not this top link since it's a
layer three link and I'm not being routed.

42
00:02:09.090 --> 00:02:12.310
I'm a person on VLAN 16
pinging somebody on VLAN 16,

43
00:02:12.310 --> 00:02:15.280
so it would probably be
this bottom link down here.

44
00:02:15.280 --> 00:02:18.020
So, those are really the three
links I need to look at to try and

45
00:02:18.020 --> 00:02:20.830
find out why my ping
is not getting across.

46
00:02:20.830 --> 00:02:26.100
Could be a layer 2 issue, could be a layer
3 issue, but it's pretty unlikely, right?

47
00:02:26.100 --> 00:02:28.760
Because I'm pinging somebody
else on the same VLAN as me,

48
00:02:28.760 --> 00:02:30.770
and that means I'm not getting routed.

49
00:02:30.770 --> 00:02:34.590
So, regular ACLs aren't going to apply,
but we could have VLAN ACLs,

50
00:02:34.590 --> 00:02:36.880
so they could be
intercepting this traffic.

51
00:02:36.880 --> 00:02:41.458
I do find it out that this question says,
Hackets from PLABCSCO01.

52
00:02:41.458 --> 00:02:44.900
They're not singling out something
specific like just pings.

53
00:02:44.900 --> 00:02:49.610
So in this case it looks like all traffic
from PLABCSCO01 is not getting over to

54
00:02:49.610 --> 00:02:50.608
core, core 2.

55
00:02:50.608 --> 00:02:52.482
They're just using pings as an example.

56
00:02:52.482 --> 00:02:55.012
So, let's jump in and
see if we can't troubleshoot this and

57
00:02:55.012 --> 00:02:56.340
if we can't figure this out.

58
00:02:56.340 --> 00:02:59.790
The first thing I want to do is, well,
I guess I wanna start with the ping and

59
00:02:59.790 --> 00:03:01.940
see whether or not I can ping across.

60
00:03:01.940 --> 00:03:04.600
But the other thing I need to do is
find out what the path would be.

61
00:03:04.600 --> 00:03:06.667
Once I get to NYACESS1.

62
00:03:06.667 --> 00:03:12.227
Where do I go from there if I'm trying
to get to NYCORE1's VLAN16 interface,

63
00:03:12.227 --> 00:03:17.160
and I don't even know the IP address
of NYCORE1's VLAN16 address.

64
00:03:17.160 --> 00:03:20.820
So maybe I should start there and figure
out the IP address they're using to test

65
00:03:20.820 --> 00:03:23.440
with, and
then troubleshoot the rest beyond that.

66
00:03:23.440 --> 00:03:26.210
So, I'm gonna jump over to NYCORE1 and

67
00:03:26.210 --> 00:03:28.490
I'm gonna solve the mystery
of that IP address.

68
00:03:30.550 --> 00:03:34.948
So, I'll just do a quick
show IP interface brief.

69
00:03:34.948 --> 00:03:36.856
And I'll exclude out those
unassigned interfaces.

70
00:03:36.856 --> 00:03:43.011
And so on VLAN 16, it is 192.168.16.1,
that's it right there.

71
00:03:43.011 --> 00:03:46.890
And so that's who Key Lab Cisco
01 is unable to contact.

72
00:03:46.890 --> 00:03:49.050
I can see it's on VLAN 16,
and while I'm in here,

73
00:03:49.050 --> 00:03:52.505
I can save a little bit of time and
just make sure that interface is up, up.

74
00:03:52.505 --> 00:03:54.906
Cuz if it was up down then we might
have found our problem already.

75
00:03:54.906 --> 00:03:58.774
But here it's up, up so
that's not gonna be an easy one today.

76
00:03:58.774 --> 00:04:03.840
All right I'm gonna jump over
PLABCS01 where I'll just fire

77
00:04:03.840 --> 00:04:10.554
up one of the command prompts here and
see if I can ping 192.168.16.1.

78
00:04:10.554 --> 00:04:12.818
Now I'm 192.168.16.10.

79
00:04:12.818 --> 00:04:16.430
192.168.16.1 should be on
the same network as me.

80
00:04:16.430 --> 00:04:19.310
So I should be able to send
them our broadcast and say,

81
00:04:19.310 --> 00:04:21.300
what's the mac address for this IP?

82
00:04:21.300 --> 00:04:24.666
And that node should get it and respond
back and say, here's my mac address and

83
00:04:24.666 --> 00:04:26.000
then we should be able to ping.

84
00:04:27.080 --> 00:04:28.700
But that's not happening here.

85
00:04:28.700 --> 00:04:33.745
And, if I wanna see that for
sure I can always do an arp-a.

86
00:04:33.745 --> 00:04:34.880
And there's my ARP table.

87
00:04:34.880 --> 00:04:38.990
And 192.168.16.1 is not in that list.

88
00:04:38.990 --> 00:04:40.850
So I'm definitely not seeing.

89
00:04:40.850 --> 00:04:42.550
I'm not getting an ARP response back.

90
00:04:42.550 --> 00:04:45.660
It's like that machines not even
on the same equipment as I am.

91
00:04:45.660 --> 00:04:46.650
All right?

92
00:04:46.650 --> 00:04:49.979
I could also do a quick check just to
make sure my Subnet Mask is right.

93
00:04:51.020 --> 00:04:54.418
Because that's a big enough difference
in numbers that we could be on different

94
00:04:54.418 --> 00:04:56.054
subnets but it looks fine to me right.

95
00:04:56.054 --> 00:04:59.170
We've got that standard
slash 24 subnet mass there.

96
00:04:59.170 --> 00:05:02.090
So, I doubt we've got a problem
here on our work station.

97
00:05:02.090 --> 00:05:06.190
But, now I need to take a look at
the path we follow on the traffic.

98
00:05:06.190 --> 00:05:09.850
Now I don't actually know the path, so
we're gonna have to unravel that mystery.

99
00:05:09.850 --> 00:05:13.728
But I do know the first step on
my journey is NYACCESS1, and

100
00:05:13.728 --> 00:05:16.453
I know that my port should be on VLAN 16.

101
00:05:16.453 --> 00:05:20.713
And then one of these links, at least
one if not both, of these links for

102
00:05:20.713 --> 00:05:22.420
VLAN 16 should be active.

103
00:05:22.420 --> 00:05:24.959
So let's jump over to ACCESS1 and
see what we've got on that one.

104
00:05:26.400 --> 00:05:28.415
All right, jumping onto access one.

105
00:05:31.853 --> 00:05:36.853
I'm just gonna do a quick show run for

106
00:05:36.853 --> 00:05:39.927
interface FA0/1.

107
00:05:39.927 --> 00:05:42.916
I'm just looking at this
interface right here.

108
00:05:42.916 --> 00:05:47.209
I wanna make sure that it's on VLAN 16 so
that my work station is on the right VLAN.

109
00:05:48.370 --> 00:05:49.059
And sure enough it is.

110
00:05:49.059 --> 00:05:53.850
Switchport access vlan 16 and
spanning-tree portfast, right.

111
00:05:53.850 --> 00:05:58.270
So, that's a typical access port
right there, we should be good to go.

112
00:05:58.270 --> 00:06:01.600
Now, I'm on VLAN 16,
who else is on VLAN 16?

113
00:06:01.600 --> 00:06:07.390
If I do a show vlan, what I'm looking for
now, are these two links here.

114
00:06:07.390 --> 00:06:12.072
It says that port 23 and
port 24 should be on VLAN 16, and so

115
00:06:12.072 --> 00:06:17.649
I'm going to pull up that output,
and I'm looking for ports 23 and 24.

116
00:06:17.649 --> 00:06:19.450
And sure enough they are.

117
00:06:19.450 --> 00:06:20.940
So all three of us are on VLAN 16, and

118
00:06:20.940 --> 00:06:23.029
I should be able to pass
over any of those links.

119
00:06:24.330 --> 00:06:29.260
And I'm just gonna do a real quick show
run for interface FA0/23 and 24 and

120
00:06:29.260 --> 00:06:32.056
the reason I wanna look
at these interfaces,

121
00:06:32.056 --> 00:06:34.500
I'm just looking for anything weird.

122
00:06:34.500 --> 00:06:36.021
Any kind of policies or

123
00:06:36.021 --> 00:06:41.600
any kind of crazy settings that might
be in place that might cause a problem.

124
00:06:41.600 --> 00:06:45.022
But I'm disappointed because all I
get is a nice, normal configuration.

125
00:06:45.022 --> 00:06:48.815
Switch board access vlan
16 spanning-tree portfast.

126
00:06:48.815 --> 00:06:52.600
Now because Cisco switches can
do dynamic trunk negotiations

127
00:06:52.600 --> 00:06:56.170
I can't necessarily trust
that these are access ports.

128
00:06:56.170 --> 00:06:59.957
They could be showing this config but
still trunk afterwards and if they

129
00:06:59.957 --> 00:07:04.310
are trunk VLANs can get pruned by VTP,
there's other things that could there too.

130
00:07:04.310 --> 00:07:06.488
Not to mention old spanning
tree is running so

131
00:07:06.488 --> 00:07:10.112
I still need to take a look at that and
just make sure these ports are active.

132
00:07:10.112 --> 00:07:13.672
So, one thing I'm gonna do is just
a quick show interface trunk so

133
00:07:13.672 --> 00:07:16.408
I can find out if ports 23 and
24 are trunking.

134
00:07:16.408 --> 00:07:17.099
And they're not.

135
00:07:17.099 --> 00:07:19.420
All right, so
they are standard access ports.

136
00:07:19.420 --> 00:07:22.670
They're just moving VLAN 16 and that's it.

137
00:07:22.670 --> 00:07:25.350
And that means I can do
a show spanning tree.

138
00:07:25.350 --> 00:07:26.920
And just look at vlan16.

139
00:07:26.920 --> 00:07:31.760
And if I do a space there that
will work a little better.

140
00:07:31.760 --> 00:07:32.816
There we go.

141
00:07:32.816 --> 00:07:36.800
I can see that I've got port 1,
port 23 and port 24.

142
00:07:36.800 --> 00:07:41.175
I've got forwarding on port one,
that's where Cisco 01 is plugged in.

143
00:07:41.175 --> 00:07:45.122
And I've got forwarding on port 23,
port 24 is blocking.

144
00:07:45.122 --> 00:07:49.115
I expected to see at least one blocking
because we do have a loop here.

145
00:07:49.115 --> 00:07:50.563
So somebody's got to block.

146
00:07:50.563 --> 00:07:53.145
So, looking at this port 23 is active.

147
00:07:53.145 --> 00:07:56.005
That's this link over here and
this link is being held down.

148
00:07:56.005 --> 00:07:59.760
So now I know my traffic is
gonna cross to this switch.

to get a better idea.
