00:21:17.400 --> 00:21:21.040
And just to stop these errors on my
screen, I'm gonna go into config and

366
00:21:21.040 --> 00:21:25.580
do a no logging console, just to get those
to stop popping up every few seconds, or

367
00:21:25.580 --> 00:21:27.270
they're gonna drive me crazy.

368
00:21:27.270 --> 00:21:32.046
All right, and now that I've done that,
let me just do a show running-config.

369
00:21:33.546 --> 00:21:35.519
And we'll take a look
at our configurations,

370
00:21:35.519 --> 00:21:37.870
see if we can't spot the issue in here,
okay?

371
00:21:37.870 --> 00:21:40.230
Now most of our configuration's
gonna be pretty straightforward,

372
00:21:40.230 --> 00:21:43.200
I'm not expecting to see anything
too crazy jump out at me.

373
00:21:43.200 --> 00:21:48.450
Here I've got some spanning-tree, I do
have spanning-tree vlan 16 priority 4096.

374
00:21:48.450 --> 00:21:52.810
So this switch is set with the lowest
priority that you're allowed to set.

375
00:21:52.810 --> 00:21:55.200
If you go zero it doesn't work right.

376
00:21:55.200 --> 00:21:57.590
So that's really the best one,
this guy is going to be the root,

377
00:21:57.590 --> 00:22:00.680
and I've been seeing that
it is indeed the root.

378
00:22:00.680 --> 00:22:02.340
So that's not too crazy.

379
00:22:02.340 --> 00:22:07.089
Scroll up just a little bit, here we've
got ip arp inspection for vlan 16-17.

380
00:22:07.089 --> 00:22:09.797
All right, so
we are inspecting that traffic.

381
00:22:09.797 --> 00:22:13.421
And then as we look down a little further,

382
00:22:13.421 --> 00:22:18.505
I'm seeing pretty typical
configurations down the way.

383
00:22:18.505 --> 00:22:24.713
And so far nothing jumping
out here as a real problem.

384
00:22:28.130 --> 00:22:32.100
Yeah, I actually really did expect to find
something a little more amazing than that.

385
00:22:32.100 --> 00:22:33.620
So [LAUGH] what I was looking for

386
00:22:33.620 --> 00:22:36.160
was potentially to have
a hard coded MAC address.

387
00:22:36.160 --> 00:22:39.220
Right, like a static MAC put in or
something like that and

388
00:22:39.220 --> 00:22:42.040
I'm kind of surprised to
not see any of that so.

389
00:22:43.870 --> 00:22:47.200
Yeah, it looks like ARP Inspection
is not our problem on this one.

390
00:22:48.590 --> 00:22:51.200
So let's see,
what else could be causing our problem?

391
00:22:51.200 --> 00:22:54.240
Let's take a look over
at NYCORE1 real quick.

392
00:22:54.240 --> 00:23:00.640
There is the possibility that
the MAC address is clearing NYCORE2,

393
00:23:00.640 --> 00:23:04.290
being sent to NYCORE1, and
NYCORE1 is rejecting it.

394
00:23:04.290 --> 00:23:06.040
That's a possibility also.

395
00:23:06.040 --> 00:23:07.380
So we'll go and take a look at it and

396
00:23:07.380 --> 00:23:09.350
see if anything jumps out
in the configuration here.

397
00:23:10.710 --> 00:23:16.087
So on NYCORE1,
I'm gonna do a show running-config.

398
00:23:16.087 --> 00:23:19.172
And we'll basically repeat
the process here, looking through for

399
00:23:19.172 --> 00:23:22.030
anything that jumps out at
us as being kinda crazy.

400
00:23:22.030 --> 00:23:23.610
And just looking at it so far,

401
00:23:23.610 --> 00:23:26.500
I'm seeing pretty much normal stuff,
nothing too crazy.

402
00:23:26.500 --> 00:23:29.904
We've got spanning-tree configured,
per vlan, spanning-tree and

403
00:23:29.904 --> 00:23:31.420
actually that's a good point.

404
00:23:31.420 --> 00:23:34.210
I haven't been paying attention
too much to the different

405
00:23:34.210 --> 00:23:36.490
types of spanning-tree
that we could be running.

406
00:23:36.490 --> 00:23:40.047
I know that NYCORE2
showed up as being root.

407
00:23:40.047 --> 00:23:43.579
But there's also the possibility that
one's set up for rapid spanning-tree and

408
00:23:43.579 --> 00:23:45.610
one's just regular spanning-tree.

409
00:23:45.610 --> 00:23:47.799
We'll have to see,
if we still don't find our problem.

410
00:23:49.010 --> 00:23:51.010
All right, so continuing to look here.

411
00:23:51.010 --> 00:23:53.632
Looks like we have a pretty
straightforward interface configuration.

412
00:23:53.632 --> 00:23:57.620
I don't see any security options or
anything too crazy like that.

413
00:23:57.620 --> 00:24:03.580
And yeah, that one that one
looks pretty Pretty okay also.

414
00:24:03.580 --> 00:24:05.170
That'll be my official
tech term of the day.

415
00:24:05.170 --> 00:24:06.850
Pretty okay.

416
00:24:06.850 --> 00:24:07.420
So.
All right.

417
00:24:08.970 --> 00:24:11.710
It looks like they've cooked up a pretty
good troubleshooting problem for

418
00:24:11.710 --> 00:24:13.910
us on this one.

419
00:24:13.910 --> 00:24:14.590
I am curious.

420
00:24:14.590 --> 00:24:16.980
Let's doublecheck our spanning tree.

421
00:24:16.980 --> 00:24:18.500
With spanning tree,
usually if you have a problem,

422
00:24:18.500 --> 00:24:22.130
it manifests itself as having a port
blocking that shouldn't be blocking.

423
00:24:22.130 --> 00:24:24.110
And in my case,
everything seemed to be fine.

424
00:24:24.110 --> 00:24:26.290
I didn't spot any actual loop or
anything like that.

425
00:24:26.290 --> 00:24:27.840
So I doubt that's our issue.

426
00:24:28.990 --> 00:24:31.560
And we talked about
dynamic arp inspection.

427
00:24:31.560 --> 00:24:33.400
There's an easy way to test whether or
not that's a problem.

428
00:24:33.400 --> 00:24:36.230
We can always just turn it off and
see if the problem goes away.

429
00:24:36.230 --> 00:24:39.040
Turn it back on and
see if a problem comes back.

430
00:24:39.040 --> 00:24:40.910
That's kind of one way to resolve it.

431
00:24:40.910 --> 00:24:45.410
I left PLABCSCO01 here just
doing a constant ping.

432
00:24:45.410 --> 00:24:47.250
So it's running in the background.

433
00:24:47.250 --> 00:24:50.286
And if I go over to Core 2,

434
00:24:50.286 --> 00:24:55.807
the commanding question is,
let's see here.

435
00:24:59.367 --> 00:25:04.050
Let's do, There we go.

436
00:25:04.050 --> 00:25:08.550
We've got that IP arp
inspection VLAN 16 through 17.

437
00:25:08.550 --> 00:25:12.370
Oh, you know what, I forgot about
something kind of important.

438
00:25:12.370 --> 00:25:16.510
All right, so,
with arp inspection turned on,

439
00:25:16.510 --> 00:25:22.480
what we're expecting is an access port
should only be carrying a single IP.

440
00:25:22.480 --> 00:25:23.040
All right.

441
00:25:23.040 --> 00:25:24.220
I'm glad I ran this command, though,

442
00:25:24.220 --> 00:25:26.580
I 've stumbled on the problem
accidentally, I think.

443
00:25:26.580 --> 00:25:32.120
So, we expect an access port to have one
IP, the problem is, in our topology here,

444
00:25:32.120 --> 00:25:37.220
our trunks are actually set
up as access ports, right?

445
00:25:37.220 --> 00:25:38.810
This is an access for VLAN 16.

446
00:25:38.810 --> 00:25:40.820
This is access for VLAN 16.

447
00:25:40.820 --> 00:25:44.330
Now, up here,
I'm not having a problem because I've got

448
00:25:45.860 --> 00:25:48.890
this guy right here,
IP arp inspection trust.

449
00:25:48.890 --> 00:25:50.980
I'm trusting that interface.

450
00:25:50.980 --> 00:25:55.130
And let me just make sure that is actually
port 23 that's returning that command.

451
00:25:55.130 --> 00:25:59.180
So, I'm gonna do a show run for
interface FA1/0/23 And

452
00:25:59.180 --> 00:26:01.420
sure enough that one's being trusted,
okay?

453
00:26:01.420 --> 00:26:03.510
So we're trusting it because it's a trunk.

454
00:26:03.510 --> 00:26:06.350
I mean it's not actually a trunk, but we
know it's going to be carrying traffic for

455
00:26:06.350 --> 00:26:08.320
more than one system.

456
00:26:08.320 --> 00:26:10.180
But this link down here, port 22.

457
00:26:10.180 --> 00:26:12.170
That one.

458
00:26:12.170 --> 00:26:17.160
I bet we'll see it's trusted, because
it didn't come back any other command.

459
00:26:17.160 --> 00:26:18.554
So I look at FA1/0/22.

460
00:26:19.590 --> 00:26:20.390
There we go.

461
00:26:20.390 --> 00:26:21.520
It's not trusted.

462
00:26:21.520 --> 00:26:25.550
That means it's expecting only
one MAC address on there as you

463
00:26:25.550 --> 00:26:29.950
would expect to see with arp inspection
with just a regular access client.

464
00:26:29.950 --> 00:26:31.475
But I'm using it as a trunk.

465
00:26:31.475 --> 00:26:36.345
So I'll bet if we just add this one to
our trusted list, that'll allow more than

466
00:26:36.345 --> 00:26:39.745
one MAC address on the interface,
and I bet that'll solve our problem.

467
00:26:39.745 --> 00:26:41.445
So let's get in there and
make that change.

468
00:26:41.445 --> 00:26:43.515
I'm gonna go into fa1/0/22.

469
00:26:43.515 --> 00:26:48.075
I'll do an IP arp inspection trust.

470
00:26:49.115 --> 00:26:52.268
And I should be able to
turn on logging console now

471
00:26:55.147 --> 00:26:59.149
Because now that I trust that interface,
now I should start learning MAC addresses

472
00:26:59.149 --> 00:27:01.830
on, or
allowing the MAC addresses to propagate.

473
00:27:01.830 --> 00:27:03.930
And we should see that pass on through.

474
00:27:03.930 --> 00:27:06.890
Now I'm gonna give that a moment, because
MAC address changes like this usually

475
00:27:06.890 --> 00:27:10.000
do take a moment, but
we can repeat what I did before,

476
00:27:10.000 --> 00:27:14.870
which is to go to each switch in the path
starting with Access1, then Core2,

477
00:27:14.870 --> 00:27:17.870
then Core1, looking to see if that
MAC address shows up in the table.

478
00:27:17.870 --> 00:27:22.100
And I'll do show MAC address table,
I'll include anybody with 4c1a.

479
00:27:22.100 --> 00:27:24.628
So here I am, on Access1,
just like I was before.

480
00:27:26.465 --> 00:27:29.300
And then, we'll jump over to Core2.

481
00:27:29.300 --> 00:27:34.110
Core2 was able to see it before, also,
right, so I expect that to still turn up.

482
00:27:34.110 --> 00:27:35.410
And there it is on port 22.

483
00:27:35.410 --> 00:27:43.310
And then what I'm hoping is that we're
now showing up over here on Core1.

484
00:27:43.310 --> 00:27:44.260
And so I'll just do a check.

485
00:27:44.260 --> 00:27:45.930
And sure enough, there it is.

486
00:27:45.930 --> 00:27:48.260
And I'll bet our ping just started.

487
00:27:48.260 --> 00:27:52.640
Let's jump back to the Cisco sever,
and sure enough, there it is.

488
00:27:52.640 --> 00:27:55.540
We're able to ping across and
there it goes.

489
00:27:55.540 --> 00:27:58.730
So that one turned out to
be a bit of a tricky one.

490
00:27:58.730 --> 00:28:03.350
Everything looked fine from a quick
glance, right, I was expecting a VLAN ACL

491
00:28:03.350 --> 00:28:07.030
or some other kind of restriction
like a port security restriction.

492
00:28:07.030 --> 00:28:09.120
But in this case it came
down to that arp inspection.

493
00:28:09.120 --> 00:28:12.250
And I didn't think to
look there first because.

494
00:28:12.250 --> 00:28:17.220
DHCP snooping is the error message and
I wasn't having a DHCP problem right?

495
00:28:17.220 --> 00:28:20.750
But we have to remember that aro
inspection is actually a sub setting

496
00:28:20.750 --> 00:28:25.950
of DHCP snooping and it builds off of
that so its kind of a tricky one there,

497
00:28:25.950 --> 00:28:28.420
but now that we trusted that port
its allowing that to happen.

498
00:28:28.420 --> 00:28:31.580
When you use aro inspection,
you need to trust all of your trunks.

499
00:28:31.580 --> 00:28:35.550
Any trunk link In this case we had access
ports that we were treating as trunks and

500
00:28:35.550 --> 00:28:38.250
that's why we had to go through
that extra step of trusting it and

501
00:28:38.250 --> 00:28:39.070
once it was done it was there.

502
00:28:39.070 --> 00:28:42.600
Now I only made that change on Core2
because that's the only place I was

503
00:28:42.600 --> 00:28:43.940
running arp inspection.

504
00:28:43.940 --> 00:28:46.650
If I was running arp inspection on the
other switches I would have had to turn it

505
00:28:46.650 --> 00:28:50.430
on there also to make sure that we had
consistent behavior across the network.

506
00:28:50.430 --> 00:28:51.970
But in this case that solves the problem.

507
00:28:51.970 --> 00:28:54.030
Now we're able to ping across the link.

508
00:28:54.030 --> 00:28:55.220
And we're in business.

509
00:28:55.220 --> 00:28:56.180
So that will wrap this one up.

510
00:28:56.180 --> 00:28:57.300
Hope you guys enjoyed it.

511
00:28:57.300 --> 00:28:57.870
Stay tuned.

512
00:28:57.870 --> 00:29:03.402
We've got more trouble
shooting issues coming up.

513
00:29:03.402 --> 00:29:07.650
>> [SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #2` from set #7. The trouble ticket states that "You are unable to see the route for 192.168.16.0 on NYCORE2 but NYCORE1 can see the route for 192.168.17.0, i.e. NYCORE1 and NYCORE2 are exchanging routes across their layer 3 link. "
episodes.title: Set 7 Issue 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:06.088
[SOUND] All right, welcome back to another

2
00:00:06.088 --> 00:00:11.814
troubleshooting episode on ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.814 --> 00:00:15.398
It's time for Set 7, Issue 2, and
we've got a troubleshooting ticket.

4
00:00:15.398 --> 00:00:17.420
Looks like we do have
a routing issue this time.

5
00:00:17.420 --> 00:00:21.790
The ticket reads,
you are unable to see the route for

6
00:00:21.790 --> 00:00:25.467
192.168.16.0 on NYCORE2 but

7
00:00:25.467 --> 00:00:30.570
NYCORE1 can see the route for
192.168.17.0.

8
00:00:30.570 --> 00:00:35.570
It says, for example, NYCORE1 and

9
00:00:35.570 --> 00:00:40.130
NYCORE2 are exchanging routes
across their layer three link.

10
00:00:40.130 --> 00:00:41.740
Which is kind of interesting.

11
00:00:41.740 --> 00:00:44.960
So, the question is worded
a little strange here.

12
00:00:44.960 --> 00:00:46.360
So, let's go to our topology, and

13
00:00:46.360 --> 00:00:48.930
see if we can't kind of unravel
what they're talking about here.

14
00:00:48.930 --> 00:00:54.590
Basically, what's going on,
is on NYCORE2, we have a VLAN, VLAN 17.

15
00:00:54.590 --> 00:00:56.850
And VLAN 17 is 192.168.17.0/24.

16
00:00:56.850 --> 00:01:00.542
And it's present right here in core 2.

17
00:01:00.542 --> 00:01:03.510
It is not present anywhere else,
just on this switch.

18
00:01:04.770 --> 00:01:09.170
And then, on this switch, NYCORE1,
we have 192.168.16.0/24 and

19
00:01:09.170 --> 00:01:14.960
that's actually present here and
down here with this server.

20
00:01:14.960 --> 00:01:17.401
Right?
These guys carry the VLAN for it but

21
00:01:17.401 --> 00:01:21.236
they're not seeing it from
a layer three perspective, right?

22
00:01:21.236 --> 00:01:22.450
Just from layer two.

23
00:01:22.450 --> 00:01:24.036
So, 192.168.17 is here.

24
00:01:24.036 --> 00:01:26.240
And .16 is here.

25
00:01:26.240 --> 00:01:30.380
And these two guys are exchanging
routes over this FA1/0/24 link.

26
00:01:30.380 --> 00:01:33.730
They've got a layer three link
between the two switches and

27
00:01:33.730 --> 00:01:35.268
they're exchanging routes.

28
00:01:35.268 --> 00:01:37.680
Now, it's kinda hard to see
here in the topology, but

29
00:01:37.680 --> 00:01:40.370
they way they're exchanging
routes is this EIGRP 800.

30
00:01:40.370 --> 00:01:43.910
So, they're running EIGRP and
exchanging routes, and

31
00:01:43.910 --> 00:01:48.870
they're saying that NYCORE1 Is
learning 192.168.17.

32
00:01:48.870 --> 00:01:51.680
It's learning it from this guy, but

33
00:01:51.680 --> 00:01:55.950
the other direction NYCORE2 is not
learning 192.168.16 from NYCORE1.

34
00:01:55.950 --> 00:01:57.830
So that's our problem.

35
00:01:57.830 --> 00:02:02.460
We've got routes going one way,
but not another.

36
00:02:02.460 --> 00:02:03.560
So the first thing I wanna do,

37
00:02:03.560 --> 00:02:06.240
cuz the wording of the question
is a little strange here.

38
00:02:06.240 --> 00:02:09.430
The first thing I wanna do is just
verify the facts as I read them.

39
00:02:09.430 --> 00:02:11.012
Right?
What they're explaining to me.

40
00:02:11.012 --> 00:02:14.210
I wanna see it, and make sure that
I'm seeing what they're telling me.

41
00:02:14.210 --> 00:02:18.510
If I look at NYCORE1,
I should see that it's running EIGRP 800,

42
00:02:18.510 --> 00:02:23.100
and it's learning the 192.168.17 network,
and

43
00:02:23.100 --> 00:02:27.082
it's learning it via port
24 to the other switch.

44
00:02:27.082 --> 00:02:30.490
All right, so let's verify that before
we dive too deep into this problem.

45
00:02:32.810 --> 00:02:33.880
Some of the things I need to know.

46
00:02:33.880 --> 00:02:36.805
I need to know the configuration
of that port 24 so

47
00:02:36.805 --> 00:02:40.886
I can kind of understand what's really
going on and if we do a show run for

48
00:02:40.886 --> 00:02:46.619
interface 1/0/24, I can see that it's
192.168.1.1 with a /30 subnet mass.

49
00:02:46.619 --> 00:02:50.510
That means there's only one other
valid ip here, which is .2.

50
00:02:50.510 --> 00:02:55.270
The other side of this line
should be 192.168.1.2.

51
00:02:55.270 --> 00:02:59.090
And if I do a show ip route,

52
00:02:59.090 --> 00:03:05.210
I expect to see a route from
192.168.17 which I do right here.

53
00:03:05.210 --> 00:03:08.640
I expect it to be learned from EIGRP,
which it is.

54
00:03:08.640 --> 00:03:13.353
And I expect it to be learned
from 192.168.1.2 on my

55
00:03:13.353 --> 00:03:17.850
FA1/0/24 interface so
that's exactly as we expect it to be.

56
00:03:17.850 --> 00:03:20.570
We are learning that route
from the other side.

57
00:03:21.690 --> 00:03:28.190
Now, we have a direct connection
to 192.168.16, right there.

58
00:03:28.190 --> 00:03:31.960
We should be teaching that to CORE2,
to the other switch.

59
00:03:31.960 --> 00:03:35.920
We're learning their routes but apparently
we're not telling them our routes.

60
00:03:35.920 --> 00:03:38.830
So, we've got a problem there and
I'm just gonna verify that real quick.

61
00:03:38.830 --> 00:03:42.890
I'm gonna jump over to CORE2 and

62
00:03:42.890 --> 00:03:45.020
we'll just take a quick
peek at it's configuration.

63
00:03:45.020 --> 00:03:49.100
I'm gonna do a show run for
interface fa1/0/24.

64
00:03:49.100 --> 00:03:50.730
Where we expect it to be .2.

65
00:03:50.730 --> 00:03:53.790
We expect it to have that /30 subnet mask,
which it does.

66
00:03:55.180 --> 00:04:00.980
If I do a show IP route,
I'm expecting not to see 192.168.16,

67
00:04:00.980 --> 00:04:04.310
and sure enough,
it gets skipped over right between those.

68
00:04:04.310 --> 00:04:05.860
Don't glance at this too fast.

69
00:04:05.860 --> 00:04:09.500
Like, you've got 193.177.16,
which is close, right?

70
00:04:09.500 --> 00:04:11.390
But it's not the same network.

71
00:04:11.390 --> 00:04:13.350
So I am not seeing it.

72
00:04:13.350 --> 00:04:19.490
If I do a show ip eigrp neighbor, I am
neighbored up with that router, though.

73
00:04:19.490 --> 00:04:21.000
Right, so I am talking to it and

74
00:04:21.000 --> 00:04:24.585
exchanging information,
I'm just not learning anything.

75
00:04:24.585 --> 00:04:27.000
Right?
I'm not actually getting any data from it,

76
00:04:27.000 --> 00:04:30.920
as far as that particular route
to add to the routing table.

77
00:04:30.920 --> 00:04:31.652
I am getting other routes.

78
00:04:31.652 --> 00:04:37.660
All right, so it looks like we got a bit
of a problem, and what could cause this?

79
00:04:37.660 --> 00:04:42.140
If I've got two devices that are
exchanging routes between each other and

80
00:04:42.140 --> 00:04:45.410
I'm just missing one route,
what could cause that?

81
00:04:45.410 --> 00:04:48.750
Well, it could be just a misconfiguration
on the originating switch.

82
00:04:48.750 --> 00:04:50.750
Maybe its not advertising it at all.

83
00:04:50.750 --> 00:04:52.740
It could be a passive interface, right?

84
00:04:52.740 --> 00:04:53.760
Where it's participating.

85
00:04:53.760 --> 00:04:55.077
But that would break communication, so

86
00:04:55.077 --> 00:04:57.200
it's more than likely
not a passive interface.

87
00:04:57.200 --> 00:04:59.790
It could be that I have
an outgoing prefix list or

88
00:04:59.790 --> 00:05:03.170
route map that's filtering
the routes that I advertise out.

89
00:05:03.170 --> 00:05:04.520
That's a possibility.

90
00:05:04.520 --> 00:05:05.910
You could say the opposite.

91
00:05:05.910 --> 00:05:07.880
There could be an incoming prefix list or

92
00:05:07.880 --> 00:05:10.870
route map on the other side that's
stopping them from coming in.

93
00:05:10.870 --> 00:05:15.095
So those are all things we need to look
at, and since I'm on CORE2 I might as well

94
00:05:15.095 --> 00:05:18.990
just check it first,
then we'll jump over and check CORE1.

95
00:05:18.990 --> 00:05:22.110
So on CORE2,
I'm just gonna do a show run, and whoops,

96
00:05:22.110 --> 00:05:25.760
[LAUGH] and I was gonna filter that for
the section.

97
00:05:25.760 --> 00:05:27.990
There we go, for the section of eigrp.

98
00:05:29.660 --> 00:05:32.510
And apparently I don't get
the section command for this one so

99
00:05:32.510 --> 00:05:34.720
we'll do a show run and
we'll just begin with eigrp.

100
00:05:36.920 --> 00:05:43.190
And what I'm expecting to see here, there
we go, are my network statements, right?

101
00:05:43.190 --> 00:05:45.140
And that's about it.

102
00:05:45.140 --> 00:05:47.320
I don't see any authentication configured.

103
00:05:47.320 --> 00:05:48.900
That's something to watch out for.

104
00:05:48.900 --> 00:05:50.580
And everything else looks
pretty straightforward.

105
00:05:50.580 --> 00:05:52.020
We looked at the interface
a few moments ago.

106
00:05:52.020 --> 00:05:53.940
There wasn't anything crazy there, either.

107
00:05:53.940 --> 00:05:56.440
So, this one appears to be okay.

108
00:05:56.440 --> 00:05:57.840
I've got router eigrp 800.

109
00:05:57.840 --> 00:06:01.310
So, my AS number is correct and you
always got to look for a mistake there.

110
00:06:01.310 --> 00:06:03.860
And I've got the network statement that

111
00:06:03.860 --> 00:06:07.920
covers the point-to-point link with the
other switch, that layer three interface.

112
00:06:07.920 --> 00:06:10.860
And I've got the network statement that's
advertising my network, all right?

113
00:06:10.860 --> 00:06:11.670
So, those are good.

114
00:06:11.670 --> 00:06:13.130
I've got one extra here
thrown into the mix.

115
00:06:13.130 --> 00:06:15.090
But that's not part of our problem.

116
00:06:15.090 --> 00:06:17.720
All right, let's go take a look at
CORE1 and see if it's the same way.

117
00:06:19.912 --> 00:06:23.250
On CORE1, I don't remember if
I looked at that interface, so

118
00:06:23.250 --> 00:06:24.380
I'm gonna just pull that up again.

119
00:06:24.380 --> 00:06:25.320
Better safe than sorry.

120
00:06:26.530 --> 00:06:27.630
And looking at the interface.

121
00:06:27.630 --> 00:06:30.060
Okay, nothing crazy there.

122
00:06:30.060 --> 00:06:33.170
And then, if I do a show run for
section eigrp.

123
00:06:33.170 --> 00:06:37.750
Apparently, whatever iOS this is
just doesn't seem to like that, so

124
00:06:37.750 --> 00:06:39.520
let me just do a begin again.

125
00:06:41.580 --> 00:06:42.833
And, what do we have here?

126
00:06:44.168 --> 00:06:48.560
All right, that is an awfully small
routing configuration for eigrp.

127
00:06:48.560 --> 00:06:50.390
It's just two lines.

128
00:06:50.390 --> 00:06:53.680
Router eigrp 800, that turned on eigrp.

129
00:06:53.680 --> 00:06:55.450
That's good.

130
00:06:55.450 --> 00:07:01.110
And then network 192.168.1.0, that's
the link between me and the other switch.

131
00:07:01.110 --> 00:07:03.924
Between CORE1 and CORE2.

132
00:07:03.924 --> 00:07:06.430
And it's gotta 0.0.0.3 wildcard mask,
but if we work that out,

133
00:07:06.430 --> 00:07:08.862
that actually covers the two switches,
right?

134
00:07:08.862 --> 00:07:10.010
192.168.1.1 and 192.168.1.2.

135
00:07:10.010 --> 00:07:14.700
So that's actually the right statement for
that link, but

136
00:07:14.700 --> 00:07:19.650
my problem here is there's nothing to

137
00:07:19.650 --> 00:07:24.550
advertise the 192.168.16 network or
really any other network, for that matter.

138
00:07:24.550 --> 00:07:28.380
So, I'm not advertising
out those other networks.

139
00:07:28.380 --> 00:07:31.310
If I'm not originating the network,
how's anybody else gonna learn about it?

140
00:07:31.310 --> 00:07:32.600
They're not.

141
00:07:32.600 --> 00:07:33.900
So I need to fix this and

142
00:07:33.900 --> 00:07:37.030
the easiest way is just to add
it in as a network statement.

143
00:07:37.030 --> 00:07:39.650
I do need to make a decision,
like how many networks do I have?

144
00:07:39.650 --> 00:07:43.790
If I do a show ip interface brief and
exclude the unassigned.

145
00:07:43.790 --> 00:07:46.570
I've only got two networks,
so there's only one missing.

146
00:07:46.570 --> 00:07:50.842
So the easiest way to do this is to
just add a network statement for

147
00:07:50.842 --> 00:07:52.540
192.168.16, right?

148
00:07:52.540 --> 00:07:55.330
Now if I did a show IP interface brief and
saw that I had

149
00:07:55.330 --> 00:07:59.195
like 20 different connected networks, I
would do a redistribute connected, right?

150
00:07:59.195 --> 00:08:00.880
Now, that would work
out really well there.

151
00:08:00.880 --> 00:08:08.480
But since it's just one network, I'll do a
network statement, that'll save some time.

152
00:08:08.480 --> 00:08:10.840
And we'll do a router eigrp 800,

153
00:08:10.840 --> 00:08:14.270
network 192.168.16.0 with
a 0.0.0.255 wildcard mask.

154
00:08:14.270 --> 00:08:19.470
So, I'm gonna run that and that's gonna
bring that network into the routing table.

155
00:08:19.470 --> 00:08:21.630
Well, the network is already
in the routing table.

156
00:08:21.630 --> 00:08:24.400
It's gonna bring it into EIGRP's
routing database, and that way,

157
00:08:24.400 --> 00:08:27.870
we'll advertise it out and
the other side should start to learn it.

158
00:08:27.870 --> 00:08:30.170
Now, I'm not gonna see anything
different here on this router.

159
00:08:30.170 --> 00:08:33.610
I need to jump over to CORE2, and
that's where I would see a difference.

160
00:08:34.710 --> 00:08:39.390
So on this guy, it should happen
pretty fast, if I do a show ip route.

161
00:08:39.390 --> 00:08:44.120
I'll just filter it down to eigrp routes.

162
00:08:44.120 --> 00:08:47.820
And there it is,
192.168.16 is now showing up in my list.

163
00:08:47.820 --> 00:08:54.250
And if I try and ping it, I get
connectivity, so we are in good shape.

164
00:08:54.250 --> 00:08:57.630
So in this case it turns out just
the originating router was not

165
00:08:57.630 --> 00:08:58.868
advertising the route.

166
00:08:58.868 --> 00:09:01.590
And we could solve that by manually
adding it to the routing process,

167
00:09:01.590 --> 00:09:05.780
which is what I did, or we could of
redistributed it in as a connected route.

168
00:09:05.780 --> 00:09:06.880
That would have worked, too.

169
00:09:06.880 --> 00:09:09.230
Either solution would have been fine.

170
00:09:09.230 --> 00:09:12.910
For me, if it's just one or two networks,
I'll normally do the network command.

171
00:09:12.910 --> 00:09:16.435
If it's a lot of networks, though,
then I'll use the redistribute command.

172
00:09:16.435 --> 00:09:17.430
Right?

173
00:09:17.430 --> 00:09:18.670
There is one more thing to add, though.

174
00:09:18.670 --> 00:09:19.850
When you use the network command,

175
00:09:19.850 --> 00:09:22.590
sometimes you need to go in to passive
interface commands also to secure it

176
00:09:22.590 --> 00:09:25.190
a little bit, versus redistributes
where you don't have to do that.

177
00:09:25.190 --> 00:09:27.330
So it's up to you how you
want to solve that one.

178
00:09:27.330 --> 00:09:29.990
Oftentimes there's more than
one solution to a problem.

179
00:09:29.990 --> 00:09:32.410
I just went with kinda
the path of least resistance.

180
00:09:32.410 --> 00:09:36.540
That network command is a lot easier than
redistribute command because an EIGRP you

181
00:09:36.540 --> 00:09:38.380
have to put in all those metrics and
it's kind of a pain.

182
00:09:38.380 --> 00:09:41.280
So this was a little bit
of the faster solution.

183
00:09:41.280 --> 00:09:42.490
But, that knocks this one out,

184
00:09:42.490 --> 00:09:45.970
we've got the connectivity, the routes
are up, it's present, everything's happy.

185
00:09:45.970 --> 00:09:48.730
We've resolved what was stated
in the troubleshooting ticket.

186
00:09:48.730 --> 00:09:49.670
So, that wraps this one up.

187
00:09:49.670 --> 00:09:50.740
Hope you guys enjoyed it.

188
00:09:50.740 --> 00:09:56.390
Stay tuned we've got more
troubleshooting tickets coming up.

189
00:09:56.390 --> 00:10:00.439
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #3` from set #7. The trouble ticket states that "When you shutdown Fas1/0/22 on NYCORE1 you are unable to ping 192.168.16.1 from PLABCSCO01 (the default gateway). You want to ensure that you access to the default gateway has an alternative path in case the link between NYACCESS1 and NYCORE1 fails. "
episodes.title: Set 7 Issue 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:08.990
[SOUND]
>> All

2
00:00:08.990 --> 00:00:12.510
right welcome back to another
troubleshooting episode here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.510 --> 00:00:16.490
This is going to be set
7 issue number 3 and

4
00:00:16.490 --> 00:00:18.960
this one is gonna be a short one,
let me tell you why.

5
00:00:18.960 --> 00:00:21.680
The troubleshooting ticket for number 3,
let me just read this out to you.

6
00:00:21.680 --> 00:00:27.120
It says when you shut down
FA1/0/22 on NY core one,

7
00:00:27.120 --> 00:00:31.980
you are unable to ping 192.168.16.1
from ping lab Cisco 01,

8
00:00:31.980 --> 00:00:36.510
you want to ensure you have access

9
00:00:36.510 --> 00:00:40.980
to the default gateway as an alternative
path that's a strange sentence.

10
00:00:40.980 --> 00:00:44.890
You want to ensure that your access to the
default gateway has an alternative path,

11
00:00:44.890 --> 00:00:49.490
in case the link because NYACCESS1 and
NYCORE1 fails, all right.

12
00:00:49.490 --> 00:00:50.500
Let me bring up the topology and

13
00:00:50.500 --> 00:00:53.520
I'll give you chance to see why this
is gonna be a short one for us.

14
00:00:53.520 --> 00:00:57.690
Basically what they're telling me is that,
if I go to NYCORE1 and

15
00:00:57.690 --> 00:01:03.100
I shut down this link right here,
now I'm no longer able to ping across

16
00:01:03.100 --> 00:01:07.242
to NYCORE1 from my server down here, okay?

17
00:01:07.242 --> 00:01:10.340
All right, if you've been doing all
these troubleshooting tickets in order,

18
00:01:10.340 --> 00:01:15.050
starting with set seven issue one,
you'll know that the path for

19
00:01:15.050 --> 00:01:18.450
our traffic right now
isn't crossing that link.

20
00:01:18.450 --> 00:01:22.240
That when we ping from
this server up to NYCORE1.

21
00:01:22.240 --> 00:01:25.530
We followed that path back
in ticket number one, and

22
00:01:25.530 --> 00:01:29.118
the path actually went around like this.

23
00:01:29.118 --> 00:01:31.600
Well remember when you troubleshoot and

24
00:01:31.600 --> 00:01:36.140
resolve a ticket, you actually have more
than one way that you can solve a problem.

25
00:01:36.140 --> 00:01:38.020
So when we were troubleshooting
that first ticket,

26
00:01:38.020 --> 00:01:42.050
we saw where the communications
weren't crossing this line.

27
00:01:42.050 --> 00:01:45.440
And we fixed it, and that got it where we
were able to come across like this and

28
00:01:45.440 --> 00:01:47.160
get to our destination.

29
00:01:47.160 --> 00:01:54.010
Well another possible solution would have
been to make this guy the route switch,

30
00:01:54.010 --> 00:01:57.210
or to make this one, either one of these
guys could've become the route switch.

31
00:01:57.210 --> 00:02:00.470
And if they were the route switch,
this link would've come up and

32
00:02:00.470 --> 00:02:05.330
then our traffic would have gone this way,
and bypassed the bad link over here.

33
00:02:05.330 --> 00:02:05.920
All right?

34
00:02:05.920 --> 00:02:08.820
That would have solved
the problem in ticket number one.

35
00:02:08.820 --> 00:02:14.140
If we had done that, shutting down port
22 would stop us from communicating.

36
00:02:14.140 --> 00:02:16.330
We wouldn't be able to communicate
here because it was shut down, and

37
00:02:16.330 --> 00:02:19.660
we wouldn't be able to
communicate here because the link

38
00:02:19.660 --> 00:02:21.810
had dynamic arp inspection turned on,
right?

39
00:02:21.810 --> 00:02:25.040
And so it would have blocked us and
we would have been dead in the water,

40
00:02:25.040 --> 00:02:29.080
but we chose to fix dynamic
arp inspection instead and so

41
00:02:29.080 --> 00:02:34.640
our traffic is able to flow this way
already and so we don't have that problem.

42
00:02:34.640 --> 00:02:39.150
In ticket number one, we actually
solved both tickets at the same time,

43
00:02:39.150 --> 00:02:41.700
issue number one and issue number three.

44
00:02:41.700 --> 00:02:45.120
So if you haven't watched issue number
one, jump back to it and watch it and

45
00:02:45.120 --> 00:02:49.300
you'll see how we traced out that path
to figure out where we were going.

46
00:02:49.300 --> 00:02:52.860
We found where the problem was,
tracked it down to CORE2 and

47
00:02:52.860 --> 00:02:57.540
we fixed Dynamic ARP Inspection by
trusting port 22 and once that happened,

48
00:02:57.540 --> 00:02:59.350
the communications came up.

49
00:02:59.350 --> 00:03:01.780
So in my scenario that we've got now

50
00:03:01.780 --> 00:03:03.610
this troubleshooting tickets
already been resolved.

51
00:03:03.610 --> 00:03:05.460
And we can just verify that real quick.

52
00:03:05.460 --> 00:03:11.100
If I go to my P Lab Cisco 01,
and I do a ping,

53
00:03:11.100 --> 00:03:16.850
I'll do a continual ping, to 192.168.16.1,
right, which I can ping it.

54
00:03:16.850 --> 00:03:20.710
And then if I go into NYCore1, and

55
00:03:20.710 --> 00:03:23.860
I shut down the interface
they're telling me to shut down.

56
00:03:23.860 --> 00:03:27.900
My network should survive that
just fine and we shall see.

57
00:03:27.900 --> 00:03:31.600
If I get into FA1/0/22 and do a shut down.

58
00:03:31.600 --> 00:03:34.440
That interface is gonna go down.

59
00:03:34.440 --> 00:03:36.280
So I just shut down this link.

60
00:03:36.280 --> 00:03:37.350
This link just went down.

61
00:03:38.420 --> 00:03:43.320
And now if my server were reliant
on that link it would stop.

62
00:03:43.320 --> 00:03:45.770
But since my server isn't reliant on it.

63
00:03:45.770 --> 00:03:49.810
When I go back to my server it's
still pinging away just fine.

64
00:03:49.810 --> 00:03:50.430
Right?
So

65
00:03:50.430 --> 00:03:53.060
we actually managed to resolved
two tickets at the same time, and

66
00:03:53.060 --> 00:03:55.090
that's not an uncommon thing, right?

67
00:03:55.090 --> 00:03:57.830
You could have one issue on the network.

68
00:03:57.830 --> 00:04:00.040
It leads to multiple symptoms.

69
00:04:00.040 --> 00:04:02.920
And in this scenario, the symptoms from
question one and the symptoms from

70
00:04:02.920 --> 00:04:05.690
question three could both be resolved
with just one fix which is what we did.

71
00:04:05.690 --> 00:04:08.760
So again, if you haven't already watched
issue number one, be sure to jump back and

72
00:04:08.760 --> 00:04:09.910
check that one out.

73
00:04:09.910 --> 00:04:11.040
Solves the same problem.

74
00:04:11.040 --> 00:04:15.460
But otherwise, that takes care of
this one so we'll call it a day and

75
00:04:15.460 --> 00:04:16.110
get ready to move on.

76
00:04:16.110 --> 00:04:17.450
And the next one, stay tuned.

77
00:04:17.450 --> 00:04:19.692
I'll see you back for issue four.

78
00:04:19.692 --> 00:04:23.999
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #4` from set #7. The trouble ticket states that "You only see the BGP route for 22.33.44.0 in NYCORE2s routing table, but the BGP table has a lot more routes "
episodes.title: Set 7 Issue 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.926
[SOUND]

2
00:00:02.926 --> 00:00:08.762
All right.

3
00:00:08.762 --> 00:00:11.710
Welcome back to another troubleshooting
episode here on IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:11.710 --> 00:00:17.580
We're ready for Set 7 Issue number 4, and
we got a BGP issue today which is awesome.

5
00:00:17.580 --> 00:00:18.940
So issue number 4 reads like this.

6
00:00:18.940 --> 00:00:24.355
It says you only see the BGP route for

7
00:00:24.355 --> 00:00:27.970
22.33.4.0 in NYCORE2's routing table.

8
00:00:27.970 --> 00:00:31.680
But the BGP table has a lot more routes.

9
00:00:31.680 --> 00:00:36.330
So this is an example of where a route
is not making it to your routing table.

10
00:00:36.330 --> 00:00:38.260
It's making it into the BGP database.

11
00:00:38.260 --> 00:00:40.010
But it's not making it
into the routing table.

12
00:00:40.010 --> 00:00:42.380
And there's a number of
things that can cause it.

13
00:00:42.380 --> 00:00:45.400
You can have rib failures and
metrics and all sorts of craziness

14
00:00:45.400 --> 00:00:47.590
that can cause a route not to
make it into the routing table.

15
00:00:48.690 --> 00:00:52.070
Regardless of what the cause is, one of
the first things that we really we need to

16
00:00:52.070 --> 00:00:54.000
do is we need to verify that
this is actually happening,

17
00:00:54.000 --> 00:00:57.710
that we are supposed to be seeing a route
and for some reason we're not seeing it.

18
00:00:57.710 --> 00:00:58.240
All right?

19
00:00:58.240 --> 00:01:01.460
So they're pretty much singling out
NYCORE2 on this one we might as well just

20
00:01:01.460 --> 00:01:04.790
jump straight to NYCORE2 and
see what its got.

21
00:01:04.790 --> 00:01:09.070
Now I guess before we do that, let's
go take a quick glance at our topology.

22
00:01:09.070 --> 00:01:12.470
And here's NYCORE2 and
they're signaling out BGP.

23
00:01:12.470 --> 00:01:16.520
And I can see that we
are running iBGP on NYCORE2.

24
00:01:16.520 --> 00:01:20.280
And it's supposed to be talking to,
NYEDGE1, so

25
00:01:20.280 --> 00:01:24.460
I've got interior BGP configured
between these two guys.

26
00:01:24.460 --> 00:01:27.380
Now looking at them, it doesn't look
like they have a direct connection, so

27
00:01:27.380 --> 00:01:30.160
there might be an undocumented
link here in between these two.

28
00:01:30.160 --> 00:01:31.820
I'm not entirely sure.

29
00:01:31.820 --> 00:01:36.230
But if there isn't, then that means
NYEDGE is sitting in between them,

30
