That's NYCORE2.

255
00:13:55.640 --> 00:14:00.210
And we've got a remote
autonomous system of 65534,

256
00:14:00.210 --> 00:14:04.180
because that's our internal or
IBGP as number.

257
00:14:04.180 --> 00:14:06.780
And it looks like we've got a prefix
list filtering what's going out.

258
00:14:06.780 --> 00:14:08.189
I'm not really worried
about that prefix list.

259
00:14:09.310 --> 00:14:11.640
Because I am seeing
the networks on the other side.

260
00:14:11.640 --> 00:14:14.540
I'm just not putting them into the routing
table because I don't know the next hop.

261
00:14:14.540 --> 00:14:18.030
So what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna add
one more neighbor command to tell it,

262
00:14:18.030 --> 00:14:22.140
when I advertise that neighbor,
make me the next hop.

263
00:14:22.140 --> 00:14:29.955
And so we can do that by getting into
our configuration saying router BGP,

264
00:14:29.955 --> 00:14:34.504
and then my BGP as here is that 65534,

265
00:14:36.767 --> 00:14:44.801
And then I'm gonna say
neighbor 192.168.17.1.

266
00:14:44.801 --> 00:14:51.025
And then here's the important part,
is we can specify there it is.

267
00:14:51.025 --> 00:14:54.380
Next-hop-self.

268
00:14:54.380 --> 00:14:55.120
Right there.

269
00:14:55.120 --> 00:14:59.540
The default is to advertise the normal
next hop, we're gonna change it to us.

270
00:14:59.540 --> 00:15:06.320
And so, when I add that, next-hop-self,
now when I advertise the routes,

271
00:15:06.320 --> 00:15:09.920
it'll show us this guy's IP, and
not some external router's IP.

272
00:15:11.330 --> 00:15:16.800
And it will take effect
on its own eventually,

273
00:15:16.800 --> 00:15:19.070
but I'm usually in a hurry,
I don't want to wait and

274
00:15:19.070 --> 00:15:21.860
if we're already got down time, it's
not that big of a deal to interrupt it.

275
00:15:21.860 --> 00:15:26.720
So, we can just really
quick say clear IPBGP *.

276
00:15:26.720 --> 00:15:27.990
Soft.
All right,

277
00:15:27.990 --> 00:15:31.590
then it says reset all my neighbor
adjacencies and do it soft.

278
00:15:31.590 --> 00:15:34.500
In other words,
don't dump my whole routing table.

279
00:15:34.500 --> 00:15:36.050
Instead just reach out to them and

280
00:15:36.050 --> 00:15:38.530
request a whole copy of their
routing table over again.

281
00:15:38.530 --> 00:15:42.310
And that should reset that and we'll
probably get a status message or two.

282
00:15:42.310 --> 00:15:45.080
And I'm gonna jump over to NYCORE2.

283
00:15:46.760 --> 00:15:50.380
And on NYCORE2, if I go back up here.

284
00:15:50.380 --> 00:15:54.070
So a moment ago I ran show IPBGP.

285
00:15:54.070 --> 00:15:57.514
And all these routes down
here that were missing,

286
00:15:57.514 --> 00:16:01.050
they all have a next hop of 172.14.0.3.

287
00:16:01.050 --> 00:16:03.150
Now that I did that next hop self,

288
00:16:03.150 --> 00:16:08.970
I expect to see 193.177.16.1 as
the next hop for all these guys also.

289
00:16:08.970 --> 00:16:12.194
And if I see that, then they should all
make it into my routing table unless

290
00:16:12.194 --> 00:16:15.785
somebody else is beating him out for
administrative distance, but I know that's

291
00:16:15.785 --> 00:16:19.033
not the case, because I just didn't
see these in my routing table at all.

292
00:16:19.033 --> 00:16:20.700
It's not like there was a better route.

293
00:16:20.700 --> 00:16:24.060
We weren't making it because we didn't
know how to get to that next top.

294
00:16:24.060 --> 00:16:24.590
All right?

295
00:16:24.590 --> 00:16:27.060
So that should solve that and
that should fix our routing table.

296
00:16:27.060 --> 00:16:29.950
We'll still have connectivity issues,
I'll wager, but

297
00:16:29.950 --> 00:16:32.950
I think that's gonna end up being
another troubleshooting ticket for us.

298
00:16:32.950 --> 00:16:34.630
So I think I've stalled long enough here.

299
00:16:34.630 --> 00:16:38.030
Let's see what show IPBGP returns now.

300
00:16:40.160 --> 00:16:41.870
And sure enough, look at all these routes.

301
00:16:41.870 --> 00:16:44.110
Now they have all got that next hop, and

302
00:16:44.110 --> 00:16:46.300
the next hop is an IP
address that I recognize.

303
00:16:46.300 --> 00:16:48.550
I know that IP, I know how to get there.

304
00:16:48.550 --> 00:16:53.280
And, they've all got that best
route flag on the left side.

305
00:16:53.280 --> 00:16:58.180
And if I do a, show IP route BGP,
now they're all in my routing table.

306
00:16:58.180 --> 00:17:01.492
They're in my routing table because i
know how to get to the next hop and so

307
00:17:01.492 --> 00:17:02.808
now I'll use them, right.

308
00:17:02.808 --> 00:17:07.723
BGP will not put a route in the routing
table unless we know how to get to that

309
00:17:07.723 --> 00:17:08.764
hop all right.

310
00:17:08.764 --> 00:17:13.980
There are certain ways to get this that
doesn't actually fix the problem though.

311
00:17:13.980 --> 00:17:18.580
What you're doing here is they
call it route synchronization

312
00:17:18.580 --> 00:17:22.200
where if we don't know the route,
well actually

313
00:17:22.200 --> 00:17:24.700
technically route synchronization
is off on this one I believe.

314
00:17:24.700 --> 00:17:28.020
So there is another scenario that
can cause these not to show up and

315
00:17:28.020 --> 00:17:32.350
it's called route synchronization and on
newer equipment route synchronization is

316
00:17:32.350 --> 00:17:38.260
off by default, on older equipment it's on
by default and if it's on it says I will

317
00:17:38.260 --> 00:17:43.550
not put a BGP route in my routing table
unless I learned it through an IGP also.

318
00:17:43.550 --> 00:17:48.130
In other words if I learned it
through like OSPF or RIP or EIGRP.

319
00:17:48.130 --> 00:17:51.030
And if I didn't learn it that way I'm not
going to put it in the routing table.

320
00:17:51.030 --> 00:17:53.940
And the reason we had routing
synchronization back in the day

321
00:17:53.940 --> 00:17:57.760
was because you knew if you learned it
through an IGP that you knew how to get to

322
00:17:57.760 --> 00:17:59.600
the next hop, right?

323
00:17:59.600 --> 00:18:02.790
But on modern routers,
that route synchronization is off or,

324
00:18:02.790 --> 00:18:03.950
it is off, by default.

325
00:18:03.950 --> 00:18:06.760
So that means I can put a BGP
route in my routing table,

326
00:18:06.760 --> 00:18:09.250
even though I didn't learn it from an IGP.

327
00:18:09.250 --> 00:18:11.640
And that means I might be attempting
to put something in a routing table and

328
00:18:11.640 --> 00:18:12.720
I don't know how to get to the next hop.

329
00:18:12.720 --> 00:18:14.740
And that's exactly what we
just bumped up against.

330
00:18:14.740 --> 00:18:21.530
We fixed that by saying let's make sure
we have that next top be an IP we know,

331
00:18:21.530 --> 00:18:24.230
but we still have reachability
issues because the IGP problem.

332
00:18:24.230 --> 00:18:27.960
We may not know how to route to get there,
necessarily, and so we can start to bump

333
00:18:27.960 --> 00:18:31.270
into issues there which I think we'll
see in a later ticket on this one.

334
00:18:31.270 --> 00:18:34.870
I haven't read through each of the tickets
cuz I didn't wanna spoil the surprise but

335
00:18:34.870 --> 00:18:37.600
I'll wager that ones gonna
come up on an upcoming issue.

336
00:18:37.600 --> 00:18:40.550
But for now what the troubleshooting
ticket asked for they said,

337
00:18:40.550 --> 00:18:44.920
we only saw the BGP route for 22.33.44.0,
but there were a lot more in the show

338
00:18:44.920 --> 00:18:50.190
IPBGP output,
why aren't they making it into the table?

339
00:18:50.190 --> 00:18:52.470
Well we found that problem,
we fixed it, and

340
00:18:52.470 --> 00:18:55.070
now our routing table has
the networks in place.

341
00:18:55.070 --> 00:18:56.090
And we should be good to go.

342
00:18:56.090 --> 00:18:58.010
So that wraps up this
trouble shooting ticket.

343
00:18:58.010 --> 00:19:03.535
Stay tuned we got issue
five coming up next.

344
00:19:03.535 --> 00:19:08.204
[SOUND].

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #5` from set #7. The trouble ticket states that "The network 219.253.183.192/26 is not being propagated from NYEDGE1 to NYCORE2 "
episodes.title: Set 7 Issue 5
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.418
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.418 --> 00:00:10.358
All right, it's that time again.

3
00:00:10.358 --> 00:00:13.349
Time for another troubleshooting
problem on ITProTV, and

4
00:00:13.349 --> 00:00:15.214
we're jumping into Set 7 Issue 5.

5
00:00:15.214 --> 00:00:18.106
And this one looks like another
BGP issue for us today.

6
00:00:18.106 --> 00:00:23.626
It says the network 219.253.183.192/26

7
00:00:23.626 --> 00:00:28.620
it is not being propagated
from NY edge one to NY core 2.

8
00:00:28.620 --> 00:00:29.120
Why not?

9
00:00:30.420 --> 00:00:32.150
Right.
So we got a route that's not making it,

10
00:00:32.150 --> 00:00:33.410
and fortunately in BGP,

11
00:00:33.410 --> 00:00:36.180
there's usually only a couple of
reasons why that's gonna happen.

12
00:00:36.180 --> 00:00:39.060
We could have a route map or
a prefix list in place that stopping it.

13
00:00:39.060 --> 00:00:42.000
We could have, well the whole neighbor
relationship could be dead, but

14
00:00:42.000 --> 00:00:43.980
we know from our previous issues
that's not the case, right?

15
00:00:43.980 --> 00:00:45.120
We are exchanging routes.

16
00:00:45.120 --> 00:00:46.340
Other things are working.

17
00:00:46.340 --> 00:00:49.990
So we can kind of rule out a lot of BGP
troubleshooting right off the bat just

18
00:00:49.990 --> 00:00:54.510
because our previous ticket, where we've
already seen BGP communicating just fine.

19
00:00:54.510 --> 00:00:57.130
So that makes me immediately
think route map or

20
00:00:57.130 --> 00:00:58.960
prefix list that's gonna
be stopping this one.

21
00:00:58.960 --> 00:01:02.240
So let's go in and
see if we can't find out which one it is.

22
00:01:02.240 --> 00:01:04.690
Now when it comes to
a route not making it,

23
00:01:04.690 --> 00:01:07.240
I usually look to
the originating router first.

24
00:01:07.240 --> 00:01:09.320
The originating router is normally
the one that causes the problem, and

25
00:01:09.320 --> 00:01:11.560
then I look to the receiving
router after that.

26
00:01:11.560 --> 00:01:15.010
And in our scenario,
the originating router is NY Edge 1.

27
00:01:15.010 --> 00:01:16.810
So I'm going to jump over to NY Edge 1,
and

28
00:01:16.810 --> 00:01:21.790
what I'm going to do is look for
anything that would stop

29
00:01:21.790 --> 00:01:24.830
The 219.253.183.192 network
from being advertised out.

30
00:01:24.830 --> 00:01:32.250
Well, the first thing that would stop
it is if it wasn't in my routing table.

31
00:01:32.250 --> 00:01:36.630
So I'm gonna do a show IP route, and

32
00:01:36.630 --> 00:01:40.070
I'm gonna look for 219.253 And
see if we can spot it in here.

33
00:01:40.070 --> 00:01:42.550
If it's a big routing table I'll
modify the command to filter, but

34
00:01:42.550 --> 00:01:43.330
it's not that big.

35
00:01:43.330 --> 00:01:44.460
There it is.

36
00:01:44.460 --> 00:01:52.310
So I'm looking for 219.53.183.192/26 and
sure enough that's this guy right here.

37
00:01:52.310 --> 00:01:54.430
So it is in my routing table.

38
00:01:54.430 --> 00:01:57.320
All right and
I didn't really care if it was BGB or

39
00:01:57.320 --> 00:02:00.170
EIGRP or directly connected for
that matter.

40
00:02:00.170 --> 00:02:02.575
I just needed to make sure that
it was actually in my table.

41
00:02:02.575 --> 00:02:05.830
Cuz if it's not in my table, I'm not
gonna advertise it to anybody else.

42
00:02:05.830 --> 00:02:08.010
So that's a big red
flag if it's not there.

43
00:02:08.010 --> 00:02:09.160
In my case it is.

44
00:02:09.160 --> 00:02:12.730
Another thing that could stop me from
advertising is if I didn't have a neighbor

45
00:02:12.730 --> 00:02:17.720
relationship, but we saw back in issues
three and four that we do have a neighbor

46
00:02:17.720 --> 00:02:24.730
relationship, definitely issue four we saw
it so if I do a show ip bgp summary, I can

47
00:02:24.730 --> 00:02:29.370
look in here and there is that neighbor
relationship we have with NYCORE2.

48
00:02:29.370 --> 00:02:32.980
So, we see them,
we're exchanging information with them.

49
00:02:32.980 --> 00:02:36.660
We're just not telling them
with this route up here.

50
00:02:36.660 --> 00:02:40.730
All right, so next let's look for
our route map or prefix lists.

51
00:02:40.730 --> 00:02:44.060
Now, route maps and prefix lists
are really easy to implement and

52
00:02:44.060 --> 00:02:46.090
then forget about, overlook them.

53
00:02:46.090 --> 00:02:49.630
So what we do is look for
the neighbor statements in BGP.

54
00:02:49.630 --> 00:02:54.520
And I'm gonna look for
the neighbor statement for 192.168.17.1.

55
00:02:54.520 --> 00:02:55.970
And see what that turns up.

56
00:02:55.970 --> 00:03:00.990
So I'm gonna do a show run and
filter that for the neighbor command and

57
00:03:00.990 --> 00:03:05.100
I'm gonna find 192.168.17.1 and
there we go.

58
00:03:05.100 --> 00:03:07.850
I was looking for
route maps or prefix lists and

59
00:03:07.850 --> 00:03:10.120
we found a prefix list right here.

60
00:03:10.120 --> 00:03:11.250
Prefix lists,

61
00:03:11.250 --> 00:03:14.700
especially outgoing ones, are used
to filter what routes we send out.

62
00:03:14.700 --> 00:03:17.900
We may not want to send them every
route so we want to pick and choose And

63
00:03:17.900 --> 00:03:20.120
I'll bet that's what's
going on right here.

64
00:03:20.120 --> 00:03:24.580
So, we can do a quick show command on this
one and determine what that's going to be.

65
00:03:24.580 --> 00:03:30.160
So I'm just gonna do a show run and
I'll include prefix dash list and

66
00:03:30.160 --> 00:03:31.780
that should turn up all
the prefix list commands.

67
00:03:31.780 --> 00:03:34.860
So, this is prefix list number ten.

68
00:03:34.860 --> 00:03:36.540
I'm gonna have a hard time saying it.

69
00:03:36.540 --> 00:03:39.830
It looks like prefix list
number ten is quite big.

70
00:03:39.830 --> 00:03:45.350
And as I look down the list,
these are the networks that I'm allowing

71
00:03:45.350 --> 00:03:51.600
to be advertised out to NYCORE2,
and I see a lot of stuff in here.

72
00:03:51.600 --> 00:03:53.090
I do not see 219.253.183.192.

73
00:03:53.090 --> 00:03:57.800
That one's missing from the list,
so we need to get it put in there.

74
00:03:57.800 --> 00:04:01.220
Now, when I go to put it in, I'm gonna
just need to remember the syntax for

75
00:04:01.220 --> 00:04:03.480
this and how they work,
how it works kinda like ACLs, right?

76
00:04:03.480 --> 00:04:06.480
When I add an entry,
it's just gonna add onto this list.

77
00:04:06.480 --> 00:04:09.700
And we can just stick it right on the end
here cause we don't have any denys or

78
00:04:09.700 --> 00:04:11.070
anything to worry about on this list.

79
00:04:11.070 --> 00:04:12.130
That makes it easy.

80
00:04:12.130 --> 00:04:13.900
So, I'll just tack it right to the end.

81
00:04:13.900 --> 00:04:16.070
And it's a slash 26.

82
00:04:16.070 --> 00:04:18.990
And so, I need to make sure that
when I add it I do kind of like what

83
00:04:18.990 --> 00:04:21.750
you see they're doing up
here with the slash 26, and

84
00:04:21.750 --> 00:04:25.920
they're doing this less than or
equal to with the next range in line.

85
00:04:25.920 --> 00:04:28.860
I just wanna make sure that I kinda
follow what they're doing to put it in as

86
00:04:28.860 --> 00:04:30.040
comparable as possible.

87
00:04:30.040 --> 00:04:31.250
They didn't really ask me to do that.

88
00:04:31.250 --> 00:04:32.970
They just want us to do /26.

89
00:04:32.970 --> 00:04:34.960
So either way would more than likely work.

90
00:04:34.960 --> 00:04:38.060
All right, so
I'm going to jump into my configuration.

91
00:04:38.060 --> 00:04:40.160
I'll do ip prefix-list.

92
00:04:40.160 --> 00:04:44.580
10 sequence 60.

93
00:04:44.580 --> 00:04:49.660
I'm just gonna add right
onto the end of that one.

94
00:04:49.660 --> 00:04:55.360
And I'm gonna permit 219
dot 253 dot 183 dot 192.

95
00:04:55.360 --> 00:04:59.550
And then I need to just add
a little bit more to that

96
00:04:59.550 --> 00:05:03.570
to make sure that it knows
the mask that I'm using.

97
00:05:03.570 --> 00:05:09.003
So I'm gonna put slash 25 LE 26, right?

98
00:05:09.003 --> 00:05:13.060
So, /25 would be the parent
network less than or

99
00:05:13.060 --> 00:05:17.850
equal to /26 that we're grabbing
anything that fits inside of that range.

100
00:05:17.850 --> 00:05:21.810
So I'm going to add that on,
and once that's in place,

101
00:05:21.810 --> 00:05:27.330
if I do that show run and
include prefix-list,

102
00:05:27.330 --> 00:05:29.920
we can verify that it made it in there and
kind of tacked on to the end.

103
00:05:29.920 --> 00:05:30.420
There it is.

104
00:05:31.430 --> 00:05:33.480
And we should be good to go.

105
00:05:33.480 --> 00:05:36.990
Now prefix lists apply every time
you advertise the traffic out.

106
00:05:36.990 --> 00:05:40.210
So within a few moments that
should kick in and start working.

107
00:05:40.210 --> 00:05:43.510
I doubt we'll even have to reset
that process, but we could always do

108
00:05:43.510 --> 00:05:46.860
a soft reset if we wanted to be on
the safe side just to clear that out.

109
00:05:46.860 --> 00:05:48.520
But we, we should be good to go.

110
00:05:48.520 --> 00:05:51.770
So let's jump over to the other side and
see if that's the case.

111
00:05:51.770 --> 00:05:53.605
So I'm gonna jump back over to core two.

112
00:05:53.605 --> 00:05:59.830
And, I never really did check to see if
it was missing in the first place, right?

113
00:05:59.830 --> 00:06:02.540
I always like to verify the problem
exists, before I trouble shoot it.

114
00:06:02.540 --> 00:06:04.080
But I, I didn't do that this time.

115
00:06:04.080 --> 00:06:05.379
But I'm gonna do a show i-p route.

116
00:06:06.760 --> 00:06:09.550
And I'm gonna look for
that 219 network, and

117
00:06:09.550 --> 00:06:11.940
see if it made it over, and there it is.

118
00:06:11.940 --> 00:06:15.840
Nice, shiny, and new, I can see I've
known about it for 19 seconds now.

119
00:06:15.840 --> 00:06:19.330
So that's good enough for me to know
that I just received that recently,

120
00:06:19.330 --> 00:06:23.360
versus some of these other BGP routes that
I've known for 18 minutes, or an hour and

121
00:06:23.360 --> 00:06:25.920
a half, this one I've only known for
19 seconds.

122
00:06:25.920 --> 00:06:27.680
So I learned that one and

123
00:06:27.680 --> 00:06:31.040
now it's in place so, just a simple
prefix list excluding a route.

124
00:06:31.040 --> 00:06:33.450
Once we put that in,
this one was fixed and

125
00:06:33.450 --> 00:06:35.860
that's another trouble shooting
ticket under our belts.

126
00:06:35.860 --> 00:06:37.420
So, that will wrap this one up.

127
00:06:37.420 --> 00:06:38.047
Stay tuned,

128
00:06:38.047 --> 00:06:42.208
we've got one more troubleshooting ticket
in this set that we'll be getting to next.

129
00:06:42.208 --> 00:06:47.826
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #6` from set #7. The trouble ticket states that "The loopback interface 20 on NYEDGE1 is not being propagated through to NYCORE2 "
episodes.title: Set 7 Issue 6
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.205 --> 00:00:08.344
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.344 --> 00:00:12.170
All right, welcome back to the last
troubleshooting issue for Set 7.

3
00:00:12.170 --> 00:00:15.070
We got a final BGP issue, or probably BGP.

4
00:00:15.070 --> 00:00:20.070
It says that the loopback interface,
loopback interface number 20

5
00:00:20.070 --> 00:00:24.960
on NYEDGE1 is not being
propagated through to NYCORE2.

6
00:00:24.960 --> 00:00:26.720
So another route that's
not making it across.

7
00:00:26.720 --> 00:00:29.790
Remember, in the last ticket we had
a route that wasn't making it across

8
00:00:29.790 --> 00:00:31.580
because of a prefix list.

9
00:00:31.580 --> 00:00:32.530
Maybe this one's the same.

10
00:00:32.530 --> 00:00:34.790
We'll luck out, same problem,
be done, and be in business.

11
00:00:34.790 --> 00:00:38.280
So, just loopback interface 20 on NYEDGE1.

12
00:00:38.280 --> 00:00:41.400
Let's jump in and
look at good old NYEDGE1.

13
00:00:42.420 --> 00:00:45.064
And we'll go ahead and enable and

14
00:00:45.064 --> 00:00:51.111
I'm gonna do a show IP interface brief
just to figure what loopback 20 is,

15
00:00:51.111 --> 00:00:56.039
and there it is, so
loopback 20 is 15.20.0.33.

16
00:00:56.039 --> 00:00:59.914
All right, and
if I do a show run interface lo20,

17
00:00:59.914 --> 00:01:04.065
it is a 255.255.255.224 network, so

18
00:01:04.065 --> 00:01:08.060
a slightly different subnet mask for
us there.

19
00:01:08.060 --> 00:01:11.770
But, basically, it's up, it's going,
and it appears to be happy.

20
00:01:11.770 --> 00:01:14.990
It's up, up, and I'm sure it's in our
routing table, I'll double check.

21
00:01:14.990 --> 00:01:17.900
It's a directly connected route, you
know it's gonna be in the routing table.

22
00:01:17.900 --> 00:01:20.920
But just to be on the safe
side we'll just scan that

23
00:01:20.920 --> 00:01:23.460
real quick to make sure
nothing crazy's going on.

24
00:01:23.460 --> 00:01:24.715
And there it is.

25
00:01:24.715 --> 00:01:26.182
15.20.0.32/27.

26
00:01:26.182 --> 00:01:27.230
All right.

27
00:01:27.230 --> 00:01:30.850
So, we've got it right here and

28
00:01:30.850 --> 00:01:35.450
if we jump over to NYCORE 2 we can
verify that it's not showing up there.

29
00:01:35.450 --> 00:01:40.410
So I'll jump over to NYCORE2 and,
just do a show IP route,

30
00:01:40.410 --> 00:01:42.279
and I'm gonna look for that network.

31
00:01:43.570 --> 00:01:46.580
And I know right away there's
nothing here that starts with 15 and

32
00:01:46.580 --> 00:01:48.580
that's where it should be and
it's not there.

33
00:01:48.580 --> 00:01:50.620
So it's definitely not
making it to this side.

34
00:01:50.620 --> 00:01:52.320
So, let's double check that prefix list,

35
00:01:52.320 --> 00:01:55.420
see if we've got revenge of
the prefix list going on.

36
00:01:55.420 --> 00:01:57.760
Oops, if I jump to the right
device that'll make a difference.

37
00:01:57.760 --> 00:02:00.921
So I jump back to EDGE1 and
I'm just gonna look and

38
00:02:00.921 --> 00:02:03.568
see if that network is in the prefix list.

39
00:02:05.274 --> 00:02:07.040
And so we'll pull that up.

40
00:02:07.040 --> 00:02:10.680
I'm doing a show running dash config and
I'm going to use the include command to

41
00:02:10.680 --> 00:02:13.350
filter it just tp lines
including prefix list.

42
00:02:13.350 --> 00:02:18.910
And there is prefix list number ten and
as I look down the line, well I've got

43
00:02:18.910 --> 00:02:23.950
this guy right here,
15.0.0.0/8 less than or equal to 24.

44
00:02:23.950 --> 00:02:31.180
So that's gonna get anything that's
a /24 or smaller, /25, /26 and so on.

45
00:02:31.180 --> 00:02:33.990
That's not gonna include this one, is it?

46
00:02:33.990 --> 00:02:37.177
This one's a slash,
did we say it was a /27?

47
00:02:37.177 --> 00:02:38.290
Let's see.

48
00:02:38.290 --> 00:02:39.180
This on is a /27.

49
00:02:39.180 --> 00:02:44.810
So that should get, I'm trying to think
if that's gonna get wrapped up or not.

50
00:02:44.810 --> 00:02:46.450
That should, well, you know what?

51
00:02:46.450 --> 00:02:47.540
Let's just be on the safe side here.

52
00:02:47.540 --> 00:02:50.200
I'm gonna go ahead and manually add and
I'll add it the right way.

53
00:02:50.200 --> 00:02:57.097
So, I'm gonna jump in here and
do an ip prefix-list 10 seq 70.

54
00:02:57.097 --> 00:02:59.120
I'm just gonna tack right
onto the end of this one.

55
00:02:59.120 --> 00:03:00.430
Better safe than sorry on this one.

56
00:03:00.430 --> 00:03:03.640
I'll make sure I put the list in
the right way so I know that it works.

57
00:03:03.640 --> 00:03:07.647
So, I'm gonna do seq 70 permit and
I'm gonna punch in this network, right?

58
00:03:07.647 --> 00:03:15.200
The 15.20.0.32/26 less than or
equal to 27.

59
00:03:15.200 --> 00:03:16.590
Right?

60
00:03:16.590 --> 00:03:21.330
And that way I know I'm getting this
/27 the way that I need it to be so

61
00:03:21.330 --> 00:03:22.730
that it gets wrapped up in that one.

62
00:03:22.730 --> 00:03:27.010
All right, now once that's done if
the prefix list is our problem,

63
00:03:27.010 --> 00:03:28.500
which it looks like it was.

64
00:03:28.500 --> 00:03:30.810
Then we should start learning
that route on the other side.

65
00:03:30.810 --> 00:03:33.740
And we saw in issue number six that
it only took about 19 seconds,

66
00:03:33.740 --> 00:03:36.360
probably less than that,
to get learned on the other side.

67
00:03:36.360 --> 00:03:38.930
So I'm gonna jump over to the other
side and we'll see what we've got.

68
00:03:38.930 --> 00:03:40.764
So jumping over to NYCORE2.

69
00:03:42.645 --> 00:03:45.500
I'm just gonna do a show ip route.

70
00:03:47.440 --> 00:03:51.180
And it is not there which I might
not have waited long enough but

71
00:03:51.180 --> 00:03:52.840
we can also look at the bgp database.

72
00:03:52.840 --> 00:03:56.720
I'll do a show IP bgp and
we can look at the bgp database and

73
00:03:56.720 --> 00:04:01.440
maybe it just hasn't made it through and
it is not here either.

74
00:04:01.440 --> 00:04:04.770
So let's see it has been
19 seconds I'm sure.

75
00:04:04.770 --> 00:04:05.930
And it's not here.

76
00:04:05.930 --> 00:04:06.930
All right.

77
00:04:06.930 --> 00:04:08.780
So still not getting that route.

78
00:04:08.780 --> 00:04:11.370
I thought we had an easy one, I thought
it was gonna be the prefix list again,

79
00:04:11.370 --> 00:04:11.950
but it was not.

80
00:04:11.950 --> 00:04:16.490
So in this scenario,
I've got some other problem.

81
00:04:16.490 --> 00:04:19.718
Okay, it could be that the route's not
coming in here and I'm filtering it,

82
00:04:19.718 --> 00:04:21.900
maybe I've got a route map or
a prefix list on my end,

83
00:04:21.900 --> 00:04:24.205
although incoming prefix
lists are pretty uncommon.

84
00:04:24.205 --> 00:04:27.755
It's not impossible,
a route map would be more realistic there.

85
00:04:27.755 --> 00:04:32.090
So, let's just do a show run, and
I'm going to jump to the bgp section and

86
00:04:32.090 --> 00:04:33.550
see what we've got in here.

87
00:04:33.550 --> 00:04:38.500
And what I'm looking for are route maps
and I'm looking for prefix lists and

88
00:04:38.500 --> 00:04:39.620
I don't see any.

89
00:04:39.620 --> 00:04:43.778
So I've got BGP turned on for BGPAS 65534.

90
00:04:43.778 --> 00:04:45.972
I know that's working because
I am exchanging routes.

91
00:04:45.972 --> 00:04:48.629
I've got a neighbor with
an update source of Vlan17.

92
00:04:48.629 --> 00:04:51.938
And again I know that's working
because I am exchanging routes.

93
00:04:51.938 --> 00:04:54.574
I don't see anything here
that's jumping out at me.

94
00:04:54.574 --> 00:04:59.820
So let's jump back to the other side and
take a look at what we've got over there.

95
00:04:59.820 --> 00:05:02.854
So im going to jump back over to NYEDGE1.

96
00:05:02.854 --> 00:05:07.275
And let's just do a show run and
I'll begin that with BGP and

97
00:05:07.275 --> 00:05:09.851
see what we've got going on here.

98
00:05:09.851 --> 00:05:12.723
All right so I've got router bgp 65534.

99
00:05:12.723 --> 00:05:17.605
And we've got quite a lot,
we've got our connection with the other

100
00:05:17.605 --> 00:05:22.232
ISP here we've got our connection
with NYCORE2 where we do have

101
00:05:22.232 --> 00:05:25.935
a prefix list that we've
kind of already resolve.

102
00:05:25.935 --> 00:05:30.239
So that's fine and
we've got our network statements and oh,

103
00:05:30.239 --> 00:05:34.610
actually I think that's gonna
be our issue right there.

104
00:05:34.610 --> 00:05:38.258
If you take a look at that network
statement, there's a network statement for

105
00:05:38.258 --> 00:05:39.927
the 15.20.0.0 network.

106
00:05:39.927 --> 00:05:43.909
But look at that subnet
mask 255.255.255.0.

107
00:05:43.909 --> 00:05:45.510
All right?

108
00:05:45.510 --> 00:05:49.120
With BGP the subnet masks
are really specific.

109
00:05:49.120 --> 00:05:51.020
It's gonna match the subnet mask for
that interface.

110
00:05:51.020 --> 00:05:54.360
And in this case that doesn't match,
right?

111
00:05:54.360 --> 00:05:57.060
We saw earlier that it was, what was it,

112
00:05:57.060 --> 00:06:01.670
it was 255.255.25, was it,
255.224, I think is what it was.

113
00:06:01.670 --> 00:06:03.310
Let's verify that.

114
00:06:03.310 --> 00:06:08.530
I'm gonna do a quick show run int lo20.

115
00:06:08.530 --> 00:06:12.002
And there it is, 255.255.255.224, right?

116
00:06:12.002 --> 00:06:17.790
Significantly smaller that the one that's
being used in that network statement.

117
00:06:17.790 --> 00:06:21.770
So looks like we have a bad network
statement, so we can get in and fix that.

118
00:06:21.770 --> 00:06:25.063
We'll do router bpg 65534.

119
00:06:25.063 --> 00:06:29.339
And then, once we're in there,

120
00:06:29.339 --> 00:06:35.297
we can do network, and 15.20.0.32

121
00:06:35.297 --> 00:06:42.570
mask 255.255.255.224, all right?

122
00:06:42.570 --> 00:06:44.950
And while we're in there, it wouldn't
hurt to take the other one out,

123
00:06:44.950 --> 00:06:48.090
since it's kind of not really
doing anything for us.

124
00:06:48.090 --> 00:06:52.060
So that was that 15.20.0
with a class c mask on it.

125
00:06:52.060 --> 00:06:55.410
So I'll just take this.

126
00:06:55.410 --> 00:06:59.330
And we'll get that one out of there, so
we don't have a bad statement in our link.

127
00:07:00.420 --> 00:07:08.570
So, once I do that, let's take
a look at that configuration again.

128
00:07:08.570 --> 00:07:11.890
And so now when I look at it I've got
a network statement that 15.20.0.32

129
00:07:11.890 --> 00:07:13.700
with the correct masks.

130
00:07:13.700 --> 00:07:16.200
That matches exactly what we've got.

131
00:07:16.200 --> 00:07:20.920
And the prefix list has been updated,
which still was an issue and so

132
00:07:20.920 --> 00:07:22.860
we've got that taken care of.

133
00:07:22.860 --> 00:07:23.979
Let's see if our route shows up now.

134
00:07:25.395 --> 00:07:30.900
I'm gonna jump over to CORE2 and on
CORE2 I'm just gonna do a show ip route.

135
00:07:30.900 --> 00:07:36.580
And Whoop, there we go.

136
00:07:36.580 --> 00:07:39.720
Way down here at the bottom because
it just came in, well 51 seconds ago,

137
00:07:39.720 --> 00:07:40.550
it says.

138
00:07:40.550 --> 00:07:45.110
So looking at this I can see I've got
that 15.20.0.32, made it right in there.

139
00:07:45.110 --> 00:07:51.500
We've got that route in place, and if I do
a show ip bgp, it should be in there too.

140
00:07:51.500 --> 00:07:52.850
And there it is right at the top.

141
00:07:52.850 --> 00:07:54.880
We didn't see that earlier but now it is.

142
00:07:54.880 --> 00:07:58.070
So in this case we had
a bad network statement and

143
00:07:58.070 --> 00:07:59.890
we had the prefix list
that we're capturing.

144
00:07:59.890 --> 00:08:02.010
And we fixed those two problems,
it came right over.

145
00:08:02.010 --> 00:08:04.340
They had me, I thought it was
just the prefix list again but

146
00:08:04.340 --> 00:08:06.120
this one turned out to
be a little bit more.

147
00:08:06.120 --> 00:08:09.840
Now on the exam, there are other problems
that can creep up that could cause this,

148
00:08:09.840 --> 00:08:15.880
things like bad next hops, we saw that,
prefix lists, bad network statements.

149
00:08:15.880 --> 00:08:17.770
Bad redistribution,
that's another big one.

150
00:08:17.770 --> 00:08:22.590
Where they redistribute into BGP and the
redistribute command has a route map or

151
00:08:22.590 --> 00:08:25.370
a filter assigned to it, and it excludes
the network you're looking for.

152
00:08:25.370 --> 00:08:27.700
So, those are all things you
want to keep an eye out for.

153
00:08:27.700 --> 00:08:29.730
But, in this scenario, that wraps it up.

154
00:08:29.730 --> 00:08:32.460
That one gets our route
in the routing table.

155
00:08:32.460 --> 00:08:33.990
And that troubleshooting
ticket is resolved.

156
00:08:33.990 --> 00:08:37.430
A loopback interface is now being
propagated in the network, and

157
00:08:37.430 --> 00:08:39.480
we can chalk that one up to being done.

158
00:08:39.480 --> 00:08:43.570
And that's the last problem here for set
number seven, so that one's taken care of.

159
00:08:43.570 --> 00:08:48.190
Definitely stay tuned cuz we're gonna
be kicking off set number eight next.

160
00:08:48.190 --> 00:08:49.946
It'll be a good time, and
I hope to see you then.

161
00:08:51.246 --> 00:08:57.264
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Don revisits Issue #4 to solve the issue of establishing reachability.
episodes.title: Set 7 Bonus
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.790
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.790 --> 00:00:12.073
All right, welcome back to another
troubleshooting segment here on ITPro TV,

3
00:00:12.073 --> 00:00:14.970
and this one, well we're going off
the paper a little bit on this one.

4
00:00:14.970 --> 00:00:18.100
I wanna double back to
an issue we had earlier.

5
00:00:18.100 --> 00:00:22.070
Issue number four where the troll
shooting ticket was a network that wasn't

6
00:00:22.070 --> 00:00:24.270
being advertised to a BGP partner, right?

7
00:00:24.270 --> 00:00:27.210
And we resolved issue number four,
if you haven't watched that go ahead and

8
00:00:27.210 --> 00:00:29.430
go back and
watch that before you do this bonus.

9
00:00:29.430 --> 00:00:32.520
But by the end of the episode
we had solved the problem.

10
00:00:32.520 --> 00:00:35.480
The route that wasn't being advertised,
we were now learning.

11
00:00:35.480 --> 00:00:38.070
Let me read to you the topology here,
I'll show you what I'm talking about.

12
00:00:38.070 --> 00:00:41.340
The routing question was
originating here on NYEDGE1.

13
00:00:41.340 --> 00:00:47.420
It was 22.33.44.0/24, I believe,
so that was the network.

14
00:00:47.420 --> 00:00:50.210
And it wasn't making it over to NYCORE2

15
00:00:50.210 --> 00:00:52.460
because there was a prefix
list that was stopping it.

16
00:00:52.460 --> 00:00:57.570
Or actually, the problem wasn't that,
the problem was the 22.33.44.0

17
00:00:57.570 --> 00:01:01.810
was making it over to NYCORE2,
the other routes weren't making it there.

18
00:01:01.810 --> 00:01:04.780
And when we looked at NYCORE2 we saw where
the other routes actually made it to us.

19
00:01:04.780 --> 00:01:06.680
It wasn't the prefix list,
the routes did make it.

20
00:01:06.680 --> 00:01:10.140
It's just we didn't put them
into our routing table,

21
00:01:10.140 --> 00:01:12.540
because we didn't know the next hop.

22
00:01:12.540 --> 00:01:14.810
And so to solve ticket number four,

23
00:01:14.810 --> 00:01:19.340
what we did is we did a next hop
self command up here on NYEDGE1.

24
00:01:19.340 --> 00:01:22.270
So the NYCORE2 would know how
to get to those networks.

25
00:01:22.270 --> 00:01:25.790
And that made them show up in the routing
table and that solved the ticket.

26
00:01:25.790 --> 00:01:28.390
But I didn't really like the way
that ticket ended because

27
00:01:28.390 --> 00:01:31.540
while we saw the networks
they weren't reachable.

28
00:01:31.540 --> 00:01:33.570
When we tried to Pinged them,
they couldn't reach.

29
00:01:33.570 --> 00:01:37.200
And I made a comment at the end of
issue number four, where I said

30
00:01:37.200 --> 00:01:40.980
I'm sure that will turn up as one of the
questions that are coming up after this.

31
00:01:40.980 --> 00:01:42.960
Cuz I haven't read the questions, right?

32
00:01:42.960 --> 00:01:44.930
I'm figuring these out
the way that you guys would.

33
00:01:44.930 --> 00:01:47.170
And it didn't, it didn't come back up.

34
00:01:47.170 --> 00:01:49.340
They never actually had us
establish reachability.

35
00:01:49.340 --> 00:01:52.580
So I wanted to revisit that and show you
guys why we don't have reachability.

36
00:01:52.580 --> 00:01:57.680
The main thing to remember is that BGP
actually doesn't care about reachability.

37
00:01:57.680 --> 00:02:00.480
BGP is not a very good routing protocol.

38
00:02:00.480 --> 00:02:04.120
It's designed to handle very, very,
very large and complex networks.

39
00:02:04.120 --> 00:02:06.390
And it sacrifices accuracy for that.

40
00:02:06.390 --> 00:02:09.530
It doesn't worry about the little
hops in between networks.

41
00:02:09.530 --> 00:02:13.850
It assumes that you have an interior
routing protocol there to help you.

42
00:02:13.850 --> 00:02:16.280
And if you don't have an interior protocol

43
00:02:16.280 --> 00:02:18.330
then you'll have reachabiity
issues like we did.

44
00:02:18.330 --> 00:02:20.600
Where we learn the network but
we can't get to it right.

45
00:02:20.600 --> 00:02:23.770
Now if you take a look at this topology,
we got BGP but

46
00:02:23.770 --> 00:02:25.890
in the background there's EIGRP 800.

47
00:02:25.890 --> 00:02:31.600
The real problem here is that while we
might have known how to get to NYEDGE2 and

48
00:02:31.600 --> 00:02:34.860
back again with BGP,
we didn't know of the other protocol and

49
00:02:34.860 --> 00:02:36.530
we didn't know that intermediary hops.

50
00:02:36.530 --> 00:02:40.440
This guy, NYEDGE2 is in the mix and
causing us problems.

51
00:02:40.440 --> 00:02:44.240
Now, iBGP really wants you to have
full match across your routers, but

52
00:02:44.240 --> 00:02:47.160
you don't have to have it as
long as you've got a good

53
00:02:47.160 --> 00:02:49.860
interior routing protocol running too.

54
00:02:49.860 --> 00:02:51.670
Let me show you how easy it is for
us to fix this.

55
00:02:51.670 --> 00:02:53.310
I'm gonna go back to NYCORE2, right?

56
00:02:53.310 --> 00:02:55.840
That's kind of where our
adventure starts here.

57
00:02:55.840 --> 00:03:01.310
And on NYCORE2 the network that I
couldn't get to was 22.33.44.10,

58
00:03:01.310 --> 00:03:04.010
that was the host.

59
00:03:04.010 --> 00:03:07.380
And if I try and
ping to it I get some unreachables, right?

60
00:03:07.380 --> 00:03:10.810
And it's the weird unreachable where you
get the little dot in between cuz it takes

61
00:03:10.810 --> 00:03:12.350
so long to time out.

62
00:03:12.350 --> 00:03:14.600
And it's really weird if
we do a trace route, right?

63
00:03:14.600 --> 00:03:17.760
If I try and trace route To that address.

64
00:03:17.760 --> 00:03:20.410
It's gonna show me
the path that I follow and

65
00:03:20.410 --> 00:03:24.450
in my routing table it says
I learned a BGP route.

66
00:03:24.450 --> 00:03:30.300
And the routing table says go
straight from NYCORE2 to NYEDGE1 and

67
00:03:30.300 --> 00:03:32.870
if you remember I made that comment where
we were talking about I said boy I hope

68
00:03:32.870 --> 00:03:36.150
there's an undocumented link between these
two otherwise this isn't gonna work.

69
00:03:36.150 --> 00:03:39.500
Well there wasn't an undocumented link and
it didn't work.

70
00:03:39.500 --> 00:03:42.220
I can't go to a next hop
that's away like this.

71
00:03:42.220 --> 00:03:45.100
I need to be directly connected somehow,
or BGP chokes.

72
00:03:45.100 --> 00:03:47.330
And in this case BGP chokes.

73
00:03:47.330 --> 00:03:49.970
I learned a BGP route and
it's not good enough.

74
00:03:49.970 --> 00:03:53.820
I really need to learn an interior route,
which I would have to learn from EDGE2,

75
00:03:53.820 --> 00:03:58.450
who is not really participating in BGP at
all, and so it doesn't have that route.

76
00:03:58.450 --> 00:04:00.440
And there's where our breakdown comes in.

77
00:04:00.440 --> 00:04:03.190
All right, and so
if I look at the trace route,

78
00:04:03.190 --> 00:04:07.570
my next hop is that other edge router,
NYEDGE2.

79
00:04:07.570 --> 00:04:09.670
And look at that response.

80
00:04:09.670 --> 00:04:12.665
Host unreachable, it can't get there,
it doesn't know how.

81
00:04:12.665 --> 00:04:15.565
My next hop doesn't know
how to get to that network.

82
00:04:15.565 --> 00:04:22.265
So I need to get my IGP working before
I can expect my EGP to function right.

83
00:04:22.265 --> 00:04:24.705
And so, just as a quick and
easy solution here,

84
00:04:24.705 --> 00:04:27.205
cuz I don't wanna spend a huge
ton of time on this one.

85
00:04:27.205 --> 00:04:30.915
But if we just go around and fix IRGP
to route for our various networks,

86
00:04:30.915 --> 00:04:31.895
that'll solve the problem.

87
00:04:31.895 --> 00:04:37.020
So if I go into NYEDGE1, and
I go into router EIGRP 800.

88
00:04:37.020 --> 00:04:41.240
Normally I would do a network command for
each of the interior networks,

89
00:04:41.240 --> 00:04:44.960
but I'll just do all zero's here, right?

90
00:04:44.960 --> 00:04:48.620
So, I'm turning on EIGRP 800 for
all of my internal networks.

91
00:04:48.620 --> 00:04:51.590
Well and my WAN interface too so we'd
want to do some passive interfaces and

92
00:04:51.590 --> 00:04:52.320
stuff to solve all that.

93
00:04:52.320 --> 00:04:54.450
But I'll go ahead and throw that in.

94
00:04:54.450 --> 00:04:57.690
And then I'll jump to NYEDGE2, and
I'm gonna do the exact same thing.

95
00:04:59.560 --> 00:05:05.230
So I'll get into router EIGRP 800 and
I'll just enable it for all my networks.

96
00:05:05.230 --> 00:05:08.390
And again, in real life lan, I would be a
little more specific here and take care of

97
00:05:08.390 --> 00:05:13.050
it, but I don't wanna waste you guys
time on a bonus one here but we'll churn

98
00:05:13.050 --> 00:05:17.660
through and knock all these out and
I'll do the same thing here on CORE2.

99
00:05:17.660 --> 00:05:22.645
All right so whats gonna happen
is the EIGRP is gonna kick in

100
00:05:22.645 --> 00:05:27.640
it's gonna start advertising
these internal networks.

101
00:05:27.640 --> 00:05:31.900
Now that network 22.33.44.10
I'm learning it via BGP.

102
00:05:33.040 --> 00:05:36.580
It's iBGP with an admin distance of 200.

103
00:05:36.580 --> 00:05:42.410
Now I'm gonna learn it through EIGRP and
I'm going to know how to get there.

104
00:05:42.410 --> 00:05:44.710
Even if I excluded it from EIGRP though,

105
00:05:44.710 --> 00:05:46.930
I would at least know how
to get to my next hop.

106
00:05:46.930 --> 00:05:49.580
And my next hop would know how
to get to the network and so

107
00:05:49.580 --> 00:05:51.540
then we're gonna have that connectivity.

108
00:05:51.540 --> 00:05:57.030
And so now if I try and
get to 22.33.44.10, there we go,

109
00:05:57.030 --> 00:06:00.290
I can ping it just fine.

110
00:06:00.290 --> 00:06:06.250
And if I do a trace route to 22.33.44.10,

111
00:06:06.250 --> 00:06:10.400
it should ping over and we should see that
we're able to successfully get there.

112
00:06:10.400 --> 00:06:12.020
So, that's the important part.

113
00:06:12.020 --> 00:06:14.690
Remember that BGP is not
designed to work by itself.

114
00:06:14.690 --> 00:06:18.230
It's and exterior gateway protocol,
it really requires and

115
00:06:18.230 --> 00:06:22.350
interior gateway protocol to run alongside
it in order to have proper communications

116
00:06:22.350 --> 00:06:26.340
that work the way we expect to be able
to get our five successful pings and

117
00:06:26.340 --> 00:06:27.680
communicate across the network.

118
00:06:27.680 --> 00:06:30.730
So always look for that,
especially on the exam.

119
00:06:30.730 --> 00:06:33.750
When you have routes that you're
learning through BGP that you don't have

120
00:06:33.750 --> 00:06:36.390
a corresponding route to be
able to get to your next hop.

121
00:06:36.390 --> 00:06:38.610
Or your next stop doesn't have
a corresponding route to get to its

122
00:06:38.610 --> 00:06:39.630
destination.

123
00:06:39.630 --> 00:06:42.920
You normally need to fix the IGP, not BGP.

124
00:06:42.920 --> 00:06:45.070
In our scenario we had prefix lists and

125
00:06:45.070 --> 00:06:46.800
other things,
that was what we had to deal with.

126
00:06:46.800 --> 00:06:49.400
But an underlying routing protocol
can be the cause of a problem too.

127
00:06:49.400 --> 00:06:50.790
So I wanted to point that out, and

128
00:06:50.790 --> 00:06:53.100
that's why we did this little
bonus segment for you guys.

129
00:06:53.100 --> 00:06:55.560
Just to kind of show
you a possibility there

130
00:06:55.560 --> 00:06:57.460
that might be a little outside the normal.

131
00:06:57.460 --> 00:06:59.690
All right, well I hope you guys enjoyed
that, and definitely stay tuned.

132
00:06:59.690 --> 00:07:03.215
We got set number eight coming up next,
it'll be full of action and adventure,

133
00:07:03.215 --> 00:07:04.696
surprises around every corner.

134
00:07:04.696 --> 00:07:07.900
Stay tuned,
I look forward to seeing you then.

135
00:07:07.900 --> 00:07:13.124
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #1` from set #8. The trouble ticket states that "PLABCSCO01 is unable to ping its default gateway at 192.168.16.1 "
episodes.title: Set 8 Issue 1
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.163
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:04.163 --> 00:00:12.081
All right, welcome back to another
troubleshooting segment here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.081 --> 00:00:16.050
And we're gonna be diving into an all
new set, Set number 8, Issue 1.

4
00:00:16.050 --> 00:00:19.270
We've got a slightly different topology,
so we'll have to keep an eye out for that.

5
00:00:19.270 --> 00:00:22.520
We've got some new routing protocols in
the mix and some different rearrangements.

6
00:00:22.520 --> 00:00:24.970
But this troubleshooting
ticket sure sounds familiar.

7
00:00:24.970 --> 00:00:30.010
We've got PLab Cisco 01 is unable to ping
it's default gateway at 192.168.16.1.

8
00:00:30.010 --> 00:00:36.110
Now let's take a look at our topology and
try and get an idea of where that is.

9
00:00:36.110 --> 00:00:38.690
You'll see the extra protocols
I was talking about.

10
00:00:38.690 --> 00:00:43.570
We've got OSPF Area 0, we've got eBGP
up here, iBGP over here couple of

11
00:00:43.570 --> 00:00:48.100
things in the network, but what I care
about is way down here at the bottom.

12
00:00:48.100 --> 00:00:49.570
Good old PLABCSCO01.

13
00:00:49.570 --> 00:00:54.790
And I can see that it's 192.188.16.10 and
it's trying to ping 192.168.16.1.

14
00:00:54.790 --> 00:00:59.430
The only problem is when
I look at this diagram,

15
00:00:59.430 --> 00:01:04.330
I don't see who's 192.168.16.1.

16
00:01:04.330 --> 00:01:09.198
Looking at all this, nobody here's
really labelled with that address.

17
00:01:09.198 --> 00:01:12.100
So I'm gonna have to do a little exploring
because it can really be any of these

18
00:01:12.100 --> 00:01:13.060
devices.

19
00:01:13.060 --> 00:01:17.480
I know in the earlier episodes
we saw where 192.168.16.1 was

20
00:01:17.480 --> 00:01:21.270
always on one of these two
devices NYCORE1 or NYCORE2 so

21
00:01:21.270 --> 00:01:24.140
wanna check those, but
ultimately will have to look at them all.

22
00:01:24.140 --> 00:01:28.910
So let's just jump through each of these
and see if we can't find that IP address.

23
00:01:28.910 --> 00:01:31.890
Now I have to be careful when
I'm hunting for an IP address.

24
00:01:31.890 --> 00:01:34.400
And I'm gonna start way
down here at NYACCESS1,

25
00:01:34.400 --> 00:01:36.290
this is as good a spot as any to start.

26
00:01:38.200 --> 00:01:43.660
And when I look for an IP address,
I'm always tempted to do show

27
00:01:43.660 --> 00:01:48.900
IP interface brief, and just filter that
for the address that I'm looking for.

28
00:01:48.900 --> 00:01:50.020
Well, if I type it right.

29
00:01:50.020 --> 00:01:51.000
There we go.

30
00:01:51.000 --> 00:01:52.470
So that's one way that we can do it.

31
00:01:52.470 --> 00:01:56.210
The problem is this won't show
things like HSRP addresses or

32
00:01:56.210 --> 00:01:58.680
other kind of virtual addresses
that might be hidden.

33
00:01:58.680 --> 00:02:01.760
So if I just rely on this I might miss it.

34
00:02:01.760 --> 00:02:07.440
So I prefer to do a show running dash
config and look for the IP that way.

35
00:02:07.440 --> 00:02:08.060
Right?
So,

36
00:02:08.060 --> 00:02:10.450
I'm just looking to see if that
address is in here and it's not.

37
00:02:10.450 --> 00:02:12.340
And so I'll just move on to the next one.

38
00:02:12.340 --> 00:02:14.610
We'll go to NYCORE1 and NYCORE2.

39
00:02:14.610 --> 00:02:20.950
This is where the IP was before so I kind
of expect it to be on one of these guys.

40
00:02:20.950 --> 00:02:24.180
But I have been wrong before so
that could happen.

41
00:02:24.180 --> 00:02:29.060
And we've got an ACL that references
it but not the actual IP assignment so

42
00:02:29.060 --> 00:02:29.720
it's not NYCORE1.

43
00:02:29.720 --> 00:02:36.920
We'll jump over to NYCORE2 and
do a show run.

44
00:02:36.920 --> 00:02:40.750
And again I'm just looking for
that same address.

45
00:02:40.750 --> 00:02:43.490
Just trying to hunt it down
as quickly as possible.

46
00:02:43.490 --> 00:02:44.960
Well now that's interesting,
it's not there either.

47
00:02:44.960 --> 00:02:46.160
So I'm starting to run out of devices.

48
00:02:46.160 --> 00:02:48.840
So I just checked my three switches and

49
00:02:48.840 --> 00:02:52.390
in all the previous sets that IP address
resided on one of these three guys, so

50
00:02:52.390 --> 00:02:54.600
it must be actually up on
one of these routers now.

51
00:02:54.600 --> 00:02:57.310
Let's do EDGE1 and EDGE2 and
then we'll look at WAN1.

52
00:02:57.310 --> 00:02:58.810
Hopefully we'll we'll find it eventually.

53
00:02:58.810 --> 00:02:59.720
Or maybe it doesn't exist.

54
00:02:59.720 --> 00:03:01.530
Maybe that's our troubleshooting
ticket right there.

55
00:03:01.530 --> 00:03:03.970
We can't ping it because
the IP's not assigned anywhere.

56
00:03:03.970 --> 00:03:05.140
That would be a fun one.

57
00:03:05.140 --> 00:03:09.470
So, let me jump over to NYEDGE1 and
we'll check that guy next.

58
00:03:10.850 --> 00:03:15.964
I'm just going to do that show run and
look for 192.168.16.1.

59
00:03:17.080 --> 00:03:18.280
And we got a winner on this one.

60
00:03:18.280 --> 00:03:22.250
Here it is 192.168.16.1 255.255.255.0 and
I don't know what interface it's on,

61
00:03:22.250 --> 00:03:27.780
so let's see if we can spot that.

62
00:03:27.780 --> 00:03:29.650
And there it is, all right.

63
00:03:29.650 --> 00:03:31.596
So the default gateway or

64
00:03:31.596 --> 00:03:37.440
PLab Cisco 01 is the GigabitEthernet0/0
interface on NYEDGE1.

65
00:03:37.440 --> 00:03:40.960
So, if I go back to my topology and
look at it,

66
00:03:40.960 --> 00:03:46.180
here is my client and
the router's way up here, NYEDGE1.

67
00:03:46.180 --> 00:03:47.830
So, when I go to connect that system,

68
00:03:47.830 --> 00:03:50.390
there's a few different
ways that I can get there.

69
00:03:50.390 --> 00:03:53.440
I'm crossing VLAN 16 to get to NYACCESS1.

70
00:03:53.440 --> 00:03:58.500
And then from here,
I can either go up VLAN16 to NYCORE1, or

71
00:03:58.500 --> 00:04:00.140
up VLAN16 to NYCORE2.

72
00:04:00.140 --> 00:04:04.000
If I go to CORE1, then I should be
able to jump right up to NYEDGE1.

73
00:04:04.000 --> 00:04:08.855
This NYEDGE1 has an interface,
GI00, or GI01, whatever it was.

74
00:04:08.855 --> 00:04:11.090
[LAUGH] GI00.

75
00:04:11.090 --> 00:04:14.720
That's hopefully on VLAN16, so
that we'll be able to connect to it.

76
00:04:14.720 --> 00:04:18.080
So it might be just a matter of
passing through these two switches.

77
00:04:18.080 --> 00:04:21.840
Or I might be jumping into a third switch
coming back over and going up that way.

78
00:04:21.840 --> 00:04:26.150
I'm gonna need to figure out that path so
I can find out where my traffic is dying.

79
00:04:26.150 --> 00:04:28.890
Something's not passing along the way,
and we've gotta find it.

80
00:04:28.890 --> 00:04:32.930
So, let me jump over to, let's see.

81
00:04:32.930 --> 00:04:34.480
We'll jump over to NYACCESS1.

82
00:04:37.200 --> 00:04:41.425
And what I wanna do is I want to find
the path that we're taking for VLAN16.

83
00:04:41.425 --> 00:04:45.530
Actually, one thing I wanna check before
I even start dealing with the path.

84
00:04:45.530 --> 00:04:50.110
The diagram shows my server plugged
into port Fa0/1 right here.

85
00:04:50.110 --> 00:04:51.210
Now it says that I'm on VLAN16.

86
00:04:51.210 --> 00:04:56.880
This troubleshooting ticket could
be as easy as I'm not on VLAN16.

87
00:04:56.880 --> 00:05:00.350
So let's look at the configuration
of that port real quick.

88
00:05:00.350 --> 00:05:08.320
So I'm just gonna do a show run for
fa0/1 or interface fa0/1.

89
00:05:08.320 --> 00:05:11.795
And we're just gonna make sure that
it is actually assigned to VLAN16.

90
00:05:11.795 --> 00:05:19.202
And when I look at that,
show run int fa0/1, it's not on VLAN16.

91
00:05:19.202 --> 00:05:22.990
Now the diagram clearly says
that I should be on VLAN16 but

92
00:05:22.990 --> 00:05:26.492
I'm not, so
that may well be our problem right there.

93
00:05:26.492 --> 00:05:28.489
This could be the easiest
ticket we've done today.

94
00:05:28.489 --> 00:05:32.330
So if I do a,
let me do just a quick show of VLAN and

95
00:05:32.330 --> 00:05:38.497
when I take a look at my VLAN
configuration, VLAN16 doesn't even exist.

96
00:05:38.497 --> 00:05:40.100
All right, so there's a problem.

97
00:05:40.100 --> 00:05:43.350
Now we gotta sort through that and
find out why VLAN16 doesn't exist.

98
00:05:43.350 --> 00:05:45.270
Now, why doesn't it exist?

99
00:05:45.270 --> 00:05:48.880
Well I don't know maybe I'm supposed
to be running VTP to learn it,

100
00:05:48.880 --> 00:05:50.920
maybe I just didn't define it right?

101
00:05:50.920 --> 00:05:56.590
So I'm gonna do a show VTP status and
let's see if we're running VTP.

102
00:05:56.590 --> 00:06:02.990
Looks like we've got VTP as a server and
my VTP domain name is null.

103
00:06:02.990 --> 00:06:04.881
When you see a null value for
a VTP domain,

104
00:06:04.881 --> 00:06:08.520
that just means that hasn't been
configured, hasn't been set in place.

105
00:06:08.520 --> 00:06:12.730
So I'm not really running VTP here,
if I'm supposed to be on VLAN16,

106
00:06:12.730 --> 00:06:14.860
I should be set for VLAN16, right?

107
00:06:14.860 --> 00:06:16.450
Well, maybe.

108
00:06:16.450 --> 00:06:17.980
There is another option here.

109
00:06:17.980 --> 00:06:21.320
So the diagram says that I'm
supposed to be on VLAN16.

110
00:06:21.320 --> 00:06:29.920
All of my ACCESS1 ports were I mean all my
NYACCESS1 ports were on VLAN1 all right.

111
00:06:29.920 --> 00:06:33.162
Well I've got these links running up
here that say they're supposed to be on

112
00:06:33.162 --> 00:06:34.070
VLAN16 also.

113
00:06:34.070 --> 00:06:38.660
It's possible that this entire switch
could just be set up as access ports and

114
00:06:38.660 --> 00:06:39.800
not trunks.

115
00:06:39.800 --> 00:06:41.110
And that these are running up here.

116
00:06:41.110 --> 00:06:44.730
And if their access ports up here,
these ports might be on VLAN 16,

117
00:06:44.730 --> 00:06:47.680
which would effectively place
this whole switch on VLAN 16.

118
00:06:47.680 --> 00:06:50.250
It's a weird configuration,
but it would work.

119
00:06:50.250 --> 00:06:51.870
So let's see if that's what's going on.

120
00:06:51.870 --> 00:06:55.960
Because I'm pretty sure 24 and
23 showed up in that output a moment ago.

121
00:06:55.960 --> 00:06:57.680
So I'm gonna do a show VLAN.

122
00:06:58.810 --> 00:07:01.080
And when I take a look at
that VLAN configuration.

123
00:07:02.100 --> 00:07:03.180
Here I've got VLAN 1.

124
00:07:03.180 --> 00:07:06.280
And when I look at all the ports,
sure enough 23 and

125
00:07:06.280 --> 00:07:09.170
24 are showing up right there
which means we are not trunking.

126
00:07:09.170 --> 00:07:14.370
So if I do a show interface trunk,
no trunks.

127
00:07:14.370 --> 00:07:19.780
So all of my ports are in VLAN 1, not VLAN
16, but that's not necessarily a bad thing

128
00:07:19.780 --> 00:07:25.220
assuming the other end of these two links
right port 22 and these two switches.

129
00:07:25.220 --> 00:07:28.500
As long as those are in VLAN 16
then I'm still going be in VLAN 16.

130
00:07:28.500 --> 00:07:31.500
So let's look at NYCORE1 and
see if that's the case.

131
00:07:31.500 --> 00:07:33.130
So I'm gonna jump over to NYCORE1.

132
00:07:35.390 --> 00:07:40.920
And I just wanna do a show run for
int fa0/22 and what I'm expecting

133
00:07:40.920 --> 00:07:45.930
to see is that it's an access
port that's been statically set

134
00:07:47.180 --> 00:07:51.230
to VLAN16 and, it's fa1/0/22.

135
00:07:51.230 --> 00:07:51.879
There we go.

136
00:07:51.879 --> 00:07:56.631
And I don't see that, right, I see this
is just, I mean it is an access board or

137
00:07:56.631 --> 00:07:59.296
it might be dynamically chunking, right?

138
00:07:59.296 --> 00:08:01.130
But it's not assigned to a VLAN and

139
00:08:01.130 --> 00:08:03.730
that was the port that I
expected to see that way.

140
00:08:03.730 --> 00:08:09.380
Now, again,
it's possible that NYCORE1 is set up where

141
00:08:09.380 --> 00:08:13.750
all the ports are in VLAN 1 also, but then
this starts to get really kind of weird.

142
00:08:13.750 --> 00:08:17.310
It could be that my diagram is wrong,
but that would seem odd.

143
00:08:17.310 --> 00:08:20.210
So let's take a look at NY, well let's

that will move them over.

362
00:20:13.870 --> 00:20:19.000
And then lastly I don't have to
move NYEDGE1 because it's a router.

363
00:20:19.000 --> 00:20:20.478
It doesn't know about VLANS anyway.

364
00:20:20.478 --> 00:20:25.411
But I do need to think about NYCORE2
over here that it's port 22 needs to be

365
00:20:25.411 --> 00:20:26.346
on vlan 16.

366
00:20:26.346 --> 00:20:27.370
So I'm gonna go over to NYCORE2.

367
00:20:29.460 --> 00:20:33.920
And we'll get into interface fa1/0/22 and

368
00:20:33.920 --> 00:20:41.090
we'll just assign it to VLAN
16 just like the others.

369
00:20:41.090 --> 00:20:44.269
All right, so now,
like the diagram indicated,

370
00:20:44.269 --> 00:20:47.230
I moved these 3 interfaces
over to VLAN 16.

371
00:20:47.230 --> 00:20:49.000
Right, so they're all set.

372
00:20:50.020 --> 00:20:54.732
And I took this link that had no VLAN
denoted on it, and moved it over to

373
00:20:54.732 --> 00:20:59.718
VLAN 16 also because NYEDGE1's IP
address is in the VLAN 16 range.

374
00:20:59.718 --> 00:21:04.496
Now, that VLAN filter's applied to VLAN 1,
I'm on VLAN 16.

375
00:21:04.496 --> 00:21:05.900
I should be able to communicate just fine.

376
00:21:05.900 --> 00:21:09.119
So, let's jump over to PLABCSCO01,
and let's see what we get this time.

377
00:21:10.420 --> 00:21:16.620
So taking a look at this guy,
if I just pull my ping back up,

378
00:21:16.620 --> 00:21:18.710
and right now it's doing
it's ARP broadcast,

379
00:21:18.710 --> 00:21:25.070
that should travel across the network and,
that's not a good sign, right?

380
00:21:25.070 --> 00:21:28.200
So, we're basically reaching out on the
network, trying to get to the other side,

381
00:21:28.200 --> 00:21:30.100
and still not getting there.

382
00:21:30.100 --> 00:21:32.570
So, something else is wrong.

383
00:21:32.570 --> 00:21:33.490
Well, what is wrong?

384
00:21:33.490 --> 00:21:35.580
Oh, apparently,
what's wrong is me being impatient.

385
00:21:35.580 --> 00:21:39.890
It knows that last ping just came through,
apparently arp may have taken a while.

386
00:21:39.890 --> 00:21:41.370
And you can see sometimes,

387
00:21:41.370 --> 00:21:44.450
if you adjusted the VLAN of more
than one link across the network.

388
00:21:44.450 --> 00:21:47.670
Remember, I had to jump through more than
one switch, so the arp broadcast were kind

389
00:21:47.670 --> 00:21:49.830
of happening throughout and
I just didn't gave enough time.

390
00:21:49.830 --> 00:21:52.815
But now I'm glad I stalled for
a second there, cuz it went through and

391
00:21:52.815 --> 00:21:55.046
now we're able to communicate
with that gateway.

392
00:21:55.046 --> 00:21:59.762
All right, now, one thing I do need to
be aware of, the diagram is not very

393
00:21:59.762 --> 00:22:04.728
feature complete as far as telling me
what interfaces should be on what VLAN.

394
00:22:04.728 --> 00:22:08.617
So I need to remember for
the rest of this set that I've moved those

395
00:22:08.617 --> 00:22:13.018
interfaces over to VLAN16 just in case
we have some other kind of issue.

396
00:22:13.018 --> 00:22:15.408
If they intended me to stay on VLAN 1,

397
00:22:15.408 --> 00:22:18.260
then I could always put
these back to VLAN 1.

398
00:22:18.260 --> 00:22:20.640
And I would just need
to remove that filter.

399
00:22:20.640 --> 00:22:22.230
And removing the filter's really easy.

400
00:22:22.230 --> 00:22:25.000
In fact, the filter's not even
doing anything at this point.

401
00:22:25.000 --> 00:22:26.850
So if I want to put that filter, or

402
00:22:26.850 --> 00:22:29.930
take that filter out,
I can jump back to NYCORE1.

403
00:22:32.400 --> 00:22:35.610
And on this one if we just
take a look at that command.

404
00:22:35.610 --> 00:22:39.390
Right, if we do a show run and
include the word filter.

405
00:22:39.390 --> 00:22:42.628
The command to implement that
is just this one right here.

406
00:22:42.628 --> 00:22:45.368
Vlan filter BLOCK vlan-list 1..

407
00:22:45.368 --> 00:22:52.110
So we can say no vlan
filter BLOCK vlan-list 1.

408
00:22:52.110 --> 00:22:55.470
And that's gonna remove that filter and
get it off of there.

409
00:22:55.470 --> 00:22:59.160
It was just blocking
PLABSCSO01's IP anyway.

410
00:22:59.160 --> 00:23:00.510
So that gets it outta there.

411
00:23:00.510 --> 00:23:04.955
And now, if I do have to move us back to
VLAN 1, then that will be easy enough for

412
00:23:04.955 --> 00:23:06.505
us to do, and it won't be a problem there.

413
00:23:06.505 --> 00:23:07.025
All right.

414
00:23:07.025 --> 00:23:10.405
So, we should be in good shape and,
ready to move on to the next question.

415
00:23:10.405 --> 00:23:14.315
So, for this one,
the problem turned out to be a VLAN ACL.

416
00:23:14.315 --> 00:23:15.315
Remember the red flag.

417
00:23:15.315 --> 00:23:20.585
If you can't communicate with the host,
but you are learning their Mac address,

418
00:23:20.585 --> 00:23:24.890
and you're not being routed, that's
the big indicator you got a VLAN ACL.

419
00:23:24.890 --> 00:23:25.970
Just have to find it, right?

420
00:23:25.970 --> 00:23:29.270
And you look for that keyword filter in
each of your configs that'll turn up,

421
00:23:29.270 --> 00:23:31.900
then you'll be able to solve that problem
and knock that one off the list and

422
00:23:31.900 --> 00:23:33.430
move onto the next one on the exam.

423
00:23:33.430 --> 00:23:35.108
Which is exactly what we're gonna do here.

424
00:23:35.108 --> 00:23:40.040
So, stay tuned, we've got more
troubleshooting questions coming up.

425
00:23:40.040 --> 00:23:45.640
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #2` from set #8. The trouble ticket states that "NYEDGE2 and NYCORE2 are not establishing a neighbor relationship in OSPF. "
episodes.title: Set 8 Issue 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.107 --> 00:00:08.440
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.440 --> 00:00:11.840
All right, welcome back to another
troubleshooting segment here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.840 --> 00:00:14.160
We're gonna be jumping right
back into set eight, and

4
00:00:14.160 --> 00:00:15.930
we've got issue two on the table.

5
00:00:15.930 --> 00:00:18.330
Looks like we've got an OSPF
issue this time around.

6
00:00:18.330 --> 00:00:20.960
The ticket reads NYEDGE2 and

7
00:00:20.960 --> 00:00:24.970
NYCORE2 are not establishing
a neighbor relationship in OSPF.

8
00:00:24.970 --> 00:00:26.830
So we've got a bit of an OSPF problem.

9
00:00:26.830 --> 00:00:28.950
We need to figure that out and
see what's going on.

10
00:00:28.950 --> 00:00:31.400
Now, before we do that,
let's take a look at our topology and

11
00:00:31.400 --> 00:00:35.330
get an idea of which devices
are gonna be involved in this.

12
00:00:35.330 --> 00:00:39.540
So they're telling me NYEDGE2,
and NYCORE2.

13
00:00:39.540 --> 00:00:41.950
That's these two guys right here.

14
00:00:41.950 --> 00:00:47.560
NYEDGE2 and NYCORE2, and they're directly
connected, so I've got a gigabit ethernet

15
00:00:47.560 --> 00:00:53.390
connection here, GI00, connecting to
a fast ethernet connection here FA101, but

16
00:00:53.390 --> 00:00:56.880
either way it's a direct connection and
we should be establishing a neighborship.

17
00:00:56.880 --> 00:00:59.630
It's telling me we're not,
so I need to find out why.

18
00:00:59.630 --> 00:01:04.340
Now, NYEDGE2 is a router, and
I expect it to be able to connect up.

19
00:01:04.340 --> 00:01:07.590
Down here on NYCORE2 I've got a switch,
now that means it's more

20
00:01:07.590 --> 00:01:10.110
than likely a layer three
switch running an OSPF process,

21
00:01:10.110 --> 00:01:13.779
but that configuration can be
a little more complex, right?

22
00:01:13.779 --> 00:01:18.820
Because this link, running in front
in from NYEDGE2, it might be a VLAN

23
00:01:18.820 --> 00:01:23.277
interface, or
it might be a routed interface, right?

24
00:01:23.277 --> 00:01:26.590
So different kind of complexities
that can come into the mix there.

25
00:01:26.590 --> 00:01:29.730
So I actually kinda wanna start
on NYCORE2 and see what it's got.

26
00:01:29.730 --> 00:01:34.270
This is port FA101 so I want to see
what that port's configured like, and

27
00:01:34.270 --> 00:01:37.060
just take a glance at OSPF, and
see if we can't immediately spot it.

28
00:01:37.060 --> 00:01:39.300
Maybe there's log files
telling us what's going on.

29
00:01:39.300 --> 00:01:40.450
We can always use debugs and

30
00:01:40.450 --> 00:01:43.960
other things to find out why OSPF
is not building that adjacency.

31
00:01:43.960 --> 00:01:47.860
So let's jump over to NYCORE2,
and see what we can see.

32
00:01:47.860 --> 00:01:50.180
Now I haven't really logged
into NYCORE2 yet, so

33
00:01:50.180 --> 00:01:54.225
this will be interesting to see if
there's any crazy logs popping up.

34
00:01:54.225 --> 00:01:54.820
Oops.
Or

35
00:01:54.820 --> 00:01:57.640
I can just start typing the wrong thing,
that'll help.

36
00:01:57.640 --> 00:02:02.200
But what I'm looking for,
is I'm looking for

37
00:02:02.200 --> 00:02:08.740
any kind of log messages that would
indicate a OSPF adjacency failure,

38
00:02:08.740 --> 00:02:11.970
and a lot of the times you'll see
those in the log file in the system.

39
00:02:11.970 --> 00:02:16.960
So I'm just going to do a show log real
quick, and skip forward and, sure enough,

40
00:02:16.960 --> 00:02:19.980
we've got plenty of OSPF
errors right there.

41
00:02:19.980 --> 00:02:23.190
OPSF4, error received.

42
00:02:23.190 --> 00:02:24.570
Received invalid packet.

43
00:02:24.570 --> 00:02:30.550
Mismatched area ID found
from 192.168.16.5 on VLAN1.

44
00:02:30.550 --> 00:02:33.930
All right, so that's pretty clear, right?

45
00:02:33.930 --> 00:02:36.160
It's telling me I've got an area mismatch,
and

46
00:02:36.160 --> 00:02:40.680
it's telling me, connections must be from
backbone, or must be from a virtual link,

47
00:02:40.680 --> 00:02:43.870
and in this scenario,
it's telling me that neither is the case.

48
00:02:43.870 --> 00:02:48.640
Well, looking at my topology, I'm
supposed to be in OSPF Area Zero, right?

49
00:02:48.640 --> 00:02:53.120
So I expect Area Zero across all of this
stuff, and that means I shouldn't have to

50
00:02:53.120 --> 00:02:56.830
worry about not connecting
to the backbone area or not.

51
00:02:56.830 --> 00:02:59.010
I shouldn't even have to
worry about virtual links.

52
00:02:59.010 --> 00:03:04.860
If everybody is in OSPF Area Zero, there's
no use for a virtual link anywhere here.

53
00:03:04.860 --> 00:03:09.690
So, in this case, I probably just have the
wrong area ID set on one end or the other.

54
00:03:09.690 --> 00:03:10.340
I don't know which end.

55
00:03:10.340 --> 00:03:12.820
So we'll have to figure that out.

56
00:03:12.820 --> 00:03:16.350
The other thing I need
to pay attention to is,

57
00:03:16.350 --> 00:03:20.040
notice that IP address,
192.168.16.5 on VLAN1.

58
00:03:20.040 --> 00:03:24.420
In issue number one,
we had that issue with the VLAN filter.

59
00:03:24.420 --> 00:03:29.310
And we notice that our machines weren't on
VLAN16 like they were supposed to be, and

60
00:03:29.310 --> 00:03:32.060
here we might be dealing
with the same thing.

61
00:03:32.060 --> 00:03:36.700
We've got that 192.168.16 address on
VLAN1 when it should be on VLAN16.

62
00:03:36.700 --> 00:03:40.985
So one of the things I said when
I first came to this device,

63
00:03:40.985 --> 00:03:42.720
was I wanted to look at that port, FA101.

64
00:03:42.720 --> 00:03:43.920
I still do.

65
00:03:43.920 --> 00:03:46.680
Let's take a look at that one and
see what we've got.

66
00:03:46.680 --> 00:03:51.900
So I'm just gonna do a show run for
interface 1/0/1, and I want to see if

67
00:03:51.900 --> 00:03:56.730
it's a routed port or a switched port, and
I can see it is, indeed, a switched port.

68
00:03:56.730 --> 00:04:01.720
All right, so it's a switched port and
that means that it's a sign to a VLAN,

69
00:04:01.720 --> 00:04:05.840
in this case, VLAN1, the default, and that
traffic from the other side that is coming

70
00:04:05.840 --> 00:04:10.880
in and ending up in on VLAN1 and on my
switch if I do a show IP interface brief,

71
00:04:12.300 --> 00:04:17.950
I can see that it's got an address
of 192.168.16.6 on VLAN1 also.

72
00:04:17.950 --> 00:04:23.730
All right, now, that's wrong, according to
the diagram, but we saw that in set one,

73
00:04:23.730 --> 00:04:27.820
these things didn't match, and what I said
at the end of issue one, not set one,

74
00:04:27.820 --> 00:04:30.650
it was at the end of set eight, issue one.

75
00:04:30.650 --> 00:04:34.270
At the end of that issue, I said, I'm
gonna move the devices over to VLAN16, but

76
00:04:34.270 --> 00:04:38.085
if it ever turns out to be a problem,
I can either move the other people over to

77
00:04:38.085 --> 00:04:40.728
VLAN16 or
I can just move everybody back to VLAN1.

78
00:04:40.728 --> 00:04:43.770
Well there's no easy way to move an IP

79
00:04:43.770 --> 00:04:46.330
address from one VLAN
interface to another.

80
00:04:46.330 --> 00:04:51.370
I would have to basically remove this
VLAN's IP, add VLAN16, add that IP.

81
00:04:51.370 --> 00:04:53.330
It be a lot work, and so in this case,

82
00:04:53.330 --> 00:04:56.660
I think its going to be easier just
to move everybody back to VLAN1.

83
00:04:56.660 --> 00:04:59.930
We've removed that VLAN ACL from
the first question, so that's gone.

84
00:04:59.930 --> 00:05:01.880
So we can just move people back to VLAN1,

85
00:05:01.880 --> 00:05:04.160
and that should kind
of sort that part out.

86
00:05:04.160 --> 00:05:07.770
Now we still have our mismatched area ID
to sort out, but I wanna fix that AC,

87
00:05:07.770 --> 00:05:08.520
not ACL.

88
00:05:08.520 --> 00:05:11.320
I wanna fix that VLAN
assignment issue first,

89
00:05:11.320 --> 00:05:14.490
because otherwise we're gonna
have some devices in VLAN16, and

90
00:05:14.490 --> 00:05:18.760
some devices in VLAN1 and we're gonna
have other connectivity issues creep up.

91
00:05:18.760 --> 00:05:22.270
So if you remember,
I changed to these three interfaces here,

92
00:05:22.270 --> 00:05:26.990
as well as these two interfaces up here,
and the interface that faced EDGE1.

93
00:05:26.990 --> 00:05:29.020
Those are the three that
I moved over into VLAN16.

94
00:05:29.020 --> 00:05:31.600
I'm just gonna move them back to VLAN1,

95
00:05:31.600 --> 00:05:35.590
and that should take care of any
kind of things that creep up there.

96
00:05:35.590 --> 00:05:37.970
And actually,
I don't remember if I fixed it on NYCORE2.

97
00:05:37.970 --> 00:05:38.750
Did I?

98
00:05:38.750 --> 00:05:39.890
Let's find out.

99
00:05:39.890 --> 00:05:42.500
Yeah.
I do have one interface on VLAN16 here.

100
00:05:42.500 --> 00:05:47.080
So I'm gonna go and just move it
back over to where I want it to be,

101
00:05:47.080 --> 00:05:50.680
which is good old switchport access VLAN1.

102
00:05:50.680 --> 00:05:53.200
And that'll put that one back.

103
00:05:53.200 --> 00:05:55.157
Then I just need to tackle access one.

104
00:05:58.147 --> 00:06:01.810
And basically run through that same thing.

105
00:06:01.810 --> 00:06:06.540
Let me do a show VLAN and
see which interfaces are on VLAN16.

106
00:06:06.540 --> 00:06:11.120
So I got one, 23, and 24, so
we're just gonna move those back.

107
00:06:13.730 --> 00:06:17.660
And so I'm gonna use the range command,
make that a little bit easier on me.

108
00:06:17.660 --> 00:06:20.300
And set those back to VLAN1, all right.

109
00:06:20.300 --> 00:06:25.100
Now, if I hadn't removed that
VLAN ACL before, then I would

110
00:06:25.100 --> 00:06:28.490
actually need to remove it here, but we
did, we removed it before, so it's gone.

111
00:06:28.490 --> 00:06:30.290
Now, let's see, that just leaves core one.

112
00:06:31.860 --> 00:06:35.200
This last guy, which apparently,
I left in my config, which is convenient.

113
00:06:36.820 --> 00:06:39.850
And for it, what does it have on VLAN16?

114
00:06:39.850 --> 00:06:47.940
Ports one and 22, so
we'll just set those in the right spot.

115
00:06:51.280 --> 00:06:51.890
Range command.

116
00:06:51.890 --> 00:06:53.750
Sometimes, they save you time,
sometimes they don't.

117
00:06:53.750 --> 00:06:56.500
And then you have to type
out these crazy things.

118
00:06:56.500 --> 00:06:58.494
All right.
Switchboard access, VLAN1, and

119
00:06:58.494 --> 00:06:59.870
that's fixed, all right.

120
00:06:59.870 --> 00:07:02.440
So now they're all nice and neat,

121
00:07:02.440 --> 00:07:07.170
back to VLAN1 where they're supposed to
be, and now I don't have VLAN16 anymore.

122
00:07:07.170 --> 00:07:11.710
And so basically all of these ports are on
VLAN1, just across this whole topology.

123
00:07:11.710 --> 00:07:12.880
And I'm okay with that.

124
00:07:12.880 --> 00:07:16.170
And over here in NYCORE2,
I've got that VLAN1

125
00:07:16.170 --> 00:07:21.080
interface that has 192.168.16.something,
I don't remember, and it's

126
00:07:21.080 --> 00:07:25.220
reaching over this link up to NYEDGE2, and
were supposed to be building adjacency.

127
00:07:25.220 --> 00:07:27.400
Now we can start to
troubleshoot that adjacency,

128
00:07:27.400 --> 00:07:31.130
and not have to worry about weird VLAN
numbers is getting the mix, all right.

129
00:07:31.130 --> 00:07:35.080
So troubleshooting this adjacency,
there's two ways to go about it.

130
00:07:35.080 --> 00:07:39.650
I know that I'm getting a report of
a mismatched error ID, I mean, an area ID.

131
00:07:39.650 --> 00:07:43.480
So the easiest way to troubleshoot this is
to do what's called the config comparison.

132
00:07:43.480 --> 00:07:45.680
Look at the configuration of OSPF up here.

133
00:07:45.680 --> 00:07:47.720
Look at the configuration
of OSPF down here.

134
00:07:47.720 --> 00:07:48.950
Whichever one's not set for

135
00:07:48.950 --> 00:07:52.490
Area Zero, that's the problem,
you put it in Area Zero, and you're fixed.

136
00:07:52.490 --> 00:07:59.090
Or I could do debug IP OSPF ADJ,
and debug IP OSPF Packet,

137
00:07:59.090 --> 00:08:02.780
and what that would do is they would
show me the communications, right?

138
00:08:02.780 --> 00:08:06.080
Packet, I would see the actual
OSPF packets coming through, and

139
00:08:06.080 --> 00:08:07.960
ADJ would be the adjacency events.

140
00:08:07.960 --> 00:08:11.770
And so I can see if there is hello and
dead timer mixups, and so on.

141
00:08:11.770 --> 00:08:13.940
In this case we just know it's
an area ID mixup though so

142
00:08:13.940 --> 00:08:15.880
I just need to look at the config,
that'll be faster,

143
00:08:15.880 --> 00:08:18.130
and we don't have to mess
around with debug commands.

144
00:08:18.130 --> 00:08:21.070
So I'm just going to
jump over to NYCORE2 and

145
00:08:21.070 --> 00:08:24.780
just do a quick show IP protocols, right?

146
00:08:24.780 --> 00:08:27.270
Show IP protocols will show
me the OSPF process, and

147
00:08:27.270 --> 00:08:32.190
it will show me the areas that I'm in,
and, well, here's our problem.

148
00:08:32.190 --> 00:08:36.520
This guy is showing 192.168.16.0
as being in Area One,

149
00:08:36.520 --> 00:08:39.680
instead of Area Zero, and that's more
than likely why we're getting a mismatch,

150
00:08:39.680 --> 00:08:44.310
because we're receiving information
from another node that's in Area Zero.

151
00:08:44.310 --> 00:08:47.170
Now, I don't know if I have
that problem with anybody else,

152
00:08:47.170 --> 00:08:52.050
so I'm gonna do a quick show
IP OSPF Neighbor, and I have no neighbors.

153
00:08:52.050 --> 00:08:53.941
So it's not like anybody
else is in Area One.

154
00:08:53.941 --> 00:08:56.655
It looks like it's just me in Area One,
so I'm the problem.

155
00:08:56.655 --> 00:08:59.613
[NOISE] You know, it's me not you.

156
00:08:59.613 --> 00:09:02.080
[LAUGH] And so we need to fix that.

157
00:09:02.080 --> 00:09:04.550
I'll do a show run and
look for the OSPF section.

158
00:09:05.900 --> 00:09:08.530
And looks like we got a simple
network statement on this one.

159
00:09:08.530 --> 00:09:09.850
OSPF is tricky remember.

160
00:09:09.850 --> 00:09:14.170
OSPF can be configured here in the global
area, the global router config, or

161
00:09:14.170 --> 00:09:16.400
it can be done on the interface.

162
00:09:16.400 --> 00:09:21.540
Somebody could have gone onto an interface
and said IP OSPF 100 Area One.

163
00:09:21.540 --> 00:09:23.430
And so then I wouldn't see
it here in this section.

164
00:09:23.430 --> 00:09:25.480
So you might have to check
the interfaces also.

165
00:09:25.480 --> 00:09:29.400
But in this case it is right
here in the router process.

166
00:09:29.400 --> 00:09:30.710
And I can just say network.

167
00:09:30.710 --> 00:09:35.280
Well actually I have to get
that one out of there first.

168
00:09:35.280 --> 00:09:36.816
So lets do a no network 192.168.16.0.

169
00:09:38.880 --> 00:09:43.810
And we'll take that one out, and then I'm
just going to rerun that same command,

170
00:09:43.810 --> 00:09:46.525
without the no, and put it into Area Zero.

171
00:09:46.525 --> 00:09:50.250
And once that's in Area Zero, now I'll
start receiving the communications from

172
00:09:50.250 --> 00:09:53.080
the other router that's in Area Zero, and

173
00:09:53.080 --> 00:09:57.900
an adjacency should form up, and
that usually doesn't take to long.

174
00:09:57.900 --> 00:10:00.560
