And so that process, there we go,
it's already running.

175
00:10:00.560 --> 00:10:04.080
I didn't get any pop-ups on my screen, so
apparently console logging is turned off,

176
00:10:04.080 --> 00:10:08.150
but either way,
I can see I now have a couple of peers,

177
00:10:08.150 --> 00:10:12.509
including 192.168.16.5,
which I'll imagine is that Edge router.

178
00:10:12.509 --> 00:10:16.990
172.14.0.2 that could be it also.

179
00:10:16.990 --> 00:10:20.898
I'm not sure who it is, so maybe I'll
jump over and verify that on NYEDGE2.

180
00:10:20.898 --> 00:10:24.830
I'm just going to do a quick
show IP interface brief here so

181
00:10:24.830 --> 00:10:26.200
I can figure out who it is.

182
00:10:30.460 --> 00:10:35.590
And oh it is 172.14.0.2,
that's it, and so when I look

183
00:10:35.590 --> 00:10:41.230
back on NYCORE2, I now have an adjacency
with that router right here,

184
00:10:41.230 --> 00:10:43.010
and we should be exchanging routes.

185
00:10:43.010 --> 00:10:46.870
If I do a show IP route,
let's see if we've learned anything.

186
00:10:46.870 --> 00:10:49.300
They didn't specify it in the question
that we should be learning anything, so

187
00:10:49.300 --> 00:10:52.030
even if we're not,
it's not that big of a deal.

188
00:10:52.030 --> 00:10:55.460
But looks like yeah I really haven't
learned anything from them yet.

189
00:10:55.460 --> 00:10:57.820
But I do have an adjacency,
and so we are up.

190
00:10:57.820 --> 00:11:00.130
It says in the ticket, NYEDGE2 and

191
00:11:00.130 --> 00:11:03.740
NYCORE2 are not establishing
a neighbor relationship in OSPF.

192
00:11:03.740 --> 00:11:04.590
We resolved that.

193
00:11:04.590 --> 00:11:07.700
It doesn't say anything about routes,
so that's going to resolve this one.

194
00:11:07.700 --> 00:11:11.000
I'm just going to do one more thing to
double check before we wrap this one up.

195
00:11:11.000 --> 00:11:13.060
I'm going to jump over to NYEDGE2, and

196
00:11:13.060 --> 00:11:15.050
just make sure I have
a neighbor relationship here.

197
00:11:15.050 --> 00:11:18.850
So I'll do a show IP OSPF Neighbor.

198
00:11:18.850 --> 00:11:22.250
I fully expect it, because a neighbor
relationship is a two way thing, but

199
00:11:22.250 --> 00:11:24.490
I just wanna be on the safe side, and

200
00:11:24.490 --> 00:11:28.700
I can see that I do have a couple of
connections out on that V line interface.

201
00:11:28.700 --> 00:11:32.290
I don't know which one
is actually NYCORE2, so

202
00:11:32.290 --> 00:11:34.100
let's go find out what it's got.

203
00:11:35.540 --> 00:11:39.170
If I do a show IP INT Brief and

204
00:11:39.170 --> 00:11:44.070
I can see that it is 192.168.16.6,
and so when I look at EDGE2,

205
00:11:45.300 --> 00:11:50.800
that's the second neighbor
statement right here, 192.168.16.6.

206
00:11:50.800 --> 00:11:51.770
All right, so we resolved it.

207
00:11:51.770 --> 00:11:54.190
In this case,
as simple as an area mismatch.

208
00:11:54.190 --> 00:11:55.900
We turned up just by doing a show log.

209
00:11:55.900 --> 00:11:58.310
It was right there in the log file,
we could see what was wrong,

210
00:11:58.310 --> 00:11:59.320
you go in and fix it.

211
00:11:59.320 --> 00:12:01.120
A debug would've turned that up also,

212
00:12:01.120 --> 00:12:03.550
but it's more trouble than
it's worth sometimes.

213
00:12:03.550 --> 00:12:04.560
This one turned out to be pretty easy.

214
00:12:04.560 --> 00:12:07.250
We fixed that, and
now ready to move on to the next question.

215
00:12:07.250 --> 00:12:08.510
So hope you guys enjoyed it.

216
00:12:08.510 --> 00:12:11.427
Stay tuned,
we've got issue number three coming up.

217
00:12:11.427 --> 00:12:17.859
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #3` from set #8. The trouble ticket states that "NYWAN1 and NYEDGE2 are configured for iBGP but they are not establishing a connection "
episodes.title: Set 8 Issue 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.227 --> 00:00:05.985
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.505 --> 00:00:12.433
All right, ladies and gentlemen, welcome
back to another troubleshooting episode on

3
00:00:12.433 --> 00:00:15.509
ITProTV, and we're going to be
jumping into Set Eight Issue Three,

4
00:00:15.509 --> 00:00:18.420
another exciting troubleshooting
adventure ahead of us.

5
00:00:18.420 --> 00:00:20.130
Looks like this time
we've got a BGP issue.

6
00:00:20.130 --> 00:00:21.460
Those are some of my favorites.

7
00:00:21.460 --> 00:00:24.040
So, this one says that NYWAN1.

8
00:00:24.040 --> 00:00:27.870
And NYEDGE2 are configured for iBGP.

9
00:00:27.870 --> 00:00:30.580
But they are not
establishing a connection.

10
00:00:30.580 --> 00:00:34.700
Now, we've seen BGP issues like this
in previous troubleshooting tickets.

11
00:00:34.700 --> 00:00:38.450
It uses TCP, it basically
establishes a dedicated connection.

12
00:00:38.450 --> 00:00:40.760
iBGP can be really finicky about things.

13
00:00:40.760 --> 00:00:44.640
It expects this full mesh, it expects to
know the network in between two nodes.

14
00:00:44.640 --> 00:00:47.930
So, it can be pretty picky,
I'm not surprised to see a problem here.

15
00:00:47.930 --> 00:00:49.620
And there's a lot of different
things that can cause it.

16
00:00:49.620 --> 00:00:52.530
So, this isn't one where I'm saying,
I bet it's this.

17
00:00:52.530 --> 00:00:53.690
And I just jump right in and find it.

18
00:00:53.690 --> 00:00:56.090
Here we're gonna have to
explore around a little bit.

19
00:00:56.090 --> 00:00:59.310
Let's start with our typology to see
exactly where we have to explore.

20
00:00:59.310 --> 00:01:02.980
They're telling me that it's NYWAN1,
and NY EDGE2.

21
00:01:02.980 --> 00:01:06.410
So, they've conveniently chosen
devices pretty far spread out.

22
00:01:06.410 --> 00:01:11.680
So, NYWAN1 has an iBGP connection
to NYEDGE2 way up here.

23
00:01:11.680 --> 00:01:16.350
So, that means in order to get there
NYWAN1 has to pass through NYCORE1,

24
00:01:16.350 --> 00:01:20.850
through NYCORE2 and
up to EDGE2, all right?

25
00:01:20.850 --> 00:01:25.230
I'm hoping and we'll see, my hopes
will probably be just trashed, but

26
00:01:25.230 --> 00:01:29.410
I'm hoping that these guys are both on
VLAN 16, or at least on the same subnet.

27
00:01:29.410 --> 00:01:31.370
And that way they can just talk
directly to each other, and

28
00:01:31.370 --> 00:01:33.360
then I don't have to worry
about anything crazy.

29
00:01:33.360 --> 00:01:35.280
But the odds are these guys
will be in different VLANS,

30
00:01:35.280 --> 00:01:38.370
which means we'll get routed, and that's
where all the headaches start to come in.

31
00:01:38.370 --> 00:01:41.530
So, let's see what we're dealing with.

32
00:01:41.530 --> 00:01:44.500
I know that NYEDGE2 is on
the 192.168.16 network,

33
00:01:44.500 --> 00:01:46.390
cuz we saw that in a previous issue.

34
00:01:46.390 --> 00:01:48.590
But if you haven't watched that one,
let's just verify.

35
00:01:48.590 --> 00:01:53.330
I'm gonna go here to NYEDGE2, and
I'm gonna verify its IP address.

36
00:01:53.330 --> 00:01:55.170
So, I'll just do a quick
show IP interface brief.

37
00:01:56.500 --> 00:02:02.220
And I can see that,
on it's LAN interface, this inside one.

38
00:02:02.220 --> 00:02:04.300
The one that's on IBGP is GI00.

39
00:02:04.300 --> 00:02:09.960
And on the GI00 side of things,
it's 192.168.16.2.

40
00:02:09.960 --> 00:02:12.230
So, I'm going to use the most
important troubleshooting tool I have,

41
00:02:12.230 --> 00:02:13.820
which is the pen.

42
00:02:13.820 --> 00:02:20.410
And I'm just going to write that down,
so I don't forget.

43
00:02:20.410 --> 00:02:21.800
So NYEDGE2 is 192.168.16.2.

44
00:02:21.800 --> 00:02:27.540
And then,
on the other end of this is NYWAN1.

45
00:02:27.540 --> 00:02:29.520
NYWAN1 is way over here.

46
00:02:29.520 --> 00:02:32.250
I've got some kind of layer
3 interface here, which.

47
00:02:32.250 --> 00:02:35.743
Again, doesn't bode well for me hoping
these guys are on the same subnet.

48
00:02:35.743 --> 00:02:37.370
[LAUGH] So let's jump over to NYWAN1.

49
00:02:37.370 --> 00:02:39.880
They have not labeled that interface for
me, so

50
00:02:39.880 --> 00:02:42.140
I really don't know
what network to expect.

51
00:02:42.140 --> 00:02:43.830
And actually,
that's going to be a bit of a problem.

52
00:02:43.830 --> 00:02:45.550
Hopefully it's running CDP at least, so

53
00:02:45.550 --> 00:02:47.760
I can see which port is
plugged into NYCORE1.

54
00:02:47.760 --> 00:02:50.800
So, let's jump over to NYWAN1 and
see if we can't figure that out.

55
00:02:53.020 --> 00:02:57.080
So, on NYWAN1, I'm gonna start with
the show cdp neighbor, just so

56
00:02:57.080 --> 00:02:58.770
I can figure out the interfaces.

57
00:02:58.770 --> 00:03:02.240
And it's connected to NYCORE1
on its Gig 0/0 interface.

58
00:03:02.240 --> 00:03:06.508
So while it's not documented here
on the diagram, this is Gig 0/0.

59
00:03:06.508 --> 00:03:12.780
And so I'm just gonna do a show run for
interface gi0/0, and it's 192.168.15.1.

60
00:03:12.780 --> 00:03:18.000
I should have known they
were on different sub nets.

61
00:03:18.000 --> 00:03:22.805
So, all right,
let me just write that down.

62
00:03:22.805 --> 00:03:26.226
NYWAN1 is 192.168.15.1.

63
00:03:26.226 --> 00:03:31.520
All right, now, the reason I was
hoping they were on the same subnet.

64
00:03:31.520 --> 00:03:32.990
If they're on the same subnet,

65
00:03:32.990 --> 00:03:35.160
they can build a neighbor
relationship to each other.

66
00:03:35.160 --> 00:03:38.670
It's gonna come right up, and
there's no big deal, whatsoever.

67
00:03:38.670 --> 00:03:44.260
But, the instant you put a single
router in between two iBGP nodes,

68
00:03:44.260 --> 00:03:46.140
things do start to get really flaky.

69
00:03:46.140 --> 00:03:50.260
And the main reason is,
BGP expects you to have.

70
00:03:50.260 --> 00:03:51.400
An IGP.

71
00:03:51.400 --> 00:03:53.360
And interior gateway
protocol under the hood.

72
00:03:53.360 --> 00:03:56.050
And we've seen that in previous
troubleshooting issues too.

73
00:03:56.050 --> 00:03:58.290
It needs to know that, to figure out
how to get to these other networks.

74
00:03:58.290 --> 00:04:01.110
When you start having routers in the mix,
that can be a problem.

75
00:04:01.110 --> 00:04:05.470
But before I dive in to complex network
topology stuff, this could be as simple as

76
00:04:05.470 --> 00:04:09.540
bad authentication, or
wrong autonomous system number.

77
00:04:09.540 --> 00:04:12.780
There's some basic BGP configurations
that could be wrong here.

78
00:04:12.780 --> 00:04:14.910
And I can save myself a lot of trouble.

79
00:04:14.910 --> 00:04:18.100
And the easiest way to spot that,
is to do a config compare.

80
00:04:18.100 --> 00:04:21.360
Compare the config on one side
with the config on the other side.

81
00:04:21.360 --> 00:04:23.270
And so I'm just gonna do that real quick.

82
00:04:23.270 --> 00:04:26.180
Here on NYWAN1 I wanna know,
I'm gonna do a show run for

83
00:04:26.180 --> 00:04:31.430
the BGPsection, and
it's nice and small, right?

84
00:04:31.430 --> 00:04:32.750
I've got a router BGP 65543.

85
00:04:32.750 --> 00:04:34.610
That's my autonomous system number.

86
00:04:34.610 --> 00:04:36.780
We've got BGP log neighbor changes.

87
00:04:36.780 --> 00:04:37.770
That's a default command.

88
00:04:37.770 --> 00:04:39.220
I can ignore it.

89
00:04:39.220 --> 00:04:45.422
And then I've got neighbor
192.168.16.2 remote-as 65534.

90
00:04:45.422 --> 00:04:48.786
That as number matches mine,
so I know it's IBGP.

91
00:04:48.786 --> 00:04:51.936
And 192.168.16.2

92
00:04:51.936 --> 00:04:56.610
is the IP address I wrote down earlier
of EDGE2, so I know that that's right.

93
00:04:56.610 --> 00:04:57.890
And that's configured.

94
00:04:57.890 --> 00:05:01.890
Okay, now there's no source added to this.

95
00:05:01.890 --> 00:05:06.460
When I configure BGP, I almost always do a
neighbor 192.168.16.2 update dash source.

96
00:05:06.460 --> 00:05:12.200
And specify the IP address or interface
I want to use in my update source.

97
00:05:12.200 --> 00:05:15.260
Because sometimes we might use
loop backs or other things.

98
00:05:15.260 --> 00:05:17.000
and in this scenario they haven't done it.

99
00:05:17.000 --> 00:05:20.410
So, it's going to use whatever
interface is closest to that network.

100
00:05:20.410 --> 00:05:23.490
If we want to find out
what that interface is,

101
00:05:23.490 --> 00:05:28.160
you can just do a show IP route For
that network.

102
00:05:28.160 --> 00:05:32.280
And well, that's going to be
a little bit of a problem there.

103
00:05:32.280 --> 00:05:35.080
Apparently I don't have a route for
that network.

104
00:05:35.080 --> 00:05:36.750
This is one of the problems with BGP,

105
00:05:36.750 --> 00:05:39.920
is that we don't necessarily
learn those networks.

106
00:05:39.920 --> 00:05:41.360
Show ip bgp.

107
00:05:41.360 --> 00:05:44.990
I'll see the BGP database,
and my database is empty.

108
00:05:44.990 --> 00:05:47.130
I don't have anything, right?

109
00:05:47.130 --> 00:05:50.140
And I didn't have any network
statements up here in BGP, so

110
00:05:50.140 --> 00:05:51.820
I'm not advertizing any networks.

111
00:05:51.820 --> 00:05:55.620
This is like just the bare minimum,

112
00:05:55.620 --> 00:05:58.250
least amount of work you
could do type configuration.

113
00:05:58.250 --> 00:06:00.700
Let me just make sure there's
no commands being excluded.

114
00:06:00.700 --> 00:06:06.350
I'm gonna do a,
begin with BGP instead of a section BGP.

115
00:06:06.350 --> 00:06:08.470
And nope, no hidden commands.

116
00:06:08.470 --> 00:06:10.090
There's just not much set up here.

117
00:06:10.090 --> 00:06:10.860
Right?

118
00:06:10.860 --> 00:06:13.050
And if I can't get to that destination,

119
00:06:13.050 --> 00:06:14.960
then I'm going to have my own
little problems right there.

120
00:06:14.960 --> 00:06:15.880
And that's more than likely.

121
00:06:15.880 --> 00:06:17.610
We're just dealing with reachability.

122
00:06:17.610 --> 00:06:19.240
If I do a show IP route,

123
00:06:19.240 --> 00:06:24.310
my routing table only has one directly
connected route, and that's it.

124
00:06:24.310 --> 00:06:27.624
And so if I try and ping 198.168.16.2,

125
00:06:27.624 --> 00:06:30.790
which is NYEDGE2 I'm
not going to get there.

126
00:06:30.790 --> 00:06:33.755
Cuz it's not on my routing table, and
I don't have a gateway of last resort.

127
00:06:33.755 --> 00:06:35.770
If I can't even ping the host.

128
00:06:35.770 --> 00:06:38.760
There's no way I'm going to build
up a BGP relationship, right.

129
00:06:38.760 --> 00:06:41.980
So, there's going to be at
least once side of our problem.

130
00:06:41.980 --> 00:06:44.210
We can have these same problems
over on the other side.

131
00:06:44.210 --> 00:06:47.050
I don't know, but at a minimum we're
going to have to fix this guy, all right.

132
00:06:47.050 --> 00:06:49.990
Let's go take a look at the other side,
and just see how bad a mess it is.

133
00:06:49.990 --> 00:06:51.630
So, I'm going to jump over to NYEDGE2.

134
00:06:51.630 --> 00:06:53.090
So again, looking at the topology.

135
00:06:53.090 --> 00:06:58.090
I'm jumping from this router over here,
all the way up to the top right, up to

136
00:06:58.090 --> 00:07:03.050
NYEDGE2, this guy so that I can jump in
there and find out what it's looking like.

137
00:07:03.050 --> 00:07:06.820
And so on this one,
I'm gonna do a show run,

138
00:07:06.820 --> 00:07:10.220
and I'll pull up the BgP section and
this one's a little better route.

139
00:07:10.220 --> 00:07:11.810
I got a couple external neighbors.

140
00:07:11.810 --> 00:07:15.430
My autonomous system number is 65534.

141
00:07:15.430 --> 00:07:21.991
And I've got a neighbor
statement from 192.168.15.1.

142
00:07:21.991 --> 00:07:23.187
That's NYLAN1.

143
00:07:23.187 --> 00:07:28.480
And its remote-as is 65534, so I do have
a proper neighbor statement in there.

144
00:07:28.480 --> 00:07:34.460
I don't have a update-source defined, so
it's just gonna use the closest interface

145
00:07:34.460 --> 00:07:37.790
to that guy, which I don't really know,
so again, I can do a show ip route.

146
00:07:39.110 --> 00:07:43.670
For 192.168.15.1, and
I do have a route for

147
00:07:43.670 --> 00:07:45.090
that network so I know how to get there.

148
00:07:45.090 --> 00:07:47.150
I'm learning an ospf, and

149
00:07:47.150 --> 00:07:52.670
if I look at it says that I can
get there on my Gi0/0 interface.

150
00:07:52.670 --> 00:08:00.127
And so if I do a show ip interface brief
my Gi0/0 well, that was 192.168.16.2.

151
00:08:00.127 --> 00:08:01.630
That's important,

152
00:08:01.630 --> 00:08:07.190
because I need that number to match the
neighbor number defined on the other side.

153
00:08:07.190 --> 00:08:10.240
The neighbor on the other
side was set to 192.168.16.2.

154
00:08:10.240 --> 00:08:13.390
If I was reaching out to it with this IP,
they wouldn't match, and

155
00:08:13.390 --> 00:08:14.620
I wouldn't get an adjacency, right.

156
00:08:14.620 --> 00:08:16.710
So, I've gotta check that out, all right.

157
00:08:16.710 --> 00:08:19.500
But honestly this side seems
to be in really good shape.

158
00:08:19.500 --> 00:08:23.000
We've got our neighbor statement,
we don't have any networks to find,

159
00:08:23.000 --> 00:08:23.870
which is a little odd.

160
00:08:23.870 --> 00:08:26.716
You know seems like you'd want
at least one network in there.

161
00:08:26.716 --> 00:08:29.380
But there's nothing,
there's no redistribute commands, so

162
00:08:29.380 --> 00:08:33.408
I am running iBGP but
im not actually advertising any networks.

163
00:08:33.408 --> 00:08:37.160
Now, that's okay I might be learning from
somebody else and pushing them along.

164
00:08:37.160 --> 00:08:39.070
And do a quick show iBGP.

165
00:08:40.130 --> 00:08:43.630
And see if we are getting anything, and it
looks like I am getting a default gateway.

166
00:08:43.630 --> 00:08:48.015
So, I'm learning a default gateway
via BGP, and it's got a next hop of

167
00:08:48.015 --> 00:08:52.490
172.14.0.4, which I know how to get to cuz
I'm directly connected to that network.

168
00:08:52.490 --> 00:08:53.610
And did we see that?

169
00:08:53.610 --> 00:08:56.780
If I do a show IP route do I,
let's see if it actually made it.

170
00:08:56.780 --> 00:08:59.650
Oh it did it made it into
the routing table there it is.

171
00:08:59.650 --> 00:09:04.390
But I already had a 196.168.15 round, to
get to the other system, learn via ospf.

172
00:09:04.390 --> 00:09:08.870
And that's that interior
rounding protocol again, right?

173
00:09:08.870 --> 00:09:11.410
BGP really expect to have that, or

174
00:09:11.410 --> 00:09:14.770
it expects to have a full mesh typology
where all the routers are connected.

175
00:09:14.770 --> 00:09:16.390
And in mine I don't have a full mesh.

176
00:09:16.390 --> 00:09:19.990
NYWAN1 is not directly
plugged into NYEDGE2.

177
00:09:19.990 --> 00:09:24.260
So, it's not a full mesh, and so
iBGP breaks, and the way to fix that,

178
00:09:24.260 --> 00:09:31.700
the easiest way to fix that is, well,
to bring NYWAN1 into my OSPF area, right?

179
00:09:31.700 --> 00:09:35.080
I've got OSPF area zero spread
across these guys right here, but

180
00:09:35.080 --> 00:09:36.520
it doesn't extend to NYWAN1.

181
00:09:36.520 --> 00:09:39.410
If I have control of that router, then

182
00:09:39.410 --> 00:09:44.010
the best thing to do is to stretch OSPF
area zero to encompass this router too.

183
00:09:44.010 --> 00:09:44.850
Right?

184
00:09:44.850 --> 00:09:47.010
But if I don't have
control of this router,

185
00:09:47.010 --> 00:09:48.870
I might not wanna do
a dynamic routing protocol.

186
00:09:48.870 --> 00:09:50.090
I might wanna do a static route.

187
00:09:50.090 --> 00:09:53.000
And we can have a static route put it
in here by whoever managed that device.

188
00:09:53.000 --> 00:09:54.530
Right?
But in this case we do manage it.

189
00:09:54.530 --> 00:09:59.830
So let's just extend out OSPF, and then
NYWAN1 will know how to get to NYEDGE2,

190
00:09:59.830 --> 00:10:01.740
and that should fix our BGP issue.

191
00:10:01.740 --> 00:10:08.070
All right, so NYWAN1 has a layer
three link running down to NYCORE1.

192
00:10:08.070 --> 00:10:09.610
And on NYCORE1 it's port two.

193
00:10:09.610 --> 00:10:12.948
So, let's look at NYCORE1 and
see if that's set up for ospf or not.

194
00:10:12.948 --> 00:10:20.020
So, on NYCORE1, I'm just gonna look
at the ospf configuration here.

195
00:10:22.550 --> 00:10:27.520
So I'll pull up the OSPF section and
it looks like we've got FA1/0/2 is

196
00:10:27.520 --> 00:10:32.475
passive and that's actually
the interface that I care about.

197
00:10:32.475 --> 00:10:36.980
And then 192.168.15 and
192.168.16 are both being advertised.

198
00:10:38.320 --> 00:10:42.950
Okay, so I'm going to need to kill
that passive interface command.

199
00:10:42.950 --> 00:10:46.650
Because I want to build
an adjacency over that link now.

200
00:10:46.650 --> 00:10:48.980
So, I'm gonna get into router ospf 100.

201
00:10:48.980 --> 00:10:52.820
And I'll do a no passive-
interface fa1/0/2.

202
00:10:52.820 --> 00:10:58.790
So now if I just verify
that configuration.

203
00:11:00.060 --> 00:11:03.012
NYCORE1 is advertising for
both of those networks, right?

204
00:11:03.012 --> 00:11:05.470
192.168.15, and 192.168.16.

205
00:11:05.470 --> 00:11:07.620
So that's good.

206
00:11:07.620 --> 00:11:11.480
Now I can jump up to NYWAN1, and
I can get it set up for OSPF.

207
00:11:13.270 --> 00:11:14.690
So I'm going to jump in here.

208
00:11:14.690 --> 00:11:19.260
And looking at my interfaces,
I really just need to get it up and

209
00:11:19.260 --> 00:11:20.600
going for GI00, right?

210
00:11:21.640 --> 00:11:22.630
So that it'll be able to learn.

211
00:11:22.630 --> 00:11:24.520
Actually, all my other
interfaces are shut down, so

212
00:11:24.520 --> 00:11:26.550
I guess it doesn't really
matter which ones I turn on.

213
00:11:26.550 --> 00:11:28.230
But I'll go ahead and be specific.

214
00:11:28.230 --> 00:11:31.600
I'm gonna say router ospf and
then whatever process number I want.

215
00:11:31.600 --> 00:11:36.190
I like to use 100, it's what I always
learned, so I'll punch that in.

216
00:11:36.190 --> 00:11:38.710
I can advertise a network, and so

217
00:11:38.710 --> 00:11:44.930
I'll put 192.168.15.0 with
a 0.0.0.255 wildcard mask.

218
00:11:44.930 --> 00:11:51.810
And then I'm gonna put that in area zero,
right.

219
00:11:51.810 --> 00:11:55.640
My entire OSPF environment is in area
zero, so I'll just bring that in and

220
00:11:55.640 --> 00:11:57.300
I see an adjacency come up.

221
00:11:57.300 --> 00:11:59.726
And when that adjacency comes up,
I should start learning.

222
00:11:59.726 --> 00:12:04.940
The 192.168.16 network that wasn't in
my routing table a few moments ago.

223
00:12:04.940 --> 00:12:10.420
So, if I scroll back to where I did a,
let's see, where did I do that?

224
00:12:10.420 --> 00:12:15.840
Where I did a show ip route and
I got that it wasn't in the routing table.

225
00:12:15.840 --> 00:12:17.742
I know I ran the command,
it's back here somewhere.

226
00:12:17.742 --> 00:12:21.210
So [LAUGH] I know I ran that command, and
it didn't turn up in the routing table.

227
00:12:21.210 --> 00:12:26.000
So, anyhow, we'll just verify
that it should show up now.

228
00:12:26.000 --> 00:12:32.280
If I do a show ip router it should
have some osp routes coming in.

229
00:12:32.280 --> 00:12:33.140
And I do.

230
00:12:33.140 --> 00:12:37.440
And I know 192.168.15,
cuz I'm plugged into it.

231
00:12:37.440 --> 00:12:38.750
Now I know 192.168.16 also.

232
00:12:38.750 --> 00:12:43.860
And so, if I try and ping 192.168.16.2,
which is NYEDGE2 now I can get there.

233
00:12:43.860 --> 00:12:48.060
And since I'm getting there,
I imagine BGP is gonna come up.

234
00:12:48.060 --> 00:12:54.545
And so if I do an ip bgp summary,
I have a neighbor,

235
00:12:54.545 --> 00:13:00.680
192.168.16.2, and as I look across here,
MsgSent and MsgRcvd, 5 and 4.

236
00:13:00.680 --> 00:13:03.580
And I've even got some prefixes
that are exchanging, right?

237
00:13:03.580 --> 00:13:05.050
Or at least one.

238
00:13:05.050 --> 00:13:09.840
And so, if I do a show ip bgp, we'll see
if we get that default gateway coming in.

239
00:13:09.840 --> 00:13:10.440
There it is.

240
00:13:10.440 --> 00:13:12.820
I've got the default gateway coming in.

241
00:13:12.820 --> 00:13:16.790
And it's got a little lowercase i,
letting me know that I got it.

242
00:13:16.790 --> 00:13:19.920
With and IGP is where it came from, so
it much be redistributed on the the end,

243
00:13:19.920 --> 00:13:20.790
and its got a star.

244
00:13:20.790 --> 00:13:23.610
Now it doesnt have a greater
than symbol by it.

245
00:13:23.610 --> 00:13:28.280
Its not showing as being the best,
and if I do show IP route and

246
00:13:28.280 --> 00:13:30.018
look at my routing table.

247
00:13:30.018 --> 00:13:32.420
And its okay in this case,

248
00:13:32.420 --> 00:13:35.080
i mean if I want that to
function I'm going to need it.

249
00:13:35.080 --> 00:13:38.480
But we got some next hop issue more
than likely is our problem there, so

250
00:13:38.480 --> 00:13:39.680
it's not making it in.

251
00:13:39.680 --> 00:13:42.400
This is one of those cases where you have
to decide how far we want to troubleshoot

252
00:13:42.400 --> 00:13:43.600
this, right?

253
00:13:43.600 --> 00:13:47.910
The question if we go back and
revisit it it says.

254
00:13:47.910 --> 00:13:51.100
NYWAN1 and
NWEDGE2 are configured for IBGP, but

255
00:13:51.100 --> 00:13:53.870
they are not establishing a connection.

256
00:13:53.870 --> 00:13:54.500
So, we've done that.

257
00:13:54.500 --> 00:13:56.830
Now, we've established a connection,
right.

258
00:13:56.830 --> 00:13:58.860
It doesn't say anything about whether or
not we're learning routes.

259
00:13:58.860 --> 00:14:00.760
So technically we solved the problem.

260
00:14:00.760 --> 00:14:04.140
But if you want to be really thorough, my
default gateway is not making it in, and

261
00:14:04.140 --> 00:14:10.470
if I go back to that show IP BGP and look
at the database, it's not making it in.

262
00:14:10.470 --> 00:14:15.120
It's showing that I got it from in an IBGP
somewhere, it originated from IBGP, and it

263
00:14:15.120 --> 00:14:18.310
doesn't have the greater than symbol right
there so I know it's not being installed.

264
00:14:18.310 --> 00:14:22.790
If I look at that next hop,
It's 172.14.0.4.

265
00:14:22.790 --> 00:14:30.020
If I look at my own routing table,
I don't have a route for 172.14.0.4.

266
00:14:30.020 --> 00:14:33.170
If I don't have a route
to get to the gateway for

267
00:14:33.170 --> 00:14:34.810
that network, then I'm not gonna use it.

268
00:14:34.810 --> 00:14:38.440
And that's gonna result in it not
making it to the routing table, so,

269
00:14:38.440 --> 00:14:39.850
I have a little bit more work to do.

270
00:14:39.850 --> 00:14:42.660
This actually wouldn't be that hard
to fix, if we wanted to fix it,

271
00:14:42.660 --> 00:14:43.710
and I'm gonna hold off,

272
00:14:43.710 --> 00:14:46.870
cuz it might turn off in one of the other
questions in this set, I don't know.

273
00:14:46.870 --> 00:14:52.040
But to fix it,
all you would have to do is go to NYEDGE2,

274
00:14:52.040 --> 00:14:56.860
which is plugged into that 172.14 network,
and just tell it to advertise that, right?

275
00:14:56.860 --> 00:14:58.600
Advertise that in the network.

276
00:14:58.600 --> 00:15:00.890
Or, [INAUDIBLE] like OSPF.

277
00:15:00.890 --> 00:15:04.580
Or, in BGP, make sure that it
uses a next hop self command.

278
00:15:04.580 --> 00:15:07.080
And I know we saw that in
another troubleshooting ticket.

279
00:15:07.080 --> 00:15:10.070
And that way,
when NYWAN1 learns that default gateway,

280
00:15:10.070 --> 00:15:12.620
it will learn NYEDGE2 is the next hop.

281
00:15:12.620 --> 00:15:14.610
Instead of some public address out there.

282
00:15:14.610 --> 00:15:16.730
So, either of those solutions
would fix that problem.

283
00:15:16.730 --> 00:15:19.380
but it goes a little bit beyond
what the ticket is asking for.

284
00:15:19.380 --> 00:15:20.780
As far as the ticket though,

285
00:15:20.780 --> 00:15:24.400
this one turned out to boil down
to just not having a route, right?

286
00:15:24.400 --> 00:15:27.050
NYWAN1 did not have
a route to get to NYEDGE2.

287
00:15:27.050 --> 00:15:30.030
Can't build a neighbor
relationship like that.

288
00:15:30.030 --> 00:15:32.690
We fixed it by extending
OSPF out to the node.

289
00:15:32.690 --> 00:15:34.060
Now, it knows how to get there.

290
00:15:34.060 --> 00:15:36.330
Neighbor relationship comes up and
now we're exchanging routes.

291
00:15:36.330 --> 00:15:38.172
Things are working the way
they're supposed to.

292
00:15:38.172 --> 00:15:40.280
All right, so that wraps up
this troubleshooting question.

293
00:15:40.280 --> 00:15:43.878
Stay tuned we got more
coming up after this.

294
00:15:43.878 --> 00:15:50.249
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #4` from set #8. The trouble ticket states that "NYCORE2 and NYEDGE2 are configured for iBGP but they are not establishing a connection "
episodes.title: Set 8 Issue 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:06.032
[SOUND] All right, welcome back to another

2
00:00:06.032 --> 00:00:12.734
troubleshooting adventure here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.734 --> 00:00:15.605
We've got Set 8 Issue 4 coming at us,
and for

4
00:00:15.605 --> 00:00:18.630
this one It's more BGP
neighbor problems here.

5
00:00:18.630 --> 00:00:22.480
Looks like NYCORE2 and
NYEDGE2 are configured for

6
00:00:22.480 --> 00:00:25.350
iBGP, but
there are not establishing a connection.

7
00:00:25.350 --> 00:00:29.330
So just like in our last issue, we've
got two systems that are not peering up.

8
00:00:29.330 --> 00:00:31.950
And NYEDGE2 we saw was in our last one,

9
00:00:31.950 --> 00:00:34.320
so I've actually still got
the IP address from it,

10
00:00:34.320 --> 00:00:36.990
because you remember reachability was
what turned out to be the problem there.

11
00:00:36.990 --> 00:00:38.310
Maybe it is here too.

12
00:00:38.310 --> 00:00:42.750
Well, let's look at our topology and
get an idea of what we're talking about.

13
00:00:42.750 --> 00:00:45.810
So this was NYCORE2 and NYEDGE2.

14
00:00:45.810 --> 00:00:49.060
Now these two guys are directly
connected to each other,

15
00:00:49.060 --> 00:00:50.840
I've got a point to point link.

16
00:00:50.840 --> 00:00:55.680
So for these two not to be peering
up is pretty unlikely, right?

17
00:00:55.680 --> 00:00:58.270
I had reachability issues before
because it was a huge network.

18
00:00:58.270 --> 00:01:00.020
I was being routed in between it.

19
00:01:00.020 --> 00:01:02.810
But, this is point to point
between EDGE 2 and CORE 2.

20
00:01:02.810 --> 00:01:05.180
Well, it doesn't have to
be point to point though.

21
00:01:05.180 --> 00:01:08.210
For example,
when you define a neighbor relationship,

22
00:01:08.210 --> 00:01:10.960
you can peer with a loopback address.

23
00:01:10.960 --> 00:01:12.760
And when you peer with a loopback address,

24
00:01:12.760 --> 00:01:15.860
it's actually like you got
more than one hop, right?

25
00:01:15.860 --> 00:01:19.150
And with eBGP,
we have that whole ebgp-multihop command.

26
00:01:19.150 --> 00:01:20.870
But with IBGP that's okay.

27
00:01:20.870 --> 00:01:22.160
You can be more than one hop.

28
00:01:22.160 --> 00:01:23.360
It's all right.

29
00:01:23.360 --> 00:01:24.890
But we just need to be on the lookout for
that.

30
00:01:24.890 --> 00:01:26.300
And then other issues that can arise.

31
00:01:26.300 --> 00:01:29.300
I don't really know how these appeared so
we'll have to find out.

32
00:01:29.300 --> 00:01:31.030
Let's start up here on EDGE2.

33
00:01:31.030 --> 00:01:34.250
And actually I really just
need to know what their IP

34
00:01:34.250 --> 00:01:36.150
addresses are first before
I even get too far.

35
00:01:36.150 --> 00:01:38.328
Cuz that's BGP is all keying off of.

36
00:01:38.328 --> 00:01:43.232
And I know from the last question that

37
00:01:43.232 --> 00:01:48.936
NYEDGE2 is 192.168.16.2.

38
00:01:48.936 --> 00:01:50.708
And I'm just writing this down again so
I've got it.

39
00:01:50.708 --> 00:01:52.870
So that was EDGE2.

40
00:01:52.870 --> 00:01:57.680
But CORE2, I don't know what it's IP
address is, so I'm actually gonna start

41
00:01:57.680 --> 00:02:01.830
over on CORE2, since it's the one that's
got information that I don't know.

42
00:02:01.830 --> 00:02:02.880
So over here on CORE2.

43
00:02:03.890 --> 00:02:08.720
We'll just start with a show ip int br,

44
00:02:10.410 --> 00:02:12.730
and I'll exclude any
unassigned interfaces.

45
00:02:12.730 --> 00:02:16.170
So this one is 192.168.16.6.

46
00:02:16.170 --> 00:02:19.970
So, if you'll remember on the last issue,
I said,

47
00:02:19.970 --> 00:02:22.540
boy, I really hope these
guys are on the same subnet.

48
00:02:22.540 --> 00:02:24.230
In this case my wish has come true, right.

49
00:02:24.230 --> 00:02:26.244
These guys are on the same subnet, and so

50
00:02:26.244 --> 00:02:29.868
if I wanna test connectivity,
this should be pretty straightforward.

51
00:02:29.868 --> 00:02:33.793
If NYCORE2 is 192.168.16.6 and

52
00:02:33.793 --> 00:02:40.138
NYEDGE2 is 192.168.16.2,
I should be able to ping and I am.

53
00:02:40.138 --> 00:02:41.959
So I've got good communications back and

54
00:02:41.959 --> 00:02:45.110
forth between these two systems
as far as base connectivity.

55
00:02:45.110 --> 00:02:48.460
Well, if I'm not building
a neighbor relationship, why not?

56
00:02:48.460 --> 00:02:52.080
Well, now is where we
come to misconfiguration.

57
00:02:52.080 --> 00:02:54.820
Even beside from that,
we could have an acl, right?

58
00:02:54.820 --> 00:02:58.070
When you look at this topology,
yes, it's a point to point link.

59
00:02:58.070 --> 00:02:59.730
But it is a link, none the less.

60
00:02:59.730 --> 00:03:01.950
And there could be an access control list.

61
00:03:01.950 --> 00:03:05.760
This is a switch and so
this is a VLAN interface down here.

62
00:03:05.760 --> 00:03:09.820
So we're probably not being routed so
I doubt it's a regular ACL but

63
00:03:09.820 --> 00:03:13.060
we could have a VLAN ACL in
place that's blocking this.

64
00:03:13.060 --> 00:03:17.165
Or we could just have a bad BGP
configuration between them.

65
00:03:17.165 --> 00:03:21.590
So let's review the BGP configuration,
that's probably our easiest solution here.

66
00:03:23.120 --> 00:03:25.660
And so if I take NYCORE2 I can do

67
00:03:25.660 --> 00:03:30.880
a showIP BGP summary just to see
what neighbors I have out there.

68
00:03:30.880 --> 00:03:35.021
And I've got a neighbor 192.168.16.20,
but I'm looking for

69
00:03:35.021 --> 00:03:38.598
a neighbor 192.168.16.2 and
that is not in the list.

70
00:03:38.598 --> 00:03:41.931
So I'm not building a neighbor
relationship with the other guy,

71
00:03:41.931 --> 00:03:43.148
kind of expected that.

72
00:03:43.148 --> 00:03:47.711
And if I do a show run for the BGP
section, I can see that I've got again,

73
00:03:47.711 --> 00:03:53.571
I've got that neighbor, .20, but
I don't have 192.68.16.2 on the list,

74
00:03:53.571 --> 00:03:58.400
so I'm missing it and that's more
than likely gonna be our problem.

75
00:03:58.400 --> 00:04:03.140
Kinda hard to peer with somebody if you
don't have a neighbor command for them.

76
00:04:03.140 --> 00:04:06.960
Right so let's see if the other side
is still configured properly for

77
00:04:06.960 --> 00:04:07.920
the other direction.

78
00:04:07.920 --> 00:04:13.310
I'm gonna jump up to NYEDGE2 and
just kinda do that same thing right.

79
00:04:13.310 --> 00:04:17.339
I'm gonna do a show run section bgp.

80
00:04:17.339 --> 00:04:22.020
And NYCORE2 the person we're supposed to

81
00:04:22.020 --> 00:04:25.960
peer with is 192.168.16.6 and I can see
that neighbor statement right there.

82
00:04:25.960 --> 00:04:27.450
So we've got a neighbor
statement on one end,

83
00:04:27.450 --> 00:04:29.940
we're missing the neighbor
statement on the other end,

84
00:04:29.940 --> 00:04:33.910
that's at least part of our problem,
if not the whole problem in and of itself.

85
00:04:33.910 --> 00:04:35.930
So let's jump back over to NYCORE2,

86
00:04:35.930 --> 00:04:39.930
and I'm gonna add a neighbor
statement to fix this.

87
00:04:39.930 --> 00:04:41.190
In fact you know,

88
00:04:41.190 --> 00:04:44.340
I'd have to look at all the other devices,
this might just be a typo.

89
00:04:44.340 --> 00:04:47.420
Like maybe this isn't supposed

90
00:04:47.420 --> 00:04:52.240
to be 192.168.16.20 maybe that was
supposed to be 192.168.16.2, I don't know.

91
00:04:52.240 --> 00:04:55.330
And the reality is on the exam
you're kind of pressed for time.

92
00:04:55.330 --> 00:04:58.420
So I don't want to go hop around all
these different devices to see if .20

93
00:04:58.420 --> 00:04:59.440
exists somewhere else.

94
00:04:59.440 --> 00:05:02.128
So it's going to be easier to just
add another neighbor statement.

95
00:05:02.128 --> 00:05:06.071
So I'm going to get into configuration and

96
00:05:06.071 --> 00:05:11.219
I'll do router BGP65534,
and then I'll just say

97
00:05:11.219 --> 00:05:17.366
neighbor 192.168.16.2
remote dash A S 65534.

98
00:05:17.366 --> 00:05:21.129
You have to get that A S member right
that's how it knows it's going to be

99
00:05:21.129 --> 00:05:22.150
I B G P and not E B G P.

100
00:05:22.150 --> 00:05:26.900
And once we run that It should reach
out and BGP peers really fast.

101
00:05:26.900 --> 00:05:30.180
So if I do a show IP BGP summary.

102
00:05:30.180 --> 00:05:30.680
Whoops.

103
00:05:33.170 --> 00:05:34.680
There we go.

104
00:05:34.680 --> 00:05:35.500
I see it.

105
00:05:35.500 --> 00:05:38.340
I've got a neighbor
relationship with 192.168.16.2.

106
00:05:38.340 --> 00:05:41.270
And as I look across the way
I've sent four messages.

107
00:05:41.270 --> 00:05:43.020
I've received four messages.

108
00:05:43.020 --> 00:05:47.120
And I've even exchanged a prefix at
this point so we are communicating,

109
00:05:47.120 --> 00:05:50.770
and now that I look at that other line,
look at this guy down here.

110
00:05:50.770 --> 00:05:53.160
Zero messages sent,
zero messages received,

111
00:05:53.160 --> 00:05:56.340
zero prefixes, up down state never.

112
00:05:56.340 --> 00:05:59.480
This one never come up,
I'm pretty sure this is a typo, right.

113
00:05:59.480 --> 00:06:02.700
So if that was a typo,
then we just fixed it but

114
00:06:02.700 --> 00:06:05.210
we could go back and
remove this other neighbor statement and

115
00:06:05.210 --> 00:06:08.310
get it out of there If it's not
communicating with anybody right?

116
00:06:08.310 --> 00:06:12.080
So somebody just entered a .20
instead of a .2 but in this case,

117
00:06:12.080 --> 00:06:14.310
it's just a bad neighbor statement, right?

118
00:06:14.310 --> 00:06:16.340
When you're dealing with
BGP period problems and

119
00:06:16.340 --> 00:06:19.090
there on the same subnet,
that's when you go whoo,

120
00:06:19.090 --> 00:06:22.209
this is gonna be an easy on cuz there's
juts not a whole heck of a lot involved.

121
00:06:23.270 --> 00:06:24.440
I'm exchanging prefixes.

122
00:06:24.440 --> 00:06:28.700
If I do a show IP BGP I should have
at least one in there and I do,

123
00:06:28.700 --> 00:06:32.310
so I've learned the route and
BGP is up and running.

124
00:06:32.310 --> 00:06:33.580
All right,
well that turned out to be an easy one.

125
00:06:33.580 --> 00:06:37.000
We'll knock that one off our list and
we've got one more troubleshooting

126
00:06:37.000 --> 00:06:40.320
question coming up here in set
number eight, so stay tuned.

127
00:06:40.320 --> 00:06:41.468
It's coming up next.

128
00:06:41.468 --> 00:06:48.209
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #5` from set #8. The trouble ticket states that "NYCORE1 and NYEDGE2 are configured for iBGP but they are also not establishing a relationship "
episodes.title: Set 8 Issue 5
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.469
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.469 --> 00:00:12.250
All right, welcome back to another
Cisco Troubleshooting segment here on

3
00:00:12.250 --> 00:00:12.797
I T Pro TV.

4
00:00:12.797 --> 00:00:16.262
We are jumping into Set 8 Issue 5,
the final issue for this set,

5
00:00:16.262 --> 00:00:20.120
this is one of the shorter ones and
we've got, yet another BGP problem.

6
00:00:20.120 --> 00:00:23.230
Whoever set up BGP in this network,
they're probably out of a job.

7
00:00:23.230 --> 00:00:24.970
So issue 5 reads like this.

8
00:00:24.970 --> 00:00:29.920
It says, NYCORE1 and
NYEDGE2 are configured for IBGP.

9
00:00:29.920 --> 00:00:32.890
But they are not establishing
a neighbor relationship.

10
00:00:32.890 --> 00:00:35.360
So we got another neighbor problem.

11
00:00:35.360 --> 00:00:37.600
Let's take a look at our map and
see what we're dealing with.

12
00:00:37.600 --> 00:00:42.120
So here at the topology what
they are calling out is NYCORE1,

13
00:00:42.120 --> 00:00:47.540
this guy right here, this switch and
NYEDGE2, this guy up here.

14
00:00:47.540 --> 00:00:49.700
So these two are suppose to be
building a neighbor relationship.

15
00:00:49.700 --> 00:00:53.500
Now there is a switch in-between them, I
don't know if they're being routed or not,

16
00:00:53.500 --> 00:00:56.580
and then you guys know from the previous
questions, I love it when they're not

17
00:00:56.580 --> 00:00:59.020
being routed because that means
it's going to be an easy question.

18
00:00:59.020 --> 00:01:01.740
If they are being routed than we've got
a couple of things we have to deal with,

19
00:01:01.740 --> 00:01:05.880
but in this scenario NYCORE1,
NYEDGE2 they're not peering up.

20
00:01:05.880 --> 00:01:10.270
Now I know from the previous questions
that NYEDGE2 is 192.168.16.2,

21
00:01:10.270 --> 00:01:14.140
we've seen that a few times.

22
00:01:14.140 --> 00:01:17.880
But CORE1, I don't know it's IP address.

23
00:01:17.880 --> 00:01:19.200
We haven't dealt with it yet.

24
00:01:19.200 --> 00:01:21.130
So I'm gonna jump over to Core1 and

25
00:01:21.130 --> 00:01:25.400
we'll kind of start there,
because it's got information that I need.

26
00:01:25.400 --> 00:01:30.040
So I'm gonna get logged into this one and
do a quick show IP interface brief and

27
00:01:30.040 --> 00:01:32.980
I'll just exclude any
unassigned interfaces.

28
00:01:32.980 --> 00:01:33.818
There we go.

29
00:01:33.818 --> 00:01:36.263
All right, it looks like I've
got two interfaces on this one.

30
00:01:36.263 --> 00:01:42.510
I've got 192.168.16.5 and 192.168.15.2.

31
00:01:42.510 --> 00:01:44.590
I'm going to assume.

32
00:01:44.590 --> 00:01:49.347
And you know what happens when you assume,
that it's 192.168.16.5 that we're

33
00:01:49.347 --> 00:01:53.060
gonna be using to appear with
the other guy 192.168.16.6.

34
00:01:53.060 --> 00:01:57.330
They're on the same network, so again
this looks like it might be an easy one.

35
00:01:57.330 --> 00:01:58.300
They're on the same subnet.

36
00:01:58.300 --> 00:01:59.970
They don't have to get routed.

37
00:01:59.970 --> 00:02:01.810
The main thing I need to
check is connectivity.

38
00:02:01.810 --> 00:02:03.880
If I can't connect to the other guy,

39
00:02:03.880 --> 00:02:06.740
then I'm definitely not going to
build a peer relationship with him.

40
00:02:06.740 --> 00:02:09.950
So I'm going to try and ping 192.168.16.2,
and I can ping it, all right,

41
00:02:09.950 --> 00:02:15.070
so I've got connectivity between NYCORE1.

42
00:02:16.110 --> 00:02:16.957
Right here.

43
00:02:16.957 --> 00:02:19.711
And NYEDGE2 up here.

44
00:02:19.711 --> 00:02:23.200
And they're on the same subnet, so they're
just passing right through this switch.

45
00:02:23.200 --> 00:02:24.920
NYCORE2 is not routing us.

46
00:02:24.920 --> 00:02:26.630
And so we're just talking directly.

47
00:02:26.630 --> 00:02:29.500
So I don't have to worry about
crazy things like extra hops.

48
00:02:29.500 --> 00:02:33.910
I don't have to worry about not knowing
the next hop or anything crazy like that.

49
00:02:33.910 --> 00:02:36.000
This should be a straightforward
neighbor statement.

50
00:02:36.000 --> 00:02:40.300
And if that's the case,
then I should just be able config compare.

51
00:02:40.300 --> 00:02:42.210
Spot the difference and fix it.

52
00:02:42.210 --> 00:02:44.300
There's a few weird things
that could pop up but

53
00:02:44.300 --> 00:02:46.200
I'll bet this one just
boils down to config.

54
00:02:46.200 --> 00:02:49.730
So since I'm already on core one,
let's start here.

55
00:02:49.730 --> 00:02:52.950
And I'll just do a show run and
I'll pull the BGP section.

56
00:02:52.950 --> 00:02:57.370
And what I'm looking for are the neighbor
statements that point to EDGE2,

57
00:02:57.370 --> 00:02:59.050
which is gonna be this guy right here.

58
00:02:59.050 --> 00:03:05.010
Neighbor 192.168.16.2 and,
I think we see the problem right there.

59
00:03:05.010 --> 00:03:09.020
Looking a little closer at this,
remember that it's iBGP.

60
00:03:09.020 --> 00:03:11.150
Interior Border Gateway Protocol.

61
00:03:11.150 --> 00:03:16.430
When you do iBGP you're peering with
people in the same AS number as you.

62
00:03:16.430 --> 00:03:20.287
While I'm in AS number 6 5 5 3 4.

63
00:03:20.287 --> 00:03:27.557
But this statement says neighbor
192.168.16.2 remote-as 65535.

64
00:03:27.557 --> 00:03:32.778
All right, that's different and
that means this is eBGP not iBGP.

65
00:03:32.778 --> 00:03:35.890
Well, unless it's like
a confederation define,

66
00:03:35.890 --> 00:03:38.525
which we don't see a confederation here so
that's not a problem.

67
00:03:38.525 --> 00:03:43.170
So in this case, these two don't match,
that's probably the issue,

68
00:03:43.170 --> 00:03:47.720
now it is possible that the local AS is
being overwritten on the other side so

69
00:03:47.720 --> 00:03:51.080
let's just double check that to be
sure before we start making changes.

70
00:03:51.080 --> 00:03:53.720
And we'll verify everything is
working the way it should, so

71
00:03:53.720 --> 00:03:57.170
I'll jump over to EDGE 2.

72
00:03:57.170 --> 00:04:00.900
And I'm gonna do a show run and look for
that BGP section and I'm gonna look for

73
00:04:00.900 --> 00:04:06.861
the neighbor statement that's
pointing to 192.168.16.5 and

74
00:04:06.861 --> 00:04:11.080
the local AS is Is not being overridden,
it is just set to 6 5 5 3 4.

75
00:04:11.080 --> 00:04:14.710
Another trick to look out for
is if there's a route map attached to it.

76
00:04:14.710 --> 00:04:17.370
Cuz the route map can actually
change the AS number also.

77
00:04:17.370 --> 00:04:19.760
There's a couple of crazy things
you can do with route maps.

78
00:04:19.760 --> 00:04:22.130
But in this case,
it's just straight forward.

79
00:04:22.130 --> 00:04:24.980
You've got 65534 on this end,
65535 on the other.

80
00:04:24.980 --> 00:04:29.070
And so we just need to go and
fix that, and, again,

81
00:04:29.070 --> 00:04:33.130
that might not be our whole problem, but
it's definitely part of our problem.

82
00:04:33.130 --> 00:04:37.818
So we'll jump over here,
and we'll put a fix in.

83
00:04:37.818 --> 00:04:43.242
So I'm gonna go ahead and get into
configuration, get into router bgp 65534.

84
00:04:43.242 --> 00:04:46.083
And I'm just gonna do a no neighbor.

85
00:04:46.083 --> 00:04:52.430
192.168.16.2 Remote-as 65535.

86
00:04:52.430 --> 00:04:59.910
So I'm gonna remove that command, and then
I'm gonna redo it with 65534 at the end.

87
00:05:01.290 --> 00:05:08.647
And, BGPs pretty fast so I expect
to get a neighbor up pretty quick.

88
00:05:08.647 --> 00:05:13.897
And I have a neighbor of
192.168.16.2 which is EDGE2.

89
00:05:13.897 --> 00:05:19.858
I've got messages sent for, messages
received for, and prefixes exchanged one.

90
00:05:19.858 --> 00:05:22.710
So we have exchanged some prefixes
there which is a good sign.

91
00:05:22.710 --> 00:05:24.120
And if I do a, show ip bgp,

92
00:05:24.120 --> 00:05:28.230
I should have that default route that's
kind of pushing through the network.

93
00:05:28.230 --> 00:05:29.890
Looks like we're in good shape.

94
00:05:29.890 --> 00:05:32.890
I'm just gonna verify that neighbor
over on the other side too, on EDGE2.

95
00:05:32.890 --> 00:05:37.690
So I'll do a quick show ip bgp summary.

96
00:05:39.520 --> 00:05:44.130
And we're looking for 192.168.16.5,
which is right there.

97
00:05:44.130 --> 00:05:45.660
And it looks like it's up and healthy.

98
00:05:45.660 --> 00:05:49.380
So in this case, the AS numbers just
didn't match on the two different sides.

99
00:05:49.380 --> 00:05:52.030
Fixed that and it's taken care of, right?

100
00:05:52.030 --> 00:05:54.020
So not a crazy mind-bending
exercise there,

101
00:05:54.020 --> 00:05:56.160
just a matter of doing
a little fact checking, right?

102
00:05:56.160 --> 00:05:59.810
Looking at the configs, making sure they
matched up, and they're squared away.

103
00:05:59.810 --> 00:06:02.130
All right,
well that wraps up set number eight.

104
00:06:02.130 --> 00:06:05.500
We still have a few more troubleshooting
sets to move through In fact,

105
00:06:05.500 --> 00:06:07.560
the next three are going
to be moving into IPv6.

106
00:06:07.560 --> 00:06:09.040
So, stay tuned for that.

107
00:06:09.040 --> 00:06:10.250
It's going to be exciting.

108
00:06:10.250 --> 00:06:12.940
But as far as set eight, that one's done,
so we'll wrap it up here.

109
00:06:12.940 --> 00:06:17.438
Thanks for watching, and I'll see you for
the next troubleshooting incident.

110
00:06:17.438 --> 00:06:23.199
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #1` from set #9. The trouble ticket states that "The port channel between the two core switches is not showing as up. This port-channel is configured as a layer 3 link between the two switches. "
episodes.title: Set 9 Issue 1
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.118 --> 00:00:08.558
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.558 --> 00:00:11.750
All right, welcome back to another
troubleshooting set here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.750 --> 00:00:15.700
We're going to be kicking off set nine,
jumping into issue one.

4
00:00:15.700 --> 00:00:20.410
And looks like we got some layer two
port channel type issues this time.

5
00:00:20.410 --> 00:00:22.090
So the ticket reads like this,

6
00:00:22.090 --> 00:00:27.830
it says the port channel between the two
core switches is not showing as up.

7
00:00:27.830 --> 00:00:32.180
This port channel is configured as a layer
three link between the two switches.

8
00:00:32.180 --> 00:00:36.074
So let's take a look at the typology
getting an idea what we're working with,

9
00:00:36.074 --> 00:00:38.320
the typology for
this one is a bit different.

10
00:00:38.320 --> 00:00:40.330
Right, again we have that reduced network.

11
00:00:40.330 --> 00:00:42.250
We don't have as many devices out there.

12
00:00:42.250 --> 00:00:44.870
We've got NY access one
down here at the bottom.

13
00:00:44.870 --> 00:00:47.040
NY core one and two, and so on.

14
00:00:47.040 --> 00:00:51.660
Now, looking at the diagram here,
I've got NYCORE1 and NYCORE2.

15
00:00:51.660 --> 00:00:57.700
And it shows them as being an OSPF area 1
but there's no interface on the diagram.

16
00:00:57.700 --> 00:01:01.450
I don't see a link there but they're
telling me that there is a port channel

17
00:01:01.450 --> 00:01:05.130
configured between these two switches and
then it's not showing it up.

18
00:01:05.130 --> 00:01:07.270
So that's where we're gonna
need to take a look and try and

19
00:01:07.270 --> 00:01:10.570
find out what the heck is going
on there and why isn't it up.

20
00:01:10.570 --> 00:01:13.690
Well, port channels have two ends,
either end can be the problem or

21
00:01:13.690 --> 00:01:16.270
both ends can be the problem so it
doesn't really matter which one we pick.

22
00:01:16.270 --> 00:01:19.710
Well let's just pick NYCORE1 and
start there and see what we can find.

23
00:01:19.710 --> 00:01:22.400
So, I'm gonna jump into my topology here.

24
00:01:22.400 --> 00:01:23.880
And I'll go into NYCORE1.

25
00:01:25.410 --> 00:01:28.870
And let's just dive into that switch.

26
00:01:28.870 --> 00:01:32.170
And I'm gonna do a quick
show IP interface brief.

27
00:01:32.170 --> 00:01:34.200
Just to see if there is a port channel or
not.

28
00:01:34.200 --> 00:01:36.200
I guess I could have done
a show EtherChannel summary.

29
00:01:36.200 --> 00:01:37.760
That would have been just as good.

30
00:01:37.760 --> 00:01:39.850
But here I can see all my VLAN interfaces.

31
00:01:39.850 --> 00:01:44.290
Those SVIs and I've got my physical
interfaces, ports one through 24.

32
00:01:44.290 --> 00:01:47.040
And then a couple of gig interfaces and
sure enough,

33
00:01:47.040 --> 00:01:49.060
there's a port channel right there.

34
00:01:49.060 --> 00:01:52.700
So I do have a port channel in place and
it is showing as down.

35
00:01:52.700 --> 00:01:56.330
So it's not a functional port,
at least, as of right now.

36
00:01:56.330 --> 00:01:59.120
And so
if I do that show EtherChannel summary.

37
00:02:00.160 --> 00:02:02.490
Which probably would have been
the better command to run first.

38
00:02:02.490 --> 00:02:04.420
I can see that I've got port channel one.

39
00:02:04.420 --> 00:02:09.910
It's status is RD and if I look up here
R tells me that it's layer three and

40
00:02:09.910 --> 00:02:11.530
D tells me that it's down.

41
00:02:11.530 --> 00:02:12.800
So, it's not happy.

42
00:02:12.800 --> 00:02:13.500
It's using LACP.

43
00:02:14.510 --> 00:02:17.138
And it's got ports 23 and 24.

44
00:02:17.138 --> 00:02:20.380
And they have a lowercase s which
tells me they are suspended.

45
00:02:20.380 --> 00:02:24.550
Now in my mind I'm thinking the most
common time where you see a port as being

46
00:02:24.550 --> 00:02:27.730
suspended is when the configuration
doesn't match the port channel.

47
00:02:27.730 --> 00:02:29.970
Right?
Our configuration needs to be the same.

48
00:02:29.970 --> 00:02:33.530
But if they've made some kind of change
like the port channel is set for trunking,

49
00:02:33.530 --> 00:02:35.780
and the interface is
set as an access port.

50
00:02:35.780 --> 00:02:36.900
That'll cause it to go suspended.

51
00:02:37.970 --> 00:02:42.050
So we may just have a simple configuration
issue which we can spot by doing a show

52
00:02:42.050 --> 00:02:44.750
run for interface port channel one.

53
00:02:44.750 --> 00:02:48.115
And here's the configuration for
my port channel no switch port so

54
00:02:48.115 --> 00:02:52.990
it's layer three and then we've got an IP
address assigned and its out in OSPF area

55
00:02:52.990 --> 00:02:57.550
one hundred or area one for process one
hundred and was this suppose to area one.

56
00:02:57.550 --> 00:03:00.710
Lets check out our topology yeah it is
area one okay so that's not a problem.

57
00:03:01.835 --> 00:03:05.050
All right then I wanna look at
the individual interfaces ports 23 and

58
00:03:05.050 --> 00:03:08.120
24 is suppose to be apart
of that port channel so

59
00:03:08.120 --> 00:03:13.060
I'll do a show run interface
FA 1 slash 0 slash 23 and 24.

60
00:03:13.060 --> 00:03:14.770
I want to look at these two.

61
00:03:14.770 --> 00:03:15.480
Okay.

62
00:03:15.480 --> 00:03:16.280
And when I look at it,

63
00:03:16.280 --> 00:03:20.010
they're both set as no switchboard
they both have no IP address.

64
00:03:20.010 --> 00:03:23.930
Now they need to be set as no switch board
so they'll operate like layer three ports.

65
00:03:23.930 --> 00:03:27.135
But they also need no IP address
because the IP address is attached to

66
00:03:27.135 --> 00:03:29.520
the port channel, not the interface.

67
00:03:29.520 --> 00:03:34.190
And then I've got
channel-group 1 mode passive.

68
00:03:34.190 --> 00:03:36.565
Now, that's an interesting
one right there, right?

69
00:03:36.565 --> 00:03:38.540
Channel-group 1 mode passive.

70
00:03:38.540 --> 00:03:44.170
When we're in passive mode that
means that we're doing LACP but

71
00:03:44.170 --> 00:03:46.770
we're not gonna actively try and
join the port channel.

72
00:03:46.770 --> 00:03:50.890
Somebody has to ask us to join,
otherwise we're not gonna do it.

73
00:03:50.890 --> 00:03:53.960
And if we don't join the port channel
we just come up as regular ports.

74
00:03:53.960 --> 00:03:56.150
And that's more than likely
what's going on here.

75
00:03:56.150 --> 00:03:58.080
Now, it can be a little
hard to see on this switch.

76
00:03:58.080 --> 00:03:59.730
Cuz we're also not showing
up as an access port.

77
00:03:59.730 --> 00:04:01.410
We're a layer three port.

78
00:04:01.410 --> 00:04:03.240
But we're just kinda sitting there.

79
00:04:03.240 --> 00:04:08.170
If I do a show IP interface brief again,
and go and

80
00:04:08.170 --> 00:04:13.340
look at ports 23 and 24, I should at least
be able to see whether they're up or not.

81
00:04:13.340 --> 00:04:15.790
And looking at 23 and 24,

82
00:04:15.790 --> 00:04:21.250
both of them have a kind of interesting
status here of being up, down, right?

83
00:04:21.250 --> 00:04:23.300
So they're up, but they're down.

84
00:04:23.300 --> 00:04:25.440
They're up because
the interface is turned up but

85
00:04:25.440 --> 00:04:28.900
the line protocol is down
because they have no IP address.

86
00:04:28.900 --> 00:04:32.420
No IP address on a layer three port
is gonna bring that interface down.

87
00:04:32.420 --> 00:04:35.910
So it's gonna stay like that unless
the port channel goes active.

88
00:04:35.910 --> 00:04:39.380
Well, let's look at the other side of this
thing and see if it's set to passive also.

89
00:04:39.380 --> 00:04:41.850
If that's the case,
if you have two ends that are passive,

90
00:04:41.850 --> 00:04:45.130
nobody asks to build a port channel,
then the channel doesn't come up.

91
00:04:45.130 --> 00:04:47.860
And if that's the case,
we can just set one side to active and

92
00:04:47.860 --> 00:04:48.720
the problem is solved.

93
00:04:48.720 --> 00:04:51.650
So, let's go look at NYCORE2 and
see if that's what's going on here.

94
00:04:53.510 --> 00:04:55.770
All right, so,
I'm gonna jump over to NYCORE2.

95
00:04:57.490 --> 00:05:01.150
And I'm gonna do a show, we'll do
a show EtherChannel summary this time.

96
00:05:01.150 --> 00:05:02.500
Save us a little bit of time.

97
00:05:03.660 --> 00:05:06.050
And I see that we've got
port channel one over here.

98
00:05:06.050 --> 00:05:07.510
It's doing LACP.

99
00:05:07.510 --> 00:05:11.830
It's got ports 23 and 24, and they're
both suspended just like we saw before.

100
00:05:11.830 --> 00:05:12.500
Status RD.

101
00:05:12.500 --> 00:05:14.989
So exactly like we saw on the other side.

102
00:05:16.110 --> 00:05:19.050
And if I do a show run for
interface port channel one,

103
00:05:20.330 --> 00:05:24.000
I see it's got no switchboard, it's got
an IP address and it's in OSPF area 100.

104
00:05:24.000 --> 00:05:26.380
That's the same as we
saw in the other side.

105
00:05:26.380 --> 00:05:29.400
And if I do a show run for
interface 23 and 24,

106
00:05:29.400 --> 00:05:34.310
sure enough, both ends are set to passive.

107
00:05:34.310 --> 00:05:37.230
If both ends are passive this
is not going to come up and so

108
00:05:37.230 --> 00:05:41.560
that's maybe not the whole problem, but
at least part of the problem, right.

109
00:05:41.560 --> 00:05:46.688
So, I'm gonna do an interface range
command here, and edit ports 23 and 24.

110
00:05:46.688 --> 00:05:50.577
And whenever you're messing around with
a port channel, it's always a good idea to

111
00:05:50.577 --> 00:05:53.645
shut down the physical interfaces,
before you make the changes,

112
00:05:53.645 --> 00:05:56.638
otherwise you run the risk of it
coming up with a partial config.

113
00:05:56.638 --> 00:05:59.582
Worst case scenario you can go into
air disabled and not noticing it,

114
00:05:59.582 --> 00:06:02.540
and then you got to troubleshoot
why the interface isn't coming up.

115
00:06:02.540 --> 00:06:05.490
So that's to shut it down
while you make the changes.

116
00:06:05.490 --> 00:06:11.910
And I'm just gonna say channel-group 1
mode, and we wanna make it active, right?

117
00:06:11.910 --> 00:06:14.160
Passive I can see as LACP.

118
00:06:14.160 --> 00:06:16.520
And we'll only respond if asked.

119
00:06:16.520 --> 00:06:19.280
Active means we're gonna go unconditional.

120
00:06:19.280 --> 00:06:22.180
And I really only have to
make the change on one side.

121
00:06:22.180 --> 00:06:23.890
I can leave the other side passive.

122
00:06:23.890 --> 00:06:27.378
This side will go active and reach out
to it and the other side should come up.

123
00:06:27.378 --> 00:06:28.440
Right?

124
00:06:28.440 --> 00:06:29.940
Now I can just do a no shutdown.

125
00:06:31.300 --> 00:06:34.260
And those interfaces should just
start doing their work pretty quick.

126
00:06:34.260 --> 00:06:34.910
All right?

127
00:06:34.910 --> 00:06:37.459
We can watch that with
a show EtherChannel summary.

128
00:06:39.200 --> 00:06:41.880
Whoops, there we go, and

129
00:06:41.880 --> 00:06:45.440
what I hope to see is them
change to a capital P like that.

130
00:06:45.440 --> 00:06:49.120
And if I look up here, the capital P
means bundled in the port channel.

131
00:06:49.120 --> 00:06:51.590
So they went active and
they became a part of it.

132
00:06:51.590 --> 00:06:56.420
And my status is RU, R because I'm
layer three, U because I'm in use.

133
00:06:56.420 --> 00:06:57.980
This one looks healthy.

134
00:06:57.980 --> 00:06:59.450
Let's look at the other side.

135
00:06:59.450 --> 00:07:06.010
So if I jump over to NYCORE one
it is still set for passive.

136
00:07:06.010 --> 00:07:07.300
But I'm okay with that.

137
00:07:08.880 --> 00:07:10.450
Because the other side is set for active.

138
00:07:10.450 --> 00:07:11.810
So it should come up.

139
00:07:11.810 --> 00:07:14.560
And sure enough I see it
switched to P's also.

140
00:07:14.560 --> 00:07:16.720
And the EtherChannel's now happy.

141
00:07:16.720 --> 00:07:24.290
If I do a show CDP neighbor I expect
to see NYCORE2 on ports 23 and 24.

142
00:07:24.290 --> 00:07:27.910
They're up and communicating and
OSPF should be working.

143
00:07:27.910 --> 00:07:31.710
So if I do a show ip ospf neighbor, well I

144
00:07:31.710 --> 00:07:34.350
don't have any neighbor relationships
there, so that's interesting.

145
00:07:34.350 --> 00:07:37.640
The interface might still be coming up,
we can verify that real quick.

146
00:07:37.640 --> 00:07:41.845
If I do a show ip interface brief and
exclude all the unassigneds,

147
00:07:41.845 --> 00:07:45.908
port channel one on this
guy is 192.168.255.1.

148
00:07:45.908 --> 00:07:49.472
Let's check the other side and make sure
that they're able to ping each other,

149
00:07:49.472 --> 00:07:50.400
all right?

150
00:07:50.400 --> 00:07:53.060
So, I'll jump over to NYCORE2.

151
00:07:53.060 --> 00:07:57.080
And I'll just do the same thing,
show ip interface brief,

152
00:07:57.080 --> 00:07:58.358
I'll exclude the unassigned.

153
00:07:58.358 --> 00:08:01.498
And it's 192.168.255.2.

154
00:08:01.498 --> 00:08:05.278
So I'm just gonna try and
ping 192.168.255.1 and

155
00:08:05.278 --> 00:08:07.850
see if I can ping across that link.

156
00:08:07.850 --> 00:08:12.140
And, well I didn't do hard broadcast,
but it did finally go across.

157
00:08:12.140 --> 00:08:14.310
Now OSPF's not peering up and
I gotta figure out whether or

158
00:08:14.310 --> 00:08:15.516
not I wanna troubleshoot that.

159
00:08:15.516 --> 00:08:16.980
Right?

160
00:08:16.980 --> 00:08:19.760
It's possible that it's gonna come up in
another troubleshooting question later on,

161
00:08:19.760 --> 00:08:22.190
and I might solve a problem
before I'm supposed to.

162
00:08:22.190 --> 00:08:26.640
Technically the port channel is up, we are
able to communicate from it, across it.

163
00:08:26.640 --> 00:08:31.460
So the questions as put forth in
our troubleshooting scenario here

164
00:08:31.460 --> 00:08:32.840
has been solved.

165
00:08:32.840 --> 00:08:35.140
But, that OSPF thing is kinda an odd one.

166
00:08:36.420 --> 00:08:38.360
Let's see if we can't
just spot it real quick.

167
00:08:38.360 --> 00:08:41.060
If I do a show run for
interface port channel one,

168
00:08:42.060 --> 00:08:45.330
this end is set to IP OSPF 100, area one.

169
00:08:45.330 --> 00:08:48.260
All right, so
it's set up to be in area one and

170
00:08:48.260 --> 00:08:50.890
on the other side,
I believe it was set the same way.

171
00:08:51.900 --> 00:08:55.230
So let's do a quick show run for
interface port channel one.

172
00:08:55.230 --> 00:08:58.010
And it's IP OSPF 100 area 1 also.

173
00:08:58.010 --> 00:09:02.420
So it looks like, as far as the basic
configuration there it should be fine.

174
00:09:02.420 --> 00:09:04.780
But I'm not getting that neighbor.

175
00:09:04.780 --> 00:09:06.750
So there's definitely a problem there.

176
00:09:06.750 --> 00:09:08.840
Let's hold off on this one,
we'll table this one.

177
00:09:08.840 --> 00:09:11.450
If we get through all the trouble
shooting scenarios and

178
00:09:11.450 --> 00:09:14.410
I haven't solved this OSPF problem
as one of those questions,

179
00:09:14.410 --> 00:09:17.040
then we'll come back and
we'll nail it as a bonus round at the end.

180
00:09:17.040 --> 00:09:20.930
But the port channel itself is up and
I know that I'm able to ping across it, so

181
00:09:20.930 --> 00:09:22.380
we're good and safe there.

182
00:09:22.380 --> 00:09:26.510
This one really just boiled down to
having two ends of a dynamic trunk, or

183
00:09:26.510 --> 00:09:27.900
a dynamic port channel.

184
00:09:27.900 --> 00:09:30.150
Both being set to passive,
which you can't do.

185
00:09:30.150 --> 00:09:31.580
At least one has to be active or

186
00:09:31.580 --> 00:09:34.380
both can be active, but
you can't have them both be passive.

187
00:09:34.380 --> 00:09:35.270
It's not gonna build up.

188
00:09:35.270 --> 00:09:38.970
So, we fixed that and we're ready to move
on to our next troubleshooting question.

189
00:09:38.970 --> 00:09:40.701
I'll see you then.

190
00:09:40.701 --> 00:09:46.279
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #2` from set #9. The trouble ticket states that "Once the port-channel is up, OSPF is not establishing a relationship across the port-channel. "
episodes.title: Set 9 Issue 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.252
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.252 --> 00:00:12.872
All right welcome to another Cisco
troubleshooting segment here on ITpro TV,

3
00:00:12.872 --> 00:00:15.350
we're ready to jump into Set 9 Issue 2.

4
00:00:15.350 --> 00:00:18.700
And for this one, well wouldn't you know,
we got an OSPF problem.

5
00:00:18.700 --> 00:00:21.920
If you watched issue number one,
you'll know at the end of that segment we

6
00:00:21.920 --> 00:00:25.590
verified that we did bring the port
channel up they were talking about and

7
00:00:25.590 --> 00:00:28.060
I noticed an OSPF problem
that we kind of tabled.

8
00:00:28.060 --> 00:00:30.170
Well, that turned out to
be question number two.

9
00:00:30.170 --> 00:00:35.150
It says, once the port channel is up
OSPF is not establishing a relationship

10
00:00:35.150 --> 00:00:36.580
across the port channel.

11
00:00:36.580 --> 00:00:38.540
We need to find out why.

12
00:00:38.540 --> 00:00:40.720
Well, if you didn't
watch issue number one,

13
00:00:40.720 --> 00:00:44.330
basically we had a port channel set up
across two links between two switches.

14
00:00:44.330 --> 00:00:47.560
They were layer three switches,
and we took two interfaces,

15
00:00:47.560 --> 00:00:50.780
bonded them together with LACP and
created a port channel.

16
00:00:50.780 --> 00:00:52.270
The port channel was
set up as layer three,

17
00:00:52.270 --> 00:00:56.000
so we had IP addresses on each end and
we were able to ping across that link.

18
00:00:56.000 --> 00:00:58.940
And I verified that the interfaces
were set-up for OSPF.

19
00:00:58.940 --> 00:01:00.050
Let me show you,.

20
00:01:00.050 --> 00:01:04.420
So going to my topology, the two switches
in question are these guys right here,

21
00:01:04.420 --> 00:01:05.680
NYCORE1 and NYCORE2.

22
00:01:05.680 --> 00:01:09.350
And they've got two links between
each other on ports 23 and 24,

23
00:01:09.350 --> 00:01:13.590
and those links are bonded
into a port channel.

24
00:01:13.590 --> 00:01:17.460
And the port channel is set up for
OSPF Area 1, just like we see right here.

25
00:01:17.460 --> 00:01:22.480
Okay, but
the OSPF adjacency is not coming up.

26
00:01:22.480 --> 00:01:26.690
And if I go back to my switches here,
I can take a look at, here's NYCORE1,

27
00:01:26.690 --> 00:01:31.930
and I can do a show run
interface port channel 1.

28
00:01:31.930 --> 00:01:37.020
And I can see where it's got
an IP address of 192.168.255.1.

29
00:01:37.020 --> 00:01:41.600
And it's set up for
OSPF process 100, area 1, right.

30
00:01:41.600 --> 00:01:44.228
So it appears to be set up correctly.

31
00:01:44.228 --> 00:01:50.116
And if I ping across that line, the other
end of the line is 192.168.255.2,

32
00:01:50.116 --> 00:01:53.110
I can try to ping it and it succeeds.

33
00:01:53.110 --> 00:01:55.985
It's a good idea to test this from the
other side though, because I might have

34
00:01:55.985 --> 00:02:00.450
uni-directional traffic,
something that UDLD could protect us from.

35
00:02:00.450 --> 00:02:02.330
But we'll just verify it here.

36
00:02:02.330 --> 00:02:05.500
You can see where I did a show run
interface port channel here or

37
00:02:05.500 --> 00:02:06.740
show run interface Port-chanel1.

38
00:02:06.740 --> 00:02:12.040
And you'll see that its got the other IP
address and it's set up for OSPF area 1,

39
00:02:12.040 --> 00:02:18.150
and if it tries to send a ping across
that link its successful also.

40
00:02:18.150 --> 00:02:21.230
So I've got two-way network
communications over the link.

41
00:02:21.230 --> 00:02:25.860
And OSPF is enable everything works right,
okay?

42
00:02:25.860 --> 00:02:28.070
But the adjacencies not coming up.

43
00:02:28.070 --> 00:02:31.500
If I do a show IP OSPF neighbor
there's nothing there.

44
00:02:31.500 --> 00:02:33.000
All right?

45
00:02:33.000 --> 00:02:35.000
So now I need to troubleshoot this and
find out why.

46
00:02:35.000 --> 00:02:37.840
When it comes to troubleshooting
OSPF there's really a couple of

47
00:02:37.840 --> 00:02:38.580
different ways to do it.

48
00:02:38.580 --> 00:02:40.560
There's three main ways that I use.

49
00:02:40.560 --> 00:02:44.340
You can just do a show running config on
one, a show running config on the other,

50
00:02:44.340 --> 00:02:45.630
and look for the differences, right.

51
00:02:45.630 --> 00:02:46.710
And that'll usually turn it up.

52
00:02:46.710 --> 00:02:48.140
But it's time-consuming.

53
00:02:48.140 --> 00:02:49.800
We can fire up debugs.

54
00:02:49.800 --> 00:02:52.700
And the debugs will show us
information about what's going on.

55
00:02:52.700 --> 00:02:55.470
But the third method is simply
to use the logs of our router.

56
00:02:55.470 --> 00:02:58.750
The logging on these things is
really good, especially with OSPF.

57
00:02:58.750 --> 00:03:01.170
And so normally if there's a problem
with OSPF, it'll turn up in the log.

58
00:03:01.170 --> 00:03:03.190
So that's usually the first place I go.

59
00:03:03.190 --> 00:03:05.710
And if it's not there,
then we can start looking at debugging.

60
00:03:05.710 --> 00:03:08.210
So, I'm gonna do a show log on NYCORE 2,

61
00:03:08.210 --> 00:03:11.260
and let's just see if we have any
messages kinda tucked away in here.

62
00:03:11.260 --> 00:03:13.440
Looks like I have some
interfaces coming up.

63
00:03:13.440 --> 00:03:16.870
Some power over ethernet being detected.

64
00:03:16.870 --> 00:03:20.570
Not, here is an entry
that has to do with OSPF.

65
00:03:20.570 --> 00:03:24.510
So, I got an entry here, OSPF-4.

66
00:03:24.510 --> 00:03:29.610
And it says no router
ID OSPF process 100 failed.

67
00:03:29.610 --> 00:03:31.990
Let's see why did it fail?

68
00:03:31.990 --> 00:03:34.880
Failed to allocate unique router ID and
cannot start.

69
00:03:34.880 --> 00:03:36.100
That's an interesting one.

70
00:03:36.100 --> 00:03:39.980
That's an error that you would get if a
system booted up with OSPF configured and

71
00:03:39.980 --> 00:03:41.860
no valid IP addresses.

72
00:03:41.860 --> 00:03:42.380
All right?

73
00:03:42.380 --> 00:03:46.560
Well this system if the only valid
IP address we had was tied to that

74
00:03:46.560 --> 00:03:47.440
port channel.

75
00:03:47.440 --> 00:03:49.100
the port channel is down in issue one, and

76
00:03:49.100 --> 00:03:51.500
that might be what generated
that error message.

77
00:03:51.500 --> 00:03:54.740
I can verify that really easy
with the show IP protocols.

78
00:03:54.740 --> 00:03:57.820
If we still don't have a router ID,
it'll show up in here.

79
00:03:57.820 --> 00:04:02.770
But I can see I've got routing protocol
OSPF 100, and I've got a router ID.

80
00:04:02.770 --> 00:04:06.610
So, that error is already gone,
that one's not going to apply.

81
00:04:06.610 --> 00:04:08.230
Alright im going to do a show log and

82
00:04:08.230 --> 00:04:11.712
I'm going to just include lines with
OSPF to make our job a little easier.

83
00:04:11.712 --> 00:04:16.255
All right that was the only error message
in my logs that had to do with OSPF there

84
00:04:16.255 --> 00:04:17.570
wasn't anything else.

85
00:04:17.570 --> 00:04:22.090
So I'm not getting any hints there as to
why my neighbor ships not building up.

86
00:04:22.090 --> 00:04:25.490
If it was a router ID problem that
would cause it not to happen but

87
00:04:25.490 --> 00:04:29.220
in this case that's not the case.

88
00:04:29.220 --> 00:04:32.150
So I'm going to have to go a step
further and do some debugging and

89
00:04:32.150 --> 00:04:33.210
try to find out what's going on here.

90
00:04:33.210 --> 00:04:37.710
I'm going to jump into my configuration
and I'm going to turn on logging console

91
00:04:37.710 --> 00:04:40.450
just to make sure that I can see
any messages that are happening.

92
00:04:40.450 --> 00:04:43.890
And then I'm going to do,
debug ip ospf packet.

93
00:04:45.040 --> 00:04:49.480
And debug ip ospf adj, okay?

94
00:04:49.480 --> 00:04:53.300
Debug ip ospf packet will show me all
the ospf packages as they come and go.

95
00:04:53.300 --> 00:04:56.440
So I can see if I'm even,
if I'm even seeing a neighbor.

96
00:04:56.440 --> 00:04:59.100
And debug ip ospf adj

97
00:04:59.100 --> 00:05:02.900
will show me any problems might happen
when adjacencies are being built up.

98
00:05:02.900 --> 00:05:06.490
And so I do see some packets
here that I'm receiving.

99
00:05:06.490 --> 00:05:08.618
So I'm receiving these
communications coming in.

100
00:05:08.618 --> 00:05:11.090
And therefore aid:0.0.0.1.

101
00:05:11.090 --> 00:05:13.618
So I know I don't have any
kind like area mismatch.

102
00:05:13.618 --> 00:05:19.350
And it's 192.168.255.1,
that's the switch on the other side.

103
00:05:19.350 --> 00:05:23.310
So I am receiving communications, but

104
00:05:23.310 --> 00:05:26.320
notice how I haven't gotten
any adjacency messages here.

105
00:05:26.320 --> 00:05:30.220
All right, so while it looks like I
am communicating with the other side,

106
00:05:30.220 --> 00:05:33.520
I'm not trying to build
an adjacency with it.

107
00:05:33.520 --> 00:05:34.470
Why not?

108
00:05:34.470 --> 00:05:36.800
Well, with OSPF, in order for

109
00:05:36.800 --> 00:05:39.600
an adjacency to build, there's
a number of things that have to match.

110
00:05:39.600 --> 00:05:41.150
The area ID is one of them.

111
00:05:41.150 --> 00:05:43.830
And if the area ID doesn't match,
you'll get all sorts of warnings.

112
00:05:43.830 --> 00:05:47.300
But there's other things that have to
match too, like our authentication.

113
00:05:47.300 --> 00:05:48.990
And you'll see mine has
authentication zero,

114
00:05:48.990 --> 00:05:50.930
that means I'm not doing authentication.

115
00:05:50.930 --> 00:05:53.370
So if that didn't match,
it would fail to come up.

116
00:05:53.370 --> 00:05:55.640
Our hello and dead timer intervals,

117
00:05:55.640 --> 00:05:58.530
those would cause us not to
come up if they didn't match.

118
00:05:58.530 --> 00:06:01.230
So these are all different
things that might happen,

119
00:06:01.230 --> 00:06:02.940
some of them don't
generate error messages.

120
00:06:02.940 --> 00:06:05.030
And so
I can debug until my face turns blue, and

121
00:06:05.030 --> 00:06:06.060
it's not going to make a difference.

122
00:06:06.060 --> 00:06:09.450
So I'm going to un-debug all,
and turn off my debugging.

123
00:06:09.450 --> 00:06:11.500
And I'm just going to take
a look at my configuration.

124
00:06:11.500 --> 00:06:15.150
So I'm going to do a show run,
and pull up the OSPF section.

125
00:06:15.150 --> 00:06:17.210
Apparently I don't have my
section command assigned.

126
00:06:17.210 --> 00:06:19.450
So I'll do a show run,
and I'll begin with OSPF.

127
00:06:20.870 --> 00:06:22.430
And when I look at OSPF out.

128
00:06:22.430 --> 00:06:26.070
Oh, I forgot about the OSPF commands on
the interface, so I'll just get past that.

129
00:06:26.070 --> 00:06:27.172
When I get down to the OSPF.

130
00:06:27.172 --> 00:06:31.110
[LAUGH] Let me begin with router OSPF.

131
00:06:31.110 --> 00:06:33.400
That'll get me right to
the spot that I actually want.

132
00:06:36.410 --> 00:06:38.930
When I get to that configuration,
I can look in here and

133
00:06:38.930 --> 00:06:43.080
see router OSPF 100 with nothing
else special on it at all.

134
00:06:43.080 --> 00:06:44.380
Right, logging adjacentcy changes.

135
00:06:44.380 --> 00:06:45.300
That's a default command.

136
00:06:45.300 --> 00:06:51.780
So we've turned on OSPF and if I do a show
run for interface port channel one.

137
00:06:51.780 --> 00:06:54.830
We've got IP OSPF 100 area 1.

138
00:06:54.830 --> 00:06:59.990
So no sneaky passive interfaces, no crazy
hold down timers or anything like that.

139
00:06:59.990 --> 00:07:01.460
This side looks perfectly normal.

140
00:07:01.460 --> 00:07:03.380
I don't see anything out
of the ordinary here.

141
00:07:03.380 --> 00:07:06.780
So let's jump over to NYCORE2 and
hope we have some better luck over there.

142
00:07:06.780 --> 00:07:08.180
I'll jump over to NYCORE2 and

143
00:07:08.180 --> 00:07:12.290
I'm basically going to repeat the same
exact process we just went through.

144
00:07:12.290 --> 00:07:16.490
I'm going to do a show log and I'm going
to look for anything with OSPF in it.

145
00:07:17.560 --> 00:07:19.830
And I've got one of those no
router ID messages again.

146
00:07:19.830 --> 00:07:20.900
