Let's make sure that's gone.

147
00:07:20.900 --> 00:07:25.360
I'll do a show IP protocol to make sure
that I actually do have a router ID and,

148
00:07:25.360 --> 00:07:26.350
sure enough, I do.

149
00:07:26.350 --> 00:07:27.600
So there we go, I've got a router ID.

150
00:07:28.640 --> 00:07:32.640
And I can do, whoops,
I can log out, that'll help.

151
00:07:32.640 --> 00:07:34.190
I can do some debugging if I want.

152
00:07:34.190 --> 00:07:41.560
I can debug IP ospf packet,
and debug ip ospf adj, right?

153
00:07:41.560 --> 00:07:43.230
And so

154
00:07:43.230 --> 00:07:47.180
now as those ospf communications start
coming through I should start to see them.

155
00:07:47.180 --> 00:07:50.360
I'm not seeing them so that means
I need to turn on logging console.

156
00:07:52.890 --> 00:07:53.450
There we go.

157
00:07:53.450 --> 00:07:57.530
And so our search should start to see
this OSPF messages coming through here

158
00:07:57.530 --> 00:07:58.900
as we communicate with the other side.

159
00:07:58.900 --> 00:08:00.950
All right, and here they go.

160
00:08:00.950 --> 00:08:04.240
There starting to get, I'm receiving
communications from 192.168.20.1,

161
00:08:04.240 --> 00:08:09.370
I don't know who that is,
that's somebody else on the network.

162
00:08:09.370 --> 00:08:12.100
So if I wait long enough, I should see
communications from the other side.

163
00:08:12.100 --> 00:08:13.960
If I don't I might have a problem there.

164
00:08:13.960 --> 00:08:17.830
Now why may I not receive communications
from the other side if I don't look.

165
00:08:17.830 --> 00:08:20.056
Let's just assume that I
don't have any pop-up here.

166
00:08:20.056 --> 00:08:22.070
I could have a passive interface.

167
00:08:22.070 --> 00:08:23.860
I could have an access control list.

168
00:08:23.860 --> 00:08:27.090
I could have all sorts of things that
block those communications from coming in.

169
00:08:27.090 --> 00:08:33.640
And as I watch this, I'm seeing a lot of
stuff coming from router id 192.168.20.1.

170
00:08:33.640 --> 00:08:37.810
But I'm not really seeing anything
from the switch on the other side.

171
00:08:37.810 --> 00:08:41.840
So I'm gonna do an undebug all,
and get that turned off.

172
00:08:41.840 --> 00:08:45.530
And let me just see if 192.168.20.1
is the router id for CORE2.

173
00:08:45.530 --> 00:08:48.620
I don't, I don't think it is, but
let's, let's find out, all right?

174
00:08:48.620 --> 00:08:52.080
You know I did a show ip protocols
on this one a while back,

175
00:08:52.080 --> 00:08:54.370
which is already scrolled
out of my buffer.

176
00:08:54.370 --> 00:08:55.880
So let me do that again.

177
00:08:55.880 --> 00:08:58.630
I just want to see what my router ID is.

178
00:08:58.630 --> 00:08:59.920
Oh my router ID is 192.168.20.1.

179
00:08:59.920 --> 00:09:02.720
I'm glad we checked that.

180
00:09:02.720 --> 00:09:06.110
So that means that I am receiving
communications from the other side.

181
00:09:06.110 --> 00:09:07.628
There's no ACL blocking this.

182
00:09:07.628 --> 00:09:11.035
I'm getting them and I'm not even
bothering to build an adjacent,

183
00:09:11.035 --> 00:09:13.498
so I'll bet we have one
of those settings wrong.

184
00:09:13.498 --> 00:09:18.100
So lets take a look at Show run interface
PO1 and the port channel that's

185
00:09:18.100 --> 00:09:22.860
pretty straightforward it's just
assigned ospf process 100 area 1.

186
00:09:22.860 --> 00:09:26.280
Then I'll do a show run and
begin that with router ospf,

187
00:09:26.280 --> 00:09:32.340
and we'll look here and see what we got,
and now we have a difference.

188
00:09:32.340 --> 00:09:33.100
Okay.

189
00:09:33.100 --> 00:09:37.970
Right here we've got router
ospf 100 area 1 stub.

190
00:09:37.970 --> 00:09:40.390
This one is flagged as a stub.

191
00:09:40.390 --> 00:09:41.590
The other one isn't.

192
00:09:41.590 --> 00:09:44.100
I mentioned hello and
dead intervals have to match.

193
00:09:44.100 --> 00:09:45.770
Authentication has to match.

194
00:09:45.770 --> 00:09:47.690
Area number has to match.

195
00:09:47.690 --> 00:09:50.510
The stub flag has to match also.

196
00:09:50.510 --> 00:09:52.750
And in this case the stub
find doesn't match.

197
00:09:52.750 --> 00:09:54.080
This one's fine as a stub.

198
00:09:54.080 --> 00:09:55.160
The other side isn't.

199
00:09:55.160 --> 00:09:56.930
It's not gonna build an adjacentcy.

200
00:09:56.930 --> 00:09:58.750
So I need to get in here and correct that,

201
00:09:58.750 --> 00:10:01.270
now this is where it
gets a little bit tough.

202
00:10:01.270 --> 00:10:02.740
Which router is wrong?

203
00:10:02.740 --> 00:10:03.830
Okay, who's wrong?

204
00:10:03.830 --> 00:10:08.740
Is it, is it NYCORE1 wrong to
think that area one is a stub?

205
00:10:08.740 --> 00:10:11.480
Or is NYCORE2 wrong,
to think that it's a stub.

206
00:10:11.480 --> 00:10:15.140
Well, maybe they're not wrong at all,
maybe it is a stub and

207
00:10:15.140 --> 00:10:17.100
I should make them both
think that it is a stub.

208
00:10:17.100 --> 00:10:18.230
I need to figure that out.

209
00:10:19.250 --> 00:10:21.140
First off, OSPF area 0.

210
00:10:21.140 --> 00:10:23.150
Area 0 should never be a stub, right.

211
00:10:23.150 --> 00:10:27.190
It should always be a transit network,
so we don't expect to see a stub there.

212
00:10:27.190 --> 00:10:31.920
But area 1, if there's only one way in and
one way out and no exit network,

213
00:10:31.920 --> 00:10:33.820
no external networks in it.

214
00:10:33.820 --> 00:10:35.980
Then it's a stub.

215
00:10:35.980 --> 00:10:39.380
We don't want other people flowing through
us to get somewhere else because we're

216
00:10:39.380 --> 00:10:41.760
Area 1, that's what Area 0 is for.

217
00:10:41.760 --> 00:10:46.760
So what I usually do is just look and
if I see redistribute commands

218
00:10:46.760 --> 00:10:49.710
then it's not a stub,
I need to make this not a stub.

219
00:10:49.710 --> 00:10:54.140
But if I don't see any redistribute
commands then it is a stub.

220
00:10:54.140 --> 00:10:58.430
Well, when I look, we looked at the router
OSPF process on both of these guys, right?

221
00:10:58.430 --> 00:11:03.200
So on this one, I've got router
OSPF 100 no redistribution.

222
00:11:03.200 --> 00:11:05.090
So no external networks brought into that.

223
00:11:05.090 --> 00:11:06.360
And if I look at the other one,

224
00:11:06.360 --> 00:11:10.250
let's find,
oh it's already scrolled out of my buffer.

225
00:11:10.250 --> 00:11:11.220
Let me get it back up here.

226
00:11:12.420 --> 00:11:17.090
If I look at this one it didn't
have any of those either right.

227
00:11:17.090 --> 00:11:21.600
It didn't have any redistributes in it,
at least not that I recall.

228
00:11:21.600 --> 00:11:25.170
So looking at it here, yeah, it's right
here, there's no redistribute commands.

229
00:11:25.170 --> 00:11:27.290
So there's no external networks.

230
00:11:27.290 --> 00:11:29.720
Area one is effectively a stub.

231
00:11:29.720 --> 00:11:32.070
So if I wanna fix this,
I can just take this guy and

232
00:11:32.070 --> 00:11:36.850
go into router OSPF 100 and
say area 1 stub.

233
00:11:37.900 --> 00:11:40.190
Now this one's a stub,
the other side's a stub.

234
00:11:40.190 --> 00:11:41.640
The stub flag now matches.

235
00:11:41.640 --> 00:11:45.850
And if that was the only difference,
then we should see the adjacency come up.

236
00:11:45.850 --> 00:11:49.660
And there it goes, I stalled just long
enough to make that adjacency come up.

237
00:11:49.660 --> 00:11:53.080
And if I do a show IP OSPF neighbor,
there it is.

238
00:11:53.080 --> 00:11:56.030
I've got a full relationship and
if I do a show IP route.

239
00:11:57.470 --> 00:11:58.660
Well, I'm not running any routes.

240
00:11:58.660 --> 00:12:00.360
But we haven't looked at
what's redistributed.

241
00:12:00.360 --> 00:12:02.820
The important part here is,
or not redistributed, but

242
00:12:02.820 --> 00:12:04.310
just what's being advertised
on the other side.

243
00:12:04.310 --> 00:12:07.150
But the important part here
is that we do have a full

244
00:12:07.150 --> 00:12:09.680
adjacency built up with our neighbor.

245
00:12:09.680 --> 00:12:13.070
And OSPF is now functioning the way
it's supposed to, all right.

246
00:12:13.070 --> 00:12:15.020
Whether or not we've advertised
routes doesn't really matter.

247
00:12:15.020 --> 00:12:17.920
The question said, the OSPF

248
00:12:17.920 --> 00:12:22.420
is not establishing a relationship across
the port channel, now it is, right?

249
00:12:22.420 --> 00:12:23.460
So we've solved that problem.

250
00:12:23.460 --> 00:12:25.570
This one turned out to be the stub flag.

251
00:12:25.570 --> 00:12:28.030
It was set on one, not set on the other.

252
00:12:28.030 --> 00:12:31.740
Once we got them in agreement it was fixed
and I fixed it by setting it as a stub.

253
00:12:31.740 --> 00:12:34.400
I could have also fixed it by
not setting it as a stub, right?

254
00:12:34.400 --> 00:12:36.260
Removing the stub flag
on the other router.

255
00:12:36.260 --> 00:12:38.040
That would have solved the problem too.

256
00:12:38.040 --> 00:12:40.010
But since there weren't any
redistribute commands here,

257
00:12:40.010 --> 00:12:43.200
it effectively was a stub so
we might as well call it what it is.

258
00:12:43.200 --> 00:12:45.327
Set it as a stub and now we're done.

259
00:12:45.327 --> 00:12:47.224
All right, well that's it for
issue number two.

260
00:12:47.224 --> 00:12:48.448
Stay tuned for number three.

261
00:12:48.448 --> 00:12:49.688
It's coming up next.

262
00:12:49.688 --> 00:12:56.964
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #3` from set #9. The trouble ticket states that "NYEDGE1 and NYEDGE2 are unable to communicate to each other. This can be seen when using ipv6 ping "
episodes.title: Set 9 Issue 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:08.503 --> 00:00:12.220
Alright, welcome back to another
troubleshooting segment here on IT Pro TV.

2
00:00:12.220 --> 00:00:16.400
We're jumping into set nine,
issue three and this one says basically

3
00:00:16.400 --> 00:00:21.070
that NYEDGE1 and NYEDGE2 are unable
to communicate to each other.

4
00:00:21.070 --> 00:00:22.930
This can be seen when using IPv6 ping.

5
00:00:22.930 --> 00:00:27.980
Oh great, all right, so we've got some
IPv6 communications to worry about here,

6
00:00:27.980 --> 00:00:31.390
and we need to find out why these two
systems can't communicate to each other.

7
00:00:31.390 --> 00:00:34.070
Well, let's take a look
at our topology and

8
00:00:34.070 --> 00:00:36.600
get an idea of the devices
we're talking about.

9
00:00:36.600 --> 00:00:41.770
So the systems in question are NYEDGE1 and
NYEDGE2, these two routers.

10
00:00:41.770 --> 00:00:43.390
They can't talk to each other.

11
00:00:43.390 --> 00:00:47.370
Now I know there's a serial link
right here between the two, so

12
00:00:47.370 --> 00:00:51.630
maybe we talk between those, so maybe we
just have a problem with that serial link.

13
00:00:51.630 --> 00:00:53.730
But they're specifically calling out IPv6.

14
00:00:53.730 --> 00:00:56.020
Well IPv6 could run over
that serial link just fine.

15
00:00:56.020 --> 00:00:59.866
But we also have another path to be
able to get between the systems,

16
00:00:59.866 --> 00:01:03.430
which would be NYEDGE1
jumping over to NYCORE1.

17
00:01:03.430 --> 00:01:07.810
Jumping over to well,
a couple of different ways, right?

18
00:01:07.810 --> 00:01:13.320
If NYEDGE1 and NYEDGE2 are in the same
subnet, then in theory I should be

19
00:01:13.320 --> 00:01:19.940
able to go from NYEDGE1 to NYCORE1 down
to ACCESS1 up to CORE2 and over to EDGE2.

20
00:01:21.200 --> 00:01:23.010
In some of our previous
troubleshooting scenarios,

21
00:01:23.010 --> 00:01:27.100
we had a trunk in between these two
switches, but we don't in this set.

22
00:01:27.100 --> 00:01:29.860
In this set,
we've gotta layer three link between here.

23
00:01:29.860 --> 00:01:32.050
So this would be like a routed link.

24
00:01:32.050 --> 00:01:34.780
If these two guys were in the same subnet,
they're not gonna use that routed link.

25
00:01:34.780 --> 00:01:36.770
They're gonna go around it.

26
00:01:36.770 --> 00:01:38.440
But if they're on different subnets,

27
00:01:38.440 --> 00:01:40.160
then in theory we should be
able to come through here and

28
00:01:40.160 --> 00:01:43.540
get routed to the other side and
come up and skip ACCESS1 altogether.

29
00:01:43.540 --> 00:01:47.430
I don't really know which way it's going
to go, so we need to go and find out.

30
00:01:47.430 --> 00:01:50.030
So the first think I want to do is
a little address reconnaissance.

31
00:01:50.030 --> 00:01:53.530
I know we're using IPv6, but I have no
idea what address range we're using.

32
00:01:53.530 --> 00:01:57.840
So I'm gonna look at EDGE1 and EDGE2 and
just see what addresses they have.

33
00:01:57.840 --> 00:02:02.940
So, if I jump over to NYEDGE1 right here.

34
00:02:04.310 --> 00:02:05.850
I just wanna take a look at the addresses.

35
00:02:05.850 --> 00:02:12.180
Now, my favorite command, the one I always
run on this show, is show ip int br.

36
00:02:12.180 --> 00:02:15.670
But that doesn't really help me when
I'm dealing with IPv6, does it?

37
00:02:15.670 --> 00:02:20.150
I need to do a show IPv6 interface brief.

38
00:02:20.150 --> 00:02:22.350
And now I get the IPv6 addresses.

39
00:02:22.350 --> 00:02:25.470
That will show IPv6 interface brief.

40
00:02:25.470 --> 00:02:28.160
And as I look at the interfaces that I got

41
00:02:28.160 --> 00:02:30.800
I've got a management
interface that's down.

42
00:02:30.800 --> 00:02:34.760
I've got a gig interface that's
up with an IPv6 address.

43
00:02:34.760 --> 00:02:39.210
I've got a serial interface
that's up with an IPv6 address.

44
00:02:39.210 --> 00:02:41.230
And so
I've got a few different things here.

45
00:02:41.230 --> 00:02:45.180
The serial interface is
the one that interests me.

46
00:02:45.180 --> 00:02:48.040
Because if I look at my topology,
Ser/0/0/0,

47
00:02:48.040 --> 00:02:50.540
that's this link between the two routers.

48
00:02:50.540 --> 00:02:52.330
And its got an IPv6 address.

49
00:02:53.610 --> 00:02:56.760
That interface should be
a great candidate to talk over.

50
00:02:56.760 --> 00:02:58.870
And then EDGE2 same thing on the way back,

51
00:02:58.870 --> 00:03:00.760
if we look at it,
we can kind of verify it.

52
00:03:00.760 --> 00:03:02.390
So I'm just gonna look at these and

53
00:03:02.390 --> 00:03:05.660
I'm gonna have to use my handy
dandy troubleshooting tool here.

54

another ACL entry in here that covers

500
00:28:19.402 --> 00:28:23.927
when that host pings the FE80,
pings that link local address.

501
00:28:23.927 --> 00:28:26.552
If I don't do that, I'm gonna
continue to have failures like this.

502
00:28:26.552 --> 00:28:29.129
So, and we can do that easy enough.

503
00:28:29.129 --> 00:28:34.620
If I do a show ipv6 Int brief,
I can get that address up on my screen and

504
00:28:34.620 --> 00:28:37.769
that address is right here, this one.

505
00:28:37.769 --> 00:28:42.331
And see if it will let me copy, let's
see if I can copy and paste on this one.

506
00:28:42.331 --> 00:28:47.101
All right, so I'm gonna copy that and
then what I'm gonna do is get back

507
00:28:47.101 --> 00:28:51.485
into that access-list and
we had sequence 40 was the deny all.

508
00:28:51.485 --> 00:28:54.710
If I do a, let me pull that
access-list back up again.

509
00:28:54.710 --> 00:28:59.450
I'll do a show access-list and
then we can see here where it was,

510
00:28:59.450 --> 00:29:03.692
actually, this very first one, sequence
10 that approved me to being the host.

511
00:29:03.692 --> 00:29:09.470
I'm gonna add a sequence 11,
that'll permit ICMP from host.

512
00:29:09.470 --> 00:29:12.125
And I'm gonna specify my guy
on the other side, right?

513
00:29:12.125 --> 00:29:17.582
So 2001:A001 :1:1::2.

514
00:29:19.852 --> 00:29:23.678
And then the destination,
I'm gonna put host.

515
00:29:23.678 --> 00:29:25.818
And then I'll paste in
that link local address,

516
00:29:25.818 --> 00:29:28.290
which I thought it wasn't
gonna let me ping.

517
00:29:28.290 --> 00:29:30.970
So I'm gonna have to write
this kind of the hard way.

518
00:29:30.970 --> 00:29:31.776
So let's see, it's.

519
00:29:33.775 --> 00:29:34.913
Let me do a.

520
00:29:37.374 --> 00:29:38.755
It's not gonna like that, is it?

521
00:29:38.755 --> 00:29:45.835
So, let me do a show ipv6 int brief and

522
00:29:45.835 --> 00:29:50.051
just include 0/0.

523
00:29:50.051 --> 00:29:51.212
Yep.

524
00:29:53.804 --> 00:29:55.676
Trying to think of the best way to get
this up on my screen, since I can copy and

525
00:29:55.676 --> 00:29:57.367
paste on this one, I should've
just written the whole thing down.

526
00:29:57.367 --> 00:29:59.260
There we go.

527
00:29:59.260 --> 00:30:05.565
All right, so now I can come in here and
just type this in and

528
00:30:05.565 --> 00:30:10.715
so, it's going to be
sequence 11 permit icmp

529
00:30:10.715 --> 00:30:15.507
host 2001:A001:1:1::2.

530
00:30:15.507 --> 00:30:16.646
Rolls right off the tongue.

531
00:30:16.646 --> 00:30:19.989
Host and then it's FE80.

532
00:30:19.989 --> 00:30:25.759
Whoops, FE80: And now for
the long part here, right?

533
00:30:25.759 --> 00:30:29.404
::1AE7.

534
00:30:29.404 --> 00:30:35.924
This is the part everybody
dreads about IPV6,

535
00:30:35.924 --> 00:30:40.977
having to write these long numbers,

536
00:30:40.977 --> 00:30:44.896
28FF:FEDD:5658.

537
00:30:44.896 --> 00:30:47.588
There we go.

538
00:30:47.588 --> 00:30:54.994
All right, and if we do a show access-list
now, and take a look at that ACL.

539
00:30:54.994 --> 00:30:59.261
I've got the first line permitting
my IP to ping this ones IP and

540
00:30:59.261 --> 00:31:02.249
then my IP pinging that
link local address.

541
00:31:02.249 --> 00:31:06.063
Okay, so that should take care of that
problem and now we should be able to ping

542
00:31:06.063 --> 00:31:09.012
across, even if we come across
on that link local address.

543
00:31:09.012 --> 00:31:12.083
Now if I jump back to NYEDGE2
can test it out one more time,

544
00:31:12.083 --> 00:31:15.450
we'll just do that ping and
we've got our successes, right?

545
00:31:15.450 --> 00:31:21.050
And if we jump back over
here to NYEDGE1 and

546
00:31:21.050 --> 00:31:24.560
take a look at here, we should have
some nice little matches that ACL.

547
00:31:24.560 --> 00:31:28.240
And that looks like it matched off
the main address that time, so

548
00:31:28.240 --> 00:31:29.750
it looks like we're going back and forth.

549
00:31:29.750 --> 00:31:32.736
But either way, now we're approved we
should be good to go for the ping, and

550
00:31:32.736 --> 00:31:33.356
it's solved.

551
00:31:33.356 --> 00:31:35.966
All right, so this problem actually
boiled down to two things.

552
00:31:35.966 --> 00:31:41.030
First off we had a broken VLAN 66 along
the path from point A to point B.

553
00:31:41.030 --> 00:31:44.160
And then secondly, we had
an access-list that blocking our ping,

554
00:31:44.160 --> 00:31:47.440
our neighbor discovery wasn't working
right, and we weren't able to get there.

555
00:31:47.440 --> 00:31:49.900
We removed the ACL that kinda solved that.

556
00:31:49.900 --> 00:31:53.310
We put the ACL back in, technically
the problem was still there, but

557
00:31:53.310 --> 00:31:55.640
we weren't seeing it,
cuz neighbor discovery already happened.

558
00:31:55.640 --> 00:32:00.050
When we fixed that ACL by adding an extra
entry for the link local address,

559
00:32:00.050 --> 00:32:02.450
that took care of that and now we know
the problem won't come back for us.

560
00:32:02.450 --> 00:32:04.540
So, that takes care of this one.

561
00:32:04.540 --> 00:32:06.842
Little bit of a long solution for
what seemed like a simple problem.

562
00:32:06.842 --> 00:32:08.818
Two routers can't see each other.

563
00:32:08.818 --> 00:32:11.001
Well, we got it resolved,
got it knocked out.

564
00:32:11.001 --> 00:32:13.299
And now we're ready to move on to
the next troubleshooting ticket.

565
00:32:13.299 --> 00:32:15.261
I hope to see you then.

566
00:32:15.261 --> 00:32:21.700
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #4` from set #9. The trouble ticket states that "NYEDGE1 and NYEDGE2 are not forming an OSPF neighbor adjacency even though they are on the same IPv6 subnet. We should see an adjacency on Gi0/0 "
episodes.title: Set 9 Issue 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.050 --> 00:00:06.340
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.360 --> 00:00:12.740
All right, welcome back to another Cisco
troubleshooting segment here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.740 --> 00:00:16.693
And we're ready to jump right back
into Set 9 with Issue number 4.

4
00:00:16.693 --> 00:00:21.778
And the ticket reads like this,
it says, NYEDGE1 and NYEDGE2 are not

5
00:00:21.778 --> 00:00:27.820
forming an OSPF neighbor adjacencies even
though they are on the same IPv6 subnet.

6
00:00:27.820 --> 00:00:31.540
We should see an adjacency on GI0/0.

7
00:00:31.540 --> 00:00:35.960
Now these are the same interfaces that we
were troubleshooting a few moments ago in

8
00:00:35.960 --> 00:00:39.780
issue number three, where they
couldn't ping each other via IPv6.

9
00:00:39.780 --> 00:00:40.650
We've resolved that.

10
00:00:40.650 --> 00:00:43.986
We've got them pinging, but
now we're not forming an OSPF adjacency.

11
00:00:43.986 --> 00:00:45.530
So we need like to kinda
figure that out and

12
00:00:45.530 --> 00:00:49.550
see what's going on there, and
troubleshoot and resolve, right?

13
00:00:49.550 --> 00:00:51.740
So, before we do that,
let's take a look at our topology again,

14
00:00:51.740 --> 00:00:53.290
just to refresh our memory.

15
00:00:53.290 --> 00:00:58.780
And the two devices in question here
are NYEDGE1 and NYEDGE2, these two guys.

16
00:00:58.780 --> 00:01:01.440
And they've got a serial link between
them, and that's all well and good.

17
00:01:01.440 --> 00:01:05.290
But the troubleshooting ticket is telling
us that we should be getting an adjacency

18
00:01:05.290 --> 00:01:08.940
here on our GI0/0 interfaces
these internal interfaces.

19
00:01:08.940 --> 00:01:11.730
And those are the ones we fixed last
time where they have that problem

20
00:01:11.730 --> 00:01:15.960
running all the way down through these
switches and back up to each other.

21
00:01:15.960 --> 00:01:19.650
And we're able to see that that did
work by the time we were done with it.

22
00:01:19.650 --> 00:01:22.350
One node was able to ping the other.

23
00:01:22.350 --> 00:01:26.205
But OSPF is not working, so
we need to find out why and go from there.

24
00:01:26.205 --> 00:01:28.775
Now when you're dealing with
an OSPF adjacency like this it

25
00:01:28.775 --> 00:01:31.925
doesn't necessarily matter which one we
start with, we could look at either node.

26
00:01:31.925 --> 00:01:36.225
Although, kind of looking at this chart
here I'm seeing some interesting things.

27
00:01:36.225 --> 00:01:39.975
So if I look at this topology, let me
just kinda go a little big picture here.

28
00:01:39.975 --> 00:01:43.505
We've got OSPF Area 1 down
here at the bottom and

29
00:01:43.505 --> 00:01:46.610
we've got OSPF Area 0
over here on the side.

30
00:01:46.610 --> 00:01:50.560
And NYEDGE2 doesn't really show
up in any of the OSPF areas.

31
00:01:50.560 --> 00:01:51.540
Right?

32
00:01:51.540 --> 00:01:52.990
Well, actually it does.

33
00:01:52.990 --> 00:02:00.370
These are the IPv4 OSPF areas but way over
here I've got IPv6 OSPF Area 0 in purple.

34
00:02:00.370 --> 00:02:03.750
And that purple cloud is extending
to encompass both of them.

35
00:02:03.750 --> 00:02:08.890
So I need to make sure that I'm
troubleshooting the IPv6 OSPF and

36
00:02:08.890 --> 00:02:10.110
not the IPv4.

37
00:02:10.110 --> 00:02:12.790
So I mentioned it wasn't forming
a neighbor relationship earlier.

38
00:02:12.790 --> 00:02:16.170
I don't remember, I might have checked for
IPv4 and not IPv6.

39
00:02:16.170 --> 00:02:18.570
So let's go back and revisit that.

40
00:02:18.570 --> 00:02:21.010
And really,
one side is as good as another.

41
00:02:21.010 --> 00:02:23.649
I'll start with NYEDGE1,
just because it's number one.

42
00:02:23.649 --> 00:02:25.370
And see what we're getting there.

43
00:02:25.370 --> 00:02:28.670
So let's just jump in on this guy and,
first off, I am gonna go ahead and

44
00:02:28.670 --> 00:02:30.880
verify that I can ping
across to the other side.

45
00:02:30.880 --> 00:02:35.520
If I do a show ipv6 int brief,
I can see my IPs.

46
00:02:35.520 --> 00:02:39.736
And on my serial interface, I've got this

47
00:02:39.736 --> 00:02:45.125
2001:D000:1::5, and on my GI0/0,

48
00:02:45.125 --> 00:02:49.941
I've got 2001:A001:1:1::2.

49
00:02:49.941 --> 00:02:53.204
And that's the interface we were working
with back in issue three trying to figure

50
00:02:53.204 --> 00:02:55.490
out why we weren't able to
ping between those two hosts.

51
00:02:55.490 --> 00:02:56.850
So we should still be able to ping.

52
00:02:56.850 --> 00:03:00.300
Here, let me test that out just
to make sure I'm not going crazy.

53
00:03:00.300 --> 00:03:05.338
So I'm gonna ping to 2001:A001:1:1::2 is

54
00:03:05.338 --> 00:03:10.180
the other side, and
sure enough I can ping across there.

55
00:03:10.180 --> 00:03:13.760
So I've got communications
on my GI0/0 interface.

56
00:03:13.760 --> 00:03:18.290
And I also have IPV6 configured
on this Serial0/0 interface.

57
00:03:18.290 --> 00:03:22.163
And those are the two interfaces that
I should be able to connect to EDGE2

58
00:03:22.163 --> 00:03:22.870
on, right?

59
00:03:22.870 --> 00:03:27.250
So, EDGE1 has that serial interface
that's direct as well as GI00.

60
00:03:27.250 --> 00:03:31.430
So I really should see two OSPF
neighbor adjacencies for that.

61
00:03:31.430 --> 00:03:36.536
So if I jump back to it,
we can jump in here and

62
00:03:36.536 --> 00:03:40.140
do a show ipv6 ospf neighbor.

63
00:03:40.140 --> 00:03:43.660
And when I do that, I can see I've
got two neighbor relationships.

64
00:03:43.660 --> 00:03:46.780
Now, it's showing a 32-bit IP address.

65
00:03:46.780 --> 00:03:47.570
Why is that?

66
00:03:47.570 --> 00:03:50.830
Well remember, with OSPF,
we might be routing for IPv6,

67
00:03:50.830 --> 00:03:54.930
but the router ID is still 32-bit, right?

68
00:03:54.930 --> 00:03:57.786
They never change that,
cuz there really wasn't a need.

69
00:03:57.786 --> 00:04:02.683
32-bit address, that gives you
the ability to do just billions of IPs or

70
00:04:02.683 --> 00:04:05.105
billions of router IDs in this case.

71
00:04:05.105 --> 00:04:09.160
And then nobody's ever gonna have more
routers than that in an OSPF environment.

72
00:04:09.160 --> 00:04:11.810
So there's no sense in changing number,
and they didn't, so

73
00:04:11.810 --> 00:04:16.070
we still see that 32-bit number right
there, which is not really an IP address.

74
00:04:16.070 --> 00:04:18.860
So the problem here is
I'm troubleshooting IPv6.

75
00:04:18.860 --> 00:04:22.690
I actually don't know the IPv4
address is that other router.

76
00:04:22.690 --> 00:04:26.720
I just know that I can get to v
on my Serial0/0/0 interface and

77
00:04:26.720 --> 00:04:28.270
my GI0/0 interface.

78
00:04:28.270 --> 00:04:30.195
So I'm gonna look over
here to the side and

79
00:04:30.195 --> 00:04:33.110
I can see that one of these
connection is on Serial0/0/1.

80
00:04:33.110 --> 00:04:34.690
That's gonna be to somebody else.

81
00:04:34.690 --> 00:04:38.110
But I do have a neighbor
relationship on Serial0/0/0.

82
00:04:38.110 --> 00:04:40.710
So as far as OSPF is concerned,

83
00:04:40.710 --> 00:04:47.550
I am able to see NYEDGE2 right
across this link, so that's working.

84
00:04:47.550 --> 00:04:49.442
But I don't see the GI0/0 interface,

85
00:04:49.442 --> 00:04:52.090
the one that's supposed
to be appearing up here.

86
00:04:52.090 --> 00:04:55.600
I should see two neighbor relationships
to the other side and I'm not.

87
00:04:55.600 --> 00:05:01.580
All right, so we fixed one issue
in the last troubleshooting issue,

88
00:05:01.580 --> 00:05:03.530
which was just reachability
between these two host.

89
00:05:03.530 --> 00:05:06.980
So I know I've got reachability,
I just did a ping to test that.

90
00:05:06.980 --> 00:05:09.010
Why isn't OSPF working?

91
00:05:09.010 --> 00:05:11.070
Well, let's see if this is a simple one.

92
00:05:11.070 --> 00:05:15.330
OSPF normally does a pretty good
job of logging into the router log,

93
00:05:15.330 --> 00:05:16.790
why it's not working?

94
00:05:16.790 --> 00:05:18.650
So if I jump in here to my config and

95
00:05:18.650 --> 00:05:23.490
just do a show logging,
I can look in the log and maybe I'll

96
00:05:23.490 --> 00:05:29.340
just see an OSPF warning popping up just
like I'm seeing on my screen right here.

97
00:05:29.340 --> 00:05:33.630
So what I'm seeing are a ton
of area mismatch warnings.

98
00:05:33.630 --> 00:05:38.191
And if I look at it the interface
is gabitEthernet0/0, for

99
00:05:38.191 --> 00:05:42.241
area 0.0.0.0, packet area 0.0.0.1.

100
00:05:42.241 --> 00:05:45.621
So, I can see my interface
is on area 0 and

101
00:05:45.621 --> 00:05:50.361
somebody is trying to peer with me and
they're in area 1.

102
00:05:50.361 --> 00:05:52.040
All right, so I've got a problem.

103
00:05:52.040 --> 00:05:56.150
Now if I go back to my diagram,
I can see right here,

104
00:05:56.150 --> 00:06:02.060
OSPF for IPv6 is Area 0,
I don't have an Area 1 for IPv6.

105
00:06:02.060 --> 00:06:06.640
So, more than likely NYEDGE2 is just
configured with the wrong Area ID

106
00:06:06.640 --> 00:06:09.620
on this interface right here,
on it's GI0/0, right?

107
00:06:09.620 --> 00:06:13.250
That's more than likely our issue,
and I just see that right in the logs.

108
00:06:13.250 --> 00:06:15.700
We could have found it other ways too,
right?

109
00:06:15.700 --> 00:06:17.580
It was in my logs, that makes it easy.

110
00:06:17.580 --> 00:06:19.931
If it wasn't there,
I could have done debugs, right?

111
00:06:19.931 --> 00:06:23.339
And debugging IPv6 or
SPF is just like IPv4.

112
00:06:23.339 --> 00:06:30.970
I could have done a little, well I wanna
let me make sure my console logging is on.

113
00:06:30.970 --> 00:06:36.395
And then we could do like debug ipv6 ospf

114
00:06:36.395 --> 00:06:41.660
adj to troubleshoot adjacencies.

115
00:06:41.660 --> 00:06:47.200
And debug ipv6 ospf packets, if I wanna
see the actual packets coming though.

116
00:06:47.200 --> 00:06:49.820
And when I debug those packets,
I'm gonna see if

117
00:06:49.820 --> 00:06:52.690
communication's coming in form the other
side, and I'll be able to spot it.

118
00:06:52.690 --> 00:06:55.360
But the problem with both of these
commands is just the amount of data we

119
00:06:55.360 --> 00:06:58.570
start getting back can be a little
bit on the excessive side.

120
00:06:58.570 --> 00:07:00.810
And so it can overwhelm your
connection if you're not careful.

121
00:07:00.810 --> 00:07:03.390
And so I don't normally use it that much.

122
00:07:03.390 --> 00:07:05.860
Instead the log had
exactly what we needed.

123
00:07:05.860 --> 00:07:07.810
But there's those messages popping up.

124
00:07:07.810 --> 00:07:11.590
And I'm just gonna do an undebug all and
get that turned off,

125
00:07:11.590 --> 00:07:13.220
and then we'll go fix the problem.

126
00:07:13.220 --> 00:07:17.800
All right, now the OSPF configuration for
IPv6 is not that bad.

127
00:07:17.800 --> 00:07:19.630
I'm gonna do a show running config.

128
00:07:19.630 --> 00:07:23.060
Basically for IPv6,
you go into each individual interface and

129
00:07:23.060 --> 00:07:24.990
that's where you define the area.

130
00:07:24.990 --> 00:07:27.000
So when I look at my config here.

131
00:07:27.000 --> 00:07:31.091
If I scroll through and
find my gigabit interfaces.

132
00:07:31.091 --> 00:07:35.416
Here is GI0/0 and
I can see IPv6 OSPF 100 area 0, so

133
00:07:35.416 --> 00:07:41.090
it's configured for area 0 and my serial
interface should be the same way.

134
00:07:41.090 --> 00:07:43.810
And sure enough, I see that is area 0 too.

135
00:07:43.810 --> 00:07:46.940
So this router does not
appear to be the issue.

136
00:07:46.940 --> 00:07:48.740
It's gonna be the other side,
and I already knew that,

137
00:07:48.740 --> 00:07:50.500
because of the way the log message reads.

138
00:07:50.500 --> 00:07:54.940
The log message is telling me I'm in
area 0.0.0.0, they're in area 0.0.0.1.

139
00:07:54.940 --> 00:07:59.330
I know area 0.0.0.1 doesn't exist,
and so they're the problem.

140
00:07:59.330 --> 00:08:03.000
So we need to jump over to our
other router and fix that.

141
00:08:03.000 --> 00:08:07.180
So if I jump over here to EDGE2,
we can get logged in.

142
00:08:07.180 --> 00:08:10.760
And what I expect to see,
is this guy is set for area 1.

143
00:08:10.760 --> 00:08:14.580
And there's a few other things I
could have done to troubleshoot this.

144
00:08:14.580 --> 00:08:19.610
Like instead of digging through the logs
or whatever, I could have done a show ipv6

145
00:08:19.610 --> 00:08:23.720
protocols, which would show the dynamic
routing protocols for ipv6.

146
00:08:23.720 --> 00:08:27.860
And right in here, I can see where
the serial interface is in area 0.

147
00:08:27.860 --> 00:08:30.050
And the gigabit interface is in area 1.

148
00:08:30.050 --> 00:08:32.330
So, I could have spotted it that way too.

149
00:08:32.330 --> 00:08:35.480
In fact, this guy should be getting
log messages about the mismatch,

150
00:08:35.480 --> 00:08:36.920
just like the other one was.

151
00:08:36.920 --> 00:08:37.900
But it'll be the other way around.

152
00:08:37.900 --> 00:08:40.250
It'll say were in area 1.

153
00:08:40.250 --> 00:08:41.180
Yeah, sure enough.

154
00:08:41.180 --> 00:08:43.060
We're in area 1 and they're in area 0.

155
00:08:43.060 --> 00:08:46.100
And so from there we just have to figure
out who it is that needs to be fixed.

156
00:08:47.310 --> 00:08:48.630
So it's gonna be this guy.

157
00:08:48.630 --> 00:08:51.639
So I'm gonna get into interface GI0/0.

158
00:08:51.639 --> 00:08:56.260
Where I'll say IPv6, ospf100.

159
00:08:56.260 --> 00:08:59.710
Oh, I'm saying 100, but I don't actually
know if that's the process number.

160
00:08:59.710 --> 00:09:03.360
Let' see, the process number is 100,
so we're okay.

161
00:09:03.360 --> 00:09:07.580
So process 100 area 0.

162
00:09:07.580 --> 00:09:11.880
And so that's gonna move that over to
area 0, that should solve the mismatch.

163
00:09:11.880 --> 00:09:17.210
Now these two gigabit
interfaces are both in area 0.

164
00:09:17.210 --> 00:09:19.060
And so an adjacency should form up.

165
00:09:19.060 --> 00:09:22.170
And we can always test
that right from here.

166
00:09:22.170 --> 00:09:28.170
So, we can just do a quick
show ipv6 ospf nei.

167
00:09:28.170 --> 00:09:31.892
And what I'm expecting to see is
a neighbor relationship on my Serial

168
00:09:31.892 --> 00:09:34.600
interface and
on my GigabitEthernet interface.

169
00:09:34.600 --> 00:09:38.720
And just to be on the safe side, I'm gonna
double check from NYEDGE1 over here.

170
00:09:38.720 --> 00:09:42.784
And I can see where it's been getting
those error messages popping up every,

171
00:09:42.784 --> 00:09:44.230
what would you say that is?

172
00:09:44.230 --> 00:09:49.030
About every, I don't know,
ten seconds, nine seconds or so.

173
00:09:49.030 --> 00:09:51.870
So, it's been popping up a lot, but
it's not popping up anymore, so

174
00:09:51.870 --> 00:09:53.820
the messages have stopped coming up.

175
00:09:53.820 --> 00:09:57.130
And if I do a show ipv6 ospf nei.

176
00:09:57.130 --> 00:10:02.870
Now I've got three adjacencies,
including the one on GigabitEthernet0/0.

177
00:10:02.870 --> 00:10:04.960
So, that fixed the problem.

178
00:10:04.960 --> 00:10:07.510
This another one of those, where we didn't
have to do a whole heck of a lot of

179
00:10:07.510 --> 00:10:10.860
troubleshooting here, because the log
message was extremely detailed.

180
00:10:10.860 --> 00:10:13.360
It told us exactly what
the problem was and

181
00:10:13.360 --> 00:10:15.980
we just had to figure out who was
the one that needed to be fixed.

182
00:10:15.980 --> 00:10:17.520
So, that takes care of this one.

183
00:10:17.520 --> 00:10:21.240
Again, OSPF, there's a lot of stuff that
has to match for an adjacency to build up.

184
00:10:21.240 --> 00:10:27.080
The area number, the stub flag, the hello
and dead timer intervals, authentication.

185
00:10:27.080 --> 00:10:29.530
Those are all different
things that have to match up.

186
00:10:29.530 --> 00:10:32.869
And if something like the area number
is wrong, they're not gonna match,

187
00:10:32.869 --> 00:10:36.270
they're not gonna build an adjacency and
we'll see what we had right here.

188
00:10:36.270 --> 00:10:40.150
Well that wraps this one up stay tuned,
we're gonna move into issue five next.

189
00:10:42.290 --> 00:10:48.349
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #5` from set #9. The trouble ticket states that "The route for NYWAN1s lopback 6 interface is not being propagated throughout the network, but loopback 16 and 26 are "
episodes.title: Set 9 Issue 5
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:09.205
[SOUND]
All right,

2
00:00:09.205 --> 00:00:13.350
it's that time again for another Cisco
troubleshooting segment here on ITPro TV.

3
00:00:13.350 --> 00:00:15.100
We're jumping into Set 9,

4
00:00:15.100 --> 00:00:19.080
Issue 5, and looks like we've got
another IPv6 routing issue on this one.

5
00:00:19.080 --> 00:00:21.110
The troubleshooting
ticket reads like this.

6
00:00:21.110 --> 00:00:26.396
It says, the route for
NYWAN1's loopback6 interface is not

7
00:00:26.396 --> 00:00:32.793
being propagated throughout the network,
but loopback16 and 26 are.

8
00:00:32.793 --> 00:00:33.340
Well, isn't that great.
So,

9
00:00:33.340 --> 00:00:36.510
looks like we got three loopback
interfaces on this one router.

10
00:00:36.510 --> 00:00:41.040
They're supposed to be advertised
out into, did it say a protocol?

11
00:00:41.040 --> 00:00:42.300
It's not saying a protocol,

12
00:00:42.300 --> 00:00:45.130
but I'm pretty sure it's gonna
be ospf because of our diagram.

13
00:00:45.130 --> 00:00:49.740
And for whatever reason,
two of the loop backs are showing up.

14
00:00:49.740 --> 00:00:51.180
One of them is not.

15
00:00:51.180 --> 00:00:52.670
We just need to find out why.

16
00:00:52.670 --> 00:00:55.120
Usually problems like this aren't that
hard because all you have to do is look at

17
00:00:55.120 --> 00:00:58.320
the ones that are working and see what's
different on the one that isn't working.

18
00:00:58.320 --> 00:01:01.900
But there could be things like
route maps in place, prefix lists.

19
00:01:01.900 --> 00:01:03.990
There could be bad route summarization.

20
00:01:03.990 --> 00:01:05.350
They could all stop this.

21
00:01:05.350 --> 00:01:10.750
Also, think about how a connected
interface gets into routing protocol.

22
00:01:10.750 --> 00:01:12.240
There's really only two ways.

23
00:01:12.240 --> 00:01:16.480
Either, one, you put that connected
interface into the routing protocol.

24
00:01:16.480 --> 00:01:20.770
Or two, you redistribute connected
interfaces into the routing protocol.

25
00:01:20.770 --> 00:01:22.290
So I'll need to look for
those two things also.

26
00:01:22.290 --> 00:01:24.620
Those are all some of the different
targets I wanna look for

27
00:01:24.620 --> 00:01:26.440
when I start troubleshooting this.

28
00:01:26.440 --> 00:01:30.280
But before I dive in, let's just
start with our old network topology.

29
00:01:30.280 --> 00:01:32.750
I'm gonna bring up the diagram here.

30
00:01:32.750 --> 00:01:35.360
And the router in
question today is NYWAN1,

31
00:01:35.360 --> 00:01:37.740
way over here on the edge of our network.

32
00:01:37.740 --> 00:01:42.695
And NYWAN1 only has one
connection inside of our network,

33
00:01:42.695 --> 00:01:47.530
Ser0/1/0, and it's in IPv6 OSPF Area 0.

34
00:01:47.530 --> 00:01:53.380
So it's connected interfaces are being
advertised into OSPF Area 0 and

35
00:01:53.380 --> 00:01:56.180
two out of the three are showing up and
two out of three is not bad.

36
00:01:56.180 --> 00:01:58.360
Maybe we just call it a day
right there and end the ticket.

37
00:01:58.360 --> 00:02:00.310
But I bet we can get that third one up and
going.

38
00:02:00.310 --> 00:02:01.220
So let's go take a look at it.

39
00:02:01.220 --> 00:02:06.080
I'm gonna jump over to NYWAN1 and
see what we've got going on.

40
00:02:06.080 --> 00:02:09.360
The first thing I wanna do is I just
wanna see what addresses those interfaces

41
00:02:09.360 --> 00:02:11.200
are using so I can recognize them.

42
00:02:11.200 --> 00:02:15.477
So I'm gonna do a show
IPv6 interface brief.

43
00:02:17.893 --> 00:02:20.380
And I'm gonna look for
those loopback interfaces.

44
00:02:20.380 --> 00:02:25.440
It was Loopback6, 16, and 26,
that's these guys right down here.

45
00:02:25.440 --> 00:02:29.183
And so looking at those interfaces,

46
00:02:29.183 --> 00:02:34.505
we've got a couple of different networks,
right?

47
00:02:34.505 --> 00:02:37.256
We've got the 2001:600::1 and

48
00:02:37.256 --> 00:02:42.670
2001:606:606::6 these are just
great numbers aren't they?

49
00:02:42.670 --> 00:02:48.647
On Loopback6, so those are a couple of
interfaces there or addresses there.

50
00:02:48.647 --> 00:02:54.550
On Loopback16 and on Loopback26
we've got 2001:1600 and :2600.

51
00:02:54.550 --> 00:02:59.140
So, supposedly these two are making
it throughout the network.

52
00:02:59.140 --> 00:03:00.340
And the others aren't.

53
00:03:00.340 --> 00:03:01.610
Let's go verify that.

54
00:03:01.610 --> 00:03:03.890
I'm gonna jump over to,
let's see, who's next in line?

55
00:03:03.890 --> 00:03:08.060
This guy should be neighbored up with,
we're neighboring between NYWAN1 and

56
00:03:08.060 --> 00:03:10.690
NYEDGE1, so
let's go see what NYEDGE1 is getting.

57
00:03:10.690 --> 00:03:15.069
That's a pretty good spot to look and
see what our network looks like.

58
00:03:15.069 --> 00:03:18.501
So, I'm just going to do
a show ipv6 route and

59
00:03:18.501 --> 00:03:23.429
I'll filter that down to ospf,
I just want to see ospf routes, and

60
00:03:23.429 --> 00:03:29.770
I can see sure enough I got 2001:1600 and
2001:2600, all right.

61
00:03:29.770 --> 00:03:32.310
Now there's a little bit more
information that I can get from here.

62
00:03:32.310 --> 00:03:34.920
For example,
these guys show up as OI routes.

63
00:03:36.290 --> 00:03:40.070
Okay, and
if you look up here in your legend,

64
00:03:40.070 --> 00:03:46.040
you'll see like O is just
an OSPF intra area route.

65
00:03:46.040 --> 00:03:50.360
In other words this came from another
router that's in the same area as me and

66
00:03:50.360 --> 00:03:54.210
there's OI which is inter area.

67
00:03:54.210 --> 00:03:59.130
This came from an OSPF router in
a different area than what I'm in.

68
00:03:59.130 --> 00:04:01.810
But then right beside that,
you'll see OU1 and OU2.

69
00:04:01.810 --> 00:04:03.320
Those are externals.

70
00:04:03.320 --> 00:04:05.490
And I'm not seeing OE1 or

71
00:04:05.490 --> 00:04:10.320
OE2, so that means the odds are, I'm not
dealing with a redistribution issue here.

72
00:04:10.320 --> 00:04:12.780
Cuz, if those connected routes
are being redistributed,

73
00:04:12.780 --> 00:04:15.590
these would show up as OE1 or OE2s, right?

74
00:04:15.590 --> 00:04:17.800
Cuz that's what an external
route would show up as.

75
00:04:17.800 --> 00:04:19.220
What they're showing is OIs.

76
00:04:19.220 --> 00:04:23.530
So, that means that those loopback
interfaces are directly added into OSPF

77
00:04:23.530 --> 00:04:26.590
they're just in a different area
than what NYEDGE1 happens to be in.

78
00:04:26.590 --> 00:04:29.060
All right, so
that's not necessarily a bad thing.

79
00:04:29.060 --> 00:04:31.100
Although I guess you could
say it's a bad thing.

80
00:04:31.100 --> 00:04:36.940
If I look at my topology
IPV6 OSPF area zero is on the map.

81
00:04:36.940 --> 00:04:39.140
I don't have any other areas on the map.

82
00:04:39.140 --> 00:04:39.640
Right?

83
00:04:39.640 --> 00:04:42.330
So everybody should be in Area 0.

84
00:04:42.330 --> 00:04:47.090
So that might be part of my problem too is
if these are in some kind of outside area.

85
00:04:47.090 --> 00:04:48.980
But it could just be
an undocumented area too.

86
00:04:48.980 --> 00:04:50.350
That's another possibility.

87
00:04:50.350 --> 00:04:53.330
The troubleshooting ticket at the end
of the day didn't really harp on areas.

88
00:04:53.330 --> 00:04:56.420
It really just said,
we need these routes to propagate out.

89
00:04:56.420 --> 00:04:59.550
And those two interfaces
are already propagating out.

90
00:04:59.550 --> 00:05:02.070
So let's just assume that those
two interfaces are right.

91
00:05:02.070 --> 00:05:05.410
Those two networks are okay so
whatever area they're set for,

92
00:05:05.410 --> 00:05:07.910
we just need to get that working for
the third loop back.

93
00:05:07.910 --> 00:05:09.100
Let's go look at this third loop back.

94
00:05:09.100 --> 00:05:11.270
We haven't actually seen much about it,
have we?

95
00:05:11.270 --> 00:05:12.360
I'm gonna go to NYWAN1,

96
00:05:12.360 --> 00:05:17.190
and I wanna get a better handle
on how this network is set up.

97
00:05:17.190 --> 00:05:19.410
So I'm gonna do a show ipv6 protocols,

98
00:05:19.410 --> 00:05:23.710
which will give me a nice little
summary of how SPF is set up.

99
00:05:23.710 --> 00:05:26.920
And I can see here that we're
running ospf process ID 100.

100
00:05:26.920 --> 00:05:32.860
I've got a router ID and
I've got two interfaces in a normal area.

101
00:05:32.860 --> 00:05:34.438
No stubs and no nssas.

102
00:05:34.438 --> 00:05:40.320
Okay, right there, I only see two
interfaces in the normal, I should

103
00:05:40.320 --> 00:05:44.020
see three, I should have those three loop
backs and that's not even counting like

104
00:05:44.020 --> 00:05:48.670
the serial interface, right, which in
theory should get us up to four right?

105
00:05:48.670 --> 00:05:51.570
But if they're in the same
area that will come down, and

106
00:05:51.570 --> 00:05:54.500
I do have two normal area's here.

107
00:05:54.500 --> 00:05:57.630
So, I assume that I've got more than
one interface in the same area.

108
00:05:57.630 --> 00:06:01.700
Looking at it here I've got
the serial interface in area zero and

109
00:06:01.700 --> 00:06:03.560
sure enough those
loopbacks are in area one.

110
00:06:03.560 --> 00:06:08.310
So I've only got two areas and that's
why my number of areas is up to two.

111
00:06:08.310 --> 00:06:10.140
Serial 010 is in Area 0.

112
00:06:10.140 --> 00:06:12.470
Loopback 16, Loopback 26, are in Area 1.

113
00:06:12.470 --> 00:06:16.090
Loopback 6, is not here.

114
00:06:16.090 --> 00:06:19.810
It should be in Area 1 we presume,
but it isn't.

115
00:06:19.810 --> 00:06:21.830
Okay, so what does that mean?

116
00:06:21.830 --> 00:06:23.750
Well, the interface could be shut down.

117
00:06:23.750 --> 00:06:25.710
The interface could be not configured.

118
00:06:25.710 --> 00:06:27.110
The interface might not exist.

119
00:06:27.110 --> 00:06:29.850
There's all sorts of stuff like that but
I know the interface existed.

120
00:06:29.850 --> 00:06:31.990
Then I can do a show run.

121
00:06:31.990 --> 00:06:37.110
For interface lo6, and
pull it up, and see where it is.

122
00:06:37.110 --> 00:06:38.570
Now, I do have an ospf command here.

123
00:06:38.570 --> 00:06:41.840
Ipv6 ospf network point to point.

124
00:06:41.840 --> 00:06:45.910
But I don't have a command
putting it in an area.

125
00:06:45.910 --> 00:06:48.840
Remember, when you configure ipv6 for
ospf.

126
00:06:48.840 --> 00:06:50.770
it's a little bit different that IPv4.

127
00:06:50.770 --> 00:06:55.780
In IPv4, I can add an interface to an area
right here from the interface if I want.

128
00:06:55.780 --> 00:07:00.760
I can say IP OSPF and a process number,
area, and an area number.

129
00:07:00.760 --> 00:07:02.860
And then I'll put that
interface in the area.

130
00:07:02.860 --> 00:07:06.400
But in IPv4 I can also do
it in OSPF's configuration.

131
00:07:06.400 --> 00:07:08.490
Right, but IPV6 you can't.

132
00:07:08.490 --> 00:07:10.390
You have to do it on the interface and

133
00:07:10.390 --> 00:07:13.120
looking at this interface
it doesn't have it.

134
00:07:13.120 --> 00:07:15.740
So this interface is actually
not participating in OSPF.

135
00:07:15.740 --> 00:07:17.790
That's it, plain and simple.

136
00:07:17.790 --> 00:07:20.240
It's not being advertised because
it's not participating in it.

137
00:07:20.240 --> 00:07:24.600
Now it could be being redistributed, but
I didn't see any redistributed routes so

138
00:07:24.600 --> 00:07:25.940
I don't think that's the case.

139
00:07:25.940 --> 00:07:30.240
But let's do a show run and
look for the OSPF section and

140
00:07:30.240 --> 00:07:33.290
we'll see if were doing any
redistribution and we're not.

141
00:07:33.290 --> 00:07:35.540
I just have IPV6 router OSPF 100.

142
00:07:35.540 --> 00:07:37.400
And that's it.

143
00:07:37.400 --> 00:07:38.840
And nothing else attached to that.

144
00:07:38.840 --> 00:07:40.530
Right?
If we do a show run and

145
00:07:40.530 --> 00:07:46.000
begin with that line you'll see
that that config is pretty simple.

146
00:07:46.000 --> 00:07:48.000
And it usually is with IPV6.

147
00:07:48.000 --> 00:07:50.450
You might have a static
router ID set here, but

148
00:07:50.450 --> 00:07:54.050
otherwise we don't really set much
under the routing process itself.

149
00:07:54.050 --> 00:07:56.080
Static router IDs and redistributions.

150
00:07:56.080 --> 00:07:59.170
That's kind of what will show up here,
maybe route maps for neighbors.

151
00:07:59.170 --> 00:08:03.310
But, if it's empty like that, everything
else boils down to the interface.

152
00:08:03.310 --> 00:08:08.120
And if I look at loopback 16 or
loopback 26,

153
00:08:08.120 --> 00:08:13.020
see how they both have an area
assignment on the interface?

154
00:08:13.020 --> 00:08:16.950
But when I looked at Loopback6, it didn't.

155
00:08:16.950 --> 00:08:21.450
And so if we add that interface, into,

156
00:08:21.450 --> 00:08:25.660
what was it OSPF100, yep.

157
00:08:25.660 --> 00:08:31.267
So I need to say IPv6 OSPF100

158
00:08:31.267 --> 00:08:35.610
area 1 that's gonna move it into area
1 just like the other loopbacks and

159
00:08:35.610 --> 00:08:37.540
that should bring it into
the ospf environment.

160
00:08:37.540 --> 00:08:40.190
It should start getting
advertised across the network and

161
00:08:40.190 --> 00:08:41.020
that should solve our problem.

162
00:08:41.020 --> 00:08:45.850
So somebody just left the interface
out and that's kinda that.

163
00:08:45.850 --> 00:08:49.210
So I'm gonna do a show ipv6 protocols.

164
00:08:49.210 --> 00:08:52.990
And let's verify, we should still have two
areas, right, I didn't add any more areas.

165
00:08:52.990 --> 00:08:56.540
But now I can see I've got
three interfaces in Area 1.

166
00:08:56.540 --> 00:09:00.830
And, if I jump over to NYEDGE 1.

167
00:09:00.830 --> 00:09:05.060
Before, it was only
showing those two routes.

168
00:09:05.060 --> 00:09:09.300
Now, now we have four.

169
00:09:09.300 --> 00:09:09.850
Right?

170
00:09:09.850 --> 00:09:15.240
There was the 2001:600 and the 2001:606
which are both now showing up.

171
00:09:15.240 --> 00:09:18.600
As well as the 1600 and
2600 that were there previously.

172
00:09:18.600 --> 00:09:23.510
And they all show up as OI, so now it's
nice and normal and propagated out.

173
00:09:23.510 --> 00:09:26.520
So the ticket, so they weren't
propagating out, we found out why,

174
00:09:26.520 --> 00:09:29.200
that interface wasn't
added to the OSPF process.

175
00:09:29.200 --> 00:09:33.260
Once we did that, it's now part of
area one, and it gets advertised out.

176
00:09:33.260 --> 00:09:34.750
That really resolves that one.

177
00:09:34.750 --> 00:09:37.640
The other option would've been I
could've redistributed it in but

178
00:09:37.640 --> 00:09:39.860
since the other two interfaces
weren't redistributed,

179
00:09:39.860 --> 00:09:42.050
we just kinda followed what
they were already doing.

180
00:09:42.050 --> 00:09:43.510
They probably had a reason for that.

181
00:09:43.510 --> 00:09:46.550
But, again,
more than one solution to a problem.

182
00:09:46.550 --> 00:09:48.490
This one was probably
the path of least resistance.

183
00:09:48.490 --> 00:09:49.890
But that one wraps this up.

184
00:09:49.890 --> 00:09:51.040
Hope you guys enjoyed it.

185
00:09:51.040 --> 00:09:53.780
Stay tuned,
we've got more troubleshooting issues.

186
00:09:53.780 --> 00:09:59.200
Coming up next.

187
00:10:00.813 --> 00:10:01.706
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #6` from set #9. The trouble ticket states that "You are unable to ping loopback 6 on NYWAN1 from NYEDGE2, you can ping the other two loopback interfaces, but not this one "
episodes.title: Set 9 Issue 6
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.038 --> 00:00:04.998
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.418 --> 00:00:12.773
All right, welcome back for the final
Cisco troubleshooting ticket in Set 9,

3
00:00:12.773 --> 00:00:17.460
we're on Set 9 Issue 6, and we've got some
more reachability issues to deal with.

4
00:00:17.460 --> 00:00:24.920
This ticket reads, you are unable to
ping loopback 6 on NYWAN1 from NYEDGE2.

5
00:00:24.920 --> 00:00:29.040
You can ping the other two loopback
interfaces, but not this one.

6
00:00:29.040 --> 00:00:34.480
Well, if you remember from Issue 5, we
had three loopback interfaces on NYWAN1,

7
00:00:34.480 --> 00:00:37.250
two of them were showing up on OSPF,
one wasn't.

8
00:00:37.250 --> 00:00:39.160
Well, we fixed that, so
all three are in OSPF.

9
00:00:39.160 --> 00:00:43.200
Now they're saying if we go to one
of our EDGE routers and we try and

10
00:00:43.200 --> 00:00:46.720
ping the three addresses,
two of them work and one of them doesn't,

11
00:00:46.720 --> 00:00:48.720
which does seem a little odd.

12
00:00:48.720 --> 00:00:51.580
So let's go and
see if we can't verify that, all right?

13
00:00:51.580 --> 00:00:52.890
Now I wanna start on my topologies, so

14
00:00:52.890 --> 00:00:56.010
we can make sure we understand
the path that we're going through.

15
00:00:56.010 --> 00:00:59.530
In that last troubleshooting ticket, the
three loopback interfaces were right here

16
00:00:59.530 --> 00:01:05.800
on NYWAN1 and they were advertising out,
and I did my verification here on NYEDGE1.

17
00:01:05.800 --> 00:01:08.130
I never actually looked at any
of the other routers out there,

18
00:01:08.130 --> 00:01:11.920
I just used that one as my test and
I saw the routes show up.

19
00:01:11.920 --> 00:01:15.420
Well, they're saying,
if I go all the way over here to NYEDGE2

20
00:01:16.610 --> 00:01:19.800
that I can ping two of the networks and
not the third one.

21
00:01:19.800 --> 00:01:22.530
They actually don't tell me, although
they tell me it's loopback six, so

22
00:01:22.530 --> 00:01:25.150
I at least know the IP range for it.

23
00:01:25.150 --> 00:01:28.180
If you didn't watch the last issue, then
you might not know those IP ranges, so

24
00:01:28.180 --> 00:01:29.510
let's jump over to NYWAN1 and

25
00:01:29.510 --> 00:01:33.480
see those real quick before we go
into the rest of the troubleshooting.

26
00:01:33.480 --> 00:01:37.572
In NYLAN1, there's three loopback
interfaces that they're talking about,

27
00:01:37.572 --> 00:01:41.380
loopback 6, 16, and 26.

28
00:01:41.380 --> 00:01:45.660
If I do a show IPV6 interface brief and

29
00:01:45.660 --> 00:01:50.938
look at the interfaces, here we can
see loopback 6, 16, and 26, all right?

30
00:01:50.938 --> 00:01:56.520
These two down here were the ones
that were working fine before,

31
00:01:56.520 --> 00:02:00.750
and apparently they're
still working just fine.

32
00:02:00.750 --> 00:02:03.410
We should be able to ping 2001:1600::1 and
2001:2600::1, but

33
00:02:03.410 --> 00:02:06.880
then we've got Loopback6 up here, and

34
00:02:06.880 --> 00:02:12.630
it actually has two addresses and they're
telling me that we can't ping those.

35
00:02:12.630 --> 00:02:13.610
They should show up in OSPF.

36
00:02:13.610 --> 00:02:17.100
They did when we fixed it at the end
of the last troubleshooting problem,

37
00:02:17.100 --> 00:02:17.810
but who knows?

38
00:02:17.810 --> 00:02:22.600
Maybe they don't, so let's jump over
to NYEDGE2 and see what we've got.

39
00:02:22.600 --> 00:02:26.180
The first thing I wanna verify, just
because I didn't do it on the last ticket,

40
00:02:26.180 --> 00:02:29.370
was whether or not we even learned
the routes on this one, right?

41
00:02:29.370 --> 00:02:33.290
It may not know those routes yet, so
we just need to get that verified, so

42
00:02:33.290 --> 00:02:40.870
I'll do a show ipv6 route, and
I'm just gonna filter down to ospf.

43
00:02:40.870 --> 00:02:45.610
That's all I need to see, and, well,
actually they're all showing up.

44
00:02:45.610 --> 00:02:49.870
I've got 2001:600, 2001:606, 2001:1600,
and 2001:2600, there they are.

45
00:02:49.870 --> 00:02:54.250
Those are the three loopback interfaces,

46
00:02:54.250 --> 00:02:58.270
these are Loopback 16 and
26, and these are Loopback6.

47
00:02:58.270 --> 00:03:02.410
All right, so we've got routes and the
routes all go to the same place, right?

48
00:03:02.410 --> 00:03:06.470
See the destination address here,
it all ends in D3BO,

49
00:03:06.470 --> 00:03:10.220
all four of those D3BO,
all out Gigabit Ethernet 0/0.

50
00:03:10.220 --> 00:03:13.010
If one route's good, any of the other
routes should be good, too,

51
00:03:13.010 --> 00:03:15.500
so I bet we're not dealing
with a routing problem.

52
00:03:15.500 --> 00:03:16.920
We could, but

53
00:03:16.920 --> 00:03:20.270
we're probably more than likely dealing
with something a little bit different.

54
00:03:20.270 --> 00:03:23.260
Maybe it's unidirectional routing, maybe
the other side doesn't know how to get

55
00:03:23.260 --> 00:03:26.670
back to us, but I haven't looked at
RIP range yet, that could be it.

56
00:03:26.670 --> 00:03:28.590
There could be access lists or

57
00:03:28.590 --> 00:03:31.910
VLAN ACLs in between,
there could be VLAN issues, right?

58
00:03:31.910 --> 00:03:34.360
We might be learning these routes but
we're on the wrong VLAN.

59
00:03:34.360 --> 00:03:36.380
There's all sorts of stuff
that it could be, so

60
00:03:36.380 --> 00:03:38.640
let's see if we can't figure that out.

61
00:03:38.640 --> 00:03:42.080
Now I don't wanna just trust that
these pings won't go through, so

62
00:03:42.080 --> 00:03:43.810
I'm gonna do some quick tests.

63
00:03:43.810 --> 00:03:48.610
I'm gonna try and
ping 2001:600::1, that's one of

64
00:03:48.610 --> 00:03:55.080
the interfaces that are present on
Loopback6, and I don't get there, right?

65
00:03:55.080 --> 00:03:58.440
See, I get a bunch of As in return so
I'm not getting there, and

66
00:03:58.440 --> 00:04:08.520
if I tried 2001:606:606::6,
I don't get there either, right?

67
00:04:08.520 --> 00:04:10.070
And those were the two IPs.

68
00:04:10.070 --> 00:04:14.600
Let's just verify I still got that right,
and yes, those are the two IPs that I

69
00:04:14.600 --> 00:04:19.110
just tried to ping right there and
I didn't get to either one of them.

70
00:04:19.110 --> 00:04:23.860
So then, I'm going to test the two that

71
00:04:23.860 --> 00:04:28.630
they're telling me are working.

72
00:04:28.630 --> 00:04:35.290
So I wanna ping 2001:1600::1, and I wanna
ping 2001:2600::1, and I get there, too.

73
00:04:35.290 --> 00:04:38.700
All right, well,
I'm getting to some of the networks,

74
00:04:38.700 --> 00:04:40.660
I'm not getting to others, right?

75
00:04:40.660 --> 00:04:44.660
So because they're different networks
this could be a routing issue, right?

76
00:04:44.660 --> 00:04:46.600
I'm not just not getting
routed to the right place, or

77
00:04:46.600 --> 00:04:50.220
it could be something else, so
let's do a little more troubleshooting.

78
00:04:50.220 --> 00:04:53.710
I need to understand the path that
I'm taking to get to these networks.

79
00:04:53.710 --> 00:04:59.000
When I look at my diagram, I know that
I have a route that sends me to gi00.

80
00:04:59.000 --> 00:05:04.340
It sends me out this route, and these
switches down here are just doing layer 2.

81
00:05:04.340 --> 00:05:07.100
Well, actually we do have an OSPF
area down there, but it's IPv4,

82
00:05:07.100 --> 00:05:11.880
so these switches down here aren't
running IPv6 in this model, and so

83
00:05:11.880 --> 00:05:15.910
I should be jumping
straight over to NYEDGE1.

84
00:05:15.910 --> 00:05:20.030
From there, going down to
OSPF Area 0 down to NYWAN1, so we

85
00:05:20.030 --> 00:05:24.240
should just be hopping right across these
links, but let me verify that real quick.

86
00:05:24.240 --> 00:05:28.780
On NYEDGE2, I saw on the routing
table who my next hop was, and

87
00:05:28.780 --> 00:05:32.330
it was this link local
address that ended in D3B0.

88
00:05:32.330 --> 00:05:37.150
I need to verify that that is NYEDGE1,
so I know my path, and

89
00:05:37.150 --> 00:05:39.412
I'm gonna go to NYEDGE1 and
verify that right here.

90
00:05:39.412 --> 00:05:43.920
We'll just do a show

91
00:05:44.920 --> 00:05:51.380
ipv6 int brief, and when I look at
the Serial Interface, it ends in D3B0.

92
00:05:51.380 --> 00:05:55.612
When I look at the GigabitEthernet
interface, it ends in D3B0.

93
00:05:55.612 --> 00:05:57.980
All right, I got myself into
a little bit of trouble here, so

94
00:05:57.980 --> 00:06:03.370
one of the problems we have with
IPV6 is it can do what's called a,

95
00:06:03.370 --> 00:06:05.140
well, they used to call anycast addresses.

96
00:06:05.140 --> 00:06:09.080
Now they're just global addresses,
where you can have one address

97
00:06:09.080 --> 00:06:13.730
you answer to on more than one interface,
so when I look at this,

98
00:06:13.730 --> 00:06:17.680
I've got that same link local address
on every one of these interfaces.

99
00:06:17.680 --> 00:06:20.830
The address doesn't actually
tell me where I went, all right?

100
00:06:20.830 --> 00:06:25.910
But I do know, I know because when I
looked at my routing table back here.

101
00:06:25.910 --> 00:06:32.220
The next hop isn't just the address,
it's also the interface, okay?

102
00:06:32.220 --> 00:06:35.730
And they do that because they know this
address might be used on more than one

103
00:06:35.730 --> 00:06:37.650
interface, exactly as it is now.

104
00:06:37.650 --> 00:06:40.180
And I'm going out my
GigabitEthernet interface, right?

105
00:06:40.180 --> 00:06:45.820
And so what that tells me is I'm
not crossing this serial link.

106
00:06:45.820 --> 00:06:48.220
And I'm definitely not leaving
the Gi0/0 interface and

107
00:06:48.220 --> 00:06:50.480
then magically coming in
the serial interface here.

108
00:06:50.480 --> 00:06:53.510
So, I know the traffic
is going down this way.

109
00:06:53.510 --> 00:06:58.980
Around here, around here, back up to
EDGE1 and then over to the destination.

110
00:06:58.980 --> 00:07:00.920
Okay, so
that's the path that I'm following.

111
00:07:00.920 --> 00:07:05.360
So there could be an access
control list or a VLAN ACL.

112
00:07:05.360 --> 00:07:09.310
Anywhere along that path,
that's stopping me.

113
00:07:09.310 --> 00:07:09.970
Okay?

114
00:07:09.970 --> 00:07:13.000
Well, these switches down here,
I'm pretty sure they're not routing,

115
00:07:13.000 --> 00:07:17.450
because I'm on a sub-net,
that's the same sub-net as over here.

116
00:07:17.450 --> 00:07:19.530
So there is probably a VLAN in the mix, so

117
00:07:19.530 --> 00:07:24.910
I'm crossing a VLAN to get to the other
side, and that is actually working.

118
00:07:24.910 --> 00:07:27.650
I know that's working because
when I did the pings for

119
00:07:27.650 --> 00:07:31.540
the other two subnets they went through,
right, and they went over that same link.

120
00:07:31.540 --> 00:07:34.700
So if I'm on a VLAN I know
I'm on the right VLAN.

121
00:07:34.700 --> 00:07:37.220
But what I don't know is
if there's a VLAN ACL

122
00:07:37.220 --> 00:07:38.650
because there could be
one that's blocking.

123
00:07:38.650 --> 00:07:41.610
But VLAN ACLs normally block
based on Mac address and

124
00:07:41.610 --> 00:07:45.790
it would usually block all of my traffic
and not just one little thing, but

125
00:07:45.790 --> 00:07:49.680
there's a really quick way that we
can test to see if we have an ACL.

126
00:07:49.680 --> 00:07:52.630
We can just do a show run config and
look for the keyword filter.

127
00:07:52.630 --> 00:07:56.400
VLAN ACLs use that filter as a great way
to spot that real quick on these guys.

128
00:07:56.400 --> 00:08:00.140
So I can just jump to each switch and

129
00:08:00.140 --> 00:08:05.440
do a show run and
filter that to use the include command and

130
00:08:05.440 --> 00:08:08.600
just include any line
with the word filter.

131
00:08:08.600 --> 00:08:11.840
And if there's a VLAN filter
it'll turn up, right.

132
00:08:11.840 --> 00:08:13.070
But I don't see one there.

133
00:08:13.070 --> 00:08:16.346
And go to NYCORE2 and
we'll look for the same thing.

134
00:08:19.678 --> 00:08:22.610
And so I'm just looking for
that word filter.

135
00:08:22.610 --> 00:08:24.290
And we got nothing.

136
00:08:24.290 --> 00:08:26.420
And the last one is access one.

137
00:08:26.420 --> 00:08:32.630
And we'll do the same thing.

138
00:08:32.630 --> 00:08:33.310
And no.

139
00:08:33.310 --> 00:08:36.310
OK, so we're not dealing
with a VLAN acl on this one.

140
00:08:36.310 --> 00:08:40.190
And I know what you're thinking is that
maybe we've got a spamming tree issue or

141
00:08:40.190 --> 00:08:41.820
a VLAN trunk or whatever.

142
00:08:41.820 --> 00:08:45.500
But anything at layer two would it
block my ability to get back to all

143
00:08:45.500 --> 00:08:47.150
three loopback interfaces?

144
00:08:47.150 --> 00:08:51.020
And I can get to two out of
the three loopback interfaces, so

145
00:08:51.020 --> 00:08:53.390
that means layer two is pretty
much out of the question.

146
00:08:53.390 --> 00:08:56.990
Ive got layer three traffic
that's making it through.

147
00:08:56.990 --> 00:08:58.680
Two out of three times, right?

148
00:08:58.680 --> 00:09:02.730
So if it's not these guys,
I need to start looking at routers and

149
00:09:02.730 --> 00:09:04.800
the first router in my path is NYEDGE1.

150
00:09:04.800 --> 00:09:06.930
The second router's my destination.

151
00:09:06.930 --> 00:09:08.860
The problem is not normally
at the destination but

152
00:09:08.860 --> 00:09:11.030
I could have an incoming ACL here or

153
00:09:11.030 --> 00:09:16.640
I could have some static route that's
overriding the return trip to NYEDGE2.

154
00:09:16.640 --> 00:09:18.180
And sending my traffic off into nowhere.

155
00:09:18.180 --> 00:09:20.410
I don't even know where
this traffic stops.

156
00:09:20.410 --> 00:09:23.740
And a great way to spot where the traffic
stops is to use a tool like Traceroute.

157
00:09:23.740 --> 00:09:27.980
Traceroute will show me, am I getting
through EDGE1 and dying down here or

158
00:09:27.980 --> 00:09:29.890
am I dying right NYEDGE1.

159
00:09:29.890 --> 00:09:34.890
And so if I go back to NYEDGE2,
we can test that theory out and

160
00:09:34.890 --> 00:09:35.870
see where it's dying.

161
00:09:35.870 --> 00:09:41.950
Now the trace route utility
works with both IPv4 and IPv6.

162
00:09:41.950 --> 00:09:48.008
So I'm gonna do a trace route to a network
that I know I can get to, 2001:1600::1.

163
00:09:48.008 --> 00:09:53.007
And I'm gonna try and trace the route
to that, and it's gonna think,

164
00:09:53.007 --> 00:09:57.760
and it's gonna think some more,
and it's gonna think some more.

165
00:09:57.760 --> 00:09:59.040
Apparently it's gonna take forever.

166
00:09:59.040 --> 00:10:00.890
So the first hob should be NYEDGE1.

167
00:10:00.890 --> 00:10:05.990
So I should get a response back on that
and then it's gonna jump down to NYWAN1.

168
00:10:05.990 --> 00:10:13.510
So here I get my first response
from 2001:A001:1:1::1.

169
00:10:13.510 --> 00:10:16.120
And then I get a response
from the other end, right?

170
00:10:16.120 --> 00:10:18.450
2001 colon D zero zero
colon one colon colon one.

171
00:10:18.450 --> 00:10:21.550
All right, so,
my trace shot made it through just fine.

172
00:10:21.550 --> 00:10:23.190
I saw both hops.

173
00:10:23.190 --> 00:10:28.420
I'm gonna repeat that except this
time I'm gonna do 2001 colon 600.

174
00:10:28.420 --> 00:10:33.750
That was one of the addresses
that I couldn't get to before.

175
00:10:33.750 --> 00:10:36.330
And I just wanna see what
the trace route looks like here.

176
00:10:36.330 --> 00:10:37.980
Do I make it to the first router?

177
00:10:37.980 --> 00:10:38.780
Yes or no.

178
00:10:38.780 --> 00:10:40.330
If I don't even make it
to the first router,

179
00:10:40.330 --> 00:10:44.140
then we more than likely have an ACL
that's blocking our traffic on the way in.

180
00:10:44.140 --> 00:10:48.010
If I do make it to the first router,
and I don't make it to the second one,

181
00:10:48.010 --> 00:10:50.960
I could still have a problem
on the first router but

182
00:10:50.960 --> 00:10:52.530
I more than likely have
a problem on the second router.

183
00:10:52.530 --> 00:10:55.390
On the first router, we could be
filtering traffic on its way out or

184
00:10:55.390 --> 00:10:56.500
even route it inside of it.

185
00:10:56.500 --> 00:10:58.000
There's various things
that could happen there.

186
00:10:59.740 --> 00:11:02.040
Well now that's an interesting one.

187
00:11:02.040 --> 00:11:06.580
My trace route made it through,
but my ping didn't.

188
00:11:07.630 --> 00:11:13.690
So when I do a ping, I get success rate
0 percent I'm not making it through but

189
00:11:13.690 --> 00:11:16.430
my trace route went through just fine.

190
00:11:16.430 --> 00:11:17.280
What the heck is that?

191
00:11:18.320 --> 00:11:19.990
All right.
Well I can only think of one scenario

192
00:11:19.990 --> 00:11:21.240
where this happens.

193
00:11:21.240 --> 00:11:24.250
And that would be if I had an access list.

194
00:11:24.250 --> 00:11:29.410
Because pings use ICMP and they actually
use something different than traceroute.

195
00:11:29.410 --> 00:11:33.520
So we could have an ACL that's
filtering ICMP and not anything else.

196
00:11:33.520 --> 00:11:37.270
In fact, now that I say that out loud,
I think back to,

197
00:11:37.270 --> 00:11:40.380
we just had a troubleshooting
issue a couple of tickets ago

198
00:11:40.380 --> 00:11:42.390
where we had some reachability issues.

199
00:11:42.390 --> 00:11:46.110
And there was an ACL on NYEDGE1
that was filtering ICMP.

200
00:11:46.110 --> 00:11:47.470
I had forgotten all about it.

201
00:11:47.470 --> 00:11:48.990
Let's go take a look at that.

202
00:11:48.990 --> 00:11:50.990
It was on NYEDGE1.

203
00:11:50.990 --> 00:11:55.990
And if I remember right,
we couldn't ping between the hosts and

204
00:11:55.990 --> 00:11:59.320
we had to add an extra entry
to it to get it to function.

205
00:11:59.320 --> 00:12:01.190
And it was right here on edge one.

206
00:12:01.190 --> 00:12:02.150
If I remember right, it was on.

207
00:12:02.150 --> 00:12:04.600
Well, here, we can just do a show,
run, and config, and

208
00:12:04.600 --> 00:12:05.810
spot which interface it was on.

209
00:12:05.810 --> 00:12:08.560
I think it was on the gigabit interface,
if I remember right.

210
00:12:08.560 --> 00:12:11.820
So this is where it's important to
remember your tickets as you go through.

211
00:12:11.820 --> 00:12:14.430
But if I look at, there it is.

212
00:12:14.430 --> 00:12:17.370
On gigabit ethernet 0/0.

213
00:12:17.370 --> 00:12:20.690
There it is, IPv6 traffic-filter BLOCK in.

214
00:12:20.690 --> 00:12:22.820
And we saw that,
it was in either issue number one or

215
00:12:22.820 --> 00:12:23.960
issue number two for this set.

216
00:12:23.960 --> 00:12:27.760
So we had seen that before and
had to work with it a little bit and

217
00:12:27.760 --> 00:12:31.590
if I keep scrolling down,
I'll get to where that is defined.

218
00:12:31.590 --> 00:12:32.990
There it goes.

219
00:12:32.990 --> 00:12:36.886
And it's permitting ICMP host.

220
00:12:36.886 --> 00:12:46.320
2001:A001:1:1::2 to ping 2::1, that was
allowing edge two to ping edge one.

221
00:12:46.320 --> 00:12:50.130
And then it's allowing us to ping 1600 and
2600,

222
00:12:50.130 --> 00:12:55.490
but no 600, and
then it's blocking every other ping.

223
00:12:55.490 --> 00:13:00.140
So that's almost a guarantee right there,
we just, we're missing a line, right, so

224
00:13:00.140 --> 00:13:02.400
we need to get in here and add this entry.

225
00:13:02.400 --> 00:13:05.730
Add these other IPs to
be able to ping to them.

226
00:13:05.730 --> 00:13:08.950
Now in order to do that, we're going to
need to know some sequence numbers, so

227
00:13:08.950 --> 00:13:10.470
let's take a look at that ACL this way.

228
00:13:10.470 --> 00:13:12.980
I'm just going to do
a show access dash list,

229
00:13:12.980 --> 00:13:15.430
because that will display
the sequence numbers for me.

230
00:13:15.430 --> 00:13:17.140
So here are the two being permitted,

231
00:13:17.140 --> 00:13:20.020
you'll see that they're
sequence numbers 20 and 30 So

232
00:13:20.020 --> 00:13:24.180
I just need to add these new lines in
between there or around them or whatever.

233
00:13:24.180 --> 00:13:27.370
So maybe I'll make like,
I don't know, 15 and 16, or

234
00:13:27.370 --> 00:13:30.860
something to make them appear before that.

235
00:13:30.860 --> 00:13:33.390
So I'll get into my configuration.

236
00:13:33.390 --> 00:13:39.460
I'll do, ipv6 access-list block.

237
00:13:41.470 --> 00:13:49.030
And then I'll do sequence, and we're
gonna do a, we'll do 15 permit icmp and

238
00:13:50.460 --> 00:13:55.300
I'll just say any host, cuz we're supposed
to be able to reach to the sub aside.

239
00:13:55.300 --> 00:13:58.380
And I'm gonna put in 2001:600 Colon,
colon and

240
00:13:58.380 --> 00:14:01.090
my head's gonna get on top of this
cuz it's kind of a long command.

241
00:14:01.090 --> 00:14:03.730
But 2001:600::1.
That was the IP assigned to the other side

242
00:14:03.730 --> 00:14:08.320
and I guess I could do
the whole network instead

243
00:14:08.320 --> 00:14:13.260
of just the host, but
I'll leave it as the host.

244
00:14:13.260 --> 00:14:17.600
That's what the question asked, that to
do is to be able to ping that one host.

245
00:14:17.600 --> 00:14:20.460
So I'm gonna permit that and

246
00:14:20.460 --> 00:14:26.130
then I'm gonna do the same thing for
that 606:606::6.

247
00:14:26.130 --> 00:14:28.930
That was the other address, and

248
00:14:28.930 --> 00:14:31.650
I need to give it a difference sequence
number or I"m gonna kinda break this.

249
00:14:33.150 --> 00:14:34.050
There we go.

250
00:14:34.050 --> 00:14:35.300
So I've got lines 15 and 16.

251
00:14:35.300 --> 00:14:38.260
So these two lines right here

252
00:14:38.260 --> 00:14:42.010
are going to add the ability
to ping those other Loopbacks.

253
00:14:42.010 --> 00:14:45.580
And if I do a show access-list
to look at the completed one,

254
00:14:46.580 --> 00:14:48.530
there they all are nice and in order.

255
00:14:48.530 --> 00:14:53.840
There's the four addresses assigned to
the three Loopback interfaces on NY Wan1.

256
00:14:53.840 --> 00:14:58.060
I guess another option is I could've
just removed this ACL all together but

257
00:14:58.060 --> 00:14:59.620
that should solve the problem.

258
00:14:59.620 --> 00:15:01.830
Let's go test this out on NYEDGE2.

259
00:15:01.830 --> 00:15:07.450
And on NYEDGE2, I'm just gonna repeat
those pings that were failing before.

260
00:15:07.450 --> 00:15:13.310
I know that I was able
to ping 2001:1600::1.

261
00:15:13.310 --> 00:15:19.064
And I was able to ping 2600::1,
but I wasn't able to ping 600.

262
00:15:20.200 --> 00:15:23.590
And I wasn't able to ping 606:606::6,
and now I can.

263
00:15:23.590 --> 00:15:29.860
So now I can ping them all.

264
00:15:29.860 --> 00:15:32.540
So this was a case of an acl blocking us.

265
00:15:32.540 --> 00:15:35.520
Now I remembered seeing that
acl in an earlier ticket, so

266
00:15:35.520 --> 00:15:36.980
we kinda had that advantage.

267
00:15:36.980 --> 00:15:39.750
But, had I not remembered,
had we had to hunt it down.

268
00:15:39.750 --> 00:15:42.640
Be aware that, that ACL could've
been more than one place.

269
00:15:42.640 --> 00:15:48.440
It was here, on traffic coming
in the Gi0/0 interface on EDGE1.

270
00:15:48.440 --> 00:15:52.210
It just as easily could've
been here on outbound traffic,

271
00:15:52.210 --> 00:15:55.110
on Serial 0/0/1, or here.

272
00:15:55.110 --> 00:15:57.010
On input traffic for 010 on NYWAN1.

273
00:15:57.010 --> 00:16:01.510
The reverse path it could have stopped
this anywhere along the way there too.

274
00:16:01.510 --> 00:16:05.260
So there's many places you can put
an ACL on here that could've stopped

275
00:16:05.260 --> 00:16:06.360
that traffic.

276
00:16:06.360 --> 00:16:10.210
But anytime you got a situation where
some traffic makes it across the link and

277
00:16:10.210 --> 00:16:12.980
other traffic doesn't,
if they're on the same network,

278
00:16:12.980 --> 00:16:14.490
it's probably not a routing issue.

279
00:16:14.490 --> 00:16:17.530
In this case,
they're on different networks and

280
00:16:17.530 --> 00:16:20.710
that's why I was thinking routing issue,
but it turned out to be ACL.

281
00:16:20.710 --> 00:16:25.090
I guess you argue that ACL are routing
issues since ACL is route traffic, but

282
00:16:25.090 --> 00:16:26.070
either way.

283
00:16:26.070 --> 00:16:29.290
We were able to track down the ACL,
fix the problem, and

284
00:16:29.290 --> 00:16:31.110
now we're able to ping across
just like we needed to.

285
00:16:31.110 --> 00:16:33.810
So that's gonna resolve this ticket.

286
00:16:33.810 --> 00:16:36.170
All right.
Well that wraps up set number nine.

287
00:16:36.170 --> 00:16:38.430
Stay tuned.
We got another set coming up next.

288
00:16:38.430 --> 00:16:40.429
Hope you guys enjoyed this one,
and I'll see you back.

289
00:16:44.380 --> 00:16:46.146
For set number 10.

290
00:16:46.146 --> 00:16:48.774
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #1` from set #10. The trouble ticket states that "EIGRP is not forming a relationship across the WAN link between NYEDGE2 and NYWAN1 "
episodes.title: Set 10 Issue 1
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.637
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.637 --> 00:00:13.080
All right, welcome back to an all new
