set of Cisco IP troubleshooting episodes

3
00:00:13.080 --> 00:00:16.190
here on ITProTV,
we're kicking off set number 10.

4
00:00:16.190 --> 00:00:21.190
And it looks like we've got an IPv6 EIGRP
issue right to kick things off with.

5
00:00:21.190 --> 00:00:26.100
The ticket reads like this, it says
EIGRP is not forming a relationship

6
00:00:26.100 --> 00:00:30.600
across the WAN link between NYEDGE2 and
NYWAN1.

7
00:00:30.600 --> 00:00:34.860
So, we've got two routers not forming
an EIGRP neighbor relationship.

8
00:00:34.860 --> 00:00:36.560
We need to find out why.

9
00:00:36.560 --> 00:00:39.840
Well, before we dive into the routers
themselves, let's look at our topology and

10
00:00:39.840 --> 00:00:41.090
get a handle on that.

11
00:00:41.090 --> 00:00:42.880
Because the topology has changed, right?

12
00:00:42.880 --> 00:00:46.030
But please listen for
a menu because items have changed.

13
00:00:46.030 --> 00:00:49.100
So, if we look at our routers, we actually
have a well-documented diagram this time.

14
00:00:49.100 --> 00:00:54.148
We got all sorts of addresses on here and
what the ticket said was NYEDGE2 and

15
00:00:54.148 --> 00:00:56.980
NYWAN1 were not forming
a neighbor relationship and

16
00:00:56.980 --> 00:01:02.220
if I look at the diagram, well, I've got
a direct link between the two right here.

17
00:01:02.220 --> 00:01:06.345
It says,
it's EIGRP autonomous system one and

18
00:01:06.345 --> 00:01:12.430
I've got Ser0/0/1 on
the EDGE2 is 2001:DA03::1 and

19
00:01:12.430 --> 00:01:16.349
it's a /92 on Ser0/1/1 on NYWAN1,

20
00:01:16.349 --> 00:01:20.410
we've got 2001:DA03::2/92.

21
00:01:20.410 --> 00:01:24.070
So, those are the systems or
the interfaces.

22
00:01:24.070 --> 00:01:26.770
And I'm just grabbing my favorite
troubleshooting tool, the pen.

23
00:01:26.770 --> 00:01:29.222
Cuz I'm gonna need to write these down or
I'm not gonna remember them.

24
00:01:29.222 --> 00:01:36.238
So, it was Ser0/0/1 on EDGE2.

25
00:01:36.238 --> 00:01:42.847
And its address was 2001:da03::1/92.

26
00:01:42.847 --> 00:01:44.693
Important to write that down, because I
need to compare it to the other side.

27
00:01:44.693 --> 00:01:49.350
We could have an IP mismatch or an ACL,
and I'll need to remember these addresses.

28
00:01:49.350 --> 00:01:54.389
And then, on WAN1,
we're talking Ser0/0/1/1.

29
00:01:55.450 --> 00:02:00.196
And then, we're talking about ::2 for
that guy.

30
00:02:00.196 --> 00:02:03.920
All right, so now, that I got that
handy let's go see what we can see.

31
00:02:03.920 --> 00:02:08.600
Now, as far as troubleshooting this link
issue, one side's as good as another.

32
00:02:08.600 --> 00:02:12.240
Now, what I normally try and do here to
make life easier on me is if I see one of

33
00:02:12.240 --> 00:02:15.630
the routers only have one routing
protocol, I'll usually start there.

34
00:02:15.630 --> 00:02:18.800
But in this case, it looks like they
all have multiple routing protocols.

35
00:02:18.800 --> 00:02:21.810
Well, actually it's not so
bad because EIGRP here is IPv4.

36
00:02:21.810 --> 00:02:25.540
The only IPv6 routing protocol is EIGRP.

37
00:02:25.540 --> 00:02:27.220
So, they all just have one,
so it's really not that bad.

38
00:02:27.220 --> 00:02:29.350
Let's just start with the guy
in the middle, NYWAN1.

39
00:02:30.630 --> 00:02:32.470
So, I will jump over to NYWAN1.

40
00:02:33.490 --> 00:02:35.690
And let's see what we've
got set up on this one.

41
00:02:35.690 --> 00:02:36.320
All right.

42
00:02:36.320 --> 00:02:39.820
The first thing I just wanna do is
see if I have basic reachability.

43
00:02:39.820 --> 00:02:40.430
Right?

44
00:02:40.430 --> 00:02:43.810
If I, even the routing protocol, I don't
even necessarily need to look that up.

45
00:02:43.810 --> 00:02:46.125
I can't even ping the neighbor.

46
00:02:46.125 --> 00:02:48.285
Then, I've got a problem, right?

47
00:02:48.285 --> 00:02:52.352
And what they've told me was that, NYWAN1,

48
00:02:52.352 --> 00:02:57.256
was, let's see we were 2001:DA03::2, and

49
00:02:57.256 --> 00:03:01.032
the guy on the other side was ::1 right?

50
00:03:01.032 --> 00:03:04.515
So, I should be able to
ping from here to there.

51
00:03:04.515 --> 00:03:09.717
So, let's just see, what we get if we
try and ping the other side, right?

52
00:03:09.717 --> 00:03:13.317
2001:DA03::1.

53
00:03:13.317 --> 00:03:17.030
All right, so, when I try and ping that,
I get no valid route for destination.

54
00:03:17.030 --> 00:03:19.530
Now, that's not what I expected to get.

55
00:03:19.530 --> 00:03:23.670
What I expected to get was either
successes or something else but

56
00:03:23.670 --> 00:03:27.180
no valid route, for something that
should be directly connected,

57
00:03:27.180 --> 00:03:30.010
right, I'm supposed to be
directly plugged into this link.

58
00:03:30.010 --> 00:03:31.760
So, maybe we do have an IP mismatch.

59
00:03:31.760 --> 00:03:35.770
Let's look at how that interface is
configured and see what we've got there.

60
00:03:35.770 --> 00:03:42.980
So, I'm gonna do a show run for
interface serial 011, all right.

61
00:03:42.980 --> 00:03:47.520
And, looking at it,
its got IPv6 address 2001:D0,

62
00:03:47.520 --> 00:03:52.460
well that doesn't match what they told me,
right?

63
00:03:52.460 --> 00:03:56.330
So, this IP address is not the IP
address they told me in the diagram.

64
00:03:56.330 --> 00:04:00.370
When I looked in the diagram,
it says here NYWAN1 is

65
00:04:00.370 --> 00:04:04.010
supposed to have serial 0/1/1,
2000:DA03::2/92.

66
00:04:04.010 --> 00:04:10.970
And when I looked at the interface myself,
that's not what I see.

67
00:04:10.970 --> 00:04:13.870
Right.
So, it looks like either the diagram is

68
00:04:13.870 --> 00:04:16.270
wrong, or the router is wrong.

69
00:04:16.270 --> 00:04:16.770
Which one?

70
00:04:17.860 --> 00:04:20.320
I don't know.
I imagine the diagram.

71
00:04:20.320 --> 00:04:22.930
We have to imagine the diagram is right,
that's the information they gave us.

72
00:04:22.930 --> 00:04:25.600
But we've seen in previous issues where
sometimes the diagram is missing some

73
00:04:25.600 --> 00:04:27.890
information, so I'm not really sure which.

74
00:04:27.890 --> 00:04:31.408
What I'm going to do, is I'm going to
write this address down, so, I've got it.

75
00:04:31.408 --> 00:04:37.061
This is 2001:D000:2::2/126

76
00:04:37.061 --> 00:04:41.614
that's a pretty small network there.

77
00:04:41.614 --> 00:04:45.422
And I'm going to jump to
the other side up to NYEDGE2 and

78
00:04:45.422 --> 00:04:48.350
see what it's got on its serial 0001.

79
00:04:48.350 --> 00:04:49.850
So, if I jump up to EDGE2.

80
00:04:51.670 --> 00:04:55.257
And I'm just gonna do a show run for

81
00:04:55.257 --> 00:05:00.453
interface serial 0002, oh sorry, hang on,

82
00:05:00.453 --> 00:05:07.400
let me make sure I got the right
interface here, serial 0001.

83
00:05:07.400 --> 00:05:12.990
Then I can see on this one 2001:D00:2::1,
so

84
00:05:12.990 --> 00:05:18.735
that's the same network as the other end,
it's just apparently the diagram is wrong.

85
00:05:18.735 --> 00:05:21.790
So, I set myself for this, didn't I?

86
00:05:21.790 --> 00:05:23.730
At the very beginning of
the episode I said look,

87
00:05:23.730 --> 00:05:28.190
we've got a well documented diagram and
the IP's are wrong on it.

88
00:05:28.190 --> 00:05:29.370
So, that doesn't help us much.

89
00:05:29.370 --> 00:05:31.360
So, we'll have to put
the diagram out of our mind.

90
00:05:31.360 --> 00:05:36.421
But this range here, if I try and
ping to the other side,

91
00:05:36.421 --> 00:05:41.387
2001:D000:2::2, was the other side.

92
00:05:41.387 --> 00:05:45.388
If I try and ping that, there we go,
no valid route for destination.

93
00:05:45.388 --> 00:05:50.140
I'm still getting the same thing as I got
before which again is not what I expected.

94
00:05:50.140 --> 00:05:51.780
I have that IP,

95
00:05:51.780 --> 00:05:55.890
that's what's assigned to the interface,
I should be able to get to that person.

96
00:05:56.920 --> 00:05:58.690
But I'm not, right?

97
00:05:58.690 --> 00:06:00.950
So, it says no valid route,
and that's odd.

98
00:06:00.950 --> 00:06:02.450
If I do a show IP route,

99
00:06:02.450 --> 00:06:06.000
a directly connected interface
should always have a route.

100
00:06:06.000 --> 00:06:09.890
Oops, if I do a show IPv6 rather,
helps if I use the right protocol.

101
00:06:09.890 --> 00:06:15.220
A directly connected route,
we should always have a route for that.

102
00:06:15.220 --> 00:06:20.090
And so, when I look I can see
like 2001:A001 and A600, B600.

103
00:06:20.090 --> 00:06:27.457
Here's 2001:D000:1 but
I'm dealing with 2001:D000:2.

104
00:06:27.457 --> 00:06:29.860
And sure enough,
it's not in the routing table.

105
00:06:29.860 --> 00:06:31.640
Now, think in your minds.

106
00:06:31.640 --> 00:06:33.030
Let's do a quick pop quiz here.

107
00:06:34.030 --> 00:06:36.480
What's the one scenario,
'cuz there's only one.

108
00:06:36.480 --> 00:06:39.850
What's the one scenario where
a directly connected interface

109
00:06:39.850 --> 00:06:41.120
wouldn't show up in the routing table?

110
00:06:42.350 --> 00:06:43.280
If it's shut down.

111
00:06:43.280 --> 00:06:44.580
If the interface, itself, is down.

112
00:06:44.580 --> 00:06:49.130
If the line protocol is down, then it's
not gonna make it into the routing table.

113
00:06:49.130 --> 00:06:51.370
Otherwise, connected
interfaces always show up.

114
00:06:51.370 --> 00:06:51.870
So.

115
00:06:53.380 --> 00:06:58.140
If I do a show IPv6 interface brief,
and I look for

116
00:06:58.140 --> 00:07:02.670
that serial interface on this
guy at serial 001, there it is,

117
00:07:04.060 --> 00:07:09.050
and that's probably a red flag right there
that the interface is administratively

118
00:07:09.050 --> 00:07:14.850
down so I didn't notice that when I
ran the show run interface serial 001.

119
00:07:14.850 --> 00:07:17.040
But sure enough,
I just looked right past it.

120
00:07:17.040 --> 00:07:22.030
I was so focused on looking at that IP,
I didn't even bother to look at that.

121
00:07:22.030 --> 00:07:24.010
And so, the interface is shut down.

122
00:07:24.010 --> 00:07:28.220
That'll cause a little bit
of a difficulty in working.

123
00:07:28.220 --> 00:07:32.160
Interfaces that are shut down tend not to
flow traffic, so I'll do no shut down to

124
00:07:32.160 --> 00:07:35.900
bring that interface up and now we should
start flowing some traffic over it.

125
00:07:35.900 --> 00:07:37.720
And so,
there I see the line protocol coming up.

126
00:07:37.720 --> 00:07:41.160
And, in fact, I see EIGRP coming up.

127
00:07:41.160 --> 00:07:45.850
And remember our original ticket was EIGRP
is not forming a relationship across

128
00:07:45.850 --> 00:07:48.320
the WAN link between NYEDGE2 and NYWAN1.

129
00:07:48.320 --> 00:07:51.040
I'll bet we just did.

130
00:07:51.040 --> 00:07:54.530
Now, it's telling me we formed
a neighbor relationship with somebody

131
00:07:54.530 --> 00:07:56.680
whose IP ends in 9b50.

132
00:07:56.680 --> 00:07:59.440
I don't know who that is but
it's on Serial0/0/1.

133
00:07:59.440 --> 00:08:04.020
I do know who that is, right,
and that points to NYWAN1.

134
00:08:04.020 --> 00:08:06.750
So, it looks like we
just solved our problem.

135
00:08:06.750 --> 00:08:09.410
Now, I do wanna do just a quick test.

136
00:08:09.410 --> 00:08:13.000
I wanna take that ping that we did
before and I just wanna rerun it and

137
00:08:13.000 --> 00:08:14.330
make sure it actually gets across.

138
00:08:14.330 --> 00:08:17.530
So, at this rate it
would've been faster for

139
00:08:17.530 --> 00:08:19.050
me to type it than to find it this way.

140
00:08:19.050 --> 00:08:22.490
But there we go, and
I am indeed able to ping across.

141
00:08:22.490 --> 00:08:24.900
All right, so
looks like dealing with a few things here.

142
00:08:24.900 --> 00:08:28.560
The main challenge for
me on this one was simply the diagram.

143
00:08:28.560 --> 00:08:31.830
These IPs are wrong, right,
it's got the wrong IPs in the diagram.

144
00:08:31.830 --> 00:08:35.320
But once we had the right IPs,
we could see the interface was down.

145
00:08:35.320 --> 00:08:38.840
We brought it up here on NYEDGE2, and
then we were able to ping across.

146
00:08:38.840 --> 00:08:40.450
And now, we have an adjacency.

147
00:08:40.450 --> 00:08:42.200
And now, we've got to make a decision.

148
00:08:42.200 --> 00:08:46.750
And the decision is, those IPv6
addresses are wrong, do I go back and

149
00:08:46.750 --> 00:08:49.020
correct them to match the diagram.

150
00:08:49.020 --> 00:08:52.910
I could, but at the end of
the day the question told me.

151
00:08:52.910 --> 00:08:56.060
I need to form a neighbor relationship
across that link, that's all it said.

152
00:08:56.060 --> 00:08:58.610
It didn't say anything about
using right IP's or wrong IP's,

153
00:08:58.610 --> 00:09:00.950
so at this point we'll just leave it be.

154
00:09:00.950 --> 00:09:04.220
We can always come back and fix it later
if we need to or we can just add these as

155
00:09:04.220 --> 00:09:07.520
secondary IP's if we just wanted it
to be accurate with the diagram.

156
00:09:07.520 --> 00:09:10.950
For right now, the link's up,
it's happy and our work is done.

157
00:09:10.950 --> 00:09:13.690
So, we'll wrap this one up and move on
to the next trouble shooting ticket.

158
00:09:13.690 --> 00:09:14.780
Hope you guys enjoyed it.

159
00:09:14.780 --> 00:09:15.800
Stay tuned.

160
00:09:15.800 --> 00:09:20.345
Issue two is coming up next.

161
00:09:20.345 --> 00:09:25.054
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #2` from set #10. The trouble ticket states that "Whilst its not causing a problem, there is a configuration error on NYEDGE1 which may be confusing to an engineer if they view the configuration of the interfaces on NYEDGE1. "
episodes.title: Set 10 Issue 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.979
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.620 --> 00:00:12.850
All right, welcome back to another Cisco
troubleshooting episode here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.850 --> 00:00:14.930
We're picking back up with Set 10.

4
00:00:14.930 --> 00:00:16.730
Jumping into issue number two.

5
00:00:16.730 --> 00:00:18.730
And we've got an odd one for us here.

6
00:00:18.730 --> 00:00:23.241
Not so much a problem as it is
a recommendation for action.

7
00:00:23.241 --> 00:00:27.896
The statement, or the issue,
says whilst it's not causing a problem,

8
00:00:27.896 --> 00:00:32.246
there is a configuration error on
NYEDGE1 which may be confusing to

9
00:00:32.246 --> 00:00:37.076
an engineer if they view the configuration
of the interfaces on NYEDGE1.

10
00:00:37.076 --> 00:00:39.585
So they're telling us that
there's something wrong, but

11
00:00:39.585 --> 00:00:41.700
it's not something wrong
that affects traffic.

12
00:00:41.700 --> 00:00:45.210
Traffic is going like normal, and
then so we don't really notice it.

13
00:00:45.210 --> 00:00:47.090
But, if somebody from
the outside were to come in and

14
00:00:47.090 --> 00:00:50.580
try and troubleshoot this,
they're gonna get confused, right?

15
00:00:50.580 --> 00:00:53.060
Because there's something in here
that just shouldn't be right.

16
00:00:53.060 --> 00:00:55.570
And they gave us a little
hint that just says check

17
00:00:55.570 --> 00:00:58.180
the autonomous systems
configured on the interfaces.

18
00:00:58.180 --> 00:01:00.970
So it looks like we're dealing
with an AS type issue.

19
00:01:00.970 --> 00:01:03.240
And when we talk about
AS type configurations,

20
00:01:03.240 --> 00:01:06.590
well, RIP doesn't use autonomous systems.

21
00:01:06.590 --> 00:01:08.580
OSPF doesn't use autonomous systems.

22
00:01:08.580 --> 00:01:10.570
It's technically just one.

23
00:01:10.570 --> 00:01:14.950
EIGRP does use autonomous systems,
and BGP uses autonomous systems.

24
00:01:14.950 --> 00:01:18.810
So I'm probably dealing with an EIGRP or
a BGP type issue.

25
00:01:18.810 --> 00:01:24.210
And they don't specify IPv4 or IPv6 so
we need to be kind of on the lookout for

26
00:01:24.210 --> 00:01:27.090
those things and see if we can
spot something that's not right.

27
00:01:27.090 --> 00:01:31.140
Well before we do that, let's take
a look at our topology diagram so

28
00:01:31.140 --> 00:01:32.690
we can see what we should be expecting.

29
00:01:32.690 --> 00:01:36.980
And the router in question
is NYEDGE1 up here.

30
00:01:36.980 --> 00:01:41.352
And so if we look at NYEDGE1, what you'll
see is that it's got three interfaces.

31
00:01:41.352 --> 00:01:46.289
Two of which are in EIGRP
autonomous system 1 for IPv6.

32
00:01:46.289 --> 00:01:50.440
We've got a third interface,
and possibly all three of them,

33
00:01:50.440 --> 00:01:54.840
that are in EIGRP autonomous system 10 for
IPv4 and that's it.

34
00:01:54.840 --> 00:01:56.360
I don't show any other routing protocols.

35
00:01:56.360 --> 00:01:58.230
So I mentioned BGP a moment ago,

36
00:01:58.230 --> 00:02:01.740
we should be able to put that out of
our mind because it's on the diagram.

37
00:02:01.740 --> 00:02:06.460
So rip's out, OSPF's out, BGP's out,
EIGRP's really all that's left and

38
00:02:06.460 --> 00:02:11.690
they told us to look for autonomous system
numbers so I'm looking for an EIGRP issue.

39
00:02:11.690 --> 00:02:15.974
Something that's wrong but that's not
actually causing a problem with routing.

40
00:02:15.974 --> 00:02:19.611
So, let's jump into NYEDGE1 and
see if we can spot something like that.

41
00:02:19.611 --> 00:02:23.793
Now, on NYEDGE1, there's any number of
commands we could jump in here to start

42
00:02:23.793 --> 00:02:25.660
troubleshooting this one.

43
00:02:25.660 --> 00:02:29.400
One challenge that I'm gonna have is
that I'm running IPv4 and IPv6, so

44
00:02:29.400 --> 00:02:33.270
every bit of troubleshooting I do,
I'm gonna have to do twice, right?

45
00:02:33.270 --> 00:02:34.740
Once for each protocol.

46
00:02:34.740 --> 00:02:37.650
The other thing is they're telling
me that something's wrong, but

47
00:02:37.650 --> 00:02:39.700
that it's not affecting routing.

48
00:02:39.700 --> 00:02:43.120
And so that means I'm probably
not gonna have errors.

49
00:02:43.120 --> 00:02:46.780
Normally I would do a show log,
or do some debugs.

50
00:02:46.780 --> 00:02:49.390
But apparently nothing is
actually happening, so

51
00:02:49.390 --> 00:02:51.110
I don't expect to get much back on that.

52
00:02:51.110 --> 00:02:53.060
Right, if I do a show log.

53
00:02:53.060 --> 00:02:55.030
And I start to look at what's in here.

54
00:02:55.030 --> 00:02:57.820
Well I might not see
anything in here too crazy.

55
00:02:57.820 --> 00:02:59.720
Right here's my normal boot stuff.

56
00:02:59.720 --> 00:03:01.290
I got a VPN tunnel coming up.

57
00:03:01.290 --> 00:03:03.850
Interfaces changing status.

58
00:03:03.850 --> 00:03:06.080
And that's about it.

59
00:03:06.080 --> 00:03:07.890
It looks like we have a neighbor
adjacentcy coming up.

60
00:03:10.270 --> 00:03:11.430
And that's it right.

61
00:03:11.430 --> 00:03:12.509
If I do a show clock.

62
00:03:13.510 --> 00:03:18.100
My system hasn't reported any log
messages in like 45 minutes, all right?

63
00:03:18.100 --> 00:03:23.080
It's been a while since it's reported
a log message, so I'm pretty stable.

64
00:03:23.080 --> 00:03:28.350
And if I do a show IP interface brief, I
can look at the interfaces and see whether

65
00:03:28.350 --> 00:03:34.620
they're up up, and all the interfaces
that have IP addresses are up, up.

66
00:03:34.620 --> 00:03:35.540
So that looks good.

67
00:03:35.540 --> 00:03:36.880
And that's kind of what I expected.

68
00:03:36.880 --> 00:03:41.140
And if I do a show ipv6 interface brief,
I expect to see the same thing.

69
00:03:41.140 --> 00:03:44.040
That most everything is gonna be up, up.

70
00:03:44.040 --> 00:03:46.700
Or if doesn't have an address,
it's administratively down.

71
00:03:46.700 --> 00:03:47.840
But I'm not worried about those.

72
00:03:47.840 --> 00:03:49.600
The ones that have addresses are all up,
ups.

73
00:03:49.600 --> 00:03:53.900
And I expected that because they told me
it wasn't actually causing a problem.

74
00:03:53.900 --> 00:03:57.720
So all our normal trouble-shooting tools,
kinda out the window.

75
00:03:57.720 --> 00:04:00.710
And all we're left with is
our verification tools.

76
00:04:00.710 --> 00:04:02.660
I could do a show running dash config and

77
00:04:02.660 --> 00:04:05.570
just start reading through it from
the very top and see if we can find things

78
00:04:05.570 --> 00:04:09.350
that are wrong, but let's see if we can't
make this a little bit easier for us.

79
00:04:09.350 --> 00:04:13.498
I know it's an EIGRP problem and they told
me to look out for autonomous systems so

80
00:04:13.498 --> 00:04:17.280
I can run show IP protocols and that'll
show me the information that I need

81
00:04:17.280 --> 00:04:19.612
as far as autonomous
systems are concerned.

82
00:04:19.612 --> 00:04:24.391
So for example, I know from looking
at my diagram that I should be

83
00:04:24.391 --> 00:04:28.918
an EIGRP autonomous system 10,
and that's it for IPv4.

84
00:04:28.918 --> 00:04:33.342
So if I run a show IP protocols, I expect
to see that I'm running EIGRP, and

85
00:04:33.342 --> 00:04:36.504
that I'm running it for
autonomous system 10, and

86
00:04:36.504 --> 00:04:39.900
sure enough there it is,
EIGRP autonomous system 10.

87
00:04:39.900 --> 00:04:42.830
I've got K values and
other things defined here.

88
00:04:42.830 --> 00:04:46.910
Automatic summarization's disabled, and
I should have some interfaces in there.

89
00:04:48.080 --> 00:04:49.230
And I'm routing for networks, right?

90
00:04:49.230 --> 00:04:53.200
Everything there looks pretty normal,
nothing too crazy there.

91
00:04:53.200 --> 00:04:57.250
All right, then if I do a show
IPv6 protocols I should

92
00:04:57.250 --> 00:04:59.790
be able to see the EIGRP side there.

93
00:04:59.790 --> 00:05:03.900
And going back to my diagram, I expect
to see autonomous system 1 for this one,

94
00:05:03.900 --> 00:05:05.080
all right.

95
00:05:05.080 --> 00:05:08.600
And so when I run that, I get my output.

96
00:05:08.600 --> 00:05:12.770
And so right here I'm seeing EIGRP for
autonomous system 1, that's good,

97
00:05:12.770 --> 00:05:15.020
I've got K values and other things.

98
00:05:15.020 --> 00:05:16.640
I've got some interfaces
that are thrown in there.

99
00:05:16.640 --> 00:05:18.004
That's all very exciting.

100
00:05:18.004 --> 00:05:20.239
And there's something odd.

101
00:05:20.239 --> 00:05:24.098
I've got IPv6 Routing Protocol is eigrp 2,
right?

102
00:05:24.098 --> 00:05:27.370
So I've got another eigrp
autonomous system here.

103
00:05:27.370 --> 00:05:31.331
And if I look at it,
K values are pretty normal.

104
00:05:31.331 --> 00:05:36.228
Serial0/0/1 is in eigrp
autonomous system 2.

105
00:05:36.228 --> 00:05:40.569
Now unlike OSPF, where I might
have an Area 0 and an Area 1 and

106
00:05:40.569 --> 00:05:44.172
they talk to each other,
here it's AS2 and AS1.

107
00:05:44.172 --> 00:05:47.747
They're completely separate,
unless I'm redistributing between them,

108
00:05:47.747 --> 00:05:48.850
which we probably are.

109
00:05:48.850 --> 00:05:50.490
But we can verify that in a moment.

110
00:05:50.490 --> 00:05:55.580
By looking at the diagram,
I'm not supposed to be in EIGRP autonomous

111
00:05:55.580 --> 00:06:00.520
system 2 and that was configured for
serial 001 and

112
00:06:01.950 --> 00:06:06.990
going back to my diagram, serial 001 is
supposed to be in autonomous system one,

113
00:06:06.990 --> 00:06:11.410
but they told me it wasn't
affecting routing, right?

114
00:06:11.410 --> 00:06:14.600
Well if this interface is in the wrong AS,
wouldn't that affect routing?

115
00:06:14.600 --> 00:06:15.773
Well, it's not.

116
00:06:15.773 --> 00:06:17.929
If I go back to my config here, and

117
00:06:17.929 --> 00:06:23.250
I go back to the part where it's telling
me about AS1 and I look at the interfaces.

118
00:06:23.250 --> 00:06:27.040
Serial 001 is an as1 also.

119
00:06:27.040 --> 00:06:32.230
A single interface can be in more
than one eigrp autonomous system

120
00:06:32.230 --> 00:06:34.290
that's different from ospf
where you can't do that.

121
00:06:34.290 --> 00:06:36.070
In eigrp you can.

122
00:06:36.070 --> 00:06:41.120
And so in this case, the eigrp two,
it's not really causing any problem.

123
00:06:41.120 --> 00:06:43.960
Autonomous system one
is working like normal.

124
00:06:43.960 --> 00:06:48.520
But the fact that eigrp two exists
could cause some confusions.

125
00:06:48.520 --> 00:06:51.450
So that's more than likely what
they're trying to point out for us.

126
00:06:51.450 --> 00:06:55.820
And if we do a show run for

127
00:06:55.820 --> 00:07:02.670
interface serial 001,
I can see right here it's got ipv6 eigrp

128
00:07:02.670 --> 00:07:07.689
two It doesn't have ipv6_ergp 1.

129
00:07:07.689 --> 00:07:10.479
So how is it operating in both?

130
00:07:10.479 --> 00:07:14.903
Well let's do a show run, and look for

131
00:07:14.903 --> 00:07:20.159
the eigrp section, and
what I'll see in here

132
00:07:20.159 --> 00:07:26.265
is that I've got a IPv4 for
autonomous system ten.

133
00:07:26.265 --> 00:07:31.746
I've got IPv6 for autonomous system one,
and IPv6 for autonomous system two,

134
00:07:31.746 --> 00:07:36.831
and you know what I'm not seeing
the network command that is dragging this,

135
00:07:36.831 --> 00:07:40.470
I expected to see a network
command to drag it in.

136
00:07:40.470 --> 00:07:44.690
You know I'm actually not
seeing it attached to EIGRP1,

137
00:07:44.690 --> 00:07:46.220
like we saw in the diagrams.

138
00:07:46.220 --> 00:07:47.330
So that's interesting.

139
00:07:47.330 --> 00:07:51.530
So, that would be a problem, but they're
saying it's not affecting routing and

140
00:07:51.530 --> 00:07:53.340
I'm not sure why that would be.

141
00:07:53.340 --> 00:07:59.150
If we're not participating in EIGRP1 like
we're supposed to, then in theory NYEDGE1

142
00:08:00.440 --> 00:08:04.180
would not know about this network
over here between these two routers.

143
00:08:04.180 --> 00:08:06.410
It wouldn't know about what was there.

144
00:08:06.410 --> 00:08:08.150
And that would affect routing.

145
00:08:08.150 --> 00:08:13.120
So, we do have some issue here, but
either way the best thing to do is get

146
00:08:13.120 --> 00:08:16.330
rid of the IGRP autonomous system
2 all together, we don't need it.

147
00:08:16.330 --> 00:08:19.520
And put that interface in autonomous
system 1 like it's supposed to be,

148
00:08:19.520 --> 00:08:23.460
so I'll go ahead do that real quick and
get that squared away.

149
00:08:23.460 --> 00:08:28.148
So I'm gonna get into
interface serial 0/0/1 and

150
00:08:28.148 --> 00:08:29.970
we saw up here what I was looking for.

151
00:08:29.970 --> 00:08:32.490
This command, IPv6 EIGRP 2.

152
00:08:32.490 --> 00:08:33.856
We're just gonna undo that.

153
00:08:33.856 --> 00:08:38.200
No IPv6 EIGRP 2.

154
00:08:38.200 --> 00:08:43.770
And then we'll say ipv6 eigrp 1, just
stick into the right autonomous system.

155
00:08:43.770 --> 00:08:49.062
And now if I get out of my config,
and I do a show ipv6 protocols,

156
00:08:49.062 --> 00:08:54.060
all right, I expect to see eigrp for
autonomous system one,

157
00:08:54.060 --> 00:08:57.784
right here, and
as I look down the list here,

158
00:08:57.784 --> 00:09:03.384
we can see we've got our K values,
K1, K2, and oh you know what?

159
00:09:03.384 --> 00:09:05.841
I just noticed that right there,
VR(TSHOOT).

160
00:09:05.841 --> 00:09:07.704
So we're actually dealing with a VRF,

161
00:09:07.704 --> 00:09:09.970
that's why I didn't see
the network command.

162
00:09:09.970 --> 00:09:11.970
It'll be a little further in the config.

163
00:09:11.970 --> 00:09:15.340
And as I look down, I'll see that it's
already in autonomous system one.

164
00:09:15.340 --> 00:09:17.510
In fact, I might've broken it by
putting that command in there, so

165
00:09:17.510 --> 00:09:19.080
we'll have to doublecheck that.

166
00:09:19.080 --> 00:09:23.210
Autonomous system 2 still exists
though with no interfaces.

167
00:09:23.210 --> 00:09:25.270
And that's because I need
to get rid of its command.

168
00:09:25.270 --> 00:09:26.680
Let me do a show run and config.

169
00:09:26.680 --> 00:09:30.000
So I wanna show you the mistake that I
think I made and make sure that I'm right.

170
00:09:30.000 --> 00:09:33.198
So when I look at this config and
I start scrolling down here,

171
00:09:33.198 --> 00:09:35.030
I've got my various interfaces.

172
00:09:35.030 --> 00:09:37.835
And kinda going down the line here.

173
00:09:37.835 --> 00:09:42.090
See how serial 0000 is
directly in the eigrp 1?

174
00:09:42.090 --> 00:09:46.580
But when I got serial 001,
it wasn't directly in eigrp 1, was it?

175
00:09:46.580 --> 00:09:47.880
It didn't show up there.

176
00:09:47.880 --> 00:09:50.510
But when I go down a little bit, you'll
see I've got that virtual router creator

177
00:09:50.510 --> 00:09:55.070
right there called TSHOOT, and that's
where they're doing the unicast family.

178
00:09:55.070 --> 00:09:59.630
To bring it in for IPv4,
and I know, you know,

179
00:09:59.630 --> 00:10:02.670
I'm not actually seeing
any vrf's in here so.

180
00:10:02.670 --> 00:10:03.540
Yeah, interesting.

181
00:10:03.540 --> 00:10:04.860
All right.

182
00:10:04.860 --> 00:10:07.510
Well, I guess I didn't make
the mistake I thought I made.

183
00:10:07.510 --> 00:10:10.470
So I am in EIGRP autonomous system one.

184
00:10:10.470 --> 00:10:14.700
I was expecting to see a VRF defined and
I should have put the interface into that

185
00:10:14.700 --> 00:10:18.470
VRF instead of out of here but no, it's
actually defined on the real interface.

186
00:10:18.470 --> 00:10:19.955
But I do need to get rid of this command,

187
00:10:19.955 --> 00:10:21.762
to actually get rid of
that autonomous system.

188
00:10:21.762 --> 00:10:25.392
So let me get into the config and

189
00:10:25.392 --> 00:10:30.985
I'm just gonna say no ipv6,
router eigrp 2.

190
00:10:30.985 --> 00:10:32.814
And that's gonna get rid of that one.

191
00:10:32.814 --> 00:10:38.895
And now, when I do a show ipv6 protocols,
while it wasn't causing any real problems,

192
00:10:38.895 --> 00:10:42.362
now, autonomous system 2 will be gone,
right?

193
00:10:42.362 --> 00:10:44.529
So here's everything for
autonomous system 1.

194
00:10:45.590 --> 00:10:48.290
And then, as I continue on, that's it.

195
00:10:48.290 --> 00:10:50.430
And that's gonna solve that problem.

196
00:10:50.430 --> 00:10:55.160
So this is an example of just some extra
config junk that was left in there

197
00:10:55.160 --> 00:10:56.950
that we could have ignored,
just left it be.

198
00:10:56.950 --> 00:10:58.730
But if somebody is troubleshooting
later on down the road.

199
00:10:58.730 --> 00:10:59.630
They come across this.

200
00:10:59.630 --> 00:11:01.020
And they're, like,
why do I have AS number 2?

201
00:11:01.020 --> 00:11:03.600
And it's just an extra thing to confuse
us and have to sort through it.

202
00:11:03.600 --> 00:11:07.100
So, whenever you have lines of
config that aren't used anymore.

203
00:11:07.100 --> 00:11:08.090
It's important to remove them.

204
00:11:08.090 --> 00:11:10.181
Clean them up.
And that's what this ticket was all about.

205
00:11:10.181 --> 00:11:15.605
So, that takes care of this one and we're
ready to move on to issue number three.

206
00:11:15.605 --> 00:11:22.549
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #3` from set #10. The trouble ticket states that "IPv6 network on NYWAN1, Loopback 6 is not being propagated to NYEDGE1 and NYEDGE2 routers. "
episodes.title: Set 10 Issue 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.016 --> 00:00:07.644
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.644 --> 00:00:12.910
All right welcome back to another Cisco
troubleshooting episode here on ITpro TV.

3
00:00:12.910 --> 00:00:16.450
We're jumping into set ten
issue number three and

4
00:00:16.450 --> 00:00:18.370
we've got,
well we've got an issue on our hands.

5
00:00:18.370 --> 00:00:23.378
Let me read the ticket to you guys,
it says IPV6 network on NYWAN1 for

6
00:00:23.378 --> 00:00:29.510
loop back six is not being propagated to
NYEDGE1 and NYEDGE2 routers, all right?

7
00:00:29.510 --> 00:00:32.940
So let's look at our topology,
and kind of figure all this out.

8
00:00:32.940 --> 00:00:36.570
So they're talking about NYWAN1,
this guy right here in the middle.

9
00:00:36.570 --> 00:00:40.930
And it's got an interface,
it's loop back six and

10
00:00:40.930 --> 00:00:46.320
whatever network is on loop back six is
not making it out to NYEDGE1 and NYEDGE2.

11
00:00:46.320 --> 00:00:50.940
And I've got EIGRP autonomous system one,
and so that AS should

12
00:00:50.940 --> 00:00:54.550
be carrying those networks across and
for some reason it isn't, all right?

13
00:00:54.550 --> 00:00:57.460
So, first off, we need to figure out what
network it is, cuz I don't know, and

14
00:00:57.460 --> 00:01:00.060
they don't tell me in the ticket,
so I need to find that out and

15
00:01:00.060 --> 00:01:03.080
then we need to look and see,
are none of my networks making it over?

16
00:01:03.080 --> 00:01:06.020
Do I even have an EIGRP neighbor
relationship with those guys?

17
00:01:06.020 --> 00:01:08.410
Like, how big is this problem?

18
00:01:08.410 --> 00:01:11.030
Or is it as simple as just a little
network that's not making it

19
00:01:11.030 --> 00:01:12.020
to the other side?

20
00:01:12.020 --> 00:01:12.570
So, let's find out.

21
00:01:12.570 --> 00:01:17.720
I'm gonna jump to NYWAN1 and
do a little information gathering first.

22
00:01:17.720 --> 00:01:21.450
And we'll be able to figure things out a
little better from there once we have some

23
00:01:21.450 --> 00:01:22.560
more information to act on.

24
00:01:22.560 --> 00:01:28.150
So the first thing I'm gonna do is,
I'll just do a show run for interface lo6.

25
00:01:28.150 --> 00:01:31.435
I wanna look at loop back six and
there it is, it's got one network on it.

26
00:01:31.435 --> 00:01:34.150
And I'm gonna write that down
with my trusty pen here.

27
00:01:34.150 --> 00:01:38.497
So on NYWAN1's loop back six,

28
00:01:38.497 --> 00:01:45.101
we've got 2001:606:606::6.

29
00:01:45.101 --> 00:01:47.172
All right?

30
00:01:47.172 --> 00:01:50.430
And it's a /64 network.

31
00:01:50.430 --> 00:01:53.390
So, that's the address I've got on
there and they're telling me that this

32
00:01:53.390 --> 00:01:56.050
network is not making it to
the other sides, all right?

33
00:01:56.050 --> 00:01:57.380
Well, who are the other sides?

34
00:01:57.380 --> 00:02:03.990
If I do a show IPV6 EIGRP neighbor, I can
figure out who's the other sides, right?

35
00:02:03.990 --> 00:02:09.560
And I do have two neighbors, one on Serial
011 and one on Serial 10, all right?

36
00:02:09.560 --> 00:02:12.640
And if I go and look at my diagram,
Serial 010 and 011.

37
00:02:12.640 --> 00:02:16.720
Those are my connections to NYEDGE2 and
NYEDGE1.

38
00:02:16.720 --> 00:02:20.980
So I do have an EIGRP
neighbor relationship up and

39
00:02:20.980 --> 00:02:23.180
I'm assuming it's for
autonomous system one.

40
00:02:23.180 --> 00:02:25.410
I guess we could double-check
that just to be sure.

41
00:02:25.410 --> 00:02:29.140
When we look here in the output for
show IPV6 EIGRP neighbor,

42
00:02:29.140 --> 00:02:33.680
it shows us things like the hold down
timer, the sequence number and that.

43
00:02:33.680 --> 00:02:37.860
But one thing it doesn't tell us is the
neighbor, I mean the autonomous system.

44
00:02:37.860 --> 00:02:43.170
For that we can do a show
IPv6 protocols and

45
00:02:43.170 --> 00:02:46.990
when we see the configuration for
EIGRP 1 right here.

46
00:02:46.990 --> 00:02:48.780
That's autonomous system one.

47
00:02:48.780 --> 00:02:53.580
In here, I'll be able to see whether or
not I'm in the right areas and so on.

48
00:02:53.580 --> 00:02:55.955
So, I said area, areas always PF right,

49
00:02:55.955 --> 00:02:57.600
autonomous system that's
what I'm looking for.

50
00:02:57.600 --> 00:03:02.070
So, EIGRP 1, I am in the right autonomous
system and looking down here I can see

51
00:03:02.070 --> 00:03:05.560
the interface is participating in it and
there's the two interfaces that

52
00:03:05.560 --> 00:03:11.330
are pointing out to my neighbors and
I've got a redistribute command here.

53
00:03:11.330 --> 00:03:16.100
It says I am redistributing connected
routes over to the other guys.

54
00:03:16.100 --> 00:03:19.203
Well, my loop back interface is
a connected interface, so that means I'm

55
00:03:19.203 --> 00:03:22.280
redistributing connected in the EIGRP and
they should learn it that way.

56
00:03:22.280 --> 00:03:24.530
Let me see if I have any
other interfaces on here,

57
00:03:24.530 --> 00:03:27.940
I'm gonna do a show IPV6 interface brief.

58
00:03:27.940 --> 00:03:29.829
And if we're redistributing
connected routes,

59
00:03:30.900 --> 00:03:32.300
all of my interfaces should make it over.

60
00:03:32.300 --> 00:03:36.131
Looks like I've got some other loop back
interfaces here, like loop back 16 and

61
00:03:36.131 --> 00:03:39.230
loop back 26,
they should be redistributed also, right?

62
00:03:39.230 --> 00:03:40.892
So I'm going to write
those networks down and

63
00:03:40.892 --> 00:03:42.869
we'll just see if they're
making it over there too.

64
00:03:42.869 --> 00:03:49.232
So I've got 2001:1600 and 2001:2600.

65
00:03:49.232 --> 00:03:52.320
Just writing those down so when I jump
to the other guys I can verify it.

66
00:03:52.320 --> 00:03:54.342
Now that was NYWAN1.

67
00:03:54.342 --> 00:03:56.537
I'm gonna jump over to NYEDGE1.

68
00:03:56.537 --> 00:04:00.136
And let's just see what's
making it over here, all right?

69
00:04:00.136 --> 00:04:03.329
So I'm gonna do a show ipv6 route and

70
00:04:03.329 --> 00:04:07.760
I'm gonna filter it down
to just the EIGRP routes.

71
00:04:07.760 --> 00:04:09.790
I don't want to mess around
with any other protocols.

72
00:04:09.790 --> 00:04:13.976
Because EIGRP is what they're
talking about and when I look at it,

73
00:04:13.976 --> 00:04:16.086
there's 2001:2600.

74
00:04:16.086 --> 00:04:19.740
I don't see 2001:1600 and
I see a couple of other routes.

75
00:04:19.740 --> 00:04:22.370
But this guy right here, 2001:2600,

76
00:04:22.370 --> 00:04:27.855
that's one of the loop back
interfaces from from and NYWAN1 and

77
00:04:27.855 --> 00:04:32.965
it's showing as EX an EIGRP
external route and

78
00:04:32.965 --> 00:04:36.425
that's exactly what I expect to see for
something that's being redistributed.

79
00:04:36.425 --> 00:04:40.625
So that network is being redistributed
from connected into EIGRP for IPv6.

80
00:04:40.625 --> 00:04:44.175
And I'm seeing it right here
in autonomous system one, so

81
00:04:44.175 --> 00:04:48.130
some of my other loop backs aren't
showing up, but this one is.

82
00:04:48.130 --> 00:04:51.400
Let's take a look at NYEDGE2 and
see if it's the same thing.

83
00:04:51.400 --> 00:04:56.200
I expect that it is, so if we look here,
I'm gonna do the same thing,

84
00:04:56.200 --> 00:05:02.100
show IPV6 route, and
just show me the EIGRP routes.

85
00:05:02.100 --> 00:05:04.954
And when we look at that,
it's the same exact thing, right?

86
00:05:04.954 --> 00:05:09.530
I've got that 2001:2600 and
it's an external EIGRP route and

87
00:05:09.530 --> 00:05:12.280
I'm not seeing any of the others.

88
00:05:12.280 --> 00:05:16.584
So I am learning some routes and
I'm not learning others and

89
00:05:16.584 --> 00:05:22.195
what that immediately makes me think
of is, we could have pre-fixed lists.

90
00:05:22.195 --> 00:05:23.884
We could route maps, right?

91
00:05:23.884 --> 00:05:26.459
That are filtering the routes we
advertised with the routes we learned.

92
00:05:27.540 --> 00:05:30.880
We could have bad metrics, if the metrics
are too large, they won't come in.

93
00:05:30.880 --> 00:05:33.290
We could have interfaces that are down.

94
00:05:33.290 --> 00:05:36.190
We're not going to advertise a route
unless it's in our own routing table.

95
00:05:36.190 --> 00:05:39.340
So there's a number of different
things that could be stopping us.

96
00:05:39.340 --> 00:05:44.270
Because I'm not seeing
the route on EDGE1 or EDGE2,

97
00:05:44.270 --> 00:05:47.940
then best place to start troubleshooting
this is going to be NYWAN1, right?

98
00:05:47.940 --> 00:05:52.570
If NYWAN1 is not advertising the route,
neither of these guys will get it.

99
00:05:52.570 --> 00:05:55.970
If it was a problem up here, it's unlikely
that we would have the same problem

100
00:05:55.970 --> 00:05:58.880
on EDGE1 and EDGE2, so
I doubt the problem's on the other side.

101
00:05:58.880 --> 00:06:01.490
But that's the logic behind me
picking where I"m going to start.

102
00:06:01.490 --> 00:06:05.370
I'm gonna start at NYWAN1, cause it's
the most likely source of the problem.

103
00:06:05.370 --> 00:06:07.050
So I'm gonna jump over to NYWAN1 and

104
00:06:07.050 --> 00:06:09.500
I just wanna take a look
at its configuration.

105
00:06:09.500 --> 00:06:14.920
Get a little better understanding of how
it's set up, and kinda go from there.

106
00:06:14.920 --> 00:06:16.680
And I'm just gonna do a show run, and

107
00:06:16.680 --> 00:06:18.760
we'll look at the whole running
configuration this time.

108
00:06:18.760 --> 00:06:23.540
Well just kinda parse through it and
the reason I'm doing that, is EIGRP under

109
00:06:23.540 --> 00:06:28.290
IPv6 is configured partly in the routing
process and partly on the interface.

110
00:06:28.290 --> 00:06:30.470
So I really need to look both places and

111
00:06:30.470 --> 00:06:33.300
a show running config is
the easiest way to spot that.

112
00:06:33.300 --> 00:06:39.870
So when I come through the running config,
remember this guy right here 2001:2600.

113
00:06:39.870 --> 00:06:43.570
That's the only route that was actually
showing up on the other sides.

114
00:06:43.570 --> 00:06:46.410
I saw that one over on EDGE1 and EDGE2.

115
00:06:46.410 --> 00:06:49.590
But this guy, 2001:1600,
he didn't show up.

116
00:06:49.590 --> 00:06:52.180
Now he's not mentioned in
the troubleshooting ticket, so

117
00:06:52.180 --> 00:06:54.870
that may be okay, but
the one that's really important to me,

118
00:06:54.870 --> 00:06:57.690
this guy right here,
he didn't show up either.

119
00:06:57.690 --> 00:07:00.280
And if I look at the configuration
of those three interfaces,

120
00:07:00.280 --> 00:07:01.660
they're all the same, right?

121
00:07:01.660 --> 00:07:05.390
There's no EIGRP configuration to be
found right here on the interface.

122
00:07:05.390 --> 00:07:08.280
And that's what I really wanted to do,
I wanted to compare and

123
00:07:08.280 --> 00:07:12.450
interface that worked against and
interface that didn't work and

124
00:07:12.450 --> 00:07:15.700
just look to see if there's a different
command there, some kind of variation.

125
00:07:15.700 --> 00:07:16.880
I don't see one.

126
00:07:16.880 --> 00:07:22.360
So now I need to keep moving and
look at the routing protocol itself.

127
00:07:22.360 --> 00:07:26.588
I guess I also should probably
pay attention to Serial 010 and

128
00:07:26.588 --> 00:07:29.650
Serial 011, those outbound interfaces.

129
00:07:29.650 --> 00:07:32.270
That were sending
the route those interfaces.

130
00:07:32.270 --> 00:07:34.720
There could be something on them
that's causing the problem.

131
00:07:35.870 --> 00:07:38.780
And so if I look at Serial 10 and

132
00:07:38.780 --> 00:07:43.303
Serial 11, that's these guys right
here and see how they're in EIGRP?

133
00:07:43.303 --> 00:07:47.840
So they've got IPv6 EIGRP1 right there,
that's, like I said,

134
00:07:47.840 --> 00:07:50.470
the EIGRP configuration is
partly on the interface and

135
00:07:50.470 --> 00:07:52.684
partly on the routing process,
so I see them here.

136
00:07:52.684 --> 00:07:57.360
Now, my loop backs didn't
have IPv6 EIGRP1 and

137
00:07:57.360 --> 00:08:00.300
that's because we're redistributing,
right, so we don't need them in here.

138
00:08:00.300 --> 00:08:03.570
They stay as connected routes, and
we redistribute them into EIGRP, but

139
00:08:03.570 --> 00:08:07.050
these guys are actively
participating in EIGRP, and

140
00:08:07.050 --> 00:08:10.160
I know that's working cuz I am seeing some
of my routes make it to the other side.

141
00:08:11.570 --> 00:08:14.640
All right,
then here's my EIGRP configuration.

142
00:08:14.640 --> 00:08:18.525
Router EIGRP 10 or wait,
nope, that's for IPV4.

143
00:08:18.525 --> 00:08:21.030
[LAUGH] Those are not IPV6 addresses.

144
00:08:21.030 --> 00:08:24.770
So, that's not it, but if I look
a little bit further down, there we go.

145
00:08:24.770 --> 00:08:26.640
IPV6 router EIGRP1.

146
00:08:26.640 --> 00:08:30.250
All right, so
it's got the redistribute command, and

147
00:08:30.250 --> 00:08:33.470
here we can redistributing connected,
it's got a metric defined.

148
00:08:33.470 --> 00:08:36.760
And you've got to remember your metric,
how it's got bandwidth and

149
00:08:36.760 --> 00:08:41.390
delay and load reliability and MTU.

150
00:08:41.390 --> 00:08:44.790
And some of these can be bad, some can
be good, but at the end of the day,

151
00:08:44.790 --> 00:08:48.910
the only ones we use by default
are bandwidth and delay.

152
00:08:48.910 --> 00:08:52.100
And so no matter how low or
high those are, it's gonna be okay.

153
00:08:52.100 --> 00:08:55.623
We have maximum metrics on other things,
but not on bandwidth and delay, so

154
00:08:55.623 --> 00:08:57.250
they can actually be quite large.

155
00:08:57.250 --> 00:08:59.140
A thousand each is no big deal, right?

156
00:08:59.140 --> 00:09:01.100
Those are nice,
normal numbers right there.

157
00:09:01.100 --> 00:09:05.400
And so I'm not worried about any crazy
metric stuff, at least not right now.

158
00:09:05.400 --> 00:09:08.810
And then as I look a little bit
further on the redistribute command,

159
00:09:08.810 --> 00:09:12.010
I can see there is a route map, so
there's a route map in place and

160
00:09:12.010 --> 00:09:14.970
that very well could be
filtering out our traffic.

161
00:09:14.970 --> 00:09:17.583
Fortunately that's the next
thing in the config,

162
00:09:17.583 --> 00:09:21.607
I can see the route map right here and
it's saying match IPv6 address REDIST.

163
00:09:21.607 --> 00:09:25.590
And that means there's an address list,
which is right down here.

164
00:09:25.590 --> 00:09:29.950
And sure enough,
IPv6 access-list REDIST and

165
00:09:29.950 --> 00:09:34.040
it's got the 2001:2600 network.

166
00:09:34.040 --> 00:09:36.650
That's the one that is making it across.

167
00:09:36.650 --> 00:09:39.290
Nobody else is on the list, and
so they're not making it across.

168
00:09:39.290 --> 00:09:42.560
Now, I know there was more than one
loop back that wasn't making it over but

169
00:09:42.560 --> 00:09:46.140
at the end of the day the troubleshooting
ticket is only talking about loop back

170
00:09:46.140 --> 00:09:51.040
six's interface and so what we need
to do is update this access list

171
00:09:51.040 --> 00:09:54.560
to include loop back six's address, right?

172
00:09:54.560 --> 00:09:56.750
And so, I can do a show run for

173
00:09:56.750 --> 00:10:02.300
interface loopback 6 to get its network
and I'm gonna add that to the access list.

174
00:10:02.300 --> 00:10:09.720
So, if I do a IPv6 access-list and
it was called REDIST, right.

175
00:10:09.720 --> 00:10:13.150
That was the distribution list and
then I just need to get us added to it.

176
00:10:13.150 --> 00:10:17.919
I'm gonna say permit IPv6

177
00:10:17.919 --> 00:10:23.519
2001:606:606 and

178
00:10:23.519 --> 00:10:29.330
then it was ::/64, right?

179
00:10:29.330 --> 00:10:31.681
I'm looking at my notes here,
because I wrote that down earlier on,

180
00:10:31.681 --> 00:10:33.277
otherwise I wouldn't have remembered that.

181
00:10:33.277 --> 00:10:38.978
But it was 2001:606:606 ::6/64.

182
00:10:38.978 --> 00:10:41.979
I'm just saying :: so
we get that whole network, right?

183
00:10:41.979 --> 00:10:44.630
So I'm gonna be permitting that.

184
00:10:44.630 --> 00:10:49.200
And with IPv6 access list, they're always
extended, so you have a source and

185
00:10:49.200 --> 00:10:52.590
a destination, and when it's a route map,
you don't really need that destination, so

186
00:10:52.590 --> 00:10:55.180
I'm just gonna put any on that to flag it.

187
00:10:55.180 --> 00:10:58.710
And that should fix that,
if I look at my access list now, so

188
00:10:58.710 --> 00:11:05.290
I'm gonna do a show access-list.

189
00:11:05.290 --> 00:11:10.230
All right, I can see the access-list and
it's got that 2001:2600 network.

190
00:11:10.230 --> 00:11:12.270
And now it's got
the 2001:606:606 network and

191
00:11:12.270 --> 00:11:16.720
it's already got four matches on it,
right?

192
00:11:16.720 --> 00:11:18.990
That means traffic is already
hitting this route map.

193
00:11:18.990 --> 00:11:23.660
EIGRP is fast, it starts advertising right
away, and soit's already getting matches.

194
00:11:23.660 --> 00:11:25.610
I bet we'll see that solves our problem.

195
00:11:25.610 --> 00:11:28.490
So, let's jump out to NYEDGE1 and see.

196
00:11:28.490 --> 00:11:30.920
So I still have my show IP route here,

197
00:11:30.920 --> 00:11:36.340
which showed the 2001 2600 network,
but not the 2001 606 network.

198
00:11:36.340 --> 00:11:42.030
And if I rerun that command, there it is,

199
00:11:42.030 --> 00:11:45.210
now I've got 2001 606 right there,
and we're in business.

200
00:11:45.210 --> 00:11:49.120
I'll check EDGE2 just to be on the safe
side, again, you might think we've

201
00:11:49.120 --> 00:11:52.390
solved the whole problem, and it turns
out they sneak a second part into it.

202
00:11:52.390 --> 00:11:55.840
So I definitely want to double check that,
but I've got it there too.

203
00:11:55.840 --> 00:12:00.930
All right, so in this case the problem was
that it just wasn't redistributed right?

204
00:12:00.930 --> 00:12:04.430
The redistribute had a route map,
the route map used an access list.

205
00:12:04.430 --> 00:12:08.350
The access list did not include
loop back six's network.

206
00:12:08.350 --> 00:12:10.350
Once we added that on there, it was fixed.

207
00:12:10.350 --> 00:12:12.040
And now it shows up in the other routers.

208
00:12:12.040 --> 00:12:13.630
So, this problem is solved.

209
00:12:13.630 --> 00:12:15.050
So that takes care of this ticket.

210
00:12:15.050 --> 00:12:20.524
Stay tuned we've got more
troubleshooting tickets coming up next.

211
00:12:20.524 --> 00:12:26.679
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #4` from set #10. The trouble ticket states that "You are unable to ping 192.168.32.5 (NYCORE2) from 192.168.16.5 (NYCORE1), yet you can ping 192.168.32.1. "
episodes.title: Set 10 Issue 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.928
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.928 --> 00:00:13.610
All right, welcome back to another Cisco
troubleshooting episode here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.610 --> 00:00:17.550
We're jumping back into set ten and
tackling issue number four, and

4
00:00:17.550 --> 00:00:21.160
it looks like we're gonna take
a step back into the world of IPv4.

5
00:00:21.160 --> 00:00:24.350
We've been doing IPv6 the last few,
but this ticket reads like this.

6
00:00:24.350 --> 00:00:29.747
It says,
you are unable to ping 192.168.32.5,

7
00:00:29.747 --> 00:00:34.420
which is NYCORE2 from 192.168.16.5,

8
00:00:34.420 --> 00:00:40.980
which is NYCORE1, yet
you can ping 192.168.32.1.

9
00:00:40.980 --> 00:00:42.210
Well, that's just confusing.

10
00:00:42.210 --> 00:00:44.480
All right, so the ticket doesn't
make a while lot of sense.

11
00:00:44.480 --> 00:00:47.460
We need to go and basically see
this in action to get an idea.

12
00:00:47.460 --> 00:00:48.550
But at a minimum,

13
00:00:48.550 --> 00:00:54.140
what we can take away from is that NYCORE1
is having a problem pinging NYCORE2.

14
00:00:54.140 --> 00:00:56.390
And it looks like we've got two
different networks involved.

15
00:00:56.390 --> 00:00:58.610
So we've probably got
a routing issue on this one,

16
00:00:58.610 --> 00:01:00.560
and we just need to find
out what's happening.

17
00:01:00.560 --> 00:01:04.420
So let's jump over to NYCORE1,
since it's our problem.

18
00:01:04.420 --> 00:01:09.040
And if I look at the topology,
NYCORE1 that's this switch, right here.

19
00:01:09.040 --> 00:01:11.268
And it's 192.168.16.5.

20
00:01:11.268 --> 00:01:15.539
And it's trying to ping 192.168.32.5,

21
00:01:15.539 --> 00:01:20.470
which is NYCORE2 right here,
and that's failing.

22
00:01:20.470 --> 00:01:24.259
But it's telling me that
we can ping 192.168.32.1.

23
00:01:24.259 --> 00:01:26.250
Now, what is that?

24
00:01:26.250 --> 00:01:29.270
That is NYEDGE2 way up here.

25
00:01:29.270 --> 00:01:34.300
So basically, if NYCORE1 tries
to ping edge two, it gets there.

26
00:01:34.300 --> 00:01:36.710
If it tries to ping core two, it doesn't.

27
00:01:36.710 --> 00:01:38.240
And looking at this topology,

28
00:01:38.240 --> 00:01:41.860
there's actually a few different paths
we can take to get to that destination.

29
00:01:41.860 --> 00:01:44.360
So we're gonna need to figure out
those paths and look at that.

30
00:01:44.360 --> 00:01:47.430
But before we start, let's just jump
over to CORE1 and verify that we

31
00:01:47.430 --> 00:01:51.720
are interpreting the question properly cuz
I might be reading this question wrong.

32
00:01:51.720 --> 00:01:52.870
It's kind of written confusingly.

33
00:01:52.870 --> 00:01:56.320
So let's jump over to CORE1 and
see if we can't sort that out.

34
00:01:56.320 --> 00:02:01.010
So on NYCORE1, I'm basically
gonna verify it's IP address.

35
00:02:01.010 --> 00:02:07.280
It's telling me that I'm 192.168.16.5 and
I doubt it's lying on that.

36
00:02:07.280 --> 00:02:08.520
So let's find out.

37
00:02:08.520 --> 00:02:13.630
If I do a show IP Interface brief, and
I'll exclude the other signed interfaces,

38
00:02:13.630 --> 00:02:17.720
Sure enough my Vlan1
interface is 192.168.16.5.

39
00:02:17.720 --> 00:02:24.320
Now, I'm trying to ping 192.168.32.5,
that's a different network.

40
00:02:24.320 --> 00:02:26.650
A network that I'm not plugged in to.

41
00:02:26.650 --> 00:02:29.300
And so that means I'm gonna need
to know a route to get there or

42
00:02:29.300 --> 00:02:30.870
have a default gateway.

43
00:02:30.870 --> 00:02:32.920
Well if this is a layer two switch,

44
00:02:32.920 --> 00:02:37.800
you can spot gateways really easy
in the config by doing a show run,

45
00:02:37.800 --> 00:02:42.440
piping it into the include command and
looking for the word gateway, all right?

46
00:02:42.440 --> 00:02:46.780
I don't have one or you could
even search for the word default.

47
00:02:46.780 --> 00:02:50.610
That's another one that it might turn
up under, and it's not there either.

48
00:02:50.610 --> 00:02:55.320
If this is a layer three switch, then we
might have a static default route defined.

49
00:02:55.320 --> 00:02:58.530
And if that's the case, we'll just see it
in our routing table or dynamic protocol,

50
00:02:58.530 --> 00:03:00.470
we'll see it in the routing table also.

51
00:03:00.470 --> 00:03:05.171
So I'll just do a show IP route and see if
I have a default route there and I don't.

52
00:03:05.171 --> 00:03:08.825
Okay, so if I don't have a default route
to be able to get to it, the only other

53
00:03:08.825 --> 00:03:12.520
way I'm gonna get there is if I learn
it from a dynamic routing protocol.

54
00:03:12.520 --> 00:03:17.450
And as I look at my list,
sure enough I'm learning 192.168.32,

55
00:03:17.450 --> 00:03:19.691
I'm actually learning it twice.

56
00:03:19.691 --> 00:03:22.570
And we look at that,
what's the difference?

57
00:03:22.570 --> 00:03:25.072
Well it's actually not much of
a difference at all here, is it?

58
00:03:25.072 --> 00:03:30.459
I'm learning 192.160.32 twice with
two different subnet masks, right?

59
00:03:30.459 --> 00:03:33.094
I'm learning a /24 and a /27.

60
00:03:33.094 --> 00:03:35.900
Now normally that would be a red flag for
me.

61
00:03:35.900 --> 00:03:37.333
I'd say oop, there's a problem, right?

62
00:03:37.333 --> 00:03:41.757
I'm learning two routes,
one more specific than the other.

63
00:03:41.757 --> 00:03:46.089
Remember, when you learn
a route like this,

64
00:03:46.089 --> 00:03:49.423
the /27 will trump the /24.

65
00:03:49.423 --> 00:03:52.230
The /27 is more specific.

66
00:03:52.230 --> 00:03:57.164
Well in this case,
I'm pinging 192.168.32.5, and

67
00:03:57.164 --> 00:04:03.259
32.5 would fall under this /27 so
it's gonna match this one and not match.

68
00:04:03.259 --> 00:04:04.210
Well, it does match the one above it.

69
00:04:04.210 --> 00:04:05.530
But it's gonna use the bottom one, and

70
00:04:05.530 --> 00:04:08.150
I say that would normally
be a red flag for me.

71
00:04:08.150 --> 00:04:09.250
Why isn't it?

72
00:04:09.250 --> 00:04:12.450
Well it's not a red flag for me,
because if I look over here,

73
00:04:12.450 --> 00:04:16.400
I've got two different routes to
get there, and where do they go?

74
00:04:16.400 --> 00:04:17.171
They go to the same place.

75
00:04:17.171 --> 00:04:21.800
They both go to 192.168.16.1
on my Vlan1 interface.

76
00:04:21.800 --> 00:04:24.770
And since they go to the same place,
what do I care which one they follow.

77
00:04:24.770 --> 00:04:28.450
So yes, I've got two routes and
no it doesn't bother me, right?

78
00:04:28.450 --> 00:04:30.270
So [LAUGH] that's not our problem.

79
00:04:30.270 --> 00:04:32.105
But we do need to be aware of it, okay?

80
00:04:32.105 --> 00:04:35.425
Now I don't know who 192.168.16.1 is.

81
00:04:35.425 --> 00:04:39.141
Let's look at our diagram and
see if they've names to tell us.

82
00:04:39.141 --> 00:04:47.464
192.168.16.1, looking at my topology
that is NYEDGE1 right here, okay?

83
00:04:47.464 --> 00:04:52.642
So when I try and reach 192.168.32.5,

84
00:04:52.642 --> 00:04:58.298
I'm going up here to NYEDGE1,
that seems a little odd.

85
00:04:58.298 --> 00:05:02.838
But NYEDGE1 could send me over here
to NYEDGE2, and I could get to that

86
00:05:02.838 --> 00:05:07.240
destination, so that works for
me but it's crossing a serial link.

87
00:05:07.240 --> 00:05:09.770
That seems a little sub optimal,
all right?

88
00:05:09.770 --> 00:05:12.980
I've got Ethernet links down here that
should be able to get me to it, and

89
00:05:12.980 --> 00:05:14.360
that would be faster.

90
00:05:14.360 --> 00:05:17.530
But it looks like I'm taking
a sub-optimal route that even in itself

91
00:05:17.530 --> 00:05:19.950
isn't a problem either because
remember the troubleshooting ticket.

92
00:05:19.950 --> 00:05:22.940
They're not telling me we need
the fastest route or best route.

93
00:05:22.940 --> 00:05:27.350
They're just saying I can't even ping,
so I'm not getting to the other side.

94
00:05:27.350 --> 00:05:28.890
Let's see if we can find out why.

95
00:05:28.890 --> 00:05:33.366
So when I exit NYCORE1,
we're exiting Vlan 1, and

96
00:05:33.366 --> 00:05:37.747
Vlan 1 is apparently taking
us up here to NYEDGE1.

97
00:05:37.747 --> 00:05:39.000
Let's make sure it really is.

98
00:05:39.000 --> 00:05:42.950
Let me make sure that I
can truly ping 16.1 and

99
00:05:42.950 --> 00:05:46.715
verify that information is all correct and
I'm not being kinda led astray.

100
00:05:46.715 --> 00:05:48.285
So that happens.

101
00:05:48.285 --> 00:05:50.485
Sometimes you see something in
a config and you're like oh,

102
00:05:50.485 --> 00:05:53.245
that's got to be the problem, and
it turns out not to be the problem.

103
00:05:53.245 --> 00:05:55.475
But it's like a distraction
that kind of draws you into it.

104
00:05:55.475 --> 00:06:02.445
So what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna ping
192.168.16.1 that's my default gateway.

105
00:06:02.445 --> 00:06:03.839
So right now, if I try and

106
00:06:03.839 --> 00:06:09.501
get to that 192.168.32.5 I'm going
to 192.168.16.1 and I can get there.

107
00:06:09.501 --> 00:06:11.486
All right, so I am able to get there.

108
00:06:11.486 --> 00:06:20.240
And if I try and ping 192.168.32.5,
I don't get there.

109
00:06:20.240 --> 00:06:25.640
Okay, so I am making it to the next stop,
but I'm not getting beyond it.

110
00:06:25.640 --> 00:06:27.900
Well, where's the breakdown?

111
00:06:27.900 --> 00:06:29.730
I've said this in multiple
troubleshooting issues.

112
00:06:29.730 --> 00:06:32.980
When you've got more than one device in
between you and a destination, it's always

113
00:06:32.980 --> 00:06:37.090
a good idea to do a traceroute and see
if you can turn up where the failure is.

114
00:06:37.090 --> 00:06:43.570
So I'm gonna go traceroute to
192.168.32.5, so I can see where it stops.

115
00:06:43.570 --> 00:06:44.730
I know the first part.

116
00:06:44.730 --> 00:06:47.430
I know I'm gonna leave NYCORE1.

117
00:06:47.430 --> 00:06:51.680
And I'm gonna go up to NYEDGE1 and
I know I can get there.

118
00:06:51.680 --> 00:06:53.820
But I don't know where
I'm going from there, and

119
00:06:53.820 --> 00:06:56.140
that's what I want the trace
route to show me and so

120
00:06:56.140 --> 00:07:00.470
if I come back here to the trace route,
I can see it's still thinking.

121
00:07:00.470 --> 00:07:01.370
There we go.

122
00:07:01.370 --> 00:07:06.510
I made it to NYEDGE1, so I hit that
first step that I knew I could get to,

123
00:07:06.510 --> 00:07:10.030
I'm really curious to see what that
second step is and third and beyond that.

124
00:07:10.030 --> 00:07:15.800
So the next step is 192.168.1.3 and
then it dies, okay.

125
00:07:15.800 --> 00:07:21.275
So I need to figure out who 192.168.1.3
is because they're either the problem or

126
00:07:21.275 --> 00:07:24.026
they're directly connected to the problem.

127
00:07:24.026 --> 00:07:27.220
They're gonna help me narrow
this down to just two devices.

128
00:07:27.220 --> 00:07:33.360
And so if I go back to my diagram,
I'm just gonna look for 192.168.1.3.

129
00:07:33.360 --> 00:07:38.844
Now looking at it, this link right here,
on edge one it's serial

130
00:07:38.844 --> 00:07:44.443
001 interface is 192.168.1.2 and
it's a /31.

131
00:07:44.443 --> 00:07:47.497
That's kind of a weird
subnet to use right there.

132
00:07:47.497 --> 00:07:51.160
/31 would include 0.2 And 0.3, so

133
00:07:51.160 --> 00:07:57.210
that would indicate that it's this
link which is leading me to NYWAN1.

134
00:07:57.210 --> 00:08:00.780
Now, this network is getting
a little bit weird, isn't it?

135
00:08:00.780 --> 00:08:06.210
It looks like I'm going up to NYEDGE1,
and down to NYWAN1,

136
00:08:06.210 --> 00:08:10.680
but NYWAN1 Is apparently
killing off my traffic.

137
00:08:10.680 --> 00:08:12.970
So let's go see if we
can't figure that out.

138
00:08:12.970 --> 00:08:17.480
First off I want to verify
this guy is actually 0.3,

139
00:08:17.480 --> 00:08:21.000
192.168.1.3 since that's
what next in my list.

140
00:08:21.000 --> 00:08:24.590
And if it is then I'll see what it can
get to and what it can't, all right.

141
00:08:24.590 --> 00:08:27.070
So let me jump over to NYWAN1.

142
00:08:28.830 --> 00:08:31.780
And we'll start off with just
a show IP interface brief to make

143
00:08:31.780 --> 00:08:33.620
sure we're on the right host.

144
00:08:33.620 --> 00:08:39.450
So I'm expecting to see
an interface that's 192.168.1.3 and

145
00:08:39.450 --> 00:08:42.881
sure enough, there it is on serial 1/0.

146
00:08:42.881 --> 00:08:45.820
So my trace route stopped here.

147
00:08:45.820 --> 00:08:49.270
I got to NYWAN1 and then I stopped.

148
00:08:49.270 --> 00:08:54.102
NYWAN1 has a direct
connection NYEDGE2 which is

149
00:08:54.102 --> 00:09:00.150
192.168.32.1 and
it said I was able to ping that.

150
00:09:00.150 --> 00:09:04.900
But I wasn't able to ping 192.168.32.5
which is the guy down here.

151
00:09:04.900 --> 00:09:09.990
And so in theory, if I ping and
get to here it should route me up to here,

152
00:09:09.990 --> 00:09:13.030
and NYEDGE2 should be able
to route me down to here.

153
00:09:13.030 --> 00:09:15.789
Now since my trace route
stopped at this node,

154
00:09:15.789 --> 00:09:20.260
that means either this guy is the problem
or this guy up here is the problem.

155
00:09:20.260 --> 00:09:23.530
I've kind of narrowed it down to these
two devices now to find out connectivity.

156
00:09:23.530 --> 00:09:26.780
Now, I doubt the problem is NYEDGE2.

157
00:09:26.780 --> 00:09:30.421
Because it's directly connected
to the 192.168.32 network.

158
00:09:30.421 --> 00:09:32.800
It could have an ACL that's stopping me.

159
00:09:32.800 --> 00:09:33.880
That's possible.

160
00:09:33.880 --> 00:09:36.222
It could be that this serial
interface is down, but

161
00:09:36.222 --> 00:09:37.917
I'll see that over here on NYWAN1.

162
00:09:37.917 --> 00:09:40.340
So let's start here on NYWAN1 and
see what it's got.

163
00:09:42.140 --> 00:09:46.985
So that link that runs in between
NYWAN1 and NYEDGE2, that's this serial

164
00:09:46.985 --> 00:09:52.696
0/1/1 link and they didn't put an IPv4
address on here so it might not have one.

165
00:09:52.696 --> 00:09:53.254
Let's look at it.

166
00:09:53.254 --> 00:10:01.260
Serial 011 on NYWAN1 and sure enough,
it doesn't have an IPv4 address at all.

167
00:10:01.260 --> 00:10:03.842
Well does that mean I can't
flow IP before traffic over it?

168
00:10:03.842 --> 00:10:04.957
Not necessarily.

169
00:10:04.957 --> 00:10:08.220
There could be an IPv6 tunnel,
like a 6 to 4 tunnel on there or

170
00:10:08.220 --> 00:10:11.928
one of the various other tunnel types
like a Teredo tunnel or whatever.

171
00:10:11.928 --> 00:10:18.760
Let's just see if there's anything
on that interface, serial 0/1/1.

172
00:10:18.760 --> 00:10:24.240
No, not looking like a tunnel this time.

173
00:10:24.240 --> 00:10:27.604
Actually if we had a tunnel, I would have
seen it under show IP interface brief,

174
00:10:27.604 --> 00:10:28.420
wouldn't I've?

175
00:10:28.420 --> 00:10:32.650
Tunnels show up as interfaces, and
I don't have any tunnel interfaces.

176
00:10:32.650 --> 00:10:39.220
All right, so now when NYCORE1
goes to ping 192.168.32.5, right?

177
00:10:39.220 --> 00:10:41.470
That was the ping that I did originally.

178
00:10:41.470 --> 00:10:48.220
I went up to EDGE1,
I went down to WAN1, and WAN1,

179
00:10:48.220 --> 00:10:54.840
I can't use this link cuz it's IPv6 only
with no tunnel, and I kinda stopped here.

180
00:10:54.840 --> 00:10:57.010
Well, look at the possible
outcomes of that.

181
00:10:57.010 --> 00:11:00.640
I could go back this link to EDGE1,
that would mean I have a loop or

182
00:11:00.640 --> 00:11:02.960
I could go back down to CORE1.

183
00:11:02.960 --> 00:11:05.240
This interface is a trunk.

184
00:11:05.240 --> 00:11:09.010
But it's trunking on the other networks,
not the 192.168.32 network, and so

185
00:11:09.010 --> 00:11:13.650
I'd have to bounce through yet
another router on my way to a destination.

186
00:11:13.650 --> 00:11:14.795
It looks like I'm being
routed to a dead end.

187
00:11:14.795 --> 00:11:18.750
All right, it looks like I'm being
sent to not the right place.

188
00:11:18.750 --> 00:11:21.010
So I need to figure out
what's going on there.

189
00:11:21.010 --> 00:11:23.000
And let's look NYWAN1's routing table.

190
00:11:24.070 --> 00:11:27.590
This one is actually looking like
a pretty good problem for us.

191
00:11:27.590 --> 00:11:29.570
I think we're just being
routed in the wrong direction.

192
00:11:29.570 --> 00:11:33.936
So what I'm looking for here in
the routing table is 192.168.32, and

193
00:11:33.936 --> 00:11:34.651
there it is.

194
00:11:34.651 --> 00:11:42.800
[LAUGH] There's two different connections
to it, and look at these connections.

195
00:11:42.800 --> 00:11:44.770
One's a EIGRP route.

196
00:11:44.770 --> 00:11:50.620
I can get to 192.168.32.0 via 192.168.1.2,
okay?

197
00:11:50.620 --> 00:11:54.103
So I can get there by going
right back across this link,

198
00:11:54.103 --> 00:11:57.150
that's that loop I was talking about,
right?

199
00:11:57.150 --> 00:12:00.080
NYWAN1 knows it can get there
by going through this loop.

200
00:12:00.080 --> 00:12:03.434
But the second route, that's the one
that's gonna be our problem.

201
00:12:03.434 --> 00:12:04.850
I guess second and third.

202
00:12:04.850 --> 00:12:09.566
Look at this, 192.168.32.0/27 there's

203
00:12:09.566 --> 00:12:14.099
a specific route is directly
connected via Loopback1.

204
00:12:14.099 --> 00:12:14.889
It's a deadend.

205
00:12:14.889 --> 00:12:16.572
This is a bad route.

206
00:12:16.572 --> 00:12:22.879
The 192.168.32.0/27 network is
overlapping with our other network and

207
00:12:22.879 --> 00:12:27.007
because it's got a better
prefix it's being preferred.

208
00:12:27.007 --> 00:12:31.582
Because it's a more specific prefix
because of that /27 that it knows

209
00:12:31.582 --> 00:12:36.307
that this is better than the /24 and
it's sending me to the sloop back and

210
00:12:36.307 --> 00:12:39.157
that's when my trace
route died here right?

211
00:12:39.157 --> 00:12:43.878
My trace route,
I left in my core one I went to NYEDGE1,

212
00:12:43.878 --> 00:12:47.000
I came to NYWAN1, and then it died.

213
00:12:47.000 --> 00:12:50.070
Because the next hop was a loop-back
interface with no other devices on

214
00:12:50.070 --> 00:12:51.170
the other end of it.

215
00:12:51.170 --> 00:12:53.330
And that was the end of that path,
all right.

216
00:12:53.330 --> 00:12:56.050
So I've got just a bad route.

217
00:12:56.050 --> 00:12:58.230
If I take that route out,
what's gonna happen?

218
00:12:58.230 --> 00:13:01.670
This guy will stop advertising that /27.

219
00:13:01.670 --> 00:13:05.470
And now the only one that'd be left
is /24 and hopefully it's correct.

220
00:13:05.470 --> 00:13:06.930
Maybe it isn't, but we'll find out.

221
00:13:06.930 --> 00:13:08.640
But let's get that bad one out of here.

222
00:13:08.640 --> 00:13:11.270
Now there's a few different ways I
can get the bad one out of here.

223
00:13:11.270 --> 00:13:14.170
The easiest one is just to shut
the interface down, right?

224
00:13:14.170 --> 00:13:16.160
If I shut that loop back interface down,

225
00:13:16.160 --> 00:13:18.940
the route comes out of the routing table
and this guy stops advertising it.

226
00:13:18.940 --> 00:13:20.490
So that's what I'm gonna do.

227
00:13:21.650 --> 00:13:23.580
That's attached to my loop back one.

228
00:13:23.580 --> 00:13:25.240
So I'm just going jump
into configuration and

229
00:13:25.240 --> 00:13:29.030
go into interface loop back one and
just do a shut down, all right.

230
00:13:29.030 --> 00:13:31.450
Now pros and cons with this.

231
00:13:31.450 --> 00:13:34.670
On a positive note it's very easy for
me to undo this.

232
00:13:34.670 --> 00:13:36.850
If I make this change and

233
00:13:36.850 --> 00:13:39.050
I decide it's not the right thing
I can just come and undo it.

234
00:13:39.050 --> 00:13:40.890
Do a no shutdown and it's back.

235
00:13:40.890 --> 00:13:45.220
But if this does solve the problem
in real life land, we'd wanna delete

236
00:13:45.220 --> 00:13:48.750
that loopback interface and we'd wanna
delete any other configuration that

237
00:13:48.750 --> 00:13:51.330
referenced it cuz otherwise it'll
make confusion down the road.

238
00:13:51.330 --> 00:13:54.730
You might hire somebody new and they're
like why is that loopback interface down?

239
00:13:54.730 --> 00:13:56.930
Let me do a no shutdown and
bring it up, right?

240
00:13:56.930 --> 00:13:58.250
And then this problem comes back again.

241
00:13:58.250 --> 00:14:00.310
So we don't wanna leave
the problem just laying around.

242
00:14:00.310 --> 00:14:02.490
But as a great way to
test the solution and

243
00:14:02.490 --> 00:14:04.980
make sure it's right,
we can do a quick shut down.

244
00:14:04.980 --> 00:14:07.240
That's gonna take it out
of our routing table.

245
00:14:07.240 --> 00:14:11.450
And if I do a show IP route now and
take a look at my routing table,

246
00:14:11.450 --> 00:14:17.350
I should only have one way to get
to 192.168.32, it's via EIGRP.

247
00:14:18.440 --> 00:14:21.139
So now I'm not advertising
that 27 anymore, and

248
00:14:21.139 --> 00:14:25.556
if I jump back to our original source of
this issue it was all from NYCORE1, right?

249
00:14:25.556 --> 00:14:30.104
If I jump back to NYCORE1,
where I left that trace route running,

250
00:14:30.104 --> 00:14:33.532
but if I get back to this guy and
I do a show IP route.

251
00:14:33.532 --> 00:14:38.036
It used to have two routes from 192.68.32.

252
00:14:38.036 --> 00:14:39.736
Now it only has one, and

253
00:14:39.736 --> 00:14:45.710
it used to route them through
192.68.16.1 and it still does.

254
00:14:45.710 --> 00:14:49.220
So that really hasn't changed,
both those routes went the same direction.

255
00:14:49.220 --> 00:14:53.900
So now I'm being routed
through 192.168.16.1 and

256
00:14:53.900 --> 00:14:56.390
from there where does it go?

257
00:14:56.390 --> 00:14:59.835
Well hopefully,
it goes to the destination, right?

258
00:14:59.835 --> 00:15:03.880
192.168.16.1 we established
was NYEDGE1 up here, and

259
00:15:03.880 --> 00:15:07.960
it was NYEDGE1 that was
sending us down to NYWAN1.

260
00:15:07.960 --> 00:15:12.700
But I saw just a moment ago that NYWAN1
is now sending that traffic to NYEDGE1.

261
00:15:12.700 --> 00:15:15.200
So if that's the case we've got a loop,
right?

262
00:15:15.200 --> 00:15:16.002
Well hopefully not.

263
00:15:16.002 --> 00:15:18.460
Hopefully NYEDGE1 has
learned about a route for us.

264
00:15:18.460 --> 00:15:22.478
Let's go back to NYEDGE1 and
see what it's got.

265
00:15:22.478 --> 00:15:25.220
Now, on NYEDGE1 oh, we've actually
never logged into this one so

266
00:15:25.220 --> 00:15:27.060
we didn't get to see where it was going.

267
00:15:27.060 --> 00:15:32.634
So let's just take a look at that and
I'm gonna do a show IP route and

268
00:15:32.634 --> 00:15:37.529
I'm gonna look for
that 192.168.32 network.

269
00:15:37.529 --> 00:15:38.029
It was 0.5.

270
00:15:39.470 --> 00:15:44.895
So there it is, and I've learned that
via 192.168.1.1 which is on my serial

271
00:15:44.895 --> 00:15:50.970
0/0/0 interface, and if I look at
the diagram, that is this link up top.

272
00:15:50.970 --> 00:15:53.180
It's gonna send me across to EDGE2.

273
00:15:53.180 --> 00:16:00.840
So if NYCORE1 tried to ping 192.168.32
something we're gonna go up here and

274
00:16:00.840 --> 00:16:05.230
then over here and
then down to get at that network, right?

275
00:16:05.230 --> 00:16:10.060
And if NYWAN1 tries to get there,
it's gonna go up here, over and then down.

276
00:16:10.060 --> 00:16:11.140
It's sub optimal, right?

277
00:16:11.140 --> 00:16:13.277
This link may be down or
oh, this link wasn't IPv4.

278
00:16:13.277 --> 00:16:16.860
It was IPv6 only, so that's why it'll
skip that and go around that way.

279
00:16:16.860 --> 00:16:20.960
So our routing topology seems sound,
this seems self-optimal right?

280
00:16:20.960 --> 00:16:23.390
because we have the Ethernet links but
at least at sound.

281
00:16:23.390 --> 00:16:25.020
Let's go see if it works.

282
00:16:25.020 --> 00:16:30.202
So I'm gonna go back to NYCORE1 and
when we started this problem,

283
00:16:30.202 --> 00:16:34.830
NYCORE1 was able to ping 192.168.32.1, but

284
00:16:34.830 --> 00:16:41.509
it wasn't able to ping 0.5 and that's
because 0.5 was covered by that /27.

285
00:16:41.509 --> 00:16:42.472
That one wasn't.

286
00:16:42.472 --> 00:16:46.650
And when I ping 0.5,
now I'm able to get there.

287
00:16:46.650 --> 00:16:48.920
So we had overlapping routes,

288
00:16:48.920 --> 00:16:53.390
and one route was good, the other route
was pointing to a loop back so it was bad.

289
00:16:53.390 --> 00:16:57.470
But the one that was bad had
a more specific subnet, right?

290
00:16:57.470 --> 00:17:01.780
It had a /27 and the more specific
subnet is always preferred if you have

291
00:17:01.780 --> 00:17:04.220
duplicate routes,
if you match more than one route,

292
00:17:04.220 --> 00:17:08.210
you pick the one with the most specific
prefix, and that's what we had here.

293
00:17:08.210 --> 00:17:12.330
So once we tracked that down we just
killed that bad route, and now we're safe.

294
00:17:12.330 --> 00:17:14.910
Now technically we solved the problem and
this one's done.

295
00:17:14.910 --> 00:17:18.070
In real life land we'd wanna go and
get rid of that loopback interface and

296
00:17:18.070 --> 00:17:20.420
get rid of any configuration
that referenced it.

297
00:17:20.420 --> 00:17:22.643
It was being advertised in the EIGRP,
so we have to take it out there too.

298
00:17:22.643 --> 00:17:27.085
But once that's done, it's now clear and
the problem is solved.

299
00:17:27.085 --> 00:17:28.890
All right,
well that takes care of issue four.

300
00:17:28.890 --> 00:17:31.000
We've got one more issue in this set,
issue five.

301
00:17:31.000 --> 00:17:32.504
Stay tuned cause it's coming up next.

302
00:17:32.504 --> 00:17:40.829
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #5` from set #10. The trouble ticket states that "You are unable to ping 192.168.5.1 or 192.168.6.1 from NYCORE1 "
episodes.title: Set 10 Issue 5
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.313 --> 00:00:08.382
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.382 --> 00:00:13.550
It's that time again for another Cisco
trouble shooting question here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.550 --> 00:00:16.890
We're back on set number ten
tackling issue number five.

4
00:00:16.890 --> 00:00:18.519
And the trouble shooting
ticket reads like this,

5
00:00:18.519 --> 00:00:21.800
it says you are unable to ping
192.168.5.1 or 192.168.6.1 from NYCORE1.

6
00:00:21.800 --> 00:00:29.360
Well NYCORE1 is one of our layer three
switches and it's having a little

7
00:00:29.360 --> 00:00:35.310
bit of reach ability issues, so
let's look at our diagram and

8
00:00:35.310 --> 00:00:37.930
see if we can figure out
where we're gonna be working.

9
00:00:37.930 --> 00:00:40.580
We know NYCORE1 is our problem, and

10
00:00:40.580 --> 00:00:46.240
on the diagram it shows it as
being 192.168.16.5 on Vlan1.

11
00:00:46.240 --> 00:00:49.530
And well, actually, right over here,
we've 192.168.5.1 and 6.1.

12
00:00:49.530 --> 00:00:55.180
Those are the two people that we
can't ping that are on NYWAN1.

13
00:00:55.180 --> 00:00:59.750
Now looking at it, those are on a gigabit
interface, and it's set for router on

14
00:00:59.750 --> 00:01:03.810
a stick, so they're doing some kind of
sub interfaces and they're attached.

15
00:01:03.810 --> 00:01:05.650
I see there's sub-interface .5 and .6 so

16
00:01:05.650 --> 00:01:09.730
we could assume that these are VLANs five
and six and we'll verify that in a second.

17
