00:01:09.730 --> 00:01:11.140
Assuming those are VLANS five and

18
00:01:11.140 --> 00:01:16.710
six I don't know if NYCORE1 even has
an interface non VLAN 5 or VLAN 6.

19
00:01:16.710 --> 00:01:20.340
We might not have created SVIs, and
if that's the case, this could actually be

20
00:01:20.340 --> 00:01:24.100
really complex because we could be getting
sent all the way over to one of these

21
00:01:24.100 --> 00:01:27.570
other systems to get routed between
the VLANs and get that access.

22
00:01:27.570 --> 00:01:28.470
So we're gonna have to try and

23
00:01:28.470 --> 00:01:32.600
figure out how we even get to
those networks in the first place.

24
00:01:32.600 --> 00:01:34.430
But I'll tell you where
I really wanna start.

25
00:01:34.430 --> 00:01:36.910
If I can't get to those two interfaces,

26
00:01:36.910 --> 00:01:39.050
it could be that they're
just configured wrong.

27
00:01:39.050 --> 00:01:41.620
This is router on a stock, and
we don't see that very often.

28
00:01:41.620 --> 00:01:43.450
So it's a great place to have a failure.

29
00:01:43.450 --> 00:01:46.750
Let's just go verify that configuration,
make sure the interfaces are up, and that

30
00:01:46.750 --> 00:01:50.070
kinda stuff and we might be able to save
ourselves a lot of time jumping around

31
00:01:50.070 --> 00:01:54.437
lots of devices to find a problem, when it
was always here at the source,all right?

32
00:01:54.437 --> 00:01:57.828
So, I'm gonna start there on NYWAN1
just verifying the router on a stick

33
00:01:57.828 --> 00:01:59.578
configuration.

34
00:01:59.578 --> 00:02:04.550
So on this one I'm gonna
start with a show IP

35
00:02:04.550 --> 00:02:11.060
interface brief so I can make sure the IP
addresses are correct on the interfaces.

36
00:02:11.060 --> 00:02:13.460
And here I see that the gigabit
ethernet is 0/0.5 and 0.6 and

37
00:02:13.460 --> 00:02:14.660
the are on 192.168.5.1 and 6.1.

38
00:02:14.660 --> 00:02:19.070
The parent interface doesn't have an IP,
but

39
00:02:19.070 --> 00:02:23.310
I don't care about that
as long as it's up up.

40
00:02:23.310 --> 00:02:27.370
And as I look at their status,
all three of them are up-up.

41
00:02:27.370 --> 00:02:30.890
So the interfaces have IPs,
and they're online.

42
00:02:30.890 --> 00:02:34.490
So that looks good on this side,
well, I say it looks good.

43
00:02:34.490 --> 00:02:36.830
Let's verify those VLAN numbers too.

44
00:02:36.830 --> 00:02:38.460
I can't see the VLAN number here.

45
00:02:38.460 --> 00:02:40.290
It's actually tied into the subinterface,
so

46
00:02:40.290 --> 00:02:45.440
I'm gonna do a show run for
interface gi0/0.5.

47
00:02:45.440 --> 00:02:50.090
And 0.0.6 and
sure enough they are VLANs five and six.

48
00:02:50.090 --> 00:02:53.770
So, things are looking okay here
as far communications on that.

49
00:02:53.770 --> 00:02:56.740
Let's go take a look at
the other end of this trunk.

50
00:02:56.740 --> 00:03:01.240
Router on a stick requires a trunk to
function and while I might not have SVIs,

51
00:03:01.240 --> 00:03:02.960
I do still have to have
a trunk configured.

52
00:03:02.960 --> 00:03:08.570
So we'll go double check
that on NYCORE1 and

53
00:03:08.570 --> 00:03:14.460
so we'll jump into this and did they
actually tell me what interface this is?

54
00:03:14.460 --> 00:03:15.300
They don't.

55
00:03:15.300 --> 00:03:18.189
Great.
I don't know what interface that's coming

56
00:03:18.189 --> 00:03:22.269
in on we've got this,
this note here that's FA1/0/22, but

57
00:03:22.269 --> 00:03:24.930
that's actually NYACESS1 port, right?

58
00:03:24.930 --> 00:03:25.990
That guy down here.

59
00:03:25.990 --> 00:03:27.410
So this one isn't named.

60
00:03:27.410 --> 00:03:30.640
It doesn't have a port number for me so
I'm gonna have to hope we're running CDP

61
00:03:30.640 --> 00:03:34.510
so I can figure that out and
kinda go from there.

62
00:03:34.510 --> 00:03:40.990
So if I do a show CDP neighbor,
what I'm looking for is that NYWAN1 and

63
00:03:40.990 --> 00:03:45.800
there it is on my Fa 1/0/2.

64
00:03:45.800 --> 00:03:48.710
So I'm going to do a show run for
interface fa1/0/2 and

65
00:03:48.710 --> 00:03:53.810
I can see it's got,
switchport trunk encapsulation dot1q.

66
00:03:53.810 --> 00:03:56.630
All right, good, so
it is set up as a trunk.

67
00:03:56.630 --> 00:03:59.890
Now it doesn't say switchport
mode trunk through,

68
00:03:59.890 --> 00:04:02.170
so that means it's doing dynamic trunking.

69
00:04:02.170 --> 00:04:05.280
Does dynamic trunking between a switch and
a router?

70
00:04:05.280 --> 00:04:06.810
Sadly the answer is sometimes.

71
00:04:06.810 --> 00:04:08.010
Sometimes it does, sometimes it doesn't.

72
00:04:08.010 --> 00:04:11.550
I want to verify that it is working
with a show interface trunk because

73
00:04:11.550 --> 00:04:13.660
that'll tell me if it's actually trunking.

74
00:04:13.660 --> 00:04:14.870
And sure enough it's not.

75
00:04:14.870 --> 00:04:19.010
Ok so remember how I said sometimes that
trunk works and sometimes it doesn't?

76
00:04:19.010 --> 00:04:20.610
This is one of those
times where it doesn't.

77
00:04:20.610 --> 00:04:25.800
I've got the interface set with a trunking
encapsulation, but I haven't hard set it

78
00:04:25.800 --> 00:04:32.040
to trunk and some switches do dynamic
trunking and some switches don't.

79
00:04:32.040 --> 00:04:34.060
And this switch, actually don't
even know what model it is so

80
00:04:34.060 --> 00:04:36.540
I'm not sure, if I do a show version.

81
00:04:36.540 --> 00:04:39.690
Like the 2950's,
they would do dynamic trunking.,

82
00:04:39.690 --> 00:04:45.030
the 3550's would do dynamic trunking but
the 2960's and the 3560's, they wouldn't.

83
00:04:45.030 --> 00:04:46.450
Cisco changed it.

84
00:04:46.450 --> 00:04:49.700
This is a 3750 and I don't remember.

85
00:04:49.700 --> 00:04:53.580
I don't remember if 3750 does dynamic
trunking or not, but in this case,

86
00:04:53.580 --> 00:04:57.340
I think it's pretty safe to say it's not
doing it cuz the trunk's not coming up.

87
00:04:57.340 --> 00:05:02.065
So what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna jump
into that interface which we decided was

88
00:05:02.065 --> 00:05:07.110
fa1/0/2 and
I'm just gonna hard set it as a trunk.

89
00:05:08.210 --> 00:05:09.800
So I'll say switchport mode trunk and

90
00:05:09.800 --> 00:05:12.630
that way I don't have to worry
about negotiation, right?

91
00:05:12.630 --> 00:05:16.980
And in fact, once I set it as a trunk,
I can say switchport nonegotiate and

92
00:05:16.980 --> 00:05:19.600
that way its either gonna be a trunk or
it's gonna be nothing.

93
00:05:19.600 --> 00:05:21.810
So if it doesn't build a trunk,
than it will just drop,

94
00:05:21.810 --> 00:05:23.670
it won't switch back to an access port.

95
00:05:23.670 --> 00:05:26.460
It's usually a good idea
on something like this.

96
00:05:26.460 --> 00:05:31.955
So now, if I look at my configuration
I still have the encapsulation set for

97
00:05:31.955 --> 00:05:36.740
.1Q and I'm set to trunk and negotiate, so

98
00:05:36.740 --> 00:05:40.800
it will show interface trunk,
I'm now carrying freelance five and six,

99
00:05:41.870 --> 00:05:47.790
but spanning tree is not
handling any of them now.

100
00:05:47.790 --> 00:05:48.970
That's normally a red flag.

101
00:05:48.970 --> 00:05:50.400
That normally is oop, we got a problem.

102
00:05:50.400 --> 00:05:52.630
Those VLANs are trimmed off, but
it could be a couple of things.

103
00:05:52.630 --> 00:05:54.980
It could be one,
that we're running loop section, right?

104
00:05:54.980 --> 00:05:56.070
That could just be happening right now.

105
00:05:56.070 --> 00:06:00.570
So they haven't gone active or two,
it could be that we don't have any SVIs.

106
00:06:00.570 --> 00:06:04.320
If we don't have a SVI on there, we
might not be participating in that VLAN.

107
00:06:04.320 --> 00:06:07.770
And if we don't have any active interfaces
on the VLAN, then it's down and

108
00:06:07.770 --> 00:06:08.970
it won't show up down here.

109
00:06:08.970 --> 00:06:11.750
Now, I don't think that's the case
because we are seeing it up here.

110
00:06:11.750 --> 00:06:14.830
So I think this is just gonna
be spanning tree doing its deal.

111
00:06:14.830 --> 00:06:18.750
So let me do a show spanning tree for
vlan 5.

112
00:06:18.750 --> 00:06:21.750
And I can see it's got 1 port forwarding.

113
00:06:22.870 --> 00:06:25.490
And vlan 6 has 1 port forwarding, but

114
00:06:25.490 --> 00:06:28.170
I've probably talked long enough for
them to come up.

115
00:06:28.170 --> 00:06:32.230
So let me rerun that show interface
trunk and sure enough there they are.

116
00:06:32.230 --> 00:06:36.400
All right, so don't freak out if
you see spanning shrink you know,

117
00:06:36.400 --> 00:06:39.750
like trimming off that network or pruning
it bnecause it could just be that you have

118
00:06:39.750 --> 00:06:42.970
to wait a moment, or it could have been
that we weren't participating that Vlan,

119
00:06:42.970 --> 00:06:44.250
but in this case we are.

120
00:06:44.250 --> 00:06:45.580
So now the vlan's up.

121
00:06:45.580 --> 00:06:47.910
All right, that was definitely a problem.

122
00:06:47.910 --> 00:06:50.910
That was definitely a problem
that could stop us from getting

123
00:06:50.910 --> 00:06:52.750
to these networks, right?

124
00:06:52.750 --> 00:06:54.445
Well not necessarily.

125
00:06:54.445 --> 00:06:56.560
[LAUGH] I know it's kind of sad.

126
00:06:56.560 --> 00:06:57.790
Yes, the trunk was bad.

127
00:06:57.790 --> 00:07:02.810
So yes, getting that network wouldn't
work, but the troubleshooting

128
00:07:02.810 --> 00:07:07.200
question really just said that I needed
to get .1, so 192.168.5.1 and 6.1.

129
00:07:07.200 --> 00:07:11.820
Those were up as far as the router
was concerned and so potentially.

130
00:07:11.820 --> 00:07:13.910
I could have gone some
other way to get there.

131
00:07:13.910 --> 00:07:17.130
Yes, the trunk was bad, but
I could have gone around one of these

132
00:07:17.130 --> 00:07:19.910
other routes to get there and
it might have been up.

133
00:07:19.910 --> 00:07:22.340
So while I just fixed the trunk,

134
00:07:22.340 --> 00:07:26.080
I might still not be able to reach
those networks so I'm going to try and

135
00:07:26.080 --> 00:07:28.650
ping it and it really wouldn't surprise
me if I still can't get there.

136
00:07:28.650 --> 00:07:34.726
So I'm going to do a ping to 192.168.32 or
not 32, .5.1 and there we go.

137
00:07:34.726 --> 00:07:40.306
We're getting it now and if we got to
one we'll probably get to the other,

138
00:07:40.306 --> 00:07:44.906
so I'll reach out to 192.68.6.1 and
there we go.

139
00:07:44.906 --> 00:07:50.590
All right, let's assume for
a moment that I didn't get there, right?

140
00:07:50.590 --> 00:07:52.960
I fixed my trunk and
I still can't get there.

141
00:07:52.960 --> 00:07:57.130
Well, the next step would be to go and
figure out what our route is.

142
00:07:57.130 --> 00:07:59.340
What route are we taking to get there?

143
00:07:59.340 --> 00:08:03.680
And if I have an interface
on that network,

144
00:08:03.680 --> 00:08:05.540
then I should be going direct, right?

145
00:08:06.560 --> 00:08:11.430
So, if I look, I actually do have
IPs directly on that network, and

146
00:08:11.430 --> 00:08:12.850
so I'm not following any route.

147
00:08:12.850 --> 00:08:16.650
But if I didn't have an IP on those
networks, then I would need to do a show

148
00:08:16.650 --> 00:08:21.590
ip route and start tracking down how I'm
going to go and get to that network and

149
00:08:21.590 --> 00:08:24.510
follow that through the map and
see where the breakdown is there.

150
00:08:24.510 --> 00:08:27.460
This could have been a much more
complex problem than it was.

151
00:08:27.460 --> 00:08:30.380
As it stands,
we did have SVIs on those networks,

152
00:08:30.380 --> 00:08:33.570
we were plugged right into it,
we just had to fix the trunk.

153
00:08:33.570 --> 00:08:35.920
The links are up and
now we're able to communicate.

154
00:08:35.920 --> 00:08:40.760
So, this one boiled down to just
simple trunk configuration, right?

155
00:08:40.760 --> 00:08:44.840
Now I started this troubleshooting
this looking at router on a stick, and

156
00:08:44.840 --> 00:08:47.550
it wasn't the router on a stick that
was a problem so much as the trunk, but

157
00:08:47.550 --> 00:08:48.800
that's a part of it, right?

158
00:08:48.800 --> 00:08:51.050
And I knew to look for that just
because it's an unusual technology.

159
00:08:51.050 --> 00:08:53.970
It's not something we use a lot, so
it's a great place to have a problem.

160
00:08:53.970 --> 00:08:54.840
You can do that.

161
00:08:54.840 --> 00:08:57.640
We could of found it the other way of just
kind of wandering through the network,

162
00:08:57.640 --> 00:08:59.350
it just wouldn't have taken a lot longer.

163
00:08:59.350 --> 00:09:02.070
Doesn't matter which way you find
the problem as long as you find it and

164
00:09:02.070 --> 00:09:04.560
then come with a solution and
get it resolved.

165
00:09:04.560 --> 00:09:08.410
And with that, we've resolved
the last ticket for set number ten.

166
00:09:08.410 --> 00:09:11.738
We've got a set number eleven coming
up though so stay tuned for it, but

167
00:09:11.738 --> 00:09:15.753
as far as this one's concerned we're going
to wrap it up here and I'll see next time.

168
00:09:15.753 --> 00:09:23.319
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #1` from set #11. The trouble ticket states that "Routes between NYCORE1 and NYCORE2 are not being exchanged in EIGRP. You should see one EIGRP route in the routing table on NYCORE2 "
episodes.title: Set 11 Issue 1
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:01.060 --> 00:00:09.490
Welcome back

2
00:00:09.490 --> 00:00:12.530
to another Cisco troubleshooting
segment here on IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:12.530 --> 00:00:14.970
We're kicking off a new set of problems.

4
00:00:14.970 --> 00:00:16.070
It's set 11.

5
00:00:16.070 --> 00:00:18.480
We're tackling issue one in this episode.

6
00:00:18.480 --> 00:00:19.520
Let's read the support ticket.

7
00:00:19.520 --> 00:00:26.220
It says routes between NYCORE1 and
NYCORE2 are not being exchanged in eigrp.

8
00:00:26.220 --> 00:00:31.730
We should see one eigrp route
in the routing table on NYCORE2.

9
00:00:31.730 --> 00:00:34.860
Well, let's take a look at our topology
and see the devices we're talking about.

10
00:00:34.860 --> 00:00:37.520
The set 11 topology's a little
different than what we've seen before.

11
00:00:37.520 --> 00:00:38.880
It's a lot more linear.

12
00:00:38.880 --> 00:00:42.100
We've got almost a bus type
topology here which is nice,

13
00:00:42.100 --> 00:00:43.440
it's almost a straight line.

14
00:00:43.440 --> 00:00:46.640
We've got EIGRP autonomous system ten, and

15
00:00:46.640 --> 00:00:51.480
IBGP autonomous system 65534
that's actually doing IPv6.

16
00:00:51.480 --> 00:00:55.190
But this problem is talking about EIGRP so
we've got an IPv4 problem and

17
00:00:55.190 --> 00:00:58.710
we're having that issue right
here between NYCORE1 and NYCORE2.

18
00:00:58.710 --> 00:01:03.240
Looking at the document here,
it's a Layer 3 link so that's good.

19
00:01:03.240 --> 00:01:06.950
The EIGRP should be able to run over
that just fine in between port 24 on

20
00:01:06.950 --> 00:01:10.650
both of those devices, and but whatever
reason, it's not exchanging routes.

21
00:01:10.650 --> 00:01:15.350
I should see one EIGRP route in
the routing table here for NYCORE, and

22
00:01:15.350 --> 00:01:17.130
apparently I'm not, all right?

23
00:01:17.130 --> 00:01:20.620
So, let's jump over to NY core two and
see if we can't find that problem.

24
00:01:20.620 --> 00:01:21.670
I'm gonna start here.

25
00:01:21.670 --> 00:01:23.230
It's the one who's supposed
to be receiving the route.

26
00:01:23.230 --> 00:01:25.140
I guess we could just as
well start at NY core one.

27
00:01:25.140 --> 00:01:27.540
It's the one that's supposed
to be sending the route.

28
00:01:27.540 --> 00:01:30.280
Think about what could be
causing this problem, right?

29
00:01:30.280 --> 00:01:32.120
This could be as simple
as a link being down.

30
00:01:32.120 --> 00:01:34.600
If the link is down,
I'll see that on both switches.

31
00:01:34.600 --> 00:01:36.860
Doesn't matter which one
I start troubleshooting.

32
00:01:36.860 --> 00:01:41.160
If it's an IP problem on one side or
the other I can send a ping and

33
00:01:41.160 --> 00:01:42.200
spot the problem that way.

34
00:01:42.200 --> 00:01:45.120
So again that doesn't matter
once I'm in the other.

35
00:01:45.120 --> 00:01:48.060
But if it's something like
an access control list,

36
00:01:48.060 --> 00:01:52.240
that's only gonna be on one side and
it could be either side in this case.

37
00:01:52.240 --> 00:01:54.980
If it's an EIGRP route map,

38
00:01:54.980 --> 00:01:58.350
well this one is the one that's
supposed to be learning a route.

39
00:01:58.350 --> 00:02:01.180
And so the route map could be applying
to routes coming in as well as

40
00:02:01.180 --> 00:02:03.950
routes coming out of CORE1 of prefix
lists so, at the end of the day,

41
00:02:03.950 --> 00:02:06.470
all the problems I've just details
could exist on either switch so

42
00:02:06.470 --> 00:02:08.730
it doesn't really matter
which one we start with.

43
00:02:08.730 --> 00:02:10.740
Just pick one and start with it.

44
00:02:10.740 --> 00:02:14.060
And I like to troubleshoot these using
the OSI model, start with layer one.

45
00:02:14.060 --> 00:02:15.270
Is the cable plugged in?

46
00:02:15.270 --> 00:02:17.530
Well, in this VLab we
have to assume it is.

47
00:02:17.530 --> 00:02:20.100
Layer 2, do we have basic

48
00:02:20.100 --> 00:02:23.080
MAC link layer address communications
across the line, right?

49
00:02:23.080 --> 00:02:27.800
Can I send a ping and actually get an ARP
request back and find the other side.

50
00:02:27.800 --> 00:02:30.450
And in Layer 3, can I resolve a tethers?

51
00:02:30.450 --> 00:02:33.120
Can I ping across to the other side and
communicate?

52
00:02:33.120 --> 00:02:33.680
Right?
And

53
00:02:33.680 --> 00:02:36.620
after that we can troubleshoot the EIGRP
and find out what's going on there.

54
00:02:36.620 --> 00:02:37.710
So let's jump to core 1, and

55
00:02:37.710 --> 00:02:41.750
we'll just troubleshoot it using,
we'll use our OSI model, right?

56
00:02:41.750 --> 00:02:45.780
So, layer 1 and layer 2 are really easy
to troubleshoot because you can usually

57
00:02:45.780 --> 00:02:50.120
just do a show ip interface brief and
look at the feedback that you get.

58
00:02:50.120 --> 00:02:52.130
So if I do a show ip interface brief or,
in fact,

59
00:02:52.130 --> 00:02:54.870
I just wan to see one interface so
I'm not gonna do the whole brief.

60
00:02:54.870 --> 00:02:56.858
I'll just do show ip interface.

61
00:02:56.858 --> 00:03:03.960
fa1/0/24 and the very first line
is gonna tell me that it's up up.

62
00:03:03.960 --> 00:03:05.100
Right?
And if we're up up that

63
00:03:05.100 --> 00:03:06.130
rules out layer one right?

64
00:03:06.130 --> 00:03:07.710
We know our cable's plugged in and

65
00:03:07.710 --> 00:03:11.940
it probably rules out layer two
cuz I got a line protocol is up.

66
00:03:11.940 --> 00:03:16.390
We can find that out for
certain I can see my

67
00:03:16.390 --> 00:03:21.096
Internet address here is 192.168.5.5/30.

68
00:03:21.096 --> 00:03:23.010
So that's a small network a slash 30.

69
00:03:23.010 --> 00:03:28.250
A slash 30 only has two hosts in it and so
it's gonna be 192.168.5.5 on this side and

70
00:03:28.250 --> 00:03:31.390
I expect 192.168.5.6 on the other side.

71
00:03:31.390 --> 00:03:36.930
Well, I don't have to jump to
the other side to test that.

72
00:03:36.930 --> 00:03:39.360
If this is up up,
I should be able to ping it and

73
00:03:39.360 --> 00:03:41.820
verify that the other
side is set right too.

74
00:03:41.820 --> 00:03:44.210
So I'm just gonna do exactly that.

75
00:03:44.210 --> 00:03:49.121
I'll ping to 192.168.5.6, and well,

76
00:03:49.121 --> 00:03:53.500
I've invented an all new
naming address structure here.

77
00:03:53.500 --> 00:03:56.330
Let me change that, there we go.

78
00:03:56.330 --> 00:03:58.430
And I'm going to ping to 192.168.5.6 and

79
00:03:58.430 --> 00:04:00.440
I had a little bit of an art
broad castaway there, but

80
00:04:00.440 --> 00:04:04.540
now, all five of my pings are going
through I will get to the other side.

81
00:04:04.540 --> 00:04:06.710
If I do a show arp,

82
00:04:06.710 --> 00:04:11.710
I should see 192.168.5.6 in the list and
an associated MAC address with it.

83
00:04:11.710 --> 00:04:13.750
Right, so,
I've got everything right there.

84
00:04:13.750 --> 00:04:18.490
Looks like layer 1, layer 2, layer 3,
we're good to go here, this link is up.

85
00:04:18.490 --> 00:04:23.170
So, if the link is up and healthy,
why am I not exchanging the eigrp routes?

86
00:04:23.170 --> 00:04:28.190
Well, could be an ACL which we could
find out by doing a show run for

87
00:04:28.190 --> 00:04:31.700
interface FA one slash zero
slash twenty four if there's and

88
00:04:31.700 --> 00:04:35.990
ACL on the line it will show up right here
and I don't know anything no switchboard

89
00:04:35.990 --> 00:04:42.180
that makes it a layer three port and
an IAP address as a sign and that's it.

90
00:04:42.180 --> 00:04:47.880
And check it out just to
see if there's an ACL.

91
00:04:47.880 --> 00:04:50.170
So if i do a show run for
interface fa1/0/24.

92
00:04:50.170 --> 00:04:51.720
Nope, no ACL.

93
00:04:53.150 --> 00:04:56.400
All right so
it's nothing sneaky like that.

94
00:04:56.400 --> 00:04:59.540
All that's really left is the IGRP.

95
00:04:59.540 --> 00:05:00.890
So let's take a look at the IGRP.

96
00:05:00.890 --> 00:05:03.630
I'm on NYCORE2 here so
we'll just look at this one.

97
00:05:03.630 --> 00:05:07.230
I'm gonna do a show run, and I'll pipe
that into the section command for

98
00:05:07.230 --> 00:05:09.050
the igrp section.

99
00:05:09.050 --> 00:05:11.520
And, the rest is pretty straightforward.

100
00:05:11.520 --> 00:05:12.660
I've got router egirp ten.

101
00:05:12.660 --> 00:05:17.180
And if I look at my diagram we
are in autonomous system ten,

102
00:05:17.180 --> 00:05:21.960
so that's the right as number.

103
00:05:21.960 --> 00:05:23.021
And then network 192.168.5.0.

104
00:05:23.021 --> 00:05:25.939
0.0.0.3.
And network 192.168.16.0.

105
00:05:25.939 --> 00:05:29.690
So it's got my networks advertised out and
everything looks okay there.

106
00:05:29.690 --> 00:05:35.090
All right, now if I jump back over
to NYCORE1, and I do the same thing.

107
00:05:35.090 --> 00:05:40.480
I'll just do a show run section eigrp and

108
00:05:40.480 --> 00:05:45.560
here I've got router eigrp 10 And
network 192.168.5.0.0.0.0.7, all right?

109
00:05:45.560 --> 00:05:51.460
Well, that mask is wrong.

110
00:05:51.460 --> 00:05:55.538
For a slash 30 we would
expect this to be 0.0.0.0.3.

111
00:05:55.538 --> 00:05:58.490
This is .7, but
it's bigger than what we need, and

112
00:05:58.490 --> 00:06:02.150
since it's bigger that means it's
going to cover our network, right?

113
00:06:02.150 --> 00:06:07.040
So we're covered and that's not such
a big deal we could change that,

114
00:06:07.040 --> 00:06:08.950
but that's not really our problem.

115
00:06:08.950 --> 00:06:10.450
That's going to encompass
our network here.

116
00:06:10.450 --> 00:06:11.490
Oh.
You know what?

117
00:06:11.490 --> 00:06:14.840
Actually.
[LAUGH] So our network, technically,

118
00:06:14.840 --> 00:06:19.730
if I wanted to be really specific and
advertise just this network, the command

119
00:06:19.730 --> 00:06:25.385
that I would need to run
would be network 192.168.5.4.

120
00:06:25.385 --> 00:06:26.850
0.0.0.3, all right?

121
00:06:26.850 --> 00:06:32.500
And the reason I would do a .4
here is because my network,

122
00:06:32.500 --> 00:06:37.783
this slash 30, it's 192.168.5.4,
is the subnet address.

123
00:06:37.783 --> 00:06:42.330
.5 and .6 are the usable addresses and
.7 is the broadcast address, so

124
00:06:42.330 --> 00:06:43.780
.4 is what we would start with.

125
00:06:43.780 --> 00:06:45.060
Here, they start with .0.

126
00:06:45.060 --> 00:06:45.590
Right.

127
00:06:45.590 --> 00:06:49.175
But it's a .7 in that wildcard match so
that's going to include 192.168.5.0 and

128
00:06:49.175 --> 00:06:50.590
192.168.5.4, so it'll cover us.

129
00:06:50.590 --> 00:06:53.780
So, I don't know if there's another,

130
00:06:53.780 --> 00:06:58.690
let me see if there's another
interface on this one.

131
00:06:58.690 --> 00:07:02.550
I'll do a show IP interface brief and
I'll exclude any unassigneds.

132
00:07:02.550 --> 00:07:03.960
And sure enough, there it is.

133
00:07:03.960 --> 00:07:06.630
So we've got a 192.168.5.2.

134
00:07:06.630 --> 00:07:10.420
That's why they did the .7 to
encompass both of these networks and

135
00:07:10.420 --> 00:07:13.050
advertise them in the EIGRP.

136
00:07:13.050 --> 00:07:15.820
Now the reason this is
not an issue here but

137
00:07:15.820 --> 00:07:19.430
I'm still highlighting it is it
is an issue on the other side.

138
00:07:19.430 --> 00:07:21.370
If I got to NYCORE2.

139
00:07:21.370 --> 00:07:23.630
And take a look at that
configuration again.

140
00:07:23.630 --> 00:07:25.400
I glanced over it kinda quick.

141
00:07:25.400 --> 00:07:27.650
And didn't do good math.

142
00:07:27.650 --> 00:07:29.955
We've got 192.168.5.0 with a 0.0.0.3.

143
00:07:29.955 --> 00:07:34.970
I laser beamed in on that wild card and

144
00:07:34.970 --> 00:07:38.370
saw that .3 and thought it was OK.

145
00:07:38.370 --> 00:07:42.900
This should be 192.168.5.4,
not 192.168.5.0.

146
00:07:42.900 --> 00:07:47.540
Well, let me see if we have
another network on this one and

147
00:07:47.540 --> 00:07:49.080
if we do we might need.

148
00:07:49.080 --> 00:07:52.620
Oh no we have a completely different
network the 192.168.16 is our

149
00:07:52.620 --> 00:07:53.180
other one here.

150
00:07:53.180 --> 00:07:55.420
But yeah that one should be dot dot fours.

151
00:07:55.420 --> 00:07:58.310
We just have a bad network statement and

152
00:07:58.310 --> 00:08:02.430
I bet if we fix that we will see things
work a little bit better for us.

153
00:08:02.430 --> 00:08:06.310
So, I'm going to put that
in here the proper way and

154
00:08:06.310 --> 00:08:08.730
then I'll remove the other one.

155
00:08:08.730 --> 00:08:12.240
And actually I just saw that neighbor
relationship come back up, so

156
00:08:12.240 --> 00:08:13.580
that's a good sign.

157
00:08:13.580 --> 00:08:18.020
But I'm gonna remove the other one because
it doesn't really serve any purpose.

158
00:08:19.800 --> 00:08:21.440
So we'll get that one out of there.

159
00:08:21.440 --> 00:08:26.130
And now If I do a show ip eigrp neighbor,

160
00:08:26.130 --> 00:08:29.400
I can see I have a neighbor
relationship that's up.

161
00:08:29.400 --> 00:08:34.560
And if I do a show ip route, there we go.

162
00:08:34.560 --> 00:08:38.040
I've got an eigrp route turning up
right there in my routing table.

163
00:08:38.040 --> 00:08:42.170
So in this case, we had a network
statement where the subnet

164
00:08:42.170 --> 00:08:44.910
Didn't match what our actual network was.

165
00:08:44.910 --> 00:08:46.590
And so
that caused a little bit of a breakage.

166
00:08:46.590 --> 00:08:48.140
That's one area where OSPF is nice.

167
00:08:48.140 --> 00:08:51.200
Cuz you can turn it on in the interfaces
and it saves it from making a mistake.

168
00:08:51.200 --> 00:08:52.010
But with EIGRP,

169
00:08:52.010 --> 00:08:55.410
we gotta use that wild card mask,
plenty of room to make mistakes there.

170
00:08:55.410 --> 00:08:57.190
And in this case, there was one.

171
00:08:57.190 --> 00:08:59.900
So once we got that corrected,
the link came up.

172
00:08:59.900 --> 00:09:01.260
We resolved the troubleshooting ticket.

173
00:09:01.260 --> 00:09:02.580
So we're ready to move on to the next one.

174
00:09:02.580 --> 00:09:03.650
Hope you guys enjoyed that.

175
00:09:03.650 --> 00:09:09.540
Stay tuned,
we've got issue number two coming up.

176
00:09:09.540 --> 00:09:14.160
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #2` from set #11. The trouble ticket states that "BGP (IPv6) is not establishing a connection between NYEDGE1 and NYEDGE2 "
episodes.title: Set 11 Issue 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.337
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.337 --> 00:00:12.424
Welcome back to another Ciso
Troubleshooting segment here on IT Pro Tv.

3
00:00:12.424 --> 00:00:15.985
In this one we're jumping into set
11 issue two and we've got another,

4
00:00:15.985 --> 00:00:19.940
looks like a routing issue on this one and
it's a BGP so this'll be fun.

5
00:00:19.940 --> 00:00:22.540
It says, BGP using IPv6,

6
00:00:22.540 --> 00:00:27.860
is not establishing a connection
between NYEDGE1 and NYEDGE2.

7
00:00:27.860 --> 00:00:30.960
Well, if you just did ticket number one or
issue one for set 11,

8
00:00:30.960 --> 00:00:34.730
it was an EIGRP neighbor relationship
that wasn't building up.

9
00:00:34.730 --> 00:00:37.830
Now we've got a BGP neighbor
relationship that's not building up.

10
00:00:37.830 --> 00:00:41.570
And it's IPv6 vs IPv4 in the last one but

11
00:00:41.570 --> 00:00:45.130
at the end of the day, we're gonna
troubleshoot this the same exact way.

12
00:00:45.130 --> 00:00:48.690
We've got two nodes, that our supposed to
be building up a neighbor relationship and

13
00:00:48.690 --> 00:00:52.100
they aren't, and we've got to run through
the same basic troubleshooting steps.

14
00:00:52.100 --> 00:00:53.260
If we look at our topology though,

15
00:00:53.260 --> 00:00:55.990
this time we're dealing with NYEDGE1 and
NYEDGE2.

16
00:00:55.990 --> 00:00:58.790
And there's a lot more
that can go wrong here.

17
00:00:58.790 --> 00:01:03.730
In the last issue, issue one, it was this
Ethernet link between NYCORE1 and NYCORE2.

18
00:01:03.730 --> 00:01:07.970
Ethernet is pretty straightforward,
but up here I've got a serial link.

19
00:01:07.970 --> 00:01:09.180
And with serial links,

20
00:01:09.180 --> 00:01:12.950
not only do you have all the same
problems that you have under Ethernet,

21
00:01:12.950 --> 00:01:16.610
but you also have encapsulation
issues that can be happening.

22
00:01:16.610 --> 00:01:21.030
This can be a frame relay link, it can
be PPP, it can have authentication, and

23
00:01:21.030 --> 00:01:23.310
those are things that we don't
see on the Ethernet side.

24
00:01:23.310 --> 00:01:26.830
So a lot of extra complexity
thrown into this one but

25
00:01:26.830 --> 00:01:29.340
at the end of the day we
troubleshoot it the same way.

26
00:01:29.340 --> 00:01:32.040
When I have two nodes that are not
building a neighbor relationship

27
00:01:32.040 --> 00:01:33.830
I take the OSI model and
I start at the bottom.

28
00:01:33.830 --> 00:01:34.870
Start with layer one.

29
00:01:34.870 --> 00:01:36.320
Is the cable plugged in?

30
00:01:36.320 --> 00:01:39.880
Well, fortunately on a serial link
it is pretty easy to spot that.

31
00:01:39.880 --> 00:01:42.770
Then after that we look up to layer
two what encapsulation is it using as

32
00:01:42.770 --> 00:01:43.440
that functioning.

33
00:01:43.440 --> 00:01:47.680
And then layer three can I ping the
address of the other end of that line and

34
00:01:47.680 --> 00:01:49.970
then we start moving into
the routing protocol itself, so

35
00:01:49.970 --> 00:01:52.550
we can kind of eliminate
any of the easy stuff.

36
00:01:52.550 --> 00:01:55.511
So with a problem like this,
like I've said in many of these questions,

37
00:01:55.511 --> 00:01:58.005
it doesn't really matter which
one we choose to start with.

38
00:01:58.005 --> 00:02:00.880
They both have the problem so
one's as good as the other.

39
00:02:00.880 --> 00:02:02.921
I'll start with NYEDGE1.

40
00:02:02.921 --> 00:02:04.810
All right, so I'm gonna pull up NYEDGE1.

41
00:02:04.810 --> 00:02:08.180
And the first thing I wanna do is
check the health of that line.

42
00:02:08.180 --> 00:02:10.660
And in my diagram,
it showed that with serials 000.

43
00:02:10.660 --> 00:02:13.310
So that's the one I'm on the lookout for.

44
00:02:13.310 --> 00:02:16.380
And I'm just gonna jump into my config.

45
00:02:17.610 --> 00:02:19.760
And I'm gonna start with
just a quick show run for

46
00:02:19.760 --> 00:02:23.280
interface 0/0/0 cuz I don't
have any information on it.

47
00:02:23.280 --> 00:02:25.100
I don't know its IPv6 address is.

48
00:02:25.100 --> 00:02:27.050
I just don't know anything about it.

49
00:02:27.050 --> 00:02:31.853
So, when I come in here and look at it, I
can see it does have an IPv4 address, but

50
00:02:31.853 --> 00:02:34.837
we're specifically dealing with BGP and
IPv6.

51
00:02:34.837 --> 00:02:39.793
So the next line's the one
that's important to me,

52
00:02:39.793 --> 00:02:47.340
IPV six address 2001:D000:1::5 and
I'm gonna write that down,

53
00:02:47.340 --> 00:02:53.085
because IPV six's addresses
are aren't easy to remember so

54
00:02:53.085 --> 00:02:58.962
EDGE1 is gonna be 2001:D000:1::5/126.

55
00:02:58.962 --> 00:03:01.860
Now that slash 126 that's pretty unusual.

56
00:03:01.860 --> 00:03:05.380
In IPv6 we have such a large address space
that people don't normally mess with

57
00:03:05.380 --> 00:03:06.250
the subnet very much.

58
00:03:06.250 --> 00:03:08.100
But here they've done a slash 126.

59
00:03:08.100 --> 00:03:10.837
That's created a very, very small network.

60
00:03:10.837 --> 00:03:13.504
This would be the equivalent
of like a slash 30 under IPv4.

61
00:03:13.504 --> 00:03:18.386
And that means that while I'm colon colon
five well, the other side really only has

62
00:03:18.386 --> 00:03:22.020
one other address that it can
use which is colon, colon, 6.

63
00:03:22.020 --> 00:03:26.140
So I can kinda predict
the address of the other link.

64
00:03:26.140 --> 00:03:28.890
And if you can do that, if you can
predict the address of the other link,

65
00:03:28.890 --> 00:03:30.300
you can actually save some time and

66
00:03:30.300 --> 00:03:33.390
test layer one, two and three all at
the same time by just pinging across.

67
00:03:33.390 --> 00:03:34.080
You don't have to predict it.

68
00:03:34.080 --> 00:03:36.330
You can just always look at
the other note and see, right.

69
00:03:36.330 --> 00:03:40.754
If I just jumped over to NYEDGE2 and
run that same command.

70
00:03:40.754 --> 00:03:48.337
We can do a show IPv6 interface brief and
figure out what address it has.

71
00:03:48.337 --> 00:03:53.952
And what we should see, assuming it's not
an addressing problem is this right here.

72
00:03:53.952 --> 00:03:57.270
It's 2001:D000:1::6 and

73
00:03:57.270 --> 00:04:02.296
that's the one that we kind of
anticipated it to have already.

74
00:04:02.296 --> 00:04:06.902
So if I jump back to edge one,
I'm just gonna ping across

75
00:04:06.902 --> 00:04:11.116
the line to see that I can
get that node and whether or

76
00:04:11.116 --> 00:04:16.020
not that's up, and so if I try and
ping that now let's see.

77
00:04:16.020 --> 00:04:16.922
Did I type it wrong.

78
00:04:16.922 --> 00:04:24.760
I did a ping to 2001:D000:1::6, and
I got a no valid route for a destination.

79
00:04:24.760 --> 00:04:27.250
Well, I tried to save some time and
skip three layers at once,

80
00:04:27.250 --> 00:04:28.920
and I failed miserably.

81
00:04:28.920 --> 00:04:32.010
So in this case, I'm not able to ping it.

82
00:04:32.010 --> 00:04:33.300
It says there's no route.

83
00:04:33.300 --> 00:04:35.640
But this is a directly connected network.

84
00:04:35.640 --> 00:04:39.030
So when would a directly connected network
not have a route in the routing table?

85
00:04:39.030 --> 00:04:41.180
When the interface is down.

86
00:04:41.180 --> 00:04:46.900
So, I imagine our interface is down, or
something else crazy is going on here.

87
00:04:46.900 --> 00:04:49.330
Well, I did a show run
of the interface and

88
00:04:49.330 --> 00:04:51.800
I didn't see anything crazy in there
that would cause it to go down.

89
00:04:51.800 --> 00:04:57.420
Like it wasn't administratively shut down,
but let me do a show, or

90
00:04:57.420 --> 00:05:03.110
not a show run,
let's do a show IPv6 interface brief and

91
00:05:03.110 --> 00:05:07.430
look at the status of that serial line,
and it's showing as down down.

92
00:05:07.430 --> 00:05:09.880
Okay, so
it's not administratively down, but

93
00:05:09.880 --> 00:05:12.500
it is down down which means
the serial link is not up.

94
00:05:12.500 --> 00:05:17.440
Now when I looked at that interface,
when I did the show run interface 0000,

95
00:05:17.440 --> 00:05:21.050
there's nothing in here that talks
about the encapsulation of that line.

96
00:05:21.050 --> 00:05:22.860
That means that it's all default.

97
00:05:22.860 --> 00:05:25.030
It's using HDLC most likely.

98
00:05:25.030 --> 00:05:27.630
I think most Cisco
routers default to HDLC.

99
00:05:27.630 --> 00:05:33.130
But we can find that out real quick
with a show interface 0000 and

100
00:05:33.130 --> 00:05:35.435
in here, yeah, encapsulation HDLC.

101
00:05:35.435 --> 00:05:38.672
HDLC is nice because almost
everything is automatic.

102
00:05:38.672 --> 00:05:41.600
With PPP there things you can tweak and
mess with.

103
00:05:41.600 --> 00:05:43.422
You do can authentication and all that.

104
00:05:43.422 --> 00:05:46.455
With HDLC you usually just turn it on and
then one side of the link's

105
00:05:46.455 --> 00:05:50.440
gonna need a clock rate and then
the whole just kicks off and that's it.

106
00:05:50.440 --> 00:05:52.630
This side didn't have a clock rate, right?

107
00:05:52.630 --> 00:05:56.730
This one was just configured as
having an IP and being turned on.

108
00:05:56.730 --> 00:05:57.800
Let's take a look at the other side.

109
00:05:58.970 --> 00:06:04.140
I'm going to go to NYEDGE2 and I wannalook
at the configuration on this side.

110
00:06:04.140 --> 00:06:12.040
So, if I do a show run for
interface serial 0/0/0 there we go.

111
00:06:12.040 --> 00:06:15.260
I see an ipv6 address right
there like we expected.

112
00:06:15.260 --> 00:06:19.620
I see the clock rate like I expected,
and I see a shutdown.

113
00:06:19.620 --> 00:06:23.080
This end of the link is down,
the other link's not gonna come up.

114
00:06:23.080 --> 00:06:28.350
And so, if I get into my configuration,
this should be a simple no shutdown.

115
00:06:28.350 --> 00:06:30.060
to bring that serial link up.

116
00:06:30.060 --> 00:06:34.580
Now, BGP was not building a relationship
over this line because the line was down.

117
00:06:34.580 --> 00:06:37.420
Just because I fixed this doesn't
mean the problem is gone though.

118
00:06:37.420 --> 00:06:38.640
We might still have issues.

119
00:06:38.640 --> 00:06:40.100
I'm gonna give it a second here.

120
00:06:40.100 --> 00:06:43.546
I see EIGRP just kicked in and
there goes BGP.

121
00:06:43.546 --> 00:06:45.672
BGP just came up.

122
00:06:45.672 --> 00:06:50.190
So it looks like it's gonna be okay but
it might not be.

123
00:06:50.190 --> 00:06:53.271
Right, we might still
have other problems going

124
00:06:53.271 --> 00:06:56.572
on with it what we'll have to
see if we do a show run and

125
00:06:56.572 --> 00:07:00.421
oh shoot I meant to do a BGP section
just let me skip down to it.

126
00:07:00.421 --> 00:07:03.629
And we take a look at our BGP
configuration in here you'll see router

127
00:07:03.629 --> 00:07:07.962
BGPC 65534 you've got a neighbor statement
that's put in place to tell us how you're

128
00:07:07.962 --> 00:07:10.606
going to connect to it and
then your address families and

129
00:07:10.606 --> 00:07:12.940
each of the different
communications in there.

130
00:07:12.940 --> 00:07:15.790
So there could still be problems
that cause it not to come up.

131
00:07:15.790 --> 00:07:19.720
For example if my remote AS
number was configured wrong and

132
00:07:19.720 --> 00:07:21.460
they mismatched or whatever.

133
00:07:21.460 --> 00:07:25.460
So don't assume the problem is
done just because we fixed that

134
00:07:25.460 --> 00:07:27.050
basic underlying problem.

135
00:07:27.050 --> 00:07:30.213
Now in this case the troubleshooting
ticket said that BGP for

136
00:07:30.213 --> 00:07:33.879
IPv6 is not establishing a connection
between NYEDGE1 and EDGE2.

137
00:07:33.879 --> 00:07:37.753
So they're not asking us to verify whether
we're learning routes or anything.

138
00:07:37.753 --> 00:07:40.880
They're just asking us to verify
that we established a connection.

139
00:07:40.880 --> 00:07:44.530
And so, assuming that's done,
we should have it.

140
00:07:44.530 --> 00:07:49.379
Now this is IPv6 for BGP so some of
the commands are a little bit different.

141
00:07:49.379 --> 00:07:53.435
Cause we're used to doing things like,
show IP BGP summary,

142
00:07:53.435 --> 00:07:56.796
which is a great way to see
your neighbors in IPV4.

143
00:07:56.796 --> 00:07:58.921
But an IPV6 is a little bit different.

144
00:07:58.921 --> 00:08:01.921
So what we need to do is show BGP.

145
00:08:01.921 --> 00:08:05.656
They just got rid of the protocol part
altogether because now it can do IPV6 and

146
00:08:05.656 --> 00:08:08.740
even some other things if
we really wanna go crazy.

147
00:08:08.740 --> 00:08:14.560
And in here we've got
show BGP IPV6 unicast,

148
00:08:14.560 --> 00:08:19.400
neighbors, all right,
that's the new show IP BGP summary.

149
00:08:19.400 --> 00:08:22.680
It's not exactly the easiest command
to remember but when you look in here,

150
00:08:22.680 --> 00:08:24.010
you'll be able to see your neighbors.

151
00:08:24.010 --> 00:08:27.270
And I've got one active neighbor session.

152
00:08:27.270 --> 00:08:31.230
And we can see that we've sent and
received communications across it.

153
00:08:31.230 --> 00:08:34.150
Here's that session for
the neighbor on the other side.

154
00:08:34.150 --> 00:08:35.570
So I do have it.

155
00:08:35.570 --> 00:08:38.336
We are communicating and
things are looking good.

156
00:08:38.336 --> 00:08:42.154
It's giving me a lot more
information than I actually needed,

157
00:08:42.154 --> 00:08:46.129
but I am able to communicate and
get the information that we need.

158
00:08:46.129 --> 00:08:47.208
So is that looks good, and

159
00:08:47.208 --> 00:08:50.290
there's not really much else that
we need to mess with in here.

160
00:08:50.290 --> 00:08:53.843
You know, we can start digging
into other things, but

161
00:08:53.843 --> 00:08:57.254
I just wanted to pull up
this one other command here.

162
00:08:57.254 --> 00:09:00.004
Show BGP IPV6 unicast Summary.

163
00:09:00.004 --> 00:09:02.400
And there I can see that neighbor again.

164
00:09:02.400 --> 00:09:04.990
And the AS number in a slightly
more concise format.

165
00:09:04.990 --> 00:09:07.550
So I don't have to see all
the extra nitty gritty details.

166
00:09:07.550 --> 00:09:09.010
Everything I need is right there.

167
00:09:09.010 --> 00:09:10.682
And I see I've got that relationship.

168
00:09:10.682 --> 00:09:12.920
I'm gonna run that same command
over on the other side.

169
00:09:12.920 --> 00:09:15.590
Just the show BGP IPV6 unicast summary.

170
00:09:16.680 --> 00:09:18.546
And just make sure we're
seeing the same thing.

171
00:09:18.546 --> 00:09:23.754
So that was show bgp ipv6 unicast summary.

172
00:09:25.962 --> 00:09:28.984
And there actually I have another
relationship with somebody else but

173
00:09:28.984 --> 00:09:30.940
that's not what this
question is all about.

174
00:09:30.940 --> 00:09:31.930
Looks like we gotta.

175
00:09:31.930 --> 00:09:34.630
BGP love triangle, but
this one is the one we were looking for.

176
00:09:34.630 --> 00:09:35.440
We've got it up.

177
00:09:35.440 --> 00:09:38.370
We're exchanging information,
and everything looks healthy.

178
00:09:38.370 --> 00:09:43.100
All right so, BGP can be terribly complex,
IPV6 can be terribly complex, but

179
00:09:43.100 --> 00:09:45.910
in this case, it just turned
out to be a downed interface.

180
00:09:45.910 --> 00:09:49.030
And once we found that, we turned it on,
we save ourself a lot of time.

181
00:09:49.030 --> 00:09:50.160
That's why I encourage you,

182
00:09:50.160 --> 00:09:52.020
use the OSI models like your
trouble shooting structure.

183
00:09:52.020 --> 00:09:54.070
Start with the easy stuff and
then move to the hard stuff.

184
00:09:54.070 --> 00:09:57.310
So you don't waste a ton of time
fussing with something when

185
00:09:57.310 --> 00:09:59.760
it turned out to be really simple,
which is how this question was.

186
00:09:59.760 --> 00:10:01.046
All right, well that wraps this one up.

187
00:10:01.046 --> 00:10:06.149
Stay tuned,
we've got issue number three coming up.

188
00:10:06.149 --> 00:10:10.300
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #3` from set #11. The trouble ticket states that "BGP between NYWAN1 and NYEDGE1 is not getting established. "
episodes.title: Set 11 Issue 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.188 --> 00:00:05.668
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.660 --> 00:00:13.236
All right, it's time for another Cisco
troubleshooting problem here at IT Pro TV,

3
00:00:13.236 --> 00:00:16.350
and we've got Set 11 Issue 3 ready for
us today.

4
00:00:16.350 --> 00:00:21.110
The troubleshooting ticket reads like
this, it says, BGP between NYWAN1 and

5
00:00:21.110 --> 00:00:24.070
NYEDGE1 is not getting established.

6
00:00:24.070 --> 00:00:27.270
All right, well, let's take a look at our
topology and see which devices these are.

7
00:00:27.270 --> 00:00:31.940
It's NYWAN1 down here and NYEDGE1 up here.

8
00:00:31.940 --> 00:00:34.030
This is very similar to
the last problem we just did.

9
00:00:34.030 --> 00:00:38.760
Issue two, it was that BGP wasn't
building up between NYEDGE1 and NYEDGE2.

10
00:00:38.760 --> 00:00:43.310
We fixed that, now we've got a little
bit different, NYEDGE1 to NYWAN1.

11
00:00:43.310 --> 00:00:47.262
The main difference that we have here
is it's not a point to point link.

12
00:00:47.262 --> 00:00:50.120
We're having to pass through
one node to get to the other.

13
00:00:50.120 --> 00:00:53.650
Now, BTP really loves to have a full mesh.

14
00:00:53.650 --> 00:00:54.620
They love for

15
00:00:54.620 --> 00:00:57.230
one router to be connected to all
the other routers that are out there.

16
00:00:57.230 --> 00:00:58.550
But it doesn't always happen.

17
00:00:58.550 --> 00:01:01.850
With eBGP that's a problem, with iBGP,
it's actually okay with it.

18
00:01:01.850 --> 00:01:04.510
As long as I can communicate
between these two nodes,

19
00:01:04.510 --> 00:01:07.515
they can build a neighbor relationship
up between themselves and it'll be fine,

20
00:01:07.515 --> 00:01:09.270
right, iBGP will handle that.

21
00:01:09.270 --> 00:01:12.200
But we still need to verify
we have that connectivity.

22
00:01:12.200 --> 00:01:13.920
And the way we're gonna troubleshoot,

23
00:01:13.920 --> 00:01:15.980
this is basically the same way
we troubleshot the last one.

24
00:01:15.980 --> 00:01:19.800
We're gonna take our OSI model,
start all the way down at Layer 1 and

25
00:01:19.800 --> 00:01:23.460
kind of move up the layers, and
see where the breakdown is occurring.

26
00:01:23.460 --> 00:01:28.330
This could be as simple as an interface
being down, or it could be more complex

27
00:01:28.330 --> 00:01:31.530
like BGP authentication
configured incorrectly or so on.

28
00:01:31.530 --> 00:01:34.960
We do kind of have the advantage that
we've already worked with NYEDGE1 and

29
00:01:34.960 --> 00:01:40.230
NYEDGE2, and I didn't see things like
authentication or route maps or ACLs.

30
00:01:40.230 --> 00:01:42.890
We didn't see any of that when
we were working with it before.

31
00:01:42.890 --> 00:01:44.340
And we're passing over those same links.

32
00:01:44.340 --> 00:01:47.670
Now, we may have those
problems down at NYWAN1.

33
00:01:47.670 --> 00:01:51.630
That's the new device in the mix, and
so it makes sense to start there.

34
00:01:51.630 --> 00:01:54.150
We'll start with NYWAN1,
and kind of troubleshoot.

35
00:01:54.150 --> 00:01:58.330
But before I do that, I do want to do
a little bit of information gathering.

36
00:01:58.330 --> 00:01:59.520
If you don't know them already,

37
00:01:59.520 --> 00:02:03.080
you do need to get the IPv6
addresses of each of these nodes, so

38
00:02:03.080 --> 00:02:06.460
that we can test the network and
see where we have a failure, right?

39
00:02:06.460 --> 00:02:09.178
When I deal with a lot of devices,
I'll usually use trace route.

40
00:02:09.178 --> 00:02:11.130
With just a few devices, like these,

41
00:02:11.130 --> 00:02:14.914
I might just use regular pings to see
how far along I can get on the network.

42
00:02:14.914 --> 00:02:20.612
So from issue two, we learned that NYEDGE1

43
00:02:20.612 --> 00:02:25.548
was 2001:d000:1::5.

44
00:02:25.548 --> 00:02:33.926
And we learned that NYEDGE2's serial
interface here was 2001:D000:1::6, right.

45
00:02:33.926 --> 00:02:35.458
So we know those from issue two.

46
00:02:35.458 --> 00:02:38.905
But I don't know this other serial
interface, so I'm just gonna jump into

47
00:02:38.905 --> 00:02:42.626
NYEDGE2 real quick, and just do a real
quick check of that interface to make sure

48
00:02:42.626 --> 00:02:46.780
it's not administratively shut down and
to write down its IP address so I know it.

49
00:02:46.780 --> 00:02:49.240
So I'm gonna jump over to NYEDGE2, and

50
00:02:49.240 --> 00:02:52.320
then we'll jump right
over to WAN1 from there.

51
00:02:52.320 --> 00:02:57.851
So on EDGE2,
I'm really just gonna do a show run for

52
00:02:57.851 --> 00:03:00.880
interface Ser0/0/1.

53
00:03:04.170 --> 00:03:07.570
And what I'm looking for is, first off,
I'm looking for a shut down command.

54
00:03:07.570 --> 00:03:10.220
So if it's shut down then
our ticket's almost over.

55
00:03:10.220 --> 00:03:12.428
But the other thing is I
need this address, right?

56
00:03:12.428 --> 00:03:16.972
So I'm gonna write that
down here that EDGE2 is,

57
00:03:16.972 --> 00:03:22.055
you know, it's got two addresses but
the address I care

58
00:03:22.055 --> 00:03:27.264
about here is 2001:D000:2::1 all right?

59
00:03:27.264 --> 00:03:30.385
Now, notice that's a /26, so
that's a small network again and

60
00:03:30.385 --> 00:03:33.196
that means there's only one
other usable IP in the network.

61
00:03:33.196 --> 00:03:37.975
I expect the other end of this
line to be 2001:d000:2::2,

62
00:03:37.975 --> 00:03:40.810
right, that's the only other usable IP.

63
00:03:40.810 --> 00:03:44.400
I also see that I've got ipv6 eigrp 1, so

64
00:03:44.400 --> 00:03:48.930
I've got an interior protocol enabled
here, and that's all fine and good.

65
00:03:48.930 --> 00:03:50.490
All right, so let's jump over to NYWAN1,

66
00:03:50.490 --> 00:03:55.320
and here's where we're really gonna
start our troubleshooting, all right?

67
00:03:55.320 --> 00:03:58.780
So layer one, is the cable plugged in?

68
00:03:58.780 --> 00:03:59.670
Well, I don't know.

69
00:03:59.670 --> 00:04:01.340
It's lab equipment,
it's kind of hard for me to see.

70
00:04:01.340 --> 00:04:03.870
It's actually not even on the same
continent as me right now.

71
00:04:03.870 --> 00:04:07.920
So, if I want to see [LAUGH] what
the status of the interface is,

72
00:04:07.920 --> 00:04:11.540
show ipv6 interface brief
is going to be my friend.

73
00:04:11.540 --> 00:04:13.950
And looking at the topology,
I'm looking for

74
00:04:13.950 --> 00:04:18.040
interface Ser0/1/1,
that's the one that I'm hunting.

75
00:04:18.040 --> 00:04:22.500
So when I get that, Serial0/1/1
right here has a status of up/up.

76
00:04:22.500 --> 00:04:25.508
So the line is up and
the line protocol is up.

77
00:04:25.508 --> 00:04:30.105
The line, that means I've got a cable
plugged in, and a line protocol means I

78
00:04:30.105 --> 00:04:34.634
might be using HDLC or PPP or any of
the various serial encapsulation types,

79
00:04:34.634 --> 00:04:38.986
whatever encapsulation it's using,
it at least thinks that it's up.

80
00:04:38.986 --> 00:04:43.781
And if I look at that address,
I've got 2001:D000:2::2,

81
00:04:43.781 --> 00:04:46.346
which was the address that I expected.

82
00:04:46.346 --> 00:04:49.946
In fact, that line looks healthy enough,
let's just do a quick test ping.

83
00:04:49.946 --> 00:04:55.246
I'm gonna try and ping to 2001:D000:2::1,

84
00:04:55.246 --> 00:05:00.440
which was NYEDGE2's address,
and I can ping across it.

85
00:05:00.440 --> 00:05:00.970
All right.

86
00:05:02.110 --> 00:05:05.950
So what I just established is that
this line right here is healthy.

87
00:05:05.950 --> 00:05:11.220
It's healthy and I can ping in
between NYWAN1 And NYEDGE2, all right?

88
00:05:11.220 --> 00:05:13.910
So now, layer one, layer two,
layer three communications,

89
00:05:13.910 --> 00:05:15.610
they're all good on this line.

90
00:05:15.610 --> 00:05:17.884
Now we start getting into
the harder stuff, all right?

91
00:05:17.884 --> 00:05:20.212
Do we have ACLs?

92
00:05:20.212 --> 00:05:23.224
Do we have other filters
that are in place?

93
00:05:23.224 --> 00:05:25.080
A route master messing with things?

94
00:05:25.080 --> 00:05:27.110
Do we have just bad routing?

95
00:05:27.110 --> 00:05:29.950
I've tested connectivity between me and
EDGE2.

96
00:05:29.950 --> 00:05:31.480
But it's not EDGE2 that
I really care about.

97
00:05:31.480 --> 00:05:33.860
At the end of the day,
I need to be able to get to EDGE1.

98
00:05:33.860 --> 00:05:36.420
Right, this is the relationship
that we're trying to fix.

99
00:05:36.420 --> 00:05:38.560
So can I get all the way
to the other side?

100
00:05:38.560 --> 00:05:40.960
This is where BGP starts to break down.

101
00:05:40.960 --> 00:05:43.570
I don't have to be directly connected
to somebody to build a neighbor

102
00:05:43.570 --> 00:05:44.870
relationship with them.

103
00:05:44.870 --> 00:05:49.200
But I do have to have a route to get
there, and BGP won't give me that route.

104
00:05:49.200 --> 00:05:51.240
I have to get it from
an interior protocol.

105
00:05:51.240 --> 00:05:54.770
So I've got to have an IGP running
under the hood or static routes, so

106
00:05:54.770 --> 00:05:56.600
one way or
another I have to have a static route.

107
00:05:56.600 --> 00:05:59.900
So let's see if I can ping
over to EDGE1 from here, and

108
00:05:59.900 --> 00:06:04.950
if I can then we can nix that out and all
that's left to troubleshoot is BGP itself.

109
00:06:04.950 --> 00:06:09.783
So on NYWAN1,
I'm just gonna do a ping, and

110
00:06:09.783 --> 00:06:14.236
I'm gonna ping the address of NYEDGE1,

111
00:06:14.236 --> 00:06:19.720
which was 2001:D000:1::5.

112
00:06:19.720 --> 00:06:22.280
Right?
So I'm gonna try and ping that.

113
00:06:22.280 --> 00:06:24.060
No valid route for destination.

114
00:06:24.060 --> 00:06:26.960
All right.
So, I am not able to get there.

115
00:06:26.960 --> 00:06:28.750
And that was the address for NYEDGE1.

116
00:06:28.750 --> 00:06:34.127
I'm directly plugged into NYEDGE2,
so let me try its address,

117
00:06:34.127 --> 00:06:37.758
which was 2001:D000:1::6.

118
00:06:37.758 --> 00:06:40.212
And when I go there,
no valid route for destination.

119
00:06:40.212 --> 00:06:46.413
All right?
I was able to ping 2001:D000:1::5 or

120
00:06:46.413 --> 00:06:51.870
I'm sorry it was :2::1, there we go.

121
00:06:51.870 --> 00:06:54.710
That is an address on NYEDGE2.

122
00:06:54.710 --> 00:06:57.540
That was, going back to my diagram,
that was this interface.

123
00:06:57.540 --> 00:07:01.040
So I can ping from NYWAN1
to this interface, but

124
00:07:01.040 --> 00:07:02.810
I can't ping to this interface up here.

125
00:07:02.810 --> 00:07:04.200
Right, on the same system.

126
00:07:04.200 --> 00:07:05.690
I know I can get there.

127
00:07:05.690 --> 00:07:07.670
But this is a great indicator that,

128
00:07:07.670 --> 00:07:09.870
much like the screen told me,
I don't have a route.

129
00:07:09.870 --> 00:07:12.120
But I'm missing a route
to get to that network.

130
00:07:12.120 --> 00:07:15.884
So if I do a show IPv6 route,
let's see what we get.

131
00:07:15.884 --> 00:07:19.217
2001:D000:2 but

132
00:07:19.217 --> 00:07:23.664
no 2001:D000:1, right?

133
00:07:23.664 --> 00:07:25.564
So, I'm missing a route.

134
00:07:25.564 --> 00:07:27.764
I need to fix that, how do I fix it?

135
00:07:27.764 --> 00:07:28.424
Well, I have two choices.

136
00:07:28.424 --> 00:07:29.544
One, I could put a static route in.

137
00:07:29.544 --> 00:07:32.690
I can just say, hey, if you need
to get to this, go up to EDGE2.

138
00:07:32.690 --> 00:07:36.528
Heck, I could put a default route in and
that would cover it too, right?

139
00:07:36.528 --> 00:07:38.224
Or we could do it the right way, and

140
00:07:38.224 --> 00:07:41.688
the right way is to use an interior
gateway protocol, an IGP, right?

141
00:07:41.688 --> 00:07:48.670
And I noticed in passing when we were on
NYEDGE2, that it was running EIGRP, right?

142
00:07:48.670 --> 00:07:49.470
ipv6 eigrp 1.

143
00:07:49.470 --> 00:07:52.860
Now, that autonomous system number
doesn't match my diagram, but

144
00:07:52.860 --> 00:07:54.310
neither does the protocol, right?

145
00:07:54.310 --> 00:07:59.968
The diagram shows that we're running
EIGRP autonomous system 10 for

146
00:07:59.968 --> 00:08:03.620
IPv4, and
it shows that we're running iBGP for IPv6.

147
00:08:03.620 --> 00:08:08.740
It doesn't show EIGRP for
IPv6 at all, anywhere.

148
00:08:08.740 --> 00:08:12.260
So, since that's the case, it doesn't
really matter what AS number we use.

149
00:08:12.260 --> 00:08:13.600
They're not telling us one.

150
00:08:13.600 --> 00:08:18.000
And so, if we're already using AS number
one here, we might as well stick with it.

151
00:08:18.000 --> 00:08:20.340
I am gonna double-check NYEDGE1, though.

152
00:08:20.340 --> 00:08:24.880
Let's see what NYEDGE1 is doing, because
it needs to be a party to this too.

153
00:08:24.880 --> 00:08:29.800
Remember, if I get my package to NYEDGE1,
NYEDGE1 has to know how to get back to me.

154
00:08:29.800 --> 00:08:32.910
And so that's why it's important
that I check on this one too.

155
00:08:32.910 --> 00:08:37.590
So, if I take a look at its interface, and
that would be Ser0/0/0, whoops, if I type

156
00:08:43.440 --> 00:08:46.180
that correctly we'll get it, there we go.

157
00:08:46.180 --> 00:08:48.850
And it's not running IGP,

158
00:08:48.850 --> 00:08:53.710
it's not running it, so
let's take a look at its routing table.

159
00:08:55.360 --> 00:08:59.810
And we'll probably need to
bring it into BGP also.

160
00:08:59.810 --> 00:09:02.100
Hang on a second here.

161
00:09:02.100 --> 00:09:03.620
Now, I just saw that it wasn't there.

162
00:09:03.620 --> 00:09:06.390
So, normally,
when when we enable EIGRP for

163
00:09:06.390 --> 00:09:09.000
IPv6 we turn it on on an interface, right?

164
00:09:09.000 --> 00:09:10.185
And so that's what I looked at.

165
00:09:10.185 --> 00:09:13.010
Now, I can see I am running EIGRP.

166
00:09:13.010 --> 00:09:17.150
Let me do a show ipv6 protocol,
[LAUGH] let's verify this.

167
00:09:17.150 --> 00:09:19.300
I'm getting mixed signals
from this router.

168
00:09:19.300 --> 00:09:24.700
So looking at it, it is running eigrp for
autonomous system 1, so

169
00:09:24.700 --> 00:09:28.410
it is running it, it's just not configured
on the interface, which is the way we're

170
00:09:28.410 --> 00:09:32.010
supposed to do these things now, but
it's not the end of the world, I guess.

171
00:09:32.010 --> 00:09:35.600
If I pull up the running config,
sure enough, here's router eigrp,

172
00:09:35.600 --> 00:09:37.560
it's got a name called TSHOOT.

173
00:09:37.560 --> 00:09:39.620
And they're just using network
statements to enable it,

174
00:09:39.620 --> 00:09:40.920
instead of doing it on the interface.

175
00:09:40.920 --> 00:09:42.000
That's fine.

176
00:09:42.000 --> 00:09:44.098
Well actually that's IPv4.

177
00:09:47.348 --> 00:09:52.990
IPv6 is showing that it's got
a unicast for autonomous-system 1.

178
00:09:52.990 --> 00:09:54.240
There's the ipv6 side.

179
00:09:54.240 --> 00:09:57.990
It's got no network statements whatsoever.

180
00:09:57.990 --> 00:09:59.880
Let me take a look at
those interfaces again.

181
00:09:59.880 --> 00:10:02.000
This might be an interesting one for us.

182
00:10:02.000 --> 00:10:04.320
So, I'm just trying to make sure
that it is actually enabled.

183
00:10:04.320 --> 00:10:09.740
It's showing in the routing table, so it
appears to be working, and as I look down

184
00:10:09.740 --> 00:10:13.650
along the line here, Serial0/0/0.

185
00:10:13.650 --> 00:10:15.370
Okay, all right, I see what's going on.

186
00:10:15.370 --> 00:10:18.410
So, we've got it configured
using a address family.

187
00:10:19.520 --> 00:10:25.688
So it's actually running under the first
process, which is set for AS number one.

188
00:10:25.688 --> 00:10:28.908
And it's a kind of a convoluted way
to go about it but it does work.

189
00:10:28.908 --> 00:10:31.718
So, see how we got one configuration here?

190
00:10:31.718 --> 00:10:33.328
And it's got autonomous system ten and

191
00:10:33.328 --> 00:10:36.650
autonomous system 1 being carried
inside of it as two address families.

192
00:10:36.650 --> 00:10:39.670
And so that's how it's able to bring
it across and learn those routes.

193
00:10:39.670 --> 00:10:41.300
So it is learning the route.

194
00:10:41.300 --> 00:10:44.140
And that's good enough for me.

195
00:10:44.140 --> 00:10:47.168
I'll just verify that one more
time to make sure it's there.

196
00:10:47.168 --> 00:10:50.291
And, sure enough, yeah, so we've got that.

197
00:10:50.291 --> 00:10:55.703
2001:D000:2, so that's right there so
it's got the return path.

198
00:10:55.703 --> 00:10:57.381
So all it's missing is me getting there.

199
00:10:57.381 --> 00:11:00.121
So honestly, a static route would
work just as well as participating in

200
00:11:00.121 --> 00:11:01.875
the dynamic routing protocol.

201
00:11:01.875 --> 00:11:04.775
But the dynamic routing protocol is
probably gonna be the path of least

202
00:11:04.775 --> 00:11:06.025
resistance on this one.

203
00:11:06.025 --> 00:11:07.650
So that's what I'll do.

204
00:11:07.650 --> 00:11:12.190
I'm gonna get into interface S0/1/1.

205
00:11:12.190 --> 00:11:14.780
And what I'm doing is I'm taking NYWAN1,
and

206
00:11:14.780 --> 00:11:19.660
I'm gonna put this interface
into EIGRP Autonomous System 1.

207
00:11:19.660 --> 00:11:22.580
And when that happens is you
start exchanging routes up here.

208
00:11:22.580 --> 00:11:24.750
And then we should learn
our full routing table.

209
00:11:24.750 --> 00:11:29.506
So if I do a ipv6 eigrp 1,
that'll do that, and

210
00:11:29.506 --> 00:11:33.568
I see a neighbor relationship coming up.

211
00:11:33.568 --> 00:11:38.614
And what I'm hoping is I learn the route
to that other network, and there it is.

212
00:11:38.614 --> 00:11:43.536
So we've got 2001:D000:1, right.

213
00:11:43.536 --> 00:11:46.300
So that's the one I was missing and
now it's there.

214
00:11:46.300 --> 00:11:51.210
So earlier, what I tried to do was ping
all the way to NYEDGE1 and it failed.

215
00:11:51.210 --> 00:11:55.970
And now, what I should be able to do
is ping all the way to NYEDGE1, and

216
00:11:55.970 --> 00:11:56.800
it succeeds.

217
00:11:56.800 --> 00:11:57.688
There we go.

218
00:11:57.688 --> 00:12:01.998
And now that it's succeeding,
in theory, EGP should work.

219
00:12:01.998 --> 00:12:04.600
As long as we have a route
to get to that neighbor,

220
00:12:04.600 --> 00:12:08.990
we should be able to build an adjacency
across it assuming that it's set up right.

221
00:12:08.990 --> 00:12:11.890
Now, I didn't see any messages
pop up on my screen, so

222
00:12:11.890 --> 00:12:14.560
it might not be set up right, or
I might have just overlooked it.

223
00:12:14.560 --> 00:12:20.180
So I'm gonna do a quick show
bgp ipv6 unicast summary.

224
00:12:21.730 --> 00:12:23.698
And, there we go.

225
00:12:23.698 --> 00:12:25.078
I must have just missed the message.

226
00:12:25.078 --> 00:12:25.638
There it is.

227
00:12:25.638 --> 00:12:29.540
2001:D000:1::5.

228
00:12:29.540 --> 00:12:30.110
It's up.

229
00:12:30.110 --> 00:12:33.310
I've sent four messages,
I've received six.

230
00:12:33.310 --> 00:12:36.950
We're exchanging routes, we've now built
our adjacency with the other side.

231
00:12:36.950 --> 00:12:39.890
So this one turned out
not to be a BGP problem,

232
00:12:39.890 --> 00:12:42.790
as much as it was just the underlying IGP.

233
00:12:42.790 --> 00:12:47.350
Remember, when you're dealing with iBGP,
if you don't have a full mesh,

234
00:12:47.350 --> 00:12:51.700
if your routers aren't directly connected
to all the other routers, then you need to

235
00:12:51.700 --> 00:12:55.600
make sure you've got an underlying IGP
that's providing the routes to get

236
00:12:55.600 --> 00:12:59.770
between them cuz BGP won't figure it out
on its own, and that's what happened here.

237
00:12:59.770 --> 00:13:04.670
As soon as we had the routes in the IGP,
BGP just started working on its own, and

238
00:13:04.670 --> 00:13:06.190
it was taken care of.

239
00:13:06.190 --> 00:13:08.530
So that wraps up issue number three,

240
00:13:08.530 --> 00:13:11.120
turned out to be EIGRP that had a problem,
not BGP.

241
00:13:11.120 --> 00:13:14.130
Now that that's resolved,
we're ready to move on to the next ticket.

242
00:13:14.130 --> 00:13:15.440
So I hope you guys enjoyed that one.

243
00:13:15.440 --> 00:13:18.878
Stay tuned,
we've got issue four coming up next.

244
00:13:18.878 --> 00:13:23.838
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #4` from set #11. The trouble ticket states that "When you observe the BGP table (IPv6) on NYWAN1 once the connection is up, you notice there is a rib failure for the network that is present there "
episodes.title: Set 11 Issue 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.228 --> 00:00:07.507
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.507 --> 00:00:11.310
Alright welcome back to another
troubleshooting question here on ITPro TV.

3
00:00:11.310 --> 00:00:13.480
We've got Set 11 Issue 4 and

4
00:00:13.480 --> 00:00:15.690
this ones actually a follow
up to issue number three.

5
00:00:15.690 --> 00:00:19.370
So if you haven't done issue number three
yet make sure you tackle that one first.

6
00:00:19.370 --> 00:00:22.110
In issue number three we had two
routers that weren't forming a BGP

7
00:00:22.110 --> 00:00:25.590
relationship we got that neighbor
relationship up and now it's functioning.

8
00:00:25.590 --> 00:00:30.300
And in this ticket it says,
when you observe the BGP table for

9
00:00:30.300 --> 00:00:34.910
IPv6 on NYWAN1 once the connection is up,
you notice there's a rib failure for

10
00:00:34.910 --> 00:00:36.690
the network that is present there.

11
00:00:36.690 --> 00:00:39.700
So it's saying now that we went through
the trouble of fixing that BGP neighbor

12
00:00:39.700 --> 00:00:40.800
relationship.

13
00:00:40.800 --> 00:00:45.070
It comes up, and in BGP we're seeing this
rib failure, and we need to find out why.

14
00:00:45.070 --> 00:00:47.270
Now if you don't remember what the rib is,

15
00:00:47.270 --> 00:00:50.700
in the background BGP maintains
its own route database, and

16
00:00:50.700 --> 00:00:54.480
only the best routes are selected and
then thrown into the routing table.

17
00:00:54.480 --> 00:00:57.790
But sometimes routes are discarded early,
they're not even put into the election

18
00:00:57.790 --> 00:00:59.500
process to find out whether
they should go up or not.

19
00:00:59.500 --> 00:01:02.380
They're just kinda killed off,
and that's called a rib failure.

20
00:01:02.380 --> 00:01:03.770
And sometimes it's good,

21
00:01:03.770 --> 00:01:06.960
sometimes it's bad, sometimes there's some
action to take, sometimes there's not.

22
00:01:06.960 --> 00:01:09.500
And we just need to find out why and
what's going on here.

23
00:01:09.500 --> 00:01:11.970
So there's a couple of commands
that can really help with that.

24
00:01:11.970 --> 00:01:14.440
Let's start by looking at
our topology real quick

25
00:01:14.440 --> 00:01:17.070
because it might have been a little
while since you've done the other issue.

26
00:01:17.070 --> 00:01:21.110
But in issue three, we fix the neighbor
relationship between NYWAN1 and NYEDGE1.

27
00:01:21.110 --> 00:01:24.570
And there's this extra hop in the middle.

28
00:01:24.570 --> 00:01:28.330
Which was causing us some problems, so we
had to create a interior routing protocol

29
00:01:28.330 --> 00:01:32.970
EIGRP to provide the internal routes so
these two could see each other and

30
00:01:32.970 --> 00:01:34.470
build up a neighbor relationship.

31
00:01:34.470 --> 00:01:38.040
And now that's up, we're getting
some kind of better route coming in.

32
00:01:38.040 --> 00:01:39.970
Well, fortunately there's some
good commands we can run that'll

33
00:01:39.970 --> 00:01:41.720
actually tell us exactly
what the problem is.

34
00:01:41.720 --> 00:01:46.490
So on NYWAN1, if we jump over to that one,
and I'm choosing NYWAN1

35
00:01:46.490 --> 00:01:48.780
because that's what the troubleshooting
ticket told me to do, right?

36
00:01:48.780 --> 00:01:54.000
It said, on NYWAN1 were getting
a rib failure, find out why.

37
00:01:54.000 --> 00:01:58.030
So, I'm just gonna get
into this guy's config and

38
00:01:58.030 --> 00:02:00.180
I'm gonna verify a few things real quick.

39
00:02:00.180 --> 00:02:05.010
Now it may have been a little while
since you've fixed the other issues, so

40
00:02:05.010 --> 00:02:08.530
I'm gonna do a show bgp
ipv6 unicast summary.

41
00:02:08.530 --> 00:02:11.140
Just to make sure that I still have
a neighbor relationship with that other

42
00:02:11.140 --> 00:02:12.710
router, and I do, okay.

43
00:02:12.710 --> 00:02:15.700
So I'm communicating with it and
I'm exchanging routes.

44
00:02:15.700 --> 00:02:19.210
When I scroll over here,
see how I've got a PfxRcd 1.

45
00:02:19.210 --> 00:02:21.350
So I've received at least one route.

46
00:02:21.350 --> 00:02:24.530
And if I'm gonna have rib failure,
that's gonna be the route.

47
00:02:24.530 --> 00:02:28.320
So the only route I've received is
a rib failure according to that.

48
00:02:28.320 --> 00:02:30.970
But I don't actually see
that here on this screen.

49
00:02:30.970 --> 00:02:32.020
Where do I see that?

50
00:02:32.020 --> 00:02:38.840
Well you can see rib failures with
the show bgp IPv6 unicast command.

51
00:02:38.840 --> 00:02:42.380
And when you run this it's gonna
show you the unicast database and

52
00:02:42.380 --> 00:02:44.650
all the routes that you've learned and
I've only learned one.

53
00:02:44.650 --> 00:02:47.640
But it doesn't matter if you learned
one or a thousand, if there's a rib

54
00:02:47.640 --> 00:02:51.170
failure it's really easy to spot
because it'll have an r right there.

55
00:02:51.170 --> 00:02:56.740
And what that r means is no matter what
happens, no matter how good this route is

56
00:02:56.740 --> 00:03:00.510
or how bad other routes are, this one is
not gonna make it into the routing table.

57
00:03:00.510 --> 00:03:03.440
There's something wrong with this route.

58
00:03:03.440 --> 00:03:07.680
And the something wrong could be a lot
of different things but if it was a good

59
00:03:07.680 --> 00:03:11.460
route, I would expect to see
an asterisk here where the r is, right?

60
00:03:11.460 --> 00:03:13.880
An asterisk means it's a valid route.

61
00:03:13.880 --> 00:03:17.290
And then if it's got a greater
than sign beside it,

62
00:03:17.290 --> 00:03:18.990
that means this is the winning route.

63
00:03:18.990 --> 00:03:21.430
This is the one that's gonna
go into the routing table.

64
00:03:21.430 --> 00:03:25.530
And then the i just let's me know
this came from an internal system, so

65
00:03:25.530 --> 00:03:26.930
IBGP in this case.

66
00:03:26.930 --> 00:03:29.240
So that's what those are telling me.

67
00:03:29.240 --> 00:03:30.690
Well, even though it's got the greater,

68
00:03:30.690 --> 00:03:33.710
even though that means this is
the best route, it doesn't matter.

69
00:03:33.710 --> 00:03:38.510
It never really participated in
the election because of that r, okay?

70
00:03:38.510 --> 00:03:41.970
But it doesn't really tell
us anything here as far as

71
00:03:41.970 --> 00:03:43.430
why that's happening, right?

72
00:03:43.430 --> 00:03:45.700
So I know I've got a route failure,
but I don't know why.

73
00:03:45.700 --> 00:03:50.807
I can get a little more
information with the show

74
00:03:50.807 --> 00:03:55.410
bgp ipv6 unicast rib-failure command.

75
00:03:55.410 --> 00:03:59.363
All right, that one will show you detailed
information about the rib failure or

76
00:03:59.363 --> 00:04:00.961
as detailed as it's gonna get.

77
00:04:00.961 --> 00:04:07.190
And so when I look at that,
here's the network, 2001:B000::/64.

78
00:04:07.190 --> 00:04:11.580
But my favorite part is if you just come
right over here, it'll tell you why.

79
00:04:11.580 --> 00:04:13.530
And I can see right here
under the rib failure,

80
00:04:13.530 --> 00:04:18.300
we've got IPv6 Higher admin distance,
all right?

81
00:04:18.300 --> 00:04:19.550
What does that mean?

82
00:04:19.550 --> 00:04:23.980
It means I'm learning this
route through some other manner

83
00:04:23.980 --> 00:04:26.390
that has a better
administration than this one.

84
00:04:26.390 --> 00:04:29.280
This one's route has a higher admin
distance than whatever's in my

85
00:04:29.280 --> 00:04:30.460
routing table.

86
00:04:30.460 --> 00:04:33.440
So, I'm learning this via BGP.

87
00:04:33.440 --> 00:04:37.120
What could possibly have a higher
administrative distance than that?

88
00:04:37.120 --> 00:04:38.520
Well, there's actually a lot of things.

89
00:04:38.520 --> 00:04:40.910
I'm learning this via iBPG.

90
00:04:40.910 --> 00:04:45.620
Remember, with BGP, an external BGP
route has an admin distance of 20.

91
00:04:45.620 --> 00:04:48.460
The only thing that's gonna beat
that by default is a connected or

92
00:04:48.460 --> 00:04:52.710
a static route otherwise,
external BGP always wins, right?

93
00:04:52.710 --> 00:04:56.970
But iBGP has an admin distance of 200.

94
00:04:56.970 --> 00:05:01.820
And that means RIP at 120, OSPF at 110,

95
00:05:01.820 --> 00:05:05.890
EIGRP at 90, they're all going to beat it.

96
00:05:05.890 --> 00:05:07.520
Even external OSPF and

97
00:05:07.520 --> 00:05:13.570
external EIGRP routes have a lower admin
distance than internal BGP, all right?

98
00:05:13.570 --> 00:05:16.860
Why is that, why does iBGP get
kinda shunted to the back?

99
00:05:16.860 --> 00:05:20.440
Well the reason is iBGP is
never expected to run alone.

100
00:05:20.440 --> 00:05:24.460
It's expected to be run in
tandem with an IGP and the IGP

101
00:05:24.460 --> 00:05:28.800
is providing all of our interior routes
and it will know them better than BGP.

102
00:05:28.800 --> 00:05:31.430
Because BGP kinda sucks
as a routing protocol.

103
00:05:31.430 --> 00:05:34.180
It doesn't do a good job
of finding optimal paths.

104
00:05:34.180 --> 00:05:37.720
It does a good job at finding
a path not necessarily optimal.

105
00:05:37.720 --> 00:05:41.360
So it leaves it up to the IGP
to find the optimal path.

106
00:05:41.360 --> 00:05:44.780
And so that's why its got such
a high admin distance for interior.

107
00:05:44.780 --> 00:05:47.850
On the exterior side, that's a different
story because you're interior protocols

108
00:05:47.850 --> 00:05:49.760
don't know about the exterior networks.

109
00:05:49.760 --> 00:05:52.560
So there's no sense in turning
it over to an interior protocol,

110
00:05:52.560 --> 00:05:54.145
it's just gonna get us lost.

111
00:05:54.145 --> 00:05:57.530
BGP takes over and
eBPG has that nice low cost.

112
00:05:57.530 --> 00:06:00.910
So here I've got that rib failure cuz I'm
already learning it from another protocol.

113
00:06:00.910 --> 00:06:10.040
And if I do a show ipv6 route I expect
to see 2001:B000 learn some other way.

114
00:06:10.040 --> 00:06:14.928
And so when I run that and
look, here it is 2001:B000 and

115
00:06:14.928 --> 00:06:19.480
sure enough here it is with
an admin distance of 90,

116
00:06:19.480 --> 00:06:23.140
because it's being learned form EIGRP,
okay?

117
00:06:23.140 --> 00:06:28.420
So we found the problem and
we know why there's a problem, okay?

118
00:06:28.420 --> 00:06:29.770
What do we do about it?

119
00:06:29.770 --> 00:06:32.730
Well the answer, absolutely nothing.

120
00:06:32.730 --> 00:06:35.820
They told us there's a rib failure,
they told us to find it and

121
00:06:35.820 --> 00:06:38.120
figure out why it's there, we know.

122
00:06:38.120 --> 00:06:40.210
We know it's there and
this is behavior as normal.

123
00:06:40.210 --> 00:06:44.660
I expect this happen so
the action I take is nothing, right?

124
00:06:44.660 --> 00:06:49.800
If the question had gone on to say, you
need to have the BGP route at the table,

125
00:06:49.800 --> 00:06:51.520
that's a different story, right?

126
00:06:51.520 --> 00:06:52.800
Now we have a choice,

127
00:06:52.800 --> 00:06:57.430
we could take that route out of EIGRP and
then it wouldn't overwrite it.

128
00:06:57.430 --> 00:07:01.060
We could modify the admin distance
of IBGP if we were crazy.

129
00:07:01.060 --> 00:07:02.970
That always leads to all to
all sorts of routing mixups,

130
00:07:02.970 --> 00:07:05.570
you have to be rally careful
when you change admin distances.

131
00:07:05.570 --> 00:07:09.810
We could do a route map to manually
set the distance just for that route.

132
00:07:09.810 --> 00:07:12.700
We could do a prefix
list to filter it out.

133
00:07:12.700 --> 00:07:16.430
We could say I'll let EIGRP teach me
everything except for that network.

134
00:07:16.430 --> 00:07:18.810
And when we take it out like that,

135
00:07:18.810 --> 00:07:21.580
then BGP will have it's opportunity
to go into the routing table.

136
00:07:21.580 --> 00:07:24.440
Those are all different ways we could make
the BGP route go in the routing table.

137
00:07:24.440 --> 00:07:28.430
But at the end of the day you don't
want the BGP route in the routing table

138
00:07:28.430 --> 00:07:31.920
because BGP is not gonna give
you an optimal route EIGRP will.

139
00:07:31.920 --> 00:07:33.780
So this behavior is normal.

140
00:07:33.780 --> 00:07:36.840
I expect to see it, so
that's a key thing to learn

141
00:07:36.840 --> 00:07:41.630
just because you see a rib failure doesn't
mean there's necessarily a problem.

142
00:07:41.630 --> 00:07:42.710
Here, it's a good thing.

143
00:07:42.710 --> 00:07:47.300
I want the route to fail in BGP because I
want the EIGRP route to take precedence.

144
00:07:47.300 --> 00:07:51.060
So this is one of those few special
trouble shooting tickets where

145
00:07:51.060 --> 00:07:51.980
we don't have to do anything.

146
00:07:51.980 --> 00:07:56.450
