Now on the exam, they're either
gonna ask you to do something or

147
00:07:56.450 --> 00:07:58.770
they're gonna ask you explain
why something is wrong.

148
00:07:58.770 --> 00:07:59.590
So this would be one that

149
00:07:59.590 --> 00:08:01.720
would have a multiple choice
question associated with it.

150
00:08:01.720 --> 00:08:03.430
Why are you getting the rib failure?

151
00:08:03.430 --> 00:08:08.080
I actually didn't know why I was getting
the rib failure until I ran this show bgp

152
00:08:08.080 --> 00:08:12.682
ipv6 unicast rib-failure command and
that's when it actually told me why.

153
00:08:12.682 --> 00:08:16.300
And so they're testing your
knowledge of those show commands.

154
00:08:16.300 --> 00:08:17.340
Do you know that?

155
00:08:17.340 --> 00:08:21.920
Otherwise you get to compare
the the actual BGP database with

156
00:08:21.920 --> 00:08:25.260
the routing table and see that over
lapse a lot harder to go that way.

157
00:08:25.260 --> 00:08:27.300
But they're testing your ability
to find out that cause but

158
00:08:27.300 --> 00:08:29.980
in this case, the ticket with no action.

159
00:08:29.980 --> 00:08:32.540
We're good to go and
we're ready to move to issue five so

160
00:08:32.540 --> 00:08:34.070
I hope you guys enjoyed that one.

161
00:08:34.070 --> 00:08:37.338
Stay tuned,
we got the final troubleshooting issue for

162
00:08:37.338 --> 00:08:38.807
set 11 coming up next.

163
00:08:38.807 --> 00:08:44.889
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #5` from set #11. The trouble ticket states that "There is no IPv4 route to NYWAN1 from NYCORE2, you are unable to ping to 192.168.5.1 but you can ping 192.168.5.2 "
episodes.title: Set 11 Issue 5
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.729
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.729 --> 00:00:12.489
Welcome back to another Cisco
troubleshooting problem here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.489 --> 00:00:14.617
We're jumping into Set 11, Issue 5, and

4
00:00:14.617 --> 00:00:16.809
the troubleshooting
ticket reads like this.

5
00:00:16.809 --> 00:00:24.330
It says there are no IPv4
routes To NYWAN1 from NYCORE2.

6
00:00:24.330 --> 00:00:29.530
You are unable to ping 192.168.5.1 but
you can ping 192.168.5.2.

7
00:00:29.530 --> 00:00:32.720
Now, those IP addresses
don't mean much to me

8
00:00:32.720 --> 00:00:35.780
right now because I haven't
seen these networks.

9
00:00:35.780 --> 00:00:38.990
But, if we look at our diagram, we can
kind of see what it's talking about.

10
00:00:38.990 --> 00:00:44.270
What they're telling us is that
NYWAN1 Is unable to ping NYCORE2.

11
00:00:44.270 --> 00:00:46.740
So, we're not able to get across to it and

12
00:00:46.740 --> 00:00:49.710
that we don't even have a route
to be able to get there.

13
00:00:49.710 --> 00:00:51.310
Now, now that I think about it,

14
00:00:51.310 --> 00:00:55.060
way back in issue one, we actually
worked on this link right here which I'm

15
00:00:55.060 --> 00:00:58.190
pretty sure is that 192.168.5
link that they're talking about.

16
00:00:58.190 --> 00:01:02.450
I wanna verify these IP address first to
make sure I know what I'm talking about.

17
00:01:02.450 --> 00:01:07.121
But it sounds like we can ping 192.168.5.2

18
00:01:07.121 --> 00:01:11.920
which is probably this interface but
not ping this guy way over here.

19
00:01:11.920 --> 00:01:16.030
So, our path that goes along
the way is kind of trailing off.

20
00:01:16.030 --> 00:01:18.270
This is one of those scenarios where
we can kind of use trace route or

21
00:01:18.270 --> 00:01:20.780
just kind of ping on the way out
to find out the way we're going.

22
00:01:22.290 --> 00:01:25.920
Let's take a look at these devices, see if
we can get a handle on their IP addresses.

23
00:01:25.920 --> 00:01:31.090
NY WAN one at this GI zero zero interface
and then we're going in to NY core one.

24
00:01:31.090 --> 00:01:33.940
This is a layer three port so

25
00:01:33.940 --> 00:01:38.710
that's gonna be one subnet and then we're
crossing this side, that's another subnet.

26
00:01:38.710 --> 00:01:42.610
So, I've got two different networks and
I'm being routed presumably here on NY

27
00:01:42.610 --> 00:01:44.900
core one unless they've done
something crazy with VLANs and

28
00:01:44.900 --> 00:01:46.150
I get routed way down here.

29
00:01:46.150 --> 00:01:49.980
But I'm presumably being
routed right here in NYCORE1.

30
00:01:49.980 --> 00:01:51.590
So, let's start on NYWAN1 and

31
00:01:51.590 --> 00:01:55.130
see if we can't fill in the blanks
on some of these IP addresses.

32
00:01:55.130 --> 00:01:56.170
So, on NYWAN1,

33
00:01:56.170 --> 00:02:01.710
I'm really curious about the IP
address assigned to Interface GiO/O.

34
00:02:01.710 --> 00:02:05.800
So, I'm gonna do a show run int gi0/0.

35
00:02:05.800 --> 00:02:08.906
And it is 192.168.5.1.

36
00:02:08.906 --> 00:02:11.330
That is not what I expected.

37
00:02:11.330 --> 00:02:14.000
Because they were telling
me there was no route.

38
00:02:14.000 --> 00:02:16.070
Oh I see, I read the question wrong.

39
00:02:16.070 --> 00:02:19.840
No route to NYWAN1 from NYCORE2.

40
00:02:19.840 --> 00:02:24.505
So, NYCORE2 is trying to get here and
this guy is 192.168.

41
00:02:24.505 --> 00:02:29.070
.5.1.
So, I'm gonna write that

42
00:02:29.070 --> 00:02:33.733
down that WAN1 is 192.168.5.1.

43
00:02:33.733 --> 00:02:40.230
All right, and if it's 5.1,
then I expect that NYCORE1,

44
00:02:40.230 --> 00:02:46.610
this guy right here is probably
.2 On its FA1/0/2 interface,

45
00:02:46.610 --> 00:02:51.460
and so if I jump into here,
we can do a show run for int FA1/0/2.

46
00:02:51.460 --> 00:02:54.660
And sure enough it is 192.168.5.2.

47
00:02:54.660 --> 00:03:00.669
So, I'm just gonna write
that done that core 1 is .2.

48
00:03:02.020 --> 00:03:07.860
And then on its port 24,
that's its connection to the other switch.

49
00:03:07.860 --> 00:03:13.920
And I can see it's 192.168.5.5.

50
00:03:13.920 --> 00:03:18.650
And that's why I was thinking
it was the 192.168.5 network and

51
00:03:18.650 --> 00:03:20.240
it looks like they overlap, doesn't it?

52
00:03:20.240 --> 00:03:22.720
But that's a really specific
subnet mask right there.

53
00:03:22.720 --> 00:03:26.180
These are /30 networks,
they only got two IPs.

54
00:03:26.180 --> 00:03:29.980
So, 192.168.5.2,
that's in the first subnet for that /30.

55
00:03:29.980 --> 00:03:34.650
And then 192.168.5.5,
that's in the second subnet of that /30.

56
00:03:34.650 --> 00:03:38.320
So, they're not overlapping but
it's got the two IPs.

57
00:03:38.320 --> 00:03:40.720
And I'm assuming this guy's the router,

58
00:03:40.720 --> 00:03:45.600
which I guess we could see if
it's got IP routing enabled.

59
00:03:45.600 --> 00:03:47.760
And in the config,
it does have IP routing.

60
00:03:47.760 --> 00:03:54.550
And if I do a show ip route,
it should have 192.168.5.1/30.

61
00:03:54.550 --> 00:03:57.290
And 192.168.5.4/30,
that's the two different networks so

62
00:03:57.290 --> 00:04:00.530
it's set up to route between them.

63
00:04:00.530 --> 00:04:02.660
We could still have ACLs and
other things, but

64
00:04:02.660 --> 00:04:05.110
I'm still in the exploration
phase right now.

65
00:04:05.110 --> 00:04:06.550
We'll come back to that.

66
00:04:06.550 --> 00:04:10.640
So, the other node is NYCORE2
way down here at the end.

67
00:04:10.640 --> 00:04:18.186
And if this one was 192.168.5.5 I kind
of expect this one to be 192.168.5.6.

68
00:04:18.186 --> 00:04:23.080
So, I'll do a show run for
interface FA1/0/24.

69
00:04:23.080 --> 00:04:24.710
And it is dot six.

70
00:04:24.710 --> 00:04:29.740
So.
CORE2 is 192.168.5.6.

71
00:04:34.900 --> 00:04:36.240
All right.

72
00:04:36.240 --> 00:04:41.490
Now, ny core two is unable to
ping 192.168.5.1 which is one.

73
00:04:41.490 --> 00:04:42.360
nywan1.

74
00:04:42.360 --> 00:04:45.210
So going back to my diagram here.

75
00:04:45.210 --> 00:04:49.340
NY core two cannot send a ping all
the way across to NYWAN1 right here.

76
00:04:49.340 --> 00:04:52.480
I'm having a hard time saying that.

77
00:04:52.480 --> 00:04:55.450
So, what I'm gonna do
is issue some testings.

78
00:04:55.450 --> 00:04:57.030
I'm gonna ping from here.

79
00:04:57.030 --> 00:05:01.340
And I'm gonna ping the inside interface
of NYCORE1 then I'll ping the outside and

80
00:05:01.340 --> 00:05:02.320
then I'll ping NYWAN1.

81
00:05:02.320 --> 00:05:03.800
And just see where we stop.

82
00:05:03.800 --> 00:05:05.380
On a bigger network,
I would use trace route.

83
00:05:05.380 --> 00:05:07.950
On a smaller network like this,
it'd be faster to use pings.

84
00:05:07.950 --> 00:05:12.960
So, I'll go ahead and
just do that right here on NYCORE2.

85
00:05:12.960 --> 00:05:16.200
And we'll start with a ping to 192.168.5.5

86
00:05:16.200 --> 00:05:20.330
That's the interface of
NYCORE1 that's closest to me.

87
00:05:20.330 --> 00:05:21.940
I'm directly plugged into that network.

88
00:05:21.940 --> 00:05:23.400
So, there's no routing going on.

89
00:05:23.400 --> 00:05:27.770
I should just be able to communicate
right to that system, and that's that.

90
00:05:27.770 --> 00:05:29.490
And I can.

91
00:05:29.490 --> 00:05:37.260
If I wanna ping to 192.168.5.2 though,
then I'm going in this interface.

92
00:05:37.260 --> 00:05:41.440
And being routed to this interface and
then my reply should come back.

93
00:05:41.440 --> 00:05:44.400
So, now I'm testing whether
I'm getting routed on NYCORE1.

94
00:05:44.400 --> 00:05:48.660
And so when I run this ping
I'm getting routed and

95
00:05:48.660 --> 00:05:51.130
I got five successes, so
we're in good shape there.

96
00:05:51.130 --> 00:05:56.040
All right, so
that means I'm getting through NYCORE1.

97
00:05:56.040 --> 00:06:02.630
Now, I can ping the rest of the way over
to NYWAN1 and that's where we drop off.

98
00:06:02.630 --> 00:06:06.090
Right or it could ARP lets give it
a second and nope we dropped off.

99
00:06:06.090 --> 00:06:08.753
All right, so we dropped off and

100
00:06:08.753 --> 00:06:14.820
that means the problem on our network
is going to be either here or here.

101
00:06:14.820 --> 00:06:16.080
It's gonna be on of those two devices.

102
00:06:16.080 --> 00:06:16.910
Right.

103
00:06:16.910 --> 00:06:19.620
Traceroute pings they always
help us narrow it down.

104
00:06:19.620 --> 00:06:21.310
To two devices.

105
00:06:21.310 --> 00:06:24.140
The problem here is more
than likely not routing.

106
00:06:24.140 --> 00:06:26.220
But I could have access control lists,

107
00:06:26.220 --> 00:06:28.140
ACLs blocking traffic on the way in or
out.

108
00:06:28.140 --> 00:06:30.910
I could have other things that
are making this traffic not make it

109
00:06:30.910 --> 00:06:31.710
to the destination.

110
00:06:32.790 --> 00:06:34.790
Or I could have a problem
up here in NYWAN1.

111
00:06:34.790 --> 00:06:39.000
Same thing, bad routing, could be an ACL,
could be all sorts of stuff.

112
00:06:39.000 --> 00:06:40.910
So, where do I wanna troubleshoot?

113
00:06:40.910 --> 00:06:43.790
Well let's jump over to NYCORE1 and
we'll start there.

114
00:06:43.790 --> 00:06:50.480
So, on NYCORE1 I just want to make
sure that it can ping NYWAN1, right.

115
00:06:50.480 --> 00:06:59.540
I know that if I do a show I P interface
brief that NYCORE1 is 192.168.5.2.

116
00:06:59.540 --> 00:07:03.480
And I know that NYWAN1 is 192.168.5.1.

117
00:07:03.480 --> 00:07:05.268
So, can I ping that?

118
00:07:05.268 --> 00:07:08.935
I'll ping 192.168.5.1.

119
00:07:08.935 --> 00:07:09.770
And I can.

120
00:07:09.770 --> 00:07:12.980
So, that link right there is up.

121
00:07:12.980 --> 00:07:16.470
So, assuming that I was able to
get routed to this interface, and

122
00:07:16.470 --> 00:07:19.420
I'm able to ping to the destination
What else could it be?

123
00:07:19.420 --> 00:07:22.320
Well, it could be bad NAT,
it could be ACL's,

124
00:07:22.320 --> 00:07:24.100
it could be all sorts of
quirky things like that.

125
00:07:24.100 --> 00:07:28.780
So, let's look at NYCORE1's configuration
and just skim through it and

126
00:07:28.780 --> 00:07:31.680
see if anything jumps out
at us here as bizarre.

127
00:07:31.680 --> 00:07:32.520
Okay?

128
00:07:32.520 --> 00:07:35.540
And so, looking at the list,
as I kinda go down it,

129
00:07:35.540 --> 00:07:39.730
this is all pretty standard configuration
here, nothing too crazy jumping out at me.

130
00:07:39.730 --> 00:07:41.650
Expanding tree's nice and normal.

131
00:07:41.650 --> 00:07:42.730
My interface, right?

132
00:07:42.730 --> 00:07:45.480
We already knew that was layer three
port and it's got the right address.

133
00:07:45.480 --> 00:07:49.180
I'm able to ping with no overlap and

134
00:07:49.180 --> 00:07:52.970
then as I keep going,
here's my other interface, no ACLs.

135
00:07:52.970 --> 00:07:55.270
That's what I'm really looking for
here, access control lists.

136
00:07:55.270 --> 00:07:56.760
No ACLs here.

137
00:07:56.760 --> 00:07:59.680
The interface isn't shut down or
anything so that looks healthy.

138
00:07:59.680 --> 00:08:01.380
And then I get down to
our routing protocol.

139
00:08:01.380 --> 00:08:07.220
We've got eigrp 10 configured, and
it's configure for 192.168.5.0.

140
00:08:07.220 --> 00:08:12.880
And it's got 0.0.0.7,
that covers both of the networks.

141
00:08:12.880 --> 00:08:16.727
That covers 192.168.5.0 and
it covers 192.168.5.4.

142
00:08:16.727 --> 00:08:19.070
Those are the two networks that we had.

143
00:08:19.070 --> 00:08:20.730
And they're both covered there, right?

144
00:08:20.730 --> 00:08:23.090
So, it looks like we're running
a dynamic routing protocol and

145
00:08:23.090 --> 00:08:25.940
that just made me think of
a potential problem here, right?

146
00:08:25.940 --> 00:08:27.610
This could actually be a routing issue.

147
00:08:27.610 --> 00:08:31.030
Maybe my traffic is making it all
the way to the other side, but

148
00:08:31.030 --> 00:08:33.340
the other side doesn't have
a route to get back to me.

149
00:08:33.340 --> 00:08:34.240
That's possible.

150
00:08:34.240 --> 00:08:37.560
It was way back either in Issue one or
Issue two of set 11 where

151
00:08:37.560 --> 00:08:42.800
we fixed eigrp across this link so I know
it's running between these two guys.

152
00:08:42.800 --> 00:08:44.860
But is it running up to this guy?

153
00:08:45.860 --> 00:08:46.490
Let's find out.

154
00:08:46.490 --> 00:08:50.840
On NYCORE1 I can do
a show IP EIRGP neighbor.

155
00:08:50.840 --> 00:08:55.530
And I've only got one neighbor.

156
00:08:55.530 --> 00:08:58.205
And that one neighbor is 192.168.5.6.

157
00:08:58.205 --> 00:09:01.510
on Fa1/0/24.
That's that link that we fixed, right.

158
00:09:01.510 --> 00:09:05.730
That's this link Right here, but I don't
have a neighbor relationship here and

159
00:09:05.730 --> 00:09:08.340
I will bet you if we jump up to NYWAN1

160
00:09:08.340 --> 00:09:11.520
it probably doesn't have a route
to get back to our network.

161
00:09:11.520 --> 00:09:14.620
Our traffic is most likely making
it to NYWAN1 just doesn't have

162
00:09:14.620 --> 00:09:15.870
a way to get back.

163
00:09:15.870 --> 00:09:17.810
So lets go to NYWAN1 and
see what we've got.

164
00:09:19.980 --> 00:09:22.150
I'm gonna do a show IP route.

165
00:09:22.150 --> 00:09:28.700
And on NYWAN1, I've only got connected and
local interfaces and that's it.

166
00:09:28.700 --> 00:09:33.540
I don't have 192.168.5.4,
it's not in the routing table.

167
00:09:33.540 --> 00:09:37.810
So, I'm not anticipating an EIGRP and
as a result, I'm not learning that route.

168
00:09:37.810 --> 00:09:39.440
I don't have a path back.

169
00:09:39.440 --> 00:09:40.560
So, I need to fix that.

170
00:09:40.560 --> 00:09:41.680
Two ways to fix it.

171
00:09:41.680 --> 00:09:43.290
I could do a static route.

172
00:09:43.290 --> 00:09:44.478
Well I guess there's three ways to fix it.

173
00:09:44.478 --> 00:09:48.500
[LAUGH] I could do a static route,
I could participate in EIGRP, or

174
00:09:48.500 --> 00:09:51.740
I can configure NAT to just
hide the address all together.

175
00:09:51.740 --> 00:09:53.540
So, I could go a few different ways.

176
00:09:53.540 --> 00:09:57.320
Participating in EIGRP is gonna be
the path of least resistance on this one.

177
00:09:57.320 --> 00:10:01.320
Now, looking at my diagram,
we're supposed to be in EIGRP 10.

178
00:10:01.320 --> 00:10:04.730
So, what I'm gonna do is
get us configured for that.

179
00:10:04.730 --> 00:10:08.790
I'm gonna say router eigrp 10, and
then network 192.168.5.0 0.0.0.3.

180
00:10:08.790 --> 00:10:14.610
That's this network that I'm
directly plugged into, right?

181
00:10:14.610 --> 00:10:17.140
I'm not worried about

182
00:10:17.140 --> 00:10:20.820
covering the other networks because
I do not have an interface on it.

183
00:10:20.820 --> 00:10:25.050
But as soon as I do that,
I'll start participating in EIGRP, and

184
00:10:25.050 --> 00:10:27.030
now I'm talking to that neighbor.

185
00:10:27.030 --> 00:10:32.900
And if I do a show IP route, I expect to
see the 192.168.5.4 network right there,

186
00:10:32.900 --> 00:10:35.080
and I'm learning via EIGRP.

187
00:10:36.110 --> 00:10:38.120
Now, I've got a return
route to that network and

188
00:10:38.120 --> 00:10:40.340
I will bet that solves our problem.

189
00:10:40.340 --> 00:10:41.996
Let's go over to NY core 2.

190
00:10:43.490 --> 00:10:48.410
And so I'm on NY core two, way down
here and this guy was unable to ping

191
00:10:48.410 --> 00:10:54.100
up to NY WAN one so
now that should be fixed,

192
00:10:54.100 --> 00:10:57.490
and so I'm gonna redo that ping and
sure enough, that was it.

193
00:10:57.490 --> 00:11:00.680
So, in this case we just had
a no that didn't return path.

194
00:11:00.680 --> 00:11:02.940
You've always gotta remember
that it's easy to lose sight.

195
00:11:02.940 --> 00:11:06.550
We think about, when I try and
ping out but there's a return path,

196
00:11:06.550 --> 00:11:08.270
they have to know how to get back to me.

197
00:11:08.270 --> 00:11:10.860
And if it's internet equipment,
you don't have any control over that.

198
00:11:10.860 --> 00:11:12.610
But with our own equipment, we do.

199
00:11:12.610 --> 00:11:15.510
Here we just need an IGP to make sure
that everybody knew the routes to

200
00:11:15.510 --> 00:11:16.330
return on the network.

201
00:11:16.330 --> 00:11:18.650
Once we got that squared away,
problem is solved.

202
00:11:18.650 --> 00:11:19.810
This one's done.

203
00:11:19.810 --> 00:11:21.270
All right, that wraps up issue five.

204
00:11:21.270 --> 00:11:23.800
We do have one more issue to tackle,
issue six.

205
00:11:23.800 --> 00:11:27.058
Stay tuned, because it's coming up next.

206
00:11:27.058 --> 00:11:32.904
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this video, Don solves troubleshooting issue #6` from set #11. The trouble ticket states that "NYWAN1 and NYEDGE2 are not forming an EIGRP relationship. "
episodes.title: Set 11 Issue 6
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.334 --> 00:00:03.205
[SOUND]

2
00:00:03.205 --> 00:00:08.948
All right.

3
00:00:08.948 --> 00:00:12.510
Welcome back for another Cisco trouble
shooting segment here, on ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.510 --> 00:00:17.180
We've got the final issue for set 11,
so we're jumping into Set 11, Issue 6.

5
00:00:17.180 --> 00:00:18.780
And the troubleshooting
ticket reads like this.

6
00:00:18.780 --> 00:00:25.380
It says, NYWAN1 and NYEDGE2 are not
forming an EIGRP relationship.

7
00:00:25.380 --> 00:00:27.270
Well, sounds pretty straightforward.

8
00:00:27.270 --> 00:00:30.160
Let's look at our diagram here and
see the devices we're talking about.

9
00:00:30.160 --> 00:00:33.722
It said NYWAN1 and NYEDGE2.

10
00:00:33.722 --> 00:00:35.490
That's these two guys right here.

11
00:00:35.490 --> 00:00:36.840
It's a point-to-point link.

12
00:00:36.840 --> 00:00:38.070
They're directly connected.

13
00:00:38.070 --> 00:00:40.390
This should be an easy question for us.

14
00:00:40.390 --> 00:00:44.340
So for some reason they're not
building up an EIGRP relationship.

15
00:00:44.340 --> 00:00:47.660
Looking at the diagram they're supposed
to be in EIGRP autonomous system ten

16
00:00:47.660 --> 00:00:49.140
and it's IPV4.

17
00:00:49.140 --> 00:00:52.350
So we just need to jump in and
find out what the heck is going on there.

18
00:00:52.350 --> 00:00:55.090
So let's start with a point to point leak.

19
00:00:55.090 --> 00:00:57.360
It doesn't really matter which one
we start in, just pick one and

20
00:00:57.360 --> 00:00:59.860
jump into it you've got a 50 50
shot at catching the source.

21
00:00:59.860 --> 00:01:04.120
So I'll jump to NYWAN1 just because
it's lower in the diagram and

22
00:01:04.120 --> 00:01:06.680
see what we can find so in NYWAN1.

23
00:01:06.680 --> 00:01:10.042
I'm just gonna get logged
into my console here and

24
00:01:10.042 --> 00:01:14.445
let's look for some low hanging
fruit here maybe the interface is

25
00:01:14.445 --> 00:01:19.327
just down I'm gonna do a show IP
Interface Brief and what I'm looking for

26
00:01:19.327 --> 00:01:25.045
is that Ser0/1/1 interface on this guy and
I just want to see what its status is.

27
00:01:25.045 --> 00:01:28.133
And so it is Serial0/1/1.

28
00:01:28.133 --> 00:01:33.780
It's 192.168.1.3 and
the interface status is currently up.

29
00:01:33.780 --> 00:01:37.490
So it's up, it's healthy, it's happy or
at least it thinks that it is.

30
00:01:37.490 --> 00:01:40.190
And that's unfortunate, I was hoping
this would be administratively down

31
00:01:40.190 --> 00:01:43.440
problem solved but it's not so
that's our address and

32
00:01:43.440 --> 00:01:45.770
I'm gonna write that down because
I need to know the address so

33
00:01:45.770 --> 00:01:48.160
I can ping across the line see
if it's working and all that.

34
00:01:48.160 --> 00:01:53.030
So this guy is 192.168.1.3 then
I'm just gonna review some

35
00:01:55.290 --> 00:01:57.010
of the configuration.

36
00:01:57.010 --> 00:01:58.400
So let me do a show IP.

37
00:01:59.590 --> 00:02:00.770
EIGRP neighbor.

38
00:02:01.880 --> 00:02:04.706
And I do have a neighbor, 192.168.5.2.

39
00:02:04.706 --> 00:02:07.080
But you'll remember that from
the last issue, issue 5.

40
00:02:07.080 --> 00:02:09.850
That is NYCORE1.

41
00:02:09.850 --> 00:02:13.210
So NYWAN1 has a neighbor
relationship with NYCORE1.

42
00:02:13.210 --> 00:02:16.710
It doesn't have a relationship
with NYEDGE2 up here.

43
00:02:16.710 --> 00:02:19.070
So I should have two
neighbor relationships.

44
00:02:19.070 --> 00:02:20.570
And I don't.

45
00:02:20.570 --> 00:02:21.550
Okay.

46
00:02:21.550 --> 00:02:23.590
And if I do a show IP.

47
00:02:23.590 --> 00:02:25.560
Well, I can show IP interface brief.

48
00:02:25.560 --> 00:02:27.180
Up here I can see I have three networks.

49
00:02:27.180 --> 00:02:32.390
On my GI00, I've got that 192.168.5
network, and that one's working in EIGRP.

50
00:02:32.390 --> 00:02:35.437
I've 192.168.1.3.

51
00:02:35.437 --> 00:02:38.330
I don't actually know if
that's an EIGRP or not.

52
00:02:38.330 --> 00:02:41.350
And then, I've got a loopback
which is apparently just there.

53
00:02:41.350 --> 00:02:42.850
So [LAUGH] I've got one of those too.

54
00:02:42.850 --> 00:02:47.890
So lets see what EIGRP is configured
to handle and go from there.

55
00:02:47.890 --> 00:02:51.030
I actually show IP protocols is as
good a place to start as any for that.

56
00:02:52.030 --> 00:02:54.520
So show IP protocols shows
that I am running EIGRP for

57
00:02:54.520 --> 00:02:56.370
our autonomous system ten.

58
00:02:56.370 --> 00:03:00.020
I don't have any filters on my interfaces,
so that's good.

59
00:03:00.020 --> 00:03:03.250
My K values look all nice and
normal, nothing crazy there.

60
00:03:03.250 --> 00:03:06.010
My router ID is being
determined by that loopback, so

61
00:03:06.010 --> 00:03:10.640
that's what it's being used for
apparently.

62
00:03:10.640 --> 00:03:13.684
And then as I look at my networks,
here's 192.168.1.2/31 and

63
00:03:13.684 --> 00:03:17.540
/31 is a little bit weird but
they're just being really specific.

64
00:03:17.540 --> 00:03:23.330
That's going to include 192.168.1.2 and
192.168.1.3.

65
00:03:23.330 --> 00:03:25.760
My interface is .3, so
that'll be included.

66
00:03:25.760 --> 00:03:27.720
So I'm okay with that.

67
00:03:27.720 --> 00:03:29.220
And then there's my one neighbor.

68
00:03:29.220 --> 00:03:32.150
So, it looks like I am set to route for
those two networks.

69
00:03:32.150 --> 00:03:35.040
Let's look at that interface and see if
there's something bizarre going on there.

70
00:03:36.610 --> 00:03:38.050
That was serial 011.

71
00:03:38.050 --> 00:03:39.320
Yeah.

72
00:03:39.320 --> 00:03:41.904
So it's got an IPV6 address, but
I can just kind of ignore that.

73
00:03:41.904 --> 00:03:44.383
It does have that 192.168.1.3.

74
00:03:44.383 --> 00:03:48.223
With a 255255255254 address.

75
00:03:48.223 --> 00:03:50.173
That's where we're getting that slash 31.

76
00:03:50.173 --> 00:03:51.372
But, that's all right.

77
00:03:51.372 --> 00:03:53.078
CISCO router can do that just fine.

78
00:03:53.078 --> 00:03:55.580
It's a point to point link so that works.

79
00:03:55.580 --> 00:03:58.830
And we're good to go there.

80
00:03:58.830 --> 00:04:05.300
Let me do a show run for the EIGRP
section, and I've got router EIGRP 10.

81
00:04:05.300 --> 00:04:09.705
There's my network statements that we
kind of saw in show IP Protocols, and

82
00:04:09.705 --> 00:04:11.025
they look good too.

83
00:04:11.025 --> 00:04:13.785
So I'm not really seeing anything
jumping out at me here that would stop

84
00:04:13.785 --> 00:04:15.695
this neighbor relationship
from building up.

85
00:04:15.695 --> 00:04:17.885
I didn't see ACL on the interface.

86
00:04:17.885 --> 00:04:20.345
I don't see authentication
configured in EIGRP.
